Subsequently, a sliding frustum mechanism is employed to dynamically partition point clouds within target regions and extract their key features, thereby refining the representation of local geometry. Moreover, a region-aligned attention module (RAAM) is designed, which utilizes 2D detection boxes as queries to guide the refinement and focus of 3D features, facilitating adaptive fusion of multi-scale point–voxel representations. Finally, extensive experiments conducted on the KITTI, NuScenes, and Waymo datasets validate the effectiveness of the proposed framework. On the KITTI test set, our method achieves 3D mAPs of 90.88%, 84.47%, and 80.99% for the Car category under Easy, Moderate, and Hard settings, respectively. On the NuScenes benchmark, the proposed model attains APs of 89.2% and 64.9% for Pedestrian and Bicycle detection, respectively. Moreover, on theWaymo dataset, our framework achieves 3DmAPHscores of 82.07% (L1) and 76.38% (L2) across all object categories, demonstrating significant improvements over current state-of-the-art approaches.

title: Design of an Explainable Deep Learning Framework for ECG-Based Arrhythmia Prediction
authors: Deepika Tenepalli, T M Navamani
abstract: Arrhythmia refers to abnormal deviations in the normal heart rhythm, possibly signifying severe cardiovascular conditions. The manual identification of arrhythmias by ECG analysis is labor-intensive, requires specialized expertise, and is susceptible to inter-observer variability. Conventional signal-based classification techniques depend significantly on manually produced features, which may exhibit insufficient resilience and generalizability across varied patient demographics and noisy datasets. These constraints underscore the pressing need for automated, scalable, and interpretable diagnostic methodologies. To rectify these deficiencies, we offer an innovative approach that converts the ECG signal into 2D waveform images, facilitating the use of advanced image-based deep learning algorithms. ECG recordings from MIT-BIH were segmented around beats and converted to waveform graphs using wfdb, matplotlib, and PIL. Each image, reduced to 224×224 pixels, graphically encapsulates about 0.7 seconds of ECG data, enabling deep neural networks to learn both temporal and morphological features. The preprocessing pipeline comprises amplitude normalization, noise filtration and augmentation to improve signal quality and model robustness. We introduce a hybrid deep learning model (ECG-CNNTX -Electrocardiogram Classification using CNN and Transformer with Explainability) that integrates EfficientNetB0 for effective and resilient feature extraction with a Transformer-based attention module to capture long-range relationships in image representations. Our model achieved a classification accuracy of 99% in identifying Premature Ventricular Contractions (PVCs). Grad-CAM visualization elucidates essential ECG areas that impact predictions, hence augmenting clinical dependability for model interpretability. This study introduces a dependable, precise, and interpretable ECG classification framework that integrates traditional signal processing with sophisticated AI-driven image analysis, providing an innovative and scalable method for arrhythmia diagnosis.

title: Contrastive Learning for Semi-Supervised Deep Regression With Generalized Ordinal Rankings From Spectral Seriation_supp1-3635904.pdf
authors: Ce Wang
abstract: Contrastive learning methods enforce label distance relationships in feature space to improve representation capability for regression models. However, these methods highly depend on label information to correctly recover ordinal relationships of features, limiting their applications to semi-supervised regression. In this work, we extend contrastive regression methods to allow unlabeled data to be used in the semi-supervised setting, thereby reducing the dependence on costly annotations. Particularly we construct the feature similarity matrix with both labeled and unlabeled samples in a mini-batch to reflect inter-sample relationships, and an accurate ordinal ranking of involved unlabeled samples can be recovered through spectral seriation algorithms if the level of error is within certain bounds. The introduction of labeled samples above provides regularization of the ordinal ranking with guidance from the ground-truth label information, making the ranking more reliable. To reduce feature perturbations, we further utilize the dynamic programming algorithm to select robust features for the matrix construction. The recovered ordinal relationship is then used for contrastive learning on unlabeled samples, and we thus allow more data to be used for feature representation learning, thereby achieving more robust results. The ordinal rankings can also be used to supervise predictions on unlabeled samples, serving as an additional training signal. We provide theoretical guarantees and empirical verification through experiments on various datasets, demonstrating that our method can surpass existing state-of-the-art semi-supervised deep regression methods. Our code have been released on <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/xmed-lab/CLSS</uri>.

title: Stitching Meaning: Practices of Data Textile Creators
authors: Sydney Purdue, Eduardo Puerta, Enrico Bertini, Melanie Tory
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Tens of thousands of people have represented data by creating data-encoding textile pieces like blankets, scarves, and more. A prototypical example is the temperature blanket, which represents the weather through rows or blocks of different colors mapped to temperature ranges. While researchers have used fiber arts mediums to create exploratory projects, data visualization and physicalization research has largely not engaged with examples from this enormous and diverse community. We explore the space of data textiles, or fiber arts that encode information, by surveying creators (i.e., data fiber artists) on their projects and processes. We create a corpus of 159 examples of data textiles and present a schema characterizing the data encoding methods used in these projects. We also gather insights into creators' data workflows as well as their motives and discoveries through making with their data. Creators of data textiles use distinct processes to map their data, building fabric from component structures and substructures while using material properties like color and texture. From diverse data-tracking procedures, creators use and relate to data in varied ways. Working on these pieces also contributes to the creators' personal growth and data understanding. Our findings point to new opportunities for visualization, including opportunities to support fiber artists with tools formatted to their needs and opportunities to incorporate concepts from data textiles into other types of visualization (e.g., using texture, structural layouts, colorways).

title: Adaptive Prescribed-Time Output-Constrained Control of Mars Powered Descent Phase With Unmeasured Input Deadzone and Unknown Mass
authors: Di Jiang, Huaiyuan Jiang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The presence of unmeasured parameters and unknown disturbances presents substantial challenges in the controller design of the Mars landing mission. In this article, the problem of adaptive prescribed-time tracking control for the powered descent phase of Mars landing with time-varying output constraints, unmeasured input deadzone nonlinearity, unknown vehicle mass and disturbances is addressed. First, a prescribed-time output-constrained function is defined and a class of time-varying barrier Lyapunov functions is developed, including estimation error information for disturbances and system parameters. Then, based on these functions and Nussbaum-type functions, an adaptive prescribed-time tracking control scheme is proposed for the powered descent phase of Mars landing in the presence of time-varying output constraints, unmeasured input deadzone nonlinearity and unknown vehicle mass, such that the tracking error converges to zero in a prescribed time and the control signals are bounded. Finally, several numerical simulations validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Design of a Quasi-Synchronous Background Detection Laser Heterodyne Radiometer and Measurements of Atmospheric Water Vapor on the Tibetan Plateau
authors: Yuan Meng, Yinbo Huang, Jun Huang, Zhensong Cao, Xingji Lu, Huanhuan Shou, Tao Yang, Hang Dong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: This paper presents a novel laser heterodyne radiometer (LHR) for measuring the water vapor concentration across the entire atmospheric column. The device implements a quasi-synchronous background detection scheme, effectively suppressing relative background drift to within 0.8%. It achieves a high spectral resolution of 0.004 cm⁻¹ and a rapid response time of 25 seconds per heterodyne spectrum. Field measurements were conducted in the Ali region of the Tibetan Plateau in August 2024. On August 14, the system continuously monitored the atmospheric H₂O absorption spectrum, and the retrieved column concentrations exhibited a relative uncertainty of 1.37%. Additional measurements on August 16 and August 21 yielded relative uncertainties of 1.16% and 2.79%, respectively, confirming the repeatability of the system. Comparison with simultaneous measurements from a Fourier transform spectrometer (Bruker EM27/SUN) showed consistent temporal variability with a correlation coefficient of 0.77. These results demonstrate that the developed LHR combines fast acquisition speed, high spectral resolution, and reliable precision and repeatability, making it well suited for stable atmospheric water vapor monitoring.

title: Correction Method for Low-frequency Time-varying Relative Radiometric Errors in Optical Remote Sensing: A Case Study of JiTian-03
authors: Li T. Li, Hao Q. Liang, Yong H. Jiang, X. Shen, Jia Y. Cao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: While systematic radiometric errors can be mitigated through on-orbit calibration, correcting low-frequency, time-varying errors often induced by complex imaging dynamics remains a greater challenge. This study introduces a correction method tailored for optical remote sensing platforms to overcome such errors in JiTian-03 imagery, particularly those arising from high-agility curve imaging. The process begins with relative radiometric calibration to correct high-frequency inconsistencies among sensor detectors, thereby suppressing striping and banding noise in the imagery. Next, the image is decomposed into low-frequency background and high-frequency detail components. A column-wise moment-matching algorithm is then applied to the low-frequency background, aligning each column’s first- and second-order central moments with global statistics to derive correction coefficients. This approach effectively compensates for low-frequency radiometric errors while preserving high-frequency texture details in the image. Experimental results confirm that, following correction of both high- and low-frequency radiometric errors, JT-03 imagery exhibits a substantial reduction in striping, banding, and brightness nonuniformity. The correction yields a uniform radiometric response across the entire field of view while preserving ground texture fidelity and image detail. As a result, the radiometric uniformity of JT-03 image products is significantly enhanced. Quantitatively, post high-frequency calibration, the striping index across all JT-03 bands improved to within 0.1% and the standard deviation of column means to 4.7%. Subsequent low-frequency correction reduced the standard deviation of column means by an average of 73.89%, achieving a final value of better than 1.3%.

title: Effect of Ferroelectric Width Variation on Gate-Drain Coupling in Negative Capacitance Double-Gate FinFET
authors: Jiafei Yao, Jincheng Liu, Yeqin Zhu, Ziwei Hu, Maolin Zhang, Man Li, Kemeng Yang, Jing Chen, Jun Zhang, Yufeng Guo
abstract: Negative capacitance FinFET (NC-FinFET) has shown excellent ability in suppressing short channel effect, reducing subthreshold swing (SS) and off-state current. In this paper, a new ferroelectric-width-varied negative capacitance double-gate FinFET (FWV-NC-DG-FinFET) is investigated. A new capacitance model fitted to FWV-NC-DG-FinFET is also established. The model is verified by TCAD simulation of FE/SiO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> interface potential. The influence of ferroelectric width variation and drain voltage VD on the gate-drain coupling is investigated by examining the simulation results of SS, threshold voltage, on-state current and off-state current, and NDR effect. The simulation results show that the FWV-NC-DG-FinFET with lager ferroelectric width at drain side results in severe gate-drain coupling effect and lead to ION/IOFF ratio over 107. In contrast, the FWV-NC-DG-FinFET with lager ferroelectric width at source side leads to slighter gate-drain coupling and is able to achieve SS of 51.9 mV/dec and reduce the increment of SS and threshold voltage with increased drain voltage. Meanwhile, the FWV-NC-DG-FinFET with lager ferroelectric width at source side can also mitigates the NDR effect. Furthermore, this paper presents a feasible method to fabricate such FWV-NC-DG-FinFET.

title: TPCM-SegNet: A Text-Prompted Dual-Path Convolution-Mamba Network for Anomaly Segmentation
authors: Borong Xu, Junyu Dong, Xinghui Dong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Anomaly segmentation has been widely applied to diagnosis of medical organs and lesions and detection of industrial defects. However, existing methods still face challenges in extracting discriminant image features and utilizing semantic information. To address these issues, we propose a Text-Prompted Dual-Path Convolution-Mamba Network (TPCM-SegNet)<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>, which integrates Residual Double-Convolution Blocks (RDCBs) and Mamba-Transformer Blocks (MTBs) in two parallel paths for the purpose of extracting local and global features, respectively. Given a pair of RDCB and MTB at the same stage, a Feature Fusion Block (FFB) is introduced in order to facilitate the interaction and fusion of the features extracted using these blocks. Furthermore, we fuse the text tokens extracted from a textual description with the image features extracted using each of those blocks through a Text Prompt Block (TPB), to enhance the semantics understanding ability of the network. A Cascade Feature Block (CFB) is also designed for each stage of the encoder, to combine the feature maps, the logit maps decoded from them and the input image. This block incorporates the prior and original characteristics into the image representation. Experimental results demonstrate that our TPCM-SegNet achieves the superior, or at least comparable, performance to baselines, across eight publicly available datasets. These promising results should benefit from the powerful ability of image representation and semantic understanding of the proposed network.

title: SMART: Semantic Matching Contrastive Learning for Partially View-Aligned Clustering
authors: Liang Peng, Yixuan Ye, Cheng Liu, Hangjun Che, Fei Wang, Zhiwen Yu, Si Wu, Hau-San Wong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Multi-view clustering has been empirically shown to improve learning performance by leveraging the inherent complementary information across multiple views of data. However, in real-world scenarios, collecting strictly aligned views is challenging, and learning from both aligned and unaligned data becomes a more practical solution. Partially View-aligned Clustering (PVC) aims to learn correspondences between misaligned view samples to better exploit the potential consistency and complementarity across views, including both aligned and unaligned data. However, most existing PVC methods fail to leverage unaligned data to capture the shared semantics among samples from the same cluster. Moreover, the inherent heterogeneity of multi-view data induces distributional shifts in representations, leading to inaccuracies in establishing meaningful correspondences between cross-view latent features and, consequently, impairing learning effectiveness. To address these challenges, we propose a Semantic MAtching contRasTive learning model (SMART) for PVC. The main idea of our approach is to alleviate the influence of cross-view distributional shifts, thereby facilitating semantic matching contrastive learning to fully exploit semantic relationships in both aligned and unaligned data. Specifically, we mitigate view distribution shifts by aligning cross-view covariance matrices, which enables the inference of a semantic graph for all data. Guided by the learned semantic graph, we further exploit semantic consistency across views through semantic matching contrastive learning. After the optimization of the above mechanisms, our model smoothly performs semantic matching for different view embeddings instead of the cumbersome view realignment, which enables the learned representations to enjoy richer category-level semantics and stronger robustness. Extensive experiments on eight benchmark datasets demonstrate that our method consistently outperforms existing approaches on the PVC problem. The code is available at https://github.com/THPengL/SMART.

title: MARHO: Hybrid Task Offloading in Maritime MEC via Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
authors: Jiahong Ning, Aimin Li, Gary C.F. Lee, Sumei Sun, Tingting Yang
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: This paper presents MARHO, a Multi-Agent Reinforcement learning-based Hybrid task Offloading framework, designed for maritime mobile edge computing (MEC) environments characterized by time-varying wireless channels, heterogeneous workloads, and stringent quality of service (QoS) requirements. The considered MEC architecture integrates unmanned surface vessels (USVs), unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), and a ship platform with high-performance edge servers. USVs generate sensing and computing tasks that can be (i) executed locally, (ii) offloaded to UAVs for aerial edge processing, or (iii) relayed through UAVs to the ship under line-of-sight (LoS) links. The system model jointly captures queueing dynamics, wireless transmission latency, computation delay, and battery constraints. The hybrid offloading problem is formulated as a Decentralized Partially Observable Markov Decision Process (Dec-POMDP), where each USV acts as an agent that decides its offloading mode under partial observations. To solve this, MARHO employs a centralized training and decentralized execution (CTDE) scheme, enabling agents to learn resource-aware strategies that effectively balance communication and computation. A Gym-based simulation environment is developed, integrating realistic maritime signal propagation, queue dynamics, and mixed offloading scenarios. The experimental results under different task loads demonstrate that MARHO consistently achieves higher throughput and has a lower average latency compared to the existing benchmark.

title: The Determination of Relaxed Deformation Error for Large Antennas Main Reflector Compensated by Shaped Subreflector
authors: You Ban, Na Wang, Qian Xu, Shufei Feng, Baoyan Duan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: A determining method of relaxed deformation error for large antennas main reflector that considers the compensation of shaped subreflector is proposed. Using the orthogonal functions describe the independent error items of antennas’ reflector that make it universal, and combining the approximate electrical field calculation and the compensation functions of shaped subreflector establish the relaxed error determination model for main reflector deformation. To solve the model that includes internal and external optimization, the path length error iterative compensation method is used to fast design the shaped subreflector. And for the external optimization, a dichotomy, taking into account the monotonic relationship between reflectors error and antennas gain, is designed to iteratively obtain the relaxed error items upper, lower bounds and the convergent results. The 110 meters standard and 80 meters offset reflector antennas working at 115 GHz and 30 GHz respectively with two classic deformation error types are taken as the examples. The excellent results obtained by a few iterations shown the effectiveness of the proposed model and the corresponding fast solution method, and both of the two type errors are relaxed by over tens and even hundreds of times, indicating the enormous potential of shaped subreflector for compensating the main reflector deformation.

title: Real-World Robot Control by Deep Active Inference With a Temporally Hierarchical World Model_supp1-3636032.mp4
authors: Shingo Murata
abstract: Robots in uncertain realworld environments must perform both goaldirected and exploratory actions. However, most deep learning-based control methods neglect exploration and struggle under uncertainty. To address this, we adopt deep active inference, a framework that accounts for human goal-directed and exploratory actions. Yet, conventional deep active inference approaches face challenges due to limited environmental representation capacity and high computational cost in action selection. We propose a novel deep active inference framework that consists of a world model, an action model, and an abstract world model. The world model encodes environmental dynamics into hidden state representations at slow and fast timescales. The action model compresses action sequences into abstract actions using vector quantization, and the abstract world model predicts future slow states conditioned on the abstract action, enabling low-cost action selection. We evaluate the framework on object-manipulation tasks with a real-world robot. Results show that it achieves high success rates across diverse manipulation tasks and switches between goal-directed and exploratory actions in uncertain settings, while making action selection computationally tractable. These findings highlight the importance of modeling multiple timescale dynamics and abstracting actions and state transitions.

title: Investigating Feedback-Informed Screen-Guided Training to Enhance Myoelectric Control and Predictability
authors: Thomas Labbé, Erik Scheme, Benoit Gosselin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering
abstract: Screen-guided training is a widely used method for calibrating myoelectric prostheses, wherein users follow visual prompts. However, this approach often fails to capture the complexities of real-world usage when the user is actively engaging with the controller. This study, therefore, aimed to develop an alternative training protocol that promotes more robust pattern recognition-based myoelectric control. In an experiment with 20 participants, we compared three training methods: conventional screen-guided training without feedback, real-time visual feedback of principal component analysis (PCA)-based projections of EMG activity, and real-time classification feedback with intentionally corrupted classifier outputs. After training, participants completed a Fitts’ law-style target acquisition task in a virtual environment, repeating it at three different difficulty levels. We then evaluated how offline accuracy and metrics, particularly Bhattacharyya Distances computed from combinations of the PCA projections, correlated with online control performance. Our findings indicate that training with feedback yielded the best performance, with PCA-based visual feedback providing the most effective calibration environment. Additionally, projecting the EMG data collected with PCA-based feedback into the PCA space derived from the no-feedback data improved the correlation between offline separability metrics and the online Fitts’ Law throughput. Interestingly, this correlation was stronger for the easy difficulty level. Nevertheless, the benefits of PCA-based feedback were consistent across the three different difficulty levels of the Fitts’ law task, it as a beneficial and robust approach worthy of further exploration.

title: A Novel Online Censoring-Based Generalized Complex-Valued Kernel Least Mean Square
authors: Buket Çolak Güvenç, Engin Cemal Mengüç
abstract: The generalized complex-valued kernel least mean square (gCKLMS) has shown superior performance in modeling circular and noncircular complex-valued nonlinear signals by leveraging both kernel and pseudo-kernel functions. However, its applicability to large-scale or real-time scenarios is hindered by the exponential increase in computational complexity caused by the growing number of kernel coefficients over iterations. To overcome this challenge, we first propose the online censoring (OC)-based gCKLMS (OC-gCKLMS), which integrates the OC strategy into the gCKLMS framework. The OC selectively retains informative input data and its corresponding kernel and pseudo-kernel coefficients by exploiting data redundancy and then incorporates them into the update process. This significantly reduces computational burden without compromising performance. Then, we theoretically analyze the mean square convergence of the OC-gCKLMS. Finally, the elegant properties of the OC-gCKLMS are validated through simulations on three benchmark problems.

title: SpectraCert: A Hierarchical System for Dynamic Spectrum License Enforcement
authors: Ryan W. West, Dustin Maas, David M. Johnson, Kobus Van der Merwe
publish: Proceedings of the ACM on Networking
abstract: While various spectrum sharing approaches aim to remedy the spectrum crunch and improve spectral utilization, they typically support only radios that are certified for and physically locked down to a single frequency band and power configuration. This limits their utility and re-usability as they do not support flexible license changes post-production, but there is generally no alternative dynamic technical license enforcement mechanism suitable for more flexible SDRs (Software-Defined Radios). This limits the utility of SDRs: SDR operators must use unlicensed bands, or obtain special permission from the FCC via a manual process. Further, they are subject to fines if they operate outside these bounds and/or interfere with other spectrum users.

title: Poster: Towards Efficient and Faithful Underwater Acoustic Network Simulation with Direct Code Execution
authors: Xun Sun, Guoliang Weng, Lizhao You
publish: Proceedings of the 21st International Conference on emerging Networking EXperiments and Technologies
abstract: Underwater acoustic networks are gaining importance across diverse applications, and simulation is a practical way to validate protocol designs given the high cost of real-world deployment. However, existing simulators suffer from low fidelity due to oversimplified abstractions and poor scalability in large networks. In this paper, we present a new simulation approach that executes the actual code designed for embedded Linux devices, thereby ensuring high fidelity. Our method intercepts system calls of real programs and integrates them with a parallel discrete-event simulator for improved efficiency. Preliminary results show that our approach achieves up to 4.8× speedup over abstraction-based simulators for the example ALOHA protocol with 841 nodes.

title: Poster: QueuePilot: Towards Adaptive Queue Scheduling via Live Digital Twins
authors: Francisco Germano Vogt, Zhiheng Yang, Victor Hugo Schneider Lopes, Fabricio Rodriguez, Marcelo Caggiani Luizelli, Christian Esteve Rothenberg, Chrysa Papagianni
publish: Proceedings of the 21st International Conference on emerging Networking EXperiments and Technologies
abstract: Queue management policies strongly influence latency, loss, and fairness, yet production switches often rely on static configurations. Changing policies in the wild is risky, as experiments can disrupt SLAs and queue dynamics are hard to reproduce offline. We present QueuePilot, a digital twin for switch queues that enables safe, traffic-driven evaluation of scheduling and Active Queue Management (AQM) policies. Our prototype, built on two Tofino switches, clones live traffic into the twin, multiplexes it across multiple queueing strategies, and monitors real-time fine-grained metrics. Preliminary results show that QueuePilot can synchronize with the production queues and simultaneously evaluate alternative queuing policies, allowing precise real-time queue management without affecting live traffic.

title: Self-Supervised Pre-Training For Multi-Temporal Remote Sensing Imagery By Joint Embedding Learning
authors: Qi Guo, Jue Wang, Yinhe Liu, Yanfei Zhong
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Data-driven methods represented by deep learning have achieved remarkable results in multi-temporal remote sensing image interpretation. Most current methods adopt the concept of transfer learning, using pre-trained weights trained on natural image datasets such as ImageNet to initialize the backbone of downstream tasks. However, the multi-temporal differences between natural scenes and remote sensing images limit the generalization of these methods in remote sensing tasks. Selfsupervised learning can leverage large-scale unlabeled remote sensing data for pre-training to provide more adaptable features for downstream tasks, but the high computational cost restricts its applicability to remote sensing tasks. This paper proposes a self-supervised pre-training method for multi-temporal remote sensing imagery by joint embedding learning named MT-JEL. By introducing multi-temporal remote sensing information as additional seasonal augmentation, the method enhances the model’s ability to represent multi-temporal land cover features. Meanwhile, a large number of diverse image patches obtained through standard augmentation of multi-temporal images are used to facilitate the joint embedding learning in the representation space. Experimental results demonstrate that MT-JEL not only significantly improves pre-training efficiency but also ensures optimal accuracy when transferred to downstream tasks.

title: Compact SER Models for Line-Source-Induced Charge Collection Using Model Order Reduction
authors: Pavlos Stoikos, Olympia Axelou, Pelopidas Tsoumanis, Georgios-Ioannis Paliaroutis, Luigi Dilillo, Anuj Pathania, George Floros
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Defect and Fault Tolerance in VLSI and Nanotechnology Systems (DFT)
abstract: Soft errors, typically caused by cosmic rays and particle strikes, have become a reliability challenge of modern electronics in aerospace, automotive, and high-performance computing. In advanced nodes with billions of transistors, a single strike can propagate errors, disrupting critical operations. As a result, traditional methods for estimating Soft Error Rate (SER), such as TCAD simulations and arithmetic formulas, are accurate but have become computationally expensive. In order to alleviate the computational burden, we propose a Model Order Reduction (MOR) approach to analyze charge collection dynamics induced by ionizing particles. More specifically, we start from the physics-based model of the diffusion-collection mechanism, then we discretize the fundamental equations in the 3D space, and formulate the system as a high-dimensional state-space problem. Finally, by applying the Extended Krylov Subspace (EKS) combined with Moment Matching (MM) techniques, we reduce computational overhead while maintaining accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate significant computational speedups while maintaining the accuracy of the full model.

title: Optimal Selection of Satellites and Bistatic Sar Configuration Optimization Based on Leo Constellations
authors: Jingjing Yang, Qian Liu, Qing Yang, Zhongyu Li, Junjie Wu, Jianyu Yang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellite-airborne bi-static synthetic aperture radar (BiSAR) system allows for the execution of tasks with more flexible flight path selections compared to monostatic SAR. However, with the increasing richness of constellation resources, efficiently allocating satellite resources for imaging is a new research issue. The method for optimal selection of satellites and BiSAR configuration optimization based on LEO constellations is proposed in this paper. Firstly, the selection of satellites and the configuration design of BiSAR are modeled as a Multiobjective Optimization Problem (MOP), where the minimal resolution cell and the maximum imaging area are used as the optimal criteria. Secondly, the improved third generation Nondomi-nated Sorting Genetic Algorithm (NSGA-III) is applied to solve the MOP, with satellite numbers introduced as discrete decision variables. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed method is verified by the experimental results.

title: Virtual Electric Machine for Extended Testing of Multi-Megawatt Power Range Technologies: Control Concept
authors: Glib Chekavskyy, John Eckerle, Kai Pietilaeinen, Hugo Wiktor, Daniel Jurkowski, Andrey Kalygin
publish: 2025 10th IEEE Workshop on the Electronic Grid (eGRID)
abstract: This paper presents an overview of a control system designed to support application of electric machine emulation based on modular medium-voltage (MV) power electronic converter (PEC) platform from large global supplier of industrial equipment. The emulation is carried out by reproducing voltage, current and power trajectories, generated by reference model executed in real time by application controller, with special control unit which compensates for the emulation error. Results of real-time simulation sessions illustrate the performance of emulation.

title: Satellite-Based Assessment of Agricultural Transformation in War-Affected Southern Ukraine
authors: Bohdan Yailymov, Hanna Yailymova, Nataliia Kussul, Andrii Shelestov, Sheila Baber, Olexandr Parkhomchuk, Olha Zhdanova, Sergii Skakun, Inbal Becker-Reshef
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Military operations in Ukraine have led to significant changes in land use, especially in the southern regions, where irrigation plays a critical role in agriculture. The destruction of infrastructure and the occupation of territories have caused a significant reduction in agricultural production, affecting food security in the region and the world. Land use changes were analyzed based on the analysis of the time series of satellite data for 2016-2024. Using the developed reference mask of cropland, the area of abandoned land increased to 17.4% (5.1 million hectares) of the total area (29.1 million hectares) detected. In the occupied territories, 46.3% of agricultural land (2.7 million hectares out of 5.9 million hectares) was not cultivated in 2024. An analysis of historically irrigated lands in the Kherson region revealed changes in the crop structure, with the largest reduction in moisture-dependent crops: soybean areas decreased by 95.8%, and maize by 52.3%. The study's results quantitatively characterize the war's impact on the agricultural sector and its consequences for food security.

title: An Infrared and Visible Image Fusion Strategy Integrating Global Multi-Scale Information
authors: Jingsui Li, Xiaorun Li, Shuhan Chen
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Infrared and visible image fusion can effectively compensate for the inherent flaws of each modality in different scenes, allowing the fused image to retain richer information. Existing deep learning algorithms based on autoencoder(AE) primarily focus on extracting local information from images using convolution neural networks(CNN). Some researchers have also introduced Transformer into image fusion networks to capture global long-range dependencies. However, there is a lack of research on global dependencies for different local features. Therefore, this paper proposes an infrared and visible image fusion strategy that integrates global multi-scale information. The proposed method extracts local features using multi-scale modules, then integrates them using a Transformer-based global feature extraction module. Finally, an attention map is generated based on the extracted features to preserve salient information and perform fusion. In the experimental section, the proposed algorithm is tested and compared on the MSRS and TNO datasets, and the results demonstrate the effectiveness and advancement of the fusion performance.

title: Integrating Satellite and Street-View Images for Urban Sidewalk Extraction
authors: Yi Lin, Jinhua Yu, Junyan Ye, Weijia Li
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Sidewalk, as a fundamental infrastructure in pedestrian environment, significantly affects the comfort and safety of pedestrian walking. Sidewalk extraction is one of the important topics in modern urban planning and management. Existing methods for sidewalk extraction based on satellite images face challenges such as occlusion by trees and buildings. To address these challenges, we propose a cross-view sidewalk extraction method that integrates satellite and street-view images. To achieve this integration, our method establishes two parallel branches to simultaneously process the cross-view inputs. Additionally, to address the significant discrepancy between satellite and street-view images, we introduce the Bird’s Eye View (BEV) transformation in the street-view branch. By converting street-view images into satellite-view BEV images, we extract perspective-aligned features, thereby solving the sidewalk occlusion problem in single remote sensing images through cross-view feature fusion. Furthermore, we introduce two new cross-view datasets for sidewalks extraction, sampling from cities of New York and Seattle, and evaluate several advanced semantic segmentation methods on these datasets. Our method achieves the best performance on both datasets with IoU values of 62.56% and 57.51%. Experimental results demonstrate that our method significantly improving sidewalk extraction performance in challenging scenarios such as tree occlusions and building shadows.

title: Time-Encoded Iterative Interactive Segmentation for Point Cloud
authors: Wentao Sun, Yiping Chen, Dedong Zhang, John S. Zelek, Jonathan Li
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Point cloud interactive segmentation can simplify the process of manual labeling; however, existing methods are far from satisfactory and face several challenges to conquer. We propose one novel deep learning-based iterative interactive segmentation network for point cloud, named Time-encoded Iterative Interactive Segmentation Network (TiisNet). This method allows users to segment the objects of interest by interactively clicking on them. TiisNet comprises two key parts: a point cloud and clicks encoder, and a general training strategy. The point cloud and clicks encoder extracts spatial and temporal features from the point cloud and user clicks. The general training strategy enhances training efficiency and prevents network degradation. Ablation experiments verify the effectiveness of the training strategy. The comparative experiments also demonstrate that TiisNet achieves superior segmentation performance compared to existing method. The code is at TiisNet GitHub

title: Investigating the Potential of Super-Resolution for Road Segmentation in Sentinel-2 Images
authors: Sandeep Kumar Jangir, Corentin Henry, Nina Merkle
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Road segmentation from Sentinel-2 imagery is challenging due to its coarse 10 m spatial resolution, yet its global coverage makes it valuable for applications like disaster relief and infrastructure monitoring. Traditional segmentation methods rely on high-resolution data, but recent approaches have explored super-resolution to enhance the spatial resolution of Sentinel-2 images. This study investigates the potential of super-resolution to perform road segmentation at 62.5 cm resolution from single-image Sentinel-2 RGB data, bridging the resolution domain gap. Both the super-resolution and the segmentation models are trained on high-resolution data, making the task more difficult. We demonstrate that these models can generalize to low-resolution data and deliver usable results for various applications, particularly in regions lacking up-to-date high-resolution imagery.

title: FGDI-NET: A Novel Flood Detection Method Fusing Global Deep Information
authors: Liansong Zhang, Zhonghuai Zhou, Yao Dai, Yufen Niu, Zhong Lu, Jinqi Zhao
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Flood detection based on Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) imagery has been widely used in crisis management and damage assessment. With the development of SAR sensor and massive SAR data, deep learning has been widely applied to change detection. For flood detection tasks, the irregular nature of water bodies and the extensive coverage of floods pose significant challenges in identifying water bodies and extracting change features. These challenges hinder the practical application of SAR imagery in flood detection and require an innovative approach to address these issues. To address these challenges, we propose a novel Fusing Global Deep Information Network (FGDI-Net) designed to achieve high-precision flood detection. Our approach has been evaluated on the publicly available SAR image flood detection dataset S1GFloods and compared with several state-of-the-art methods. Experimental results show that FGDI-Net exhibits the best performance, achieving 97.61%, 96.24%, 92.75%, and 94.49% in terms of OA, F1, IoU, and Kappa, respectively.

title: A Grid Cell Inspired Neural Network for 1D Robot Navigation
authors: Joseph Wang, Scott Koziol
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: This study presents a simple neural network model that simulates, in MATLAB, grid-cell-like activity and interprets location data in a 1D-axis environment. By encoding spatial information through overlapping Gaussian distributions of simulated grid cell firings, the model produces activation patterns that are then processed by an artificial neural network to train it to predict location based on these firing patterns. Simulation results demonstrate that the model achieves high accuracy in predicting location, with performance influenced by factors such as hidden layer size, varying use of grid cells, the number of location outputs, and the introduction of noise into the grid cell data.

title: A Dual-Branch SAR Object detection Framework Using Wavelet Decomposition and Attention-Guided Feature Fusion
authors: Huang Siyang, Su Shaojing, Wei Junyu, Hu Liushun, Cheng Zhangjunjie, Zhao Zongqing
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) object detection presents unique challenges due to noise, clutter, and the need for both local and global feature extraction. Traditional single-branch detectors, whether purely CNN or Transformer based, often encounter feature competition, resulting in suboptimal performance. In this paper, we propose a dual-branch network comprising a CNN branch (e.g., ConvNeXt) and a Transformer branch (e.g., Swin Transformer) to tackle these issues. By separating local and global feature extraction, we harness the inherent strengths of each architecture and mitigate feature competition. A frequency-guided attention module (FGMA) then aggregates their complementary representations, leading to more accurate and robust detection outcomes. Experimental results on multiple benchmark SAR datasets demonstrate that our method consistently outperforms single-branch baselines in terms of both quantitative metrics (e.g., mean Average Precision) and qualitative visual analysis. This framework, leveraging prior knowledge of CNNs and Transformers, provides a promising direction for advancing SAR object detection.

title: Enhancing SAR Object Detection with Self-Supervised Pre-Training on Masked Auto-Encoders
authors: Xinyang Pu, Feng Xu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Supervised fine-tuning methods (SFT) perform great efficiency on artificial intelligence interpretation in SAR images, leveraging the powerful representation knowledge from pre-training models. Due to the lack of domain-specific pre-trained backbones in SAR images, the traditional strategies are loading the foundation pre-train models of natural scenes such as ImageNet, whose characteristics of images are extremely different from SAR images. This may hinder the model performance on downstream tasks when adopting SFT on small-scale annotated SAR data. In this paper, an self-supervised learning (SSL) method of masked image modeling based on Masked Auto-Encoders (MAE) is proposed to learn feature representations of SAR images during the pre-training process and benefit the object detection task in SAR images of SFT. The evaluation experiments on the large-scale SAR object detection benchmark named SARDet-100k verify that the proposed method captures proper latent representations of SAR images and improves the model generalization in downstream tasks by converting the pre-trained domain from natural scenes to SAR images through SSL. The proposed method achieves an improvement of 1.3 mAP on the SARDet-100k benchmark compared to only the SFT strategies.

title: Cell Design Optimization of 1700 V Micropattern Trench IGBTs
authors: Paula Reigosa, Nick Schneider, Roger Stark, Tommaso Stecconi, Coris Li, Leon Liang, Lars Knoll
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: In this paper, an analysis of the trench cell structure for next generation micropattern trench IGBTs is presented. The impact of the trench density and cell structure while maintaining same mesa width, channel dose and buffer/anode is investigated. A figure of merit with the most relevant parameters (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{V}_{\text{ce,sat }}, \mathrm{E}_{\text{off }}, \mathrm{E}_{\text{on }}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{I}_{\text{sc }}$</tex>) is introduced to compare the fabricated designs. The RBSOA capability, turn-off softness, and controllability are experimentally verified.

title: Reducing Overvoltage Stress on FB-SMs in the Coordinated Operation of Hybrid MMCS and Hybrid CBs During DC-side Fault Conditions
authors: Hossein Imaneini, Mahdi Aslanian, Marco Liserre
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper presents a method to limit overvoltage stress on full-bridge submodules (FB-SMs) in Hybrid Modular Multilevel Converters (H-MMCs) when a DC short-circuit fault happens. The H-MMCs will employ a reduced number of FBSMs per arm to minimize conduction losses during normal operation, while being coordinated with hybrid circuit breakers (H-CBs) to enable fast fault isolation in multi-terminal DC (MTDC) systems. After confirming a DC fault, the CB initiates the opening of the mechanical switch, and the H-MMC is blocked to prevent the discharge of MMC submodules, thereby limiting the current rise in the MMC and CB components. However, due to the blocking of the H-MMC, the FB-SMs in certain upper and lower arms may experience significant overvoltage stress. To mitigate this stress, two measures are implemented: (1) the voltage across the contacts of the mechanical switch in the H-CB is gradually increased during its opening process, and (2) the FB-SMs in the arm experiencing higher overvoltage stress are bypassed once a critical threshold is reached. These steps alleviate the stress on the FB-SMs without requiring an increase in their capacitance or the addition of auxiliary circuits in the H-MMC. The validity of this approach is verified through simulation results obtained in the PSCAD/EMTDC environment, demonstrating its effectiveness in HVDC systems.

title: Effect of Solder Layer Thickness on the Reliability of Silicon Carbide Power Devices
authors: Shengjie Luo, Xingjian Shi, Haoze Luo, Xiangning He, Naoto Fujishima, Keiji Okumura
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Compared to silicon (Si)-based devices, silicon carbide (SiC) devices are more applicable to high-frequency, high-voltage, and high-temperature environments. However, the material and structural characteristics of SiC devices introduce more severe reliability issues, necessitating the optimization of packaging parameters to extend their operational lifespan. Currently, the packaging failures of SiC modules have not been well studied in the past. Since the solder layer is one of the primary failure sites in SiC modules, this study investigates the impact of solder layer thickness on module reliability. A combination of finite element simulation and power cycling tests is employed, and the solder layer is scanned using a 3D X-ray imager. The results indicate that as the solder layer thickness increases from 0.10 mm, the thermal stress experienced by the module first decreases and then increases, with the highest reliability observed at a thickness of approximately 0.20 mm. This study enhances the understanding of the relationship between thermal stress, solder layer voids, and lifespan, providing a foundation for investigating failure mechanisms. By employing thermal stress analysis and porosity statistics, it reflects the failure process and aids in developing more precise lifespan models. The findings also offer guidance for optimizing solder layer parameters during module design to minimize thermal stress, thereby improving lifespan and achieving high-reliability module design.

title: Study on Influencing Factors of Voltage Unbalance Ratio in Snubber Capacitor Self-Balancing Circuits for Series-Connected Sic MOSFETs Applied to High-Voltage Pulsed Power Systems
authors: Jiaxuan Niu, Xu Yang, Fan Zhang, Kexin Zhao, Haonan Li, Keliang Chen, Xu Cheng, Yong Chen
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: SiC MOSFETS, with advantages such as high switching speed and high breakdown voltage, are a key focus in the development of pulsed power switches. The snubber capacitor self-balancing circuit, characterized by simplicity, high reliability, and full-speed switching capability, provides an effective solution for dynamic voltage balancing in seriesconnected SiC MOSFETS under extremely fast switching conditions. To meet the voltage withstand requirements of pulsed power switches, ranging from tens to hundreds kV, dozens of low-voltage SiC MOSFETS must be connected in series. However, factors such as loop impedance, gate drive delay, the count of switches connected in series, and duty cycle affect the voltage balancing capability of the topology, thereby influencing the voltage withstand limit and safe operation of each switch. This paper analyzes the working principle and waveforms of the snubber circuits, investigates the impact of influencing factors on voltage unbalance ratio and validates through LTspice simulations, and proposes solutions for further optimizing the voltage withstand and balancing capabilities of the topology.

title: A Comprehensive Analysis of Zero-Current Switching Losses in SiC Power Modules
authors: Tushar Bang, Ramona Buckreus, Ho Ngoc Tran
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Efficiency is a critical factor in the development of battery electric vehicle powertrains, directly influencing the achievable range. This paper investigates the switching losses which occur in half-bridge power modules even if no load current is provided to the electric machine (zero-current switching losses). The contribution to these losses from the output capacitances of SiC MOSFETs and from the parasitic capacitances introduced by power module packaging are analyzed. We differentiate between the energy stored in the output capacitance, and subsequently lost during discharging, and the losses incurred during the charging of output capacitance via the opposite switch, which are often overlooked in datasheets. We also investigate the additional losses coming from capacitances of power module packaging. Two experimental methods are introduced to determine zero-current switching losses and results indicate that the energy stored in output capacitance accounts for only a fraction of the total zero-current switching losses. Results also show the significant effect of package capacitances on zero-current switching losses. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of zero-current switching losses in half-bridge power modules and shows two methods to effectively determine these losses.

title: Implementation of Augmented Reality-Based Learning Media to Enhance Students’ Conceptual Understanding and Learning Independence in Informatics Subjects
authors: Gres Dyah Kusuma Ningrum, Dila Umnia Soraya, Ahmad Mursyidun Nidhom, Rizky Rahmad Andre Anang, Rutria Sarah Hasna Tsabita Afaf, Miftah Fadhlurrohman, Hikmatul Afifah Fikriati, Arisandi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: The development of digital technology in the Society 5.0 era requires education systems to cultivate learners who are not only academically competent but also adaptive and innovative. Augmented Reality (AR) offers an effective learning medium to connect abstract concepts with practical experiences, particularly in technology-related subjects. This study investigates the effectiveness of an AR-based learning medium called “AR-Curity” in enhancing students’ conceptual understanding and learning independence. Employing a quantitative approach with a quasi-experimental one-group pretest-posttest design, the study involved 25 ninth-grade students from SMP Negeri 25 Malang. Instruments consisted of multiple-choice tests to assess conceptual understanding and Likert-scale questionnaires to measure learning independence, both validated and tested for reliability. Data were analyzed using paired sample t-tests and N-Gain scores. Results showed significant improvement in both variables: conceptual understanding increased from 71.40 to 88.88 (N -Gain $=0.55$, moderate), while learning independence rose from 77.05 to 86.40 ($\mathbf{N}$-Gain $\boldsymbol{=} \mathbf{0. 4 1}$, moderate). These findings demonstrate that ARCurity not only improves cognitive outcomes but also fosters metacognitive skills and learning independence, positioning AR as an innovative and effective medium to support 21st-century learning competencies.

title: Exploring Inertia and Damping for GFM Converters with Hybrid Synchronization Control
authors: Haowen Wang, Zejie Li, Fangzhou Zhao, Ilka Jahn, Xiongfei Wang
publish: 2025 10th IEEE Workshop on the Electronic Grid (eGRID)
abstract: The hybrid synchronization control (HSC) method and active susceptance controller (ASC) have been demonstrated to be effective approaches for addressing the instability of grid-forming inverters under strong grid conditions. In this paper, HSC and ASC are demonstrated to share the same essence—introducing a voltage-based synchronization loop. Furthermore, differing from previous studies that rely on small-signal analysis, this paper establishes a unified large-signal model for both HSC and ASC to characterize the inertia and damping, and to elaborate that how they affect the dynamic responses. Based on the large-signal model, it is revealed that the introduced voltage-based synchronization loop of both HSC and ASC reduces the damping and inertia, thereby resulting in a faster response and higher overshoot. The findings are confirmed by the experimental results.

title: A High-Precision Synchronization Algorithm for X-Band Unmanned Aerial Vehicle-Borne Bistatic SAR
authors: Yonghua Cai, Zongbiao Chen, Bo Li, Pingping Lu, Yingfei Sun, Robert Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Time synchronization and phase synchronization are critical for bistatic synthetic aperture radar (BiSAR), as synchronization accuracy is closely related to both imaging quality and interferometric precision. However, clocks with lower stability require higher synchronization frequencies to achieve the desired synchronization accuracy, which presents a significant challenge for BiSAR systems. To overcome this issue, a high-precision phase synchronization algorithm assisted by synchronization compensation time is proposed. The method utilizes two-way time transfer (TWTT) to acquire the synchronization compensation time, from which the bistatic frequency deviation is estimated. With the assistance of the estimated frequency deviation, the synchronization phase can be correctly unwrapped under low synchronization frequency, allowing for interpolation and phase compensation. The proposed algorithm has been validated through laboratory tests and unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV)-borne flight experiments, achieving phase synchronization accuracy of better than 1° in the X-band under a synchronization frequency of 250 Hz, using low-cost commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) oscillators.

title:
Spatiotemporal Patterns and Urban-Rural Disparity in Stroke Mortality Related to PM
                    <sub>2.5</sub>
                    Pollution in China: 2005-2020
authors: Yuxin Zheng, Ming Liu, Renpeng Liu, Gaoxiang Zhou
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Exposure to fine particulate matter (PM2.5) has been significantly associated with cerebrovascular diseases, especially strokes. However, the large-scale and long-term spatiotemporal patterns and urban-rural disparities in PM2.5-related stroke mortalities have barely been explored. Therefore, the PM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2.5</inf> levels and its attributed stroke mortalities were estimated across China from 2005 to 2020 using the Global Exposure Mortality Model (GEMM). The disparity of stroke mortality attributable to PM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2.5</inf> pollution was explored between urban and rural regions. The results show that the stroke mortalities decreased from 638.95 thousand in 2005 to 544.77 thousand in 2020, despite intermittent fluctuations observed in specific subregions. This is related to the reduction of pollution revealed by the spatiotemporal patterns of PM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2.5</inf> levels. The findings also underscore a significant rural-urban divide in PM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2.5</inf>-related stroke mortality across Chinese cities in 2005 and 2020, with urban areas consistently experiencing higher stroke mortality compared to rural areas. Despite observing a reduction in the urban-rural gap in PM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2.5</inf>-related stroke mortality from 2005 to 2020, the sustained existence of this disparity underscores the necessity for sustained attention. Targeted policy interventions are imperative to establish a more equitable atmospheric environment, in line with and conducive to the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals.

title: Evaluating Flood Impacts on Environment and Socio-Economics with Google Earth Engine and Remote Sensing
authors: Nai Wei, Yi Lin, Hao Zheng
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Extreme weather-induced flood disasters significantly impact global human activities and livelihoods. Rapid and accurate damage assessment is essential for effective rescue efforts and resource allocation. This study employs the Google Earth Engine (GEE) platform to develop a flood impact assessment model, focusing on the major flood event around Poyang Lake in July 2020. The model provides a comprehensive flood assessment solution, evaluating both environmental and socio-economic impacts. By integrating Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) and optical imagery, it enhances flood extent extraction accuracy and assesses environmental impacts through the Remote Sensing Ecological Index (RSEI) before and after the flood. The results indicate a flooded area of 204,063 hectares and an impact area of 302,633 hectares. The average RSEI index decreased from 0.71 to 0.65, reflecting negative environmental effects. The total number of individuals affected was approximately 1.77 million, with 122,880 hectares of cropland and 15,670 hectares of urban areas being impacted. These findings are consistent with the damage reports at the provincial level, thereby confirming the reliability of the model. This research provides an efficient method for flood information extraction and analysis, supporting flood risk management and sustainable regional development.

title: Advancements in Marine Surface Analysis Using SAR for Wind Field and Sea Surface Velocity Mapping: Insights from the COMBINO Project
authors: Pietro Mastro, Andrea Petrossi, Giacomo De Carolis, Alfredo Renga, Giovanni Paolo Blasone, Deodato Tapete, Simona Zoffoli, Gianfranco Fornaro, Virginia Zamparelli, Simona Verde
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This work considers the radar monostatic and bistatic geometry and the observation parameters related to the estimation of wind fields and sea surface currents currently under investigation for the upcoming PLATiNO-1 SAR mission of the Italian Space Agency in the framework of the COMBINO project. Leveraging Fois’ polarimetric scattering model, the study evaluates the capability of such a model in monostatic and bistatic X-Band SAR acquisition geometries and under varying wind conditions to derive the Doppler shift and the Normalized Radar Cross-Section (NRCS) in the marine environment. This work showcases the results of this analysis, providing insights into the applicability of advanced modeling techniques and bistatic SAR configurations for marine studies. The findings allow to bridge the gap of knowledge in this context toward future SAR mission system design.

title: A 16-Gb/s CTLE with Active Inductor Load and Feed-Forward Architecture in 28-nm CMOS for High-Speed Serial Links
authors: Shameer Basha Yerragudi, Ashwin P Pramod, Santosh Yachareni, Khanh M Le, Zia Abbas
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: A 16-Gb/s continuous-time linear equalizer (CTLE) is designed in 28-nm CMOS technology, featuring an active inductor load and feedforward compensation to enhance high-frequency performance. The proposed design features a power-efficient architecture, achieving a remarkable eye opening of 45.75 ps and a vertical differential eye opening of 781.19 mV. The design achieves reliable operation for channel losses of 9 dB, consuming a total power of 3.3 mW from a 0.9 V supply. This CTLE provides an energy-efficient solution for high-speed SerDes applications, with a calculated figure-of-merit of 0.022 pJ/hit/dB.

title: Analytical Description of Simple Optimal Voltage Pulse Patterns for Single-Phase Inverters
authors: Ingo Hahn
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Recently a novel mathematical parameterization of simple single-phase synchronous voltage pulse patterns using pulse width <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{\Delta} \boldsymbol{T}_{1}$</tex> and delay <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{T}_{1}$</tex> instead of switching times for power inverters was suggested by the author. This method allows for a direct and easy calculation of the present harmonics of the voltage pulse patterns. There is an infinite number of parameter combinations for the pulse width <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{\Delta} \boldsymbol{T}_{1}$</tex> and the delay <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$T_{1}$</tex> for both the simple single-phase synchronized half-wave and quarter-wave symmetric voltage pulse patterns which lead to a desired value of the fundamental harmonic of the voltage pulse pattern. An exact mathematical solution will be presented within this manuscript to determine these parameter combinations. For each set of infinite parameter combinations for a given fundamental harmonic of the voltage pattern the Weighted Harmonic Distortion (WHD) is used to estimate the expected current harmonics content of a connected inductiveresistive load to the power inverter, and, therefore, the iron losses. Parameter combinations leading to the minimal WHD of the voltage pulse pattern for a fixed fundamental harmonic amplitude are determined and can be used for later implementation in the control algorithm of the power inverter.

title: An Intersection Detection Method based on Road Network Extraction from Optical Remote Sensing Images
authors: Zongyang He, Xiangli Yang, Fang Xu, Jiawang Ge, Chao Yang, Qiaoyun Zheng
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Road networks play a crucial role in urban planning and emergency management. As key nodes of road networks, intersections are vital for road network updates and traffic modeling, making their accurate detection essential. In optical remote sensing images, road intersections are often affected by occlusion and small, dense targets, leading to lower detection accuracy. To address this problem, an intersection detection method based on road network extraction from optical remote sensing images is proposed. The method first utilizes a deep learning model to extract the road network, followed by morphological operations for denoising and gap repair. Next, skeletonization extracts the road centerlines. Finally, intersection detection and shape segmentation are performed using an improved Harris corner detection algorithm. Experimental results on the DeepGlobe and Massachusetts datasets show F1-scores of 0.957 and 0.935, respectively, demonstrating its efficiency and robustness.

title: Assessment of Radiometric Resolution Impact on SAR-Assisted Optical Remote Sensing Image Cloud Removal
authors: Hongkun Liu, Jianmei Wang, Ziyang Zhu, Xinyan Li
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Using SAR imagery to assist optical imagery for cloud removal and reconstructing cloud-covered data for subsequent analysis holds significant practical value. Current researches mainly focus on the cloud removal method itself, and usually improve cloud removal method performance by optimizing network structures or increasing model parameters. However, these methods are often accompanied by higher demands for computational resources and sample sizes. The impact of data accuracy on a method's ability to distinguish geomorphological changes, such as the influence of the radiometric resolution of optical images on cloud removal, has received insufficient attention. In this paper, taking the public dataset SEN12MS-CR as an example, the classic U-Net and Former-CR cloud removal methods are used as experimental verification methods to evaluate the impact of radiation resolution on SAR assisted optical remote sensing image cloud removal. Experimental results show that improving radiometric resolution significantly enhances the quality of cloud-removal images and compensates for the shortcomings of the cloud removal methods themselves, which is of great significance for practical applications.

title: AI-Driven Physics-Based Onboard Charger for Optimised Battery Management
authors: Khursheed Sabeel, Maher Al-Greer, Chitra A, Maria Jenisha Charles Thanasingh
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Power-efficient battery management is critical for enhancing energy storage systems' performance, lifespan, and sustainability in modern technologies, including electric vehicles and renewable energy applications. This work introduces an AI-driven, physics-based onboard intelligent charger design that enhances battery charge and discharge processes and introduces assurance with its precision by leveraging physics data; the system predicts battery behaviour, adapts to varying conditions, and ensures optimal charging efficiency while reducing energy loss and preventing degradation. The solution incorporates a dynamic control system that adjusts charging parameters based on the state of charge (SoC), state of health (SoH), and thermal conditions of the battery, enabling adaptive and predictive control across diverse battery chemistries and operational requirements. The neural network (NN) training demonstrated stable convergence, achieving high precision in charge-discharge control through effectively optimising battery parameters. The system can also exhibit robust adaptability across diverse battery chemistries, including lithium-ion and lithium-iron-phosphate, and enhance the performance of second-life batteries.

title: Large Language Models with Retrieval Augmented Generation to streamline Sentinel-2 data Description
authors: Teodor Costăchioiu, Corina Văduva, Daniela Faur
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In this paper, we introduce a novel methodology for interpreting the content of Sentinel-2 multispectral imagery by leveraging a combination of spectral indices, Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), and context-aware prompting strategies. Specifically, we calculate spectral indices at the patch level to enhance the representation of image content and integrate this information with the Mistral Small 3.1 large language model (LLM) to generate interpretable context-aware analyses. Our approach aims to bridge the gap between remote sensing expertise and the reasoning capabilities of LLMs. Importantly, the proposed framework is lightweight and does not require fine-tuning, making it suitable for real-world use cases on modest hardware; all experiments were conducted on a consumer-grade PC with a 24GB VRAM GPU.

title: Semi-Supervised Seabed Sediment Classification Based on Multi-level Contrastive Learning and Uncertainty Measurement
authors: Haoyi Wang, Siyang Wan, Weitao Chen, Xianju Li, Xuwen Qin
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Seabed sediment classification and understanding are of great significance for marine mineral exploration, ecological protection, and underwater navigation. The annotation of sonar data is time-consuming and costly, and the scarcity of labeled data makes it particularly important to develop semi-supervised learning methods that can effectively leverage unlabeled data. To address the high variability of seabed sediment features and spatial distribution differences, this study proposes a semi-supervised seabed sediment classification framework based on multi-level contrastive learning and uncertainty measurement (MCUF). 1) Optimization based on multi-level contrastive learning addresses the variability of seabed sediment features. It extracts and aggregates multi-level features to capture more comprehensive seabed sediment characteristics. By embedding sediment samples into the feature space through contrastive learning, the features of unlabeled data are aligned with those of labeled data, thereby improving the separability between sediment categories and the consistency within each category. 2) Pseudo-label filtering based on uncertainty measurement addresses the significant spatial distribution differences of seabed sediments. Dynamic computation of pseudo-label class weights is utilized to mitigate the bias caused by class imbalance. By calculating entropy to measure the uncertainty of model predictions, the threshold for pseudo-label selection is adaptively adjusted for sediment samples, enhancing the flexibility of filtering and discarding unreliable pseudo-labels. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves performance improvements under various labeled data ratios. The proposed framework effectively leverages unlabeled data and significantly improves the accuracy of seabed sediment classification.

title: Multi-Temporal Impact Assessment of Urban Wastewater
authors: Nouha Mezned, Belgacem Dkhala, Faten Alayet
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) are responsible for approximately 1–2% of global greenhouse gas emissions, primarily releasing carbon dioxide (CO₂), methane (CH₄), and nitrous oxide (N₂O) during the treatment process. This environmental concern is particularly acute in urban areas, where dense populations generate large volumes of wastewater, often pushing treatment facilities to their capacity limits and reducing their efficiency in pollutant removal.This study demonstrates the enhanced applicability of Sentinel-2 (S2) satellite imagery, acquired during both summer and winter seasons, for mapping wastewater within urban WWTPs and monitoring their discharge into adjacent aquatic environments. The approach is based on customized algorithms adapted to process surface reflectance data, taking into account atmospheric effects. These methods have proven effective in identifying, mapping, and tracking the spatial extent and movement of wastewater, thereby offering a more accurate evaluation of its environmental impact.Such an approach is essential for assessing ecological risks and guiding sustainable water management, particularly in urban regions where WWTPs are critical infrastructure for safeguarding public health and achieving environmental sustainability aligned with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

title: Towards Automatically Mapping Mineral Forming Processes from CRISM Hyperspectral Data: Automatic Open-Set Mineral Identification
authors: Sandeepan Dhoundiyal, Malcolm Aranha, Kalimuthu R, Moni Shankar Dey, Shashikant Singh, Debosmita Paul, Arun P. V, Guneshwar Thangjam, Alok Porwal
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This study evaluates the effectiveness of Random Forest (RF) and Gradient Boosted Trees (GBT) for mapping minerals from CRISM hyperspectral data, using performance metrics and SHAP-derived explanations. The results demonstrate that RF outperforms GBT in mineral identification. To overcome limitations in existing methods, RF is integrated with an Extreme Value Analysis (EVA). The method’s effectiveness is demonstrated using the CRISM Machine Learning toolkit’s mineral dataset. Furthermore, a novel pipeline is introduced that combines RF and EVA with domain knowledge. This combination enables automatic mapping of mineral-forming processes from CRISM datacubes.

title: Gridless High-Speed Maneuvering Target Detection and Estimation for Bistatic Radar Based on Local Minimum Entropy
authors: Chong Song, Bingnan Wang, Yinshen Wang, Manlai Ding, Hao Liu, Maosheng Xiang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Bistatic radar high-speed maneuvering target detection has drawn increasing attention in wide-area surveillance and reconnaissance due to its flexible transmitter and receiver configuration. This paper proposes a novel gridless target detection and estimation method for bistatic radar based on local minimum entropy. By combining the target’s entropy information with the particle swarm optimization algorithm, the phase compensation is designed using the gridless target parameters to maximize the target signal energy and recover its resolution, thereby enhancing the detection performance of high-speed maneuvering targets. Experiments on a measured radar dataset are conducted to validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Joint Spatio-Temporal Correction for Both Turbulent and Stratified Tropospheric Delays in TS-InSAR
authors: Hong’an Wu, Nan Liu, Yonghong Zhang, Lei Zhang, Yonghui Kang, Jujie Wei
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Synthetic aperture radar interferometry (InSAR) has been applied in ground deformation monitoring. However, the interferograms are susceptible to tropospheric delay artifacts, including both turbulent delays and stratified ones, especially in mountainous regions, due to temporal and spatial variation of temperature, humidity and pressure in the troposphere. Most atmospheric correction methods only address one of the delays and lack comprehensive consideration, thus it is hard to suppress the atmospheric artifacts completely. In this paper, we proposed a joint spatio-temporal correction (JSTC) method for both turbulent and stratified delays, which applies a dual-scale temporal low-pass filter to separate turbulent delays from other low-frequency components in temporal domain, then adopts the quadtree segmentation to correct stratified delays caused by spatial heterogeneity. The proposed method was first validated by simulated data, and then tested by real data in the mountainous region. The results demonstrated that our method can significantly reduce the impact of atmospheric artifacts on the interferograms.

title: A Single-Ended Digital Power Amplifier with Variable Coding for Harmonic Rejection
authors: Weibo Li, Tianshuo Xie, Minghao Jiang, Yongzhen Chen, Jiangfeng Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: The digital switch-capacitor power amplifier (SCPA) suffers from the harmonics distortion which results in degraded out-of-band (OOB) suppression and the communication quality. This paper proposes a method that features variable amplitude control word (ACW) in one local oscillator (LO) cycle to eliminate the third-order harmonic with a single-ended architecture. The method reduces the number of the arrays and the total capacitors dynamic power consumption, while avoiding the mismatch of multiple arrays. The circuit simulation based 28nm CMOS process was conducted to validate the effectiveness.
