The results demonstrate a peak output power of 14 dBm and 52% efficiency at 2.4 GHz LO, with second- and third-order harmonics suppressed to 66 dBc and 53 dBc, respectively.

title: Memristor Logic Array Design for Efficient Stochastic Computing
authors: Yan Chen, Xiaoning Gao, Yani Fan, Hongwei Yue, Jian Xu, Sa Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computational Intelligence and Robotics (CIR)
abstract: Stochastic computing (SC) has been shown to be effective for arithmetic operations by representing data as binary bitstreams. Memristors hold the potential to perform in-memory computations, thereby effectively addressing the challenges posed by the memory wall and power wall. However, prior works have often encountered difficulties in achieving computational efficiency. In this paper, we design an SC calculator utilizing a memristor logic array to achieve high efficiency. To efficiently support typical SC computations in memristor arrays, we develop two types of circuit models: single-stage and multi-stage computational models. Single-stage model performs operations in a memristor array for basic SC operations, while multi-stage model performs operations in multi-cascaded memristor arrays for complex SC operation. To verify the efficiency of the proposed SC calculator, we conduct simulations using LTSPICE, and the results demonstrate the efficiency of the memristor-based SC calculators.

title: Towards High-Voltage Hundred-Megawatt-Level Energy Storage Systems: Cost-Effective and Efficient Grid-Forming Multilevel Converters
authors: Kaiyu Chen, Yufei Li, Laili Wang
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Energy storage converters, namely the power conversion systems (PCSs), are essential components for energy storage systems (ESS), which manage the voltage, current, and power flow of the grid-integration system. Traditional PCSs rely on low frequency transformers (LFTs) to integrate the ESS into the medium- or high-voltage power grid. However, LFTs are exceptionally bulky, noisy, costly, and highly space-consuming. Consequently, the transformerless PCS architecture stands out as a promising solution for reducing the cost and volume of ESSs. Currently, research on transformerless PCSs mostly focus on the low- or medium-voltage levels, there is hardly research involving high-voltage hundred-megawatt level ESSs thus far. Therefore, this paper investigates four topologies for high-voltage hundredmegawatt ESSs and analyzes their costs, efficiencies and volume. Ultimately, a comparatively cost-effective and efficient solution with promising performance is identified, offering guidelines for engineering practices and paving the way towards high-voltage hundred-megawatt-level ESSs. Finally, simulation results show that the proposed topology can operate under the grid-forming control, enhancing the stability and reliability of the power system as a grid-forming converter.

title: A Novel High Voltage/High Frequency Solid State Switch with SiC MOSFETs for Particle Accelerator Applications
authors: Lars Dresel, Gerd Griepentrog, Bernhard Zipfel
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This article describes a solid state switch that is used to temporarily deactivate a synchrotron RF cavity. An accelerating cavity serves as an example here, which has a fundamental sinusoidal voltage of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 25 \text{kV}$</tex> with a frequency of 0.1 MHz to 5.4 MHz. These values are a combination of the properties of different cavity systems that will be used in the FAIR synchrotron SIS100 in order to cover all requirements. The particle ion beam reaches peak currents of up to 100 A to 150 A with a pulse duration of 50 ns. Due to interference of the ion beam with the cavity, the impedance of the cavity has to be reduced temporarily, resulting in the requirement for a solid state switch consisting of semiconductors that are either turned off or turned on. Due to the harsh environement such as radiation, high temperature, high frequency and high voltages, the research questions guiding this inquiry are designed to explore the utilization of SiC MOSFETs, comprising up to 20 stages in total. An equivalent circuit of the used cavity and the gap switch is presented.

title: Yieldfusion: Enhancing Yield Prediction with Transfer Learning
authors: Anamika Dey, Somrita Sarkar, V. V. S. Sri Harsha, Chandranath Chatterjee, Arijit Mondal, Pabitra Mitra
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Accurate crop yield prediction is essential for food security, export-import strategies, and food storage planning. Our study presents the YieldFusion model, integrating Time2Vec embedding and domain adaptation through transfer learning. The model incorporates temporal convolutional networks, bidirectional LSTM, and multi-head attention layers in architecture for sequence modeling. Focused on rice yield prediction in West Bengal, India, where rice is the country’s primary staple crop, this study utilizes deep learning models alongside datasets comprising meteorological variables and district-level production data. Preprocessing steps like spatial clipping, temporal smoothing, and scaling captured the relationship between environmental factors and rice cultivation. Transfer learning from the M4 dataset fine-tuned the models, and comparisons with traditional models like LSTM and GRU highlighted the ability of advanced architectures. A systematic evaluation using metrics such as Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score, and Symmetric Mean Absolute Percentage Error (SMAPE) provided valuable insights into the efficacy of each model. The YieldFusion model achieved significantly lower RMSE (0.0135) compared to the TCN, Transformer, Bi-LSTM, and Bi-GRU models, with an average improvement of approximately 60%.

title: Mobocean: Multi-Objective Bilevel Optimization For Ocean Acidification
authors: Violina Doley, Aakash Mallik
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Ocean acidification, driven by rising atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>) levels, presents a major threat to marine ecosystems worldwide. Accurately predicting ocean pH trends is crucial for understanding the impacts of acidification on marine life. This research introduces MOBOCEAN, a novel methodology to enhance pH prediction by applying Multi-Objective Bilevel Optimization (MOBO) combined with Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks. This approach simultaneously optimizes feature selection and model hyperparameters, targeting ocean pH while accounting for auxiliary biogeochemical factors such as Carbon Dioxide Fugacity (fCO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>) and Apparent Oxygen Utilization (AOU). The optimization process uses a binary mask for feature selection and hybrid algorithms to fine-tune model parameters, improving predictive accuracy. Our findings demonstrate the effectiveness of MOBO in refining ocean acidification models, providing insights for environmental management and mitigation strategies. This work highlights the potential of advanced optimization techniques in addressing complex ecological challenges.

title: Uncertainty-Aware Flood Segmentation from Sentinel 2 Observations with Conformal Prediction
authors: Ioannis Konidakis, Klea Panayidou, Grigorios Tsagkatakis, Panagiotis Tsakalides
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Flood segmentation using supervised deep learning models like U-Net plays a pivotal role in disaster response by facilitating rapid and accurate identification of flood-affected areas. However, ensuring the reliability of these models’ predictions is essential, especially in high-stakes applications. Conformal Prediction (CP) provides statistically valid uncertainty estimates and is increasingly recognized as a robust tool for uncertainty quantification. This paper investigates the performance of the two major approaches in CP, namely Inductive CP and k-fold Cross-Validation CP (CV+), in the context of flood segmentation. By evaluating these methods on a baseline bitemporal U-Net model, we demonstrate that CP can offer critical insights into model confidence. Our findings highlight the limitations of Inductive CP in data-scarce scenarios and underscore the advantages of CV+ in achieving a superior balance between calibration and training data usage. This study highlights the importance of CP techniques in enhancing trustworthiness in flood segmentation models.

title: Utilization of the IGBT On-Chip Temperature Sensor for Online Temperature Monitoring Considering Continuous Switching Operation
authors: Narender Lakshmanan, Thomas Radke, James Abuogo, Jörg Franke, Josef Lutz, Thomas Basler
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: IGBT junction temperature determination is an important task for implementing condition monitoring. Although there are several indirect methods to determine the junction temperature of an IGBT, it has been a challenge to acquire the junction temperature during device operation. The on-chip junction temperature sensor allows for direct junction temperature measurement without interrupting the normal operation of the IGBT. There are transient effects which influence the temperature sensor signal during switching operation. This study analyzes the factors influencing the on-chip temperature sensor signal during IGBT operation which includes switching and proposes a practical approach for online junction temperature monitoring.

title: An Update on The NASA Tropics Constellation Mission After Two Years Of Science Operations
authors: W. Blackwell, M. Diliberto, R. Leslie, A. Milstein, G. Perras, M. Pieper, N. Zorn, S. Braun, C. Kidd, T. Matsui, D. Herndon, C. Velden, S. Griffin, Y. You
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: New constellations to provide high-resolution atmospheric observations from microwave sounders operating in low-earth orbit are now coming online and are providing operationally useful data. The first of these missions, the NASA TROPICS (Time-Resolved Observations of Precipitation structure and storm Intensity with a Constellation of Smallsats) Earth Venture (EVI-3) mission, was successfully launched into orbit on May 7 and May 25, 2023 (Eastern Daylight Time, two CubeSats in each of the two launches). TROPICS is now providing nearly all-weather observations of 3-D temperature and humidity, as well as cloud ice and precipitation horizontal structure, at high temporal resolution to conduct high-value science investigations of tropical cyclones. TROPICS is providing rapid-refresh microwave measurements (median refresh rate of better than 60 minutes early in the mission with four functional CubeSats, and now approximately 70-90 minutes with three functional CubeSats) over the tropics that can be used to observe the thermodynamics of the troposphere and precipitation structure for storm systems at the mesoscale and synoptic scale over the entire storm lifecycle. Hundreds of high-resolution images of tropical cyclones have been captured thus far by the TROPICS mission, revealing detailed structure of the eyewall and surrounding rain bands. The new 205-GHz channel in particular (together with a traditional channel near 92 GHz) is providing new information on the inner storm structure, and, coupled with the relatively frequent revisit and low downlink latency, is already informing tropical cyclone analysis at operational centers. Here we present an an update on the TROPICS mission after over two years of science operations with a focus on the suite of geophysical (Level 2) products (atmospheric vertical temperature and moisture profiles, instantaneous surface rain rate, and tropical cyclone intensity). All TROPICS standard data products meet the mission baseline requirements.

title: Dynamic Adjustment of Random Keyframes for Enhanced 3DGS-based Slam Performance
authors: Daoqiang Zhou, Yali Cheng, Longfan Yang, Wenbo Xu, Haitao Jia, Le Chang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This paper investigates the influence of selecting varying numbers of random keyframes during camera motion on the performance of 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) based Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) system. The analysis reveals that excessive random keyframes in the later stages of motion can detrimentally impact pose estimation accuracy and environment reconstruction quality. To address this issue, we propose a novel strategy that dynamically adjusts the number of selected random keyframes. This strategy leverages more random keyframes during the early stages to reduce cumulative errors while reducing the number in the later stages to avoid incorrect pose influence. Experimental evaluations on multiple public datasets demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly enhances pose tracking accuracy and reconstruction quality. These findings validate the effectiveness of the method, providing a promising direction for improving 3DGS-based SLAM performance.

title: It’s still Hungry People and Mining – Deforestation in Kahuzi-Biega National Park - Eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo
authors: Richard A Beck, Hongxing Liu, Song Shu, Lei Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: High-resolution satellite imagery, Landsat-based, well-documented deforestation data products and two field visits indicate that deforestation in Kahuzi-Biega National Park in the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo is caused mostly by the conversion of forested park land to agricultural fields and some mining. Deforestation is worsening steadily (1.40 to 5.58 percent from 2013 to 2023) and is especially acute in the highland part of the park which is home to Grauer’s gorillas. This highland area is situated mostly above low-value volcanic rocks that are less attractive to miners and therefore less contentious in terms of conservation. This study supports early studies that indicated small mines are relatively common in the large lower western mineral-rich part of the park but cover small areas. Importantly, farming and some mining have effectively severed the forest corridor between the upper and lower parts of the park. This study suggests that western aid agencies and conservation organizations accept these unpleasant realities and allow the Congolese park rangers to focus their limited resources on conservation of the original mountainous upper part of the park with its well-known gorillas above low-value volcanic rocks before it is too late to save them. It is time for unpopular triage.

title: Few-Shot Class Incremental Learning with Precognition and Retrospection for Mars Hyperspectral Image Classification
authors: Yun Zhang, Bobo Xi, Xunfeng Zhao, Jiaojiao Li, Yunsong Li
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Hyperspectral image classification (HSIC) has been extensively studied in the context of Earth observation. However, its application in Mars exploration remains limited. Specifically, the Martian environment is highly complex and may contain previously unseen mineral categories. The traditional trained HSIC models can only make predictions on pre-defined classes, which limits its application. Class incremental learning (CIL) addresses this issue by updating the model with new classes and incrementally incorporating new knowledge. However, the challenge becomes more pronounced when there are insufficient instances of new classes. Few-shot class-incremental learning (FSCIL) is proposed to tackle the challenge. Although making the updated model similar to the old one is efficient for FSCIL, it is crucial to consider how to incorporate future new classes into the current model seamlessly. Based on this, we propose few-shot class incremental learning with precognition and retrospection for Mars HSIC (FSCILPR). In the framework, we first assign virtual prototypes and samples in the embedding space and introduce a space reservation loss in the base session. Then, we propose a knowledge aggregation module to fuse the logits from base and novel branches adaptively, which preserves base class knowledge when accommodating novel concepts. Extensive experiments and analyses on the Mars datasets verified the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Design and Control of Grid-Forming Active Power Filters
authors: Muhammad Waqas Qaisar, Jingyang Fang
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Grid-forming converters (GFMCs) have gained significant attentions for their functionality in grid voltage formation and grid-supportive services. However, managing harmonic distortions caused by nonlinear loads remains a critical challenge in weak grids. This paper presents a novel grid-forming active power filter (GFM-APF) that integrates voltage and frequency regulation with effective harmonic control. The proposed control method generates harmonic voltage commands by detecting voltage at the point of common coupling. The GFM-APF compensates harmonic voltages by creating a near short-circuit impedance path for harmonics, thereby preventing harmonic currents from propagating into the grid. In addition to improving harmonic performances, the system enhances grid stability by enhancing inertia, damping, and short-circuit capacity while suppressing wide-frequency oscillations. The proposed method avoids complex parameter tuning, ensuring simplicity and scalability. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the GFM-APF in delivering precise harmonic control, improved power quality, and enhanced grid-forming capabilities.

title: Time Series Analysis of Precipitation Trends in the Beas Basin, Northwestern Himalayas
authors: Tanuja, Rajesh Kumar, Akhilesh Gupta
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The Beas Basin is one of the major basins of the Indus River system in the northwestern Himalayas and is sustenance for millions. It is crucial in supporting regional water resources, agriculture, and biodiversity. However, this vital hydrological and ecological hotspot faces increasing challenges from the changing climate. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of precipitation patterns by integrating high-resolution gridded datasets of the India Meteorological Department (IMD), Government of India and a remote sensing dataset. The monthly and seasonal climatology analysis reveals crucial insights into precipitation variability and its spatiotemporal distribution across the basin. Advanced trend analysis techniques reveal significant long-term shifts in rainfall patterns, underscoring the growing influence of climate change on this fragile Himalayan ecosystem. Dharamshala recorded the highest long-term average rainfall (1948.90 mm), with extreme anomalies exceeding +1000 mm in the late 1980s and dipping below -750 mm in the early 2000s. Bhuntar, Manali, and Sunder-Nagar experienced significant dry periods with anomalies below -500 mm, while the late 1980s saw widespread above-average rainfall, peaking at +800 mm in Manali. In conjunction with ground-based observations, the remote sensing data enhances the spatial and temporal resolution of the analysis, offering a more comprehensive view of precipitation patterns in areas with limited ground data. Additionally, a high-resolution Digital Elevation Model (DEM) was utilized to analyze precipitation changes with elevation, helping to better understand orographic influences on rainfall distribution. These findings highlight the pressing need for adaptive strategies to address challenges in water resource management and disaster mitigation. This research lays the foundation for sustainable development and resilience in the most climate-sensitive regions by enriching our understanding of Himalayan monsoon dynamics.

title: Performance Analysis of a Five-Phase Self-Excited Synchronous Machine in a Wind Turbine
authors: Sukanya Kamboj, Arjun Vijay, Christian Trapp, Dieter Gerling
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper begins with a technical review of wind energy systems, focusing on the parameters required for design of a generator system for a wind turbine. In addition, it extends the application of a five-phase self-excited synchronous machine from traction in a plug-in hybrid electric vehicle (PHEV) to generator operation in a wind turbine. The efficiency of the system is studied with respect to the wind power curve. The advantages and disadvantages of this system are presented with supporting literature. Finally, a finite element analysis is conducted for the entire power curve and the results are discussed.

title: An Image Domain Detection Optimization Method for LEO-Based Distributed Passive Radar of Multiple Maritime Targets
authors: Aocheng Li, Yuhua Zhang, Xingye Qiu, Zhongyu Li, Junjie Wu, Jianyu Yang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium

title: Fourier-Modulated Implicit Neural Representation for Multispectral Satellite Image Compression
authors: Woojin Cho, Steve Andreas Immanuel, Junhyuk Heo, Darongsae Kwon
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Multispectral satellite images play a vital role in agriculture, fisheries, and environmental monitoring. However, their high dimensionality, large data volumes, and diverse spatial resolutions across multiple channels pose significant challenges for data compression and analysis. This paper presents ImpliSat, a unified framework specifically designed to address these challenges through efficient compression and reconstruction of multispectral satellite data. ImpliSat leverages Implicit Neural Representations (INR) to model satellite images as continuous functions over coordinate space, capturing fine spatial details across varying spatial resolutions. Furthermore, we introduce a Fourier modulation algorithm that dynamically adjusts to the spectral and spatial characteristics of each band, ensuring optimal compression while preserving critical image details.

title: Microresonator Frequency Comb Implementations in Photonic Integrated Circuits for PNT
authors: Curtis R. Menyuk, Logan Courtright, Alioune Niang, Ergun Simsek, Gary M. Carter
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: We begin by reviewing three optical technologies (the worldwide optical network, integrated photonics, and frequency combs) that are poised to revolutionize land-based positioning, navigation and timing (PNT) by greatly reducing our dependence on the global position system (GPS) and other global navigation satellite systems (GNSS). To achieve this revolution a holdover clock with sufficient resolution must be developed. We describe the required elements in a holdover clock and an architecture that was proposed by colleagues at the Army Research Laboratory (ARL) in Adelphi, MD with collaborators at the University of Maryland Baltimore County (UMBC). Microresonator frequency combs are a key element in a holdover clock. We then describe work being carried out at UMBC in collaboration with scientists at other institutions including AIM-Photonics to advance the state-of-the-art in microresonator frequency combs for PNT applications.

title: Mining in the Southern Ecuadorian Amazon: Hotspots analysis and regulatory efficiency
authors: Daniela Romero-Bermeo, Isabel Adriana Chuizaca-Espinoza, Aluizio Brito Maia, Valentina Ramírez San Miguel, Dimitri Bulatov, Petra Helmholz, Meryeme Boumahdi, Sergio Mauricio Molano Cárdenas, Dayla Carolina Rodrigues Santos, Lucas Lima Raiol, Andrés Velastegui-Montoya
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The Amazon hosts 40% of the world's rainforest, and its rivers represent 15% of the total fluvial discharge to the oceans. In Ecuador, this biome is the focus of socio-environmental conflicts due to the development of mining processes that affect Conservation Units and Indigenous Territories. This study proposes to explore the development of mining processes in the southern Ecuadorian Amazon, using land use and land cover data and spatial analysis tools to evaluate the efficiency of mining regulations and laws implemented during the last 15 years in Ecuador. The results revealed the mining projects, rivers, conservation units and indigenous territories where the most significant mining hotspots are located. The spatial analysis techniques of satellite data used in this study contribute to monitoring and tracking the progress of surface mining activities, providing a new perspective for assessing the impact of mining in areas where economic and socio-environmental interests converge.

title: K-CloudGAN: Weakly Supervised Cloud Removal towards Automated Satellite Surveillance
authors: Xiaofan Wu, Changtsun Li, Peter M. Atkinson, Ce Zhang, Plamen P. Angelov, Richard Jiang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Cloud occlusion significantly impairs the quality and usability of remote sensing imagery. This work tackles the problem in two stages: cloud segmentation and cloud removal. For segmentation, we employ transfer learning with three advanced models—U-Net, DeepLabV3+, and PSPNet—achieving approximately 90% accuracy on real-world datasets, thereby demonstrating the effectiveness of transfer learning for this task. For cloud removal, we introduce K-CloudGAN, a weakly supervised inpainting framework that integrates K-means-based pseudo-labeling with SN-PatchGAN and transfer learning. This design reduces reliance on large-scale labeled datasets while enhancing restoration quality. Compared to existing approaches like CloudGAN, our method achieves a 10% improvement in terms of SSIM and PSNR metrics, confirming its superior performance in restoring cloud-obscured satellite imagery.

title: Multiscale Correlation Regression for Joint Change Detection and Classification in SAR Time Series
authors: Matthieu Gallet, Maia de Souza Ugarte, Aluísio de Souza Pinheiro, Abdourrahmane Atto, Christophe Lin-Kwong-Chon
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: We propose a new method for supervised classification of spatio-temporal change detection maps. The proposed method is based on the Wavelet Energy Change Statistics (WECS) method, which is a non-parametric method for change detection. We adapt WECS to a multiscale context, by introducing two parameters: a neighborhood size and a local weight. This new method is called M-WECS (Multiscale-WECS). First, we evaluate M-WECS on the change detection task in Cierro Prieto, Mexico. The results demonstrate better detection than the original method. M-WECS is then applied on the Reunion Island, with the two polarimetric channels VV and VH and their ratio. We use a post-classification with K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) algorithm to classify the resulting maps, according to a ground truth obtained with optical images on a set of 5 classes. The results show that the proposed method outperforms the original WECS method, by 10% on average upon all classes.

title: Cross-Domain Hyperspectral Image Classification Based On Feature Disentanglement
authors: Yunfei Xu, Minchao Ye, Fengchao Xiong, Yuntao Qian
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Cross-domain hyperspectral image (HSI) classification algorithms utilize the information from the dataset with abundant samples (source domain, SD) to enhance the classification accuracy of the dataset with only a few samples (target domain, TD). This paper proposes a feature disentanglement and adaptation network (FDANet) for cross-domain HSI classification. A cross-domain mask mechanism (CDMM) is proposed to disentangle the domain-invariant features and domain-specific features from the original features. For the domain-invariant features, we design an attention-based cross-domain fusion (ACDF) module to obtain a hybrid representation. Moreover, a prediction consistency constraint (PCC) is introduced to ensure that the domain-invariant features have shared and discriminative information. Experiments on three real-world heterogeneous cross-domain HSI datasets show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Extraction of Tree Diameter at Breast Height Using UAV-based Point Cloud Data
authors: Yaokun Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Accurate measurement of diameter at breast height (DBH) is one of the crucial tasks for estimating the biomass of individual trees. This paper proposes a method for extracting tree DBH based on Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV)-based point cloud data. This method is characterized by its simplicity, speed, and accuracy, enabling the rapid extraction of tree DBH in a given scene. The point cloud data are acquired through the Structure from Motion (SfM) algorithm. To mitigate the influence of outliers within the DBH range of the trunk, statistical filtering is employed to preprocess the point cloud data and eliminate outliers. To address the impact of ground points on DBH data extraction, the Random Sample Consensus (RANSAC) algorithm is utilized for ground fitting. To alleviate the effect of missing point cloud data at the DBH due to canopy obstruction, point cloud data at a height of 1.2 - 1.4 meters above the ground are extracted as the DBH range and projected onto a two-dimensional plane. Subsequently, clustering is performed to fit circles for each category, thereby determining the DBH. When applied to UAV-based point cloud data, this method yields promising results.

title: RS-Ship-VLD: Remote Sensing Ship Vision Language Dataset
authors: Tingyu Zhang, Haitao Lang, Ke Ma
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Advancing research in ship detection and analysis within the remote sensing domain requires comprehensive datasets that integrate diverse modalities and rich annotations. In this study, we present RS-Ship-VLD, a multi-source remote sensing ship dataset comprising approximately 20,000 Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) and optical images, capturing ship imagery across various environments and conditions. Enhancing the semantic richness of the dataset, we include 8,000 high-quality descriptive captions generated through a combination of manual and automated methods. Each image is accompanied by detailed descriptions, encompassing scene contexts such as riverside, port, and dock, and object-specific information including color, shape, quantity, absolute position, and ship movement status. This multimodal dataset addresses existing gaps in remote sensing resources concerning data scale, annotation depth, and diversity, thereby providing researchers with a robust tool for developing and evaluating tasks such as ship detection, recognition, and visual question answering in remote sensing imagery. The dataset is expected to promote the advancement of deep learning and visual language models(VLMs) in the field of remote sensing, accelerating the development of intelligent analysis techniques for remote sensing data. Our code and dataset are available at https://github.com/epiphanydeer/RS-Ship-VLD.

title: SAR-Based Subsurface Tomography: An Iron Mine Case Study
authors: Daiane Münch, Luiz Antonio Pereira Silva, Bruna Cordeiro, João Roberto Moreira Neto, Fernando Marinho, Gian Carlos Oré Huacles, Rosa Elvira Correa Pabón
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Accurate subsurface geological models are crucial for a productive mining industry. However, despite mapping efforts, lithological uncertainties still impact mineral processing. The advancement of drone-based remote sensing technologies has enabled the mapping of specific areas at a reduced cost. This study aimed to perform subsurface tomography using a drone-mounted radar system equipped with a P-band antenna. A case study has been performed on an iron ore mine in Brazil. The tomography was used to discriminate waste rock from iron ore. The material permittivity values were included in SAR processing to increase the tomography accuracy. Results showed a reflectivity intensity and depth correlation aligned with the expected distribution of ore bodies, correlating higher reflectivity regions with waste rock. Furthermore, a direct relationship between reflectivity and chemical content is revealed. These findings highlight the potential of the P-band radar system to improve the quality and detail of subsurface models, specifically to discriminate waste rock from iron ore. This approach can significantly help companies enhance operational efficiency and reduce costs.

title: Evaluating FeFET and Memristor Performance in Time-Domain Computing Applications
authors: Jacob O'Donnell, Elaine Greenfield, Hagar Hendy, Karsten Bergthold, Cory Merkel, Tejasvi Das
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: This work evaluates the performance of ferroelectric field-effect transistors (FeFETs) and memristors as nonvolatile memory (NVM) elements for time-domain (TD) neuromorphic computing. Key metrics considered include energy per operation, throughput, mismatch sensitivity (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sigma / \mu$</tex>), and cell area. We use our high-efficiency TD computing cell as the platform for this analysis. Simulations indicate that FeFET-based implementations achieve operating frequencies exceeding 30 MHz while occupying only 33% of the area of an equivalent memristor-based circuit, though with higher energy consumption. The three-terminal nature of the FeFET also offers performance advantages that two-terminal memristor-based implementations can only replicate through more complex cell architectures. These performance benefits, along with their compatibility with existing CMOS processes, position FeFETs as a strong candidate for neuromorphic TD computing applications.

title: A Vision-Language Framework for Multispectral Scene Representation Using Language-Grounded Features
authors: Enes Karanfil, Nevrez Imamoglu, Aykut Erdem, Erkut Erdem
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Scene understanding in remote sensing often faces challenges in generating accurate representations for complex environments such as various land use areas or coastal regions, which may also include snow, clouds or haze. To address this, we present a vision-language framework named Spectral-LLaVA, which integrates multispectral data with vision-language alignment techniques to enhance scene representation and description. Using the BigEarthNet-v2 dataset from Sentinel-2, we establish a baseline with RGB-based scene descriptions and further demonstrate substantial improvements through the incorporation of multispectral information. Our framework optimizes a lightweight linear projection layer for alignment while keeping the vision backbone of SpectralGPT frozen. Our experiments encompass (1) scene classification using linear probing, and (2) language modeling for jointly performing scene classification and description generation. Our results highlight Spectral-LLaVA’s ability to produce detailed and accurate descriptions, particularly for scenarios where RGB data alone proves inadequate, while also enhancing classification performance by refining SpectralGPT features into semantically meaningful representations. The code and dataset for this project are available here.

title: Recommendations for Life Cycle Inventory of Magnetic Components in Power Electronic
authors: Suzanne Guillou, Elise Chaumat, Florentin Salomez, Yves Lembeye, Lucas Riondet, Charley Lanneluc, Laura Vauche, Jean-Christophe Crebier
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The widespread and growing use of Power Electronic (PE) systems has made it essential to assess and minimize the environmental impacts of these systems. Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) is a recognized methodology to determine the environmental impacts (EI) of a product, enabling to target their reduction through eco-design. However, when carrying out LCA, PE designers must contend with the complexity and time-intensive nature of data collection (Life Cycle Inventory or LCI), the lack of reliable aggregated LCA data representative of their systems, and the challenge of translating LCA results into actionable decisions. This article will showcase current LCA databases shortcomings in supporting eco-design initiatives in PE, focusing on inductors - significant contributors to the EI of PE systems. These claims will be supported by an experimental analysis of commercially available inductors. These findings will highlight the need for a parametric Life Cycle Inventory (LCI) model for Inductors, to estimate their unknown material breakdown from known electrical parameters, enabling more meaningful LCA for eco-design.

title: Addressing the consistency of Geometric Error Model of Terrestrial Laser Scanners (TLS) across Different Devices
authors: Mansoor Sabzali, Lloyd Pilgrim
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The consistent approach for calibration of terrestrial laser scanners (TLS) is always the main issue to validate the observations which are obtained from different scanners. One of the important criteria to consider in designing the calibration network for TLS is the precise estimation of the parameters which rely on less correlated or decorrelated parameters. Enhancing both criteria – precision and correlation - lead to the highly accurate observations (e.g., 3D point cloud). From the practical perspective, having high quality measurements assists in better distinction between geometric movement of objects and the uncertainty of TLS observations, especially for investigation of structural health in monitoring tasks. In this work, the developed stepwise algorithm for TLS self-calibration method was proposed with the core emphasis on minimum correlation and maximum precision of the quantities (i.e., parameters including exterior orientation parameters, calibration parameters (entire 18 parameters) and object points of the bundle block adjustment). The novel consideration of the work resulted in the least uncertainty for the observations and, importantly, consistent standardizations for TLS geometric error models. Additionally, compared to the former investigations, the advised error modellings were verified on various manufactured TLS systems - Leica ScanStation P50, Maptek I-sites 8820 (an Australian product) and Leica RTC360 – taking into account the highly redundant observations throughout the data collection steps.

title: Comparing Sentinel-5p NO2 Products with Ground-Based Measurement Across Europe
authors: Antonio Mazza, Tony Christian Landi, Stefano Decesari, Gemine Vivone
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Air quality monitoring is essential to mitigate the presence of pollutants that adversely affect human health. Nitrogen dioxide (NO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>), a significant pollutant primarily produced by anthropogenic sources, is typically monitored using ground-based stations that provide accurate but spatially limited measurements. Recently, the Sentinel-5P satellite was launched to monitor various atmospheric pollutants, including NO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>, on a global scale. However, the satellite provides columnar measurements, which account for atmospheric contributions, rather than ground-level concentrations. This study aims to perform a comprehensive analysis to identify the similarities and differences between these two measurement approaches, evaluating the degree of correlation across three distinct scenarios: rural, suburban, and urban areas in Europe.

title: Assessment of PV Placement Strategies to Reduce Losses in Distribution Networks under High EV Charging Station Penetration
authors: Yanuar Muhammad Iqbal, Roni Irnawan, Yohan Fajar Sidik
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: The increasing adoption of electric vehicles (EVs) in Indonesia has driven the rapid expansion of electric vehicle charging stations (EVCS) in medium voltage distribution networks. While aligned with national decarbonization goals, this trend introduces technical challenges, particularly increased power losses, raising concerns for PT PLN (Persero) as the national electricity provider. To address these issues, this study evaluates $\mathbf{P V}$ placement strategies to mitigate the impact of $\mathbf{E V}$ charging station penetration, which introduces significant loads to distribution networks. A 20 kV urban feeder in Makassar is modeled using real field data, and various PV configurations are assessed through load flow simulations to examine their impact on network performance. The results show that certain configurations provide better performance in terms of power loss reduction while maintaining acceptable voltage profiles. The most feasible scenario achieves a $\mathbf{2 2. 5 \%}$ loss reduction. In some cases, adding more PV leads to infeasibility due to reverse power flow at weak load buses. These findings highlight that proper PV placement is more critical than simply increasing capacity. This research underscores the importance of strategic PV planning and offers practical insights for utilities in integrating renewable energy and EVCS expansion into urban power networks.

title: Fine-Tuning-Based Zero-Shot Pansharpening with Residual Double Attention Network
authors: Rika Sustika, Andriyan B. Suksmono, Donny Danudirdjo, Ketut Wikantika
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In deep learning-based pansharpening, the best-fused images were obtained from the network trained using extensive training data, and the testing images came from the same sensor as the training images. However, in some cases, a large amount of training images from the same sensor as the testing images were hard to get. To overcome this problem, this research presents a fine-tuning-based zero-shot pansharpening with a residual double attention network (RDAN) to improve the spatial resolution of a single scene of the testing image. In the experiment, an RDAN network was pre-trained by zero-shot learning using four large Spot-7 images. At test time, we fine-tuned the parameters of the pre-trained model and iteratively updated them using a single scene of the testing image from the Pleiades satellite. The experimental results demonstrated that the proposed method was better than zero-shot pansharpening with the same number of epochs, and it was also better than using transfer learning without fine-tuning.

title: The Fire Detection Capabilities of Meteosat Third Generation: A Comparison with Meteosat Second Generation Using Early Operational Data
authors: Valerio Pampanoni, Giovanni Laneve, Simone Saquella, Alvise Ferrari
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This study performs a preliminary investigation of the capabilities of the Meteosat Third Generation (MTG) Flexible Combined Imager (FCI) for the detection of thermal anomalies, with a particular focus on the increase in performance compared to its predecessor Meteosat Second Generation (MSG) Spinning Enhanced Visible and Infrared Imager (SEVIRI). For this purpose, we used an updated version of the Satellite Fire Detection (SFIDE) algorithm to detect hotspots from FCI and SEVIRI imagery, while using thermal anomalies obtained from NASA's Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) in Italy as a ground truth. Despite the limitations related to using non-concurrent acquisitions of another satellite as a ground truth and the limited spatial and temporal extension of this preliminary analysis, the results show a significant leap forward in terms of detection sensibility offered by MTG with respect to MSG: while MSG matched only 7% of the thermal anomalies in the MODIS database, MTG matched 34%. This finding highlights the potential of MTG-FCI for operational detection and monitoring of wildfires, volcanic activity, industrial emissions and other applications requiring accurate and timely information on surface temperature variations. Despite the promising results, a validation conducted on a hand-curated thermal anomaly dataset is needed to perform a proper classification accuracy assessment of MTG.

title: Electrode Channel Multiplexing Optimization in Very Large-Scale Microelectrode Arrays
authors: Hanfeng Cai, Jianxiong Xu, Junyu Ma, Qiaosong Deng, Hao You, Mustafa Kanchwala, Amirali Amirsoleimani, Roman Genov
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: High-density implantable integrated neural interfaces are at the forefront of treating neural disorders, offering potential for medical advancements. Effective neural recording relies heavily on the noise performance and spatial coverage of the neural interface. The noise performance determines the recording accuracy, while spatial coverage dictates the number of simultaneous recording sites. Typically, increasing spatial coverage and reducing noise presents a trade-off. This paper explores the balance between spatial resolution and noise performance in two types of neural implants: central nervous system (CNS) and peripheral nervous system (PNS) applications. CNS recordings require high spatial resolution to accurately capture neuronal activity, while PNS recordings prioritize low noise levels due to the micro-volt range of neural signals. Despite significant advancements in high-density neural interfaces, current technology still falls short of the spatial density required for neuroscience research. This paper presents a comprehensive strategy for optimizing multiplexed channel structures by addressing factors such as area, signal-to-noise ratio, bandwidth, and noise limitations. Optimizing the number of electrodes per channel can enhance the performance of neural recording systems. This paper analyzes the design trade-offs and provides insights into the number of electrodes per channel for neural interfaces.

title: A Customized Neural Network Model for Detecting Foreign Object Debris in UAS-borne SAR Images
authors: Jingfeng Shan, Lapo Miccinesi, Alessandra Beni, Luca Bigazzi, Massimiliano Pieraccini
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Foreign object debris (FOD) can cause serious accidents and economic loss. Synthetic aperture radar (SAR) aboard unmanned aerial systems (UAS) provides high-resolution images independent of light and weather conditions, making it ideal for automated FOD detection. In this paper, a novel enhanced FOD detection model is proposed, based on the popular You Only Look Once (YOLO). Since FODs are small objects with few pixels, an additional head is inserted into YOLOv8 to specifically enhance small-object feature extraction. Moreover, slice-assisted hyper-inference (SAHI) is employed during the prediction stage to refine detection at multiple scales and reduce missed detections. The model was trained using real experimental data obtained from UAS-borne SAR, and tested on unseen images. The results demonstrate that the proposed model can effectively and efficiently detect FOD with a detection rate of 83.3%.

title: Pseudo-Warming Experiment of Heavy Rainfall in Arid Regions : A Case Study of Iran
authors: Y. Yoshino, R. Nakamura, S. Mahya Hoseini, S. Matsunaga, M. Soltanpour
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This study explores the impact of global warming on short-term heavy rainfall in arid regions using the Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model and pseudo-global warming (PGW) methodology. Six flood-inducing heavy rainfall events in Iran (2015–2024) were analyzed Model performance was evaluated using observational data and Climate Prediction Center (CPC) products, with the Critical Success Index (CSI) reaching 0.60, and Kling-Gupta Efficiency (KGE) and RMSE values of 0.33 and 1.52 mm, respectively. PGW simulations showed no significant change in total precipitation but revealed increased concentration in regions with pre-warming rainfall of 30–50 mm and 50–100 mm, with mean increases of 14.5% and 28.5%. Water vapor pressure increased by an average of 7.97% per 1 K surface temperature rise, aligning with Clausius–Clapeyron scaling. However, as precipitation is influenced by multiple factors, further research is needed to fully elucidate its response to warming.

title: Budyko Framework to Assess Long-Term Hydrological Responses to Climate Variability in the Ganges Basin
authors: Ashwani Raju, Ramesh P Singh
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The Gravity Recovery and Climate Experiment (GRACE) satellite has observed depleting groundwater storage (GWS) at many places around the world. However, detailed estimation of GWS remains challenging due to the limited availability of critical hydroclimatic variables, especially Potential Evapotranspiration (PET). This study uses hydroclimatic variables such as PET, Evapotranspiration (ET), Precipitation (P), and Groundwater Storage (GWS) data to quantify the long-term P and PET response over climate variability in the Ganges Basin (GB) watersheds using the Budyko framework. Budyko Curve signifies that any change in precipitation and evapotranspiration leads to a shift in the curve, which is indicative of prevailing environmental conditions. Results indicated that the climate change in the GB directly correlates to precipitation, decreased ET, and PET stress in the system (the difference between ET and PET), suggesting that a continuous increase in ET facilitates a reduction in water storage under a warming condition. The agreements between the hydroclimatic variables (ET, P, and PET) indicate a future water balance shift with P and ET uncertainty.

title: Delineating Abandoned Coastal Aquaculture Ponds in Cauvery delta using Time Series Sentinel data
authors: S. Ravi Prasanth, Senthamizh T.K., Kumar Arun Prasad, Sulochana Shekhar
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The conversion of vital ecosystems and lands previously designated for other purposes into aquaculture, followed by their subsequent abandonment after short-term utilization, poses a significant threat to the sustainability of coastal resources. Insights into the abandoned aquaculture ponds and their characteristics remain underexplored but are very crucial in the sustainable aquaculture management. The delineation of abandoned aquaculture ponds has been explored in this study based on pixel based NDWI water frequency, and edge detection techniques in the Cauvery delta of Tamil Nadu using Sentinel time series data. The mean pixel value of aquaculture ponds have been calculated using NDWI water frequency and then classified into operational, semi-operational and non-operational ponds. The pixel-based time series analysis has been used to study the presence and temporal variations of water on the aquaculture ponds. Further, the edge detection techniques were utilized to delineate the abandoned ponds based on their edges and boundaries, since the abandoned ponds have disintegrated boundary due to lack of maintenance. Based on that, the abandoned ponds in the villages of the Cauvery delta districts were delineated and results show that abandoned ponds are prevailing more in the villages of Cuddalore and Mayiladuthurai districts. Understanding the spatial distribution of the coastal abandoned aquaculture ponds will play a vital role in the Sustainable development of the coastal regions.

title: CFAR Vessel Detection in PRISMA Hyperspectral Images
authors: Salvatore Maresca, Stefania Matteoli
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In this work a processing strategy is proposed for detecting vessels in PRISMA hyperspectral images based on the constant false alarm rate (CFAR) criterion. The detection statistics is derived from the reciprocal of the pixel data density in the NIR-SWIR spectral range. CFAR detection is then performed for each pixel by a suitable evaluation of the detection threshold based on local background statistics. Finally, the density-based spatial clustering of applications with noise (DBSCAN) algorithm is applied to cluster connected detections into objects.The proposed strategy is applied to PRISMA images acquired over the Venice lagoon, where performance is assessed using vessel navigation messages from the automatic identification system (AIS) as ground-truth information. Experimental results demonstrate the potential of PRISMA mission in the context of maritime surveillance and contribute to increase PRISMA data exploitation possibilities. Future development directions are provided as well.

title: AggFormer: Coarse-to-Fine UAV Image Matching Based on Aggregated Attention
authors: Li Ren, Rui Zhong, Haitao Jia, Shuya Yang, Shiyi Xu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Autonomous drone navigation systems heavily rely on the precision of image correspondence driven by computer vision techniques. Existing algorithms persistently suffer from inherent limitations in inference speed and matching robustness, particularly when processing highly dynamic aerial imagery. While linearized Transformer models have demonstrated potential for accelerating feature matching processes, they struggle to capture multi-scale local pixel interactions, hindering accurate correspondence estimation.To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes AggFormer, a novel framework dedicated to efficient semi-dense correspondence generation. Unlike prior methods that uniformly deploy Transformers over entire feature maps (inducing computational overhead ), AggFormer leverages hierarchical attention with content-aware token selection, substantially optimizing computational resource allocation. Furthermore, a dual-stage correlation layer with integrated subpixel refinement ensures precise correspondences under spatial displacement variations. Extensive experiments validate that AggFormer achieves state-of-the-art matching performance and inference speed compared to existing approaches, establishing its practical value for real-world drone navigation systems.

title: Opportunities for Photonic Integrated Circuits in Microwave and Millimeter Wave Applications
authors: Thomas R. Clark, Trisha Bora
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: This paper surveys the state of integrated microwave photonic circuits for application to wideband microwave and millimeter wave applications. We discuss current photonic integrated circuit technology and explore techniques for photonic signal processing and photonic signal conditioning for future microwave and millimeter wave systems.

title: Application of Zero Overvoltage Switching in Switched Mode Power Supplies
authors: Moritz Kerscher, Nico Schmied, Stefan Matlok, Bernd Eckardt, Martin März
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: With the increasing adoption of wide bandgap (WBG) semiconductor devices, new methods are required to manage their faster switching characteristics, particularly addressing voltage overshoots caused by fast switching. Zero Overvoltage Switching (ZOS) leverages circuit resonances during the turnoff process to nearly eliminate voltage overshoot, making fast switching essential and reducing switching losses to a minimum. This paper explores two methodologies for a novel ZOS current control in DC/DC converters: Variable Frequency Forced Continuous Conduction Mode (VF-FCCM), while efficient under specific conditions, suffers from turn-off overvoltages and significant AC losses due to high current ripple, making it unsuitable for low-load operations. In contrast, Valley Switching Discontinuous Conduction Mode (VS-DCM) mitigates overvoltage spikes and switching losses, maintaining a consistent ripple but struggles with low-load scenarios due to frequency limitations. Both methodologies were simulated and tested on a lightweight aircraft DC/DC prototype. The findings suggest VS-DCM as a promising candidate for future development.

title: Utilizing Quantum Annealing to Address Vehicle Routing Challenges in Cold Chain Logistics
authors: Elle, Wing Ho, Chow, George, To Sum, Ho, Valerie Tang, Manviel, Man Fei, Tam
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 9th International Conference on Intelligent Systems, Metaheuristics & Swarm Intelligence
abstract: None

title: Accelerating Distributed Systems by In-Network Computing
authors: Wenfei Wu
publish: Proceedings of the ACM CoNEXT Workshop on In-Network Computing and AI for Distributed Systems
abstract: In-Network Computing (INC) can accelerate distributed systems. We present our efforts in studying the methods to design INC protocols for specific applications, manage INC jobs in shared clusters, and adapt diverse INC applications to heterogeneous environments.

title: The Three Faces of Networking
authors: Ang Chen
publish: Proceedings of the 21st International Conference on emerging Networking EXperiments and Technologies
abstract: What does a network connect: people? machines? infrastructures? All three are true, but one tends to dominate at any given time in response to societal needs. Telephony networks interconnected people, but the Internet recast communication as connecting machines. This was a subtle yet profound change---machines have different failures, misbehaviors, and performance goals, which translated into the network design and still define much of our problem space today. As of late, however, another quiet shift has been playing out which demands a rethinking of networks. Societal infrastructures, such as power grids, water systems, and datacenters, are increasingly interdependent, but historically they were not designed for coordinated operation. Networking at the ''infrastructure nexus'' is becoming a pressing need, bringing with it a fresh source of research problems.

title: Poster: Cluster-Aware Federated Caching in Non-IID Environment
authors: Shinyoung Cho, Junho Jeong, Jaeseong Park, SuKyoung Lee
publish: Proceedings of the 21st International Conference on emerging Networking EXperiments and Technologies
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) has been applied to edge caching, but its performance often degrades under non-IID user request patterns. Therefore, we propose a cluster-aware caching algorithm where the caching space of the edge server is dynamically allocated to each cluster of similar user devices, while highly requested content from all clusters is stored in a shared cache to maximize the hit ratio of edge devices in strongly non-IID scenarios.

title: Harmonics: Scalable Collective Scheduling in Multi-Tenant GPU Clusters
authors: Hossein Shafieirad, Amir Shani, Manaf Bin-Yahya, Seyed Hossein Mortazavi, Geng Li, Xinle Du, Tao Su, Wei Wang, Jingbin Zhou, Majid Ghaderi
publish: Proceedings of the ACM on Networking
abstract: Distributed machine learning (DML), such as large language model (LLM) training, has become one of the most critical services in multi-tenant cloud computing. However, communication contention among concurrent DML jobs significantly degrades overall GPU utilization, leading to inefficient training cluster performance. Existing approaches either achieve high performance at the cost of long scheduling runtime or reduce scheduling time at the expense of poor performance. We present Harmonics, a novel two-tier scheduling framework that strikes a balance between scheduling latency and performance. It coordinates decisions between Local Schedulers and a lightweight Global Coordinator to enable scalable and adaptive scheduling. By combining rack-level epoch-based optimization with global coordination, Harmonics alleviates communication contention and improves resource efficiency. We implement and evaluate Harmonics on real distributed ML workloads running on a GPU testbed. Compared to state-of-the-art methods such as fair sharing, optimal scheduling, Crux, and Cassini, Harmonics reduces training time by up to 33% and communication time by up to 48%. Large-scale simulations show that it reduces scheduling time by up to 91× while improving training time by 26% in large-cluster settings.

title: BCT: Modeling Block Completion Time for Transport Protocols
authors: Gang Yi, Lei Zhang, Chuan Ma, Yong Cui
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACM 33rd International Symposium on Quality of Service (IWQoS)
abstract: Many applications based on block transmission have strict latency requirements. Existing solutions to reduce latency primarily focus on enhancing packet loss resistance through redundancy and scheduling transmission orders. However, the performance of these algorithms depends on accurate block transmission time estimation. Current evaluation methods, which do not account for the impacts of complex network protocols and packet loss, result in significant estimation errors.In this paper, we propose Block Completion Time (BCT) as a transmission delay index for block-based applications. We develop a BCT distribution model that incorporates packet-level block transmission under complex protocols and apply it to predict BCT for typical TCP and QUIC protocols. As a use case, we demonstrate how our model can assist in optimizing redundancy configurations. The model is evaluated under varying network conditions, application types, and transport protocols, showing improved accuracy in predicting both the mean and distribution of BCT compared to baseline methods.

title: Hierarchical-ISA Supporting Row-wise Operands for Efficient DNN Computation
authors: Zhiwang Huo, Wenzhe Zhao, Qiwei Dang, Chengyu Ma, Guoming Yang, Gelin Fu, Tian Xia, Pengju Ren
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) have become a cornerstone in advancing artificial intelligence, but their complexity often leads to inefficient hardware utilization due to varying structure characteristics and excessive memory accesses. Domain-specific architectures (DSAs) offer a solution by optimizing data locality through data stationary, tiling, and layer fusion, which minimize memory access and energy consumption while boosting performance. However, current approaches lack flexibility for efficient memory management at the appropriate granularity, causing misaligned accesses and decreasing reuse potential for variable-sized tiles. To this end, we propose a hierarchical Instruction Set Architecture (hierarchical-ISA) combining a RISC-V ISA and a flexible CISC-style macro-ISA (mISA). Unlike byte-level RISC-V, mISA employs row-wise tiles as the fundamental operand, enabling efficient data reuse across adjacent iterations as well as residual connections. This mISA approach simplifies DNN programming, enhances data partitioning and manipulation efficiency, and enables a hardware-software co-designed Remapping mechanism that facilitates data reuse without physical data movement. Experiments show 31.8%–72.0% reductions in off-chip memory access across MobileNet, ResNet, Swin Transformer, MobileViT, along with speedups of 2.9× to 7.4× compared to previous DNN accelerators. We also conduct comparisons under the roofline model with NVIDIA RTX A6000 and Intel Core i7-10700K. The results show that our arithmetic intensity reaches up to 26.0× that of i7-10700K and 22.6× that of A6000.

title:
Operation of AlGaN channel HEMTs at 850°C with ON/OFF ratio >10
                    <sup>4</sup>
authors: James Spencer Lundh, Brianna A. Klein, Andrew A. Allerman, Andrew J. Cantrell, Alfred Zhao, Daniel J. Pennachio, GlenAsia Gonzalez, Eric Cruz, Tolen M. Nelson, Geoffrey M. Foster, Alan G. Jacobs, Andrew D. Koehler, Marko J. Tadjer, Giovanni Esteves, Troy Olsson, Andrew M. Armstrong, Karl D. Hobart, Michael A. Mastro
abstract: We report 850 °C operation of ultrawide bandgap (UWBG) Al-rich Al<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0.68</sub>Ga<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0.32</sub>N channel high electron mobility transistors (HEMTs) at atmospheric pressure in nitrogen ambient. Temperature dependent DC electrical characteristics were measured in situ up to 850 °C, after exposure to 850 °C for 60 minutes, and at 25 °C after high temperature testing. At 850 °C (time, t = 0 min), all HEMTs tested maintained an on/off ratio greater than 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sup> (maximum of 4.6×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sup>). The threshold voltage demonstrated excellent stability with less than ±10% deviation. After returning to 25 °C, the devices showed negligible degradation. In fact, the off-state gate current decreased and on/off ratio slightly increased. The robustness of these UWBG AlGaN transistors at temperatures up to 850 °C demonstrates their viability for extreme environment applications.

title: Optimal Stochastic Containment Control of Discrete-Time Multiagent Systems With Process Disturbances
authors: Junhao Ren, Jing Lai, Xiaofeng Zong, Shuping He, Gaoxi Xiao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: This article explores the optimal containment control of discrete-time multiagent systems (MASs) with the digraph and unknown dynamics under process disturbances. We first demonstrate, through a model transformation, that the mean square bounded containment of MASs can be achieved by guaranteeing the mean square boundedness of the containment error systems. Hence, we can transform the optimal stochastic containment control problem of MASs into a stochastic optimal control problem for containment error systems. Subsequently, utilizing the Bellman optimality principle and the stochastic Lyapunov equation (SLE), we design a model-based policy iteration (PI) algorithm for the optimal stochastic containment control of MASs. This model-based algorithm, by minimizing the cost function in linear quadratic form, enables MASs to achieve mean square bounded containment with the least possible energy input. To circumvent the dependency on the model information, we introduce an online model-free algorithm for the stochastic optimal control problem. The model-free algorithm is developed based on the Q-learning algorithm. Specifically, it uses a historical MAS trajectory to estimate the kernel matrix H of the Q function, enabling the resolution of the optimal stochastic containment control problem without model information. To realize the model-free algorithm, the LSTD estimator with bounded bias is employed in the policy evaluation step. We prove the equivalence between the model-free algorithm and the model-based algorithm. Finally, a numerical case is presented to demonstrate the efficacy of the proposed algorithms in achieving the optimal stochastic containment control of MASs.

title: Neurofeedback System Over Frontal Alpha Asymmetry Modulates Fairness-Related Social Decision-Making
authors: Lu Shen, Ze Wang, Fali Li, Linling Li, Zhiguo Zhang, Peng Xu, Zhiying Zhao, Wenya Nan, Feng Wan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: Effective regulation of social decision-making is crucial for achieving equitable outcomes in human interactions. This study explores the impact of endogenous regulation on social decision-making and associated neural changes through a neurofeedback (NF) training framework. Given the relationship between social decision making, emotions, and frontal alpha asymmetry (FAA), this NF training enables individuals to self-regulate their FAA, thereby influencing their decision-making behavior. Eighty-one participants were randomly divided into the up-FAA group aiming at up-regulating FAA, the down-FAA group aiming at down-regulating FAA, and the sham-NF group. First, our results validated the specific NF training effect on selfregulating FAA. Notably, not all participants in the up-FAA and down-FAA groups successfully learned to regulate their FAA, leading to further subdivision into up-learner, down-learner, up-nonlearner, and down-nonlearner categories based on learning efficacy. Participants who effectively learned to reduce their FAA (down-learners) showed significant changes in decision behavior under moderately unfair conditions, characterized by increased rejection rates during the ultimatum game (UG) task. They also exhibited larger N200 amplitudes while balancing the decisionmaking period. In contrast, up learners demonstrated minimal behavioral changes despite increases in FAA. We conclude that decreases in FAA have a more pronounced impact on social decision-making than increases during NF training. This study highlights the effects of FAA self-regulation on fairness-related decision-making, revealing the neurobiological factors that shape decisions influenced by fairness perceptions. These findings offer valuable insights for enhancing social cooperation and justice.

title: Analyzing the Impact of Inclined Airflow Within the EFEM on the Lateral Flow Around the FOUP Using Flow Visualization Techniques
authors: Shih-Cheng Hu, Tee Lin, Omid Ali Zargar, Yi-Chang Lin, Yang-Cheng Shih, Graham Leggett
abstract: With rapid advancements in technology, Taiwan has become a global leader in semiconductor manufacturing. Over the past decade, process technologies have continually advanced, reaching the latest 1.2 nm node. However, as feature sizes shrink, the complexity of processes increases, leading to more stringent requirements for the stability of the manufacturing environment. Cleanroom environments have become increasingly critical in semiconductor manufacturing, significantly impacting production capacity and yield. In the equipment front-end module (EFEM), we observed that when the front opening unified pod (FOUP) door is opened, internal pressure differentials can cause air ingress into the microenvironment. This ingested air may carry moisture and oxygen, which, upon entering the FOUP, can damage the wafers, leading to decreased yield. In real-world scenarios, we found that despite the use of laminar air curtain devices, wafer box yields remained unstable due to the influence of inclined airflow. To simulate this situation, our experiment utilized flow field visualization to observe the effects of different air curtain flow rates (0.3 m/s,0.4 m/s and 0.5 m/s) and environmental wind speeds (0.3 m/s and 0.5 m/s) on inclined airflows (7∘, 15∘, and 30∘) when the FOUP door is opened. While flow field visualization provided clear images of airflow directions, it could not determine whether the ingested air contained contaminants harmful to the wafers. Therefore, we supplemented our experiment with relative humidity monitoring data to identify whether the ingested air originated from the external environment or the air curtain device itself, providing effective recommendations based on the findings.

title: LOSDR: Lightweight Open-Set Drone Recognition via RF Semantics Alignment
authors: Rui Guo, Sijia Yan, Jiang Wang
abstract: The popularization of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) has raised critical concerns about public security and personal privacy, necessitating drone recognition technology. Radio frequency-based monitoring methods are widely used because of their advantage of non-line-of-sight. However, most existing radio frequency-based recognition methods have closed-set assumption vulnerabilities. Although several open-set methods have been proposed, they still face robustness deficiencies when video transmission signal attenuation conditions are severe or when interference signals are present. To address this challenge, we propose a lightweight open-set drone recognition (LOSDR) method. First, IQ data are transformed into time-frequency spectra via a short-time Fourier transform. Second, regional block details and global frequency-hopping patterns are jointly extracted via a flight control signal block extractor and pattern extractors. Then, a semantic alignment module, which integrates text embeddings derived from the contrastive language-image pretraining model, and a class decorrelation module with orthogonal constraints are designed to increase the degree of interclass separation and reduce the ambiguity of classification. Additionally, an adaptive dynamic entropy threshold mechanism is used to balance known/unknown decisions under varying noise and interference levels. We construct datasets for three different electromagnetic environments. Extensive experiments conducted on these datasets demonstrate that LOSDR outperforms the state-of-the-art methods in terms of generalizability and accuracy.

title: Practical Predefined-Time Synchronization for Complex Networks With Time-Varying Coupling via Intermittent Dynamic Event-Triggered Control
authors: Jiong Yu, Lei Xue, Jian Liu, Yongbao Wu, Changyin Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Signal and Information Processing over Networks
abstract: This paper proposes an aperiodically intermittent dynamic event-triggered control (AIDE-TC) to investigate the practical predefined-time synchronization (PTS) for complex networks (CNs) with time-varying coupling. Notably, the proposed AIDE-TC strategy is based on the average control rate, which makes the theoretical conditions more applicable to practical scenarios. In contrast to fixed-time synchronization, we design a time-varying function to ensure that all states of CNs converge to a common adjustable region within a user-defined time. Moreover, unlike the existing literature that considers bounded time-varying coupling weights, this paper employs average time-varying coupling weights to relax the requirements for the coupling weights. More importantly, a new auxiliary function is designed to overcome the difficulties caused by intermittent control in practical PTS. By constructing a Lyapunov function with the auxiliary function, we derive the practical PTS criterion for CNs with time-varying coupling. Meanwhile, the Zeno phenomenon is excluded when the coupling weights have an upper bound. Finally, we present a numerical simulation applied to an islanded microgrid system to verify the effectiveness of the obtained results.

title: A Comprehensive Review on Control Barrier Functions: Uncertainty Handling, Design Optimization, and Feasibility Analysis
authors: Shanshan Zhao, Zheng Yan, Tingwen Huang, Shiping Wen
abstract: Control barrier functions (CBFs) provide a rigorous framework for enforcing safety in control-affine systems by ensuring system states remain within predefined safe sets. However, practical deployment faces fundamental challenges that limit real-world applicability. This review analyzes recent progress in CBF methodologies across three interconnected domains: uncertainty handling, structural optimization, and feasibility assurance. For uncertainty, we distinguish strategies tailored to unknown dynamics, modeling discrepancies, and dynamic environments, spanning robust theoretical methods and learning-based approaches. For structural design, we examine class-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathcal {K}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> function selection, parameter tuning, and advanced modifications that jointly address conservatism and feasibility. For feasibility, we identify the root causes of CBF-QP infeasibility and survey solution strategies, including constraint relaxation, structural redesign, and mathematical guarantees. By synthesizing these directions into a unified framework, this review highlights key interdependencies and outlines future research opportunities for advancing CBF-based safety-critical control in robotics, autonomous systems, and beyond.

title: Strategic Concealment of Environment Representations in Competitive Games
authors: Yue Guan, Dipankar Maity, Panagiotis Tsiotras
abstract: This letter studies the strategic concealment of environment representations used by players in competitive games. We consider a defense scenario in which one player (the Defender) seeks to infer and exploit the representation used by the other player (the Attacker). The interaction between the two players is modeled as a Bayesian game: the Defender infers the Attacker’s representation from its trajectory and places barriers to counteract, while the Attacker obfuscates its representation type to mislead the Defender. We solve for the Perfect Bayesian Equilibrium via a bilinear program that integrates Bayesian inference, strategic planning, and belief manipulation. Simulations show that purposeful concealment naturally emerges: the Attacker randomizes its trajectory to manipulate the Defender’s belief, inducing suboptimal barrier selections and thereby gaining a strategic advantage.

title: Self-Supervised SAR Despeckling by Integrating Denoiser Prior with Attributed Scattering Center
authors: Xiandong Duan, Huangxing Lin, Tianpeng Liu
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Deep learning has become the mainstream approach for SAR image despeckling. However, the lack of speckle-free SAR images poses a significant challenge for supervised deep learning methods. To overcome this limitation, we propose a self-supervised SAR despeckling method that leverages a denoiser prior and attributed scattering centers to enhance the training process. Specifically, we use the output of an external denoiser as a pseudo-label for despeckling, while spatially correlated speckle noise in SAR images is decorrelated through random downsampling. The network is then updated by optimizing the similarity between its output and the pseudo-label. Additionally, an attributed scattering center map is introduced to help the network recognize strong scatterers and better preserve image details.
