Experiments on both synthetic and real SAR datasets demonstrate that our method outperforms existing despeckling approaches. Specifically, our method improves ENL by 16% over the recent self-supervised MERLIN framework on the TerraSAR scene. Meanwhile, our method achieves MOR and VOR values that are closer to the ideal value of 1.0. The code of our work is made freely available at https://github.com/Duan-NUDT/SARDIDP_ASC.

title: Privacy-Preserving Image Retrieval With Deep Learning in Edge Computing
authors: Mingyue Li, Yuntao Li, Ruizhong Du, Chunfu Jia, Guanxiong Ha
abstract: With the rapid development of edge computing and the explosive growth of image data generated by IoT and mobile devices, an increasing number of users prefer to perform privacy-preserving image storage and retrieval tasks directly at the edge. However, existing solutions typically rely on basic encryption methods and shallow feature extraction, leading to inadequate data security and poor retrieval performance. In this paper, we propose a Dynamic Multi-Stage Encryption (DMSE) method combined with a semantically rich fusion feature to achieve high-precision and privacy-preserving image retrieval in edge environments. Specifically, the proposed method first divides the image into blocks and applies random shuffling, followed by channel and pixel-level XOR encryption to generate a hybrid encrypted image. Then, we extract global features from the encrypted image using the histogram of Discrete Cosine Transform (DCT) coefficients. In addition, a multi-scale convolution block is designed to extract stable and robust local features under encryption. Finally, deep learning is utilized to fuse the global and local features, capturing both the holistic structure and fine-grained semantics of the image. This comprehensive feature representation significantly improves retrieval accuracy while ensuring privacy. Extensive experiments validate that our approach outperforms existing methods in both security and retrieval effectiveness, making it well-suited for edge computing scenarios with limited resources and high privacy demands.

title: Synthesis of DNA Conjugated MoS for ultra-low level of 2,4-D Detection_supp1-3634194.pdf
authors: Milan Sasmal
abstract: MoS2 was synthesized using a novel synthesis method “liquid phase sonication technique” followed by conjugation with Deoxyribonucleic Acid (DNA) for 2,4-D pesticide detection. This DNA conjugated MoS2 (DCM) shows an immense ability to detect ultra-low-level of 2,4-Dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2,4-D). A highly sensitive 2,4-D detection scheme was set up using a basic drop casting technique. The essential characterizations of the DCM were carried out using UV-Vis spectroscopy, FESEM, Fluorescence spectroscopy, XPS, FTIR technique prior to fabricate the sensor for pesticide detection. The Fluorescence spectroscopic study was utilized for optical detection of 2,4-D. The DCM device working principle depends upon the change in current/ conductance with different concentrations of 2,4-D. A deep study was carried out upon the synthesis of DNA conjugated MoS2 to investigate the effect of 2,4-D upon transport properties of DCM for ultra-sensitive pesticide detection.

title: Latency Insertion Method for Fast FinFET Simulation Based on the BSIM-CMG Model
authors: Yi Zhou, Bobi Shi, Qingyi Wang, Thong Nguyen, Patrick Goh, José E. Schutt-Ainé
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: FinFETs have been replacing traditional planar MOSFETs in modern circuits. However, the real-device effects of FinFETs make fast and accurate simulation challenging. This paper introduces a new algorithm for fast FinFET simulation based on the latency insertion method (LIM). Compared to the conventional modified nodal analysis (MNA) method, LIM exhibits linear numerical complexity and has proven to be superior in speed. In this work, we combine the BSIM-CMG compact model with the LIM to perform fast DC and transient simulation of FinFETs. The Newton Raphson (NR) iteration method is incorporated to further improve the simulation speed. The algorithms for both DC and transient analyses are explained. Optimization methods for accelerating the code are discussed. The proposed algorithm is tested on several circuit examples. While providing accurate results, the proposed method can be more than an order of magnitude faster than conventional solutions.

title: An Area-Efficient Integrated RF Reflectometer Based on Low-Power Logarithmic Power Detector
authors: Ting-Li Hsu, Valentyn Solomko, Amelie Hagelauer
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: In this article, an area-efficient radio frequency (RF) scalar reflectometer is presented. Coupled incident and reflected power waves are detected with a low-power logarithmic detector without utilizing active RF amplifiers. The differential output voltage of the power detector (PD) is converted to a digital code, which is proportional to the return loss in decibels. A current-mode successive approximation register (SAR) analog-to-digital converter (ADC) with a reference digital-to-analog converter modulated with digital-to-time conversion is adopted to minimize the area of the readout circuitry while maintaining a high linearity. The device is implemented in a 90-nm RF silicon-on-insulator (SOI) complementary metal–oxide–semiconductor (CMOS) technology, occupying a core area of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${0.37}\text {mm}^{2}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>. The implemented reflectometer demonstrates a measurement error of less than <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${2}\text {dB}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> for load points with return loss worse than <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${15}\text {dB}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> from <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${900}\text {MHz}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${2.5}\text {GHz}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>. The implemented reflectometer consumes a dc current of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${190}\text {$\mu ${A}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> from a 1.8 V supply during detection.

title: A 4 K 0.7 mW 9.1–14 GHz Low-Noise Amplifier With Cryogenic Numerical Noise Analysis
authors: Teng-Shen Yang, Liang-Hung Lu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This article presents a 0.7mW, 9.1–14GHz low-noise amplifier (LNA) designed for quantum applications and characterized at both room temperature (300 K) and cryogenic temperature (4 K). By performing numerical analysis, the temperature coefficients of the dominant noise mechanisms from 300 to 4 K are extracted. Furthermore, a practical methodology is proposed for simulating cryogenic RF performance without requiring an accurate cryogenic process design kit (PDK). By modifying the electromagnetic (EM) substrate model and adjusting the simulation temperature to 200 K, the simulated S-parameters and power consumption closely match the measured results at 4 K. Fabricated in 90-nm complimentary metal–oxide–semiconductor (CMOS), the stacked inverter–common-source LNA consumes 0.7mW at 4 K and achieves 15.5dB gain with a 9.1–14GHz bandwidth and 0.9dB minimum noise figure (NF). The measured noise is reduced by a factor of 5.72 at 12GHz and 3.68 at 9GHz when cooled from 300 to 4 K, and a temperature coefficient of 3.33 is extracted for induced channel noise.

title: Comparison of Classical and Sequential Model Predictive Control Techniques in a Grid Connected Three-Level NPC
authors: Beichen Duan, Marco Rivera, Jakson Bonaldo, Patrick Wheeler, KV Ling, Tabish Mir, Javier Muñoz
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper compares Classical Model Predictive Control (CMPC) and Sequential Model Predictive Control (SMPC) for a three-level Neutral Point Clamped (NPC) converter. Although CMPC is simple to implement, it faces challenges such as variations in switching frequency and the complex tuning of weighting factors. SMPC addresses these issues by prioritising control objectives sequentially, eliminating weighting factors, and simplifying controller design. The simulation results demonstrate that SMPC improves the tracking of output currents, reduces harmonic distortion, and improves the balancing of DC link voltages under both steady-state and transient conditions. These findings establish SMPC as a robust alternative to CMPC, improving power quality and system performance in multi-level converter applications.

title: Comparison of Different Bidirectional Three-Phase Grid Rectifiers with Various Wide-Bandgap Semiconductors
authors: Matthias Klintz, Lukas Radomsky, Regine Mallwitz
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Bidirectional charging is a crucial aspect for utilizing grid-tied storage systems. Wide-bandgap semiconductors enable the enhancement of energy conversion efficiency. Given the extensive range of semiconductor products, it is crucial to identify an optimized design efficiently. In this context, this paper presents a fast model-based evaluation process. The design of a 22 kW three-phase bidirectional rectifier operating with a DC-link voltage ranging from 750 V to 850 V, utilizing different topologies and wide-bandgap semiconductor switches, is demonstrated. The results indicate that both efficiency and thermal behavior can be accurately reproduced and that top-cooled semiconductor devices exhibit superior thermal performance. A direct comparison of the advantages of the ANPC over the B6 topology is presented.

title: Local Atmospheric Profiles Construction for Absolute Radiometric Calibration of Spaceborne Optical Sensors
authors: Shupeng Li, Jian Zeng, Yaokai Li, Qijin Han, Changping Huang, Yingxian Wang, Zhaopeng Xu, Xinmeng Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Radiometric calibration is a critical process for ensuring the accuracy and reliability of remote sensing data. Standard atmospheric models, when applied to localized regions, fail to accurately reflect the specific atmospheric state characteristics, significantly increasing the uncertainty of radiometric calibration. In this study, high-precision atmospheric profiles for the Golmud region were constructed using ground-based radiosonde data and reanalysis datasets through spatiotemporal correction methods. These constructed atmospheric profiles were applied to radiometric calibration experiments conducted in September 2021, with experimental data derived from MODIS and GF-1 WFV sensors. The results demonstrate that the constructed atmospheric profiles significantly improve radiometric calibration accuracy, exhibiting lower relative errors and root mean square errors (RMSE) compared to the MODTRAN standard profiles. Specifically, the RMSE of the monthly, seasonal, and annual atmospheric profiles improved by 1.811%, 2.418%, and 2.223% on average, respectively. In particular, the seasonal profiles performed exceptionally well in capturing atmospheric stratification, further validating their effectiveness in radiometric calibration for remote sensing applications.

title: CP2M: Clustered-Patch-Mixed Mosaic Augmentation for Aerial Image Segmentation
authors: Yijie Li, Hewei Wang, Jinfeng Xu, Zixiao Ma, Puzhen Wu, Shaofan Wang, Soumyabrata Dev
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Remote sensing image segmentation is pivotal for earth observation, underpinning applications such as environmental monitoring and urban planning. Due to the limited annotation data available in remote sensing images, numerous studies have focused on data augmentation as a means to alleviate overfitting in deep learning networks. However, some existing data augmentation strategies rely on simple transformations that may not sufficiently enhance data diversity or model generalization capabilities. This paper proposes a novel augmentation strategy, Clustered-Patch-Mixed Mosaic (CP2M), designed to address these limitations. CP2M integrates a Mosaic augmentation phase with a clustered patch mix phase. The former stage constructs a new sample from four random samples, while the latter phase uses the connected component labeling algorithm to ensure the augmented data maintains spatial coherence and avoids introducing irrelevant semantics when pasting random patches. Our experiments on the ISPRS Potsdam dataset demonstrate that CP2M substantially mitigates overfitting, setting new benchmarks for segmentation accuracy and model robustness in remote sensing tasks. In the spirit of reproducible research, the code, dataset, and experimental results are publicly available at: https://github.com/Att100/CP2M.

title: GAN-Driven Inverse Modelling of EM Backscatter Data for 2-D Dielectric Shape Reconstruction
authors: Ehtasham Naseer, Ali Imran Sandhu, Muhammad Adnan Siddique, Waqas Ahmed, Pai Yen Chen, Mohamed Farhat, Ying Wu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Reconstructing the shape of dielectric scatterers from electromagnetic (EM) backscatter, commonly referred to as EM imaging, presents significant challenges due to the ill-posed and non-linear nature of the problem. Furthermore, the computational complexity of conventional numerical approaches increases substantially with the growing electrical dimensions of the domain of interest. This study proposes a deep learning (DL)-based framework to address these challenges, offering a computationally efficient solution while simultaneously tackling the inherent non-uniqueness of the ill-posed problem. The proposed framework employs an inverse neural network (INN) architecture comprising a dense layer network to map backscatter EM fields into a lower-dimensional latent space constrained to follow a Gaussian distribution. A pre-trained generator reconstructs the scatterer shapes from this latent representation, while a pre-trained forward neural network (FNN) imposes physical constraints to resolve the non-uniqueness issue. Experimental evaluations demonstrate the effectiveness of the trained INN, achieving a mean binary cross-entropy (BCE) loss of 0.04 and a structural similarity index (SSI) of 0.94 on test data. The findings underscore the potential of DL-based approaches to overcome existing limitations in EM imaging and contribute to advancements in computationally efficient scatterer reconstruction techniques.

title: A Study on The Impact of Earth’s Surface Inhomogeneity on the Estimation of InSAR Coherence
authors: Guanshu Ao, Cunren Liang, Jinting Zheng, Yuxiao Qin
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Accurate InSAR coherence estimation requires multiple observations of a resolution cell. However, in practice, ergodicity is typically assumed, and coherence is estimated using multiple surrounding pixels. When Earth’s surface is not homogeneous, the ergodicity assumption is violated, leading to biased coherence estimates. Through both simulation and real data experiments, we demonstrate that the conventional Boxcar estimation method tend to overestimate coherence in inhomogeneous regions and underestimate it in regions dominated by Permanent Scatterers (PS).

title: An Embedded Point Cloud Pre-Processing Accelerator on FPGA
authors: Yiming Gao, Herman Lam
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: Point cloud is an important type of geometric data structure for many robotics or 3D applications such as Autonomous Driving, Augmented Reality (AR), and Virtual Reality (VR). Raw point clouds generated by 3D sensors are typically large-scale and irregular. For these reasons, most of point cloud applications require an expensive down-sampling pre-processing phase for the raw point cloud to regularize it. With the traditional down-sampling methods, this preprocessing phase often accounts for the majority of the end-toend latency. Recently, the Octree-based pre-processing method has been proposed to efficiently perform the down-sampling phase. Building on this approach and the spatial proximity function of Octree nodes, we propose an Approximate Octree-Indexed Sampling (OIS) method to further accelerate Octreebased down-sampling and implement it as an FPGA-based accelerator, functioning as a near-sensor processor. In our evaluation, using benchmarks from three popular point cloud datasets, we first present the theoretical workload savings (ranging from 27.3% to 50%) achieved through the optimization of the approximation method. We then demonstrate that, compared to the current Octree-based down-sampling accelerator, our FPGA-based prototype accelerator performing the Approximate OIS method achieves additional speedups ranging from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.5 \times$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.01 \times$</tex>. Using point cloud AI benchmarks, we further demonstrate that the Approximate OIS method introduces close-to-zero loss in accuracy.

title: Impact of Adversarial Training on Model Bias and Decision-Making in SAR Image Classification
authors: Tianrui Chen, Chenxing Mao, Limeng Zhang, Weiwei Guo, Ting Shu, Zenghui Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Adversarial training is a crucial technique for enhancing the robustness of deep learning models. Previous studies have shown that adversarial training can alter the frequency bias of deep learning models, but its impact on model bias and decision-making behavior in SAR image classification remains underexplored. This study investigates how adversarial training affects these aspects in the context of SAR image classification. Using the MSTAR dataset, we trained the ResNet18, ResNet34 and ResNet50 models under standard training and PGD adversarial training, resulting in both standard and robust models. To analyze the effects, we leveraged mask information from the SARBake dataset to segment images into shadow, target, and background regions. These segmented regions were separately tested on both standard and robust models. By comparing the classification accuracy of the two types of models across different regions, the study provides insight into how adversarial training influences model bias and decision behavior, contributing to the development of more explainable and reliable SAR classification models.

title: Quantification of Cell-Wall-Midpoint-Ratio Characteristics for Equal Area Discrete Global Grid System
authors: Hongwei Wang, Qiang Lu, Dong Fan, Fuli Luo
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The alignment of cell walls and their dual cell walls, quantified by the "cell wall midpoint ratio", is crucial for applications, such as tidal simulation, ocean current calculation, and atmospheric modeling on spherical grids. The OGC has highlighted that cell geometry is a primary feature of Discrete Global Grid Systems (DGGS). While the cell area, shape, and uniformity have been extensively discussed, the "cell wall midpoint ratio" has often been overlooked. In this study, we quantified the geometric characteristics of this index for equal-area DGGS models, based on the Snyder projection, with three different cells shapes: triangle, diamond, and hexagon. Experimental results reveal that DGGS models with the same cell shape exhibit similar geometric characteristics, which resemble the deformation patterns of the Snyder projection. Additionally, the "cell wall midpoint ratio" deviation for diamond-shaped DGGS is slightly smaller than that of triangular and hexagonal models. These geometric characteristics provide a foundation for grid selection in discrete differential computations on spherical surfaces and enhance the reliability, credibility, and practicality of DGGSs across various fields and applications.

title: Doppler Phase Coherence Method: A Novel Approach to Determine Heights and Motions of Targets from Single SAR Acquisitions
authors: Francesco Vecchioli, Federico Minati, Francesco Trillo, Massimo Zavagli, Carmine Clemente, Mario Costantini
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: We propose a novel approach, named Doppler Phase Coherence (DPC), that introduces a new perspective on how to detect and measure, from single SAR acquisitions, heights and complex motions (including vibrations) of targets such as vessels, cars/trucks, buildings and infrastructures, for a variety of applications mostly related to safety and security. The proposed approach finds a model for the phase of the whole Doppler history corresponding to a target height and/or motion to be retrieved. Then, for each target, the model parameters are robustly and efficiently estimated by maximizing the coherence, i.e. the alignment, of the Doppler history phasors with the phase model. The tests performed for the complex use case of target vibrations, using real SAR data and ground truths, confirm the validity of the method.

title: Joint Clutter Suppression and Coherent Integration Method for High-Speed Target Energy Focusing with Airborne Radar
authors: Zihao Xiao, Zhi Sun, Jiangyun Deng, Chen Cheng, Xiaolong Li, Guolong Cui
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Significant target energy focusing is a prerequisite for effective detection and synthetic aperture imaging with airborne radar. However, it is inevitably to confront two main issues for low altitude high-speed target energy focusing: One is the strong clutter component in the echo may shelter the target energy. The other is the high-speed motion may cause severe range migration (RM) and then shorten the focusing period. To address these issues, it is common to perform serial processing for space-time adaptive processing (STAP) and coherent integration (CI) based RM correction. Therefore, this paper presents a joint implementation method based on Radon-STAP, which is different from the traditional serial processing. First, the target RM is converted into phase variation through Fourier transform (FT) along fast time dimension. Next, the RM-Doppler joint compensation filter is designed. Finally, the improved space-time adaptive filtering is implemented to obtain the results of energy focusing by joint clutter suppression and CI. The results of numerical simulation and real-measured data processing validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Weather Radar Beam Blockage Correction Using Deep Learning for Improved Precipitation Remote Sensing
authors: Songjian Tan, Haonan Chen
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Missing or low-quality data regions often occur in weather radar observations. One of the most common situations is beam blockage. Therefore, correcting weather radar observations that are partially or fully blocked is an indispensable step in radar data quality control and subsequent quantitative applications, especially in complex terrain environments such as the western United States. In this paper, we propose a deep learning framework based on Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) for correcting partial beam blockage regions in polarimetric radar observations. Data from the KDAX radar, located in northern California, is used to demonstrate the proposed methodology. The corrected data are validated with disdrometer measurements during independent precipitation events in northern California. The results show that the deep learning-based approach effectively addresses the data discontinuity caused by partial beam blockage, with the corrected radar observations showing strong agreement with ground truth. The beam blockage correction has a positive impact on radar quantitative precipitation estimation (QPE), demonstrated by a significant improvement in the average of reflectivity and rainfall rate estimates, highlighting its potential for enhancing precipitation mapping in complex terrain regions.

title: 6.78 MHz 500W Wireless Power Transfer System with PCB-Integrated Resonant Wireless Power Link
authors: Krigar Tim, Pfost Martin
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Wireless power transfer is emerging as a critical technology in industrial applications by overcoming the limitations of conventional wired connections, such as mechanical wear and maintenance issues. This paper presents a 6.78 MHz, 500 W WPT system that exploits l-frequency operation to reduce the size of coils and compensation components. A cost-effective LLC-Series-None network is employed to achieve Zero Voltage Switching at high switching frequencies, with all compensation elements located on the primary side. Notably, the resonant capacitance is formed by the printed circuit board (PCB) via a four-layer interleaving design, reducing component count by eliminating the need for costly C0G capacitors and enabling a compact receiver configuration. The system also supports robust integration with the half-bridge inverter, making it highly suitable for industrial applications.

title: Deep Learning-Based Complex-Valued Binary Transform for Millimeter-Wave FMCW Radar Range-Domain Target Detection
authors: Xibo Chen, Kai Xiong, Hongrui Zhang, Xiguang Wu, Bo Li, Bing Chen, Yan Liu, Genquan Han
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Conventional millimeter-wave (MMW) frequency-modulated continuous-wave (FMCW) radar requires several times discrete Fourier transform (DFT) within signal processing obtaining the range, velocity, and angle information of the target. However, although DFT can be accelerated with fast Fourier transform (FFT), this operation still requires a massive multiplication calculation. To address this, this paper proposes a deep learning-based complex-valued (CV) binary transform (BT) substituting FFT within MMW FMCW signal processing. Specifically, a deep network with a two-path symmetric CV binary structure is introduced to realize transformation from echo to range domain and its inversion, respectively, which ensures frequency analysis characteristic and invertibility of CVBT. Subsequently, we establish a loss with range and echo information, and then learn binary weights in the CV structure by data-driven back propagation. Lastly, the targets can be detected in range domain with the well-trained single-path forward propagation of CVBT, which merely demands CV addition operations. Numerical simulations demonstrate the feasibility and efficiency of the proposed CVBT.

title: A Fast SAR Image Generation Method Based on System Transfer Function Convolution
authors: Chang Liu, Bing Sun, Yihang Zhi
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The scarcity of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) datasets is a fundamental issue in the field of SAR image applications. Large-scale, diverse and high-quality data is the key to achieving good generalization in target detection and recognition for deep learning algorithms. However, the existing means of obtaining SAR image data are limited and costly. Traditional synthetic aperture radar imaging algorithms have problems such as electromagnetic computation errors, complex imaging processes and slow computation. To solve this problem, we propose a rapid image simulation method based on convolution of the system transfer function. The adjusted GAN network is used to expand the data diversity of the existing SAR grayscale images. Then, the transfer function of the big squint SAR simulation system is constructed, and the existing data is convolved with the transfer function. By changing the transfer function, SAR ship image data with different resolutions and azimuth angles can be obtained. The quality of the generated SAR images is evaluated through classification networks and image quality indicators.

title: Harnessing Self-Supervised Deep Learning and Geostationary Remote Sensing for Advancing Wildfire and Associated Air Quality Monitoring: Improved Smoke and Fire Front Masking using GOES and TEMPO Radiance Data
authors: Nicholas LaHaye, Xiaohua Pan, Hazem Mahmoud, Thilanka Munashinge, Gonzalo Gonzalez Abad, Jennifer Wei, Hugo Lee
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This work demonstrates the possibilities for improving wildfire and air quality management in the western United States by leveraging the unprecedented hourly data from NASA's TEMPO satellite mission and advances in self-supervised deep learning. Here we demonstrate the efficacy of deep learning for mapping the near real-time hourly spread of wildfire fronts and smoke plumes using an innovative self-supervised deep learning-system: successfully distinguishing smoke plumes from clouds using GOES-18 and TEMPO data, strong agreement across the smoke and fire masks generated from different sensing modalities as well as significant improvement over operational products for the same cases.

title: Cross-Modal Transformer and Optimal Transport for Sar-Optical Image Matching
authors: Xinlin Wang, Baozhu Liu, Shuiping Gou, Nuo Tong, Jinming Mu, Jie Peng
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: SAR-optical image matching has been a major problem in remote sensing application. However, it is difficult to achieve a balance between speed and accuracy for SAR-optical image matching. To this end, we propose an end-to-end SAR-optical template image matching method based on cross-modal Transformer and optimal transport theory. The proposed method designs a correlational mapping constraint module and added into the network structure of SegFormer, to control the self-attention interval in the search image. Meanwhile, a cross-modal attention module is constructed to facilitate better interaction between two modalities and enhance the response of feature weights of both modalities in the other modality. Moreover, an optimal transmission module is first introduced to formulate the optimization for similarity evaluation in multi-modal image matching. Different features are given different importance through the class activation map, which effectively avoids the situation that multiple points are matched to the same point. Finally, experimental results illustrate that the proposed method obtains more accurate matching than other compared methods and meanwhile reduces the matching time.

title: Impact and Optimization of Dead Time in Full-Bridge MMC for Enhanced Performance
authors: Shalini Deshmukh, Moumita Das, Pietro Tricoli
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This study investigates the influence of dead time in a full-bridge Modular Multilevel Converter (MMC), highlighting its effect on capacitor voltages, output waveform, and circulating current harmonics. The study highlights how voltage deviations caused by dead time lead to reduced circulating and output current amplitudes, affecting overall power transfer efficiency. A MATLAB-based simulation is conducted using an MMC with four submodules per arm and a 1 kV DC input to validate these findings. The converter operates with unipolar carrier phaseshift pulse width modulation (CPS-PWM) to enhance switching performance and reduce harmonics. Additionally, a new method is proposed to optimize the deadtime, offering insights into its influence on MMC performance. Future work may involve experimental validation and advanced control techniques to further improve system efficiency and minimize dead time-related distortions.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Machine Learning Algorithms Using Google Earth Engine for Land Use Land Cover Classification
authors: Narayan Vyas, Sartajvir Singh, Ganesh Kumar Sethi
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Data collected through remote sensing techniques is fundamental for a better understanding of processes on the surface of the Earth, supporting knowledge-based decision-making in multiple fields. The data used in this analysis included Sentinel-2 satellite images obtained from the COPERNICUS/S2_SR_HARMONIZED dataset through the Google Earth Engine (GEE) platform to classify the land use land cover (LULC). The dataset containing 12 spectral bands was initially preprocessed using GEE tools to eliminate atmospheric and radiometric errors. Random forest (RF), classification and regression trees (CART), and naive bayes (NB) machine learning (ML) classifiers were used to classify land cover types such as water, vegetation, barren, and built-up. Among all these techniques, RF had the best performance of 94.12% overall accuracy (OA) and a Kappa Coefficient (KC) of 92.12%, confirming it is the most accurate method for the results compared to all other mentioned techniques. NB achieved an OA of 85.29% and KC of 80.39%, whereas CART gave an OA of 91.18% and KC of 88.21%.

title: UPQC-Based Compensation Strategy for Grid Current Imbalance and Load Fluctuation in AC Railway Traction Systems
authors: Bei Liu, Pietro Tricoli
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: During the operation of alternating current (AC) railway systems, the inherently unbalanced nature of single-phase traction loads results in a significant presence of negative-sequence currents in the power grid. Moreover, frequent power peaks induce fluctuations in the load voltage, further impacting power quality. To mitigate these issues in the conventional single-phase transformer-based traction substations, this paper proposes a unified power quality conditioner (UPQC) designed to compensate negative-sequence currents and load voltage variations. This paper first introduces the topological structure and compensation principles of the proposed UPQC system. Subsequently, a detailed control framework for each compensation function is presented. Finally, a Matlab/Simulink model is developed, and simulation results are analysed to validate the effectiveness of the proposed compensation strategy.

title: Microcontroller-Based Integrated Control Circuits for Precision Multi-Point Electromagnetic Actuation
authors: Guanglin Qu, Xiazhen Xu, Bohui Jia, Nuoshi Chen, Qiufeng Yi
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: While recent progress in multi-actuator control systems has yielded notable improvements, prevailing architectures continue to exhibit limitations in optimizing cost efficiency, control precision, and physical compactness. Many solutions rely on custom circuitry or specialized controllers, which increase costs and hinder scalability. In addition, general-purpose platforms that are reproducible and suitable for hardware validation or educational use in reconfigurable electromagnetic systems remain scarce. To address these limitations, this paper presents a highprecision multi-point motion control system featuring a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \times 3$</tex> matrix of electromagnetic linear actuators (solenoids) controlled by a single Arduino Mega 2560 microcontroller. The system enables independent and coordinated control of nine actuators via a custom H-bridge driver array and a power architecture that ensures voltage stability during switching. The Arduino manages the timing of each actuator's motion, supporting both sequential and simultaneous control depending on the mode. Functional mode allows concurrent activation for rapid execution, while debugging mode supports stepwise testing of individual actuators. Key innovations include (1) a tightly integrated control architecture managed by a single microcontroller, (2) a stable multipoint power management scheme, and (3) a compact mechanical assembly based on a modular 3D-printed frame. Experimental validation confirms reliable push-pull motion across all actuators with low latency and consistent performance. Compared to existing tactile and microfluidic actuator systems, the proposed platform achieves a better balance between integration and flexibility, while demonstrating good scalability. This work establishes a technical foundation for larger electromagnetic actuator arrays and shows strong potential in applications such as smart reflecting surfaces (SRS), mechanically driven phasedarray radar systems, and tunable radio frequency (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R F}$</tex>) reflector platforms.

title: An Extremely Pipelined FPGA-Based Accelerator for SAR Satellite On-Board Real-Time Processing
authors: Tong Wang, He Chen, Ning Zhang, Shuo Ni, Zhenyang Li, Liang Chen
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Directly implementing intelligent real-time processing on the satellite can effectively reduce data processing latency and alleviate communication burdens. Existing convolution neural networks (CNNs) typically have a huge magnitude of parameters and intensive computation, making it a challenge to deploy CNN-based models onboard. To resolve this issue, this paper proposes an extremely pipelined FPGA-based accelerator with both algorithm and hardware optimization for SAR satellite on-board real-time processing. Firstly, in order to reduce the hardware resource overhead, convolution kernel weights and activations are quantized to signed and unsigned integers respectively, lightening the pressure of computing resource overhead. Secondly, a multi-level data prefetching strategy is proposed to optimize the data flow and resource consumption, making it possible to eliminate expensive off-chip memory access. Finally, an accelerator that computes all layers in simultaneous pipeline is proposed, significantly reducing the latency of data processing. Extensive experiments conducted on AMD-Xilinx XC7VX690T FPGA board show that the mAP reaches 93.5% on SSDD dataset while the throughput of the accelerator achieves 1.72 tera operation per second (TOPS) with 15.302W in 200MHz, demonstrating the capability of proposed accelerator for real-time processing.

title: Evaluation of EMO1 Gridded Meteorological Data and its Application to Crop GPP Modelling
authors: Rahul Raj, Bagher Bayat, Carsten Montzka
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This study evaluated the efficacy of high-resolution gridded meteorological data from the European Meteorological Observations (EMO), specifically focusing on agricultural and environmental applications. Both EMO1 and EMO5 datasets are available, but this study utilized EMO1 due to its high spatial resolution of 1.5km. Through comprehensive validation against flux tower measurements across nine agricultural sites, we assessed the reliability of EMO1-derived meteorological variables. The analysis spans a decade (2011-2020), focused on validating air temperature, vapour pressure deficit, and shortwave radiation, crucial for crop photosynthesis modelling (gross primary production: GPP). Statistical criteria, including the Kling-Gupta Efficiency (>0.42), normalized root mean square error (<0.1), and correlation coefficient (>0.85) demonstrated strong agreement across all variables and all sites. Although vapour pressure deficit showed slightly lower performance compared to the other variables, its accuracy was still sufficient for estimating crop GPP. A light use efficiency model was employed to estimate GPP at one site as a case study to illustrate the agricultural application of EMO1 data. The consistency observed between EMO1-driven and flux tower-driven GPP estimations further validated the applicability of EMO1 data in crop photosynthesis modelling. This study validated EMO1 for agricultural applications, with potential extensions to diverse ecosystems, supporting sustainable agricultural practices and carbon sequestration studies.

title: Review and Outlook: China’s GaoFen-3 Constellation Mission
authors: Zhibin Wang, Jiaxin Shen, Yuxiao Qin, Qingjun Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: GaoFen-3 (GF-3) is China’s first civilian high-resolution synthetic aperture radar (SAR) satellite. Since its launch in 2016, it has achieved significant application results in various fields, thanks to its 12 imaging modes, full-polarization capability, and high-precision data. However, as the demand for applications increased, the response time and data coverage of the single satellite became limited. To address this, GaoFen-3B (GF-3B) and GaoFen-3C (GF-3C) were launched in 2021 and 2022, forming China’s first SAR constellation with GF-3, significantly reducing revisit cycles and improving data timeliness and richness. The new satellites feature several technical improvements, including advanced imaging modes, automatic identification system (AIS) data reception, and real-time data processing. This paper provides a comprehensive review of the system design, technological highlights, and operational applications of the GF-3 satellite, analyzes the current status and technical improvements of the GF-3 constellation, and explores its promising future applications.

title: Leveraging Microfinance for Solar Energy Access: Policy and Practice in Rural Areas for Sustainable Development of Marginalized Rural Communities
authors: Mohit Kumar Gautam, Rudra Prakash Pradhan
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society Conference - Global (TEMSCON Global)
abstract: Rural regions require economical, sustainable energy for advancement. Notwithstanding global electrification initiatives, 14% of the worldwide population remains without electricity, predominantly in rural areas. This energy gap obstructs poverty alleviation and sustainable development. Solar household systems provide effective solutions in Bangladesh, India, and Nepal, where extending the grid is problematic [1]. Renewable energy meets increasing energy demands while mitigating greenhouse gas emissions, so advancing UN SDG 7 for clean energy access and SDG 13 for climate action. Microfinance institutions (MFIs) deliver essential financial services to marginalized communities via small loans, savings, and insurance products [2]. The integration of microfinance with solar energy assists rural populations in surmounting energy poverty and financial exclusion. Microfinance empowers households, especially women, by augmenting economic engagement and mitigating dangers. This integration fosters sustainable business models and facilitates rural electricity [3]. The research offers significant insights for policymakers, development practitioners, and financial institutions pursuing innovative financing frameworks for rural energy access, hence facilitating the attainment of SDG 7 and economic empowerment.

title: Short-Circuit Protection Scheme for Power Electronics in DC Grids with Distributed Capacitors
authors: Kevin Pilgrim, Finn Jansen, Martin Pfost
publish: 2025 10th IEEE Workshop on the Electronic Grid (eGRID)
abstract: Short-circuit events are critical to the reliability and stability of DC microgrids, including industrial settings such as production facilities where electric monorail systems run on conductor rails powered by a central DC supply. Recent work proposes relocating the bulk DC-link capacitance from each moving monorail and the central supply onto the rail itself by distributing capacitors along the conductor. This strategy simplifies vehicle construction and reduces mass. Because the distributed capacitor conductor rail behaves as a transmission line with greatly reduced propagation velocity, its wave-propagation properties can be exploited to improve short-circuit performance and achieve a nearly zero-current switch-off point. This paper presents a protection scheme that leverages that effect. A detection method identifies the optimal instant for fault interruption, and experimental results confirm the method’s effectiveness.

title: An Effective Tie Points Matching Method for Relative Geometric Calibration of Multispectral Pushbroom Images
authors: Zhongli Fan, Jianping Zhao, Mi Wang, Yingdong Pi, Qiyan Luo, Lekang Wen
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In this paper, we propose a highly accurate and radiometric variation insensitive image matching method for relative geometric calibration of optical multispectral images. First, a large number of salient feature points are extracted from the image using the scale invariant feature transform (SIFT) feature detector. Then, a set of first-order Gaussian steerable filters are used to extract structural information from the image as a basis for feature description. We calculate the feature description vectors with radiation resistance using the direction index of the largest feature value in the direction dimension. Finally, we obtain a large number of high-accuracy tie points by an effective outlier removal strategy. We integrate the proposed method into a relative geometric calibration scheme, and experimental results on multiple Ganfen-1B multispectral images show that the proposed method outperforms the SIFT method in terms of calibration success rate and calibration residual.

title: DiffRPTraj: Diffusion-Based Realistic Pedestrian Trajectory Generation
authors: Taehoon Kim, Kyoung-Sook Kim, Haoyi Xiu, Xin Liu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This study introduces DiffRPTraj, a novel framework for generating realistic pedestrian trajectories using diffusion models while incorporating essential spatiotemporal features. Unlike traditional generative models like GANs or VAEs, diffusion models in DiffRPTraj offer superior accuracy by addressing the challenges of capturing intricate environmental interactions and preserving data privacy. Key contributions of this work include integrating conditional information, such as occupancy grid maps and spatiotemporal density matrices, to enhance trajectory realism. The framework employs Traj-UNet, an adaptation of the UNet architecture, to model noise prediction effectively at each diffusion timestep, ensuring the generated trajectories align closely with real-world patterns. Additionally, novel modules such as the map image encoder and spatial density image encoder are introduced to handle diverse spatiotemporal characteristics. Extensive evaluations on a real-world indoor pedestrian dataset demonstrate DiffRPTraj’s superior performance over existing methods, with enhanced spatial and temporal density accuracy, trajectory realism, and adaptability to diverse spatiotemporal density distributions. Compared to the baseline model, we improved the similarity of spatiotemporal density distributions by up to 260% when evaluating with data having the same spatiotemporal density distribution and up to 2949% when evaluating with data having different spatiotemporal density distributions. These findings underscore DiffRPTraj’s potential applications in urban planning, public safety, and privacy-preserving mobility analysis.

title: A High-Precision Dynamic Phasor Model of Resonant Dual-Active-Bridge Inverters Using the Double Fourier Series
authors: Yanxiang Yin, Jingyang Fang, Chenghui Zhang
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Due to their merits of high efficiency and power density, resonant dual-active-bridge (DAB) inverters are receiving heightened attention in the application of microinverters. However, the existing models of resonant DAB inverters, such as the first harmonic approximation (FHA) model, are nonlinear without any steady-state operating point and suffer from low accuracy. This paper proposes the first high-precision dynamic phasor model of resonant DAB inverters that allows model linearization and the analysis of the resonant inductor current even without any relevant current sensor. Moreover, this paper derives the analytical expression for the Fourier coefficients of switch functions using the double Fourier series. Simulation and experiments validate the accuracy of the proposed model. The voltage error under a 50% load change is less than 3%, leading to an accuracy improvement of over 20% compared with the FHA model.

title: Drone-Borne Video SAR System Design for Moving Target Indication
authors: Jaekun Ko, Jungmin Byun, Myeong-Jin Lee, Myunghun Shin
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Although moving target indication in video SAR sequences using target shadows has been studied, acquiring high-quality video SAR data suitable for such research remains challenging. To address this, we designed a drone-borne video SAR system that leverages the practicality, cost-effectiveness, and operational flexibility of drones. The system accommodates nonlinear platform trajectories, integrates an autofocusing algorithm, and compensates for viewport instability caused by misaligned SAR frames. We built a video SAR testbed with static and moving targets and assessed the quality of video SAR sequences at each processing stage using entropy for autofocusing and mean matching point distance for registration.

title: Performance Evaluation and Analysis of Deep Learning Based Season-Aware Atmospheric Correction Model on Nvidia Jetson Agx Orin
authors: Maitrik Shah, Jay Chaudhari, Mehul S Raval, Srikrishnan Divakaran
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Recent advances in deep learning have transformed atmospheric correction (AC) in remote sensing, but deploying these models on edge devices poses significant challenges. To our knowledge, this is the first paper on the implementation of AC in edge devices. It investigates the performance of the Season Aware Atmospheric Correction Network (SAAC-Net) on the NVIDIA Jetson AGX Orin for edge deployment, with the PARAM Shavak DL GPU, a high-performance enterprise system, serving as a benchmark for comparison. The model’s performance is analyzed across different precision levels (FP32, FP16, INT8) and frameworks (TensorFlow, TensorRT). The results reveal that the quantization reduced model sizes from 30MB (FP32) to 2.5MB (INT8). Ten-Sorflow FP32 achieves the lowest RMSE (0.055) on both platforms, with the PARAM Shavak GPU exhibiting slower inference times (45 seconds). In contrast, TensorRT on the Jetson AGX Orin significantly accelerates inference (≈0.96 seconds with INT8) but introduces increased RMSE (0.73 for INT8). These findings underscore the trade-offs between memory usage, accuracy, and speed, offering insights for optimizing deep learning models for edge-based AC.

title: Analysis of Visual Sequences for Driver Drowsiness Detection
authors: Novriadi Antonius Siagian, Poltak Sihombing, Amalia Amalia, Ade Candra
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: Driver drowsiness remains one of the leading causes of traffic accidents, highlighting the urgent need for accurate and non-invasive monitoring systems. This study proposes a hybrid deep learning framework that integrates Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) with Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks to detect drowsiness from facial visual sequences. Four prominent CNN architectures, ResNet50, ResNet101, InceptionV3, and DenseNet121, are utilized to extract spatial features from video frames, while the LSTM component captures temporal dependencies to model the progression of fatigue-related facial dynamics. The evaluation leverages the NTHU Driver Drowsiness Detection (NTHU-DDD) dataset, which encompasses challenging visual conditions such as varying illumination and the use of glasses or sunglasses. Preprocessing steps include facial landmark detection, cropping, normalization, and construction of sequential input. Among all tested models, DenseNet121 demonstrates the most robust performance, achieving 94.63% accuracy and exhibiting high recall in detecting drowsy states. The findings underscore the model’s strong generalization capabilities across diverse real-world conditions, positioning DenseNet121 as a highly promising candidate for deployment in vision-based Advanced Driver Monitoring Systems (ADMS).

title: Temporal analysis of coastal dynamics at Matanzas beach using satellite images
authors: Isidora Díaz Quijada, Idania Briceño de Urbaneja, Waldo Pérez Martínez, Joaquín Valenzuela Jara
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Globally, 60% of beaches are experiencing erosion due to sea-level rise, coastal storms, and human activity, with Chile being a critical case, as 80% of its coastlines are affected. This study, conducted at Matanzas Beach in the O’Higgins Region, utilizes remote sensing (CoastSat and MNDWI), wave climate analysis (ERA5), and geomorphological techniques (DSAS and drones) to assess coastal dynamics. Between 1985 and 2024, differentiated patterns of erosion and accretion were observed, influenced by ENSO, storms, and the 2010 earthquake. The findings highlight the importance of monitoring and managing coastlines in the face of natural and anthropogenic disturbances.

title: A Self-Resonant Transformer for CLLC Converter
authors: Yam Siwakoti, Md Imran Hasan, Sajib Ahmed, Aswin Palanisamy, Kawsar Ali, Dan Rogers, Teng Long
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: To date, the dominant method of passive component miniaturisation in power converters is through increases in switching frequency, which is enabled by emerging high frequency Wide-Band-Gap devices. However, to push the performance limits for the next generation of high-power-density power converters, research into integrated passive components-such as inductors, capacitors, and transformers into a single structure is essential. This manuscript presents an integrated self-resonating transformer based on Flexible Multilayer Foil (FMLF) for CLLC converters. In this design, all resonant components on both the primary and secondary sides-such as leakage or physical inductance and capacitance-are combined into a single unit, referred to as a Self-Resonant Transformer. This not only reduces the volume, but also the cost and weight of the overall system thereby enabling next-gen highly power dense converters. Moreover, the proposed structure employs a novel trifilar winding configuration to mitigate the effects of bypass capacitance typically observed in conventional winding arrangements. Analysis, design, and experimental measurements are presented to show the efficacy of the proposed structure.

title: A Remote Sensing Approach for Monitoring Spatial and Temporal Dynamics of Hydrological Products in Kruger National Park
authors: S. Daly, J. Judge, M. L. Almendra
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Shifting climate patterns have intensified drought conditions in South Africa, altering water availability and necessitating an understanding of temporal and spatial interactions between hydrological products. To address limited ground-based observations, satellite products from CHIRPS, Landsat, Sentinel-1, SMAP, and GRACE were utilized to investigate hydrological dynamics within Kruger National Park (KNP), an undisturbed savanna landscape. Spatiotemporal trends in precipitation (PPT), soil moisture (SM), normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI), and liquid water equivalent (LWE) were examined for 2015– 2024. All variables exhibited trends of increasing availability, indicating recovery from the 2015–2016 drought in the region. Spatial analyses revealed higher rainfall and SM in southern KNP, whereas NDVI patterns reflected the park’s heterogeneous land cover. A widening north–south gradient was observed for SM and PPT. These findings demonstrate the utility of remote sensing for monitoring hydrological products in data-scarce regions.

title: Evaluating Seawater Intrusion Disaster from Satellite Image and Social Media Data
authors: Jilin Yan, Bo Wu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Approximately 40% of the global population resides within 100 kilometers of coastal areas. With the intensification of global climate change and the rising sea levels, coastal communities are facing unprecedented challenges. Seawater intrusion, a phenomenon characterized by its short duration and significant impact, poses a serious threat to the safety of coastal residents. Therefore, the ability to map seawater inundation and water level using limited information is critical for effective emergency management. This study utilizes high-resolution satellite image and social media data collected during the seawater intrusion event in Erjiegou Town in October 2024. An improved Residual Neural Network(ResNet) model is employed to extract water level data from social media data, which is then integrated with seawater inundation information derived from satellite image to generate a seawater intrusion water level map. The findings demonstrate that water level map generated from satellite image and social media data can provide valuable reference information for disaster management authorities.

title: Active Low-Voltage Half-Bridge-Based CM EMI Filter for Three-Phase Motor Inverters
authors: Rahel Herzog, Jonas Huber
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Voltage-source inverters (VSIs) provide dc-ac conversion in three-phase motor drives, e.g., operating from a common dc-bus in industry or from a battery in electric vehicles. To comply with electromagnetic interference (EMI) regulations, dc-side passive filters are needed, which can contribute up to 30% of the total converter weight/volume. Consequently, active filters (AFs) are of interest: Even though the AF effectiveness becomes limited at higher frequencies, the cutoff frequency of the remaining passive filter can be increased and its size thus substantially reduced. This paper proposes a common-mode (CM) AF for six-switch three-phase VSIs operated with standard SPWM or SVM. The AF only requires two low-voltage half bridges and a capacitive injection network. The operating principle, sensitivities, and design aspects are presented, and detailed circuit simulations of an industrial motor drive (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 0 0 ~ V ~ d c, ~} \mathbf{2. 5 ~ k W}$</tex>, IEC <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6 1 8 0 0 - 3 ~ E M I}$</tex> limits, 24 V AF supply) and an EV traction inverter (800 V dc, 125 kW, CISPR 25 EMI limits, 48 V AF supply) verify the concept, indicating a reduction of the required CM filter inductance by a factor of 2 (EV) to 6 (industrial) compared to a passive filter.

title: Burned Area Mapping of Boreal Forests Using Automatically Generated Samples
authors: Yunxiao Wang, Zhiyu Zhang, Wenjian Ni, Zhifeng Guo
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Accurately mapping wildfire extent and dynamics in boreal forests is essential for climate and ecological research. Currently, only two medium-resolution burned area datasets, generated based on a large number of visual interpretation samples, are available for research on the entire Boreal Forest: the Global Forest Loss (Fire_GFL) and the Global Annual Burned Area Map (GABAM). Fire_GFL has an 8% omission in North America and globally, while GABAM suffers from severe "stripe" and "box" effects, making it unsuitable for use. Therefore, a new burned area dataset covering the boreal region is needed for more precise wildfire mapping. This study develops a large-scale fully automated wildfire extraction algorithm named BAMS for the boreal forests, which can automatically generate training samples. Its effectiveness and robustness are tested using the 2023 Canadian wildfires as a case study. Compared to the TIIC produced by Natural Resources Canada and the publicly released Fire_GFL, BAMS achieved the highest OA of 93%, compared to 91% and 86%, respectively. At the regional scale, BAMS shows a strong correlation and consistency with TIIC, while the forest burned area estimated by Fire_GFL is systematically lower than that of BAMS and TIIC. These preliminary results suggest that the proposed method can accurately and automatically delineate wildfire areas in boreal forests.

title: An Unsupervised Deep Subdomain Adaption Method for SAR Automatic Target Recognition
authors: Yifei Li, Timo Balz
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) automatic target recognition (ATR) using deep learning networks has gained significant attention in recent years. These methods typically require a large volume of labeled data to train deep models, which poses a challenge for SAR-ATR, as annotating SAR images is both costly and time-consuming. An alternative approach is to use electromagnetic simulation samples for model training. However, due to substantial distribution differences between the simulated and real domains, cross-domain recognition remains a significant challenge. This paper presents an unsupervised domain adaptation method for SAR-ATR, which enhances recognition accuracy in the target domain by aligning similar samples across domains. Experimental results show that the proposed method effectively leverages information from the simulation sample set, facilitating successful transfer of the model from simulated to real samples.

title: An Advanced SPICE Model for SiC MOSFETs Incorporating Third-Quadrant Operation and Reverse Recovery
authors: Chihiro Kawahara, Takashi Masuhara, Seiya Yoshida, Kohei Tajiri, Yuki Matsutaka, Takeshi Horiguchi, Junichi Nakashima, Dai Kitano, Naoto Kaguchi, Yasushige Mukunoki
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: In recent years, Silicon Carbide (SiC) Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor Field-Effect Transistors (MOSFETs) have become prominent in power electronics applications due to their low on-state resistance and high switching speed. However, parasitic elements in circuits can cause surge voltage and current imbalance, potentially degrading these advantages. Accurate circuit simulation is essential for effective design and verification. This paper presents an advanced Simulation Program with Integrated Circuit Emphasis (SPICE) model for SiC MOSFETs that includes third-quadrant characteristics and reverse recovery behavior, crucial for applications utilizing the internal reverse diode (body diode). The third-quadrant model incorporates gate-source voltage (Vgs) and temperature dependence. The reverse recovery model, which is implemented as a newly proposed diffusion capacitance model using simple fitting parameters, replicates the current and temperature dependence. Validation through experimental comparisons shows high accuracy, with peak recovery voltage within an error of 2% and peak recovery current within an error of 7%, in the given experimental condition. It is a practical tool for circuit design, accurately reproducing reverse recovery current and surge voltage, including temperature dependencies. This advanced SPICE model enhances the reliability and efficiency of SiC MOSFET-based systems, aiding engineers in optimizing circuit designs.

title: Adaptive SOR Method for ICESat-2 ATL03 Extraction in Deformation Monitoring of Multiple Scenarios
authors: Jianqi Lou, Chaoying Zhao
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: ICESat-2 has been widely used for monitoring glacier elevation, canopy height, and water levels, but existing point cloud extraction methods face challenges in multiple scenarios deformation monitoring. These include manual filtering, fixed thresholds, and difficulties balancing accuracy with point cloud density. To overcome these, we propose an Adaptive Statistical Outlier Removal (ASOR) algorithm, which dynamically adjusts filtering factors and iterations based on the standard deviation (STD) gradient between ICESat-2 data and reference DEM. Validated in glacier melting ASOR increased point cloud density by 27.4% and 65.6% compared to SOR and DBSCAN, respectively, while maintaining accuracy. Reliable performance in multiple Scenarios deformation monitoring of glaciers, mines, and urban surfaces. It captured glacier melting trends in the Pyrenees, detected a 41.5 m topographic change in Puertollano, and achieved a 0.81 correlation with InSAR for urban subsidence in Lorca. ASOR offers an efficient, scalable approach to multiple scenarios deformation monitoring, reducing manual intervention.

title: Continuous Wave Metal Detetor for 3D Imaging
authors: Ivan Romero, Thomas Walter, Simon Mariager
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This research introduces an advanced continuous wave metal detector designed for object localization in three dimensions. By implementing a novel multi-receiver coil configuration, the system can estimate the spatial position of metallic objects along the X, Y, and Z axes. The proposed methodology focuses on analyzing variations in the magnetic response across multiple coils to reconstruct the object's position relative to the sensor array. The primary application of this technology is in the field of humanitarian demining, where accurate and reliable detection of buried landmines is critical.

title: Variable Power Compensation Control of Electrolytic Capacitor-Less Dual Inverter with Single-Phase Power Supply
authors: Kotaro Takasu, Taiju Sakurai, Hitoshi Haga
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper proposes a variable power compensation control method to reduce a floating capacitor capacitance of an electrolytic capacitor-less dual inverter with a single-phase power supply. In the system, a main inverter outputs pulsating power to the motor for a power factor correction, and an additional inverter compensates for power pulsation by charging and discharging a floating capacitor. However, the floating capacitor capacitance becomes larger with mechanical output, resulting in an increase in the system size. The proposed control method controls an additional inverter output power variably on the basis of load condition. The experimental results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed control method, as the capacitor capacity is reduced by 43% compared to the conventional control method. The proposed control method contributes to the system miniaturization of the electrolytic capacitor-less dual inverter with the single-phase power supply.

title: Brotani.ai: Aggregator-Driven IoT Smart Sensor Networks for Melon Farm Monitoring
authors: Muhammad Ashar, Mohammad Agung Rizki, Muhammad Iqbal Akbar
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: Agriculture is under pressure to meet rising food demand while facing challenges such as climate change, limited resources, and labor shortages. Traditional farming methods are increasingly insufficient, requiring innovative technologies to ensure sustainable production. The Internet of Things (IoT), integrated with mobile applications, has emerged as a promising solution to support smart agriculture through real-time monitoring, efficient resource management, and improved decision-making. This study aims to evaluate the integration of IoT devices with mobile applications in greenhouse agriculture. The proposed system includes sensor devices for temperature, humidity, soil moisture, and light intensity; actuator devices such as pumps, fans, and lights; an aggregator for data processing; and mobile and station applications for remote monitoring and control. Sensor data are transmitted continuously to the cloud, visualized for real-time insights, and processed to generate decisions for automated or manual control of actuators. The evaluation focuses on historical sensor data, water consumption efficiency, and crop condition. Results demonstrate that the system enables timely monitoring, reduces water usage, and supports healthier crop growth. Overall, the integration of IoT with mobile applications enhances agricultural productivity and offers a scalable framework for sustainable and precision farming practices.

title: L-Band Radar Backscatter and Tree Water Dynamics: Insights from the BorealScat-2 System
authors: Shivam Rawat, Albert Monteith, Jose Gutierrez Lopez, Ylva Sjöberg, Hjalmar Laudon, Lars M.H. Ulander, Henrik J. Persson
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This study investigates the influence of diurnal variations in sap flux density and vapor pressure deficit (VPD) on L-band radar backscatter patterns, using BorealScat-2 data to focus on polarization and height-specific correlations for understanding forest water dynamics. Multi-polarization and height-resolved backscatter profiles from BorealScat-2 were analyzed alongside sap flux and VPD measurements. Temporal heatmaps highlighted distinct backscatter dynamics, with the mid-to-upper canopy (14 to 20 m) having influence on radar signals. Diurnal cycles of backscatter intensity correlated strongly with sap flux density under varying VPD conditions, demonstrating the radar’s sensitivity to canopy water dynamics. Co-polarized backscatter (HH and VV) consistently exhibited stronger and more stable correlations with sap flux compared to cross-polarized signals. By integrating BorealScat-2 radar data with physiological and meteorological variables, this study underscores the potential of L-band radar backscatter as a proxy for transpiration and forest water exchange processes. The findings enhance understanding of the interplay between environmental factors and radar scattering mechanisms, contributing to advancements in radar-based monitoring of forest hydrology and evapotranspiration.

title: The Trends in Aerosol Optical Depth Over Eastern Asia Using Modis Measurements from 2001 to 2022
authors: Xuehua Fan, Xiaoqiong Zhen, Xiaoguang Sun, Mei Zheng, Tianle Zhang, Wenying He, Congzheng Han
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Based on the satellite aerosol optical thickness (AOD) data from MODIS/Terra (2001-2022) and MODIS/Aqua (2002-2022), we investigated the temporal-spatial distribution and trends of AOD in East Asia and the Northwest Pacific. An increasing trend, ranging from 0.002 to 0.02/year with 95% confidence, was observed across all seven sub-regions from 2001 to 2013. The highest increase rates were found in North China and South China, both at 0.02/year. Following the implementation of China's Air Pollution Prevention and Control Action Plan in 2013, AOD levels in Northeast China, North China, South China, the East China Sea, and the Northwest Pacific significantly decreased, ranging from -0.002 to -0.02/year. The results indicate that the Air Pollution Prevention and Control Action Plan has been effective in reducing aerosol emissions in China, thereby decreasing the aerosol loading transported to downwind areas.

title: 3D Representation of Tree Trunks and Roots from SAR Tomography Obtained by a Drone-Borne SAR System
authors: Henrik J. Persson, João Roberto Moreira, Gian Carlos Oré Huacles, Ansgar Jörgenfelt, Shivam Rawat, Juliana De Almeida Góes, Christian Wimmer, Eduardo Freitas, Ruben Valbuena, Hugo E. Hernandez-Figueroa
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Synthetic aperture radar (SAR) has traditionally been employed via satellites for global forest monitoring. In Sweden, boreal forests are comprehensively mapped using airborne laser scanning and photography, which provide high- resolution data that limits the additional value SAR can offer due to its relatively lower resolution, despite its ability to acquire data under all weather conditions. However, by addressing the various factors that currently hinder the extraction of useful information from SAR images, the technology holds significant potential for applications such as vegetation and subsurface mapping, including soil conditions and tree root analysis. This study introduces a drone-based SAR experiment configured to capture the forest at an exceptionally high spatial resolution, tailored for root analysis. Additionally, SAR tomographic processing is employed to produce a 3D reconstruction of tree roots and trunks. Extensive reference datasets for both vegetation and soil, gathered through complementary sensors and methodologies, support groundbreaking analyses in this domain.

title: Modeling and Stability Analysis of Parallel Grid-Forming Converter Systems Based on Virtual Oscillator Control and VSG Control
authors: Zhiteng Wang, Jason Ye
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The grid-forming converter has voltage source characteristics that can support the grid voltage and frequency, effectively improving the stability of power systems with power electronics. The Andronov-Hopf-Oscillator-based Virtual Oscillator Control (AHO-based VOC) strategy has emerged as a novel approach in recent years. As for a system of parallel gridforming converters includes both this strategy and the Virtual Synchronous Generator (VSG) control strategy, the stability of the system has rarely been studied so far. In this paper, a threephase system with two grid-forming converters in parallel is established. Subsequently, a small-signal model of the system is built, and the influence of controller parameter and transmission line parameters on the small-signal stability of the system is investigated. Simulation results show that the system remains stable when the parameters are changed and has better power quality than the parallel system only using VSG control.

title: Grid-Forming Control Method of Two-Stage Interlinking Converters in Hybrid AC/DC Microgrids
authors: Mehdi Baharizadeh, Mohammad Sadegh Golsorkhi, Thomas Ebel
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Hybrid AC/DC microgrids (MGs) are formed by connecting AC and DC MGs using either a one-stage or twostage interlinking converter (ILC). This paper proposes a novel control strategy for two-stage ILCs in islanded hybrid AC/DC microgrids. The proposed approach not only achieves primary objectives such as global power sharing (GPS) and DC link voltage regulation of ILC but also improves overall system stability through advanced ILC control techniques. Developed based on regulating the energy stored in the DC link capacitor, this method enables grid-forming operation for both the DC-AC and DC-DC converters of the ILC and eliminates the necessity for a phase-locked loop (PLL). Time-domain simulations confirm that the proposed strategy maintains hybrid MG stability, even during DC or AC distributed energy resources disconnections, while the voltage and frequency are regulated close to the rated values.

title: Wheat Yield Prediction: The Case Study Of Ahmedabad District Using Multi-Source Data And Deep Learning
authors: Apoorva S. Mehta, Pragneshkumar G. Patel, Maitrik K. Shah
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Accurate prediction of wheat yield is essential for effective agricultural planning and ensuring food security, especially in regions like Ahmedabad district in Gujarat, India, where wheat cultivation plays a significant role in the local economy. This study evaluates the performance of four machine learning models—GRU, LightGBM, ConvLSTM, and RNN—using multi-source data that includes NDVI, meteorological, and historical yield records. The models were assessed based on Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) and Mean Absolute Error (MAE) under two configurations: with and without NDVI data. The results demonstrate that integrating NDVI data significantly improves model performance, with LightGBM consistently achieving the highest accuracy across configurations. GRU and ConvLSTM showed remarkable improvements when NDVI was included, emphasizing the value of vegetation indices in capturing spatiotemporal crop dynamics. These findings highlight the potential of combining multi source datasets and advanced machine learning techniques for enhancing agricultural productivity and decision-making.

title: Downscale Goes Measurements for Fire Detection
authors: Luke Taulbee, Yifan Yang, Haonan Chen, Changyong Cao, Zhengwei Yang, Qi Chen, Zhe Li, Rick Mueller, Noa K. Lincoln
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Accurate wildfire detection using satellite sensors remains challenging due to the limitations in spatio-temporal resolution of current satellite imagery. Existing satellite-based fire products struggle to identify real-time fire perimeters effectively. For instance, the GOES-R series provides high temporal resolution for frequent observations but suffers from poor spatial resolution, while low Earth orbit (LEO) satellites like VIIRS offer high spatial resolution but lack temporal frequency. In this research, we propose a deep learning framework for wildfire detection that leverages GOES observations downscaled to a spatial resolution of 500 meters using a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN). The VI-IRS high-resolution images serve as target labels during the training phase. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework achieves a high 500m spatial resolution while maintaining the high temporal resolution of GOES, enabling more precise and timely wildfire detection.

title: Model-Based Control of a Three-Phase PFC Converter with Minimal Sensor Requirements
authors: Simon Peter, Karl Stephan Stille, Jan Boris Loesenbeck
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: A new three-phase AC/DC converter topology is presented that achieves galvanic isolation with only two high voltage semiconductor switches. A modelbased control is developed for this system that makes current measurement unnecessary.
