By using models, state variables are calculated in real time, which enables a pulse pattern calculation at a switching frequency of 880 kHz. The proposed approach reduces measurement requirements and costs. The topology including the control is verified in practice.

title: Adaptive Flocking Control Algorithm for Airborne Sensor Networks Based on Fuzzy Logic System
authors: Lanjun Li, Mengfan Yang, Manqi Yang, Jing Liang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The mobility of airborne sensor offers a significant advantage in surveillance sensor networks, greatly enhancing both measurement precision and adaptability. This research proposes a fuzzy system-based adaptive flocking algorithm (FSAFA), addressing the issue of balancing area search and target tracking. This approach uses the whale optimization algorithm to optimize the parameters of the objective function for selecting search areas, maximizing search area efficiency, while employing a fuzzy logic system to determine each node’s action commands for more efficient task completion. Simulation results show that our method increases tracking performance and area coverage efficiency for multiple stationary and moving targets. Compared to traditional flocking algorithms, it enhances tracking robustness and reduces task area coverage time, providing a basis for multi-sensor networks in real-time monitoring.

title: Decoding Teleconnection Impacts on Hydrological Switches in the Conus Using Wavelet Analysis
authors: Surendra Maharjan, Wenzhao Li, Shahyar Fazl, Hesham Morgan, Hesham El-Askary
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Hydrometeorological teleconnections are key drivers of hydrological processes, representing the influence of large-scale atmospheric circulation patterns on regional climates. Understanding these teleconnections provides crucial insights into the mechanisms underlying hydrometeorological phenomena, particularly hydrological switches—rapid transitions between extreme events such as droughts and floods. These switches have become increasingly prevalent across the contiguous United States (CONUS), fueled by climate variability and evolving atmospheric patterns.This study utilizes cross-wavelet transform analysis to examine the spatial and temporal dynamics of hydrological switches and their correlations with major teleconnection indices, including NAO, ONI, WP, PDO, PNA, and QBO. The findings indicate significant coherence between hydrological switches and teleconnection indices across different temporal scales, with ONI and QBO showing dominant correlations at frequencies of 16–32 months across all regions from 1951 to 2023. Phase analysis reveals a mix of synchronized and lagged impacts, highlighting the intricate interactions between teleconnections and hydrological extremes. Additionally, other indices such as NAO, WP, PDO, and PNA exhibit region-specific correlations, with values peaking at frequencies of 64–256 months during notable periods, underscoring the complex temporal and spatial variability of these influences.

title: APSS Metrics for Fault Detection: Area, Position, Symmetry, and Shape in Image Segmentation
authors: V. Turco, L. Fezza, A. Ruospo, E. Sanchez, M. Sonza Reorda
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Defect and Fault Tolerance in VLSI and Nanotechnology Systems (DFT)
abstract: In recent years, the impact of hardware-induced faults on neural networks performing image classification tasks has gained a lot of attention. Specifically, failures have been directly associated with wrong classifications. When it comes to different tasks, this association is less explicit. For example, the critical impact of hardware-induced faults on image segmentation tasks is less interpretable. In this work, we propose a novel technique for detecting critical permanent faults, relying on a dataset profiling phase to extract four metrics. These metrics are designed to assess and monitor the area, position, symmetry, and shape of prediction patterns across the output mask at the pixel level. Validation was performed through a statistical fault injection campaign on Fast-SCNN model trained on Cityscapes. To evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed method, a Faulty Output Dataset (FOD) was developed and employed to compare state-of-the-art (SOTA) metrics, such as Pixel Accuracy (PA) and mean Intersection over Union (mIoU), with the proposed one. The results show a high capability to detect critical faults, with an accuracy greater than 99%, comparable to SOTA methods, but with the advantage that the proposed method does not require a golden mask, increasing its applicability in real-world scenarios.

title: Group Convolution Attention based Multi-Scale Object Detection of Remote Sensing Images
authors: Han Zhang, Tao Xu, Xiaohui Yang, Yuqian Zhang, Chenxin Xiao
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Object detection is a crucial step in the analysis of remote sensing images. Remote sensing images often encompass vast scenes characterized by significant variations in object scales. The inherent characteristics of remote sensing images often lead to inaccurate detection results. As a result, to improve object detection performance, it is essential to enhance the model’s capability to capture multi-scale features. To address this issue, we propose a group convolution attention (GCA) module to increase the performance of multi-scale object detection. The GCA module consists of a feature grouping module (FGM) and an attention extraction module (AEM). The FGM performs grouped convolutions on the features extracted by the backbone network to obtain features with improved scale representation. Then, the AEM extracts channel attention weights from the features obtained by the FGM to obtain cross channel attention for multi-scale features. These process captures cross-channel attention and contextual information, increasing the representation of multi-scale features of the object. We conducted experiments employing models such as the object detection algorithms Faster R-CNN, YOLOX, and RtmDet. Comparative and ablation experiments were performed on datasets DIOR, MS_Building and SSDD. The experimental results demonstrate that the network incorporating the GCA module improves object detection performance, further validating the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: 10m Resolution of Indonesia and Malaysia Oil Palm Plantation Map: Sentinel-2 Based Approach
authors: Nuttaset Kuapanich, Jiaying Liu, Jiayin Jiang, Jiatao Huang, Juepeng Zheng
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The increasing global demand for palm oil has driven the rapid expansion of oil palm plantations, particularly in Indonesia and Malaysia, resulting in significant deforestation. Satellite-based monitoring offers an efficient approach to tracking these plantations; however, the resolution of existing datasets often limits their ability to capture the detailed spatial dynamics of oil palm cultivation. This study presents the development of a high-resolution oil palm plantation map for Indonesia and Malaysia using Sentinel-2 satellite imagery with a 10-meter spatial resolution. The proposed method utilizes existing oil palm maps as noisy labels and employs a U-Net segmentation model to produce precise, high-resolution outputs. To address the resolution mismatch between existing maps and high-resolution imagery, a Determinant-based Mutual Information (DMI) loss function is integrated during model training. Bayesian inference is subsequently applied to refine the results and merge them with the Annual Oil Palm Area Dataset, a previous oil palm plantation map. The resulting map exhibits significantly greater detail and accuracy compared to previous datasets, achieving an F1 Score of 0.72, a 21.86% higher user accuracy, and a 25.85% higher overall accuracy. The high-resolution map is publicly available at https://zenodo.org/records/14545667.

title: Leveraging Satellite Data For Water Usage Insights: A Comparison Of Sen-Et, Eeflux, And The Pre-Trained U-Net Model SAR2ET Using Uav-Derived Evapotranspiration As Ground Truth
authors: Zeynep Kuru, M. Rasit Cevikalp, Esra Erten, Nebiye Musaoğlu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In addition to its central role in hydrology and climate studies, evapotranspiration (ET) is the most crucial parameter in understanding agriculture’s water use. Due to its critical role in managing water resources, this study will evaluate the three satellite-based ET estimation products, having Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV)-derived ET as ground truth. The ground truth data is acquired from a height of 200 m over irrigated cotton fields with thermal orthomosaics based on Zenmuse H20T thermal camera integrated into Matrice 300 RTK UAV. We explore and compare three satellite-based ET data over these agricultural fields to uncover their usage potential in practice at time t. The first data is Landsat-based Analysis Ready Data (ARD) called the Earth Engine Evapotranspiration Flux (EEFlux), which provides 30 m resolution global ET data but with limited time resolution, 16 days. The second dataset is Sentinel-1-based ET data, generated using a pre-trained U-Net structure with the SAR2ET model, providing regular updates based on Sentinel-1 passes. The last one is based on the Sen-ET using Two-Source Energy Balance (TSEB) model and proposed for obtaining high (~ 20 m) resolution ET data from Sentinel-2 and Sentinel-3 as inputs.A general underestimation and reduced variability —a narrower range of values— are observed for all satellite-based ET products compared to the RGB+thermal UAV-based ET values, likely due to the coarse spatial resolution that the spatial variability of ET cannot be detected. Compared to the Landsat-based ARD ET estimations, the Sentinel-2/-3-based ET estimations displayed higher agreement with UAV acquisitions. This could be related to calibrating the model with more site-specific conditions at acquisition time, leading to capturing the RGB+thermal UAV-based ET values. Given that SAR2ET is trained by EEFlux data, SAR2ET model-based ET estimations are, as expected, closer to the one from EEFlux.

title: Challenges and recommendations for leveraging remote sensing for crop monitoring
authors: Filippo Sarvia, Abdullah Barhy, Federica Chiozza, Ameni Khatteli, Anis Bousselmi, Matieu Henry, Dario Spiller, Gizem Senel, Gautam Dadhich, Andries Potgieter, José Bofana, Abdourahman Maki, Livia Peiser
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Droughts, floods and seasonal climate variations increasingly constitute a significant threat to global food security, particularly in regions with vulnerable agricultural systems. In this context, timely monitoring of agricultural status through new and emerging geospatial applications has become an essential step. Land cover and crop monitoring have become important for assessing and forecasting various crop-related indicators. such as for crop type identification and yield estimation. Advances in satellite-based information and cloud computing have expanded the potential of remote sensing for monitoring these indicators. Moreover, growing access to agricultural datasets—including crop calendars, agro-ecological zones, water resources, management practices, spectral signatures among others—offers new opportunities for leveraging emerging remote sensing and AI applications and improve informed decision-making in agriculture. New methods are increasingly being developed to overcome challenging access to local-specific information. This paper highlights key challenges and recommendations for leveraging these tools to improve assessing agricultural land, crop types, and yields in various regions. It explores (1) the role of remote sensing in land cover and crop monitoring, (2) current applications at various scales. Recommendations focus on integrating data sources, improving collaboration, and strengthening local expertise to enhance crop monitoring and food security.

title: Snowline Change Monitoring in the Galongla Mountain Based on the DeepLabV3+ Model and Multi-Temporal Remote Sensing Data
authors: JingWen Zhang, Hong Fan
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Studying snowline elevation changes is crucial for understanding the cryosphere's response to climate change and provides important data for water resource management in snow-dominated regions. This paper presents a snowline monitoring method based on GF-1 and Sentinel-2 remote sensing imagery, utilizing the DeepLabV3+ model to identify snow cover and cloud in images. A multi-source, multi-temporal data fusion strategy is proposed, where snowline elevations are derived through the integration of DEM data. This method effectively addresses the challenges of cloud cover and data gaps in mountainous regions, enabling precise detection of the snowline at a fine scale. The Galongla Mountain region was selected as the study area. The results indicated that from 2013 to 2023, the snowline elevation of Galongla Mountain fluctuated between 4200 and 4700 meters, with an overall upward trend. On the south slope, snowline elevation showed more significant variation due to factors such as water vapor and topography, while the north slope exhibited smaller fluctuations and a more consistent distribution. Analysis of seasonal snowline changes from 2018 to 2023 revealed that the snowline increased from April to September and decreased from November to April.

title: A Generative AI Approach Using Synthetic Side-Channel Signals for Detecting Hardware Trojans in FPGAs
authors: Rohit Abilash Dobbali, Akshay Raghavendra Kulkarni, Mohammed Niamat
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: Hardware Trojan (HT) detection in integrated circuits including Field Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs) faces significant challenges due to the scarcity and imbalance of high- quality side channel datasets. This paper addresses the above-mentioned challenge by employing Conditional Wasserstein Generative Adversarial Networks (CWGANs) to generate synthetic side channel traces, specifically power signals, under both Trojan infected and Trojan free circuit conditions. The generated synthetic signals not only replicate real world side channel characteristics but also support scalable and costeffective model training. A Random Forest (RF) classifier trained on original power dataset achieves 93% accuracy, validating its effectiveness. When trained and tested solely on synthetic data, the models exhibit near perfect accuracy, confirming the realism and utility of the generated samples. However, evaluations reveal a domain shift when synthetic trained models are applied to real data, resulting in a reduced accuracy of 83.62%. To address this domain shift, we implement Domain-Adversarial Neural Network (DANN) adaptation techniques, which significantly improve crossdomain performance to 92.87%, nearly matching the baseline accuracy. These findings highlight the importance of generative models in hardware security and provide practical options for bridging the synthetic-to-real performance gap using advanced domain adaption techniques.

title: Path Planning of Radar-Enabled UAV for Maneuvering Target Pursuit
authors: Kui Xiong, Maosen Liao, Long Zhang, Linchuan Gan, Guolong Cui
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This paper studies the maneuvering target pursuit problem of the radar-enabled unmanned aerial vehicle (RUAV). First, the target pursuit problem is modeled as an autonomous sensing and decision-making process of the RUAV, in which the state of the target is estimated by the radar and is utilized as the environmental information to plan the flight trajectory of the RUAV. Then, the utility function is designed utilizing the cumulative distance between the RUAV and the target plus the trajectory length in multiple predictive steps, and a dynamic optimization model with practical constraints is formulated on the basis of the model predictive control framework. The predatory search maneuvering target pursuit (PSMTP) algorithm is proposed to obtain the real-time path planning strategy while avoiding the forbidden region. Finally, numerical results are provided to evaluate the effectiveness and superiority of the PSMTP algorithm over some typical counterparts.

title: Modelling Above-Ground Biomass in a Semi-Arid Mokala National Park Using Earth Observation Satellite Data
authors: Simbarashe Jombo, Mohamed Abd Elbasit
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Aboveground biomass (AGB) has important roles in specific ecological tasks, including storing carbon and preserving species, especially in protected areas in the semi-arid zones. This research aims to assess AGB in Mokala National Park, South Africa, from satellite synthetic aperture radar (SAR) and multispectral data against ground truth. This study entailed ten experiments using SAR (Sentinel 1) and multispectral (Sentinel 2) datasets, applying background regression techniques and the random forest model. The findings that adding Sentinel 1 VV and VH (V = vertical, H = horizontal) polarizations, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> values increased from 0.60 and 0.78 to 0.81, indicating a high level of precision in biomass estimates. This study also showed that the Green Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (GNDVI) and Normalized Difference Red Edge (NDRE) 1 are the significant vegetation indices for producing a relationship with AGB. The GNDVI and NDRE1 improved the accuracy of AGB estimates, demonstrating their effectiveness in biomass assessment. The study brings into focus the use of satellite technology along with statistical models in the determination of the AGB in semi-arid regions and examines the impact of biomass equations in the determination of ecological health. The combination of SAR and multispectral data is regarded as a promising method for developing AGB estimations for better nature reserve management and subsequent conservation strategies. This work shows that AGB can be improved using more sophisticated technologies and models, thereby facilitating the sustainable use and protection of nature reserves.

title: Unimodular MIMO radar Waveform Design with Spectral Compatibility for Desired ISL Properties
authors: Xiangqing Xiao, Yiran Zhang, Jinfeng Hu, Kai Zhong, Xin Tai, Yongfeng Zuo
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Unimodular waveform design with good integrated sidelobe level (ISL) is a key technique in MIMO radar systems. The problem is formulated as a complex quartic problem under constant modulus constraint (CMC), and in the existing methods, two issues that need to be further addressed: (1) the designed waveforms lack spectral compatibility, (2) performance degradation due to relaxation-induced errors. To address these issues, we propose a spectrally compatible waveform design method without relaxation. In general, spectral notches are formed at the stop band to enhance the spectral compatibility of the waveform, and we note that the energy spectral distribution (ESD) at the notch can be constructed as the inequality constraint to be numerically control, which facilitates to make a better trade-off with ISL performance. Furthermore, utilizing the property that complex circle manifold naturally satisfies CMC, the resulting problem can be projected as an unconstrained problem on that space, avoiding relaxation. Based on the above considerations, a non-relaxation penalty Riemannian manifold (PRM) method is proposed. Firstly, the multiple inequality spectral constraints are converted into an precise penalty term by an exact penalty mechanism and incorporated into the objective function. Subsequently, the CMC is satisfied by constructing a Riemannian manifold space, allowing the resultant problem to be projected as an unconstrained one onto this space. Finally, the spectrally compatible waveforms are obtained by a derived manifold-based conjugate gradient algorithm. Numerical results show that the proposed method achieves a significant improvement in ISL, while achieving a precise numerical control over multiple spectral notches.

title: Hyperspectral Image Classification Using Patch-Based Attention and Restricted Isometric Regularization
authors: Abhiroop Chatterjee, Susmita Ghosh, Ashish Ghosh
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Hyperspectral images provide rich spatial-spectral information, enabling detailed analysis of remotely sensed images. This article presents a novel ultra-lightweight deep neural net model for hyperspectral image (HSI) classification by introducing a patch-based attention mechanism along with a Restricted Isometric Regularization (RIR). The patch attention mechanism is embedded onto a 3D convolutional neural network (CNN) and operates on fixed spatial neighborhoods to dynamically weigh the local spatial-spectral features, thereby enhancing the model’s ability to capture intricate patterns across spectral bands. Due to the presence of a large number of bands in HSI images, preservation of intrinsic structure is a challenge. The present article formulates a novel regularizer, RIR, which facilitates stable feature projection in high-dimensional spaces and effectively addresses the curse of dimensionality while preserving the overall structure of the image. The proposed method achieves 99.79% accuracy on Pavia University dataset, setting a new benchmark in HSI classification. It also performs excellently on other benchmark datasets, e.g. 98.63% OA and 98.44% Kappa on Indian Pines, 99.94% OA and 99.93% Kappa on Salinas, and 99.54% OA and 99.50% Kappa on Botswana. In addition, ablation studies highlight the importance of each mechanism. With only 33,337 parameters, our framework significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods by a considerable margin.

title: Dynamic Watermark Generation for Digital Images Using Perimeter Gated SPAD Imager PUFs
authors: Md Sakibur Sajal, Marc Dandin
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: Digital image watermarks as a security feature can be derived from the imager's physically unclonable functions (PUFs) by utilizing the manufacturing variations, i.e., the dark signal non-uniformity (DSNU). While a few demonstrations focused on the CMOS image sensors (CIS) and active pixel sensors (APS), single photon avalanche diode (SPAD) imagers have never been investigated for this purpose. In this work, we have proposed a novel watermarking technique using perimeter gated SPAD (pgSPAD) imagers. We utilized the DSNU of three <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$64 \times 64$</tex> pgSPAD imager chips, fabricated in a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.35 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> standard CMOS process and analyzed the simulated watermarks for standard test images from publicly available database. Our observation shows that both source identification and tamper detection can be achieved using the proposed source-scene-specific dynamic watermarks with a controllable sensitivity-robustness trade-off.

title: Time-Scale Extension Algorithm of MUSES LAI Products Using Image Super-Resolution
authors: Chunyu Zhao, Zhiqiang Xiao, Jinling Song, Hua Yang, Yunteng Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Leaf Area Index (LAI) is a key parameter in analyzing land-atmosphere processes. Several LAI products with different spatial resolutions have been generated using physical methods, or empirical methods. However, due to the short time span of these products, it is not conducive to conducting long-term series analysis. This study designs a Time span Extension Algorithm (TEA) for these LAI products based on the deep learning image super-resolution technology. The CNN was trained using LAI data from the 5km and 1km Multiscale Satellite Remote Sensing (MUSES) LAI products for 2000-2015, and the trained neural network was used to generate 1km LAI data for 1981-1999 according to the 5 km MUSES LAI product from the same period, 5km and 1km MUSES LAI in 2016-2019 were used as verification. The training performance of the neural network achieved a Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR) of 31.27 dB, and the annual average R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> between TEA 1km and 1km MUSES LAI values reached 0.94105 in 2016 to 2019. This study demonstrated the TEA can successfully extend the time span of the 1km MUSES LAI product back to 1981. When compared to the bicubic interpolation, the TEA achieved superior performance. In the near future, the TEA will be used to extend the time span of the 500m and 250m MUSES LAI products back to 1981.

title: CareerCraft- Workforce Training Programs in Semiconductors and Mobility for Southeast Michigan
authors: Gozde Tutuncuoglu, Caisheng Wang, Mohammad Alhawari, Yong Xu, Mohammad Ismail, Amar S. Basu
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: This paper describes a four-part workforce training curriculum designed for southeast Michigan's needs for technical expertise in semiconductors, electric vehicles, and mobility. Developed for the state of Michigan's Economic Development Corporation (MEDC), this program seeks to train both students and working professionals in 4 topical areas: 1) Power electronics and EV motors; 2) Printed circuit board (PCB) design and manufacturing; 3) Semiconductor chip design; and 4) Semiconductors and sensors for automotive applications. This paper describes the overall structure of the program and the details of each area. The curriculum is expected to be deployed in the 2025–2026 academic year.

title: Equilibrium Strategy in Competitive Electricity Market via MAPPO Algorithm
authors: Yuxuan Zhou, Lichao Wang, Lei Ma, Fan Ji, Yu Wang, Yaojie Sun
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: As the penetration of renewable energy increases, new market participants are integrated into a competitive day-ahead electricity market. However, under incomplete information, it is challenging to find the strategic equilibrium in an electricity market with multiple participants, due to the complex coupling and strategic bidding interactions among different types of market participants. This paper proposes a Multi-Agent Proximal Policy Optimization (MAPPO)-based bidding method for competitive electricity markets to achieve a strategic equilibrium for the new type market participants, in which the action probability and policy space are further calculated. In this method, a centralized training framework is applied to handle the dynamic environment resulting from multi-agent interactions, and PPO is used to model the high-dimensional continuous action space in electricity market bidding. The proposed method has been tested and validated through simulations on the IEEE 30-bus system, which features various types of market participants. The results indicate that the proposed method can achieve a strategic equilibrium for the bidding rewards among multiple market participants in an incomplete-information game setting.

title: Application Evaluation of Urban Heat Island Effect based on Data from New Generation Satellite Infrared Camera of China
authors: Yingjuan Wei, Dandan Wei, Chenchao Xiao
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In response to the limited application of domestic satellite data in urban heat island effect in China, this paper carries out surface temperature inversion and urban heat island intensity calculation based on HJ2 satellite infrared camera data of Beijing. The accuracy and application potential of HJ2 satellite in urban heat island effect are evaluated by comparing with the temperature inversion and heat island effect results of Landsat8 thermal infrared band during the same time phase. The research results show that the HJ2 satellite can accurately invert surface temperature and urban heat island intensity with its advantages of multiple spectral bands, high resolution, wide width, and strong timeliness. It has important significance for the development of surface temperature inversion algorithms, improving the independent application of satellite remote sensing in China, and reducing the dependence on foreign thermal infrared remote sensing data for urban heat island monitoring.

title: Synchronization in Distributed SAR: Testing a Data Driven Approach on Simulated Data
authors: Gianluca Coppa, Antonio Gigantino, Francesca Pelliccia, Maria Salvato, Alfredo Renga, Maria Daniela Graziano, Antonio Moccia
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Recently, the concept of Distributed Synthetic Aperure Radar (DSAR) has been introduced to overcome the limits of a single monolithic SAR satellite, thanks to the possibility to exploit several smaller platforms, like Cubesats. Time and phase synchronization aspects represent an open question in this field, in particular when an illuminator of opportunity is exploited. For this purpose, a simulation environment has been developed to produce suitable data used to test specific algorithms tackling the problem at image level.

title: Feedback Loop Gain Analysis Using Driving Point Admittance to Identify the Feedback Return Signal
authors: Agustin Ochoa
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: Negative feedback in analog circuits is used to stabilize system response to device variations arising from changes in manufacturing, aging, and temperature. Since its introduction, feedback analysis has focused on the innate device forward transfer property such as a device transconductance (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$g_{m}$</tex>), leading to a misinterpretation of key variables and conceptual properties. A feedback ‘loop’ was imagined which led analysis in the direction of describing this loop. In this paper a simple and unifying analysis is presented where interacting elements are identified and properly combined to describe the feedback return signal as a component of a port admittance, and manipulated to show the loop gain function, fully accounting for loading and feedforward paths both external and internal to the active element, a single device or amplifying subcircuit, useful for high frequency designs as well. And the idea of ‘loop’ is corrected to lie in the math rather than directly in the circuit.

title: Estimation of Stator Iron Loss Build Factor from Shrink Fitting and Laser Cutting in a Permanent Magnet Synchronous Machine
authors: Anaugh Banerjee, Juliette Soulard, Edward Griffin, Xiyun Ma, Sreeju S Nair
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper presents an efficient method to investigate the combined impact of shrink-fit and laser cutting on the stator iron losses. It is applied to a 3-phase 12-slot 10-pole interior permanent magnet synchronous machine for twowheeler traction applications. Two grades of electrical steel, M250-35A and NO20-1200, are considered. The mechanical stress in the stator back iron is derived by FEA simulations and an average value is identified. Material magnetic properties are measured using a single sheet tester using EDM and laser cut samples. Data under compression load and laser cut damage are reported, including BH curves and derived iron loss model parameters. The grade NO20 is more influenced than M250-35A by compressive stress and laser cut. As expected, low flux densities and low frequencies are the most impacted (hysteresis loss). The stator iron losses are calculated with and without stress from shrink-fitting and cut edge damage. The stator iron loss build factors are presented on the torque-speed plane. The stator iron loss in the e-machine at low loads are considerably increased across the frequency range, while the efficiency is impacted the most at low load and 700 Hz. The WMTC drive cycle efficiency, with the M250-35A results in a drop of 0.8% and 0.9% for NO20-1200. However, no significant impact on the peak performance is predicted. The presented method estimates the impact of cut edge and shrink-fit effect on e-machine performance without increase in the simulation time, therefore it is optimal for initial selection of electrical steel grade.

title: Radiation Effects on NVIDIA Jetson SoCs: Insights from Heavy Ion Irradiation
authors: Ivan Rodriguez-Ferrandez, Eric Rufart-Blasco, Leonidas Kosmidis, Maris Tali, David Steenari
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Defect and Fault Tolerance in VLSI and Nanotechnology Systems (DFT)
abstract: This study examines the vulnerability of modern embedded GPUs—specifically the NVIDIA Jetson Orin NX and Xavier NX System-on-Modules (SoMs)—to Single-Event Effects (SEEs) under heavy ion irradiation. Originally developed for safety-critical environments such as automotive systems, these high-performance SoMs integrate advanced computing capabili-ties with built-in functional safety, positioning them as promising candidates for deployment in radiation-prone domains like space. We assess SEE behavior across various ion energy levels, focusing on the central System-on-Chip (SoC), which includes the CPU, GPU, and peripheral components. Our evaluation covers both the runtime and boot-time phases, providing a comprehensive view of fault susceptibility and its implications for system uptime and reliability in space conditions. The paper presents an in-depth analysis of error signatures observed in both the CPU and GPU due to ion strikes, contrasting these with outcomes from previous proton-based studies. Additionally, we compare the two NVIDIA platforms in terms of SEE types—including Single-Event Latch-up (SEL)—to evaluate their relative robustness and inform their potential adoption in space-grade applications.

title: Exploring Simplified Reservoir Computing Systems for Resource-Constrained Edge AI Hardware
authors: Ziyi Niu, Shuai Song, Joseph S. Najem, Azeemuddin Syed, Md Sakib Hasan
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: We present a low-overhead reservoir computing framework optimized for edge AI applications by leveraging a combination of several techniques. Specifically, we employ the Simple Cycle Reservoir (SCR) as an alternative to the widely used Echo State Network (ESN), offering a more hardware-efficient design. Our framework evaluates five simplified nonlinear activation functions alongside the conventional hyperbolic tangent function. Additionally, we employ a hyperparameter that enables a tunable trade-off between memory retention and nonlinearity by adjusting the ratio of linear to nonlinear activations. A genetic algorithm is utilized for efficient hyperparameter optimization. To further reduce hardware cost, we developed a framework for 16-bit reduced-precision arithmetic without significantly compromising model performance. Extensive evaluations on standard benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach delivers competitive accuracy while significantly lowering computational and hardware overhead, making it well-suited for resource-constrained edge environments.

title: A Novel Neuropredictive SAR ADC Architecture for Ultra-Low Power Applications
authors: Alexander Spielberger, Christof Pfannenmüller, Lucas Spitzkopf, Wolfgang Armbrecht, Albert-Marcel Schrotz, Robert Weigel, Norman Franchi
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: This paper proposes a new type of neuromorphic analog-to-digital converter: a neuropredictive successive approximation register analog-to-digital converter (SAR ADC). By estimating the next input value using a neuromorphic predictor, the conversion time of a modified SAR ADC - and thus the energy consumption - can be reduced. In a preliminary investigation, a demonstrator designed for audio signals shows a 41.09% reduction in energy consumption compared to conventional SAR sampling. This ADC architecture proposes an alternative for ultra-low power applications.

title: IoT Based Lake Monitoring System
authors: Anjali Shivsharan, Surya S. Durbha, Pratyush Talreja
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Water is one of the important factors for human lives. Given the importance of water in any form, its overwhelming presence: causing floods and underwhelming presence: causing draught, can be problematic. Hence it becomes important to monitor water levels in commonly found water bodies and remotely located glacial lakes. In urbanized cities, an increase in water level of any water body may cause flood like situation, while GLOFs in case of Traditional water level sensors are generally mounted on permanent structure in open environment. Here, weather conditions such as moisture, temperature and humidity affect the sensor and sensor may deteriorate over time resulting in poor performance. In case of satellite imagery or airborne data, processing causes delay, developing latency between collection and processing of the data. Hence development of a system which can be used for prolonged period of time in real time to monitor the water level has become essential. The proposed buoy system solves both physical limitations of existing monitoring systems and existing latency in data transmission. The proposed system is composed of hermetic container which will contain the components of hardware and uses CEP (Complex event processing) using Apache Flink for real time data processing with LoRa WAN. Our proposed system can be employed for disaster situation like GLOFs and can prove to be helpful in that case.

title: Near-Field Height Estimation using Millimeter-Wave InSAR
authors: Yuina Abe, Hiroyoshi Yamada, Kota Murota
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The objective of this research is to estimate the height of near-field object, such as surface variations, that are not clearly visible. In this paper, a millimeter-wave radar-based system is employed, and InSAR (Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar), which estimates the height from the phase difference between two observation points, is utilized for height estimation. A fundamental study on the optimal parameters for InSAR image analysis using millimeter-wave radar is conducted through simulations, and the validity of this application is confirmed through experiments.

title: Optimization and Measurement of Low Stray Inductance Two-Layer Bus Plane for SiC Power Modules
authors: Wing Chun Chan, Nick Wright, Barrie Mecrow, Peter Malkin
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The technology for implementing stacked bus planes in half-bridge power modules is the most prominent solution for enabling high current capability and minimizing switching noise. A significant increase in stray inductance is observed in the commutation path with the use of two parallel coplanar busbars, leading to severe voltage overshoots and ringing during turn-off switching transients. This paper presents three bus plane configurations that characterize and optimize the design of a two-layer bus plane for SiC power modules. All prototypes are constructed by stacking the drain and ground plates with a Kapton sheet placed in between to provide insulation. An energy-based method is performed to mathematically estimate the potential stray inductance of a bus plane or busbar design. A comprehensive investigation into the common direct measurement methods for low impedance characteristic and connection setups incorporating a test fixture is undertaken to identify an appropriate empirical methodology for stray inductance measurements. The measured stray inductance of the proposed design is 22.2 nH, which is improved by 33 % compared to the minimal plane design. The proposed bus plane, with its heavily overlapping design and the shortest terminals, is validated to achieve a significant decrease in stray inductance and maximize magnetic flux cancellation.

title: Dual-polarized Sentinel-1 SAR Data Calibration Using PS-InSAR Technique and SVR Model
authors: Jiangtao Xv, Yong Wang, Dingfeng Duan
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Polarization crosstalk and channel imbalance errors exist in the dual-polarized synthetic aperture radar (SAR) system/data. The error correction is critical for the data's quantitative application in Earth observation. Here, we proposed a novel calibration method that combines permanent scatterer interferometric SAR (PS-InSAR) techniques with support vector regression (SVR) for SAR data calibration in urban environments. Experiments were conducted using the Sentinel-1 C-band SAR data near Munich, Germany. Calibration results using the proposed and corner reflector methods agree satisfactorily. The R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> value between the two calibrated |S<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">vv</inf>| data is 0.98. The value is 0.82 for the |S<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">hv</inf>| data. The results are encouraging in the further study of the dual-polarized SAR data calibration without permanently deployed calibrators (e.g., corner reflectors or active transponders).

title: Stochastic Artificial Neural Networks for Music Chord Recognition
authors: Eric Zietz, Breanna Sanchez, Eugene Chabot, John DiCecco, Scott Koziol
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: For event-driven audio processing, Stochastic Artificial Neural Networks (SANNs) present a viable substitute for conventional Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). Using a simplified surrogate event-based artificial cochlea, this study assesses through simulation a SANN's capacity to identify musical chords in the presence of noise. A study on training noise was performed using (1) spatial-domain Gaussian noise and (2) frequency-domain noise. Spatial-domain noise generates artifacts that is shown to impair performance for some bitstream lengths. Frequency-domain noise training more accurately replicates realworld aberrations, and is show to be successful. Datasets with higher noise levels showed persistent convergence but decreased accuracy. These results demonstrate the potential of SANNs for reliable processing of auditory signals.

title: EANV: An Edge Attention Network with VMamba Block for Semantic Segmentation from Remote Sensing Images
authors: Chenxin Xiao, Tao Xu, Xiaohui Yang, Wenjun Kang, Junyuan Zang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Remote sensing semantic segmentation plays a crucial role in natural disaster prevention and land use/land cover studies. Despite significant advancements in the field, challenges such as inaccurate boundary prediction remain, often leading to misclassification of target regions. In this study, we propose an improved semantic segmentation model, SegNeXt-ENVC, which integrates the SegNeXt backbone with a U-shaped architecture. To capture complementary information from edge and deep features, we introduce an edge-enhanced model that incorporates the Visual State Space (VSS) module with channel attention and the 2D Selective Scan (SS2D) method. This approach improves the processing of boundary information. Additionally, we enhance the upsampling process by integrating the VSS block with bilinear interpolation, further refining model performance. Using SegNeXt as the baseline, we evaluate our method on the LRBS and WHDLD datasets. On the complex land cover of large river basins, the model achieved state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance, with a 1.39% improvement in mean Intersection over Union (mIoU). These experimental results underscore the effectiveness of the proposed structure.

title: Multi-Scale Attention and Contrastive Learning for Signal Modulation Classification
authors: Hongbo Li, Yongyu Ge, Feiyu Yu, Youjia Guo, Jian Zhao
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Classification of radar signals under low SNR conditions is challenging, especially for modulation types such as LFM slope direction and Barker code length. A network with multi-scale attention and contrastive learning (MSAC-Net), is proposed, which integrates multi-scale attention and contrastive learning to enhance feature discrimination. The multi-scale attention module focuses on discriminative time-frequency patterns, making the slope differences between LFM-down and LFM-up more pronounced, while the contrastive learning module enhances the separability of Barker codes with different lengths. Our method significantly improves classification accuracy, achieving a 3% to 5% improvement across different SNR levels and demonstrating remarkable performance in challenging environments.

title: Improved Method for Soil Salinity Mapping With Polarimetric SAR
authors: Tingting Zhang, Yun Shao, Lihua Lan, Baolin Wang, Junwei Bao, Yongming Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In this paper, an improved method was developed to enhance the accuracy of salinity mapping. Soil salinity qualitative classification was performed based on the soil salinity. Salinized soil was categorized into three grades. The soil salinity in each grade was accurately predicted using GA-PLS. When compared to predictions without classification, a significant improvement in accuracy was observed with the classification approach. This demonstrates that the modeling accuracy can be significantly enhanced using the improved method. GA-PLS proves to be effective in identifying the dominant variables for soil salinity inversion across different grades of salinized soil.

title: 3D Insar Time Series for Displacement Monitoring Utilizing Capella Space Mid-Inclination Orbits
authors: Kristof Bognar, David Mackenzie, Todd MacKenzie, David Holden, Nestor Yague-Martinez, Victor Cazcarra-Bes, Shaunak De, Craig Stringham, Gordon Farquharson
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: A major limitation of current-generation InSAR solutions is their limited sensitivity to north-south motion. Capella Space’s constellation of SAR satellites is poised to remove this constraint with satellites in mid-inclination orbits. Here, we present high-resolution 3D InSAR displacement time series estimates for the first time. Combining mid-inclination Capella data with TerraSAR-X/PAZ data, we show that a 3D solution provides sensitivity to previously-underestimated displacement and removes biases inherent to widely used 2D approaches. These results represent a major step forward for InSAR displacement monitoring, paving the way for products that support better risk assessment and decision-making.

title: Federated Transfer Learning for Two-Stage Decoding of LDPC Codes
authors: Linh Nguyen, Quoc Bao Phan, Cheol-Hong Min, Tuy Tan Nguyen
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: The performance of fifth-generation (5G) coding techniques, such as low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes, is significantly affected by the error floor, which occurs in high signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) regions. Federated transfer learning (FTL), with its ability to learn from distributed data, can effectively improve error correction in low-SNR environments and extract crucial decoding features for high-SNR conditions. This paper introduces a two-stage decoding method that integrates layered LDPC decoding with FTL to mitigate the error floor and enhance system performance. Experimental results demonstrate that this approach significantly reduces error rates and improves decoding efficiency.

title: Imaging Glacier Bed Geometry Using Radio Frequency Over Fiber Multi-Input Multioutput Radar Arrays
authors: Daniel May, Olivers Pranis, Dustin Schroeder
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Imaging of the internal structure of glaciers through radio-echo sounding (RES) is often conducted using towed or airborne systems which rapidly cover large spatial footprints. However, the scarcity of repeat measurements means temporal resolution is low. Stationary radar systems used for generating time series data are limited in the number of antenna elements they can support due to the radio frequency (RF) hardware that is typically used. This results in images with poor azimuth resolution, limiting the ability to infer structural changes within the glacier. To overcome this limitation, we integrate radio frequency over fiber (RFoF) hardware into existing radar systems with the goal of constructing and deploying large multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) arrays that can be used for high-resolution timelapse imaging of a glacier’s internal structure.

title: Dynamic Wireless Charging Using Dynamic Frequency Tuning with Sliding Mode Control
authors: Mahdi Salimi, Pedram Asef
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper presents a novel sliding mode control (SMC) based on a dynamic frequency tuning strategy for capacitive wireless power transfer (CWPT) chargers to ensure maximum power transfer and efficiency optimization under continuous misalignments in harsh environments, such as dynamic wireless charging for ground vehicles and offshore vessels. In the realm of maritime applications, complex matching networks like LCLC are known for their stability against misalignment. However, they struggle with efficient power transfer when coupling capacitance varies widely. Our proposed controller dynamically tunes the operating frequency to maintain resonance, ensuring the elimination of reactive power and the maximization of power transfer. Rigorous simulations validate the controller's effectiveness under severe misalignments, confirming that the promising SMC effectively compensates for parameter uncertainties and outperforms conventional approaches in adverse working environments.

title: Hybrid Deep Learning and Machine Learning Approach for Early Detection of Oil Palm Leaf Diseases Using ResNet50-Based Feature Extraction
authors: L Harlinda, Dewi Ernita Rahma, Huzain Azis, Irawati, Ramdaniah, Mahmud Isnan
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: The objective of this work is to develop an automatic classification system that can accurately and consistently distinguish between healthy and Curvularia-infected oil palm leaves, even in the face of inadequate data. The proposed approach uses the ResNet50 model as a feature extractor in conjunction with more conventional machine learning techniques like Random Forest and K-Nearest Neighbors. With a focus on implementation feasibility and efficiency in real-world applications, this combination has shown competitive performance when compared to the end-to-end ResNet50 approach. With these contributions, this study offers methods for diagnosing plant diseases that are intelligent, flexible, and resource-efficient, facilitating digital transformation in the agriculture industry. These findings highlight the potential of hybrid deep learning systems in providing accurate, fast, and cost-effective disease diagnosis solutions for oil palm plantations, particularly in tropical environments with limited resources.

title: Equivariance-Embedded TomoSAR Robust Imaging
authors: Jinyu Qiu, Tianjiao Zeng, Mou Wang, Jun Shi, Shunjun Wei, Xiaoling Zhang, Xu Zhan
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Tomographic synthetic aperture radar enables effective 3D mapping of urban buildings. While deep learning methods have improved upon traditional iterative optimization approaches, they struggle with robustness when processing real-world data that differs from training samples—particularly in terms of building spatial distributions and noise conditions. These challenges can result in degraded spatial features and increased residual clutter, yet this issue remains understudied. To address it, we explore equivariance—a property ensuring that transformations in input data lead to predictable corresponding transformations in output. In urban scenes, buildings appear as prominent components with diverse shapes, lines, and orientations. Additionally, varying noise conditions affect signal scales. Without equivariance, methods may produce inconsistent results when processing these natural variations. By improving rotation and scale equivariance, the method’s robustness is improved. Technically, we propose a two-phase imaging approach. The first phase performs deep-unrolled light reconstruction for each pixel. The second phase uses a spatial feature-enhanced multi-scale equivariant convolutional neural network to enhance both spatial features and equivariance properties. Experiments on both simulated and measured data show that our proposed method achieves better robustness across different signal-to-noise ratios while better spatial feature retrieval compared to the mainstream deep learning-based reconstruction method.

title: A Universal, Communication-Free Inductive Power Transfer System Achieving Uniform Voltage Gain for Electric Vehicle Charging
authors: Mahmoud Issa, Mostafa S. Hamad, Amany El-Zonkoly, David Campos Gaona, Olimpo Anaya-Lara
publish: 2025 10th IEEE Workshop on the Electronic Grid (eGRID)
abstract: As electric vehicles (EVs) continue to gain popularity, inductive power transfer (IPT) has emerged as a promising method for wireless charging of EVs due to its simplicity, safety, and enhanced user convenience. This paper presents a universal IPT system that features a series-series LC resonant circuit and a novel control method that ensures uniform voltage gain across a wide range of magnetic coupling and load conditions. Unlike conventional approaches that rely on predefined operating frequencies or iterative frequency tracking, the proposed method automatically identifies the optimal operating frequency, allowing for faster initialization of the charging process. The system employs a communication-free parameter estimation technique that relies solely on primary-side measurements, thereby eliminating the need for secondary-side feedback. Moreover, the proposed method operates without prior knowledge of secondary-side parameters, even with nonidentical LC circuits, provided that both sides share the same resonance frequency, which can be standardized in future designs. The simulation results confirm that the proposed system outperforms traditional techniques, with the voltage gain remaining close to the theoretical value, and the frequency estimation accuracy exceeding 99.9% under varying coupling conditions. The approach can be easily integrated into existing EV charging infrastructure with minimal modification, offering a universal, cost-effective, and scalable solution for future wireless power transfer applications.

title: Evaluating UAVSAR for Monitoring Relative Water Level Changes in New Orleans wetlands, Louisiana
authors: Changxu Shen, Zixuan Wang, Zhoutan Shang, Yufen Niu, Liquan Chen, Jinqi Zhao
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The New Orleans wetlands in Louisiana, as one of the most productive coastal wetland ecosystems in the United States, play a crucial role in biodiversity conservation and climate regulation. In this article, we conduct a detailed analysis of the L-band interferometric synthetic aperture radar (InSAR) images acquired by Uninhabited Aerial Vehicle Synthetic Aperture Radar (UAVSAR) from 2009 to 2013 to assess UAVSAR's capability in monitoring relative water level changes in the New Orleans wetlands in Louisiana. To validate the effectiveness of our method, we compared the water level change maps derived from InSAR with field observations from gauge stations within the swamp forest. The results show a high correlation (r<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.79) and high accuracy (RMSE = 0.13). Experimental results indicate that long time series L-band UAVSAR data are suitable for monitoring relative water level changes in wetlands.

title: SIGN: Saliency-Aware Integrated Global-Local Network for Cross-View Geo-Localization
authors: Ziqian Mo, Yuxi Sun, Meng Xu, Sen Jia
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Cross-View Geo-Localization (CVGL) matches images from different platforms, such as Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) and satellites, to estimate target locations using geographic data. This task poses significant challenges due to viewpoint differences and scale inconsistencies. We propose a novel CVGL method named saliency-aware integrated global-local network (SIGN) to effectively tackle the challenges of viewpoint differences and scale inconsistencies between drone and satellite images. SIGN employs a transformer-based network for fine-grained feature extraction and utilizes the Saliency-Aware Partition (SAP) module to divide images into key regions for local alignment. The model integrates global feature contrast learning with saliency-aware local block contrast learning to enhance alignment accuracy at both global and local levels. Experiments on the University-1652 dataset show that SIGN achieves state-of-the-art performance, demonstrating superior accuracy and robustness in handling viewpoint variations.

title: Reliable Co-Predictability of Patterns in Decentralized Stochastic Discrete-Event Systems and Polynomial-Time Verification
authors: Hui Liao, Junfeng Peng, Shengzhi Zhou, Guoming Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computational Intelligence and Robotics (CIR)
abstract: This paper studies the issue of reliable pattern copredictability of decentralized stochastic discrete-event systems (SDESs) under the possible failure of some local sites. Firstly, a pattern recognizer is constructed to identify the fault pattern occurrences and the notion of l-reliable pattern copredictability is formalized. In general, even if <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$m-l$</tex> sites fail <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(1 \leq l \leq m)$</tex>, the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$l$</tex>-reliable copredictable SDESs can predict fault pattern. Then, a reliable pattern coverifier is constructed and a condition to verify l-reliable pattern copredictability of SDESs based on the reliable pattern coverifier is proposed, which is polynomial-time complexity.

title: Vaclnet: View Augmentation Contrastive Learning for Limited FOV Cross-View Geo-Localization
authors: Wei Wang, Jinkai Cui, Xianwei Cao, Jingxi Sun, Dou Quan, Shuang Wang, Licheng Jiao
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Cross-view geo-localization identifies the geographic location of a ground-level query image by matching it with the corresponding satellite imagery. Although significant progress has been made with panoramic images, obtaining directionally aligned panoramic images is not always feasible in practical applications. Moreover, when the orientation of ground query images is unknown and the field of view (FoV) is limited, challenges arise due to large viewpoint differences and the lack of information in the ground query image. To address these issues, we propose VACLNet, a framework for limited FoV cross-view geo-localization based on view augmentation contrastive learning. Specifically, to reduce the disparities in FoV and viewpoints between ground and satellite images, we perform view augmentation through two forms. First, we mask the panoramic satellite images based on the limited FoV to create symmetric limited FoV satellite views. Second, we project the limited FoV ground images to a bird’s-eye view (BEV) perspective through geometric transformations. Next, we establish cross-view and intra-view contrastive learning to enhance the model’s robustness to the same scene location under different viewpoints and to improve the perception of surrounding scenes in limited FoV images. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that VACLNet significantly outperforms existing methods in addressing the challenges of limited FoV with unknown orientation.

title: Adaptive Gait Biometrics for Real Time Continuous Authentication
authors: Mehdi Mekni, Emmanuel Ogunwobi, Shannon Russell
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 9th International Conference on Intelligent Systems, Metaheuristics & Swarm Intelligence
abstract: This paper presents a continuous authentication system that leverages gait analysis by integrating real-time image processing and machine learning to overcome the vulnerabilities of traditional one-time verification methods. Utilizing gait—a natural, spoof-resistant biometric—the framework enables non-intrusive, real-time identity validation. A Microsoft Kinect sensor captures 3D kinematic features (speed, stride length, joint angles), which are processed by machine learning models to authenticate users against pre-trained profiles. The system dynamically adapts to environmental variables (lighting, terrain) and mitigates gait variability (e.g., injuries) via confidence-based early stopping, thereby optimizing computational efficiency. Privacy is maintained through encrypted data storage and processing. Evaluations reveal robust performance in controlled settings and scalability for high-security applications such as access control. Although accuracy is promising, challenges persist in heterogeneous environments, underscoring the need for multi-sensor integration. This work advances gait biometrics by balancing security and usability, offering a passive authentication solution that enhances convenience while protecting against impersonation threats.

title: Efficient Lagrangian Grid Based Filter using Spectral Differentiation
authors: Jakub Matousek, Jindrich Dunik
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: In GPS-denied environments, vehicles and aircraft must rely on alternative navigation methods. In recent years, terrain-aided navigation (TAN) has emerged as a widely used alternative, offering robustness in challenging conditions. TAN is particularly well-suited to grid-based filters, which can accurately handle the highly non-linear nature of the estimation problem. However, such methods are typically slow and computationally demanding. This paper introduces an efficient variant of the Lagrangian Grid-Based Filter (LGbF) for non-linear Bayesian state estimation, using spectral differentiation to accelerate the filter's time update step. Traditional LGbFs, though more stable than particle filters and much faster than standard Grid-Based Filters (GbF), still suffer from higher computational complexity. By reformulating the diffusion part of the time update as a heat equation and solving it using spectral differentiation, the proposed method achieves a large computational complexity reduction without noticeable loss of accuracy. The proposed method is validated on a synthetic example with known ground truth, as well as on real-world terrain-aided navigation dataset, demonstrating comparable accuracy and substantial speed-ups over the standard LGbF. The code and the dataset are published on GitHub.

title: Adaptive Energy-Saving Control for Vehicle Suspensions via Coupling and Disturbance Effects Utilization
authors: Menghua Zhang, Jing Zhao, Haokun Geng, Zengcheng Zhou, Zhixin Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: This paper proposes a novel energy-efficient control method for vehicle suspensions that addresses key application-oriented issues, including inevitable disturbance, inherent nonlinearity, state-coupling effects, and energy consumption. Unlike conventional schemes, the proposed method explicitly quantifies the influence of disturbance and state-coupling by designing dedicated effect indicators and exploiting the beneficial aspects of nonlinear dynamics. Positive effects are harnessed, while negative effects are transformed into advantageous contributions, thereby delivering superior robustness, lower energy consumption, and improved response rapidity. Specifically, a fuzzy disturbance observer is developed to accurately estimate the disturbance factors, including both parametric/unmolded uncertainty and external disturbance. Effect indicators are introduced to characterize the positive and negative impacts of disturbance and coupling on the active suspension system, and these insights are incorporated into the design of a novel adaptive controller. In addition, biologically inspired nonlinear reference model is deliberately introduced to make use of favorable nonlinear stiffness and damping effects. Furthermore, Lyapunov’s theory is employed to ensure the asymptotic stability of the overall suspension system. Experimental validation demonstrated that the proposed approach achieves excellent transient performance and significant energy savings, with reductions of up to 80% or more.

title: DiffOG: Differentiable Policy Trajectory Optimization With Generalizability_supp1-3636302.mp4
authors: Yu She
abstract: Imitation learning-based visuomotor policies excel at manipulation tasks but often produce suboptimal action trajectories compared to model-based methods. Directly mapping camera data to actions via neural networks can result in jerky motions and difficulties in meeting critical constraints, compromising safety and robustness in real-world deployment. For tasks that require high robustness or strict adherence to constraints, ensuring trajectory quality is crucial. However, the lack of interpretability in neural networks makes it challenging to generate constraint-compliant actions in a controlled manner. This paper introduces differentiable policy trajectory optimization with generalizability (DiffOG), a learning-based trajectory optimization framework designed to enhance visuomotor policies. By leveraging the proposed differentiable formulation of trajectory optimization with transformer, DiffOG seamlessly integrates policies with a generalizable optimization layer. DiffOG refines action trajectories to be smoother and more constraint-compliant while maintaining alignment with the original demonstration distribution, thus avoiding degradation in policy performance. We evaluated DiffOG across 11 simulated tasks and 2 real-world tasks. The results demonstrate that DiffOG significantly enhances the trajectory quality of visuomotor policies while having minimal impact on policy performance, outperforming trajectory processing baselines such as greedy constraint clipping and penalty-based trajectory optimization. Furthermore, DiffOG achieves superior performance compared to existing constrained visuomotor policy.

title: Dual-Attention ResUNet with Masked Focal-Tversky Loss for Robust SAR-Based Flood Mapping
authors: Atanu Das, S. M. Abrar Rajin, Goh Kah Ong Michael, Shuvodip Biswas, Nabibun Billah, Riasat Khan
abstract: Floods are among the deadliest natural disasters, threatening lives and infrastructure worldwide, and require rapid and accurate mapping for effective emergency response. Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) technique is highly valuable because it operates independently of weather conditions and sunlight availability. However, flood segmentation in SAR imagery remains challenging due to speckle noise, diverse terrain characteristics, and uncertain labels in publicly available datasets. To address these challenges, we propose a dual-attention ResUNet that integrates channel recalibration and spatial attention to capture complex floodwater patterns more effectively. Unlike conventional U-Net architectures that rely solely on encoder–decoder skip connections for feature extraction, the proposed dual-attention ResUNet incorporates both Squeeze-and-Excitation channel attention and spatial attention mechanisms at multiple encoder–decoder scales, thereby enhancing feature discrimination and spatial context understanding in noisy SAR data. For datasets such as SEN1FLOODS11, where labels often contain uncertain pixels, we design a masked Focal–Tversky loss guided by pixel-level validity masks. This approach enables the model to exclude unreliable labels while addressing severe class imbalance. Additionally, conventional VV and VH polarizations are complemented with engineered spectral indices—such as normalized difference, root mean square intensity, and polarimetric ratio—to better distinguish flooded regions from surrounding land areas. Experimental results on the SEN1FLOODS11 and S1GFloods datasets demonstrate that our model achieves 97.50% accuracy, 92.65% IoU, and 96.18% F1 score on S1GFloods. Ablation studies show that dual attention provides an 11.85% IoU improvement over the baseline ResUNet, while the masked Focal–Tversky loss yields a 15.16% gain compared to BCE–Dice. Further hyperparameter tuning of its α, β, and γ parameters improves boundary sensitivity, and robustness tests confirm stable performance under varying speckle noise conditions. Grad-CAM++–based interpretability analysis verifies that the model focuses on meaningful SAR backscatter patterns, enhancing its transparency and reliability. Overall, the proposed system establishes a new benchmark for SAR-based flood detection and provides a strong foundation for future developments in emergency management applications.

title: A computational model of infant sensorimotor exploration in the mobile paradigm
authors: Josua Spisak, Sergiu Tcaci Popescu, Stefan Wermter, Matej Hoffmann, J. Kevin O’Regan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive and Developmental Systems
abstract: We present a computational model of the mechanisms that may determine infant behavior in the “mobile paradigm”. This paradigm has been used in developmental psychology to explore how infants learn the sensory effects of their actions. In this paradigm, a mobile (an articulated and movable object hanging above an infant’s crib) is connected to one of the infant’s limbs, prompting the infant to preferentially move that “connected” limb. This ability to detect a “sensorimotor contingency” is considered to be a oundational cognitive ability in development. To understand how infants learn sensorimotor contingencies, we built a model that attempts to replicate infant behavior. Our model incorporates a neural network, action-outcome prediction, exploration, motor noise, preferred activity level, and biologically inspired motor control. We find that simulations with our model replicate the classic findings in the literature showing preferential movement of the connected limb. An interesting observation is that the model sometimes exhibits a burst of movement after the mobile is disconnected, shedding light on a similar occasional finding in infants. In addition to these general findings, the simulations also replicate data from two recent more detailed studies using a connection with the mobile that was either gradual or all-or-none. A series of ablation studies further shows that the inclusion of mechanisms of action-outcome prediction, exploration, motor noise, and biologically inspired motor control was essential for the model to correctly replicate infant behavior. This suggests that these components are also involved in infant sensorimotor learning.<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>

title: Improving Foot Rocker via Robot-Resisted Gait Training with Self-awareness Biofeedback in Adults with Cerebral Palsy_supp1-3636432.pdf
authors: Jiyeon Kang
abstract: Cerebral palsy (CP) is a non-progressive neurological disorder that impairs motor control and coordination due to brain injury or abnormalities before, during, or shortly after birth. Although robotic gait training can improve overall gait patterns in CP, interventions targeting the ‘foot rockers’ motion, essential for stable weight transfer and effective push-off, have received limited attention. In this study, five adults with CP were recruited to train on a robotic treadmill system in which controlled downward forces were applied to the pelvis during walking, promoting implicit motor learning to develop an improved foot rockers strategy. Following this, during overground walking, participants received distinct real-time auditory cues at heel strike and push-off, providing self-awareness feedback to reinforce and maintain the foot rockers pattern acquired during treadmill training. Post-training analyses reported increased Tibialis Anterior activation during early stance, enhancing dorsiflexion and heel strike, and greater Soleus and Gastrocnemius engagement in late stance for stronger push-offs (p < 0.05). These functional gains were reflected in key spatiotemporal metrics: longer step length, greater toe clearance, a reduced stance percentage, and a shorter double stance time (p < 0.05). Participants also exhibited increased range of motion of the foot and increased knee and hip extension throughout stance, reflecting a more upright lower limb (p < 0.05). Survey responses confirmed that participants acknowledged the resistive treadmill training for strengthening their muscles and influencing their walking patterns, and reported that the auditory biofeedback enhanced their awareness of heel-to-toe contact. Participants emphasized the necessity of incorporating both interventions, highlighting its potential as a promising approach to improving foot rockers and overall gait pattern in adults with CP.

title: Modeling and Analysis of Land-to-Ship Maritime Wireless Channels at 5.8 GHz
authors: Shu Sun, Yulu Guo, Meixia Tao, Wei Feng, Jun Chen, Ruifeng Gao, Ye Li, Jue Wang, Theodore S. Rappaport
abstract: Maritime channel modeling is crucial for designing robust nearshore communication systems, yet reliable models that account for the dynamic marine environment with varying sea waves, wind conditions, and vessel motions remain scarce. This article investigates land-to-ship maritime wireless channel characteristics at 5.8 GHz based upon an extensive measurement campaign, with concurrent hydrological and meteorological information collection. First, a novel large-scale path loss model with physical foundation and high accuracy is proposed for dynamic marine environments. Then, we introduce the concept of sea-wave-induced fixed-point (SWIFT) fading, a peculiar phenomenon in maritime scenarios that captures the impact of sea surface fluctuations on received power. An enhanced two-ray model incorporating vessel rotational motion is propounded to simulate the SWIFT fading, showing good alignment with measured data, particularly for modest antenna movements. Next, the small-scale fading is studied by leveraging a variety of models including the two-wave with diffuse power (TWDP) and asymmetric Laplace distributions, with the latter performing well in most cases, while TWDP better captures bimodal fading in rough seas. Furthermore, maritime channel sparsity is examined via the Gini index and Rician K factor, and temporal dispersion is characterized. The resulting channel models and parameter characteristics offer valuable insights for maritime wireless system design and deployment.

title: Stochastic Value-at-Risk based Optimization and Independent Dominating Sets for Wireless Network Design
authors: Pablo Adasme
abstract: This paper studies new deterministic optimization models for wireless network design based on the Independent Dominating Set (IDS) structure. We first present deterministic formulations of the IDS and then extend them with risk-aware objectives using Value-at-Risk (VaR) and Conditional Value-at-Risk (CVaR) under the normal distribution.We compare all the proposed models in terms of solution quality and computational performance metrics such as branch and bound nodes, CPU time in seconds, and MIPGaps in percentages of the best solutions obtained in one hour of CPU time limit compared to the lower bounds reported by the Gurobi solver. Thus, we highlight the trade-offs between deterministic and risk-based formulations. Our contribution also lies in emphasizing the importance of an IDS-based structure as a flexible framework for network design. Subsequently, we show how VaR and CVaR capture uncertainty in transmission distance costs while maintaining tractable deterministic reformulations. Next, we demonstrate empirically how the solutions obtained with the proposed deterministic models can be used as a warm start for the stochastic formulations, obtaining tight near-optimal solutions within a fraction of a second. Consequently, we further propose logic bender decomposition algorithms for the deterministic models to study the scalability of the proposed deterministic models that allows one to obtain high-quality near-optimal solutions that can also be used as a warm start for stochastic models. Our numerical results confirm that the proposed models and algorithms provide near optimal, and optimal solutions for most of the instances tested, and a flexible and stochastic design framework.

title: Auto-Encoder based Structural Correspondence Learning with Pivot Augmentation for Indian Languages
authors: D K Meghana, K Kiran, P Deepa Shenoy, K R Venugopal
abstract: Sentiment analysis in low resource languages has become a challenging task owing to the lack of labeled data. Domain Adaptation method, which uses labeled data from a high resource language like English solves this problem by transferring its knowledge to resource scarce languages. In this study, we propose an Auto-Encoder based Structural Correspondence Learning (SCL) with a Pivot Augmentation method for cross-lingual tasks in Indian languages. Traditional SCL leverage pivot features create a shared feature space across domains, but its effectiveness is limited by the availability of relevant pivot features.
