To solve this problem, we introduce two approaches Auto-Encoder based Structural Correspondence Learning with Pivot Augmentation (AE-SCL-PA) and Auto-Encoder based Structural Correspondence Learning with Pivot Augmentation and FastText embeddings (AE-SCL-PA-FT), which extends the pivot set through automatic translation and synonym expansion, specifically tailored for Indian languages. By utilizing bilingual embeddings, we mapped the non-pivot features into a shared space and predicted the augmented pivot features using an autoencoder architecture. Our method enhances the transferability of models between languages by aligning monolingual embedding spaces without the need for parallel corpora or bilingual dictionaries. Evaluating our approach for different combinations of domains with the Indian Languages Kannada and Telugu, we obtained a considerable improvement in all combinations. The proposed model provides an approach for identifying sentiments in any language without labeled data.

title: Terahertz Time-Domain Spectroscopy for the Characterization of Dielectrics and Foams using Amplitude and Phase in Reflection Mode
authors: Silvia Tofani, Walter Fuscaldo, Tiziana Ritacco, Romeo Beccherelli, Dimitrios C. Zografopoulos
publish: IEEE Transactions on Terahertz Science and Technology
abstract: Amplitude-only measurements have recently been proposed to avoid phase sensitivity issues in terahertz (THz) time-domain spectroscopy (TDS) in reflection mode. These methods, however, are typically applied to open-boundary setups and may fail in scenarios where the Fabry–Perot interference is weak or absent. Here, we show that phase information can be essential in the characterization of low-index materials, such as dielectric foams. We address this limitation by focusing on a grounded Fabry–Perot configuration (i.e., a reflective backplane geometry), which enhances spectral features and allows for full exploitation of both amplitude and phase information. To this end, two effective protocols are developed here to accurately determine the complex permittivity of dielectric materials by exploiting both the amplitude and the phase of THz-TDS measurements. The first method fits directly the physical parameters of established permittivity dispersion models describing the unknown material by minimizing the weighted Euclidean norms of the amplitude and phase errors. This convex fitting approach improves convergence stability, especially when interference fringes are weak. The second method first estimates the optimal real permittivity values from the phase measurements, and then the loss tangent from the amplitude measurements. These mathematical values are then fitted through a suitable permittivity model to ensure causality. Both techniques are tested against materials with different dielectric properties, highlighting the case scenarios in which phase measurements significantly improve the accuracy of material dielectric characterization.

title: A Hybrid-Biased Dual-Band GaN MMIC Doherty Power Amplifier for 6G FR3
authors: Ruijia Liu, Haoyang Jia, Qian Wu, Jing Xia, Anding Zhu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This article presents a novel dual-band gallium nitride (GaN) monolithic microwave integrated circuit (MMIC) Doherty power amplifier (DPA) employing a hybrid-biased carrier amplifier for 6G frequency range 3 (FR3) multiband applications. To overcome the bandwidth limitations imposed by the steep periodic phase requirements of the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\lambda /4$</tex-math> </inline-formula> impedance inverter in conventional constant-voltage (CV)-biased dual-band DPAs, a hybrid-biasing architecture is proposed, where the carrier amplifier operates with a gate bias voltage of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$V_{G1}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> under constant-current (CC) biasing in the lower band to enable reverse load modulation, and with a gate bias voltage of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$V_{G2}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> under CV biasing in the upper band to enable regular load modulation, while the peaking amplifier remains CV-biased across both bands. To validate the concept, a dual-band GaN MMIC DPA covering 10.5–12.5 GHz and 14–16 GHz was implemented in a 120-nm GaN high-electron-mobility transistor (HEMT) process. Measured results demonstrate a saturated output power of 34.5–36.1dBm with a drain efficiency (DE) of 43.8%–48.9%. At6-dB output-power back-off (PBO), the DE remains 32.6%–40% from 10.5 to 12.5 GHz and 30.8%–36.5% from 14 to 16 GHz. When excited with a 200-MHz 256-QAM 5G new radio (NR) modulated signal, the amplifier achieves less than 1.3% of error vector magnitude (EVM) after using digital predistortion (DPD).

title: GA-MAE: Gradient-guided Activation-aware Masked Autoencoder for Remote Sensing Image Classification
authors: Xiangyu Xu, Zhixi Feng, Shuyuan Yang, Mengchang Li, Gechang Yao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: In the field of remote sensing self-supervised learning, the self-supervised learning paradigm based on masked image modeling (MIM) effectively promotes the learning of structural and contextual semantic information in images. However, the random masking strategies employed in past studies have not effectively utilized the distribution of semantic information within images. Furthermore, overly simple reconstruction tasks cannot effectively improve self-supervised learning performance. To address these challenges, this paper introduces a gradient-guided activation-aware autoencoder (GA-MAE). Specifically, this approach computes and captures the spatial spectral activation map (SSAM) with semantic distribution information during the process of backpropagation of spatial-spectral reconstruction loss in the pre-training phase, thereby enabling masking operations on similar visual patches with higher reconstruction loss. Additionally, we introduce an Activation-Aware Self-Attention mechanism (ASA) that adjusts the self-attention dependencies by utilizing the weight information of visual patches provided by SSAM. Extensive experiments conducted on three public datasets (Houston2013, Augsburg, and Berlin) demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach. With only ten labeled training samples per class, the proposed method achieves anoverall accuracy (OA) of 91.24%, 84.69%, and 73.43% on the Houston2013, Augsburg, and Berlin datasets, respectively, indicating improvements of 1.09%, 2.05%, and 2.40% over state-of-the-art methods.

title: RIS-Assisted DF Relay System Based on PAC Codes for Short Packet Communication
authors: Shunwai Zhang, Hong Liu
abstract: In this letter, we propose a reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS)-assisted decode-and-forward (DF) relay system based on polarization-adjusted convolutional (PAC) codes to achieve enhanced ultra-reliable and low-latency performance in short packet communications. Firstly, we derive closed-form expressions for the upper and lower bounds of the ideal ergodic capacity (EC) under Rayleigh fading channels using Jensen’s inequality and Taylor series expansion. Secondly, for practical short packet communications, we further derive the upper bound of the EC with finite blocklength via Gamma approximation method. Simulation results demonstrate the tightness of the derived bounds. The results also show that the proposed system based on PAC coding scheme is superior to the benchmark polar coding scheme and low density parity check (LDPC) coding scheme for short packet communications.

title: OPUS: Optimal Pricing for UAV-as-a-Service Using Bargaining Game
authors: Prince Kumar, Veera Manikantha Rayudu Tummala, Arijit Roy
abstract: This work proposes an optimal pricing scheme– OPUS– for UAV-as-a-Service (UaaS) using a bargaining game. In a UaaS platform, multiple actors participate– end-users request services, UAV owners lease their UAVs, and a centralized service provider allocates UAVs equipped with heterogeneous onboard sensors. A UAV can support multiple applications by moving across task locations, where both its mobility and the operations of its onboard sensors contribute to overall energy consumption. Consequently, energy use directly affects the price charged to end-users. On the other hand, the service provider aims to maximize revenue, while end-users seek to pay a minimum chargeable price without compromising the service quality. Thus, the challenge is to design an efficient pricing mechanism that balances these conflicting objectives. Therefore, in this work, we aim to design a pricing scheme, OPUS, capable of determining an optimal chargeable price by jointly considering energy consumption, time of use, resource utilization, and UAV reputation. Specifically, time-based pricing accounts for the duration of UAV engagement, resource-based pricing captures operational overheads such as transmission and storage, and reputation-based pricing reflects UAV reliability and past performance. We formulate the problem using the Rubinstein bargaining model to ensure a fair trade off between the service provider's profit and the end-user's satisfaction. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that OPUS outperforms existing schemes– QUEST, TMSC, and Yu's strategy– for UaaS. Specifically, OPUS improves service provider profit by an average of 33.7%.

title: Robust Covert ISAC: A Collaborative Sensing and Communication Approach Against Mobile Warden
authors: Bowen Yang, Yao Yu, Xin Hao, Yuchi Lu, Lei Guo, Yonghui Li
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: This paper proposes a novel robust covert integrated sensing and communication (RC-ISAC) system, where mobile Warden tracking is leveraged to assist covert communication design. We focus on a typically overlooked yet highly threatening Warden-blocked scenario, in which temporary tracking loss prevents timely updates of covert communication strategy. To overcome this challenge, the reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) is introduced to establish a controllable sensing link that bypasses the obstacle. Furthermore, a robust extended Kalman filtering (R-EKF) strategy with a sensing-failure fallback mechanism is developed to achieve reliable Warden tracking, where sensing failures are detected and promptly addressed through re-scanning of the Warden. In addition, a high-capacity covert optimization (HCO) scheme is proposed to improve the covert transmission performance and maintain reliable Warden tracking, which is achieved by the joint design of ISAC sensing-communication beamforming and RIS passive beamforming. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed RC-ISAC system achieves superior robustness and covert transmission performance compared with the no-RIS baseline and the element-wise optimization baseline.

title: Meta-Learning and Multi-Kernel MMD Based Decoupled Diagnosis Method for Compound Faults under Varying Operating Conditions
authors: Xin-Zhe Su, Huimin Wang, Guang-Hong Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Existing compound fault diagnosis methods under varying operating conditions often generalize poorly to unknown operating conditions and rely heavily on large labeled sample sets. To address these issues, this paper proposes a novel compound fault diagnosis method under varying operating conditions based on meta-learning and multi-kernel maximum mean discrepancy (ML-MKMMD). First, to improve the model generalization capability under varying operating conditions, a leave-one-domain-out model-agnostic meta-learning (LODO-MAML) strategy is designed to learn the initialization parameters that can quickly adapt to varying operating conditions. Based on this, a training strategy combining MKMMD and contrastive learning is proposed to extract high-quality domain-invariant features. Furthermore, a capsule network classifier is constructed to decouple and classify the faults from the coupling relationship. Finally, the proposed method is verified through a comprehensive case study of two heterogeneous varying operating conditions datasets. The results demonstrate the effectiveness and superiority of the method for generalization to unknown operating conditions and small sample scenarios.

title: The Role of Vegetation Clumping in Regulating Global Heat Fluxes: Based on Land-Atmosphere Coupled Model Runs
authors: Zhicheng Huang, Peirong Lin, Zimin Yuan, Naijie Peng, Dechao Zhai, Qunchao He, Wenjie Fan
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The clumping index (CI) quantifies the deviation of vegetation from a random spatial distribution and plays a critical role in canopy radiation transfer processes. However, its impact on the surface energy balance and atmospheric dynamics remains insufficiently understood. In this study, we integrated remotely sensed CI into the land-atmosphere coupled model within the Community Earth System Model (CESM) to evaluate its influence on global heat fluxes. The results reveal that incorporating CI increases sensible heat flux from the ground while reducing sensible heat flux from vegetation. Similarly, latent heat flux from evaporation rises, whereas latent heat flux from canopy transpiration decreases. These findings highlight the pivotal role of CI in modulating the global energy balance and underscore its importance in climate modeling.

title: MARVEL: An End-to-End Framework for Generating Model-Class Aware Custom RISC-V Extensions for Lightweight AI
authors: M. Ajay Kumar, Cian O’Mahoney, Pedro Kreutz Werle, Shreejith Shanker, Dimitrios S. Nikolopoulos, Bo Ji, Hans Vandierendonck, Deepu John
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Circuits and Systems
abstract: Deploying deep neural networks (DNNs) on resource-constrained IoT devices remains a challenging problem, often requiring hardware modifications tailored to individual AI models. Existing accelerator-generation tools, such as AMD’s FINN, do not adequately address extreme resource limitations faced by IoT endpoints operating in bare-metal environments without an operating system (OS). To overcome these constraints, we propose MARVEL–an automated, end-to-end framework that generates custom RISC-V ISA extensions tailored to specific DNN model classes, with a primary focus on convolutional neural networks (CNNs). The proposed method profiles high-level DNN representations in Python and generates an ISA-extended RISC-V core with associated compiler tools for efficient deployment. The flow leverages (1) Apache TVM for translating high-level Python-based DNN models into optimized C code, (2) Synopsys ASIP Designer for identifying compute-intensive kernels, modeling, and generating a custom RISC-V and (3) Xilinx Vivado for FPGA implementation. Beyond a model-class specific RISC-V, our approach produces an optimized bare-metal C implementation, eliminating the need for an OS or extensive software dependencies. Unlike conventional deployment pipelines relying on TensorFlow/PyTorch runtimes, our solution enables seamless execution in highly resource-constrained environments. We evaluated the flow on popular DNN models such as LeNet-5*, MobileNetV1, ResNet50, VGG16, MobileNetV2 and DenseNet121 using the Synopsys trv32p3 RISC-V core as a baseline. Results show a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2\times $ </tex-math></inline-formula> speedup in inference and upto <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2\times $ </tex-math></inline-formula> reduction in energy per inference at a 28.23% area overhead when implemented on an AMD Zynq UltraScale+ ZCU104 FPGA platform.

title: Ultra Low Power Multimodal Remote Sensing Night Emergency Search and Rescue Model for Resource Constrained Unmanned Platforms
authors: Kefan Li, Yuting Wan, Haoyu Yao, Shiyu Liu, Ailong Ma, Yanfei Zhong
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In nighttime emergency rescue scenarios involving unmanned aerial vehicles, traditional artificial neural network (ANN)-based object detection algorithms are challenging to efficiently deploy on resource-constrained edge computing platforms due to their high computational complexity and energy consumption. In contrast, spiking neural networks (SNN), which emulate the brain’s information processing through sparse event-driven computations, significantly improve energy efficiency. Low-light and infrared images, as critical sources of information for nighttime rescue missions, can provide clear feature representations under low-light and complex environmental conditions. The efficient computational characteristics of SNN are highly compatible with the properties of these modalities, further enhancing their potential for nighttime emergency rescue tasks. For this emergency rescue scenario, this paper proposes a low-power object detection method for nighttime emergency rescue tasks, leveraging the fused characteristics of low-light and infrared imagery and the energy-efficient computational advantages of SNN. The method is based on Spiking-YOLO and was tested on self-constructed emergency rescue tasks. Experimental results demonstrate that, compared to the ANN-based Tiny YOLO, the proposed method achieves theoretical power consumption reduced to 1/2000 of the original network, with performance metrics degradation not exceeding 2%.

title: Feasibility of Large-Scale Soil Erosion Mapping in Queensland, Australia from Interferometric Radar Coherence
authors: Jan Schultz, Pascal Castellazzi, Okke Batelaan, Eddie Banks
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Soil erosion and sediment load into the Great Barrier Reef has increased in the last century, mainly due to vegetation clearing. The increased sediment load reduces light availability for marine ecosystems, can smother corals and seagrasses, increases the nutrient influx and can damage fish gills. While LiDAR data are often used to map erosion hotspots and guide remediation efforts, it is not possible to deploy across all catchments draining into the Great Barrier Reef (GBR) due to the large spatial scale. Here, we test the feasibility of Sentinel-1 (C-Band) and ALOS-2 ScanSAR (L-Band) data using coherence change detection, which maps anomalous InSAR coherence loss during major erosion events, for soil erosion mapping at the scale of the entire GBR catchment.

title: Assessing OLS, WLS, and RLS Performance in 2-DOF Inverse Dynamics Identification Under Limited and Rich Trajectories
authors: Fauzy Satrio Wibowo, Hsien-I Lin, Wen-Hui Chen, Siti Sendari
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative study of three inverse dynamic identification methods: ordinary least squares (OLS), weighted least squares (WLS), and recursive least squares (RLS). The experiment was applied to a 2-DOF robotic manipulator under two excitation conditions. Identification Trajectory 1 (‘ID1’) comprises ten harmonic sinusoids and, while Trajectory 2 (‘ID2’) spans a wider frequency band. We quantify the fidelity of the static parameter estimation via the mean absolute error in nine basic inertial and friction parameters, and assess the precision of the dynamic torque prediction using RMSE and MAE in both the identification and the held test trajectories. Under limited excitation, WLS achieves the lowest parameter error and joint RMSE (0.1173 Nm), closely followed by OLS. Under rich excitation, OLS produces the most accurate parameter estimates, and RLS attains the lowest joint RMSE. These results demonstrate that increasing trajectory richness improves both static parameter recovery and dynamic torque prediction performance.

title: Enhanced Generalized Regression Neural Network Coupled with Stacking Ensemble Learning for Soil Moisture Estimation over the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau
authors: Ling Zhang, Yusha Zheng, Zhaohui Xue
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The existing research on soil moisture (SM) estimation using ensemble learning often directly applies traditional models by constructing a multi-feature variable space and has shortcomings in aspects such as improvements of base models or ensemble strategies. To overcome this issue, by coupling our previously proposed enhanced generalized regression neural network (EGRNN) with stacking ensemble learning, we propose a novel ensemble learning based SM estimation method, termed EGRNN-Stack. Based on the Stacking ensemble learning framework, a primary learner set is constructed using GRNN, EGRNN, and random forest (RF), with EGRNN employed as the secondary learner, thereby proposing the EGRNN-Stack ensemble learning model for SM estimation. Experiments conducted on the QinghaiTibet Plateau during 2015 to 2016 demonstrated that: 1) EGRNN-Stack achieves the best estimation accuracy compared to other methods, with a low variance, indicating a better robustness of the method; 2) The deviations between the SM estimates from this model and the measured values are small, demonstrating its strong capability in fitting nonlinear data; 3) EGRNN-Stack can better reflect the temporal dynamics of SM in the Tibetan Plateau region; 4) The spatial distribution of soil moisture in the Tibetan Plateau overall presents a trend of "more in the east and less in the west, more in the south and less in the north". This work is performed using in-situ SM measurements and other ancillary data.

title: Mapping of Aboveground Biomass Using Local and Global Spectral Features from Hyperspectral Images
authors: Linze Bai, Sihang Zhang, Ke Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The assessment of urban tree aboveground biomass (AGB) is vital for maintaining ecological balance and forest resource management. Utilizing the rich vegetation information from hyperspectral images (HSI), Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) are introduced for HSI feature extraction. To address the limitation of CNNs in capturing only local spectral features, a local-global spectral features (LGSF) extraction method is proposed. This method first transforms 1D spectra into 2D spectral images, and then extracts complementary local and global features that represent the spectral curves, fully exploiting the information between spectral bands. After convolution operations, the features are passed through a regression module for prediction. Based on Zhuhai-1 OHS data, the effectiveness of this method is validated using Hengqin New Area as a case study.

title: Atomic-Scale Insights Into the Switching Mechanisms of RRAM Devices
authors: Md Tawsif Rahman Chowdhury, Alireza Moazzeni, Gozde Tutuncuoglu
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: The growing energy demands of information and communication technologies, driven by data-intensive computing and the von Neumann bottleneck, underscore the need for energyefficient alternatives. Resistive random-access memory (RRAM) devices have emerged as promising candidates for beyond von Neumann computing paradigms, such as neuromorphic computing, offering voltage-history-dependent switching that mimics synaptic and neural behaviors. Atomic-scale mechanisms, such as defect-driven filament formation and ionic transport, govern these switching processes. In this work, we present a comprehensive characterization of Tantalum Oxide based RRAM devices featuring both oxygen-rich and oxygen-deficient switching layers. We analyze the dominant conduction mechanisms underpinning resistive switching and systematically evaluate how oxygen stoichiometry influences device behavior. Leveraging a bottom-up design methodology, we link material composition to electrical performance metrics-such as endurance, cycle-to-cycle variability, and multilevel resistance states-providing actionable guidelines for optimizing RRAM architectures for energy-efficient memory and computing applications.

title: Visualizing the Reduction of Carbon Dioxide Emissions Through The use of Ammonia Co-Firing
authors: Eijin Suzuki, Jun Kato, Sayuri Inoue, Takumi Hashizume, Hirofumi Kasahara, Mitsuteru Kaneoka, Ryo Suzumoto, Tomonori Deguchi, Hayato Ishijima, Benjamin D. Mecklosky, Munenori Miura
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: One measure to respond to the threat of climate change is the transitioning away from fossil fuels, which are the current standard, to alternative fuels such as hydrogen and ammonia. This shift to alternative fuels is not expected to occur immediately; rather, it will be promoted in stages, beginning with the use of co-firing technology and eventually leading to the exclusive burning of these fuels. To achieve these objectives, it is imperative to comprehend the potential of these new fuels to curtail emissions through the utilization of objective measurement. In this study, we conduct an experiment designed to visualize CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions at the ground level. This experiment serves as a proof of concept for the use of alternative fuels in responding to the threat of climate change and by starting with on-the-ground observations, provides the first step to quantifying reductions in CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions via satellite. In this experiment, the CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> concentration emitted was controlled by altering the mixing ratio of kerosene and ammonia. To confirm these results, an infrared camera dedicated to CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> visualization as well as a reference infrared camera equipped with a filter that is distinct from the absorption and radiometric characteristics of other gases, including CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>, were used, such that the camera was to extract only the changes in CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>. This success in ground based visualization of the reduction in CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions through the alteration of co-firing ratios of ammonia fuel provides the first step towards future visualization of CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions reduction through satellite data.

title: Identification of slow-moving landslides in large rugged terrain with enhanced persistent scatterers (PS) density
authors: Ding Xiaoli, Shahzad Naeem, Peng Xing, Liang Hongyu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This study tests an integrated interferometric synthetic aperture radar (InSAR) strategy to map slow-moving landslides in the rugged terrain of Pakistan using Sentinel-1 descending orbit images from January 2017 to December 2022. In this integration, we combined the three persistent scatterers (PS) candidate selection criteria (i.e., spectral diversity, temporal variability, and phase stability) and processed them jointly for deformation modeling. The results obtained through this integration were compared with the standard interferometric approach which resulted in achieving a 2.3 times higher point density. The obtained average deformation velocities range from -60 mm/year to +60 mm/year, with a PS density of 65/sq. km, which also helped identify 2,000 unstable slopes of varying sizes up to 1 sq. km. The study also presents a pre-failure slope deformation trend of a failed slope, with precipitation as a potential contributing factor. The findings may enhance landslide risk management.

title: Overview and Analysis of Electromagnetic Interference Potential in Electrified Propulsion System
authors: Aunanna Rashid, Stefanie de Graaf
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: As the aviation sector advances toward hybrid and all-electric propulsion systems, managing electromagnetic interference (EMI) is of critical importance to ensure safety and reliability. Power electronic devices in electric powertrains generate EMI that can disrupt avionics, communication systems, and other aircraft electronics. Components of electric propulsion system can also be susceptible to EMI from other aircraft system, while external EMI sources, such as lightning strikes, add further risks. Addressing EMI during the preliminary design phase of electrified aircraft, while maintaining power quality, safety and reliability, remains a significant challenge. This paper provides a comprehensive qualitative and partially quantitative analysis of predicting EMI sources and sinks during the preliminary design phase, emphasizing component and topology selection strategies to enhance aviation safety in electrified propulsion systems.

title: An Efficient Real-Time Vision System for Papaya Mealybug Detection Based on Haar Features
authors: Siska Anraeni, Arman, Mardiyyah Hasnawi, Poetri Lestari Lokapitasari Belluano, Tasrif Hasanuddin, Ihwana As’Ad
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: This study investigates the application of camera technology and image analysis using the Haar Cascade Classifier algorithm for real-time detection of mealybug (Paracoccus marginatus) infestations on papaya (Carica papaya) plants. A total of 180 papaya images were collected from plantations in Mamuju Regency, South Sulawesi Province, consisting of 90 images depicting mealybug-infested specimens and 90 images of healthy, non-infested specimens. Image acquisition involved direct field observations and farmer interviews to differentiate infested and non-infested plants, with standardized imaging protocols applied to ensure consistency in distance, lighting, and orientation. The proposed system was evaluated at varying camera-to-target distances, with results indicating optimal detection performance at close range (10-20 cm), where accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score all achieved $100 \%$. Performance decreased progressively with distance, with accuracy declining to 73% at 60 cm and reaching zero detection capability at $\mathbf{1 0 0 ~ c m}$, primarily due to reduced image resolution, increased background interference, and diminished illumination. The model training process, employing quantitative analysis techniques on the dataset, successfully adapted the classifier to the specific visual characteristics of mealybugs on papaya under real agricultural conditions. The findings demonstrate that the proposed approach offers an efficient, real-time solution suitable for deployment on resourceconstrained devices, providing a practical tool to support pest management in papaya cultivation.

title: Influence of Ground Level Vegetation and its Frequency Dependence on GPR-Applications
authors: Michael Schneider, Thomas Walter, Hubert Mantz
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This investigation explores the influence of local vegetation on ground penetrating radar (GPR) system results, with a focus on the variability of vegetation structure and water content. Rather than considering vegetation as a homogeneous entity, this study adopts a multifaceted approach by examining the frequency dependence of water content in leaves alongside the plant structure. This innovative method enables radar-based classification, providing insights into vegetation dynamics in relation to environmental factors. The SFCW radar, operating within the available measurement bandwidth of 0.8 GHz to 15 GHz, generates distinct frequency bands with a constant bandwidth of 4 GHz being a fundamental characteristic of all bands. The varying frequencies result in an enhancement of the influence of scattering and attenuation caused by the plants. Depending on the selected frequency band, different characteristics can be derived. Within the laboratory setting, the system is expanded to include an additional layer in which a target is buried. The combination of diverse frequencies enables the generation for characteristic surface maps of the vegetation.

title: Harmonic Injection for Stability Enhancement in Grid-Forming Modular Multilevel Converters
authors: Lei Jia, Li Peng, Yuxuan Ying, Xinchen Yao
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Injecting appropriate circulating currents can reduce the submodule capacitor voltage ripple in the modular multilevel converters (MMCs) and improve their internal performance. However, few studies have explored the impact of circulating current injection control (CCIC) on the system stability of grid-forming MMCs (GFM-MMCs), especially across a wide range of grid strengths. In this article, sequence impedance responses are modeled for stability analysis. A direct link is established between low-frequency oscillations and the negative damping region in the sequence impedance model. By applying CCIC based on instantaneous information, the sequence impedance of the MMC is reshaped, which reduces the negative damping region and enhances system stability. This behavior differs from its effect in grid-following MMCs (GFL-MMCs). However, the circulating current injected based on the output instantaneous is deterministic, which limits its ability to improve the system stability. To overcome this limitation, a power secondharmonic injection control (PSHIC) is proposed. By tuning the control coefficient, the stability margin can be further extended. The proposed impedance model and stability assessment are validated through simulations.

title: PBO-Based Pattern Replacement for Compacting Diagnostic Patterns to Achieve Complete Diagnostic Resolution
authors: Tatsuya Aono, Toshinori Hosokawa, Masayoshi Yoshimura, Koji Yamazaki, Masayuki Arai
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Defect and Fault Tolerance in VLSI and Nanotechnology Systems (DFT)
abstract: In testing and fault diagnosis for VLSIs, it is important to generate a test set which achieves a high fault efficiency and is able to distinguish a large number of fault pairs. Therefore, diagnostic test generation methods have been proposed. The conventional methods generate additional test patterns which distinguish fault pairs that are not able to be distinguished using an initial test set with high fault coverage. However, since the number of additional diagnostic patterns is large, there is a problem that the size of the final test set becomes large. To solve this problem, this paper proposes a method to replace test patterns which do not contribute much to improving diagnostic resolution with test patterns which improve diagnostic resolution while maintaining fault coverage using pseudo-Boolean optimization for stuck-at faults or transition faults. For stuck-at faults, experimental results for ISCAS'89 and ITC'99 benchmark circuits show that the number of additional diagnostic patterns was 10.3% on average. For transition faults, experimental results for ISCAS'89 benchmark circuits show that the number of additional patterns was 18.0% on average.

title: Simulation of Tropical Cyclone Observation With Different Scatterometer Systems
authors: Ziming Dong, Xingou Xu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Tropical cyclones (TCs) are high and extreme wind conditions, which illustrate different measuring characteristics from common sea conditions of wind field observations in spaceborne microwave scatterometers. There are generally rotating pencil-beam, rotating fan-beam and fixed fan-beam scatterometers in operation. This paper establishes an end-to-end simulation model to evaluate these three basic scatterometer systems for TC observations. The performance of these systems was comprehensively analyzed in terms of both backscattering coefficient measurement accuracy and wind retrieval precision. The results demonstrate that rotating and fixed fan-beam scatterometers achieve superior performance in both backscattering measurement and wind retrieval under simulated TC conditions. Further research will extend this model by incorporating real observation geometry parameters.

title: Multi-View SAR Target Recognition based on Semantic-View Dual-Branch Feature Embedding Fusion Network
authors: Haochuan Wang, Wei Yang, Hongcheng Zeng, Bing Sun, Chunsheng Li, Guanhe Lin
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In the single-view SAR target recognition task, the image features of SAR targets may not be adequately represented from a single observation view, and these features may vary significantly across different observation views, leading to recognition failure when relying solely on single-view images. Existing multi-view fusion methods usually implicitly hypothesize that the views of images are known, which restricts the applicable scenarios. To address these issues, we propose a semantic-view dual-branch feature embedding fusion network, which achieves flexible and accurate multi-view target recognition by utilizing prior view information. The model design mainly consists of three parts: 1) A dual-branch feature extraction module is constructed to extract the semantic features and view features of single-view images respectively. 2) A multi-view feature fusion module is built based on Transformer, which conducts embedding on the dual-branch feature maps and realizes multi-view feature fusion through the self-attention mechanism. 3) A multi-task learning loss function is designed to jointly optimize the tasks of single-view semantic classification, view classification, and multi-view semantic classification. Experiments demonstrate that the proposed method can effectively enhance the accuracy and robustness of target recognition, and it enables end-to-end recognition of multi-view images with unknown views.

title: Impact of Climate trends on Ecosystem productivity
authors: Amitesh Gupta, Karthikeyan Lanka
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Understanding the influence of climate variables—air temperature (AT), vapor pressure deficit (VPD), precipitation (PRC), and soil moisture (SM)—on global vegetation is essential for evaluating ecosystem responses to climate change. Among several vegetation descriptors, the Fraction of Photosynthetically Active Radiation (FPAR) and the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) play complementary roles in assessing vegetation dynamics, thus warranting their investigation. NDVI, derived from optical reflectance data, quantifies vegetation greenness, providing insights into canopy density and biomass. However, it is prone to saturation in dense vegetation and atmospheric interferences, thus is better represented by kernel-NDVI (kNDVI). FPAR represents the proportion of incoming solar radiation absorbed by vegetation for photosynthesis, serving as a proxy for plant productivity and carbon assimilation efficiency. Analyzing kNDVI and FPAR, which exhibit distinct responses to climatic stressors, allows for a nuanced understanding of vegetation-climate interactions. As rising AT and VPD increase evaporative demand, reduced SM availability may impede vegetation productivity. Changes in precipitation significantly influence soil moisture, affecting the physiological functions of terrestrial ecosystems. Alterations in the long-term patterns of these climatic drivers can lead to shifts in ecosystem functioning and altered vegetation composition, impacting regional carbon and water cycles. Examining the spatiotemporal variability of these relationships across regions is crucial for predicting ecosystem resilience and enhancing the accuracy of land surface models. Analyzing vegetation descriptor trends alongside climate variables enhances the understanding of terrestrial ecosystem dynamics in the context of climate change, facilitating advancements in ecosystem conservation and sustainable resource management. This study examines the non-linear relationships between vegetation trends and climatic variables in both global and regional contexts.We acquired spatiotemporally consistent data regarding vegetation descriptors from GIMMS and climate variables from ERA5. After removing seasonal effects from the monthly time series of all variables through Seasonal-Trend decomposition using LOESS (STL), we employed the Modified Mann-Kendall test and also computed Sen’s slope to assess their long-term trends. Subsequently, we employed the Maximal Information coefficient (MIC) to investigate the non-linear association between the magnitude of trends in climate variables and vegetation parameters. We noticed enhanced spatial patterns in photosynthetic efficiency than greening. Vegetation descriptors exhibit significant increases in South Asia, East Asia and Europe. Central and Southern parts of Africa also registered increased vegetation productivity and greenness. However, vegetation conditions have deteriorated in eastern Australia and southern South America. We found a significant increase in AT over northern extra-tropical areas. There is also a prominent decrease in SM in central Africa, central Europe, western North America, the southern part of Australia and South America. Over the same areas, VPD trends show significant increments. Using MIC, we found that the global trend in photosynthetic efficiency is more sensitive to long-term temporal patterns in VPD than the rest of the climate variables, contrary to vegetation greenness, which shows a stronger association with PRC trends. While FPAR shows a greater association with VPD and PRC in the tropics, greening shows a more substantial relation with the same variables in the northern extra-tropics. PRC trend in the tropical and northern extra-tropical regions is the primary factor influencing vegetation descriptors, whereas AT trend exhibits equivalent importance in its association with vegetation descriptors over the southern extra-tropics. Our investigations also highlight regional contrasts in these intricate associations between trends in vegetation and climate conditions. Inferences from this study will be obligatory for further region-specific analysis of climate-vegetation interactions in various aspects of climate change, adaptation, and ecosystem conservation management practices.

title: Geofm Embedding Trajectories for Crop-Livestock-Forest Time Series
authors: Antonio José Homsi Goulart, Matheus Papa, Gustavo Bayma, Ivan Bergier, Sandra Furlan Nogueira, Durval Dourado Neto
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In this paper a new approach to the challenge of mapping integrated crop-livestock-forest systems is presented. A geospatial foundation model is leveraged to produce embeddings for images in examples of remote sensing time series. The embeddings, initially in high dimensional space, undergo a principal component analysis. Embedding trajectories are assembled considering the two principal components of each embedding from an image series, resulting in sequences of points in the plane. Considering time series from different cases of integrated systems, embedding trajectories are presented and the patterns for each case are analysed in terms of visual inspection and Euclidean distance based metrics, suggesting that the framework shows potential to be further explored in classification systems.

title: Multi-Level Feature And Dual-Keys Attention For Remote Sensing Image Captioning
authors: Pengke Li, Wenbo Xu, Yu Li, Boyang Zhang, Xufeng Wei, Haitao Jia
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The encoder-decoder framework is widely used in existing remote sensing image captioning (RSIC) models, with the introduction of attention mechanisms yielding significant results. However, current attention-based captioning models only establish relationships between local features, without considering their relationship with global features. This limitation leads to the generation of descriptive sentences that are weakly correlated with the image scene. To address this, we propose a Multi-Level Feature and Dual-Keys Attention (MFDKA) mechanism. Specifically, in the encoder, both local and global features of the image are extracted. Then, the attention mechanism is used to fuse the global and local features, while an attention gate is employed to filter out redundant feature components from the fused image features. In the decoder, inspired by GLU, we introduce a novel attention block, the Dual-Keys attention block, which improves the effectiveness and accuracy of caption generation by generating "related values" and reverse keys. Experimental results on public datasets demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms existing approaches.

title: Evolution Analysis of the CAMPI Flegrei Caldera Geodetic Anomaly Ground Displacements through the Exploitation of Spaceborne Multi-Frequency DInSAR Measurements
authors: Francesco Casu, Manuela Bonano, Sabatino Buonanno, Claudio De Luca, Prospero De Martino, Federico Di Traglia, Mauro Di Vito, Marianna Franzese, Adele Fusco, Flora Giudicepietro, Riccardo Lanari, Giovanni Macedonio, Michele Manunta, Fernando Monterroso, Pasquale Noli, Giovanni Onorato, Yenni Roa, Pasquale Striano, Muhammad Yasir, Giovanni Zeni, Ivana Zinno
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The Campi Flegrei caldera is an active volcano located in southern Italy that, over the last two decades, was affected by a phase of progressively rising uplift accompanied by increasing seismicity and geochemical anomalies. The ground displacement pattern, which is monitored through GNSS and Differential SAR Interferometry (DInSAR), is mainly radial with a maximum uplift in the area corresponding to Rione Terra (Pozzuoli). Recently, we have identified a geodetic anomaly in the uplift displacement pattern, near the Mt. Olibano–Accademia area, where most of the recent seismicity of the caldera is concentrated. In particular, the area affected by the detected anomaly experiences a reduced uplift with respect to the surrounding region. This anomaly, which is analyzed by exploiting the DInSAR measurements of several spaceborne SAR systems operating at different frequencies, becomes clearly recognizable starting from 2021 and represents a potentially critical area for the caldera dynamics and related hazard understanding.

title: Invertible Networks for Image Augmentation in Interactive Satellite Image Change Detection
authors: Hichem Sahbi
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This paper devises a novel interactive satellite image change detection algorithm based on active learning. Our framework employs an iterative process that leverages a question-and-answer model. This model queries the oracle (user) about the labels of a small subset of images (dubbed as display), and based on the oracle’s responses, change detection model is dynamically updated. The main contribution of our framework resides in a novel invertible network that allows augmenting displays, by mapping them from highly nonlinear input spaces to latent ones, where augmentation transformations become linear and more tractable. The resulting augmented data are afterwards mapped back to the input space, and used to retrain more effective change detection criteria in the subsequent iterations of active learning. Experimental results demonstrate superior performance of our proposed method compared to the related work.

title: A transferable multicriteria flood risk assessment methodology at high spatial resolution: two case studies in Greece and Cyprus
authors: Alexia Tsouni, Constantinos F. Panagiotou, Stavroula Sigourou, Josefina Kountouri, Vasiliki Pagana, Panayiotis Dimitriadis, Nikos Mamasis, Demetris Koutsoyiannis, Diofantos Hadjimitsis, Charalampos Haris Kontoes
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Floods are the most frequent disasters and affect the largest number of people at a global level. In the framework of a Programming Agreement between the Prefecture of Attica and the National Observatory of Athens, a state-of-the-art methodology was developed and implemented in Greece for multicriteria-based flood risk assessment and management planning at high spatial resolution (building block level). The proposed methodology was then transferred, slightly adapted and applied in Cyprus within the framework of the EXCELSIOR project. This work integrates different data sources and modeling tools, including remote sensing, in situ measurements, field visits, decision tools and physical simulations. It is characterized by considerable added value, as it supports the relevant authorities in improving disaster resilience in many aspects, particularly on raising awareness, designing civil protection exercises, implementing flood risk mitigation measures, prioritizing short-term and long-term flood protection interventions, and making rapid responses more effective during flood events.

title: Implementation of Wireless BadUSB as an Automation Device to Perform Multi-step Attack Using P4wnP1 on Raspberry Pi Zero W
authors: I Made Wisnu Bakti Saputra, Septia Ulfa Sunaringtyas, Setiyo Cahyono, Mohammad Syahral, Jacob Lumbantoruan, Rheva Anindya Wijayanti, Stefanus Santori Zen
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: Windows is one of the most widely used and popular operating systems compared to other operating systems. USB ports are open ports and are used on all operating systems. Attackers utilize this port to be able to spread viruses or malware because it cannot be detected by antivirus. This research aims to implement Wireless BadUSB as an automation device to perform multi-step attacks using Raspberry Pi Zero W based on the P4wnP1 platform. The research method used is System Development Life Cycle (SDLC) with an iterative development model. The results of this study show that the Wireless BadUSB device succeeded in automating attacks on the Windows 11 operating system connected to the internet by using a local administrator account and successfully obtaining information about the Windows system, Wi-Fi credentials, and successfully turning off windows defender. In addition, this research also managed to steal passwords from all browsers used and take Instagram cookies on the Google Chrome browser to avoid Multi Factor Authentication (MFA). The attack ended with the deletion of windows run history, powershell history, and chrome extensions. This research provides understanding and insight into how to gain access to Windows systems using Wireless BadUSB automation devices which is important for the development of cybersecurity defense strategies in the face of the impact of USB device attacks.

title: Lexicon-Enhanced Chinese Named Entity Recognition with Temporal Information Integration
authors: Xiaohua Ke, Huiqi Zhu, Jiao Lin
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computational Intelligence and Robotics (CIR)
abstract: The existing Chinese Named Entity Recognition (CNER) methods based on lexicon enhancement do not fully utilize the temporal information in the text and have a weak processing ability for complex information, thereby affecting their deep semantic understanding. This paper proposes a lexicon-enhanced CNER method that integrates temporal information. This method first employs Lexicon Enhanced BERT (LEBERT) to obtain character representations enhanced by lexicons. It then introduces a Temporal Information Extraction Module (TIEM) to process complex temporal information. To better handle the extracted features, an Information Modeling Enhancement Module (IMEM) is also incorporated. This module filters out redundant information, enabling the model to focus on key information and further improving the recognition performance of the model. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model outperforms other baseline models on three public datasets, thereby validating its effectiveness.

title: Tracking the Invisible Enemy: Methane Detection Using Machine Learning Methods
authors: Agata M. Wijata, Nicolas Longépé, Jakub Nalepa
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Detecting methane in airborne and satellite hyperspectral images (HSIs) can play a crucial role in environmental monitoring, as timely and spatially-scalable actions to reduce emissions and address unexpected super-emitters are of critical importance. We tackle this challenge and propose a machine learning process—coupling unsupervised clustering for determining superpixels with supervised models for their later classification—for the detection of methane, with the ultimate goal of making it flexible and deployable on board a satellite. Such a solution not only potentially offers global scalability, but can act as an intelligent data prioritization step, as only HSI containing methane can be transmitted for further analysis. Our experimental study performed over the STARCOP dataset demonstrated that the suggested pipeline can precisely detect methane in a limited number of spectral bands.

title: Multi-Feature Fusion Network for Polarimetric SAR Aircraft Target Detection
authors: Ping Han, Jielong Zhou, Jirui Bai, Cheng Fang, Ruihua Liu, Zhizheng Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In deep learning-based synthetic aperture radar (SAR) image aircraft target detection, detection accuracy is affected by limited target number, small target sizes and unclear texture structures. To tackle these issues, a multi-feature fusion network based on the YOLOv10M framework is proposed. By using polarization information of the targets for more feature extraction, a network with three-channel input is designed in the backbone. To enhance the extraction capabilities of texture and deep features, a Reparameterized Convolution based on channel Shuffle (RCS) module is employed in the Backbone and Neck part. In addition, a new hybrid loss function is constructed to enhance the localization capability of detection boxes for small targets. Experimental results on the UAVSAR dataset demonstrate that the proposed network achieves map50 and map50-95 scores of 83.4% and 67.5% respectively, representing improvements of 8.1% and 18.0% over the YOLOv10M model and outperforming typical single-stage target detection and traditional detection methods.

title: Temporal U-KAN: Exploring the Potential Of U-KAN for Cloud and Haze Removal
authors: Qingwei Tong, Qinling Dai, Leiguang Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Cloud and haze removal is a critical task in remote sensing image analysis, as it significantly impacts the accuracy of subsequent image interpretation tasks, such as land cover classification and change detection. Recently, Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks (KANs) have gained attention as a promising alternative to traditional Multi-Layer Perceptrons (MLPs), due to their more robust performance in approximating high-dimensional functions. In this paper, we propose Temporal U-KAN, the first application of the U-KAN network to the cloud removal task. Our method introduces pseudo-temporal modeling to simulate the dynamic process of cloud evolution over time. By embedding a time variable to capture the dynamic changes of clouds and integrating KAN layers, we explore the potential of Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks in cloud removal tasks. We compare Temporal U-KAN with state-of-the-art methods, demonstrating its effectiveness in cloud removal, particularly in significantly reducing parameter count and training time.

title: Detecting Partial Updates in Elsevier’s SDG Mappings: Diff-Based Workflows for Efficient Version-Aware Reprocessing
authors: Muhammad Jauharul Fuady, Aji Prasetya Wibawa, Dika Aurelya Aleandra Taroreh, Adelia Miftakul Janah, Anissa Alifia Putri
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: Sustainable Development Goal mappings provide structured, query-based frameworks for linking scholarly publications to global sustainability targets. The Elsevier SDG Mapping dominates this domain, yet its evolving Boolean queries introduce hidden label drift that necessitates frequent reprocessing of publication corpora as a computationally prohibitive task for large-scale bibliometric datasets. This study presents a lightweight diff-based methodology to detect partial updates across five releases (2019-2025), enabling selective reprocessing only when definitional changes occur. Pairwise comparison of 80 query pairs reveals $\gt 50 \%$ of version transitions modify fewer than half the SDGs (e.g., 2023-2025: $7 / 16$ changed). Syntax normalization and systematic differencing capture subtle changes, ensuring reclassification targets exclusively affected publications. The resulting workflow reduces redundant computation by $\mathbf{\gt 8 0 \%}$ for minor updates without compromising accuracy. Identification of persistent datapoints surviving definitional updates offers future pathways for high-confidence corpora. Version-aware query differencing maintains reproducibility, efficiency, and transparency in sustainability research analytics.

title: A Sensitivity Analysis of PSO Parameters in SVM Hyperparameter Tuning for Ultrasound Breast Cancer Classification
authors: Muhammad Ridho Ramadhan, Ahmad Ataka Awwalur Rizqi, Hanung Adi Nugroho
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: Support Vector Machine (SVM) is a widely used algorithm for breast cancer classification, but its performance critically depends on the tuning of its hyperparameters. While Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) is prominent for such tasks, its internal parameters are often chosen without a systematic investigation, potentially leading to suboptimal results. This study addresses this gap by designing several experimental scenarios to carry out a systematic sensitivity analysis of several key PSO parameters, which include population size, number of iterations, inertia weight, and acceleration coefficients, for SVM hyperparameter tuning using UDIAT ultrasound breast cancer dataset. We implemented a multi-objective PSO using a weighted-sum fitness function to optimize for accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity simultaneously. The experimental results demonstrate that a moderate configuration of $\mathbf{5 0}$ particles and 50 iterations provides the best balance between the performance model and computational efficiency. Furthermore, the analysis reveals that a balanced inertia weight ($\boldsymbol{w}=\mathbf{0. 5}$) and balanced acceleration coefficients ($c_{1}=1.5, c_{2}=1.5$) are crucial for effective convergence. These findings provide useful insights for future research into how to configure PSO parameters more efficiently in the medical image classification.

title: A Modified Ambiguity Matrix Resolution Algorithm for Time-Division multi-PRF Passive Bistatic Radar
authors: Peng Zhao, Pengbo Wang, Tao Tang, Chang Chai
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Passive bistatic radar are widely used for target detection and tracking due to their unique bistatic geometric configuration. However, traditional Doppler radar struggles to detect long-range, high-speed targets. Inevitably, it leads to range ambiguity, Doppler ambiguity, or both occurring simultaneously. This paper proposes a modified ambiguity matrix algorithm for time-division multiple pulse repetition frequency (TD-multi-PRF) passive bistatic radar systems to address the two-dimensional ambiguity problem under a constant acceleration (CA) motion model and suppress false alarms. To improve data processing efficiency and reduce storage burden, the simultaneous transmission of multiple PRF signals was replaced with time-division transmission mode. The proposed algorithm was validated using TD-multi-PRF passive bistatic radar simulation experiment and performs well. The average optimal sub-pattern assignment (OSPA) range in the simulation experiment is 0.3269.

title: Analysis of a New Modular E-Type Consequent Pole Flux Reversal Motor
authors: Mohammad Reza Sarshar, Mohammad Amin Jalali Kondelaji, Pedram Asef, Mojtaba Mirsalim
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel modular consequent pole flux reversal permanent magnet (CPFRM) motor, which improves air-gap flux density and enhances performance under both no-load and full-load conditions. The improvement in air gap flux is demonstrated through a simplified magnetic equivalent circuit (MEC) in comparison with a conventional flux reversal motor (FRM). Furthermore, the proposed CPFRM is optimized using a genetic algorithm (GA) to maximize average torque while minimizing torque ripple. Performance enhancements over conventional motors are analyzed using finite element analysis (FEA) under no-load, full-load, and overload conditions. FEA results validate the superiority of the proposed motor, showing a 33.3% and 7.1% increase in full-load torque compared to fluxswitching and flux-reversal PM motors, respectively. Additionally, the motor prototyping procedure is described in detail. A comprehensive conclusion summarizes the key findings.

title: The 10m-Resolution Global Leaf Chlorophyll Content Product
authors: Hu Zhang, Jing Li, Chenpeng Gu, Xiaohan Wang, Qinhuo Liu, Jiachen Li
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The leaf chlorophyll content (LCC) is a crucial parameter indicating vegetation’s photosynthetic activity. However, the resolution of current global LCC products ranges from 300m to 500m, and the existing 30m-resolution Multisource data Synergized Quantitative remote sensing production system LCC (MuSyQ LCC) product is only available in China region, resulting in a lack of global high-resolution LCC products. This study used an empirical relationship method based on the chlorophyll sensitive index to produce a high-resolution global LCC product (MuSyQ Global LCC) using the Google Earth Engine platform. The validation result shows the accuracy of 500m-resolution MuSyQ Global LCC is slightly higher than the MODIS LCC and the accuracy improves when the resolution increases. The 10m-resolution LCC product has an RMSE of 15.33 μg/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.27. The high-resolution MuSyQ Global LCC product can show more detailed spatial distribution than the existing MODIS LCC product, indicating its ability in precision agriculture, forestry monitoring, and related research.

title: A Dual-Loop CDR with an Extended Bidirectional Frequency Detection Technique for Wide Tuning Applications
authors: Pratik Anand, Rajesh Mahadev, Khanh M Le, Zia Abbas
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a dual-loop reference-less Clock and Data Recovery (CDR) architecture implemented in TSMC 28 nm CMOS technology for PCIe Gen3 applications. The proposed design features an extended BiDirectional Frequency Detector (BFD) that enables rapid frequency acquisition in both directions over a wide locking range. By utilizing <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$D N_{F A S T}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$D N_{\text {SLOW }}$</tex> signals, the BFD dynamically adjusts the correction rate based on frequency error, ensuring accurate frequency tracking and a seamless transition from frequency acquisition to phase tracking. This approach significantly enhances the locking performance and stability of the CDR system. The proposed CDR achieves a locking time of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.1 \mu s$</tex> when transitioning from PCIe Gen1 (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{2. 5 ~ G b p s}$</tex>) to PCIe Gen3 (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{8 ~ G b p s}$</tex>) under a PRBS7 pattern with a power consumption of 3.9 mW at 0.9 V power supply.

title:
Using Automated Machine Learning with Multi-Source Satellite Data to Predict Daily Net CO
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    Exchange at a Moso Bamboo Forest in Subtropical China
authors: Ngoc Tu Nguyen, Wei He, Haishen Lv, Hua Yang, Shuai Liu, Mengyao Zhao, Xinhui Lei
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Bamboo forests play an important role for land carbon sink in subtropical China, yet little is known on the magnitude and distribution of bamboo carbon sink because of modeling capacity deficiency. Here, based on eddy covariance measurements and multiple remote sensing data, we apply state-of-the-art automated machine learning (AutoML) technique to predict carbon dioxide fluxes on a daily scale at a subtropical Moso bamboo forest in China and investigate their controls. Our results show the AutoML (Lazy Predict) performed well in the prediction of net ecosystem exchange of CO2 (NEE) fluxes. Among the different ML algorithms in the Lazy Predict library, the Histogram-based Gradient Boosting Regression Tree performed the best, with R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.99 and RMSE of 0.14 gC m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-2</sup> s<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-1</sup> for the training set and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.95 and RMSE of 0.32 gC m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-2</sup> s<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-1</sup> for the testing set respectively. Using the SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP), we further found that FAPAR, LAI, and SIF are the main feature variables for predicting NEE of the bamboo forest. This study provides useful guidance to the modeling of carbon fluxes, which would advance our understanding of the carbon sequestration capacity of bamboo forests in China.

title: A Wet Snow Detection Method Considering SAR Temporal Characteristics
authors: Wei Ma, Jiancheng Shi, Yang Lei, Jinmei Pan, Lingmei Jiang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Timely and accurate monitoring of the dry or wet state of snow is crucial for climate change research and snow disaster early warning. Since microwave signals are highly sensitive to changes in snow wetness, this study proposes a new wet snow identification method based on Sentinel-1 imagery during the snowmelt season (February to July 2021) in the Sierra Nevada Mountains, western United States. Combining theoretical and empirical analyses, the method calculates the snowmelt runoff onset date (ROD) using the temporal characteristics of backscatter. Snow after this date is classified as wet snow, effectively improving the accuracy of wet snow detection. Validation against ground-based observations demonstrates that the overall accuracy the overall accuracy of wet snow detection reached 0.79, effectively addressing the underestimation of wet snow areas caused by backscatter threshold-based methods. In the future, this method will be further validated and evaluated across additional regions using more ground measurements.

title: High Performance Computing Research Landscape: A Topic Modeling Approach
authors: Hwasun You, Myunggwon Hwang, Jangwon Choi
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society Conference - Global (TEMSCON Global)
abstract: High-performance computing (HPC) is a key research infrastructure and a strategic technology for countries that supports innovation in the nation, economy, and society as a whole. In particular, the importance of HPC is being emphasized further due to the explosive increase in data and the advancement of artificial intelligence in the era of digital transformation. Competition is emerging among countries to take the lead in the market growth trend of HPC, and policy support is being strengthened. Therefore, this study aimed to analyze the HPC research landscape. To this end, the study collected paper data and performed LDAbased topic modeling analysis. The analysis resulted in six topics: Resource Management and Utilization, Modeling and Simulation, Computational Science in HPC, Energy Efficiency Technologies for HPC, Data Analytics in HPC, and HPC Architecture and Infrastructure. It was confirmed that recent research is focused on HPC utilization. The results of this study will contribute to the establishment of new policies to promote the use of HPC in the future.

title: Generative Approach for Building Change Detection in Temporary Settlement Areas for Humanitarian Emergency Response
authors: Getachew W. Gella, Stefan Lang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Information about buildings and building change is essential for many practical applications, especially for humanitarian emergency response in temporary settlement areas hosting forcibly displaced people. In a classical building change detection approach, pairs of pre- and post-images and corresponding annotations indicating building change are required. This approach has two critical limitations. First, it is inefficient in time-sensitive applications like emergency response to create annotations, which is constrained by the availability of post- and pre-event images and is hard to create sufficient annotations in a limited response time. Second, even under normal circumstances, changed objects could be rare and getting sufficient change examples to train a change detection model is a challenging task. We followed a generative approach to generate synthetic bi-temporal images from a single-time image to train a change detection model. Our results show that the generative models employed managed to generate bi-temporal images with structural and style similarity. A change detection model trained on the generated synthetic dataset has achieved a mAP ranging from 4.7% to 42.6% without accessing real bi-temporal building change annotations.

title: Rapid Prototyping of Analog Spiking Neuron for MNIST Classification Using Hardware-in-the-Loop
authors: Parker Allred, David Nichols, Collin Lambert, Ammon Wolfert, Soojin Kim, Matthew R. Linford, Barry Lunt, Shiuh-hua Wood Chiang
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: This paper presents the rapid prototyping of an analog spiking neuron for MNIST classification using hardware-in-the-loop to construct a convolution neural network (CNN). The neuron is implemented as a voltage-mode neuron using an op amp to perform time-domain integration of the synaptic inputs. The synapse is realized with a digital-to-analog converter (DAC) that modulates the input voltage spike magnitude by the synaptic weight. A switched-capacitor bank implements the feedback capacitor allowing a tunable constant of integration. A time-multiplexed approach emulates a fully parallel convolution neural network (CNN). The system employs commercial off-theshelf components (COTS) to realize the neuron design, making it suitable for rapid, low-cost prototyping prior to full-scale integrated circuit (IC) implementation.

title: Accelerating Generative Adversarial Network for Hyperspectral Anomaly Detection
authors: Kun Yu, Zebin Wu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Hyperspectral anomaly detection is an important research in the remote sensing domain. In previous studies, deep learning has been successfully applied to anomaly detection. However, due to the complex backgrounds and redundant spatial-spectral information in hyperspectral images, anomaly detection still faces challenges in feature extraction and processing efficiency. In this paper, we propose an efficient hyperspectral anomaly detection method based on Generative Adversarial Network (GAN). First, a croase detection is performed to identify widely distributed background pixels. The background pixels selected are then used as training samples for the GAN model. Upon generating the background, the RX detector is employed to identify anomalies by analyzing the residuals between the original image and the generated background. Furthermore, a parallel optimization strategy for the GAN framework is introduced, substantially reducing data processing time. Experimental results on hyperspectral image datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed method.

title: DGSM-TM: A Saliency-Guided Multi-Scale Transformer For Remote Sensing Image Captioning
authors: Boyang Zhang, Wenbo Xu, Yu Li, Pengke Li, Haitao Jia
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The encoder-decoder framework and attention mechanisms have significantly advanced the performance of remote sensing image captioning (RSIC) models. However, existing attention-based captioning models primarily focus on relationships between local features, failing to effectively integrate global features and highlight salient regions, thus hindering the generation of accurate scene descriptions. To address these challenges, we propose the Detail-Global Saliency-guided Multi-scale Transformer Model (DGSM-TM), which combines a dual-branch encoder with a multi-scale decoder framework. In the encoding stage, saliency maps are generated via a pixel-level saliency assessment task, and a Detail-Global Saliency-guided Fusion Module (DGSFM) is introduced to merge global and detailed features, significantly enhancing the representation of critical regions. In the decoding stage, a Multi-head Dilation Cross-Attention (MDCA) mechanism is employed to effectively capture relationships between local and global features through multi-scale attention, generating more precise descriptive sentences. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed DGSM-TM model achieves superior performance on the UCM-Captions and RSICD datasets.

title: Toward Spectrally Integrated Water Cloud-Precipitation Retrievals with Hyperspectral Microwave Radiometers
authors: I. Fenni, K-S. Kuo
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: NASA’s Instrument Incubator Program funded a hyperspectral microwave instrument in 2021, focusing on Earth’s planetary boundary layer (PBL) remote sensing applications. While the instrument’s primary application is on PBL’s thermodynamic sounding, it also offers an opportunity to improve water cloud and precipitation retrievals with better spectral constraints. The shapes of liquid waterdrops in water clouds and precipitation are mostly spherical, to which the Mie solution is applicable to solve for their electromagnetic scattering. The essential variable of Mie solutions is mkd (or equivalently mkr), where m is the complex refractive index of water, k = 2π/λ the angular wavenumber, and d (r) the diameter (radius) of the waterdrop. Consequently, spherical waterdrops’ single-scattering properties, e.g., extinction and scattering efficiencies Q<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">e</inf> and Q<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">s</inf>, are functions of mkd alone. This provides a convenient pathway to parameterize water-drop single-scattering properties across the electromagnetic spectrum. In this paper, we first demonstrate that the numerical Mie solution depends indeed only on mkd. We then present our attempt to parameterize extinction efficiency across the microwave spectrum 6-250 GHz and across drop radius.

title: Closed-Loop Control of a Three-Phase IPT System Based on Periodic Mutual Inductance Estimation
authors: Bita Esmaeili Jamakani, Carl Ngai Man Ho, David R. Swatek
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper proposes a closed-loop control method for a three-phase inductive power transfer (IPT) system, incorporating periodic mutual inductance calculations based on voltage and current measurements. In conventional open-loop systems, even a slight variation in mutual inductance between the transmitter pad (TP) and receiver pad (RP) can cause excessive current flow, leading to increased power loss and reduced efficiency. To address this, the proposed control system continuously monitors mutual inductance by extracting phase and amplitude information from voltage and current signals. Using this data, the system dynamically adjusts the gate signals to optimize current regulation and minimize switching and conduction losses. The effectiveness of the proposed method is validated through analytical analysis and simulation results for a 3.3 kW IPT system.

title: Vessel-DINO: Multimodal Foundation Models for Maritime Vessel Detection
authors: Chenyu Li, Danfeng Hong, Bing Zhang, Jocelyn Chanussot
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Due to limitations in sensor imaging capabilities, most maritime vessel detection techniques currently rely on single-modal imagery (e.g., SAR, infrared, or visible light). However, these approaches often struggle to effectively extract, represent, and distinguish vessel features. To address these challenges, we propose a novel multimodal foundation model, called Vessel-DINO, within the DINO detection framework.
