Vessel-DINO consists of three main parts: multimodal information extraction and alignment via ViT-based pretrained foundation models, multi-scale fusion and feature embedding, and a DINO-like detection head. In addition, we introduce a new dataset, Vessel-10k, including 12210 images, partly collected from existing well-known datasets. Extensive experiments on Vessel-10k demonstrate that Vessel-DINO achieves state-of-the-art performance, highlighting its potential for advancing maritime vessel detection.

title: Change Detection of Bridge Behavior Based on Insar Time Series Analysis: A Case Study of Steel Rod Breakage at a Girder Edge
authors: Kosuke Kinoshita, Yukihiro Yano, Takahiro Kumura
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This paper reports on a result of deformation analysis using time-series InSAR data for a prestressed concrete (PC) bridge in Japan. This bridge had a 20 cm bump accident in the past due to steel rods (tensile members) breakage at the girder edge. This report includes the following two analysis results utilizing the measurement data collected over six years, including the accident date: 1. Accuracy evaluation of InSAR displacement by comparing it with an in-situ measured data of the bridge after the accident, 2. Identification of the behavior change timing at which the steel rods failed. In the analysis, deformation modeling based on an extended PSI method is applied to efficiently extract the structural displacement from the limited reflection points on the bridge. In addition, a change detection method that focuses on anomalous deformation, excluding thermal-expansion displacement, is proposed to identify the behavior change timing. As a result, the following were revealed: 1. High consistency was confirmed between the InSAR displacement and the actual measured data. 2. The center of the span moved downward and the girder edge moved upward, which are thought to be the result of the steel rods degradation. 3. As the result of behavior change detection, it was found that the deformation velocity had increased by about five times at both the center and the edge from about one year before the accident, and the timing of the change, which is considered to be the steel rods breakage, was detected.

title: Integrated Design of Hybrid Random Number Generators on FPGA: Combining TRNG and PRNG for Enhanced Security
authors: Shelby Williams, Sonia Akter, Kasem Khalil, Magdy Bayoumi
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: This work introduces a hybrid random number generator (HRNG) combining true and pseudo-random sources to improve randomness thus security, balancing overhead, and enhancing scalability. The design incorporates Ring Oscillators to generate true random seeds for fibonacci Linear feedback shift register (LFSR) each time a new encryption key is needed. It is tested with NIST, Diehard, and other suites to ensure statistical validity, with a 96.8 % passing rate among all random tests. This indicates high randomness with close to zero autocorrelation coefficients and high entropy. Finally, it is synthesized in 14 nm, 32 nm, and 45 nm technology nodes to analyze area, power, and frequency trade-offs.

title: Effective Hyperspectral Plant Canopy Image Classification Using an Enhanced Hybrid-CNN
authors: Keng-Hao Liu, Hung-Yi Chien, Chinsu Lin
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Plant species recognition is critical in various research domains. In recent years, deep learning approaches, particularly Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), have achieved notable success in this task. Studies have shown that integrating hyperspectral imaging (HSI) with hybrid 3D-2D CNN classifiers can significantly improve recognition accuracy. However, CNN performance may degrade when training data are insufficient, primarily due to limited sample diversity. In addition, the high spectral redundancy of HSI, where adjacent bands carry similar information, can further reduce classification accuracy. To address this issue, this study proposes an Enhanced Hybrid CNN (EH-CNN) for highaccuracy plant canopy image classification. The EH-CNN incorporates optimization strategies such as factorized 3D convolution, multilevel feature fusion, and residual blocks to improve feature learning efficiency. The experiment was conducted on a hyperspectral canopy image dataset comprising 140 plant species. To validate the feature learning capability of the EH-CNN, Class Activation Mapping (CAM) visualization was employed for comparison with a reference model. Experimental results demonstrate that the EH-CNN significantly outperforms the baseline model, achieving up to 98% accuracy. CAM results confirm that the EH-CNN effectively captures critical features necessary for distinguishing plant species.

title: Field by Field: Moving from Area-Based Metrics to Instance-Level Agricultural Parcel Assessment
authors: Quentin Yeche, Dino Ienco, Raffaele Gaetano
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In this work, we introduce a comprehensive framework for the evaluation of agricultural parcel delineation methods that rely on binary semantic segmentation models. The framework consists of three main components: a binary semantic segmentation model trained specifically on parcel interiors, a watershed-based post-processing approach for parcel instance retrieval, and the application of Hoover metrics. We compare several state-of-the-art deep learning architectures. Our analysis reveals that traditional metrics, such as IoU and F1-score may fail to capture important qualitative differences between methods, particularly in their ability to separate adjacent parcels. Consequently, we adopt Hoover metrics to provide more nuanced insights into model performance by categorizing instance detection outcomes. This approach offers a pathway to transition from overall area-based metrics to instance-level analysis for agricultural parcel assessment.

title: A Generative Approach for Self-Supervised TomoSAR Multidimensional Imaging
authors: Liang Liu, Tianjiao Zeng, Mou Wang, Jun Shi, Shunjun Wei, Xiaoling Zhang, Xu Zhan
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Tomographic synthetic aperture radar (tomoSAR) enables effective 3D mapping of urban buildings. Recently, researchers have leveraged data-driven deep learning for tomoSAR imaging to extract scene priors. Most current research focuses on supervised learning using deep unrolling, with training data generated through physical model-based simulated measurements. However, the simulated training data may not accurately represent real-world conditions. Therefore, it would be beneficial to explore alternative approaches that can leverage deep learning’s capabilities in an unsupervised manner. In this context, we propose a generative approach using self-supervised learning for tomoSAR imaging. Unlike conventional frameworks, this self-supervised approach decouples the system measurement process from simulation while enabling the extraction of scene priors, particularly spatial features. Technically, we introduce a one-step self-supervised deep generative model for intra-slice prior extraction and cascaded modules of U-Net and LSTM model for inter-slice prior extraction, working together for multidimensional imaging. These modules are integrated into a multi-task optimization problem for complete tomoSAR reconstruction, incorporating the physical measurement model. The corresponding solution method is derived using the proximal gradient algorithm. Experiments on both simulated and measured data show that our proposed method achieves better reconstruction quality in terms of spatial features, effectively harnessing deep learning in a self-supervised manner, just as existing supervised approaches have done.

title: Integration of GNSS-R Derived Soil Moisture into the USGS Wildland Fire Potential Index
authors: Kurtis Nelson, Sreeja Roy-Singh, Vinay Ravindra, Mahta Moghaddam, Archana Kannan, Amer Melebari
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Observations of soil moisture have been found to improve predictions of fire danger as soil moisture impacts both fuel load and fuel moisture. A relative soil moisture process was developed and integrated into the USGS Wildland Fire Potential Index data products. The process uses soil moisture estimates from the CYGNSS GNSS-R constellation and compares current to historical values which then modifies the fuel moisture term in the WFPI equations. Comparisons of WFPI with the soil moisture enhanced version over known large fire events indicate a potential improvement in predicting large fire probability. The goal of this process is to identify areas prone to large fire activity that can be used to target additional CYGNSS observations to assist with wildfire monitoring.

title: SAR Aircraft Target Generation with Attributed Scattering Center Constrained DDIM
authors: Xiang Zheng, Lanyu Zhang, Jiyuan Liu, Ping Lang, Jin Ma, Tao Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The generation of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) images plays a crucial role in automatic target recognition and electronic warfare within the field of remote sensing. At present, most SAR aircraft generation methods suffer from a lack of feature guidance, which leads to an inability to accurately generate the polarization scattering centers characteristic of aircraft. To deal with this problem, we propose a denoising diffusion implicit model (DDIM)-based generation method that incorporates a constraint loss designed around attribute scattering centers (a physically meaningful and concise representation of aircraft scattering centers in high-frequency radar bands), thereby improving DDIM’s modeling capability for aircraft targets. Experimental results demonstrate that DDIM with ASC constraints can produce more realistic aircraft samples than the baseline.

title: Assessing the Spatial Distribution of Forest Water Retention Capacity in Sichuan Province and its Influencing Factors
authors: Feiyang Liu, Mingfang Zhang, Shiyu Deng
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The water retention capacity (WRC) of forest ecosystems has become a hotspot in the field of ecosystem services under increasing global water scarcity. However, the spatial heterogeneity of forest WRC and its driving environmental factors remains poorly understood, especially in large watersheds. Here, we evaluated the spatial distribution pattern of forest WRC in Sichuan Province, China based on an empirical model, coupled with multi-source remote sensing datasets (e.g., IMERG and SRTM) and in situ forest inventory. The key findings are: (1) The long-term mean WRC in Sichuan Province spatially ranged from 14.55 m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>/hm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> to 2,406.87 m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>/hm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. (2) The WRC of forest in the southeastern region was highest, followed by the southwestern region. (3) The spatial distribution pattern was caused by the combined influence of factors such as precipitation, altitude, slope gradient, leaf area index (LAI), and vegetation types. This study provides scientific guidance for enhancing the WRC in Sichuan Province as well as in other subtropical forest regions.

title: Cell - Type Multilevel DC/DC Converter for Green Hydrogen Production
authors: Symeon Fountoukidis, Konstantina Dimitriadou, Nena Apostolidou, Nick Papanikolaou
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The objective of this paper is to introduce a new type of DC/DC converter, which is applicable for green hydrogen production applications. The proposed converter lies upon the introduction of a cell - type interconnection among electolyzer (EL) cells, achieving higher hydrogen flow rate and cell stage voltage control while avoiding undesired conditions (e.g., overvoltages) and being fault tolerant against damaged cells. To further improve system robustness, a secondary stage comprising a step-down DC/DC converter is integrated, providing fast dissipation of excess energy and maintain operational safety during fault conditions. Simulation results validate the converter's performance demonstrating its effectiveness, as well as a thermal analysis is implemented, in order optimized auxiliary semiconductor devices to be selected - achieving higher power density.

title: Refinements to Magnitude Comparison and Bit Replacement in a Correlation Enhancement Algorithm for Stochastic Computing
authors: Tsuyoshi Iwagaki, Soma Onari, Hideyuki Ichihara
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: Stochastic computing (SC) is an approximate computing paradigm that uses stochastic numbers (SNs) representing the probability of a ‘1’ appearing in a bit stream. In certain SC operations, a strong correlation between two SNs is necessary to improve computational accuracy. This paper refines a leading correlation enhancement algorithm by modifying the condition for determining the magnitude relationship when processing SNs sequentially. Moreover, by partially relaxing the conditions for bit replacement and introducing thresholds to control these conditions, more opportunities for correlation enhancement are created. Experimental results show that the proposed algorithm improves correlation and reduces output errors compared with the existing method, with small area overhead and negligible impact on delay. Power consumption increases moderately depending on whether one or both refinements are applied.

title: Finite Field Multiplier Using Single Electron Technology
authors: Chen Zhang, Raqib Ahmed Asif, Hemanth Goganaboina, Chunhong Chen, Huapeng Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: Single Electron Transistor (SET) is a nanoscale device that exploits quantum tunneling and the Coulomb blockade to control electron flow with high precision. This paper reviews single-electron technology and introduces novel SET-based logic gates designed for efficient computational applications. These proposed logic gates are subsequently utilized to implement finite field multiplication. To enable the integration of SET-based logic, several multiplication architectures are analyzed and adapted. The complexities of the resulting multipliers in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbb{F}_{2^{s}}$</tex> are evaluated and benchmarked against conventional MOS implementations, demonstrating significant improvements in spatial complexity for the presented designs.

title: Revealing Stroke Prevalence with Fine-Grained Temperature Indicators in Global Urban Areas: A Long-Term Time-Series Analysis
authors: Dingming Zhang, Li Wang, Xinyu Wang, Ningjing Wang, Wanqiang Yao, Yanfei Zhong
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Epidemiological studies are increasingly focusing on environmental risk for stroke, especially in the context of climate change. To investigate the impact of ambient temperature on stroke prevalence under global warming, while addressing limitations in previous studies that assessed individual temperature factors and neglected population background. For the first time, we conducted an analysis of a fine-grained temperature indicator system—including fundamental, high-temperature, and low-temperature indicators—and its association with stroke prevalence, constrained by global urban boundaries. We found that high and low temperatures are associated with increased stroke prevalence, while extreme temperatures defined differently have different effects on stroke prevalence.Reducing exposure to extreme temperatures in work and living environments is essential for mitigating the stroke risk associated with climate change.

title: Virtual Synchronous Generator Control for Three-Phase Grid-Tied Inverter Using Current Source Type Electric Motor Emulator
authors: Gensui Tanaka, Hiroki Watanabe, Jun-ichi Itoh
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel virtual synchronous generator (VSG) control method for a three-phase grid-tied inverter employing a current-source type electric motor emulator (EME). The proposed method enables both gridfollowing (GFL) and grid-forming (GFM) operations while accurately incorporating the transient dynamics of a synchronous generator's armature. By utilizing the current-source-type EME, the volume of the grid-tied inductor can be reduced, similarly to conventional current-controlled VSG approaches. Furthermore, substituting virtual impedance with a motor model not only provides virtual inertia but also enables GFM operation, which conventional current-controlled VSG schemes cannot achieve. The effectiveness of the proposed method in delivering inertia support and enabling GFM operation is demonstrated through simulation results.

title: Approximate Memory Protection Against Double-Adjacent Bit Errors with Low Redundancy SEC-DAEC Codes
authors: Wenqi Zhang, Shanshan Liu, Yin Cheng, Zhen Gao, Pedro Reviriego, Fabrizio Lombardi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Defect and Fault Tolerance in VLSI and Nanotechnology Systems (DFT)
abstract: Error protection schemes (e.g., Error Correction Codes (ECCs)) must be implemented for memories in safety-critical applications to guarantee a dependable system operation. However, for hardware-constrained systems at the nanoscale, the maj or challenge of employing ECCs is to meet the requirements of both dependability and hardware efficiency. A solution is to further consider the specific protection requirements of different systems, rather than developing only generic ECCs. For example, for some applications like machine learning, data tends to have different importance and only errors on some critical bits can degrade performance. In this paper, an approximate protection scheme using codes derived from original Single Error Correction-Double Adjacent Error Detection (SEC-DAED) codes is proposed. The proposed codes expand the correction capability for several critical bits under DAEs (the most frequent error pattern for memories with advanced technology), while keeping the number of parity bits and decoding complexity unchanged. The design of such codes is established to achieve the maximum number of critical bits that can be protected; examples for protecting 16- and 32-bit memories are provided to verify the theoretically supported number of critical bits (6 and 20 bits respectively). Moreover, compared to existing ECCs with similar protection capability, the proposed codes incur the smallest memory redundancy and lower (or similar) encoder/decoder overhead as per synthesis results. Finally, a case study for protecting the parameter memory of neural networks is presented; results show that although protecting only some critical bits under DAEs, the model with the proposed scheme achieves the same accuracy as in the error-free case.

title: Soil Total Nitrogen Spectral Inversion Based on the DANN Model
authors: Zhenyuan Ji, Ao Yang, Zhiguo Liang, Haoxuan Yuan, Yun Zhang, Yong Du, Yaohua Li
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Soil degradation threatens agricultural sustainability and food security. This study explores the effects of spectral preprocessing methods and machine learning models on predicting soil total nitrogen using the LUCAS2009 dataset. Preprocessing techniques, including first derivative (FD) and detrending (DT), enhanced spectral sensitivity. Machine learning models such as partial least squares regression (PLSR), support vector machines (SVM), random forest (RF), and a novel Density-Aware Neural Network (DANN) were evaluated. DANN achieved the best performance on FD data, with R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.872, RMSE = 1.362, and RPD = 2.795. These findings provide insights into optimizing soil spectral analysis for precision agriculture.

title: Development of a Live Tracking System Using GPS and Backend for Real-Time Emergency Response
authors: Ihsan Muhammad Iqbal, Erna Hikmawati
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: Urban safety challenges, such as crime incidents and delayed emergency responses, reduce community confidence in public security systems. To address this issue, this study proposes a real-time tracking system that integrates a GPS device and SOS button with Kafka middleware and a backend server to enhance emergency response. The system consists of five main components: SOS button, GPS with TCP client, Kafka, backend with RESTful APIs, and a live dashboard. These components work together to collect, transmit, and visualize emergency and tracking data. Experimental testing shows that the backend can process continuous location updates and SOS alerts reliably, while the dashboard provides clear and responsive monitoring. The findings demonstrate the system’s feasibility for improving response speed and safety oversight, with future work directed toward hardware prototyping and optimized Kafka deployment.

title: Joint Retrieval of Cloud Properties Using Attention-Based Deep Learning Models
authors: Zahid Hassan Tushar, Adeleke Ademakinwa, Jianwu Wang, Zhibo Zhang, Sanjay Purushotham
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Accurate cloud property retrieval is vital for understanding cloud behavior and its impact on climate, including applications in weather forecasting, climate modeling, and estimating Earth’s radiation balance. The Independent Pixel Approximation (IPA), a widely used physics-based approach, simplifies radiative transfer calculations by assuming each pixel is independent of its neighbors. While computationally efficient, IPA has significant limitations, such as inaccuracies from 3D radiative effects, errors at cloud edges, and ineffectiveness for overlapping or heterogeneous cloud fields. Recent AI/ML-based deep learning models have improved retrieval accuracy by leveraging spatial relationships across pixels. However, these models are often memory-intensive, retrieve only a single cloud property, or struggle with joint property retrievals. To overcome these challenges, we introduce CloudUNet with Attention Module (CAM), a compact UNet-based model that employs attention mechanisms to reduce errors in thick, overlapping cloud regions and a specialized loss function for joint retrieval of Cloud Optical Thickness (COT) and Cloud Effective Radius (CER). Experiments on a Large Eddy Simulation (LES) dataset show that our CAM model outperforms state-of-the-art deep learning methods, reducing mean absolute errors (MAE) by 34% for COT and 42% for CER, and achieving 76% and 86% lower MAE for COT and CER retrievals compared to the IPA method.

title: Evaluation of a Small and Lightweight Snow Radar in Upper Ice Shelf Imaging
authors: Adrian Eng-Choon Tan, Daniel Price, Pauline Barras, Wolfgang Rack, Christian Haas
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In this paper, we present an evaluation of a snow radar in imaging the cross section of an ice shelf. The snow radar is a small, lightweight and high-frequency (1-5 GHz) radar that can measure the thickness of the snow layer on sea ice. In this study, we planned to further explore the extent to which the snow radar was able to image an ice shelf. A 6 km line on the McMurdo Ice Shelf was surveyed by the snow radar mounted on a sledge and compared with data from a 400 MHz ground penetrating radar. Comparing the radargrams from both radars, we found good agreement in the observation of a brine layer at depths of up to 15 m. In addition, we observed that the snow radar was more effective in detecting finer features, like near surface buried large-scale undulations and the cross-cutting of numerous stratigraphic horizons of fresh ice by the brine layer.

title: U-LAR: Ubiquitous Learning Assisted by Augmented Reality on Learning Computer Network Transmission Media
authors: Akrimullah Mubai, Agariadne Dwinggo Samala, Naseh Ulwan
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: The limitations of using teaching aids pose a problem in the learning of Computer Network Media Installation. Flexibility, mobility, and quantity are constraints in Ubiquitous learning. Therefore, this study aims to create an application that can present teaching aids in the learning of computer network media installation in a Ubiquitous manner based on Augmented Reality. The application is called Ubiquitous Learning Assisted by Augmented Reality (U-LAR). This application was developed using the waterfall model, which consists of the following stages: needs analysis, design, development, testing, and maintenance. The result of this research is the U-LAR application, which can display 3D objects and videos of practical tools from computer network media installation learning. Learning tools or videos for computer network media installation can be displayed simply by scanning the images of the tools from the printed or digital lab sheets. The U-LAR application can be run on Android-based smartphones, which are widely accepted by students, with a positive response rating of 8.51. The results of this study are expected to contribute to the enhancement of ubiquitous learning, particularly in computer network media installation. Future development of the U-LAR application will focus on expanding its capabilities and usability.

title: 22 kW High Efficiency Wide Voltage Range 3-Phase LLC Converter for On-Board-Charger Applications
authors: Jitendra Solanki, Hugues Nijende, Heiko Figge, Peter Ide
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper presents 3- phase LLC as a DC-DC stage topology for 22 kW, 800 V automotive on-board charger. Paper discusses requirements of DC-DC stage of OBC and provides rationale of selection of 3-phase LLC over two parallel 1-phase LLCs. Design of 22 kW 3 -phase LLC is discussed and implementation of the converter using state of the art SiC FETs and SiC diodes is presented. A peak-efficiency of 98.7% is achieved. A very good efficiency of more than 98% is maintained over the wide voltage and power range.

title: Evaluation of Retraining of Convolutional Neural Networks to Classify Humpback Whales from Planetscope Images in the Colombian Pacific
authors: Javier Medina, Estefanía Garcia, Valentina Alvarez, Diego Culma, Erika Upegui
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Whales play a leading role in the marine ecosystem and climate change mitigation. Recently, different studies have been carried out in order to identify, classify and monitor whales from satellite images of very high spatial resolution using deep learning frameworks. This study focuses on whale image classification using six leading CNNs pre-trained in Matlab, namely: AlexNet, GoogLeNet, VGG-19, ResNet-101, SqueezeNet, EfficientNet-b0. For this, it is necessary to create a dataset of humpback whale images from PlanetScope images taking the Colombian Pacific as the study area. Retrain techniques from scratch and transfer learning are used. Results are evaluated with seven popular measures, namely: Sensitivity, Precision, False Positive Rate, Accuracy, F1 Score, IoU and time. Results obtained are promising, and in general, show an accuracy greater than 80%. Furthermore, results show that transfer learning is faster and offers higher values than retraining from scratch.

title: Graphene-Based Interdigitated Supercapacitor
authors: Aryan V S, Jwala Lakshmi Narasimha Gummadilli, Rajalekshmi TR, Harikrishnan MP, Alex James
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: This study presents the fabrication and experimental analysis of interdigitated supercapacitors through the utilization of a screen printing technique. The proposed device features an interdigitated structure with a primary graphene electrode and a secondary layer of silver paste, employing a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{H}_{3} \text{P O}_{4}/\text{P V A}$</tex> gel electrolyte as the dielectric medium. Furthermore, cyclic voltammetry (CV) analysis at different sweep rates highlighted the versatility of the fabricated supercapacitors. In order to further validate the design and performance features, simulations were run to assess the electrode potential under an external bias. The integration of graphene and silver paste layers, along with the efficient screen printing technique, make this research a promising step toward advancements in energy storage applications.

title: GKANs-KNN: Enhancing Crop Recommendations with Deep Learning
authors: Somrita Sarkar, Sadique Amin, Anamika Dey, Chandranath Chatterjee, Pabitra Mitra
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Sustainable agriculture and food security require integrating weather and soil data to improve farming practices, enhance resilience against adverse conditions, and ensure crop productivity. This study presents a novel precision agriculture crop recommendation model for farmers based on multiple parameters. A Graph Convolutional Network (GCN) is proposed and enhanced with a Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks (KAN) layer, a first in crop recommendation systems. The model utilizes a K-nearest neighbors (KNN)-based adjacency matrix to construct a farming graph based on the similarity of environmental factors. Our approach analyzes critical soil properties such as nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), potassium (K), and pH, as well as weather data, including temperature, humidity, and rainfall from various regions in India, to recommend the most suitable crops for different conditions. The inclusion of KAN layers enhances the model’s ability to capture complex relationships between soil, climate, and crop types. The proposed GKANs-KNN model demonstrates superior performance, achieving a remarkable recommendation accuracy of 98%, significantly surpassing existing state-of-the-art models. This innovative integration of GCN, KAN, and KNN offers a highly reliable and efficient solution for precision agriculture, with the potential to improve crop recommendation and resource management.

title: Multi-View Approach for Physically-Guided SAR Image Generation Based on StyleGAN2
authors: Ran Yang, Tao Lai, Haifeng Huang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: With the growing use of synthetic aperture radar (SAR), there is an increasing demand for multi-target, multi-view SAR image datasets. In this paper, we propose a physically guided multi-view SAR image generation method that combines conditional information with StyleGAN2, based on a newly constructed multi-target SAR image dataset. This method offers a practical solution to the challenges of incomplete viewpoints and mode collapse in small sample SAR image datasets. Finally, the quality of the generated images is evaluated using six metrics to assess the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Range Ambiguous Clutter Suppression for Spaceborne Surveillance Radar by ISSF-STAP
authors: Zhihao Wang, Shijian Shen, Xiaofeng Wang, Wei Chen, Mengdao Xing, Yongliang Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Severe range ambiguity will degrade the performance of clutter suppression and moving targets detection for a spaceborne surveillance radar (SBSR). To solve this problem, a novel range ambiguous clutter suppression method for SBSR based on Intra-pulse superimposed stepped frequency (ISSF) design and space time adaptive processing (STAP) is proposed in this paper. By transmitting series of stepped frequency signals simultaneously during a pulse period, ISSF introduces an extra dimension which is related to slant range and called the slant range domain here for echo. Then digital beam forming (DBF) can be utilized in the slant range domain to form nulls where range ambiguous components locate and suppress the relative range ambiguous clutter. After that, STAP is performed to suppress the unambiguous clutter. Besides, the method of constrain and design on system parameters for SBSR is also discussed to avoid grating lobes in the slant range domain. Finally, simulation experiments are conducted to verify the effectiveness of the proposed ISSF-STAP.

title: An Active Damper with Pre-Oscillation Stability Monitoring for Grid-Connected Power Electronics Systems
authors: Yihan Zhou, Jinjun Liu, Zipeng Liu
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Grid-connected system stability is frequently compromised by dynamic interactions between inverters and the grid. Conventional active dampers-typically employed to mitigate such stability issues-exhibit delayed responses to emerging oscillations and rely on fixed parameter settings that lead to excessive power loss. To address the inherent latency and fixed-parameter limitations of conventional active dampers, this paper proposes a novel active damper employing a preoscillation stabilization framework. This framework uniquely integrates real-time impedance-based stability assessment with adaptive virtual resistance control. The core novelty lies in its ability to continuously monitor system impedance characteristics and trigger adaptive damping measures as the system approaches predefined stability margin thresholds, rather than reacting to existing oscillations. This preemptive approach, combined with a closed-loop virtual resistor regulator that precisely maintains critical stability margins, significantly enhances adaptability to grid impedance variations and improves power quality compared to conventional delayedresponse active dampers. The operational effectiveness and robustness of the proposed active damper are validated through detailed time-domain simulations.

title: Accurate Calorimetric Loss Measurement in SiC MOSFET under Zero-Loss Switching
authors: Iñaki Orradre, David Elizondo, Pablo Sanchis, Ernesto L. Barrios
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: A significant increase in the switching frequency of silicon carbide (SiC) power semiconductors can be achieved through soft-switching techniques such as Zero-Loss Switching (ZLS). ZLS consists of two complementary techniques: ZeroVoltage Switching (ZVS) turn-on and a fast turn-off with no current through the MOSFET channel. Thus, the size and cost of the passive components in the converter can be reduced. However, even under ZLS, some residual loss persists, due to the charge transfer within the devices' parasitic capacitances. In this work, a calorimetric method is presented to measure this power loss, supported by a rigorous uncertainty analysis that provides precise and reliable results even at very low power dissipation levels. Experimental tests show that switching loss under ZLS condition can be up to two orders of magnitude lower than under hard-switching. However, this loss should not be systematically neglected, as it limits the maximum achievable switching frequency. Furthermore, they are found to increase with both switched voltage and current, consistent with a resistive-like behavior linked to the parasitic capacitances. Hence, the proposed methodology forms a solid basis for accurately characterizing ZLS residual loss.

title: A Deep Learning Framework using Remote-Sensing Foundation Model with Siamese U-Net and KAN-Based CNN for Optical and SAR Change Detection
authors: Shubhrangshu Ghosh, Syed Mujibul Islam, Abhishek Roy Choudhury, Arpan Pal
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Change detection (CD) is a key research area in remote sensing. With advances in imaging techniques, cross-domain CD (CDCD), between optical and synthetic aperture radar (SAR) images has gained significant attention. However, CDCD is challenging due to their differing modalities, which provide complementary information. Previous methods rely on transformation-based approaches involving two tasks: image translation (SAR to optical) and CD. Recent multitasking approaches reduce this gap but demand highly compute-intensive training due to complex generative models. Notably, remote-sensing foundation models (ReFM), built solely using remote-sensing data, remain underexplored for addressing this issue. We propose a novel deep-learning (DL) architecture, ReFUnet, which integrates a pre-trained ReFM with a locally trainable custom Siamese U-Net in a single network for change detection in optical and SAR images. The approach leverages generic embeddings from the extensively pre-trained ReFM alongside locally trained embeddings. This design aims for the reduction in training resource requirements. ReFUnet efficiently fuses these embeddings and employs a Kolmogorov-Arnold Network (KAN)-based CNN classifier to generate change maps. It outperforms current State-of-the-Art (SOTA) methods on two benchmark datasets, demonstrating its effectiveness and robustness. An ablation study further confirms KAN’s superiority over Multi-Layer Perceptrons in this architecture. ReFUnet sets a promising direction for the adaptation of ReFMs in cross-domain CD of optical and SAR images.

title: Change Mask-Guided Multi-Temporal Image Pair Generation Based on Diffusion Model
authors: Shuyu Gan, He Chen, Miaoxin Cai, Can Li, Yuting Shi, Yikang Sun, Ye Zhu, Yin Zhuang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Building change detection (BCD) in remote sensing images primarily involves using multi-temporal images of the same region to extract information about building changes. The development of data-driven deep learning has significantly advanced BCD. However, due to the slow frequency of building changes, it is challenging to obtain effective BCD data pairs, making it difficult to construct a class-balanced BCD dataset. This limitation severely restricts the performance improvement of BCD models. To address this issue, In this paper, a change mask-guided multi-temporal image pair generation (CMMG) is proposed, which utilizes the de-noising process to enlarge the latent representation space for multi-temporal image pair generation. To achieve this, first, a mask-guided building remote sensing image generation approach (MBG) based diffusion model is designed. This approach enables the controlled generation of building information while randomly generating non-building information. Second, a change-controllable multi-temporal background-diverse change detection image pair generation strategy (CDMG) is proposed. This strategy leverages a trained MBG and multi-temporal building masks whose changes can be controlled to generate diverse change detection image pairs. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method exhibits excellent generative capabilities, and the generated diverse and realistic change detection data significantly unleash the potential of plain change detection model, especially under conditions of limited training data.

title: Polar Format Algorithm for WideField Staring SAR with Modified Wavefront Curvature Correction
authors: Yujie Liang, Yi Liang, YiHeng Guo, Tan Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Polar format algorithm (PFA) is a widely used high-resolution SAR imaging algorithm that can be implemented in advanced widefield string synthetic aperture radar (WFS-SAR). However, the planar wavefront assumption that violates the actual situation will cause significant azimuth defocusing in PFA imaging processing, which can negatively impact the focusing performance and image quality, especially in WFS-SAR mode that combines high-resolution and large-swath. This letter proposes a modified wavefront-curvature-corrected polar format algorithm for WFS-SAR imaging. By deducing the differential phase in the two-dimensional wavenumber domain, we analyzed the influence of the higher-order phase on the scattering point's envelope and phase, and constructed a new wavefront curvature error (WCE) compensation function with a range cell migration (RCM) recalibration component to refocus the scattering point precisely. The simulation experiment demonstrates the effectiveness of the method.

title: Performance of 3D Ground Deformation using Mid-inclination Orbits and Multi-squint. Applicability to the Capella Space System
authors: Nestor Yague-Martinez
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The sensitivity to 3D ground deformation employing repeat-pass interferometry is highly dependent on the diversity of the employed acquisition geometries. Most of the current SAR systems use sun-synchronous orbits (SSO) with fixed look direction (typically right), which provides a poor sensitivity to deformation in the North direction at low and middle latitudes. Agile systems with selectable look direction and orbiting in mid-inclination orbits (MIO) provide an improved performance. Additionally, the use of single-pass multi-squinted StripMap acquisitions and the application of multi-squint techniques to long-dwell Spotlight collects shows high potential to reduce the number of necessary acquisition geometries from three to two. This contribution presents a comparison of the expected performances to 3D ground deformation using mid-inclination and quasi-polar orbits, its combination, and the use of squinted collects. The analyses are particularized for the Capella Space SAR system.

title: A Local Anomaly Detection Method for Occluded Targets with Multispectral Point Clouds
authors: Likun Chen, Yanfeng Gu, Xian Li
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Multispectral point clouds (MPC) collected by Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) simultaneously encompass spectral-spatial information of land covers, making occluded target detection possible. Research on anomaly detection based on UAV-mounted MPCs is limited due to the high dimensionality of unstructured data, which increases the computational load, and anomalies that pollute the global background, leading to high false alarm rates. These factors limit the efficiency and accuracy of detection, particularly for occluded targets. A local anomaly detection method based on supervoxel segmentation has been proposed for MPC data. The false alarm rate is reduced through supervoxel segmentation, and then a spherical model is used for localized background selection to minimize false alarms caused by background contamination from anomalies. Compared to applying advanced global anomaly detectors directly to MPCs, the proposed method achieves higher detection accuracy and is more capable of detecting occluded targets.

title: A Class Activation Mapping-Injected Network for Target Azimuth Regression In Remote Sensing Images
authors: Chunhui Li, Qian Guo, Jiyun Chen, Hui Bi
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: As one of the most typical geometric attributes, the azimuth angle plays a crucial role in various tasks such as target classification and generation, particularly when dealing with limited samples. However, due to the scarcity of labeled data, the sensitivity of parameters, and the variability of imaging results, precise azimuth prediction of targets in remote sensing images remains a challenge. We attribute the possible causes to two factors: the lack of an efficient angular encoding module, and the insufficient awareness to samples with adjacent angles. Therefore, an end-to-end Angle Regression-based Class activation mapping-guided Network (AR-CAMN) is proposed, achieving precise target azimuth prediction. Firstly, an angle extraction module based on trigonometric functions is employed for efficient angular encoding and feature learning. Then, an angle regression-based class activation mapping module is designed to enhance the model’s awareness and sensibility to adjacent angles. By using the paired feature maps of CAM as explicit attention constraints, the proposed method effectively enhances the representation of continuity and consistency for adjacent angles. Experiments conducted on the optical and SAR images demonstrate the superiority of the proposed method, which achieves an average reduction of 6.45° in angle prediction error compared with existing representative algorithms.

title: A Frequency-to-Voltage Converter with Tunable Range and Sensitivity for Sensor Readout in $65-\text{nm}$ CMOS
authors: Shuwei Ji, Hossein Yaghobi, Khan Md. Zobayer Hassan, Hossein Miri Lavasani
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a low-power innovative frequency-to-voltage converter (FVC) with tunable frequency range and sensitivity for sensor readout applications. The proposed FVC is implemented in a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \mathrm{P} 8 \mathrm{M} 65-\text{nm}$</tex> standard CMOS and does not use a reference clock; it takes advantage of the capacitance charging/discharging and charge redistribution to enable operation across a wide frequency, ranging from hundreds of KHz to several MHz. The measured results show a sensitivity <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 6000 \text{mV} / \text{MHz}$</tex> and linearity better than 0.2 % with a flexible tuning range from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{5 \%}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1 0 \%}$</tex>.

title: Comparative Analysis of 3-L Inverters Considering Conducted EMI Emissions Performances
authors: Meriem Ouzouigh, Alain Lacarnoy, Jean-Luc Schanen, Timothé Delaforge
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative analysis of the performance of 3-Level inverter topologies for variable speed drives that address EMI conducted emissions requirements at both the input and output sides, as outlined by IEC 61800-3. First, a preliminary design optimization technique is used to derive the 3-Level inverters Pareto-front regarding price, loss, and volume, focusing on functional constraints such as signal quality, ripple, and voltage variation. Next, a review of the EMI equivalent circuit of 3-Level inverters is conducted and completed for 3-L SNPC. An automated design methodology for EMI filters is then defined and applied to derive the optimal design that complies with standards while balancing the previously defined trade-offs. Finally, the contribution of the EMI filter in terms of price and footprint is added to the inverter performances, providing complete insights into the overall system. The analysis is conducted at various power levels to emphasize the importance of addressing EMI requirements when selecting the suitable topology, as this can reverse performance trends.

title: Sea-Fog Detection based on CALIOP and meteorological data
authors: Luyu Yan, Ling Yang, Zhuhui Jiang, Xiaoqiong Zhen, Xuehua Fan, Disong Fu, Xiang-ao Xia
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This study presents a remote sensing method for sea fog detection using multi-source data from CALIOP, MERRA-2, and ICOADS. The proposed approach leverages CALIOP Level 1B data and Level 2 Vertical Feature Mask (VFM) products to develop a profile-scanning algorithm for retrieving the vertical structure of atmospheric features. Additionally, MERRA-2 reanalysis data and ICOADS observations are employed to analyze near-surface meteorological conditions (including relative humidity, temperature inversion, and wind speed) associated with sea fog events in the study region (15°N–60°N, 110°E–180°E). A seasonally adaptive detection algorithm is established to distinguish sea fog from other weather conditions (e.g., stratus clouds and stratus precipitation) by accounting for variations in atmospheric stability and boundary layer dynamics. ICOADS reports serve as ground truth for validation. The results demonstrate robust detection performance, with seasonal accuracy rates of 89.29% (spring), 92.86% (summer), 83.33% (autumn), and 92.31% (winter). The highest observed false alarm rate is 10.58%.

title: Understanding Converter Interactions Using Active and Reactive Characteristics: A Comparison Between Grid-Following and Grid-Forming Control
authors: Amir Reza Zamani, Jin Wang, Mebtu Beza, Massimo Bongiorno, Anant Narula, Jan R. Svensson
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper investigates the impact of active and reactive characteristics of grid-connected converters for system stability assessment. In particular, the reactive characteristics of the converter and the connecting grid are used to identify system resonances, while active-power characteristics (passivity) indicate the risk of destabilizing the different resonances. Through a comparison between grid-forming and grid-following control, it is shown that the passivity theory might be insufficient in assessing the risk for instability in grid-connected converter systems. Theoretical findings are validated via time-domain simulations.

title: STTM: An Object Group Temporal Relationship Description Method Based on Spatial-Temporal Transformer with Motion Feature
authors: Qianwen Rui, Yanan You, Jingyi Cao, Yuanyuan Qiao
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Dynamic scene graph generation has garnered widespread attention in natural image processing; however, its application in the high-resolution optical remote sensing images, particularly for high-value object groups, remains unexplored. These complex remote sensing images pose unique challenges for relationship modeling due to dynamic object interactions and intricate spatial contexts. Despite progress in natural image methods, existing approaches have failed to adequately account for the importance of object motion features and local spatial context in temporal relationship descriptions. To address these issues, this paper proposes a novel method for describing temporal relationships in remote sensing object groups by incorporating object motion features and employing a global-local spatial encoder combined with a temporal decoder structure. Compared to existing methods, this approach significantly improves feature extraction and context optimization, achieving excellent experimental results on our dataset OGTR.

title: Transformer-Based Arbitrary Oriented Object Detection in Very-High-Resolution Remote Sensing Images
authors: Jinmin Lee, Aisha Javed, Changhui Lee, Youkyung Han
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In remote sensing (RS) field, arbitrary oriented object detection (AOOD) technology is dominated with convolutional neural networks (CNNs). However, CNN-based AOOD technologies suffer from the structural limitations for capturing the contextual relationships in RS image. To address this issue, we propose a transformer-based AOOD method capable of effectively capturing and understanding the rotational characteristics of individual objects. Specifically, we replaced certain convolutional layers in the CNN backbone with a module capable of dynamically generating feature maps based on the directional characteristics of objects. Additionally, we adopted a detection transformer (DETR) framework as the detector, enabling the generation of oriented object queries and designing a network that effectively considers both local and global rotational characteristics of objects. To demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach, we trained the network on an open-source dataset including very-high-resolution (VHR) images for AOOD tasks. The results showed that the proposed method achieved superior region proposal accuracy and rotation angle estimation performance compared to other networks.

title: Progressive Multi-Scale Geometric Cost-Volume Network for Stereo Matching Of High-Resolution Satellite Images
authors: Ying Shang, Jiangbo Huang, Tao Shen, Qingwang Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Binocular disparity estimation of satellite stereo images is the key to the task of 3D elevation reconstruction of large-scale scenes. However, existing studies for high-resolution satellite stereo images suffer from disparity blurring in densely built-up regions, disparity non-smoothing in weakly textured regions, and geometrical accuracy of edges, etc. To optimize the processing of the aforementioned challenging regions, we propose a Progressive Multi-scale Geometric Cost-volume network, referred to as PMGC-Net. Specifically, we introduce geometric cost-volumes and convolutional gating units to refine the disparity while improving the recognition of geometric details. In addition, we construct an improved multi-scale cost-volume model using feature pyramids to accommodate the diversity of remote sensing image scales. To further improve the accuracy of disparity maps in critical regions, we design a gradient consistency loss function to explicitly guide its optimization. The experimental results on WHU-Stereo demonstrate that our method enhances the accuracy and clarity of disparity estimation in satellite stereo images, particularly in urban areas.

title: Cross-Modal Enhanced Interactive Transformer for HSI and LiDAR Joint Classification
authors: Pengbo Mi, Yi Yang, Deqiang Han
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: With the rapid development of remote sensing technology, the joint classification of hyperspectral image (HSI) and light detection and ranging image (LiDAR) has shown broad prospects. But the limited number of labeled training samples is a bottleneck problem that needs to be solved urgently, which leads to insufficient data separability and hinders the improvement of classification performance. To solve this problem, the cross-modal enhanced interactive Transformer (CEAT) is proposed for HSI and LiDAR joint classification. First, in order to enhance the representation ability of spatial-spectral and elevation features, heterogeneous feature enhancement module is designed to mine the position information in features. Then, the cross-modal interactive module is designed to facilitate information exchange between heterogeneous features and improve the position awareness, thereby forming a more comprehensive feature representation. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed method is evidenced through comparative and ablation experiments.

title: A Novel Vessel Detection Method for SHFSWR Using Ocean Dynamic Environmental Parameters
authors: Xinyu Li, Yiming Wang, Weifeng Sun, Yonggang Ji, Yongjian Wu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Vessel target detection in sea clutter is an issue to be effectively solved in shipborne high frequency surface wave radar (SHFSWR). In particular, the complex sea clutter in the practical application with unknown sea environment greatly affect the vessel detection performance, due to the inability to accurately describe the differences in characteristics between sea clutter and vessel echoes. This paper proposes a novel method for detecting vessel targets in sea clutter using ocean dynamic environmental parameters. The proposed approach involves constructing the sea clutter spectrum using ocean dynamic environmental parameters, extracting clutter-sensitive features influenced by vessel echoes, detecting anomalies of sensitivity features, and ultimately achieving target detection. The experimental results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed method, and the vessel detected in sea clutter is further confirmed by the synchronous ship automatic identification system information.

title: Design of SAR and Communication Symbiotic Signal Based on Spectrum Sharing
authors: Qidong Zhang, Gaogao Liu, Pei’e Zhao, Ziyu Huang, Beibei Mu, Hongfu Guo
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In the context of limited spectrum resources in the current environment, integrating and combining multiple radio device modules is one of the research focuses. The symbiotic technology design aims to integrate Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) and communication, and the symbiotic signal designed has the ability to transmit communication data while completing SAR imaging of specific areas. This paper provides a reasonable analysis of the spectral characteristics corresponding to SAR periodic signal and proposes a mechanism for their coexistence with communication signal, thereby meeting the dual functional requirements of simultaneous and same frequency. The effectiveness of the proposed method was verified through simulation experiments.

title: 2D Sparsity-Inspired Moving Target Detection Under Integrated Sensing and Communication System
authors: Zhuoyang Liu, Yixiang Luomei, Feng Xu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) is a pivotal application within the framework of 6G networks, leveraging spectrum and waveform reuse to achieve joint communication and sensing. This integration optimizes spectrum utilization but restricts perception capabilities, particularly affecting the detection of pedestrians and moving vehicles in urban environments, while still ensuring communication quality. In this study, we propose a single-channel ISAC base station (BS) solution for detecting and identifying moving targets. Specifically, we develop a 2D FISTA-based target detection algorithm grounded in compressive sensing principles, designed to enhance the efficiency of sensing and accelerate detection speed. Our approach begins by modeling the sensing signals received at the BS and formulating a 2D signal model based on the range-Doppler spectrum. The model leverages the sparse distribution of targets in urban road environments, which are typical application scenarios for ISAC, and formulates optimization problems to reconstruct the positions and velocities of the targets. The proposed algorithm extracts moving targets in ISAC scenarios by efficiently solving the 2D range-velocity map reconstruction problem. Simulation results demonstrate the capability for high accuracy in moving target detection and velocity estimation under challenging conditions in a complex urban road environment.

title: Space 3DGS: 3D Reconstruction for Realistic and Complex Space Environments
authors: Jiayuan Huang, Shuaifeng Zhi, Jingyuan Xia, Weidong Jiang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Space object 3D reconstruction plays a crucial role in space domain awareness, providing solid support for vasious space missions that include space surveillance, pose estimation, on-orbit service, etc. However, existing methods suffer from issues such as long pre-train time, large demand for data, insufficient reconstruction details, and so on. The emerging method, 3D Gaussian splatting (3DGS), effectively addresses these problems with its high quality image synthesis and low training overhead. Nevertheless, 3DGS faces performance degradation due to the challenges inherent in the space object 3D reconstruction such as strong light contrast, incomplete observation, weak texture, and so on. In this work, an analysis is conducted on the challenges and a suite of strategies has been proposed to address these challenges. We use image-wise adaptive floater suppression to avoid the drastic lighting variations and improved gaussian densification to strengthen the reconstruction of sparse textured areas. Compared with other methods, we can achieve more realistic rendering effects and complete geometric surfaces along with realistic images.

title: Sentry: QoE-Aware Failure Handling in Large-Scale Overlay Networks via Spatiotemporal GNNs
authors: Xingxing Yang, Bo Wang, Wufan Wang, Yixin Shen, Minhu Wang, Wangqiu You, Linhui Lou, Pei Xu, Lihang Gao, Zongzhi Hou, Mingwei Xu
publish: Proceedings of the ACM CoNEXT-2025 Workshop on Computing and Network Convergence
abstract: With the widespread deployment of large-scale overlay networks, transmission failures among edge servers occur frequently, severely impacting service availability and Quality of Experience (QoE). Existing failure handling solutions struggle to effectively address such scenarios. Accordingly, we propose Sentry, a QoE-aware failure handling method based on spatiotemporal graph neural networks. Instead of relying on precise localization of specific faults or root causes, Sentry directly identifies and offlines a set of edge servers related to failures to ensure service level objective (SLO) while minimizing QoE degradation. Sentry constructs a state graph based on real relay streams, combining temporal modeling and graph neural networks to effectively filter out short-term network fluctuations and transform the complex combinatorial optimization problem into an efficient node-level prediction task. The experimental results show that Sentry outperforms existing solutions in both success rate and cost of failure handling, demonstrating strong overall performance and deployment potential.

title: Computing Transformation: From Large Language Model to Agentic AI
authors: Kun Tan
publish: Proceedings of the 21st International Conference on emerging Networking EXperiments and Technologies
abstract: This talk examines the computing transformation during the era of modern AI revolution. Driven by high computing and bandwidth demand, scale-out datacenter architecture has shifted to scale-up super AI computers. And the evolution of AI models, from dense transformers, to sparse mixture-of-experts, to future agentic AI systems, continuously bring new types of workloads and cast new requirements to computing. Taken together, these render the next-generation accelerated and parallel techniques as well as distributed software designs.

title: Covert Performance of Bidirectional Air-Water Cross-Boundary Optical Wireless Communication Systems
authors: Qingqing Hu, Bin Chen, Chen Gong, Murat Uysal
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: Optical wireless communication (OWC) has been recognized as a promising solution for establishing high-speed, low-latency data connectivity between air and water. During the propagation of optical beams across dynamic water surfaces, random scattering and refraction can result in information leakage issues, significantly increasing the probability of an adversary listener (Willie) detecting the signal transmission. In this paper, we investigate the covert performance of bidirectional air-water cross-boundary OWC systems under the detection of arbitrary underwater/aerial Willie for the first time. To characterize the detection accuracy at Willie and communication quality between a legitimate transmitter (Alice) and a legitimate receiver (Bob), the covert performance metrics including the covertness outage probability and covert throughput are computed based on the theoretical derivations of channel gain under dynamic wave, surface refraction, and particle absorption and scattering. The numerical simulation reveals the variation patterns of covert performance metrics with respect to multiple environmental and system parameters, which shows that wave intensity and transmitted beam’s divergence angle have opposite effects on detection performance of Willie locating at different positions, and both the optical wavelength beyond blue-green band and strong ambient light can increase Willie’s detection uncertainty. Furthermore, it can be seen that the upper bound on covertness outage probability reaches 1 and the achievable covert throughput approaches 0 in some cases, while covert threat regions exist in both atmospheric and underwater areas within several meters, which indicates that covert transmission strategy and system parameters are required to be further designed and optimized to enhance communication security.

title: Efficient Prediction of HEMP Coupling Response to Multilocation Transmission Lines Within a Rectangular Enclosure With Small Aperture
authors: Haizhe Zhong, Jiantao Liang, Anxue Zhang, Fei Yang, Guoqing Wang, Xihai Li
abstract: To address the challenges of modeling complex pulse fields in partially shielded enclosures and the inefficiency of traditional methods in evaluating multilocation transmission line (TL) coupling responses, this letter proposes an efficient plane wave superposition based model for intraenclosure pulse field-to-TL coupling. By directly linking plane wave parameters to intraenclosure pulse propagation, the model overcomes limitations of existing plane wave methods and avoids the repetitive field solving inherent in the conventional “field-first, coupling-second” approach, eliminating complex pulse field modeling and enabling rapid multipoint response prediction. Validation using 99 distinct TL layout cases shows the model’s computed peak currents all fall within the range of transmission-line modeling method results, while reducing computational time by 95.98%. Leveraging theoretically driven dimensionality reduction, the method provides a highly accurate and computationally efficient solution for electromagnetic compatibility analysis of intra-enclosure TL systems under high-altitude electromagnetic pulse.

title: Editorial
authors: Roberto S. Murphy, Héctor J. De Los Santos
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques

title: Machine Learning-Based Adaptive Codebook Design and Beamforming for Near-Field Communications
authors: Mianyi Zhang, Yunlong Cai, Guanding Yu, Jiaqi Xu, A. Lee Swindlehurst
abstract: Extremely large-scale antenna arrays (XL-arrays) and ultra-high frequencies are two fundamental technologies for future sixth-generation (6G) wireless networks, providing enhanced system capacity and substantial bandwidth expansion. To fully leverage these technological advancements, conventional far-field models must be replaced by more accurate near-field spherical-wave propagation models. This paper investigates a near-field communication system comprising a hybrid analog-digital beamforming base station (BS) and multiple mobile users, aiming to maximize system sum-rate through optimized codebook design, beam selection, and digital precoding. To accommodate dynamic user distributions, we propose two model-agnostic meta-learning (MAML)-based frameworks that enable prompt adaptation by learning well-initialized models for fine tuning. The first framework integrates the MAML method with a deep neural network (DNN) to design near-field codebooks tailored to the user distributions, addressing the limitations of conventional uniform codebooks. The second framework employs a joint neural network (NN) for beam selection and digital precoding, combining deep reinforcement learning (DRL) and deep unfolding. The DRL NN formulates beam selection as a Markov Decision Process, while the deep-unfolding NN approximates optimal digital precoding through a lightweight iterative algorithm without matrix inversion. Simulation results show that the proposed frameworks significantly outperform conventional methods, achieving superior generalization and overall performance in dynamic near-field scenarios.

title: Design and Test of a Photonic-Assisted Ultrawideband Receiver Based on Optical Subsampling
authors: Lei Huang, Qihui Zhou, Liyuan Zhao, Xin Zhang, Weicheng Kong, Hongmeng Zhao, Zhuohang Zhang, Jianfeng Zhang, Wuxin Xiao, Xin Zheng, Jianghua Zhang, Tian Jiang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This article presents a photonic-assisted ultrawideband receiver architecture based on dual-parallel optical subsampling using two mode-locked lasers (MLLs) with distinct repetition rates. The proposed architecture resolves frequency ambiguity and suppresses aliasing without requiring a third optical link, thereby significantly reducing system complexity, size, weight, and power (SWaP). Carrier-suppressed single-sideband (CS-SSB) modulation is implemented using a dual-parallel Mach-Zehnder modulator (DP-MZM), while balanced coherent detection enhances noise suppression. Compared to conventional double-sideband (DSB) schemes, the system achieves a twofold increase in instantaneous processing bandwidth. Simulation and experiments demonstrate frequency measurement errors below 3 MHz across the 2–18-GHz band, with a measured spurious-free dynamic range (SFDR) of 107 dB<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\cdot $</tex-math> </inline-formula>Hz<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${}^{{2}/{3}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>. Fabricated in a 130-nm silicon photonics process, the receiver provides a compact, low-SWaP, and stable solution for wideband electronic reconnaissance.

title: No-Proof Consensus-based Light Blockchain for Distributed Computing Scenarios
authors: Chenggang Mu, Tao Ding, Zhuopu Han, Shanying Zhu, Mohammad Shahidehpour
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Distributed computing faces a persistent multi agent trust dilemma. In the computation process, participants may maliciously attack the system for personal gain by providing false data. Blockchain provides a possible solution for this problem with its immutability and multi-party consensus. However, existing blockchain data throughput has long been queried owing to its exorbitant time and energy costs by consensus mechanisms. This paper proposes a light blockchain structure in distributed computing scenarios. A No-Proof consensus (NPC) mechanism is designed for distributed computing problems with no extra proving process such as Proof-of-Work or Proof-of-Stake. This consensus mechanism notices that the distributed computing result has proven to be valid in the computation process automatically, which does not need to be verified again in the consensus mechanism. Further, the single-threaded data processing ability of the blockchain structure certainly leads to low efficiency when applied to distributed computation problems. An NPC-based blockchain is constructed in this paper to solve this problem. In this structure, the distributed computing is done off chain, and an oracle is designed to upload the computing results to the blockchain asynchronously. Upon the contribution in this paper, a distributed energy trading model is provided as a case study to verify the superiority of the designed blockchain in contrast with other similar structures.

title: Visual Safety Mapping for UAV Landings Using Ordinal Regression Networks_supp5-3635093.avi
authors: Sakineh Abdollahzadeh
abstract: As Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) see growing use in civilian applications, reliably identifying Safe Landing Zones (SLZs) in varied environments is essential for autonomous navigation and emergency response. Passive vision sensors offer a low-cost, lightweight solution for real-time terrain analysis and 3D scene reconstruction, making them ideal for onboard systems. We introduce OR-SLZNet, an original deep learning model based on ordinal regression to predict SLZs from UAV imagery. Unlike prior approaches, OR-SLZNet produces dense, multi-level safety maps by jointly leveraging photometric (e.g., color and texture) and geometric cues (e.g., flatness, slope, and depth), assigning each pixel an ordinal safety score that reflects landing suitability. With real-time inference (~0.02s/frame), the model supports onboard deployment and rapid decision-making in time-critical situations. Extensive experiments on five diverse datasets demonstrate OR-SLZNet effectiveness and strong generalization across a wide range of structural complexities. Additional materials and code are available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/saba129/OR-SLZNet</uri>.

title: Miniaturized Ultrasonic Transducer with PMN-PT Embedded into Flexible LCP Substrate for Biocompatible Applications
authors: Julian Kober, Tönnis Trittler, Edgar M. G. Dorausch, Cornelius Kühnöl, Julius Weber, Marc Hauer, Martin Oppermann, Henning Heuer, Jochen Hampe, Richard Nauber, Moritz Herzog
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Ultrasonics, Ferroelectrics, and Frequency Control
abstract: Emerging ultrasound imaging technologies such as wearables and miniaturized invasive devices require exceptional piezoelectric performance alongside flexibility, small form factors, biocompatibility and scalable production capabilities. To address this, we investigate the embedding of high-performance lead magnesium niobate-lead titanate (PMN-PT) transducers in a flexible and biocompatible Liquid Crystal Polymer (LCP) substrate with integrated conductor tracks. This approach aims to improve mechanical reliability and enable industrial-scale production of compact ultrasound devices. The piezoelectric elements were contacted during the embedding process, involving exposure to heat and pressure, requiring a subsequent repolarization process to restore the piezoelectric behavior. Performance was validated against encapsulated wire-bonded reference samples through electrical impedance measurements and acoustic pitch-catch experiments using a hydrophone in a water tank, with different sound incidence angles. After repoling, the embedded single crystal transducer demonstrated expected piezoelectric behavior in impedance data and achieved a peak negative output pressure amplitude of 4.70 kPa (measured at 10 mm distance in water), compared to 4.45 kPa for the encapsulated wire-bonded reference sample, representing a difference of ≈ 5 %. Directivity patterns showed minimal differences in emission angle, with resonance frequencies varying between prototypes due to the inherent characteristics of different manufacturing approaches in the acoustic stack. This embedding approach shows promising results for miniaturized applications, including external ultrasound wearables and patches, as well as invasive devices such as intravascular and implantable ultrasound systems.

title: Complexity-Aware Policy via Heterogeneous Experts for Robotic Manipulation
authors: Ming Yang, Yunzhe Hu, Ge Yuan, Difan Zou, Jianxin Pang, Dong Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Robotic manipulation requires learning a generalizable policy that can adapt to complicated new environments. However, existing methods typically overlook the inherent task complexity and employ a policy with the same budget for tasks with varied difficulties, facing challenges in inefficient computational resource allocation and zero-shot generalization. In this work, we identify three facets of complexity imbalance issues in the current manipulation tasks at the Inter-task, Intra-task, and Noise-timesteps levels. To address this gap, we introduce the Complexity-Aware Policy (CAP), a novel approach integrating flow matching with a Transformer-based backbone and a Mixture of Heterogeneous Experts (MoHE) structure for policy learning. By leveraging Rectified Flow and dynamically adjusting model capacity based on task complexity, which is assessed through features like object counts and precision needs, our method allocates computational resources efficiently and effectively. This results in faster convergence, optimized computational resource usage, and improved precision across diverse manipulation tasks. Our proposed method achieves the state-of-the-art performance on widely-used CALVIN, LIBERO, and SimplerEnv benchmarks, and is further validated through six real-world experiments, where it consistently outperforms baseline methods across all tasks.

title: LPV-Based Adaptive Robust-Augmented Control for a Blended-Wing-Body Aircraft under Icing, Faults, Disturbances and Uncertainties
authors: Weizhi Lyu, Qian Zhang, Congjie Yang, Jiaxin Chen, Shiqian Liu, James F. Whidborne
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: A novel adaptive robust icing and fault tolerant composite control for the trajectory tracking problem of a large blended-wing-body (BWB) aircraft with ice accretion, actuator faults, unknown disturbances and uncertainties is proposed. Firstly, a linear parameter varying (LPV) model is developed from the nonlinear dynamics of the BWB aircraft, and a neural network (NN) based LPV controller is investigated for the trajectory tracking. The disturbance observer is designed to overcome the effect of external unknown disturbances. For the actuator faults of the aircraft, a low-complexity fault tolerant controller is developed by fault estimation. To improve the anti-icing performance of the BWB aircraft system, a new icing adaptive compensator is proposed. Simulation scenarios are presented to illustrate that the proposed composite controller has better performances on trajectory tracking under both icing and actuator faults.

title: TRIDENT: Temporal Reasoning and Detection of Emerging Network Threats
authors: Ghadah Almousa, Yugyung Lee
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: The rapid spread of misinformation on social media threatens public discourse, trust, and decision-making. Existing rumor detection methods—ranging from multimodal fusion to graph-based reasoning—have achieved promising results but often struggle to capture the multiview, heterogeneous, evolving, and adversarial nature of real-world rumor propagation. Common limitations include oversimplified graph structures, shallow temporal modeling (TM), and limited semantic grounding or robustness.
