To address these challenges, we propose temporal reasoning and detection of emerging network threats (TRIDENT), a unified and interpretable framework that represents rumor events as multiview heterogeneous temporal graphs enriched with external knowledge. TRIDENT integrates a novel partial differential equation–graph convolutional network (PDE-GCN) module for continuous-time temporal encoding, cross-view attention for joint reasoning over user interactions, content semantics, and propagation structure, and multimodal adversarial training to defend against label-preserving manipulations in both text and graph domains. Comprehensive evaluations on four benchmark datasets, Twitter15, Twitter16, Weibo, and PHEME, show that TRIDENT consistently outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, with especially strong gains on challenging rumor types such as false and unverified claims. These results highlight the importance of unifying TM, semantic grounding, and adaptive multiview graph reasoning for robust and explainable rumor detection in dynamic social ecosystems.

title: Prediction of White Matter Hyperintensity Progression: A Systematic Comparison of Preprocessing Methods and Deep Learning Models
authors: Jin-Su Kim, Yong-Hwan Kim, Sun U. Kwon, Bum-Joon Kim, Hyun-Chul Kim
abstract: White matter hyperintensity (WMH) progression is a critical marker of cerebral small vessel disease; however, its prediction remains challenging due to inter-institutional variability and the inherently non-deterministic nature of lesion evolution. To our knowledge, this is the first study to systematically evaluate preprocessing strategies and prediction frameworks for WMH progression using a large-scale, multi-institutional dataset from the PICASSO trial (67 institutions). We compared three preprocessing pipelines, harmonization, normalization, and their combination, with three prediction frameworks: fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR)-to-FLAIR, WMH-to-WMH, and disease evolution map (DEM). These were assessed in conjunction with multiple deep learning architectures. Our results demonstrate that harmonization substantially reduces inter-institutional variability and that the DEM framework consistently outperforms direct image-to-image prediction in volumetric and spatial agreement. Furthermore, we provide the first direct comparison of U-Net, GAN, and diffusion models under identical experimental conditions, showing that diffusion models deliver balanced performance in capturing non-deterministic lesion dynamics. At the same time, U-Net achieves the highest spatial agreement. Collectively, these findings establish the first comprehensive benchmark of WMH progression prediction across preprocessing strategies, prediction frameworks, and model architectures, and underscore the translational potential of DEM-based prediction with harmonization for individualized risk stratification and clinical decision-making.

title: Simultaneous Input and State Estimation for Systems With Arbitrary Inherent Delay
authors: Grigorios Gakis, Malcolm C. Smith
abstract: This paper derives a filtering and a smoothing algorithm for simultaneous input and state estimation for linear discrete-time systems of any inherent delay. The exogenous input is assumed to be completely unknown and the only stochastic assumptions are on the output measurements and the initial state. The algorithm includes the Kalman filter which is itself a special case of a system with an inherent delay of zero. The derived recursions take a similar form to the Kalman filter, and are straightforward to implement. The approach uses a standard characterisation of a system's inherent delay in terms of the incremental ranks of a sequence of Toeplitz matrices of Markov parameters. Two judiciously chosen rank decompositions of the relevant Toeplitz matrix corresponding to the inherent delay are used to develop the algorithm. Conditions for the convergence of the filter are also derived and consist of a controllability condition and a minimum phase condition. The paper also presents a smoothing algorithm that can estimate the states and inputs of the system over a fixed time horizon. The theory is illustrated on a field controlled DC motor system with an inherent delay of two and a mass-spring-damper chain system with an inherent delay of five.

title: Ultrawideband Passive Phase Shifters With Dual-Compensated High–Low-Pass Network in 0.25-μm GaAs Technology
authors: Tianci Zhang, Yuying Zhang, Kuisong Wang, Xuming Sun, Yuepeng Yan, Shushan Qiao, Xiaoxin Liang
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: This brief presents a design method for ultrawideband passive phase shifters using a dual-compensated high–low-pass network (DCHLPN). The proposed DCHLPN is made up of a capacitor and an inductor. The inductor path provides phase lag, while the capacitor path provides phase advance. Utilizing this method, the degraded phase of phase shifter can be effectively compensated, thus expanding the operational bandwidth of the phase shifter. To validate the effectiveness of this method, 180° and 90° passive phase shifters are designed and tested in 0.25-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu $</tex-math> </inline-formula>m GaAs technology. Test results demonstrate that the 180° phase shifter achieves a phase error below 7.5° over a 152.9% fractional bandwidth (FBW) from 0.8 to 6.0 GHz. Similarly, the 0° phase shifter maintains a phase error under 6° across a 160% FBW from 2 to 18 GHz.

title: Secure and Efficient RDMA NIC Cryptography Offloading for Memory Disaggregation
authors: Wonsup Yoon, Sue Moon
publish: Proceedings of the ACM on Networking
abstract: Confidentiality and integrity are essential for secure communication. In RDMA-based systems, however, they are often neglected because security mechanisms impose significant performance overheads. In this work, we design a secure RDMA data path that ensures confidentiality and integrity by protecting data in transit and at the remote side using encryption and checksums. To reduce security overhead, our system offloads cryptographic operations to the RDMA NIC (RNIC). However, hardware limitations and relatively slow cryptography performance in RNICs make a secure and efficient design challenging. We address these challenges with three key techniques: dynamic key reconfiguration, configuration-data batching, and context pooling. We also conduct a case study with RDMA memory disaggregation systems to evaluate when offloading is beneficial. We find that naive offloading degrades performance and that overlapping CPU's computation with RNIC's cryptography is essential to realizing its benefits. Our evaluation shows that overlapping achieves up to 9.63x lower P99.9 latency than a CPU-based secure RDMA data path on RocksDB.

title: Improving Label Reliability in Martian Hyperspectral Data: An Application of Confident Learning to CRISM TRDR Spectra
authors: Sampriti Soor, Priyanka Kumari, Arijit Sur, B. S. Daya Sagar
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Mineral mapping on the Martian surface using CRISM hyperspectral data is challenging due to the lack of ground truth for validation. Recently, a TRDR dataset was released, containing over half million spectra collected from 70 locations on Mars and classified into 38 mineral classes using a hierarchical Bayesian approach. While this dataset provides valuable insights, ensuring the reliability of its labels remains a key concern. In this study, a vanilla convolutional neural network classifier is applied to the TRDR dataset, coupled with a confident learning strategy to identify and address potential label inconsistencies. By refining the training data through confident learning, the classification accuracy on a balanced sample of the dataset improves from 90.6% to 92.1%. The trained model is used to generate mineral maps on Martian surface.

title: Mapping Kochia Patches Using Machine Learning and High-Resolution Satellite Imagery
authors: Thuan Ha, Japjyot Sandhu Singh, Kwabena Nketia, Sarah van Steenbergen, Hansanee Fernando, Brianna Zoerb, Steve J. Shirtliffe
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Kochia (Bassia scoparia) is a highly competitive weed that reduces crop yields in the Canadian Prairies due to its adaptability and herbicide resistance. Its stress tolerance and resistance to herbicides pose challenges for effective management. In this study, we map annual kochia patches using very high-resolution satellite remote sensing imagery. Field surveys (using drones and GPS) were conducted to collect samples for crop vs kochia classification. Very high-resolution Pleiades NEO (PNEO) imagery (30 cm) was collected for six regions (167 fields, nearly 1000 square kilometers) in Saskatchewan, Canada in August 2024. Kochia and crop areas were labeled, and 26 map features, including spectral bands and indices, were compiled. Through a Random Forest algorithm, survey data and drone imagery were integrated into a model to assess satellite-based mapping effectiveness of mapping kochia using satellite imagery. The workflow, implemented in Google Colab, enabled provincial scalability. Key variables observed to highly influence the robustness of our model included image bands of Green, Red, and Visible Atmospherically Resistant Index. Using PNEO imagery, a 97% prediction accuracy was achieved, highlighting its potential as a scalable tool for monitoring and managing kochia across varying agricultural landscapes.

title: Explainable Data-Driven Battery State of Charge Estimation
authors: Shalman Ojukwu, Sidharth Maheshwari, Mohamed Mamlouk, Volker Pickert, Alex Yakovlev, Rishad Shafik
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: In the domain of battery energy storage systems for Electric Vehicles (EVs) applications and beyond, the adoption of machine learning techniques has surfaced as a notable strategy for battery modeling. Machine learning models are primarily utilized to forecast the state of batteries, specifically focusing on analyzing the state of charge (SOC). A crucial barrier to the adoption of machine learning algorithms in SOC estimation is their lack of explainability. Current ML SOC estimators researched, are highly focused on model performance while neglecting model explainability. This lack of explainability is crucial for stakeholders as they require trust and assurance in models' predictions, particularly applications like EVs, where erroneous SOC estimation can cause potential safety hazards. This work focuses on the explainability of SOC estimation using the Tsetlin Machine. The Tsetlin machine (TM) is a novel intrinsically explainable machine learning algorithm that offers competitive accuracy across various applications with simple Boolean-based logic computation. This paper aims to bridge the gap of model explainability by also comparing the explainable AI technique SHAP with the novel TM algorithm. The results present the TM as a highly competitive algorithm for accurate SOC estimation while offering a precise quantification of the influence of individual attributes to the final prediction without the need for post-hoc techniques.

title: Triple-Excitation Variable Flux Memory Machine with Axial-Radial Magnetic Circuit for Torque Density Enhancement
authors: Jinya Chen, Kan Liu, Xiaoyan Peng, Z.Q. Zhu, Dong Wei, Huaqiang Cai, Yan Ding, Kaiqing Li, Junjie Tao
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper proposes a triple-excitation variable flux memory machine (TE-VFMM) with axial-radial magnetic circuit, in which high coercive force (HCF) permanent magnet (PMs), low coercive force (LCF) PMs, and field windings (FWs) cooperate to achieve high torque density and wide flux regulation capability. TE-VFMM is configured with energysaving mode and high-performance mode, each of which has flux-enhanced and flux-weakened states. Under the same external machine dimensions, good regulation capability and torque density improvement can be achieved in TE-VFMM, compared with conventional permanent magnet synchronous machine (PMSM). The LCF PMs and FWs are placed in redundant space between rotor core and bearing housing, which improves the space utilization rate. Finally, the proposed TE-VFMM with axial-radial magnetic circuit is fabricated and tested to experimentally validate the analyses.

title: Superpixel-based Building Damage Detection from Post-Earthquake Imagery Using Deep Neural Networks
authors: Jun Wang, Ninglun Gu, Liwei Liu, Jin Yang, Sha Li, Liqin Han, Lipeng Jiao, Ling Wu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Building damage detection after natural disasters like earthquakes is crucial for initiating effective emergency response actions. Remotely sensed very high spatial resolution (VHR) imagery can provide vital information due to their ability to map the affected buildings with high geometric precision. However, we suffer from suboptimal performances in detecting damaged buildings due to earthquakes. This paper presents a novel superpixel based approach incorporates Deep Neural Networks (DNN) with a modified segmentation method, for more precise building damage detection from VHR imagery. Firstly, a modified Fast Scanning and Adaptive Merging method is extended to create initial over-segmentation. Secondly, the segments are properly merged based on the Region Adjacent Graph (RAG). Thirdly, a pre-trained DNN using Stacked Denoising Auto-Encoders (SDAE-DNN) is presented, to exploit the rich semantic features for building damage detection. Experimental results on a WorldView-2 imagery from Nepal Earthquake of 2015 demonstrate the feasibility and effectiveness of our method, which could boost detection accuracy through learning more intrinsic and discriminative features, which outperforms other methods using alternative classifiers.

title: Assessing Mobile RTK and QR Code-Based Control Strategies for Precise 3D Georeferencing
authors: Yu-Ching Lin, Ying-Tung Shen, Ming-Da Tsai
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This study evaluates the use of an iPhone 14 Pro combined with the viDoc RTK rover to assess the impact of RTK fix rates and QR code strategies on the accuracy of 3D point cloud in GNSS-challenged environments. The integration of QR codes as manual tie points, particularly using a multi-point Autotag strategy, significantly improved accuracy, especially under degraded RTK signal conditions. Projects with low fix rates demonstrated enhanced precision when QR codes were utilized, whereas relying on QR codes solely as natural features yielded limited benefits. The findings emphasize the critical role of QR codes in mitigating poor fix rates and optimizing 3D geospatial workflows. This work establishes a practical and scalable approach to high-precision 3D modeling using smartphone-based RTK systems.

title: Development of an Exploratory Maturity Assessment Model for Smart Healthcare: Case of Telemedicine
authors: Salman Alshmrani, Tugurl U. Daim
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society Conference - Global (TEMSCON Global)
abstract: Healthcare is a very important factor in human lives and plays a major role in people's quality of life. Countries spend much money on healthcare and invest in new technologies to provide high-quality, cost-effective healthcare. Telemedicine is one of the healthcare technologies that has been around for at least a decade. However, in the last five years, interest in telemedicine increased rapidly due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Quick adoption of healthcare organizations resulted in different challenges while using or adopting telemedicine. This paper uses a comprehensive literature review to identify telehealth challenges and build a preliminary Hierarchical Decision Model (HDM) for telemedicine maturity assessment. The paper maps challenges into perspectives for telemedicine adoption and use. Also, it identifies different factors contributing to each perspective on the adoption of telemedicine.

title: Reconfigurable Analog Neural Networks: Architecture, Design, and Performance Evaluation
authors: Amr Elhossan, Samuel Parent, Shaan Suthar, Anthony Turco, Hydar Zartash, Mohamed B. Elamien
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a reconfigurable analog neural network architecture implemented with discrete components for machine learning inference tasks. We use digital potentiometers to store model parameters and digital-to-analog converters to represent input data as DC voltages. The system implements matrix multiplication through the op-amp summer configuration and incorporates ReLU activation functions using active rectifiers. The system achieves nearly the same accuracy as its software counterpart when evaluated on the MNIST validation dataset. We also measure the end-to-end propagation delay, and power consumption. Our results demonstrate the viability of application-specific analog computing for AI tasks. The work highlights the potential of reconfigurable analog hardware for edge computing applications where energy efficiency is paramount.

title: GAN Based Non-Linear Hyperspectral Unmixing Using Patch Transformer on Chandrayaan-2 IIRS Data
authors: Soorya Suresh, Arun PV, Alok Porwal
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Hyperspectral unmixing is a key challenge in remote sensing, crucial for identifying and quantifying materials within mixed pixels. Traditional methods, including linear and basic nonlinear approaches, often fail to capture the complex spectral-spatial interactions, noise, and sparsity in high-resolution datasets like those from the Chandrayaan-2 Imaging Infrared Spectrometer (IIRS). To address these limitations, we propose a novel GAN-based framework with a patch transformer and innovative constraints for effective nonlinear unmixing. Our contributions include: (1) a patch transformer integrated into the generator to capture complex spatial-spectral relationships; (2) relaxation labeling in the latent space to refine abundance predictions and ensure spatial-spectral consistency; (3) a denoising constraint to enhance noise resilience, leading to reliable abundance maps and reconstructions; and (4) sparsity in abundance maps for efficient representation and improved interpretability. Additionally, synthetic data generation using superpixel segmentation and convolutional autoencoders enriches the training process. Experimental validation on the Cuprite and Chandrayaan-2 IIRS datasets demonstrates superior performance, with significant reductions in RMSE and SAD, addressing challenges of nonlinearities, noise, sparsity, and spatial variability. Our method shows transformative potential for hyperspectral unmixing, enabling accurate and reliable material detection in both terrestrial and extraterrestrial remote sensing applications.

title: Converter-Based Fault Interruption: A Pathway to Effective DC Protection
authors: Moein Ghadrdan, Honeymol Mathew, Giovanni De Carne
publish: 2025 10th IEEE Workshop on the Electronic Grid (eGRID)
abstract: The interruption of DC faults remains a major obstacle to the widespread deployment of DC grid technologies. The rapid rise of fault currents and the absence of natural current zero-crossing points in DC systems have limited the performance and cost-effectiveness of conventional protection strategies, especially when compared to their AC counterparts. This has led to a growing interest in rethinking traditional protection paradigms, particularly the dependence on dedicated circuit-breaking devices. This paper investigates the feasibility of converter-integrated or breaker-less protection approaches for basic DC-DC converter topologies. By introducing structural modifications, specifically the integration of additional switching components, these converters are adapted to autonomously detect and clear faults on the grid side. Although these modifications may not directly improve efficiency or reduce cost, they can significantly enhance fault response time and the practicality of integrated protection schemes. The study begins with an analysis of conventional DC-DC converter behavior under pole-to-pole short-circuit conditions, followed by simulation-based validation of the proposed modifications. Results demonstrate that the modified converters can effectively interrupt fault currents, highlighting the potential of power electronic converters to serve dual roles in both energy conversion and system protection.

title: Smart Microgrid Optimization in Villages Using Digital Twins and AI-Based Hybrid Algorithms
authors: Rahma Gantassi, Celestine Emeka Obi, Yonghoon Choi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: In the wake of the Fourth Industrial Revolution and recent strides in information and communication technologies, the digital twin concept has emerged as a focal point for researchers and industry professionals worldwide. Its integration into the digital transformation of power systems underscores its growing importance. This paper proposes a novel strategy for optimizing the performance of village-level microgrids, the reliability, and efficiency of energy systems by incorporating the K-Medoids clustering machine learning algorithm (ML) and digital twin technology with a hybrid neural network-based multiobjective genetic algorithm (HNNMOGA). Our optimization has 3 objectives: investment, reliability, and profit. The neural network-based method proves effective in handling complex and dynamic behaviors. This is demonstrated through accurate forecasting of load demand, solar and wind generation, and analysis using the Pareto front.

title: Sparse-Enhanced Dynamic Fusion Experts Network for Multi-Modal Object Detection
authors: Zhenyu Gao, Xin Wu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: UAV-based multi-modal object detection has become critical in environmental monitoring and emergency rescue. However, few studies have explored how to evaluate the contribution of each modality under varying lighting conditions. In this paper, we propose a Sparse-Enhanced Dynamic Fusion Experts Network for Multi-modal Object Detection (SDFENet), which asymmetrically enhances the contextual features of each modality and adaptively learns the optimal contribution of each modality. Specifically, we develop an asymmetric multimodal sparse attention (AMSA) mechanism to enhance unimodal features. For visible light, we create a learnable sparse-k operator that can filter the important information in the image. For infrared, we combine sparse-level features to enhance the infrared data’s global and local context. Additionally, we design the Light Intensity Expert-guided Multimodal Fusion (LEMF) module, which uses a multimodal light intensity expert evaluation mechanism to identify the optimal contribution of each modality. The experimental results show that the proposed method outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods.

title: A Photonic Multi-Chip Module (P-MCM) Platform for Microwave and Other Applications
authors: Paul W. Juodawlkis, Siva Yegnanarayanan, William Loh, Dave Kharas, Patrick T. Callahan, Jason J. Plant, Christopher Heidelberger, Cheryl Sorace-Agaskar
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: Similar to electronic multi-chip modules (MCMs), photonic MCMs (P-MCMs) integrate multiple chips onto a common substrate to provide benefits (e.g., performance, size, power consumption, yield) that cannot be achieved through monolithic, single-chip integration. We report the development of a novel P-MCM platform that integrates best-in-class photonic components (e.g., external-cavity lasers, thin-film lithium-niobate (TFLN) optical modulators, high-Q optical filters, balanced-waveguide photodiodes) onto a silicon-wafer “intermount” that facilitates efficient optical coupling between components and provides environmentally stable mechanical support. The performance demonstrated from the integrated components make the P-MCM platform a strong candidate for realizing microwave photonic (MWP) subsystems having radio-frequency (RF) performance superior to what can be achieved from discrete, fiber-pigtailed photonic components or other photonic integrated circuit (PIC) technologies. Other potential applications include optical interfaces for atom-based quantum computers and optical clocks, free-space lasercom, and remote optical sensing.

title: Strategic Product Management Education in the Era of Artificial Intelligence
authors: Sathya Prasad, Raghavendra Deshmukh, Madhukar Narasimha
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society Conference - Global (TEMSCON Global)
abstract: In today's tech-driven landscape, product innovation is critical for competitive advantage, but product management (PM) education often fails to keep pace with real-world industry demands. The rise of AI is reshaping product development, requiring skills beyond traditional PM expertise and widening the gap between academia and practice. Engineering curricula emphasize technical proficiency but often overlook essential aspects like product strategy, market dynamics, and innovation management. As a result, aspiring product managers must learn through experience rather than structured education. To address this, the authors developed an elective course “Product Management for the AI Era,” designed for final-semester engineering students. This course is not just a set of lectures but a collaborative learning experience that integrates practical frameworks, industry collaboration, and expert insights to equip students with the skills needed for AI-driven product innovation. The paper outlines the motivation for introducing this multidisciplinary topic with a non-traditional curriculum crafted with inputs from industry/startup practitioners and an engaging delivery format. We hope this helps narrow the academia-industry gap in product management education, fostering innovation and entrepreneurship in the AI era.

title: Design of an Auxiliary Resonant Commutated Pole Three-Phase Inverter for Motor Drive Applications
authors: Dario Cucuccio, Giacomo Scelba
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of auxiliary resonant commutated pole topology, which can be used to achieve soft switching and EMI reductions for traction inverters. The operating principles and design methodology are thoroughly presented in this work. Modelling and simulations are then used to evaluate the performance benefits of this topology, particularly when implemented in a hybrid configuration combining SiC and IGBT devices, and compared against a standard hard-switched two-levels voltage source inverter.

title: Unveiling Student Trial-and-Error Patterns through a Optimized Deep Learning for Accurate Profiling
authors: Faiz Hilmawan Masyfa, Tibyani Tibyani, Novan Andre Andriansyah Putra, Moh. Zulfiqar Naufal Maulana
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: Student trial-and-error behavior plays a crucial role in cognitive development, yet traditional profiling methods often fail to capture the underlying patterns accurately. This study introduces a novel approach to uncovering these patterns through a deep learning framework designed for accurate profiling. The framework utilizes a hybrid model combining DBSCAN clustering, Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) classification, and Genetic Algorithm (GA) for training optimization, enhancing model accuracy. One of the key challenges addressed by this framework is the invisible distribution of trial-and-error tendencies in the data, as the class distribution is not readily apparent, small samples, and the dataset suffers from class imbalance. The results demonstrate significant improvements in profiling accuracy compared to traditional methods, with accuracy reaching $86.67 \%$, precision at $89.45 \%$, recall at $86.67 \%$, and $\mathbf{F 1}$-score of $85.78 \%$. This research provides a comprehensive solution for predictive cognitive characteristic, laying the foundation for personalized learning strategies and improved educational outcomes.

title: BS-ConvKAN: Hyperspectral Band Selection Based on Sparsified KAN Convolution and Hybrid Teacher Guidance
authors: Kangfei Shen, Jie Feng, Junpeng Zhang, Di Li, Jiao Shi
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel hyperspectral band selection method, termed BS-ConvKAN, which is based on sparsification-driven KAN convolution. To enhance the representational power of features and allows for a more refined modeling of the importance of spectral band characteristics, we uses 1×1 KAN convolution to construct a deep convolutional layer as the first layer for selecting bands. In the KAN convolution layer, one band corresponds to a spline function, the band weight is represented by the control points of the spline function. By sorting the weights of the control points, the important bands are selected. This method builds additional layers to perform feature extraction and classification on the selected spectral bands. To enhance the band selection process, a multi-teacher approach is proposed to provide guidance, facilitating the model in selecting more optimal bands. It integrates band selection, feature extraction, and classification into an end-to-end framework, achieving joint optimization. Experimental results show that the proposed method BS-ConvKAN achieves promising performance.

title: Multi-Satellite Multi-Target Signal Processing and Target Positioning Using BDS Signals
authors: Qi Wang, Jinxing Li, Min Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: BeiDou Satellite Navigation System (BDS) reflection measurement receives the echo signals of the different coded signals emitted by BeiDou navigation satellites at different positions, and the background reflections of the ocean, land, and other objects. It processes them to realize the detection of the characteristics of the target to be detected. This paper proposes a multi-satellite multi-target signal detection model and focuses on the key technologies in related signal processing based on the BDS signals in the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS). The method of navigation message acquisition and demodulation is given. It is analyzed that the NH(Neumann-Hoffman) code setting of BDS is beneficial to acquiring navigation message. Further, it is proposed to separate the direct and reflected signals using the delay-Doppler map (DDM) and suppress the direct signal to restore the peak value of the reflected echo signal, thereby facilitating the resolution of target information.

title: Performance Analysis and Optimization of a 2000V Silicon-Carbide(SiC)-Based Boost Converter for Photovoltaic Applications
authors: Jinzhou Cao, Weiwei Gan, Liangjie Liu, Yu Qi, Fei Liu, Shunmeng Xie
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper analyzes 2000V silicon carbide discrete devices based two-level boost converter for photovoltaic applications. It also optimizes the power loss characteristic affected by input voltage, current ripple, and switching frequency. The double-pulse test shows that the static unbalance current and dynamic unbalance current are both found to be less than 5%. The optimized design has achieved a high efficiency of 99.43% at rated power and rated voltage.

title: A Spatial-Frequency Multi-Branch Framework for Building Extraction from Optical and SAR Images
authors: Jianhao Li, Yingjian Li, Hao Shi, Liang Chen
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Multimodal fusion processing of optical and Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) remote sensing images is a practical approach to enhance building extraction performance. However, overcoming domain gaps and efficiently integrating features from different sensors remains challenging. In this study, we propose a novel optical-SAR multi-branch multimodal fusion processing framework that achieves efficient building extraction by leveraging both spatial and frequency domains. We utilize an attention mechanism to fuse global and local features of optical and SAR images in the spatial domain. Additionally, we employ wavelet transform to fully integrate multi-scale, multimodal frequency domain features. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed method achieves excellent results on the SpaceNet6 dataset.

title: Digital Fertilisation Maps from Satellite Canopy Nitrogen Estimates and Crop Model Simulation Information
authors: Luca Miazzo, Lorenzo Parigi, Giorgio Ragaglini, Francesco Nutini, Gabriele Candiani, Mirco Boschetti
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This study proposes a novel approach to generate smart fertilization maps and implementing sustainable agronomic practices for wheat production. The approach combines crop model simulations and remote sensing techniques. The ARMOSA crop model was utilized to assess nitrogen demands in relation to soil and weather conditions, while ground data and machine learning regression algorithms (MLRA) were employed to map canopy nitrogen content (CNC) from Sentinel 2 (S2) and PRISMA (PR) data. The findings demonstrated that CNC can be effectively mapped from satellite with promising accuracy when assessed on independent data (R2 = 0.7 and 0.6, and NRMSE = 15% and 18% for S2 and PR, respectively). A seven-year crop model simulation enabled the assessment of crop performances across soil management zones (MZ), estimating nitrogen uptakes, nitrogen uptake efficiencies, residual soil nitrogen, and the conversion coefficient to convert CNC into actual nitrogen uptake. The prescription maps obtained agreed with farm best practice management. Additionally, this digital product provides information on spatial variability of crop needs and fertilization dose, allowing for optimization of nitrogen application that is both ecologically and economically viable.

title: Integration of Switching Cell Design Including Parasitics and EMI into a Converter Optimisation Framework
authors: Georgios Papadopoulos, Florian Krismer, Jürgen Biela
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Wide-bandgap (WBG) semiconductors enable high switching speeds and low losses. However, these high speeds amplify the impact of parasitic elements, leading to voltage and current spikes, oscillations, and thus, increased electromagnetic noise emissions. This paper presents a comprehensive switching cell (SC) electro-mechanical modelling framework that also calculates the parasitics based on the mechanical layout of the SC. The calculated parasitics are inputs into existing semiconductor models to evaluate the impact of the SC design parameters on the losses and EMI emissions. With the modelling framework, design guidelines are derived for achieving a high efficiency and low EMI emissions.

title: Impact of Dead Time on Power Efficiency in Si and GaN Micro PV Systems
authors: Miguel Lajas, Iker Almandoz, Iosu Aizpuru, Asier Arruti
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Selecting the appropriate dead time is crucial for maximum power point tracking (MPPT) controllers in micro-PV systems. The optimization is critical because excessive dead time can adversely affect the system's efficiency and the reliability of the power conversion system. This paper examines the impact of dead time on a synchronous buck converter operating in various switching modes, including soft switching and hard switching. The analysis has been performed with a 48 V PV panel, evaluating the converter's performance under different operating points of the panel. The analysis is conducted using various technologies, including Silicon (Si) MOSFETs and Gallium Nitride (GaN) FETs, to examine the impact on losses in both devices. Additionally, thermal tests are performed to optimize the dead time and improve the overall efficiency of the system.

title: Bi-Level Optimization Pricing Scheme for Assessing Flexible Regulation Capability Value
authors: Yusong Yang, Zhenting Tian, Runfan Zhang, Tong He, Runze Han, Gengfeng Li, Zhaohong Bie
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: With the rapid increase in the penetration of renewable energy sources, power systems encounter challenges due to the lack of flexible regulation capabilities needed to manage the stochastic, intermittent, and fast variations in output power from these sources. Traditionally, hydro and coal-powered units have served as regulation resources for power system adjustments, but they have limited regulation and ramping capabilities currently for flexible regulation. As the demand for flexible regulation resources grows, new approaches are required to address this issue. This paper reveals and evaluates the value of multiregulation properties to incentivize the provision of regulation capabilities and investment/improvement in flexible regulation resources. A bi-level pricing scheme is proposed to evaluate the value of regulation capabilities based on the marginal utility indicated by dual multipliers. First, price signals for regulation capability is analyzed with dual multipliers. Furthermore, the components of local marginal prices are combined for value expression. Then, a bi-level pricing model incorporating dual multipliers as variables is developed to optimize the value of flexible regulation capabilities. Finally, a modified PJM 5-node example is used to validate the pricing model. The proposed mechanism not only facilitates pricing but also helps characterize the value of a unit's regulation capability.

title: Black Box Adversarial Sample Generation of Remote Sensing Image Description
authors: Guanlong Liu, Yangyang Li, Shuangkang Fang, Ronghua Shang, Licheng Jiao
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Remote sensing image description task studies how to use models to automatically generate text description of remote sensing image content, which belongs to the cross research field of computer vision and natural language processing. In recent years, with the development of remote sensing large-scale model, remote sensing image description has received more and more attention. Remote sensing image application scenarios have high requirements for security and stability, but there are few researches on black-box attack at present. In this paper, we study the generation method of adversarial samples in remote sensing image description task for security and stability. We propose a black-box attack method for codec structure. The target attack is realized by approaching the target sample code to the target sample, and the black-box attack is realized by the idea of integrated attack. This method does not need to know the specific encoding and decoding network of the model to realize effective attack. This method can be used to judge the robustness and security of existing methods, and also provides a basis for further improving the robustness and security of the methods.

title: Minimization of Switching Frequency in Two-Terminal Active Impedance Circuit
authors: Kazutada Yamashita, Keita Ohata, Keisuke Kusaka, Hiroki Watanabe, Jun-Ichi Itoh
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper proposes a wide-band active impedance circuit that emulates various impedance characteristics using a single-phase power converter. To achieve a wide frequency range, the switching frequency must be increased; however, a higher switching frequency leads to increased switching losses. This paper identifies the minimum switching frequency required for wideband active impedance circuit. The steady-state performance of the current control system limits the emulation bandwidth of the active impedance circuit. A phasor-based analysis is employed to evaluate the minimum switching frequency in terms of both gain and phase, ensuring conformity with the target impedance characteristics. As a result, it is demonstrated that the switching frequency must be at least 29 times the emulated bandwidth to maintain an error within 50%.

title: A Novel GEO SAR FFBP Imaging Algorithm Based on Iso-Range Iso-Doppler General Surface
authors: Hongxu Bian, Wenlong Dong, Wenkang Liu, Quan Chen, Guangcai Sun, Mengdao Xing
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The GEO SAR earth observation system has the advantages of large observation swath and short revisit time, and is one of the main development trends of spaceborne SAR in the future. However, its characteristics such as ultra-long synthetic aperture time, ultra-large observation width and complex imaging geometry make the azimuth space-invariance of raw data no longer valid. The frequency domain algorithm has the disadvantages of complex process flow and low precision in processing azimuth space-variant signals. This paper mainly analyzes the time-frequency distribution and azimuth space-variance of LuTan-4 GEO SAR signals. Due to the serious azimuth space variance, constructing a two-dimensional matched filter based on the scene center target leads to pronounced defocusing and residual RCM for targets located at the azimuthal edges. Moreover, we propose a GEO SAR time domain fast imaging method based on the Iso-Range Iso-Doppler General Surface (IRID-GS) Grid. Theoretical analysis shows that the sub-aperture wavenumber spectrum structure is independent of the choice of Imaging Surface, and the traditional Fast Factorized Back-Projection (FFBP) is a special case of the proposed algorithm under straight trajectory and plane surface. The simulation results verify the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Measurement of the Commutation Loop Inductances in a GaN-Based Current Source Inverter
authors: Simon Holzmann, Benjamin H. Zacher, Kai Franck, Christian Schumann
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The measurement of commutation loop inductances plays a crucial role in evaluating the quality of a power electronic circuit design, especially when dealing with fast switching semiconductors such as GaN-eHEMTs. For the efficient operation of these transistors, it is essential to reduce parasitic effects. The high current gradients in addition to the parasitic inductances lead to voltage overshoots, which increase the switching losses or can even destroy the semiconductor. It is therefore important to quantify and experimentally determine these parasitics. This requires a fast and robust measurement method, which provides accurate values. The proposed method is based on the evaluation of oscillations caused by a negative step response and is universally applicable. In this paper, the commutation loop inductances in a GaN-based current source inverter are measured. Experimental results are presented and compared to simulation results.

title: Seeing The Difference: Vision Transformer-Powered Multitemporal Generic Change Detection
authors: Mikhail Klassen, Ramesh Nair, Ash Hoover, Brad Neuberg, Creon Levit
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The rapid advancement of Earth observation technologies has resulted in unprecedented volumes of remote sensing imagery, offering a continuous and detailed record of global environmental and human activity. High-cadence datasets, such as those generated from daily satellite imagery, have opened new possibilities for monitoring change across the Earth’s surface. These datasets enable applications ranging from land-use enforcement and disaster response to agricultural monitoring and environmental conservation. However, the scale and complexity of these datasets present significant challenges in identifying actionable insights, particularly when monitoring expansive geographic regions over extended time periods. Traditional change detection methods in remote sensing, dating back decades, have evolved from basic statistical techniques to advanced machine learning approaches. Recent developments leverage deep learning architectures, including convolutional neural networks, autoencoders, and Siamese networks, for bi-temporal and, increasingly, multitemporal change detection. These approaches enable the identification of nuanced patterns of change that are critical for understanding long-term environmental dynamics. This paper explores a novel multi-temporal change detection framework, leveraging high-frequency satellite imagery, the vision transformer neural network architecture, and a multidimensional time-series change point detection algorithm to identify meaningful changes across diverse geographies and change event types. By combining advanced machine learning techniques with the unique attributes of remote sensing data, this work aims to advance scalable and automated solutions for change detection, providing actionable insights.

title: MSFANet: A Multi-Scale Feature Alignment Model For Optical/SAR Change Detection
authors: Yu Duan, Kaimin Sun, Wei Cui, Tao He, Yingjiao Tan, Heng Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Optical and Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) images exhibit inherent differences in imaging mechanisms and feature representation, making it difficult to directly compare their features, which impacts the performance of cross-modal change detection. To address this issue, we propose the Multi-Scale Feature Alignment Network (MSFANet), which utilizes multi-scale features to enhance feature representation and achieve effective feature alignment. We introduce the Low-Dimensional Feature Fusion Module (Dual-Modal Attention Fusion Module, DMAF Module) and the High-Dimensional Feature Selection Module (Channel Ranker). DMAF Module employs an attention mechanism to weight and fuse low-dimensional optical and SAR features, and uses a global self-attention mechanism in the transformer to capture the relationships between cross-modal features, achieving spatial and semantic alignment of optical and SAR features. The Channel Ranker utilizes a Squeeze-and-Excitation mechanism to select important channels from high-dimensional features, reducing feature redundancy and improving the effectiveness of feature representation. Experimental results demonstrate that MSFANet outperforms other methods on multiple evaluation metrics, validating its effectiveness in optical and SAR change detection tasks.

title: Implementation and Evaluation of Voting Smart Contract on Private Blockchain With PoA Consensus
authors: Lalu Usamah Wahidil Qahar, Heri Wijayanto, Raphael Bianco Huwae, Royana Afwani
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: Blockchain is a decentralized framework that distributes and secures data across a network, eliminating the need for centralized control. Its potential has been especially noted in the field of digital voting, where traditional methods often struggle with issues like tampering, limited transparency, and lack of trust. This research sets up a private Ethereum environment using Geth, configured with a Proof of Authority (PoA) consensus mechanism, to deploy a custom voting smart contract. Developed in Solidity and implemented via the Remix IDE, the contract is designed to enforce secure and efficient voting. The performance of the private PoA network was then compared with the Ethereum Sepolia public test network and private blockchain network Kurtosis using Proof of Stake (PoS). Experimental results show that Geth PoA successfully executed all smart contract functions with significantly lower gas costs and faster block times compared to Sepolia and Kurtosis. These findings demonstrate that Geth PoA offers a lightweight, efficient, and reliable platform for running smart contracts in controlled environments such as institutions or organizations. Based on these results, we can conclude that Geth PoA is a solid option for running smart contracts.

title: A SAR Image Simulation Method for Moving Ships
authors: Lanting Shen, Zhifeng Xie, Xiaoqing Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Ships are one of the most common targets at sea. A rich and diverse Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) dataset of moving ships is crucial for research on these targets. However, acquiring real SAR data is costly, and existing simulation methods for moving ships often consider only single motion states. This paper proposes a novel SAR image simulation method for moving ships, integrating attitude equivalence, electromagnetic scattering and SAR imaging. The attitude equivalent avoids reconstructing the geometric model of the moving target at each slow-time (azimuth) step. Additionally, the proposed method corrects the electromagnetic scattering data through single-path phase compensation. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method not only simulates high-quality SAR data for various complex ship motions but also retains the structural characteristics of the target.

title: Optimization of PC-LFM Orthogonal Waveforms for Downward-Looking 3D SAR
authors: Yonghong Chai, Qinghai Dong, Chong Song, Bingnan Wang, Maosheng Xiang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Downward-looking linear array three-dimensional synthetic aperture radar (DLLA 3D SAR) typically utilizes multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) systems in the cross-track direction to achieve high-resolution 3D reconstruction. However, conventional single-carrier phase-coded signals are sensitive to Doppler effects, which hinders the preservation of orthogonality in MIMO systems on moving platforms. To address this issue, this paper proposes a fast-time phase-coded linear frequency modulation (PC-LFM) signal, which offers improved Doppler tolerance over traditional slow-time PC-LFM signals. Within the required Doppler range for imaging, the fitness function is defined by minimizing both the average auto-correlation peak side-lobe ratio (PSLR) and the normalized cross-correlation peak (CP). Waveform optimization is performed using the Sparrow Search Algorithm (SSA) based on the Hadamard matrix. Experimental results demonstrate that the optimized waveforms exhibit excellent orthogonality and improved SAR focusing performance, making them highly suitable for DLLA 3D SAR systems.

title: Exploring Digital Transformation Models in Latin America: Insights from Tech Firms in Cuenca, Ecuador
authors: Erwin J. Sacoto-Cabrera, César Vilora-Núñez, Carlos M. Fernández-Márquez, Francisco J. Vazquez, Yair Rivera Julio
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society Conference - Global (TEMSCON Global)
abstract: Digital Transformation (DT) has become a fundamental strategy for modern organizations. However, significant disparities in the maturity of DT persist in Latin America. This study analyzes six digital transformation maturity models (DTMMs), selecting the MIT DTMM for application in 14 technology companies in Cuenca, Ecuador. Using surveys of 280 employees, we assessed four key pillars of digital maturity: Digital Intensity, Transformation Management Intensity, Digital Culture, and Technology Capabilities. Key findings reveal internal heterogeneity across these dimensions, despite similar overall maturity scores. Finally, this research represents one of the first regional applications of MIT DTMM and provides practical information for strategic planning and digital policy for companies in Cuenca, Ecuador.

title: A Novel Linear Control Method for Junction Temperature Balancing in Multilevel Inverters
authors: Roopa ViswadevDamodaran, Juan Carlos Rodriguez, William Holland
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: One of the challenges with multilevel topologies for grid-connected inverters is balancing the power losses and junction temperatures of their switching devices. This is essential to improve lifetime and reliability. Existing solutions either have stringent computational requirements or are non-linear in nature, which brings about discontinuities and uncertainties in the control response. To improve on this, a junction temperature balance control method that swaps inverter operation between predefined pulse width modulation strategies using linear control is proposed in this paper. The concept is illustrated in one leg of an active neutral-point clamped inverter, and the results validate the efficacy of the thermal balance technique, without affecting total harmonic distortion.

title: Heatsink Thermal Model Identification Based on Bi-Level Optimization
authors: Riccardo Sancio, Martin Votava, Md Akik Ibn Hasan, Marco Liserre
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: An effective thermal management of power electronics converters requires a balance between accuracy and computational feasibility of the adopted thermal model for their reliable and optimal operation. However, low-complexity models often lack accuracy under dynamic conditions, such as varying loads and cooling degradation, necessitating an adaptive thermal model. Traditional simplified models are prone to overfitting and are able to adapt the thermal model only if the optimal parameters are identified based on sufficient large amounts of data. To address this, the proposed method for thermal model parameters identification integrates the information of temperature slope and acceleration in the estimation error cost function. Furthermore, the generalization of the thermal model for different converter operation scenarios is enhanced by deploying a Bayesian inference to determine suitable weightings for the aforementioned additional terms. A Sequential Quadratic Programming (SQP)based optimization is performed to determine the thermal model parameters based on this Bayesian-weighted approach.

title: High-Speed Cyber-Physical Security Using Robust Physical Layer Authentication
authors: Sydney Lang, Tawfiq Musah
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: The increasing integration of high-speed wireline networks in cyber-physical systems has raised critical security concerns, particularly regarding unauthorized access and control of safety-critical functionality. This work investigates physical layer authentication techniques that leverage intrinsic channel characteristics for secure, physically and spatially unique communication in high-speed broadcast networks. Specifically, we explore jitter-based fingerprinting and channel cursor adaptation as viable authentication mechanisms. Both techniques are evaluated in terms of their practicality for real-time implementation, distinguishability, and robustness to environmental variations. Simulation results demonstrate that jitter-based authentication provides overall superior uniqueness, with high distinguishability at high losses, whereas cursor adaptation performs better at low losses. The complementary nature of these approaches suggests potential benefits in their dual application in a multi-metric authentication framework.

title: Blockchain's Role in Addressing Challenges in the Development of Regenerative Business Models
authors: Claudia Franzè, Mariam Al Khatib, Sabine Baumann
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society Conference - Global (TEMSCON Global)
abstract: Sustainability remains the dominant framework for addressing socio-ecological challenges but often fails to tackle root causes. This has led to a shift toward regenerative business models (BMs), which actively restore and enhance ecosystems, communities, and cultural heritage. While blockchain has been explored in sustainable BMs, its role in regenerative BMs remains underexamined. This study investigates how blockchain can overcome key challenges, including measurement and accountability, stakeholder coordination, financial constraints, and governance barriers. Through a case study of Quantum Temple (QT), a blockchainenabled platform for cultural heritage preservation and regenerative tourism, we analyze how decentralization, transparency, smart contracts, and tokenization enhance value creation, delivery, and capture. Findings reveal that blockchain facilitates impact measurement, equitable revenue distribution, and decentralized funding models. This research contributes to literature on emerging technologies and sustainability, offering insights for practitioners and policymakers on blockchain's potential for socio-environmental regeneration.

title: A Two-step Method for LAI and LCC retrieval using high spatial resolution data base on APPLE-GO model
authors: Naijie Peng, Siqi Yang, Qunchao He, Dechao Zhai, Zhicheng Huang, Huazhong Ren, Wenjie Fan, Dan Yin
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Leaf Area Index (LAI) and Leaf Chlorophyll content (LCC) are vegetation structural parameters and physiological parameters respectively, they are two critical indicators for forest growth condition and global carbon cycle. Accurately estimating LAI and LCC based on remote sensing at high spatial resolution is of great significance for forest dynamics monitoring. The APPLE-GO model is a novel forest canopy BRDF model established at high spatial resolution scenes, providing a new approach for the inversion of biophysical variables at high spatial resolution. In this study, a two-step method was used to retrieve LAI and LCC separately from forest at high spatial resolution imagery. The first step is estimating LAI using adaptive gradient descent algorithm, then based on the retrieval LAI, the leaf reflectance was converted by canopy reflectance using Look-up tables (LUTs) generated from the APPLE-GO model. The second step is retrieving LCC from derived leaf reflectance using the PROSPECT-PRO model. Retrieved LAI and LCC were validated against simulation in LESS. The results indicate a good agreement between retrieved and simulated LAI with RMSE of 0.310 and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.87. Retrieved LCC is of good quality compared to simulated LCC, with R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.64 and RMSE of 4.25 μg/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. This method is also applied to retrieve the LAI and LCC of forests using BJ-3 high-resolution remote sensing images, yielding promising results. In conclusion, this study shows the potential in estimating LAI and LCC of forest using high spatial resolution imagery base on APPLE-GO model.

title: A Speckle-Based Approach To Monitor Intermittent Lakes Using Full-Resolution SAR Measurements
authors: Anna Verlanti, Maurizio Migliaccio, Christian Bignami
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This study is to analyze the ability of full-resolution speckled Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) imagery to estimate the water-coverage status of intermittent lakes. The methodology models SAR speckled measurements using a compound K-model which is shown to allow distinguishing between two cases: the lake full covered by water (namely the fractional area coverage is around 100%) or completely empty (namely the fractional area coverage tends to 0).The model is first verified using a data set of SAR scenes collocated with ancillary optical measurements and, then, applied to a time-series of SAR imagery to monitor the variation of water-area coverage in an Italian intermittent lake.Experimental results confirm the soundness of the proposed approach confirming that speckle can be successfully used to extract information about intermittent lakes.

title: Two-Dimensional Deformation Retrieval of LuTan-1 Space-Surface Bistatic SAR
authors: Shimeng Zhou, Zhiyang Chen, Yuanhao Li
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: All-day, all-weather, low-cost deformation measurement data can be obtained by processing differential interferometric synthetic aperture radar (D-InSAR) data collected through the space-surface bistatic SAR (SS-BSAR) system. Previously, traditional polar-orbit spaceborne SAR faces the limitations of lack of deformation measurement dimensions and poor north-south deformation precision. In this paper, first, we design a dual-angle reception configuration based on SS-BSAR, and present a two-dimensional (2D) deformation retrieval model applicable to this configuration. Furthermore, we introduce the deformation retrieval scheme and conduct the first SS-BSAR dual-angle reception experiment utilizing the LuTan-1 (LT-1) SAR constellation. Finally, the results show a centimeter-level accuracy of 2D deformation measurement, demonstrating the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Bipolar DC Microgrids Supporting Multiport Next-Generation EV Ultra-Fast Charging Stations: A DC Transformer-Based Architecture
authors: Saghir Amin, Muhammad Awais, Joao Rocha, Joao L. Afonso, Nuno Costa, Vitor Monteiro
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper presents a DC transformer-based isolation architecture using a dual output LLC converter topology (DCX) for bipolar DC microgrids, aimed at addressing the challenges in next-generation electric vehicle (EV) ultra-fast charging stations (UFCS). The proposed architecture establishes a bipolar DC microgrid, offering a scalable and efficient approach to multiport EV UFCS. Notably, the proposed architecture enables the integration of multiple EV charging points connected to the bipolar DC microgrid, enhancing the flexibility and scalability of the charging DC microgrid. Through the performed analysis, it is demonstrated that the proposed DCX bipolar DC microgrid effectively mitigates unbalancing voltage issues without requiring additional control strategies, while achieving soft switching at both the primary switches and secondary diodes. Experimental results of the DCX operating at 5 kW with soft start ability indicate that the proposed architecture is a flexible and promising solution for next generation EV UFCS.

title: Net primary productivity of cropland simulated using the BEPS model
authors: Peng Wang, Yong Xue, Zhigang Yan, Botao He, Wenhao Liu, Xiaolu Ling
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Net primary productivity (NPP) of cropland is an important indicator for agricultural land management and monitoring, providing a basis for terrestrial carbon budgets and crop yield prediction. High spatial and temporal resolution NPP data can help us better understand the agricultural carbon cycle, more accurately capture NPP variations, and reduce uncertainties. In this study, we used the BEPS model to simulate the daily NPP of crops in the Yangtze Plain from 1984 to 2000, with a spatial resolution of 500 meters. The results show that: (1) From 1984 to 2000, the annual mean NPP of crops in this region was 435.079 gC/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>/year. The spatial distribution shows higher values in the northeast and lower values in the southwest. (2) Between 1984 and 2000, the NPP of crops ranged from 432.04 to 502.23 gC/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, showing a slight decreasing trend with a slope of -0.28 gC/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>/year. (3) The annual variation of NPP exhibits a three-peak waveform, which is related to the different crop types, planting systems, and cropping patterns. The results can provide a valuable reference for crop carbon cycle research and the formulation of planting policies.

title: DepthSeg: Depth Prompting in Remote Sensing Semantic Segmentation
authors: Ning Zhou, Shanxiong Chen, Mingting Zhou, Haigang Sui, Lieyun Hu, Han Li, Li Hua, Qiming Zhou
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Remote sensing semantic segmentation is crucial for extracting detailed land surface information, enabling applications such as environmental monitoring, land use planning, and resource assessment. In recent years, advancements in artificial intelligence have spurred the development of automatic remote sensing semantic segmentation methods. However, the existing semantic segmentation methods focus on distinguishing spectral characteristics of different objects while ignoring the differences in the elevation of the different targets. This results in land cover misclassification in complex scenarios involving shadow occlusion and spectral confusion. In this paper, we introduce a depth prompting two-dimensional (2D) remote sensing semantic segmentation framework (DepthSeg). It automatically models depth/height information from 2D remote sensing images and integrates it into the semantic segmentation framework to mitigate the effects of spectral confusion and shadow occlusion. During the feature extraction phase of DepthSeg, we introduce a lightweight adapter to enable cost-effective fine-tuning of the large-parameter vision transformer encoder pre-trained by natural images. In the depth prompting phase, we propose a depth prompter to model depth/height features explicitly. In the semantic prediction phase, we introduce a semantic classification decoder that couples the depth prompts with high-dimensional land-cover features, enabling accurate extraction of land-cover types. Experiments on the LiuZhou dataset validate the advantages of the DepthSeg framework in land cover mapping tasks. Detailed ablation studies further highlight the significance of the depth prompts in remote sensing semantic segmentation.

title: Orca Predation Algorithm for Large-Scale Economic Dispatch with Valve-Point Effect
authors: Vivi Aida Fitria, Danang Arbian Sulistyo
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: The digital transformation of the music industry has This study introduces the Orca Predation Algorithm (OPA), a novel bio-inspired optimization technique developed to address the Economic Load Dispatch (ELD) problem in power generation systems, particularly considering valve-point effects and operational power constraints. ELD is a critical challenge in power system operation, involving the allocation of generation loads among multiple units to minimize total fuel cost while satisfying system constraints. The proposed OPA draws inspiration from the predatory behavior of orca whales, aiming to enhance both convergence speed and solution quality in complex optimization landscapes. The algorithm was rigorously tested on a large-scale power system comprising 140 generation units, representing a highly complex environment for optimization due to the nonlinear and non-convex characteristics introduced by valve-point effects. Performance comparisons were conducted against well-established metaheuristic algorithms, including Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), Bat Algorithm, and Whale Optimization Algorithm (WOA). Simulation outcomes demonstrated that OPA achieved the lowest total generation cost of ${\$}$1566089.13, outperforming competing algorithms while maintaining computational efficiency. These results suggest that OPA is a promising and effective approach for solving large-scale ELD problems with practical constraints. Future research may focus on further refining the algorithm’s parameters, integrating it with hybrid methods, and applying it to other complex power system optimization challenges to validate its robustness and versatility.

title: An Approach for Simultaneous Radar Target Detection and HRRP Imaging Utilizing a Regularization-Based Super-Resolution Technique
authors: Zixi Wang, Jinfeng Hu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Traditionally, radar target detection and high-resolution range profile (HRRP) imaging have been implemented as two relatively independent processes, which not only results in a waste of pulse resources but also poses challenges in meeting the coherence and real-time requirements for target information acquisition in modern radar systems. This paper introduces an approach for simultaneously achieving radar target detection and HRRP imaging. By incorporating a novel variant range-dimensional regularized super-resolution technique, this approach effectively restores the scattering point distribution characteristics of the target, enabling the radar to generate more precise HRRP images while detecting targets. This approach not only simplifies the radar workflow and enhances processing efficiency but also provides more accurate information for subsequent tasks such as radar feature extraction and target recognition. At last, experiments are conducted to verify the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Improving Aerosol Retrieval from Himawari-8 with a Transformer Deep Learning Method
authors: Siyu Liu, Lina Xu, Minghui Tao, Xincai Chang, Siyu Zheng, Yihang Zou
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Himawari-8, an advanced geostationary meteorological satellite, provides high-frequency observational data, but still faces certain challenges in aerosol inversion. This paper proposes an improved algorithm based on the Transformer deep learning method to enhance the accuracy of aerosol retrieval. By leveraging the self-attention mechanism of the Transformer algorithm to effectively capture the complex relationships between aerosol characteristics and satellite observation data, while retrieving two parameters, Aerosol Optical Depth (AOD) and Angström Exponent (AE). The AOD retrieved from the algorithm is highly consistent with AERONET AOD measurements, with a correlation coefficient (R) of 0.931, and the precision of AE has also been improved (R=0.626), with over 70% of the samples for both parameters falling within the expected error (EE) range. Further comparisons with MODIS and AHI products were made to assess extreme aerosol events and a continuous aerosol variation event, demonstrating the algorithm's outstanding advantages.

title: Weighted Group Sparsity-Regularized Low-Rank Matrix Factorization in Gradient Domains for Hyperspectral Image Denoising
authors: Yao Wang, Jian-Li Wang, Rui Wang, Peng Liu, Heng-Chao Li
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Hyperspectral image (HSI) denoising is an important preprocessing step in subsequent image processing. Fully exploring the spatial-spectral priors of HSI is the core issue for HSI denoising. In this paper, we propose a weighted group sparsity-regularized low-rank matrix factorization (LRMF) model in the gradient domain for HSI mixed noise removal. Particularly, we first introduce the powerful LRMF on the spatial and spectral gradient maps to exploit the global low-rankness of HSI, which factorizes them into the corresponding spatial factor and spectral factor. Moreover, considering the group sparsity of spectral-spatial gradient maps, we introduce a weighted group sparsity regularization on spatial factors, which captures group sparsity more efficiently as compared with directly regularize on gradient maps. The proposed model can be efficiently solved by the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) algorithm. Numerous experiment results indicate that our method is superior to other state-of-the-art HSI denoising methods.

title: Enhancing Fine-grained Object Detection in Aerial Images via Orthogonal Mapping
authors: Haoran Zhu, Yifan Zhou, Chang Xu, Ruixiang Zhang, Fang Xu, Wen Yang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Fine-Grained Object Detection (FGOD) is a critical task in high-resolution aerial image analysis. This paper introduces Orthogonal Mapping (OM), a simple yet effective method aimed at addressing the challenge of semantic confusion inherent in FGOD. OM introduces orthogonal constraints in the feature space by decoupling features from the last layer of the classification branch with a class-wise orthogonal vector basis. This effectively mitigates semantic confusion and enhances classification accuracy. Moreover, OM can be seamlessly integrated into mainstream object detectors. Extensive experiments conducted on three FGOD datasets (FAIR1M, ShipRSImageNet, and MAR20) demonstrate the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed approach. Notably, with just one line of code, OM achieves a 4.08% improvement in mean Average Precision (mAP) over FCOS on the ShipRSImageNet dataset. Codes are released at https://github.com/ZhuHaoranEIS/Orthogonal-FGOD.

title: A Visual Large Model for SAR-to-optical Translation Based on Cross-ModaL Feature Extraction and Decoupling
authors: Kaiwen Zhu, Song Qiu, Yanan You, Qiang Wang, Yuanyuan Qiao
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) offers all-weather, high-resolution imaging capabilities but poses significant challenges for image interpretation due to its complex imaging mechanism. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a multimodal alignment-based generative model that transforms SAR images into more interpretable optical images, thereby enhancing their explainability. Specifically, the proposed model leverages the latest stable diffusion model as its backbone and incorporates a dual-path architecture comprising a layout controller and a content controller. An innovative cross-modal alignment image feature adapter is used to map SAR image features to optical image content. This design ensures the preservation of SAR geometric information while generating fine-grained optical texture details. Experimental validation on the SpaceNet 6 dataset demonstrates the effectiveness of our approach, with quantitative evaluations performed using Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR), Structural Similarity Index Measure (SSIM), and Fréchet Inception Distance (FID).

title: Low-Complexity NTT and INTT Structures via Twiddle Shifting
authors: Sin-Wei Chiu, Keshab K. Parhi
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: Polynomial modular multiplication is an important operation used in post-quantum cryptography and homomorphic encryption, which are based on ring learning with errors (RLWE) problems. For long polynomial lengths, this operation can be efficiently computed using number theoretic transform (NTT) and inverse NTT (INTT). In particular, negative wrapped convolution (NWC) has been proposed to compute this operation where zero padding is eliminated. Low-complexity structures for NTT (LCNTT) and INTT (LC-INTT) have been derived in prior work by using a divide-and-conquer approach. This paper presents an alternate derivation of the LC-NTT and LC-INTT structures from traditional NTT and INTT structures. Specifically, we show that using twiddle factor pushing (pulling) from left to right (right to left), we can derive the prior LC-NTT (LC-INTT) structures. We present systematic algorithms for twiddle factor pushing and pulling to derive the equivalent architectures. The alternate approach may provide opportunities for optimizing hardware implementations of polynomial modular multiplication.

title: Landslide Susceptibility Assessment based on the Coupling of Information Model and BP Neural Network
authors: Huiyu Yang, Lina Xu, Siyu Zheng, Yihan Wang, Yihang Zou, Huang Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Landslide disasters are frequent, large-scale and widely distributed in the world, which seriously affect the human living environment, national economic development and infrastructure construction. It is concentratedly distributed and has a mass occurrence, which has a great impact on the property safety and life safety of the people in the disaster area. In this study, Yuan ‘an County of Hubei Province was selected as the research area. According to the landslide characteristics of the study area, the evaluation indexes were selected and screened from the aspects of topography, geological structure, human engineering activities, meteorology and hydrology, and then the information value of each factor was calculated based on the information model. Finally, it was coupled with BP neural network to carry out the landslide susceptibility zoning of the study area.

title: Patent Landscape and Emerging Trends in Biosensors for Smart Systems
authors: Tia Pope, Ahmad Patooghy
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: Biosensor innovation is advancing, yet structured, data-driven patent analysis remains limited. We introduce an API-driven retrieval and classification framework, leveraging the PatentsView API to collect and categorize 138 biosensor patents since 2019. A keyword-based classification scheme and network and trend analysis identify key technological domains, innovation trajectories, and collaboration networks. Findings show leading contributions from Illumina, Inc., IBM, and Duke University. Patent filings declined in 2021 due to pandemicrelated disruptions but rebounded from 2022 to 2024, indicating renewed research efforts. Faster patent grant timelines suggest an accelerating innovation cycle, with AI-driven biosensing, wearable monitoring, and biocompatible materials emerging as key trends. However, commercialization challenges persist for graphene-based and nucleic acid biosensors. This study provides a scalable, replicable methodology with open-source code and visual analytics, enabling automated patent retrieval, computational analysis, and interactive visualization for future research.

title: Knock-Tolerant Integrated Energy Management in Series-Parallel Hybrid Electric Vehicle Using Bees-Inspired Adaptive Optimisation: Submit in the Special Session AI-Enhanced E-Mobility and Electrification of Propulsion Systems for Low-Carbon Transportation Applications
authors: Xu He, Ji Li, Duc Truong Pham, Bo Wang, Guoxiang Lu
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
