abstract: For current hybrid vehicles, the engine, electric motor, and battery combination require innovative management strategies to achieve efficient, safe, and coordinated operation of their components. This paper proposes a new integrated energy management strategy that considers the safe and efficient operation of both the engine and the battery. First, the artificial potential field guidance method is applied to engine management, integrating the engine's knock risk and thermal efficiency into the design of the dedicated field. Then, a Bees-inspired adaptive optimisation method is combined with a typical series-parallel state machine to split the required power for different power sources. Extensive verification of multiple laboratory calibration driving cycles shows that the proposed strategy significantly and robustly improves fuel economy while ensuring the efficient and safe operation of the battery and engine and reduces the engine state risk by 71.9% compared with the baseline method.

title: SAR Multi-Source RFI Mitigation Method Based on Low-Rank Matrix Decomposition and Completion
authors: Mingxing Shen, Zhaoyi Shao, Yu Hai, Zhongyu Li, Junjie Wu, Jianyu Yang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Ultra-wideband Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) is recognized for its high-resolution imaging capabilities. However, its broad spectral range increases susceptibility to both intentional and unintentional multi-source radio frequency interference (RFI). If not effectively suppressed, such interference can significantly degrade image quality, hindering subsequent applications. Various methods, including notch filtering in the frequency or time-frequency domain, have been proposed, but these often distort the echoes and the spectrum. Other methods that rely on interference modeling may underperform when the model is inaccurate. To address these issues, a multi-source RFI mitigation method for SAR based on matrix completion is proposed. Low-rank matrix completion theory is utilized to restore the damaged spectrum after interference notch filtering. An efficient algorithm is developed using a double Hankel matrix structure and matrix factorization decomposition, eliminating the need for singular value decomposition. Experiments validate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

title: Cross-Augmentation Based Adaptive Clustering for Semi-Supervised Cross-Scene Classification in Remote Sensing
authors: Shangyu Li, Yin Zhuang, Huazhe Guo, Can Li, Ye Zhu, He Chen
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Cross-scene classification aims to transfer knowledge from a source domain to a target domain with different distributions, and semi-supervised domain adaptation is commonly used to achieve high-performance cross-scene classification based on a few labeled target domain samples. However, there are significant discrepancies between the source and target domains, which hinder dual-domain alignment and knowledge transfer, resulting in limited performance improvement. Therefore, to solve the above issues, a novel semi-supervised cross-scene classification approach called Cross-Augmentation based Adaptive Clustering is proposed. First, a cross-domain data augmentation structure is proposed to facilitate alignment between the source and target domains. By utilizing the CutMix operation to labeled and unlabeled data, the method bridges domain discrepancies and facilitates the pseudo-label propagation through consistency regularization. Second, a adaptive clustering method for pseudo-labeled target domain data is introduced, grouping target data into clusters and further improving the quality of pseudo-labels. This approach facilitate dual-domain alignment and knowledge transfer, therefore improving cross-scene classification performance. Finally, experimental results on two publicly available datasets confirm that the proposed method effectively improves cross-scene classification performance for remote sensing imagery.

title: Evaluating MODIS and VIIRS Satellite AOD for Ground-Level PM2.5 Estimation in Thailand
authors: Suhaimee Buya, Hideomi Gokon, Sasiporn Usanavasin, Jessada Karnjana
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This study assesses the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) (1 km resolution) and the Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite (VIIRS) (6 km resolution) Aerosol Optical Depth (AOD) data for estimating PM2.5 concentrations in Thailand. Using data from 2018 to 2023, simple linear regression (LR) and random forest (RF) models were employed to gauge the accuracy of PM2.5 predictions from both AOD sources. LR results showed significant MODIS and VIIRS AOD correlations with PM2.5 (P < 0.05), achieving R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> values of 25.1% and 15.7%, respectively. RF models, accounting for the Digital Elevation Model (DEM) and week of the year (WOY), achieved R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> values of around 65% for validation. While MODIS slightly outperformed VIIRS, both products are reliable for PM2.5 estimation. MODIS AOD is suggested for historical analyses, and VIIRS is recommended for future monitoring to advance remote sensing in air quality studies.

title: Assessing High Voltage Substation Reliability Using Event Tree Analysis Under Protection Failures
authors: Adytia, Tumiran, Lesnanto Multa Putranto
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: Substations are critical components in electric power systems, serving as key nodes that connect generation sources, transmission networks, and load centers. Any failure occurring at a substation can have widespread consequences, potentially causing large-scale outages due to its direct connection to both the generation and distribution segments of the grid. Therefore, the reliability of a substation is a vital metric in assessing the overall performance of a power system. Different substations are built with various switching configurations which influences the system’s switching flexibility, fault tolerance, and ultimately, its reliability profile. These configuration differences result in varying reliability indices across substations. In this paper, the reliability of high voltage substations is analyzed using event tree analysis. This study aims to evaluate the impact of substation configuration types and their constituent components including main and backup protection systems, circuit breakers, and busbar protection on substation reliability indices. The results of this analysis are intended to serve as a technical reference for predicting substation performance and as a decision-making foundation for evaluating the reliability performance of power utility companies.

title: High-Level Synthesis Based FPGA Accelerator for GPS Signal Image Feature Extraction
authors: Kevin Young, Darshika G. Perera
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: GPS is becoming increasingly important for many applications, due to their precise positioning, navigation, and timing capabilities. The signals broadcasted by satellites are often quite weak and extremely susceptible to interference. Hence, the need for robust GPS receiver hardware. Many GPS systems (e.g., on UAVs) are deployed on resource-constrained embedded devices. In this paper, we propose an HLS-based FPGA hardware accelerator for image feature extraction of GPS interference signals, on embedded systems. Our HLS-FPGA hardware achieves up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8.2 \times$</tex> speedup compared to its software counterpart.

title: Co-Registration Analysis of Coherent Multitemporal Radargrams
authors: Elena Donini, Miguel Hoyo García, John Paden, Francesca Bovolo
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Radar Sounder data provide insights into subsurface geology and are typically analyzed using automatic techniques on single-pass acquisitions. A few preliminary studies have explored multitemporal RS data from the cryosphere. However, challenges related to data co-registration exist because of the acquisition geometry and the characteristics of the targets. This paper examines co-registration accuracy in overlapping bi-temporal RS acquisitions co-registered with coherent and non-coherent approaches to evaluate the importance of the phase signal. We project and co-register overlapping radargram pairs to mitigate the horizontal changes related to the ice motion and vertical variations in mass balance. We used the log ratio to compare the co-registered data and highlight backscattering differences in the radargrams due to residual misregistration (and morphological changes). We analyze overlapping radargram pairs acquired in Antarctica in 2014 and 2016.

title: Insights from Swot Data on Transboundary Upstream-Downstream Impacts in The Nile Basin
authors: Hesham Morgan, Wenzhao Li, Ali Elgendy, Surendra Maharjan, Rejoice Thomas, Hesham El-Askary
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This study utilizes high-resolution data from NASA's Surface Water and Ocean Topography (SWOT) mission to investigate water dynamics and upstream-downstream impacts across key reservoirs in the Nile Basin. Focusing on the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD), Rosaries Dam, Merowe Dam, and the Aswan High Dam, the analysis spans 15 months (August 2023 to October 2024). By systematically selecting 30 points across each reservoir, monthly boxplots of surface water elevation were generated, revealing significant temporal and spatial variability. The results show that GERD’s filling phase led to a steady increase in water levels (peaking at ~615 meters from June to October 2024), while downstream reservoirs experienced sharp declines. Rosaries and Merowe recorded their lowest levels in July 2024, with delayed recovery starting in September 2024, while the Aswan High Dam showed a gradual decline from April to August 2024, reflecting reduced upstream flows.The findings highlight the hydrological interdependence of Nile Basin reservoirs, where upstream water management, particularly GERD’s operations, has cascading effects on downstream regions. This study demonstrates the value of SWOT satellite data in capturing transboundary water dynamics and emphasizes the need for cooperative water governance strategies, including coordinated reservoir operations and data-sharing mechanisms, to address downstream water stress. By offering actionable data for sustainable resource management, this research represents a critical advancement in leveraging satellite Earth observations to inform policy and foster resilience in the conflict-prone Nile Basin.

title: Underwater Sensing of Ship-Radiated Noise Based on Interpretable Deep Learning and Acoustic Feature Fusion
authors: Haipeng Qin, Xinwei Chen, Weimin Huang, Linlin Xu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The detection of ship radiated noise holds great significance for the monitoring of marine environment. Deep learning (DL) methods have proven effective in enhancing the efficiency and accuracy of ship-radiated noise classification and have seen widespread application. However, challenges arise due to limited data availability and the difficulty of hydrophone placement for underwater noise signal collection. Additionally, comparative studies across methods remain scarce. This study addresses these challenges by expanding the dataset in two terms of ship model diversity and signal duration. Data fusion with a channel attention module is conducted on three types of acoustic features, which are combined as inputs to the classification models. The classification accuracy of various models and feature combinations is systematically compared. To elucidate the decision strategy for model classification, the Local Interpretable Model-Agnostic Explanation (LIME) algorithm is employed to visualize the distribution of effective classification areas. By integrating acoustic features, our method improves classification accuracy meanwhile provides insights into the underlying reasons for this improvement.

title: Comparative Evaluation of a New Bearingless Single-Stator Axial Flux Motor for an Implantable Pediatric Fontan Blood Pump
authors: Andreas Horat, Jonas Huber
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Implantable rotary blood pumps (RBPs) for pediatric patients who underwent the Fontan surgery support the patients' single heart ventricles, aiming at improving long-term outcomes. Such RBPs should be as small as possible (to facilitate implantation in very young patients) while the maximum power dissipation must not exceed 4 W (to limit blood heating), and mechanical bearings should be avoided to improve hemocompatibility. Therefore, this paper proposes a new bearingless single-stator axial flux motor (BSSAFM) using a magnetic counterweight. We include a comparative evaluation against two widely used slice motor topologies, namely the temple motor and the slotless motor, based on a multi-objective Pareto optimization framework including FEM simulations and detailed closed-loop dynamic models. An RBP based on the proposed six-phase BSSAFM shows about half the volume <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(8 \text{cm}^{3}\right)$</tex> of the temple and slotless motors at the same steady-state power dissipation of 1 W and with similar bearing stiffnesses.

title: Design Methodology for Multiresonant Gate Drivers: A SPICE-Based Optimization
authors: Asjad Elahi, Mohamed Youssef
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This study presents a novel optimization technique based on parameter sweep using a Simulation Program with Integrated Circuit Emphasis (SPICE) for Multi Resonant Gate Drivers (MRGD) that are used in resonant power converters and Switched Mode Power Supply (SMPS) applications. Unlike standard design approaches that use numerical methods as reported in previous studies, the proposed approach streamlines the design process and shortens the product development time by relying on data from simulation models. The proposed optimization is carried out in LTspice, optimizing only the key parameters that affect the frequency response of the multi-resonant filter. The MRGD aims to maximize operational efficiency at high frequencies when used in SMPS and resonant power converters. The proposed concepts are assessed and validated through a hardware prototype. With the help of simulation and hardware verification, the MRGD demonstrated improved efficiency, achieving a 34.8% reduction in gate drive losses compared to an off-the-shelf conventional Voltage Source Gate Driver (VSGD) based on UCC27517.

title: A birefringence correction for multi-frequency radar sounding
authors: Benjamin H. Hills, Matthew R. Siegfried, Duncan A. Young, John D. Paden, Shivangini Singh, Donald D. Blankenship, Dustin M. Schroeder
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: An ice crystal has uniaxial symmetry about its c axis and is therefore electrically anisotropic. Anisotropy in the real dielectric permittivity at radio wavelengths means that ice is birefringent to radar waves, including those commonly used to sound through ice masses. Radar birefringence can be targeted as a measurement signal to interpret ice anisotropy for ice rheology or ice-flow history; however, birefringent losses can also act as noise when targeting the reflected radar power as a measure of interface properties or attenuation. Here, we implement a method for correcting birefringent losses in multi-frequency radar sounding. Birefringent loss fringes occur at a regular interval that depends on the center frequency of the transmitted signal, so correlating loss fringes from independent measurements (i.e. from radar systems with different frequencies) enables a more precise and robust estimate of electrical anisotropy, which can then be used as a correction for birefringent power losses. We demonstrate our method with an example from a dual-frequency instrument recently used for sounding the Antarctic Ice Sheet. We choose an example where the loss fringes are visible within the specular englacial layers, but we argue that our correction method is useful even for a single diffuse reflector where the loss fringes may be obscured by variations in the reflector properties. Similar birefringent correction methods can be applied to planetary radar sounding cases, such as the two radar sounders orbiting Mars or the dual-frequency radar instrument onboard the Europa Clipper.

title: Secure Blind Signature-Based E-Voting System Using STRIDE and OWASP
authors: Rakha Maulana, Nathanael Berliano Novanka Putra, Ray Novita Yasa
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: This paper presents the design, implementation, and security evaluation of an institutional-level electronic voting (e-voting) system based on RSA blind signature cryptography. The system is developed using the Secure Software Development Life Cycle (SSDLC), with threats identified using STRIDE modeling and mitigated based on the OWASP Top Ten 2021 framework. Security validation is conducted through black-box testing with Burp Suite and Invicti, and white-box analysis using DeepSource. The evaluation revealed three low-severity vulnerabilities and six threat categories addressed through specific mitigation strategies. Performance measurements show that the system processes vote casting in approximately 91.2 ms and tabulation in 0.030 ms per vote. While the results demonstrate adequate performance and low-risk exposure under controlled conditions, limitations include the lack of manual penetration testing, potential blind spots in business logic validation, and the use of a self-signed certificate. These findings indicate the proposed system is suitable for institutional use, provided that further validation and refinement are undertaken prior to production deployment.

title: Refining Residents Evacuation Prediction Model: A Data-Driven Approach to Improve Accuracy Based on Objective Evaluation Metrics
authors: Akira Matsuki, Keisuke Ikeda, Kenta Senzaki, Masahiro Tani, Michinori Hatayama
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This paper proposes methods for improving prediction accuracy based on the objective evaluation of techniques predicting residents' evacuation behavior during flood events. Traditionally, technologies for predicting evacuation behavior during floods have lacked methods to assess prediction accuracy based on objective data and standardized metrics. In this study, we propose a method for evaluating prediction accuracy using spatiotemporal population distribution data from past flood events. Additionally, to enhance prediction accuracy as per the proposed evaluation metrics, we attempt to improve the evacuation behavior models of residents. While conventional evacuation behavior prediction models are built on survey results from residents, our proposed method makes it possible to conduct simulations that are more realistic by also considering the geographical characteristics of each resident's location and the timing of evacuation. Experimental results indicated that the proposed method achieved 7.2% reduction in prediction error compared to traditional evacuation behavior models.

title: Surpassing the Limits: Boosting Wind Turbines Power Capability with Optimized Converter Modulation
authors: Ioannis Tsoumas, Tinus Dorfling, Georgios Darivianakis, Mikko Saransaari
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: A novel modulation method for three-level neutral point clamped (3LNPC) converters which limits the dclink voltage low frequency ripple that appears in direct drives is presented. It allows to increase the generator power without the half dc-link voltage exceeding the blocking voltage of the semiconductors. This enables a substantial increase of the power that can be transmitted from the generator to the grid through the power electronic converter. The performance improvement is validated in Simulink and in HiL.

title: Large-Scale Leo Satellite Constellation Design for Bistatic Radar Detection of Aerial Target
authors: Ke Zeng, Yi Li, Yinsong Luo, Hui Kuang, Yongfei Mao, Zhichao Sun, Junjie Wu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: LEO satellites have been widely applied in areas such as regional surveillance and remote sensing. However, a single satellite is limited by its revisit time and cannot provide continuous monitoring of the interested target area. By implementing a constellation of satellites and designing the constellation appropriately, high revisit frequency and even continuous coverage over designated regions can be achieved. This paper proposes an LEO satellite constellation for bistatic radar to achieve detection and surveillance of aerial targets in key regions. The coverage and detection performance of a constellation are closely related to its configuration, which determines the satellites’ positions within the constellation. The overall performance can be optimized by carefully designing this configuration. The constellation design problem can be modeled as a constrained multi-objective optimization problem. However, when satellite orbital elements are treated as optimization variables, the decision space increases with the number of satellites, making it difficult for traditional optimization methods to find the optimal solution. This paper proposes a multi-orbit-multi-satellite (MOMS) optimization method, which uses four parameters to define the satellites in an orbital plane, significantly reducing the number of optimization variables for large-scale constellations. Additionally, it modifies the sorting mechanisms of the evolutionary algorithm to adapt to this method. The simulation results show that this method offers rapid convergence capability for large-scale constellations.

title: Symbiotic Evolution-Based Framework for Generating Music to Perform Routines Enjoyably and Appropriately
authors: Noriko Otani, Ayaka Ogiwara
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 9th International Conference on Intelligent Systems, Metaheuristics & Swarm Intelligence
abstract: Routines, as habitual daily tasks, are often performed unconsciously due to their repetitive nature. However, routines can become boring and may deviate from appropriate procedures. This paper focuses on the emotion- and behavior-inducing effects of music to reduce boredom and promote adherence to appropriate procedures. We propose a framework for automatically generating music that adapts to a person’s sensibility or mood to be played during routines, making them more enjoyable and appropriate. Since routines often involve repetitive short actions, symbiotic evolution is employed to create guiding music. Two case studies — instant soup making and tooth brushing — demonstrate the proposed framework.

title: Partial Ensemble Estimation for Complex-Shaped Pareto Fronts
authors: Kosuke Kikawada, Naru Okumura, Keiki Takadama, Hiroyuki Sato
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 9th International Conference on Intelligent Systems, Metaheuristics & Swarm Intelligence
abstract: This paper proposes a partial ensemble Pareto front estimation method for robustly estimating Pareto fronts with complex shapes, including both concave and convex regions. The conventional Pareto front estimation method faces difficulties in estimating complex-shaped Pareto fronts because it attempts to estimate the entire Pareto front at once. In contrast, the proposed method iteratively estimates each simpler segment of the complex-shaped Pareto front. The conventional method relies on a single response surface. However, multiple response surface methodologies exist, and their accuracy depends on the specific problem characteristics. To address this issue, the proposed method ensembles multiple response surfaces, each tailored to a specific segment of the Pareto front. To evaluate Pareto front estimation accuracy, this study compares the conventional and proposed methods using two- and three-objective WFG1 test problems with complex-shaped Pareto fronts. The comparison is conducted by varying both the number of known solutions used for Pareto front estimation and the number of concave and convex regions in the Pareto front. The results demonstrate that the proposed ensemble Pareto front estimation method achieves lower estimation errors than the conventional method in the majority of cases.

title: Machine Learning-based Feature Evaluation of the Factors Affecting the Effective Infrastructure Project Implementation
authors: Alfie T Cabael, Dante L Silva, Jimmy Catanes, Meriam P Leopoldo, Sheina R Pallega, Crispin Lictaoa
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 9th International Conference on Intelligent Systems, Metaheuristics & Swarm Intelligence
abstract: Numerous factors affect how well infrastructure projects are implemented in different agencies and organizations, therefore identifying the important factors requires a data-driven approach. This study uses neural network simulations to examine the relative impact of various components using a feature evaluation based on machine learning. Neural network simulations yielded high predictive accuracy, with correlation coefficients (R) ranging from 0.97294 to 0.99084 and mean squared errors (MSE) between 0.014255 and 0.024731, validating the robustness of the model. Results indicate that the absence of a Project Procurement Management Plan (PPMP) and Annual Procurement Plan preparation is the most critical parameter in implementation requirements. In fund management, interagency funds not taken up in trust accounts emerged as the most influential factor, highlighting potential financial inefficiencies. Architectural & Engineering (A&E) and Administration & Supervision (A&S) expense allocations were found to be the primary determinants in the budget allocation category. For procurement of equipment, supplies, materials, and services, the absence of lease-to-own agreements significantly impacts cost-effective resource acquisition. Additionally, deviations from audit guidelines in rental fee disbursements pose financial accountability risks in the authority to charge fees for equipment rental. These results highlight the necessity of better financial supervision, procurement planning, and regulatory compliance to increase the efficiency and transparency of infrastructure projects, offering policymakers and agency administrators practical insights.

title: App2: Model for apple leaf disease detection based on deep learning
authors: Erick Aronès, Jefferson Espinal, Cesar Salas
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 9th International Conference on Intelligent Systems, Metaheuristics & Swarm Intelligence
abstract: Accurate diagnosis of apple leaf diseases is essential for agricultural productivity in the Lima region, which accounts for 80% of apple production in Peru. Efficient management of these diseases is critical for preserving the health of local crops. This study proposes a hybrid model combining Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Support Vector Machines (SVMs) to diagnose diseases in apple leaves. In this approach, the CNN serves as a feature extractor, while the SVM classifies the extracted features to determine the presence of diseases. This method provides an effective diagnostic tool, contributing to improved disease management in their crops. By combining a CNN with an SVM, high performance is achieved in diagnosing apple leaf diseases. The model was trained and validated using the PlantVillage dataset, with data augmentation and a sample from the Plant Pathology 2021 dataset to increase the diversity of the dataset. Augmentation techniques included rotation, flipping, zoom, translation, and cropping. The proposed model achieved 98.25% in metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 Score, outperforming traditional CNN models and other hybrid approaches. These results demonstrate the robustness and effectiveness of the model, establishing it as a promising tool for disease detection in agricultural applications.

title: Evaluating Agricultural Crop Mask Generation: Case Study of a District in North India
authors: Aditya Singla, Ankit Chaudhary
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 9th International Conference on Intelligent Systems, Metaheuristics & Swarm Intelligence
abstract: Accurate crop mapping is critical for enhancing agricultural productivity and managing resources effectively. This paper presents an advanced method for generating crop masks using remote sensing data, specifically targeting wheat fields in the Karnal district of Haryana, India. Leveraging Sentinel-2 satellite imagery and machine learning techniques, we integrate supervised (Maximum Likelihood Classification) and unsupervised (ISODATA) classification methods with multi-temporal NDVI profiles to develop precise crop masks. Our approach addresses the spatial heterogeneity of wheat crops, facilitating better estimation of crop area and supporting decision-making for agricultural management. These findings contribute to the development of scalable, automated solutions for agricultural monitoring, providing insights for future applications in precision farming and food security.

title: OPCM: Opportunistic Performance-driven Connectivity Management for 5G/xG Networks
authors: Ahmad Hassan, Wei Ye, Anlan Zhang, Rostand A. K. Fezeu, Jason Carpenter, Ruiyang Zhu, Shuowei Jin, Myungjin Lee, Akshay Jajoo, Morley Mao, Zhi-Li Zhang, Feng Qian
publish: Proceedings of the ACM on Networking
abstract: 5G and future 6G networks deploy cells with diverse combinations of access technologies, architectures, and radio frequency bands/channels. Cellular operators also employ carrier aggregation for higher data access speeds. We investigate the fundamental question of how to intelligently and dynamically configure and reconfigure a user equipment's serving cells to deliver the best network performance. Through comprehensive measurements across 12 cities in 5 countries, we experimentally show the wide availability, heterogeneity, and untapped performance gains of today's cell deployments. We then present a principled, performance-driven connectivity management framework, dubbed OPCM. It is a centralized solution deployed at the base station, allowing it to coordinate multiple UEs, enforce operator policies, and facilitate user fairness. Extensive evaluations show that OPCM improves the application QoE by up to 65.2%.

title: On General Linear Encoding–Decoding Pairs for Quantized Iterative Learning Control
authors: Taojun Liu, Dong Shen, Daniel W. C. Ho
abstract: As control systems increasingly rely on limited-bandwidth networks, quantization and data rate constraints present significant challenges for iterative learning control (ILC). This study aims to design a general framework of linear encoding–decoding pairs for quantized ILC under channel transmission constraints. We first develop a unified mathematical framework that integrates existing encoding–decoding schemes within the quantized ILC loop, enabling both the linear encoder and decoder designs to be parameterized by a common set. By employing a p-type controller, we derive a convergence criterion for quantized ILC using the general linear encoding–decoding pair. Furthermore, we introduce a control signal fidelity metric (CSFM) to quantify the discrepancy between the control signal generated with and without a general linear encoding–decoding pair. Based on the CSFM, we provide systematic guidelines for selecting the parameters of the linear encoding–decoding pair. Finally, we establish practical selection rules for the parameters of linear encoding–decoding pairs when finite-level quantizers are used. These rules ensure that no saturation occurs while minimizing both the steady-state output tracking error and the CSFM, thus facilitating the practical quantizer selection in quantized ILC. The theoretical findings are validated through simulations involving industrial robot joint models.

title: Multi-timescale cross-platform co-simulation framework for electromagnetic-thermal-mechanical coupling analysis of solid-state power controllers
authors: Yongsheng He, Li Wang, Zihan Yin, Xing Li
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: With the rapid development of aerospace power distribution systems, conventional solid-state power controller (SSPC) modeling approaches exhibit significant limitations in multi-physics coupling coordination, complex characteristic representation, and predictive capability, which is difficult to meet the design requirements of high reliability and high efficiency. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a collaborative electromagnetic-thermal-mechanical co-modeling and simulation method for SSPC applications. By integrating detailed electrical circuit simulations with finite element thermal-mechanical analyses, a unified cross-domain modeling framework encompassing electrical, thermal, and mechanical fields is established. A multi-time scale coupling strategy related to SSPC operating conditions is designed to efficiently and accurately capture steady-state and rapid transient behaviors, balancing computational efficiency and simulation precision. The proposed method is validated on a 270 V/200 A SSPC module, demonstrating a good match between simulated and experimental results, with errors of key electrical and temperature parameters below 5%, and thermal strain differences less than 10%, which verifies the accuracy of the proposed method. The proposed methodology provides a comprehensive and precise tool for SSPC design optimization and reliability evaluation, and effectively improves the accuracy, efficiency and reliability of product development.

title: A Dual-Generalization Low-Light Enhancement Framework for Capsule Endoscopy Image Restoration and Segmentation
authors: Shuocheng Wang, Jiaming Liu, Ruoxi Zhu, Chengkang Huang, Minge Jing, Yibo Fan
abstract: In recent years, deep learning technology has automated the diagnosis of gastrointestinal (GI) tract disease, enabling doctor-machine collaborative diagnosis. However, the images captured by wireless capsule endoscopy (WCE) easily suffer from varying brightness levels of low-light degradation due to the complex structure of GI tract and the limitations of the light source, which impacts both human and machine diagnostic accuracy. Moreover, images may contain varying degrees of structural and semantic details even under a similar brightness level, which still can compromise segmentation accuracy. To address these issues, we propose a dual-generalization framework for low-light WCE images. Our framework includes an Image Guidance and Laplacian Fusion Module (IGLFM), a Brightness Level Generalization Module (BLGM) and a Wavelet Segmentation Generalization Module (WSGM). IGLFM and BLGM can restore low-light images across different brightness levels and WSGM can enhance segmentation accuracy by generalizing the varying degrees of details across images. With BLGM and WSGM, our framework enables two aspects of generalization: generalization to input images with different brightness levels and generalization to images with varying detail levels. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method achieves significant performance under varying brightness levels and improvements in segmentation accuracy, surpassing the existing state-of-the-art (SOTA) method with gains of 4.70 dB / 0.022 (PSNR/SSIM) on Kvasir-Capsule dataset and 1.61 dB / 0.018 on RLE dataset. WSGM consistently improves segmentation accuracy across six popular networks, achieving up to +4.7% mIoU and +5.3% Dice improvements on RLE dataset. Our code will be available at https://github.com/superwsc/Dual-Gen-Frame.

title: Comparative Analysis of Deep Learning Models for Real-World ISP Network Traffic Forecasting
authors: Josef Koumar, Timotej Smoleň, Kamil Jeřábek, Tomáš Čejka
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: Accurate network traffic forecasting is crucial for internet service providers to optimize resources, improve user experience, and detect anomalies. Until recently, the lack of large-scale, real-world datasets limited the fair evaluation of forecasting methods. The newly released CESNET-TimeSeries24 dataset addresses this gap by providing multivariate traffic data from thousands of devices over 40 weeks at multiple aggregation granularities and hierarchy levels. In this study, we leverage the CESNET-TimeSeries24 dataset to conduct a systematic evaluation of state-of-the-art deep learning models and provide practical insights. Moreover, our analysis reveals trade-offs between prediction accuracy and computational efficiency across different levels of granularity. Beyond model comparison, we establish a transparent and reproducible benchmarking framework, releasing source code and experiments to encourage standardized evaluation and accelerate progress in network traffic forecasting research.

title: Symbol-Level Precoding for Integrated Sensing and Covert Communication
authors: Yufei Wang, Qiang Li, Hongli Liu, Ying Zhang, Jingran Lin
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: Integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) systems have emerged as a promising solution to improve spectrum efficiency and enable functional convergence. However, ensuring secure information transmission while maintaining high-quality sensing performance remains a significant challenge. In this paper, we investigate an integrated sensing and covert communication (ISCC) system, in which a base station (BS) simultaneously serves multiple downlink users and senses malicious targets that may act as both potential eavesdroppers (Eves) and wardens. We propose a novel symbol-level precoding (SLP)-based waveform design for ISCC that achieves covert communication intrinsically, without requiring additional transmission resources such as artificial noise. The proposed design integrates symbol shaping to enhance reliability for legitimate users and noise shaping to obscure transmission activities from the targets. For imperfect channel state information (CSI), the framework incorporates bounded uncertainty models for user channels and target angles, yielding a more robust design. The resulting ISCC waveform optimization problem is non-convex; to address this, we develop a low-complexity proximal distance algorithm (PDA) with closed-form updates under both PSK and QAM modulations. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves superior covertness and sensing-communication performance with negligible degradation compared to traditional beamforming and conventional SLP approaches without noise-shaping mechanisms.

title: Direct Synthesis of Characteristic Polynomials and Practical Topologies for Codesigned Filters With Independent Subband Responses
authors: Yuxing He, Lunyong Xiao, Changning Wei, Xihua Zou, Lianshan Yan, Giuseppe Macchiarella
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This work presents a direct synthesis methodology for realizing codesigned filters that integrate low-pass/multi bandpass or high-pass/multi bandpass responses within a unified network. The proposed approach enables independent control over each subband—such as order, bandwidth, and return loss—while supporting flexible placement of transmission zeros (TZs) for enhanced out-of-band selectivity. The synthesis is built upon a new class of characteristic polynomials defined in the nonnormalized <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\omega $</tex-math> </inline-formula>-domain, which intrinsically realizes composite low-pass and multi bandpass filtering behavior without requiring frequency transformation. These polynomials are then mapped to a transversal prototype comprising low-pass and bandpass blocks, which can be corresponded to a high-pass/multi bandpass form via <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\omega $</tex-math> </inline-formula>-to-1/<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\omega $</tex-math> </inline-formula> inversion. The obtained transversal networks are then simplified into practical topologies through matrix-based manipulations. A series of examples, including synthesis and experimental validations, confirms the effectiveness and flexibility of the method. The proposed technique establishes a legitimate approach toward the integration of complex codesigned filtering functions based on simple resonator and coupling models.

authors: Xin Du, Haijuan Wu, Chao Tan, Guohua Hu, Siyuan Luo, Zegao Wang
abstract: Because of their anisotropic properties, certain 2-D materials exhibit distinct polarization-dependent optical response behaviors. Previous studies have mainly focused on light intensity detection, while limited research has been conducted on polarization detection. Notably, these studies generally concentrate on the dichroic ratio but overlook improvements in response sensitivity, rendering it challenging to achieve optoelectronic devices with both light intensity detection capability and excellent polarization detection performance. In this article, the optoelectronic and polarization detection properties of MoS<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>/In<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>Se<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub> heterojunction-type devices are systematically investigated. The results demonstrate that the MoS<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>/In<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>Se<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>/MoS<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> structure achieves optimal comprehensive performance, with a responsivity of32.7A/W under400nm light excitation, a specific detectivity of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$1.97\times 10^{{9}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> Jones, and a maximum dichroic ratio of18.6 at400nm. This study provides experimental and theoretical support for designing high-performance optoelectronic polarization detectors, promoting the development of related fields.

title: Joint Knowledge and Power Management for Secure Semantic Communication Networks
authors: Xuesong Liu, Yansong Liu, Haoyu Tang, Fangzhou Zhao, Le Xia, Yao Sun
abstract: Recently, semantic communication (SemCom) has shown its great superiorities in resource savings and information exchanges. However, while its unique background knowledge guarantees accurate semantic reasoning and recovery, semantic information security-related concerns are introduced at the same time. Since the potential eavesdroppers may have the same background knowledge to accurately decrypt the private semantic information transmitted between legal SemCom users, this makes the knowledge management in SemCom networks rather challenging in joint consideration with the power control. To this end, this paper focuses on jointly addressing three core issues of power allocation, knowledge base caching (KBC), and device-to-device (D2D) user pairing (DUP) in secure SemCom networks. We first develop a novel performance metric, namely semantic secrecy throughput (SST), to quantify the information security level that can be achieved at each pair of D2D SemCom users. Next, an SST maximization problem is formulated subject to secure SemCom-related delay and reliability constraints. Afterward, we propose a security-aware resource management solution using the Lagrange primal-dual method and a two-stage method. Simulation results demonstrate our proposed solution nearly doubles the SST performance and realizes less than half of the queuing delay performance compared to different benchmarks.

title: On the Distributed Transmission for Mid-Band ELAA Wireless Communication Systems
authors: Jiachen Tian, Yu Han, Xiao Li, Shi Jin, Chao-Kai Wen
abstract: The mid-band frequency range, combined with extra-large-scale antenna arrays (ELAA), is emerging as a critical enabler for future communication systems. However, deploying mid-band ELAA systems presents significant challenges due to the high complexity and overhead associated with signal processing tasks such as channel state information (CSI) acquisition. This paper introduces an efficient transmission framework that incorporates a distributed hardware architecture, distributed channel modeling, and a dual time-scale transmission protocol. Building upon this framework, a practical implementation is proposed, leveraging the discrete Fourier transform (DFT)-based radio frequency (RF) front-ends and linear receivers as the hardware foundation. Additionally, a novel transmission strategy is developed, exploiting both statistical and instantaneous CSI. The proposed framework includes approximations of the ergodic spectral efficiency (SE) to guide DFT beam selection based on statistical CSI. Furthermore, two user scheduling strategies are introduced, utilizing statistical CSI and location information, respectively, with angular division implemented in a distributed manner. Reduced-dimensional instantaneous CSI is then employed for both local and centralized processing. To support system design, the proposed transmission strategy’s ergodic SE performance is analyzed, focusing on the DFT RF front-end and the eigenvalue characteristics of channel correlation matrices. Numerical results reveal that the proposed framework and transmission strategy achieve SE comparable to fully-digital architectures, while significantly reducing overhead and complexity.

title: RSRWKV: A Linear-Complexity 2D Attention Mechanism for Efficient Remote Sensing Vision Task
authors: Chunshan Li, Rong Wang, Xiaofei Yang, Dianhui Chu, Xishuang Han, Xiaowen Chu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Deep learning methods have got a great success in high-resolution remote sensing analysis, especially Convolution Neural Network (CNN) and Transformer. However, CNNs have a failure in modeling the long-range dependency because of their fixed receptive fields and Transformers suffer from quadratic computational complexity relative to image resolution. The RWKV model achieves breakthroughs in natural language processing (NLP) through its linear-complexity sequence modeling; however, it exhibits anisotropic limitations in vision tasks due to the constraints of its one-dimensional scanning mechanism. To address these challenges, we adapt the RWKV architecture to high-resolution remote sensing and propose the Remote Sensing RWKV (RSRWKV) model, which incorporates a Linear-Complexity 2D Attention Mechanism. Specifically, RSRWKV employs a novel 2D-WKV scanning mechanism that bridges sequential processing with two-dimensional spatial reasoning while maintaining linear computational complexity. This design facilitates the aggregation of isotropic contexts in multiple spatial directions. Then, the MVC-Shift module further optimizes multiscale receptive field coverage, whereas the Efficient Channel Attention (ECA) module improves cross-channel feature interaction and semantic saliency modeling. Experimental evaluations on the NWPU RESISC45, VHR-10 v2, SSDD and GLHWater datasets demonstrate that RSRWKV surpasses CNN and Transformer baselines in classification, detection and segmentation tasks, establishing a scalable framework for high-resolution remote sensing analysis. Code available at https://github.com/Ling-yunchi/RSRWKV.

title: Deep Learning-Based Fault Diagnosis in Wind Turbine Bearings and Gearboxes Using Vibration Signals: Survey, Challenges, and Recommendations
authors: Tales Moreira Tavares, Mateus Giesbrecht
abstract: Wind power plays an important role in current global electric power generation scenario. With the increasing number of installed wind power generation units worldwide, efficient and cost-effective condition monitoring strategies become more relevant. Gearboxes and bearings are critical components in wind turbine (WT) operation, and enhancing the monitoring of these components contributes to improving wind power technology reliability and overall performance. In recent years, Deep Learning (DL) methods have emerged as tools for fault diagnosis in gearboxes and bearings in many different rotating machines, with the capacity to extract features from data and perform fault diagnosis in a more automated way. Even though DL methods can achieve high accuracy rates in diagnosis tasks, proper model training and application pose several challenges. In rotating machines fault diagnosis, DL models learn from labeled datasets; thus, these models can show poor generalization to classify data from unseen conditions. Such problem is concerning for WTfault diagnosis, where public available labeled datasets are scarce. In addition, DL models have inherently low interpretability, raising concerns about its application to real scenarios. In this context, this paper presents a literature review of the recent research on DL methods applied to fault diagnosis of WT bearings and gearboxes. The review focuses on the main challenges faced in this field, presenting and discussing the main strategies proposed to address them, including Transfer learning and explainable artificial intelligence techniques. This work aims to support future research and development on WT condition monitoring by providing a critical overview of current methodologies.

title: Optimization Design of Three-Phase CLLC Resonant Converter Based on Planar Magnetic Integration
authors: He Cheng, Xingyue Li, Jiaxuan Wang, Kai Xu, Jing Zhou
abstract: The three-phase CLLC resonant converter is widely used in on-board-charger application due to its low component stress, low output ripple, and high power density. However, the large number of switches, driver circuits, and magnetics in the converter can lead to low efficiency under light-load conditions. Although phase-shedding method can effectively improve light-load efficiency by shutting down one or two bridges when the load current decreases, implementing these strategies in resonant converters based on integrated magnetic cores is challenging due to the magnetic coupling between phases. To address this issue, this paper proposes and optimizes a planar integrated magnetic core structure that integrates all magnetic components, significantly enhancing power density. This structure effectively mitigates the coupling between phases, simplifying the implementation of the phase-shedding method and further reducing core losses with additional optimization. The effectiveness of the proposed optimized design is validated through experimental testing on a 2.5 kW three-phase CLLC resonant converter prototype based on SiC devices.

title: Elaborated Dual-Path SOT-MRAM Achieving 500-MHz Read and 100-MHz Write for Energy-Constraint Applications
authors: Zhenghan Fang, Hongjin Zhu, Haoran Du, Shuyu Wang, Hao Cai
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: This brief proposes a novel read-write scheme for energy-efficient SOT-MRAM. First, a dual-path-based smart write scheme is introduced, which utilizes a low-leakage half Schmitt Trigger (LLH-ST) to enable both early judge termination and write complete termination in a dual write path. Based on the pulse-width-dependent critical switching current characteristics of SOT devices, we propose a dynamic gradient-ascent (DGA) write driver to mitigate write energy consumption under device level variations. For write operation, a feedback voltage-controlled negative differential resistance (FV-NDR) structure is applied. It enables voltage latching by comparing and feeding back the stored data, allowing rapid readout during the discharge phase and achieving low power consumption. Based on a 40nm CMOS technology, the proposed dual-path-based smart write scheme with DGA write driver achieves power savings of 86.27% at early judge termination and 67.64% at write complete termination, with no additional timing overhead compared to other write termination schemes. The proposed FV-NDR structure achieves 75.35% read power savings compared to traditional readout, offering a read window of 257.1 mV and enabling 1.9ns readout.

title: Ester Oil Ageing Characteristics of Titania Doped Silicone Rubber Nanocomposites
authors: P Aneesudheen, Palash Mishra, Pawel Rozga, R Sarathi, Alok Ranjan Verma, Mithun Mondal
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: Ester based insulating oils are increasingly favored over mineral oils for transformer applications due to their high dielectric strength, biodegradability, and environmental compatibility. To enhance antipollution flashover performance in porcelain based oil filled transformer bushings, silicone rubber coatings are widely used. However, silicone rubber undergoes significant degradation when exposed to transformer oil, necessitating material enhancement. This study investigates the aging performance of TiO₂ doped silicone rubber composites thermally aged in synthetic ester oil at 80°C for 250 hours. TiO₂ was selected for its high thermal conductivity, dielectric strength, and potential to improve aging resistance. Composites with 0, 1, 5, 10 and 15 wt.% TiO₂ nanoparticles were synthesized. Ester oil aging degraded all specimens physicochemical, thermal, and electrical properties. Weight gain analysis showed reduced oil absorption in TiO₂ doped samples compared to unfilled specimens. FTIR analysis revealed scission of Si-O-Si backbone and Si-CH₃ side chains post aging, resulting in reduced surface hydrophobicity. Thermal stability, evaluated through thermogravimetric analysis, showed decreased residual weights and increased surface cracking in all aged samples. Tracking and erosion resistance, assessed per IEC 60587, declined in aged specimens. Also, infrared thermography revealed significantly lower surface temperatures in TiO₂ filled composites during tracking and erosion testing. Surface charge studies indicated reduced charge accumulation and faster decay rates in aged samples, with TiO₂ composites showing better retention properties. Among tested formulations, the 10 wt.% TiO₂ composite exhibited superior resistance to ester oil aging degradation, demonstrating its potential as an enhanced coating material for transformer bushing applications.

title: Deep Learning Approaches for Partial Discharge Localization and Apparent Charge Prediction in Generator Stator Windings
authors: Mehdi Nourollahi, Mohammad Hamed Samimi, Arash Abyaz
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: Partial discharges (PDs) are critical indicators of insulation degradation in generators, and their early detection is essential to prevent severe damage and costly repairs. This study investigates the application of deep learning techniques to enhance both the detection and localization of PD events in generator stator windings, as well as to predict the associated apparent charge. Using a comprehensive finite element method (FEM)-based simulation model, PD data are generated and subsequently analyzed with various neural network architectures, including multi-layer perceptron (MLP), convolutional neural networks (CNN), temporal convolutional networks (TCN), CNN + long short-term memory (LSTM) hybrids, and transformer. The models are evaluated on two primary tasks: PD localization and apparent charge prediction. The transformer model demonstrates superior performance in PD event localization, largely due to its self-attention mechanism, which captures long-range dependencies within the data. In contrast, the CNN model outperforms the other models in charge prediction, achieving the lowest max deviation and max variation, thereby minimizing prediction errors. The study also explores the trade-offs between model complexity, computational efficiency, and prediction accuracy, offering valuable insights into optimal model selection for specific tasks in industrial applications.

title: Oil Spill Segmentation in SAR Imagery with a Deep Encoder-Decoder Network
authors: Awais Tahir, Ehtasham Naseer, Muhammad Adnan Siddique
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Oil spills pose a serious risk to coastal and marine ecosystems. Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) sensors are extensively utilized to monitor oil spills due to their efficacy in diverse weather and illumination conditions. In this research, we utilize a publicly available Deep SAR Oil Spill (SOS) dataset comprising ALOS PALSAR and Sentinel-1 data. We propose an computationally efficient U-shaped encoder-decoder based method for the oil spills segmentation. A lightweight MobileNetV3 is introduced as the encoder backbone for the feature extraction. Additionally, multiparallel depthwise dilated separable convolutions with different receptive fields are employed to improve the detection performance of the oil spills. Our proposed architecture comprises 7.49 million parameters, representing a reduction of 4.21 times compared to the state-of-the-art model for this dataset. The method achieves a mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) score of 88.19% for Sentinel-1 data and 88.0% for ALOS PALSAR data. Compared to the existing state-of-the-art, our approach demonstrates an improvement of 2.44% in mIoU on the Sentinel-1 dataset and 1.28% on the ALOS PALSAR dataset, while significantly reducing the model complexity.

title: Physics-Informed Deep Learning for Universal Tropical Cyclone Monitoring Using Satellite Infrared Imagery
authors: Chong Wang, Xiaofeng Li
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Accurate tropical cyclone (TC) monitoring is critical for disaster warnings and risk reduction. Satellite infrared imagery plays a pivotal role in TC monitoring. However, traditional TC monitoring methods often rely on separate models for different tasks, requiring multi-step workflows and pre-alignment of TC centers, which introduces inefficiencies and limits their robustness. To address these challenges, we propose a physics-informed deep-learning framework for Universal TC Monitoring (UTCM). The UTCM model leverages satellite infrared imagery to simultaneously perform three key monitoring tasks: TC center location, intensity estimation, and R34 wind radius estimation. The model integrates a ResNet152-based feature extraction module with a multi-task branching module, enhanced by a cross-branch learning mechanism to capture inter-task relationships. Additionally, a physics-informed constraint derived from the mathematical relationships among TC center, intensity, and R34 wind radius is embedded into the loss function to improve accuracy and physical consistency. Experimental results demonstrate that the UTCM model outperforms single-task models, achieving 3.81%, 4.74%, and 4.03% improvements in TC center location, intensity estimation, and R34 wind radius estimation, respectively. This study highlights the effectiveness of combining satellite infrared imagery with physics-informed deep learning for robust, efficient, and accurate TC monitoring, contributing to improved warning systems and disaster management strategies.

title: An Improved AVHRR Fractional Snow Cover Mapping Algorithm Using MODIS Observations Combined with Time-Scale Decomposition
authors: Yifei Zheng, Lingmei Jiang, Fangbo Pan
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Long-term fractional snow cover (FSC) data is a critical input for hydrological, climatic, and energy balance models, making its monitoring essential for understanding global climate and hydrological processes. AVHRR, as a unique long-term remote sensing sensor, provides valuable snow cover data, but its low spatial resolution and limited spectral bands present challenges for accurate snow cover retrieval. To overcome these challenges, this study proposes an improved AVHRR FSC mapping algorithm by combining time-scale decomposition with XG Boost, using MODIS observations to enhance spatial resolution and accuracy. The model generates AVHRR FSC products with 500 m resolution, significantly improving FSC accuracy compared to the original AVHRR data, with RMSE reduced from 0.196 to 0.107. These results highlight the potential of AVHRR in long-term snow cover monitoring and the benefit of combining machine learning and higher-resolution data.

title: Coastal Wetland Mapping Using CNN_RF based on Multi-Temporal and Multi-Source Sensors
authors: Zixuan Wang, Changxu Shen, Zhijun Fan, Hongtao Shi, Zhong Lu, Jinqi Zhao
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In order to acquire classification results from limited ground truth data to other years and address the challenges in extracting high-quality features with limited samples, a novel coastal wetland mapping using CNN_RF based on multi-temporal and multi-source sensors is proposed. Firstly, change detection using the Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM) is applied to Sentinel-1 and Sentinel-2 data, leveraging spectral and backscatter features to accurately identify unchanged areas. Subsequently, a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) is employed for feature extraction, enabling the extraction of deeper, abstract features from the images. Finally, Random Forest (RF) is used for mapping, capitalizing on its ability to process high-dimensional data effectively. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieved excellent class separability, with an average overall accuracy (OA) of 88.2% and an average Kappa coefficient of 0.853. In addition, the CNN_RF classification conducted on the Yellow River Delta from 2019 to 2024 reveals that the extensive eradication of Spartina alterniflora is achieved as a result of government intervention.

title: FDA-MIMO Radar Interference Identify Using Multi-Channel Cosine Similarity and Random Forest
authors: Zhonghao Wang, Yizhen Jia, Wen-Qin Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This paper introduces a space-time multi-channel interference classification method for FDA-MIMO radar to enhance interference detection and anti-jamming capabilities. By integrating traditional time-frequency features with a novel cosine similarity feature, the method effectively captures relationships between multi-channel signals, improving interference discrimination accuracy. A Random Forest model is employed for classification. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves a classification accuracy of 99.14%, outperforming the 98.99% accuracy obtained using time-frequency features alone. Moreover, the method exhibits robustness across varying Interference-to-Noise Ratio (INR) conditions. It successfully identifies and classifies six distinct types of complex radar interference, offering a promising solution for improving FDA-MIMO radar performance in electronic warfare environments.

title: Optimal Ground Target Path Planning for Angular Rate Constrained Agile Satellite Imaging Maneuvers
authors: Dennis D. Langer, Simen Berg, Tor A. Johansen, Asgeir J. Sørensen
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Agile satellite imaging can improve coverage and image quality depending on application, for example, covering a lake with a cyanobacteria bloom event in a single image scan as opposed to several. Previous work relating to agile imaging focuses mostly on scheduling, for example by dividing point, line and area targets into straight line segments that are scheduled to be consecutively imaged. A question that is little addressed in the literature is how to define curved imaging target paths for agile satellites. We present a simple approach to generate a curved imaging target path for agile imaging that considers coverage goals and an angular velocity constraint. The approach is verified by commanding the curved imaging paths to the push-broom hyperspectral imaging satellites HYPSO-1/2. The approach is able to automatically define suitable imaging paths given HYPSO-1/2’s maneuvering constraints, and specified ground target and observation time.

title: Comparative Analysis of Single-Stage and Multi-Stage Transformer Solutions for Electrolyzer Plants Supplied from HVDC Grids
authors: Anna Shubnaya, Ashkan Raki, Hans-Peter Nee
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: As the demand for hydrogen increases, large-scale electrolyzer plants powered by renewable energy sources are gaining attention. High Voltage Direct Current (HVDC) grids can be used to supply these plants, as they are widely employed to transmit large amounts of renewable energy over long distances. In this paper, a low-frequency transformer-based solution for providing the required output voltage for electrolyzers is explored. Specifically, this paper focuses on designing a transformer cascade that enables high-ratio, high-power voltage conversion. The applicability of transformer scaling laws to this scenario is examined and the increase in transformer window size at different voltage ratings is analyzed. A detailed comparison of single-stage and two-stage transformer solutions is performed, considering factors such as material usage, losses, and leakage impedance. The proposed solutions are modeled and simulated using Ansys Maxwell software. The results indicate that the increase in material costs for a two-stage solution is considerably lower than predicted by conventional scaling laws.

title: Shadow-Aware 3D Gaussian Splatting for Multi-View Satellite Images
authors: Jiawei Zhang, Xiangrong Zhang, Junxiao Li, Xu Tang, Tianyang Zhang, Guanchun Wang, Feixiang Liu, Licheng Jiao
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Novel View Synthesis (NVS) in satellite remote sensing aims to generate images from previously unobserved viewpoints, facilitating a more comprehensive analysis of Earth’s surface. Recently, 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) has demonstrated significant computational efficiency due to its explicit scene representation and fast differentiable rasterization algorithm. However, its direct application to satellite remote sensing is hindered by the precise camera pose requirements and the challenges posed by complex lighting conditions. To address these limitations, we propose an improved 3DGS algorithm (Shadow-GS) to enhance the accuracy and efficiency of 3D satellite image reconstruction. First, we mitigate 3DGS’s reliance on precise camera poses by converting the Rational Polynomial Coefficient (RPC) parameters of satellite images into equivalent pinhole camera parameters, simplifying the projection process. Second, we introduce a shadow-aware irradiance model to learn the irradiance under different solar angles, enabling the method to handle multi-view satellite images with varying lighting conditions. Experimental results on the DFC2019 dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our method in satellite scene reconstruction.

title: ASC-SEM: ASC-based Scattering Enhancement Matrix for SAR ATR
authors: Jiacheng Chen, Tingyi Kang, Haipeng Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Deep learning recognition methods for synthetic aperture radar (SAR) remote sensing images are adapted from approaches used in optical image recognition. However, due to the fundamental differences between SAR and optical images, directly applying optical image interpretation methods to SAR images faces certain limitations. Many researchers have introduced the attribute scattering center (ASC) model to address the challenge of using deep learning methods for SAR image interpretation. Existing mainstream methods include ASC-CNN fusion approaches. However, most fusion methods generally have several issues: (1) the ASC extraction process must be completed in advance, making the approach non-end-to-end; (2) directly combining the low-dimensional features of ASC with the high-dimensional features of CNN leads to mismatched features; (3) the fusion process is often complicated, making it difficult to develop a general and effective enhancement methodology for SAR automatic target recognition (ATR). To tackle these issues, this paper proposes a performance enhancement paradigm based on the ASC model, namely an ASC-based Scattering Enhancement Matrix (SEM). The matrix is generated by a brief dual-encoder single-decoder network and performs pixel-level dynamic enhancement on original SAR images. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method can improve the performance of various networks in SAR image target recognition tasks, particularly when faced with insufficient training samples.

title: Evaluating User Experience in a Multi-User Virtual Reality Environment for Vocational Certification
authors: Syaad Patmanthara, Dwi Agus Sudjimat, Dhega Febiharsa, Hakkun Elmunsyah, Wahyu Nur Hidayat
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: The Multi-User Virtual Environment for Profession Certification Assessment (MUVE PCA) utilizing virtual reality (VR) technology is designed to address equipment limitations in vocational competency assessments. This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness and user experience of the MUVE PCA application in the vocational certification process, particularly in the fields of networking and computers. The study tested the MUVE PCA application using the Meta Oculus Quest 2 Head Mounted Device (HMD) and gathered participant feedback using the User Experience Questionnaire (UEQ). The long version of the UEQ, employing a 7-point Likert scale, was analyzed using UEQ Analysis Tools version 12. A total of 49 vocational high school students participated, with 42 valid responses analyzed after excluding 7 inconsistent data points. The results show that MUVE PCA received positive scores in all UEQ categories. The Attractiveness aspect scored 1.88, the Pragmatic Quality aspect scored 1.6, and the Hedonistic Quality aspect scored 1.56, suggesting overall user acceptance of the application. Although $8 \%$ of respondents experienced discomfort while using the HMD device, the majority reported feeling comfortable with the application. Based on the findings, it can be concluded that the MUVE PCA application provides a positive user experience and is a viable tool for use in classroom learning experiments. Despite minor discomfort from the HMD, the overall acceptance of the application indicates its potential for use in vocational education and certification assessments.

title: Physics-Based Circuit Model for Nonlinear Magnetic Loss and Permeability
authors: Liwen Zou, Han Cui
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Magnetic materials exhibit nonlinear losses and permeability that vary with excitation amplitude and frequency, posing significant challenges in modeling and designing magnetic components. Traditional models utilizing curve-fitting methods require large amount of measurement data to match with, which lacks accuracy and generality. In contrast, this work proposes a physics-based model that directly links microscopic magnetic dynamics to macroscopic material properties, providing an intrinsic description of nonlinearity. The model translates the Landau-Lifshitz-Gilbert (LLG) equations into equivalent circuits that capture the rotational dynamics of a magnetic domain, where the three-dimensional magnetization is represented by voltages, and the magnetic fields by currents. This approach clarifies the physical origins of nonlinear magnetic losses and permeability variations. Simulation results demonstrate the model's ability to accurately simulate magnetization processes, frequency-dependent complex permeability, B-H loop and magnetic core losses under different DC bias conditions, with validation against datasheet data for a commercial ferrite core (N87).

title: Optimizing Deployment Strategies for Large Language Models: A Comparative Analysis of Cloud, On-Premises, and Hybrid Solutions for Enhanced Efficiency and Continuous Improvement
authors: Ramkinker Singh, Madhuri Sesha Sarma
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society Conference - Global (TEMSCON Global)
abstract: Large language model deployment strategies optimize their usability and performance. In the comparison here, cloud, on-premises, and hybrid models are the options, each with their advantages and limitations. Cloud deployment is cost-efficient and scalable, but has issues with data security and vendor lock-in. On-premises deployment offers control and security but at the expense of costly infrastructure and maintenance. The hybrid model uses the best of both approaches to realize resource utilization and performance optimization. This contrast highlights the need for consideration of deployment strategies based on scalability, cost, security, power efficiency, and accessibility to facilitate effective LLM deployment.

title: Anomaly Detection in Drone Videos for Preventive Maintenance of Power Lines
authors: Guillaume Fourret, Marc Chaumont, Gérard Subsol, Christophe Fiorio, Samuel Brau
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Power lines are composed of various components that can deteriorate over time due to use. To detect potential issues with these components and prevent costly network outages, aerial drones are increasingly being utilized. They allow for the rapid inspection of large distances and provide a clear view of the different components and their defects. However, the manual analysis of flight videos by experts is labor-intensive. Moreover, the wide variety of anomalies that can cause network interruptions makes it impractical to develop dedicated automated solutions for each type, particularly due to the limited number of examples available for many anomalies. We thus propose a method to automatically detect anomalies in scenarios where no prior information about the visual appearance of anomalies is available, using drone-acquired videos. The approach relies on the computation of an anomaly score based on a generic feature vector. Results demonstrate that this approach is effective in scenarios without any examples of anomalies and requires very limited computational resources for learning.

title: Millimeter-Wave Radiation Brightness Temperature Modeling of Ship with Wake Based on Ray-Tracing
authors: Shen Ren, Danmeng Zhang, Jinxing Li, Wangqiang Jiang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Modeling and simulation of millimeter-wave (MMW) radiation imaging for maritime targets is a critical aspect of modern remote sensing and radar technology, which offers supplementary data to measurements, aiding in the interpretation and prediction of oceanic MMW radiation phenomena, while also enabling the evaluation of the performance of radiation detection systems. This research explores a simulation method specifically tailored to complex maritime environments. The method incorporates several key components, including the modeling of maritime targets along with their wakes, facet division, ray-tracing, and the calculation of brightness temperature. A radiation model for maritime targets is developed, combining the radiation emitted by the targets themselves with the radiation from their surrounding background. Additionally, the model takes into account the reflections of the targets, capturing the effects of both direct radiation and multiple reflections between the target and its environment.

title: The Application Procedures of High Wind From Scatterometer Products in Hainan Island
authors: Chang Xu, Xiaoqing Xiong, Xingou Xu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Early disaster warnings are critical for risk reduction, as highlighted by the World Meteorological Organization (WMO). Ocean surface wind field data, especially from tropical cyclone observations, play a key role in disaster prediction and management. Microwave scatterometers, with over 40 years of proven reliability, provide high-quality wind data using normalized radar cross-sections and geophysical model functions. This research examines the application of scatterometer wind data for tropical cyclone monitoring, focusing on Hainan Province, China. A detailed implementation plan demonstrates how enhanced wind remote sensing integrates with geoinformation systems to improve disaster prediction and decision-making, advancing early warning systems and reducing disaster impacts.

title: MCA-BIT: A Multi-Scale Coordinate Attention BIT Model for Building Change Detection
authors: Yujie Song, Tong Li, Linlin Wang, Junping Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In the context of rapid urbanization, building change detection is of great significance in many fields. However, due to the influence of light, shadow and other factors, building change detection faces the challenge of limited accuracy caused by incomplete edge and multi-scale identification problems. In this paper, multi-scale Coordinate Attention bitemporal image transformer(MCA-BIT) model is proposed to address the aforementioned issue based on bitemporal image transformer (BIT) model. Coordinate Attention is introduced into the backbone network of MCA-BIT model to improve the integrity of the object edge. Besides, Atrous Spatial Pyramid Pooling is added after the Transformer encoder to enhance the multi-scale feature extraction ability. The experiments on two building change detection datasets show advanced performance compared to other state-of-art models.
