title: A Computationally Efficient Splitting Wavelet Compression Algorithm for Wearable ExG Acquisition and Transmission System
authors: Yiming Han, Jiankun Li, Yaoyao Jia
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a computationally efficient Discrete Wavelet Transform (DWT) compression algorithm designed for implementation in resource-constrained microcontrollers (MCU) of wearable devices for electrophysiological (ExG) processing. With such a limited computational resource, we introduce two major strategies to improve the proposed algorithm's computational efficiency. First, given that ExG signals usually exhibit distinct specific patterns, the DWT for them can be simplified by focusing on certain wavelet levels. This excludes redundant convolution operations and resulting wavelet coefficients, reducing the computation load. Second, the algorithm employs a splitting strategy that distributes the DWT computation load across the intervals of other MCUs' tasks, such as data sampling, to reduce the peak computation time. To verify the performance of the proposed computationally efficient algorithm, we implemented it in the MCU (nRF52832) using the MIT-BIH ECG dataset as input. Extensive evaluations demonstrate that the proposed DWT algorithm achieves a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.62 \times$</tex> compression ratio (CR) with a percentage root-mean-square difference (PRD) of 3.1 %. Moreover, our algorithm reduces total computation time by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.9 \times$</tex> and peak computation time by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20.9 \times$</tex>.

title: Energy-Recycling High-Voltage Resonant Driver for Ultrasound Systems
authors: Ardavan Javid, Mehdi Kiani
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a resonant driver with energy-recycling capability for battery-powered, high-voltage (HV), portable ultrasound (US) systems, where minimizing power consumption is crucial. The proposed HV driver significantly reduces power loss by utilizing a capacitor matched to the transducer's capacitance and a small off-chip inductor to recycle energy, which is typically wasted in conventional class-D designs. Additionally, an on-chip calibration mechanism compensates for capacitor mismatches, further optimizing power efficiency. The theoretical analysis of the proposed energy-recycling technique is also provided. The proposed driver can efficiently drive large capacitive loads, particularly those inherent in piezoelectric micromachined US transducers (PMUTs). The circuit is designed and simulated in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.18-\mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> HV BCD technology, driving a 1 nF load at 2 MHz with 30 V pulses, achieving 80.1 % reduction in power consumption compared to conventional class-D pulsers.

title: IEEE Standard for Qualifying Alternating Current Class 1E Motors for Nuclear Power Generating Stations
authors: N/A
abstract: Class 1E motors, along with their interfaces, are required to meet or exceed the specified performance requirements throughout their service life. This is accomplished through a program that includes, but is not limited to, design, qualification, production quality control, shipping, storage, installation, operation, maintenance, periodic testing, and surveillance. The qualification portion of the program is addressed by this standard. The requirement for maintenance, repair, and surveillance of motors to maintain their qualification throughout their service life is discussed, but detailed guidance on how these programmatic items must be implemented and maintained is not provided. When the qualification requirements of this standard are met, the ability of the motor and/or insulation system to perform its safety function(s) under specified service conditions is demonstrated and documented.

title: External Deformation Measurement of a Rockfill Dam by PSInSAR Analysis Using ALOS-2 SAR Data for Eight Years
authors: Hidenori Abo, Takahiro Osawa
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: PSInSAR analysis utilizing Advanced Land Observing Satellite (ALOS) -2 SAR data was conducted for a rockfill dam that has entered the stabilization phase but has exhibited a deformation of up to approximately 10 mm per year over the past several years. PSInSAR analysis employing ALOS-2 SAR data demonstrated that a substantial number of PS points were obtained across the entire outer surface of the rockfill dam. The accuracy of the PSInSAR analysis was validated by comparing the displacement measurements from the PSInSAR analysis with survey data.

title: Assessing the Sensitivity of Semi-Empirical Snow Depth Retrieval Algorithms to Inter-Sensor Brightness Temperature Differences
authors: Guangjin Liu, Lingmei Jiang, Huizhen Cui, Jinmei Pan, Wei Ma
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Spaceborne microwave radiometers are key instruments for retrieving snow depth, but brightness temperature differences (TBDs) among different sensors make it challenging to build consistent long-term snow depth datasets. This study compared the brightness temperature differences between DMSP-F18/SSMIS and AMSR2, and FY-3D/MWRI and AMSR2 sensors. The results indicate that the TBDs between FY-3D/MWRI and AMSR2 are lower than those between F18/SSMIS and AMSR2. Then, we compared the sensitivity of seven semi-empirical snow depth retrieval algorithms to TBDs from different sensors. The results show that the AMSR2 algorithm exhibits a lower mean difference, while the SPD algorithm shows a lower standard deviation (std) compared to other global algorithms. China-specific algorithms are less sensitive to TBDs compared to other semi-empirical algorithms in China, with the mean and std of snow depth difference less than 0.8 cm and 1.9 cm, respectively. Specifically, Foster algorithm shows higher sensitivity to TBDs in forest regions. This research provides essential support for constructing precise, long-term snow depth datasets.

title: Evaluation of the Surface Albedo Estimation from FY-3D MERSI-II Over High Latitudes
authors: Andi Meng, Tao He, Xin Yang, Yueming Zheng
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Surface albedo is a fundamental parameter for understanding Earth's climate and calculating energy balance. The Fengyun-3D (FY-3D) satellite, China’s second-generation polar-orbiting meteorological satellite, is equipped with the Medium Resolution Spectral Imager-II (MERSI-II), which conducts global surface observations. However, limited studies have focused on surface albedo retrieval with MERSI-II observations, particularly over high latitudes, where albedo products often exhibit considerable uncertainty. In this paper, we propose a direct estimation method for surface albedo tailored to high-latitude regions and evaluate its accuracy based on MERSI-II observations. The validation of ground measurements indicates that our algorithm achieves high accuracy, with an overall root mean square error (RMSE) of approximately 0.040 and an absolute mean bias of 0.022. Furthermore, our study reveals that the reliability of retrieval results is significantly influenced by the quality of MERSI-II cloud mask products, which demonstrate an overestimation of cloud cover compared with ground-based clear-sky observations.

title: Research on Personal Information Anonymization Verification Algorithm
authors: Xincheng Jiang, Lei He, Yuxia Li, Jinglin Zhang, Zhenye Niu, Xinjun Fu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Recent advancements in intelligent transportation systems, autonomous driving, and unmanned vehicle technologies have elevated the role of onboard cameras as critical tools for traffic data acquisition. However, the associated risks of personal privacy exposure deserve greater attention. Anonymization validation for small-scale license plates and facial targets in complex scenarios is particularly challenging. This research proposes a personal information anonymization validation algorithm to address such issue. First, the YOLOv8s model is employed to detect anonymized images' color block targets and extract their coordinate information. Subsequently, an enhanced yolov8s-ATS model is proposed specifically for detecting small-scale faces and license plates, and obtaining their coordinate information. Finally, the algorithm determines the success of anonymization by analyzing the occlusion relationships among facial, license plate, and color block targets. Experimental results demonstrate that the YOLOv8s-ATS model achieves a 2.4% improvement in detection accuracy for faces and license plates and a 1% increase in anonymization detection rate.

title: A New Spatiotemporal Fusion Method for Remote Sensing Images Based On Texture Detail Compensation
authors: Zhaoxu Ma, Wenxing Bao, Wei Feng, Xiaowu Zhang, Xuan Ma, Kewen Qu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Remote sensing images in environmental monitoring demand high spatial and temporal resolution, which are challenging to achieve with a single sensor. To address this challenge, spatiotemporal fusion provides an effective solution. This paper presents a novel method based on the Vision Trans-former (ViT). A multi-scale ViT extracts fine-grained spatial and temporal features, which are then fused using an adaptive feature fusion module and enhanced with texture compensation to predict high-quality images. Compared to existing methods, the proposed approach better utilizes spatial prior information of reference images, reduces fusion errors, and enhances usability. Evaluations on two public datasets demonstrate that it achieves state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance.

title: Improved Optimal Fault-Tolerant Control Considering Thermal Balance for Six-Phase PMSM in Aviation Electric Propulsion Application
authors: Jiakang Zhao, Hong Guo, Jinquan Xu
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: An improved optimal fault-tolerant control (IOFTC) strategy, which considers thermal balance, is proposed for the six-phase fault-tolerant permanent magnet synchronous motor (FTPMSM) in the aviation electric propulsion area. This strategy addresses localized overheating in motor winding due to imbalanced phase currents during fault-tolerant operation. First, the electromagnetic torque model and the thermal model of FTPMSM are proposed, enabling precise calculation of the motor's output torque and temperature. Then, the IOFTC is proposed to reduce the maximum winding temperature during fault-tolerant operation. Additionally, a simplified solution method is proposed for the six-phase FTPMSM to facilitate the application of the IOFTC in engineering. Finally, the effectiveness of the IOFTC is validated on a simulation platform, which can ensure stable output torque and significantly reduce the maximum winding temperature during fault-tolerant operation, thereby enhancing the motor's electromagnetic torque output under fault conditions.

title: Current Fluctuation Suppression in Hysteresis Controller-Based Fault-Tolerant Control for Dual Three-Phase YASA Machine
authors: Lingyun Shao, Zhihong Liu, Zhuoran Zhang, Zhimian Wang, Wei Hua, Zhongze Wu
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The dual three-phase yokeless and segmented armature (YASA) axial flux permanent magnet (AFPM) machine has become one of the research hotspots in recent years, not only for its high power density but also for the faulttolerant capability brought by its multi-phase winding structure. However, the characteristic of small winding inductance leads to a rapid current change rate, making it difficult to apply the current hysteresis control. For the hysteresis controller-based open-circuit fault-tolerant control, this paper applies a series inductor between the stator windings of the YASA machine and the inverter to suppress the current fluctuations. Additionally, the traditional hysteresis controller is improved by introducing self-adaptive duty cycle, thereby increasing the switching frequency without adding computational burden to the controller. By combining these two methods, the current fluctuation and peak-to-peak torque can be reduced by 95.2% and 91.65%, respectively.

title: Real-time Processing Solution for Single-Photon Sensitive Geiger-mode APD Based Airborne Lidar Systems
authors: D. Rivera, A. Vasile, J. Kloss, L. Skelly, B. Edwards, H. Chen, J. Kuczynski, S. Potu, R. Chapurin, R. Hatch, M. J. Khan
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: MIT Lincoln Laboratory has successfully deployed numerous airborne 3D Lidar systems in operational environments, in support of both DoD applications as well as FEMA homeland disaster relief support. Those systems are based on single-photon sensitive avalanche photo-diodes arrays operating in Geiger mode. Though there are many advantages to using single-photon sensitive detector technology, airborne Geiger-mode sensors produce enormous amounts of data that often include considerable amount of noise from both temporal and spatial clutter. These sensor data characteristics have historically imposed high computational processing requirements and consequently made airborne real-time low size, weight and power processing solutions somewhat challenging. This paper presents the design and implementation of a novel on-board GPU-based processing solution. This advancement has achieved an 83% reduction in the size, weight, and power requirements of the airborne data processing system, while also enabling real-time visualization of 3D imagery during flight.

title: Ecosystem Extent Mapping in the Great Western Woodlands, Australia, Using Optical and SAR Satellite Imagery
authors: Adriana Parra, Zheng-Shu Zhou, Matthew C. Garthwaite, Shaun Levick
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In this paper, we present preliminary results on the implementation of a classification workflow for ecosystem extent mapping in the Great Western Woodlands region of Australia. Our analysis aims to evaluate the benefits of fusing optical and SAR data to improve the separation between similar ecosystem types, e.g. obligate-seeder and mallee woodlands, and to assess possible improvement in classification accuracy through the implementation of different machine learning approaches. We conduct our analysis by incorporating multi-source Analysis Ready Data on a cloud computing platform. This study is part of ongoing work initiated by the Committee on Earth Observation Satellites to support reporting and monitoring efforts of countries adopting the Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework.

title: Vegetation Fire Characterization and Fire Trends in India Using Remote Sensing Data
authors: Sumit Kumar, Sanjay Kumar Ghosh, Brijendra Pateriya
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Fire is an Essential Climatic Variable (ECV) that helps understand the Earth’s ecosystem. Human-induced fire events, such as crop residue burning, have exacerbated air pollution, while forest fires have caused biodiversity loss. Considering the rising concerns around fire-induced environmental damage, detailed mapping and analysis of fire regimes have become necessary. The study analysed the mapping of fire regimes and spatio-temporal fire patterns. The k-means algorithm has been used to cluster the fire regimes based on various fire regime variables. Six distinct fire regimes have been identified, and statistical analyses have been conducted to observe fire trends over time. The study revealed more than 88% of the land has been affected by vegetation fires. Cropland burning has accounted for most fire events, particularly in the northern Indo-Gangetic plains, where agricultural residue burning has become prevalent. The results show more than 48% of the area is affected by cropland burning.

title: Automatic Identification of Basal Units in Ice Sheets Based on Signal Feature and Weigth Control
authors: Shinan Lang, Changli Liu, Xiangbin Cui, Lin Li, Bo Sun
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In recent decades, radio-echo sounding (RES) has been extensively applied to study the flow and form of polar ice sheets. In certain regions within the ice sheet, the RES reveals a structure referred to as a 'basal unit', which differs from the overlying ice in terms of its characteristics, structure, and origin, and plays a significant role in the ice's rheology and flow dynamics. However, methods for detecting basal units in RES data are semi-quantitative and can lead to inconsistent identification. To address this issue, we propose an automatic ‘basal unit identification method’ based on signal feature and weight control. The method improves upon previous works in three aspects. 1) It simultaneously uses the signal and image features of RES and reduces inaccuracies associated with image analysis. 2) This method assigns weight to signal features that are affected by particle concentrations consistent with backscattering in basal units, reduces the interference of concentration on signal characteristics, and improves the ability to identify basal unit. 3) It provides weights related to signal feature recognition and calculates a composite recognition result that automatically identifies basal units. To validate the method’s effectiveness, we applied it to airborne RES data collected in recent years from the Gamburtsev Subglacial Mountains (GSM) and Princess Elizabeth Land (PEL) regions in East Antarctica. A comparative analysis of the new method and previous methods indicates more accurate basal unit identification due to stronger resistance to interference from particle concentrations consistent with backscattering.

title: Efficient Semantic Segmentation of Multispectral Land Cover Images Using Mask2Former
authors: Pablo Canosa, Álvaro Ordóñez, Dora B. Heras, Francisco Argüello
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Semantic segmentation for EO is a process that involves assigning a specific label or category to each pixel in an image, enabling precise analysis for land cover applications such as environmental conservation, urban planning or disaster management. Deep learning-based segmentation models have proliferated in recent years, but they often are not well adapted to the unique properties of multi and hyperspectral images, frequently used in remote sensing. Mask2Former is a universal segmentation model based on the concept of masked attention and employs a pretrained classification model as backbone to create intermediate representations. This article presents a preliminary adaptation of Mask2Former for the segmentation of multispectral remote sensing images. This adaptation includes modifying the backbone to accept multispectral inputs and adapting the data processing pipelines to leverage all available spectral bands effectively. The computational cost of the method has also been analyzed as an initial assessment of potential scalability and efficiency for large-scale applications. Experimental results using the FiveBillionPixels dataset reveal a notable improvement in segmentation accuracy when incorporating multispectral bands, outperforming RGB-only performance without a relevant increase in computational cost.

title: A Study of Ice Dielectric Constant versus Temperature and Frequency
authors: Rahul Kar, Mustafa Aksoy, Lennox Apudo
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This study introduces a new model for the real part of the relative permittivity, i.e., dielectric constant, of pure ice, addressing the limitations of existing models by extending the measurement range to lower temperatures and a broader microwave frequency spectrum. Using state-of-the-art facilities involving a temperature chamber and a microwave analyzer, permittivity measurements were conducted at temperatures from -70°C to 0°C and across frequencies from 0.1 GHz to 50 GHz. The results led to the development of a temperature and frequency-dependent model for the real part of the ice dielectric constant. This model differs from the current expressions for the real part of the pure ice relative permittivity, such as Matzler and Tiuri models, by introducing a weak frequency dependence. The updated model is anticipated to enhance the accuracy of microwave remote sensing applications for Cryosphere studies, particularly in scenarios involving cold ice and broad frequency bands. Future work will aim at measuring the imaginary part of the dielectric constant as well and validating the new permittivity model through simulations and real-world remote sensing data comparisons.

title: Drought Causal Analysis based on Remote Sensing Data and Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: Ming Wang, Lei He, Han Luo, Yuxia Li, Yunhao He, Yuheng Lei
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Climate warming has caused a lot of natural disasters, such as high temperature and drought. Focused on formation mechanism on drought, the theory and method of drought prediction and changes in disaster risk need to be paid more attention. In the research, three drought indices were utilized to construct a Synthetical Drought Characteristic Index (SDCI), aiming to accurately characterize drought events. Furthermore, a deep learning model, integrating the Convolutional Block Attention Module (CBAM), VGG network, and Convolutional Long Short - Term Memory (ConvLSTM), was developed to predict the SDCI. Subsequently, the SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) interpretative model was established to screen out features of greater significance to the deep learning model. The research comprehensively analyzed the screened factors in terms of temporal evolution, spatial distribution patterns, and factor interdependencies. The results demonstrate that the CBAM-VGG-ConvLSTM model is highly effective in predicting drought events and SHAP model can identify features with a greater impact on drought. By correlating historical drought events with the interpretative model to analyze the contribution of each feature, more effective remote sensing meteorological indices for drought prediction can be screened out.

title: Context Synergy and Multitask Interaction Network for Semantic Change Detection in High-Resolution Remote Sensing Images
authors: Siyu Yang, Hanchao Zhang, Xiaogang Ning, Ruiqian Zhang, Minghui Hao, Hao Wang, Qi Li
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: High-resolution remote sensing images (RSIs) are usually characterized by complex backgrounds and significant intra-class and inter-class scale variance, making long-range contextual information (LRCI) essential for semantic change detection (SCD). However, image cropping operations tend to truncate the LRCI inherent in RSIs, that would compromise the integrity of geometric features and disrupts the dependency of semantic correlations. To address these limitations, we propose a context synergy and multitask interaction network (CSMINet). Specifically, an extra context synergy branch is introduced to aggregate LRCI from broader image regions, compensating for the loss of contextual correlations in cropped images. CSMINet comprises three pivotal modules: the context synergy guidance module (CSGM), the local-dominant context-synergy fusion module (LCFM), and the decoder feature-aligned interaction module (DFIM). The CSGM is utilized to filter valuable LRCI that enhances contextual associations. The LCFM achieves fine-grained feature fusion, which is dominated by local features and synergized with long-range contextual information. The DFIM facilitates efficient information interaction across subtasks, bridging the gap between semantic representations and change targets. Extensive testing on two benchmark datasets validates the effectiveness of our proposed method, outperforming six comparative methods across various evaluation metrics and achieving Fscd of 62.13% and 67.83%, respectively.

title: A Tri-Mode Series Resonant Converter for Wide Input Voltage Applications
authors: Grigorios Sergentanis, Yales Rômulo De Novaes, Danielly Lima Bezerra, Liliana De Lillo, Lee Empringham, Mark C. Johnson
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: In recent years, the demand for high-efficiency voltage regulation over a wide input voltage range is appearing in many applications, such as fuel cells, solar panels, and battery-powered systems. In this context, although resonant converters can achieve high efficiency level, the regulation over a wide input voltage range remains a challenge. Additionally, the newer Gallium Nitride (GaN) devices offer new opportunities for power conversion, owed mainly to their exceptional switching performance. Therefore, this paper presents an isolated topology-morphing Series Resonant Converter (SRC) applied to the solar panel application, with a rated power of 300 W, which operates in three distinct modes to offer high efficiencies above <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 2 \%}$</tex> with a large input voltage variation (8-35 Volts) and an impressive peak efficiency of over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 8. 4 \%}$</tex>. Design guidelines and experimental results are showcased in this paper to demonstrate the feasibility of this proposal.

title: Predicting Arctic Sea Ice with Global Climate Models : Adopt the Concept of Pseudo-Global Warming
authors: Yukihiro. Ogura, Ryota. Nakamura
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The consequence of anthropogenic global warming is more pronounced in the Arctic area, as rapid melting of sea-ice in the Arctic Ocean. It also leads to the availability of Northern Sea Route (NSR), making sea-ice future prediction a more important problem. In this study, the concept of pseudo-global warming (PGW) usually used in the Regional Climate Model (RCM) was applied to the Global Climate Model CESM2 to perform numerical calculation of Arctic sea ice (G-PGW). The accuracy of the G-PGW was then verified in order to explore the applicability of this configuration to future projections. As a result, G-PGW reproduced sea ice conditions well except for the summer season, indicating the possibility of applying the configuration used in this study to future forecasts.

title: Research on Temporal and Spatial Differences in the Risk of Rainstorm and Flood in the Middle and Lower Reaches of the Yangtze River
authors: Yunhao He, Lei He, Yuxia Li, Guangsong Yan, Ming Wang, Yuheng Lei
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Rainstorm and flood occur frequently in the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze River. Based on GIS technology and natural disaster risk assessment theory, the research selected seven provinces or municipalities in the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze River as research areas, focusing on the hazard of disaster factors, environmental sensitivity of disaster pregnancy, and vulnerability of disaster bearing bodies. A rainstorm and flood disaster risk assessment system including 11 evaluation indicators was constructed by using multi-time series meteorological data, remote sensing data and socio-economic data from 2010 to 2020. The results show that from 2010 to 2020, the high risk of rainstorm and flood disaster in the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze River is distributed in the northeast and central areas in a radiation-type distribution, and the highest risk is in Anhui, Jiangxi and Hubei provinces.

title: Exploring Text Similarity Patterns in Open-Ended Concept Maps Using FastText Model
authors: Didik Dwi Prasetya, Ricky Tirta Hardiyanta, Azlan Mohd Zain, Tsukasa Hirashima
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: Advancements in AI and machine learning have introduced innovations in education, including the use of concept maps. Concept maps help identify gaps in understanding between learners and educators by analyzing text similarity. However, traditional methods for measuring text similarity are often inefficient. This study employs FastText, an NLP-based machine learning model, to analyze text similarity patterns in a corpus of concept maps from a relational database course. The FastText model was trained on the collected corpus to generate deep vector representations of words, enabling more accurate similarity measurements. Results demonstrate that FastText outperforms traditional methods, with potential applications in personalized learning recommendation systems, cross-course concept mapping, and analysis of conceptual understanding development. The best performance was achieved at a threshold of 0.9822 with $93 \%$ accuracy and balanced evaluation metrics, demonstrating the effectiveness of FastText in identifying proposition similarity in open-ended concept maps. This research highlights the importance of integrating AI to enhance the effectiveness of educational tools like concept maps.

title: Automating Geospatial Intelligence for Crisis Response: The Rise Web Application
authors: Paolo Campanella, Lucas Falk, Laura Giustarini, Valentina Leone, Marco Menapace, Nikhil Mohan, Cristiano Nattero, Betty Spurgeon, Alberto Tasso, Jihed Ben Zarb, Anis Amziane, Marco Chini, Aolin Jia, Yu Li, Kanishka Mallick, Patrick Matgen, Joao Vinholi, Daniel Ledesma, Ana Carolina Oliveira Helena, Michelle Joseph, Bethany Plant
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The Remote Imaging Support for Emergencies (RISE) web application is designed to democratize access to geospatial intelligence for emergency management. Developed by WASDI in collaboration with the Luxembourg Institute of Science and Technology (LIST) and the Shelter Research Unit (SRU) of the Luxembourg Red Cross (AICRL), and funded by the World Food Programme, RISE aims to address the significant barriers in the adoption of satellite-based Earth Observation (EO) data, such as processing complexity, data latency, limited expertise, and accessibility. By integrating state-of-the-art algorithms for processing EO data with a user-friendly web interface, RISE delivers actionable insights in near-real time. The application focuses on flood mapping, drought monitoring, and urban area analysis, providing critical geospatial intelligence to support informed decision-making during humanitarian crises. RISE has a global coverage, but a validation exercise is about to be conducted in collaboration with the Luxembourg Red Cross, aiming to assess the performance improvements and practical usability of RISE in real-world conditions. The expected outcomes include reduced costs, shortened response times, improved safety, enhanced accuracy, and strengthened preparedness for future crises.

title: Minimising Rare-Earth Magnet Use in Traction Electric Machines
authors: Oliver Lee, Mohammadali Abbasian
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This study investigates alternative magnetic materials and machine topologies to reduce reliance on rareearth NdFeB magnets in electric machines, by addressing both economic and environmental challenges. Simulations compared a reference permanent magnet synchronous machine (PMSM) with two alternative configurations: the permanent magnet-assisted synchronous reluctance machine (PMaSynRM), which reduces magnet use, and the wound-field synchronous machine (WFSM), which eliminates magnets entirely. Additionally, the performance of ferrite and recycled NdFeB magnets was assessed. Results show that recycled NdFeB magnets offer a costeffective alternative, requiring only a slight machine volume increase (3.5% for PMSM, 2.9 % for PMaSynRM) when substituted for primary (non-recycled) NdFeB magnets to output the same torque. In contrast, replacing the Primary NdFeB magnets with ferrites required substantial volume increases (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 2 \%}$</tex> for PMSM, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 1 \%}$</tex> for PMaSynRM), resulting in higher costs and reduced torque density. The WFSM, despite having the highest losses, demonstrated the best value-for-money performance at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Sigma 1.47 \text{kW} /$</tex> £.

title: Modeling of the Gate Leakage Current for Schottky-Type p-GaN Gate HEMTs Over Their Complete Operating Temperature Range
authors: Tim Egener, Carla Tillmann, Martin Pfost
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper investigates the gate leakage current of Schottky-type p-GaN gate HEMTs over their operating temperature range (−55° C to 150° C) and over a wide gate bias range (−6 V to 6 V) for three manufacturers. We observe that different gate designs of the manufacturers and low temperatures result in different dominant mechanisms contributing to the leakage current. Existing physics-based p-GaN gate HEMT models have been verified for these mechanisms by comparison to measurements. Based on physics-based models, a simplified model is presented to describe the dominant mechanisms with fewer parameters over the wide temperature range. The parameter extraction does not require any detailed information about the devices, which is often not available. This provides a basis for using the gate leakage current as a temperature-sensitive electrical parameter (TSEP). Even fabrication spread of GaN HEMTs can be taken into acount in the proposed simplified model by adjusting only two parameters.

title: The Integration of Sustainable Design and Responsible Project Management in Designing Complex Product Service Systems: A Case Study of Smart HVAC Control System Design
authors: Yiting Zhao, Lihong Zhang, Eunice Maytorena-Sanchez
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society Conference - Global (TEMSCON Global)
abstract: The increasing demand for energy-efficient and intelligent climate control solutions has driven innovations in Smart HVAC (Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning) control systems. The design of such systems that involve complex decision-making processes face challenges in balancing technological advancements, sustainability requirements, and multi-stakeholder needs. This study investigates how Sustainable Design (SD) and Responsible Project Management (RPM), as strategic approaches, are integrated into the design of Smart HVAC control systems. The data analysis employs a Grounded Theory coding strategy to systematically explore six key dimensions shaping this integration: design triggers, interaction facilitation, integrative design strategies, process management, multidisciplinary knowledge exchange, and project performance evaluation. Through a case study of a Smart HVAC control system project in practice, this study develops a structured understanding of how SD and RPM shape the design and development of a Complex Product-Service System (CoPSS). The findings also offer practical insights for R&D engineers, project managers, and policymakers seeking to optimize the design of Smart HVAC systems.

title: Capacitor Current Minimization Algorithm for Asymmetric Interleaved DC/DC Converters
authors: Ogün Altun, Göktuğ Tonay, Öztürk Şahin Alemdar, Ozan Keysan
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper introduces an analytical algorithm for minimizing the output capacitor RMS current in asymmetric multi-input interleaved converters. By jointly considering the first and second harmonics of the capacitor current, the method determines optimal phase shifts between converter modules without requiring iterative computation. Experimental validation on two- and three-module three-level boost converters confirms that the proposed technique accurately predicts the phase angles that achieve minimal capacitor current. Reducing the capacitor RMS current not only lowers losses but also enhances reliability and extends component lifetime.

title: Improving Venus Digital Elevation Map Absolute Accuracy Using 3D Localization of Ground Control Features
authors: Tobias Köhne, Christoph Gisinger, Marie Lachaise, Thomas Fritz
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The Venus Emissivity, Radio Science, InSAR, Topography, and Spectroscopy (VERITAS) mission is designed to produce the first Digital Elevation Map (DEM) of another planet using bi-static Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR). To achieve its scientific goals, the DEM is required to reach 300 m posting and 10 m vertical accuracy. While these metrics are routinely surpassed in Earth observation projects, spacecraft orbit uncertainties and atmospheric influences make the Venus case more challenging. As an alternative to reference stations not available on the surface of Venus, naturally-occurring radar-bright features have been proposed to provide additional constraints for the absolute referencing of DEM and orbit calibration. In this study, we present simulation results of localizing such Ground Control Features (GCFs) in 3D under noisy conditions similar to the ones expected from VERITAS. We also consider the influence of spatiotemporally-variable atmospheric delays affecting the radar measurements in X-band (the frequency applied by the VERITAS SAR instrument). Finally, we discuss the potential of 3D GCF localization to provide the necessary constraints to achieve the DEM vertical accuracy requirements as determined by the mission.

title: Artifact Cancellation in Neurostimulators: A Review
authors: Vighnesh Rudra Das, Aydin I. Karsilayan, Jose Silva-Martinez, David Genzer, Larry J. Stotts
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: Implantable Medical Devices (IMD) have been around for few decades and they form a big piece of the new group of therapeutic agents known as the Electroceuticals. In the spectrum of healing, IMDs are positioned between drugs and surgery and have increasingly become acceptable as well as available, thereby providing patients with life-saving therapies like cardiac pacing to well-being monitoring like glucose tracking. One of the groundbreaking applications of IMDs has been neurostimulation based Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS) and Spinal Cord Stimulation (SCS), where not only ailments like Epilepsy and Parkinson's Disease have been successfully addressed but effective pain management has been achieved. The advancement in treatment based on neurostimulation needs a closed loop system where the patient needs are addressed quickly. The impediment in that pursuit has been the existence of artifacts in the neural sensing path. This review presents an overview of challenges presented by artifacts and the state-of-the-art in circuit-based artifact cancellation techniques applied to achieve concurrent neural sensing and stimulation.

title: Adaptive Federated Learning for Ship Detection Across Diverse Satellite Imagery Sources
authors: Tran-Vu La, Minh-Tan Pham, Yu Li, Patrick Matgen, Marco Chini
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: We investigate the application of Federated Learning (FL) for ship detection across diverse satellite datasets, offering a privacy-preserving solution that eliminates the need for data sharing or centralized collection. This approach is particularly advantageous for handling commercial satellite imagery or sensitive ship annotations. Four FL models—FedAvg, FedProx, FedOpt, and FedMedian—are evaluated and compared to a local training baseline, where the YOLOv8 ship detection model is independently trained on each dataset without sharing learned parameters. The results reveal that FL models substantially improve detection accuracy over training on smaller local datasets and achieve performance levels close to global training that uses all datasets during the training. Furthermore, the study underscores the importance of selecting appropriate FL configurations, such as the number of communication rounds and local training epochs, to optimize detection precision while maintaining computational efficiency.

title: Online Condition Monitoring for Resonant Tank Capacitors in Llc Converters Using Voltage Gain
authors: Sen Tan, Wenfa Kang, Jingxuan Wu, Juan C. Vasquez, Josep M. Guerrero, Baoze Wei
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: LLC converters are extensively utilized in highpower, high-density applications due to their zero-voltage switching capabilities and galvanic isolation, with the resonant tank being considered a critical component for achieving efficient power conversion. However, the resonant tank capacitor is particularly susceptible to aging and eventual failure, as it is subjected to high-frequency charging and discharging cycles that accelerate wear and degradation. To address this issue, a new capacitance estimation method has been presented, specifically designed for the online condition monitoring of the resonant tank capacitor. An in-depth analysis is provided on the voltage gain characteristics of resonant tank to accurately estimate capacitance values, thereby enabling proactive detection of capacitor degradation. Notably, the need for additional external circuitry is eliminated by this approach, simplifying implementation and reducing costs. Simulation studies have been conducted to verify the performance and effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Versatile Converter Impedance Modeling with Matrix Signal Flow Graphs to Include Frequency Coupling
authors: Dominik Schulz, Rüdiger Schwendemann, Thomas Eckstein, Andreas Liske, Marc Hiller
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The behavior of grid-connected converters is defined by their control systems over a wide frequency band. Understanding the impact of the control design on the converter output impedance is thus essential. In the lower frequency range, asymmetric control elements such as the phase-locked loop (PLL) or DC link control introduce frequency coupling, resulting in a multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) system structure. Deriving the MIMO converter impedance model can be a complex and demanding task. This paper presents a structured approach to model the converter output impedance based on its signal-flow graph that accounts for asymmetric control loops and frequency coupling. The technique is applied to analyze the impedance of a real converter system, focusing on the lowfrequency range. The obtained analytical impedance curves are validated by experimental impedance measurements that capture frequency coupling. Finally, the validated converter impedance matrix is used to assess and mitigate a low-frequency instability observed in a power hardware-in-the-loop (PHIL) setup.

title: Research on Adaptive Tube Model Predictive Control for Wave Energy Converter
authors: Zihao Mou, Lei Huang, Baoyi Pan, Haitao Liu, Jianlong Yang, Haodong Wang
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: In response to the complexity of the impact of wind turbine operation on the energy capture of the float in a Wind-Wave Energy Platform, this paper proposes an Adaptive Tube Model Predictive Control (ATMPC) method. By combining a Kalman filter (KF) for state prediction and introducing a feedback adjustment mechanism, which enables real-time adjustment of the tube width under uncertain external disturbances, thereby achieving Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) of the wave energy device under small disturbances. Simulation results demonstrate that, compared to Robost Tube Model Predictive Control (RTMPC) and classic MPC, ATMPC exhibits significant robustness and wave energy capture efficiency when dealing with wind turbine disturbances. It effectively addresses the complex dynamic environment of wind-wave energy platforms, further improving system stability and energy efficiency.

title: Energy-Efficient Attention-Based Spiking YOLO Network for SAR Ship Detection
authors: Zihan Wang, Yanxing Liu, Jinxin Li, Bingchen Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) ship detection plays a crucial role in diverse maritime applications. Although artificial neural networks (ANNs)-based methods have achieved remarkable detection performance, their substantial energy consumption limits practical deployment on edge devices. In contrast, spiking neural networks (SNNs), inspired by biological neural systems, exhibit significant advantages in energy efficiency by encoding information through sparse spatiotemporal spike patterns. Additionally, attention mechanisms can effectively mitigate the inherent limitations of local receptive fields, thereby enhancing target feature representation and suppressing background clutter , which improves detection accuracy. Motivated by these observations, this paper proposes an energy-efficient attention-based spiking YOLO network (EAS-YOLO) for SAR ship detection. Specifically, we adopt a spike-driven paradigm leveraging sparse additive computations to significantly reduce energy consumption. Moreover, we incorporate a spiking attention mechanism designed to capture content-dependent global interactions and effectively learn long-range contextual information, further enhancing detection performance. Experimental results on the HRSID dataset demonstrate the advantages of SNNs in terms of energy efficiency for SAR ship detection tasks when deployed on edge devices.

title: Voltage Stability Enhancement in IEEE 14-Bus System Using Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient for EV Charging Management
authors: Arash Mousaei, Yahya Naderi, Syed Muhammad Arif, I. Safak Bayram
publish: 2025 10th IEEE Workshop on the Electronic Grid (eGRID)
abstract: The increasing integration of Electric Vehicles (EVs) into power systems presents significant challenges for voltage stability due to their unpredictable charging behaviors and potential grid disturbances. This paper proposes a novel Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) framework to coordinate EV charging and voltage control in distribution networks using the Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (DDPG) algorithm. A two-layer control architecture is introduced, where the upper layer handles charging scheduling while the lower layer focuses on voltage regulation. The framework is modeled as a Markov Decision Process (MDP) and trained using an Actor-Critic structure capable of managing mixed discrete-continuous action spaces. Simulation results on a modified IEEE 14-bus system validate the effectiveness of the proposed method. Compared with conventional methods like Deep Q-network (DQN), Proximal policy optimization (PPO), and Soft Actor Critic (SAC), our approach achieves faster convergence and superior voltage stability across varying levels of EV penetration, ensuring all nodal voltages remain within safe operational limits. The results demonstrate the potential of DDPG-based strategies in enhancing grid reliability and supporting smart EV integration.

title: A Nonlocal Means Based Filtering Algorithm for Das Phase Signal
authors: Hengyi Jia, Hanwen Yu, Taoli Yang, Chenghao Lu, Xinghao Wang, Lingshen Zeng
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Distributed acoustic sensing (DAS) technology has become a research hotspot in the international industry due to its applications in seismic exploration, perimeter intrusion warning and other fields, as well as its advantages such as high spatial sampling rate and low construction cost. However, due to the generally low quality of DAS signals and the complexity of noise types, the application of the technology is limited. In response to the current problem, this study extends a non-local mean filtering method based on PDNet (a phase denoising technology in the InSAR field). This method makes full use of the characteristics that the noise in the simulated DAS signal obeys a zero-mean distribution in the phase domain and satisfies the conditions of a stationary ergodic process. By identifying the similarities between signal samples at different times at the equivalent optical fiber position, the original simulated DAS signal is processed. Experimental results show that this method can significantly reduce the phase noise of the DAS signal and retain key signal characteristics.

title: Feasible Configuration Analysis for Bistatic SAR Based on Decision Space Partitioning Strategy
authors: Juntao Shen, Zhichao Sun, Zhifeng Luo, Junjie Wu, Jianyu Yang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Bistatic Synthetic Aperture Radar (BiSAR) is a SAR imaging system where the receiver and transmitter are located on different platforms. The imaging performance of BiSAR is influenced by its observation geometry. Therefore, the imaging performance can be improved by adjusting the bistatic configuration. In practical applications, specific imaging tasks have performance requirements, e.g., spatial resolution and SNR to be better than a desired value. Therefore, it is necessary to find the suitable bistatic configuration that meets the performance requirements in order to accomplish the task. Consequently, this paper models the problem as a nonlinear inequality system (NIS) and the goal is to determine the feasible regions of bistatic configuration that satisfy the NIS. To solve this problem, a multi-objective evolutionary algorithm based on decision space partitioning strategy (DSPS-MOEA) is proposed. It can obtain a set of solutions evenly distributed within the feasible region of the NIS, so as to describe the boundary of the feasible region. The appropriate configuration can thus be selected from the feasible region according to the actual environment and flight constraints for a real imaging mission.

title: Frequency-Enhanced Spatial-Spectral Network for Hyperspectral and Multispectral Image Fusion
authors: Pan Liu, Xiyou Fu, Nan Xiao, Ruyan He, Shuyu Zhang, Sen Jia
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Fusion of hyperspectral images (HSIs) and multispectral images (MSIs) is an effective approach to enhance the spatial resolution of HSIs. Existing deep learning-based methods have achieved excellent results, but they often overlook the important role of frequency information. To address this issue, we propose a frequency-enhanced spatial-spectral fusion network for HSIs and MSIs fusion, called FSSNet. First, we designed a frequency information extraction module (FIEM) to extract frequency features. Subsequently, the extracted frequency features are integrated into spatial-spectral features through the stripe feature enhancement module (SFEM). Finally, a deep residual reconstruction module (DRRM) is introduced to integrate all features and reconstruct the high-resolution hyperspectral image (HR-HSI). Qualitative and quantitative experiments on the Chikusei dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method compared with five state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods.

title: Deep Learning for Wheat Yield Prediction Using RGB-NIR Multispectral Data
authors: Justin P. Ma, Prabahar Ravichandran, Keshav D. Singh, Raju Soolanayakanahally, Kirby T. Nilsen, Oscar Molina, Jatinder Sangha, Elizabeth Brauer, Harpinder S. Randhawa
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Predicting crop yield from images in scenarios with limited and low-quality data is a significant challenge. This study demonstrates a straightforward effective approach by adapting the EfficientNetV2 convolutional neural network, originally designed for image classification, into a regression model for direct yield prediction. We have used this architecture to handle 4-channel RGB-NIR wheat canopy data collected using the University of Saskatchewan Field Phenotyping System (UFPS). We found a statistically significant (p = 0.0171) improvement in RMSE when using transfer learning with pre-trained weights from ImageNet-21k (RMSE: 443 kg/h, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.8902) compared to random initialization (RMSE: 508 kg/ha, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.8170). An ensemble approach further reduced the RMSE to 385 kg/ha and boosted the R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> to 0.9176. This method demonstrates how existing RGB models, with simple adaptations for handling additional spectral band inputs, can deliver accurate predictions, making advanced deep image regression techniques more accessible for broader application.

title: Optimizing Rainwater Harvesting Site Selection Using Machine Learning Models
authors: Sri Priyanka Kommula, Bharat Lohani, Dongryeol Ryu, Stephan Winter
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Rainwater harvesting (RWH) can assist in securing a valuable supplementary resource to mitigate water scarcity. The effectiveness of RWH systems depends significantly on the appropriate placement of RWH structures. However, identifying suitable sites effectively over large areas remains a challenge. Traditionally, the Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP) has been used as a decision support system for RWH site selection. However, there is a need to evaluate the effectiveness of machine learning (ML) techniques in this domain. This study examines if ML methods can enhance RWH site identification, particularly check dams in the Tiruvannamalai district of Tamil Nadu, India, using high-resolution geospatial data. The biophysical variables considered include elevation, geology, geomorphology, soil, land use and land cover, slope, and annual streamflow. Three ML models—Support Vector Machine (SVM), Random Forest (RF), and K-Nearest Neighbor (KNN)—were trained and tested using a dataset of 450 ground-verified RWH locations across two distinct cases: Case I using the original dataset, and Case II incorporating 232 additional unsuitable locations. Model performance was evaluated based on overall accuracy (OA) and Cohen’s kappa (κ) score. While all ML models produced comparable suitability maps, limited training data for unsuitable sites in Case I resulted in large false positives (F P ), especially for SVM and KNN. Case II showed substantial improvements in accuracy and spatial predictions, particularly in identifying suitable zones along stream networks. Compared to AHP, the ML models achieved higher overall accuracy and Cohen’s κ score. This study demonstrates the efficacy of ML algorithms in integrating geospatial and ground-truth data for RWH site selection, offering a scalable and data-driven approach. It also highlights the implications on the quality of training data that can significantly impact the performance of ML approaches applied to RWH siting, particularly when the number of training data points is limited.

title: On-Chip Row Pruning for One-Hot Encoded Snns in Memristive Dot Product Engines
authors: Sree Nirmillo Biswash Tushar, Graham Buchanan, Tanjina Sabrin, Hritom Das, Garrett S. Rose
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: The energy consumption of Memristive Dot Product Engine is a major concern for low-energy AI applications. This paper discusses an on-chip, data-independent row pruning scheme for one-hot encoded Spiking Neural Networks (SNN) at the custom circuit level, facilitating dynamic energy management. This scheme can prune a significant number of rows with a marginal performance drop for three machine learning applications. Moreover, the scheme can save up to two orders of magnitude of energy after running the system for 1000 cycles in pruned mode, compared to the energy cost of the row pruning system.

title: Development and Application of Batch Inversion Algorithm for Sentinel-2 LAI Based on GPR Hybrid Model on GEE Platform
authors: Xinyu Li, Yunping Chen, Juncheng Chen, Jinming Zhang, Yungao Deng, Wangmin Jiang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Leaf Area Index (LAI) is a crucial vegetation parameter that determines the efficiency of sunlight absorption and utilization by leaves. It is closely related to the biological and physical processes of vegetation. The acquisition methods for LAI include ground measurement and remote sensing inversion. Remote sensing inversion, as a significant means for large-scale monitoring, holds great significance for the evaluation of global LAI remote sensing products. In this study, we selected the Yucheng Farmland Ecological Station in Shandong Province and utilized Sentinel-2 satellite data to retrieve LAI. When implementing the inversion process with the PROSAIL model as the theoretical basis, the traditional algorithmic approach generally requires iterative estimations of multiple biophysical parameters. This relatively complex parameter retrieval mechanism may result in suboptimal computational performance and a relatively high demand for computing resources. Therefore, we constructed a Sentinel-2 LAI batch inversion algorithm centered on the Gaussian Process Regression (GPR) hybrid model on the Google Earth Engine (GEE) platform. This algorithm initially simulates Sentinel-2 L1C-level data using the PROSAIL model and processes it with the 6SV model. Subsequently, the GPR model is optimized and trained using active learning technology. Finally, batch inversion is achieved through steps such as image processing and data extraction. By comparing the ground-measured LAI data with the inversion results and evaluating them using the R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, MAE, RMSE, and EE, the results indicate that the Sentinel-2 LAI inverted from March to December 2020 shows good consistency and periodicity with the ground-measured values. The R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, value reached 0.805, the RMSE was 0.55, and the MAE was 0.46. Compared with the inversion results of the PROSAIL model, the difference values between the two LAI pixel maps are concentrated between -0.092 and 0.165. This suggests that the batch inversion algorithm can efficiently and accurately obtain LAI data and has high consistency with traditional methods, providing powerful support for vegetation research.

title: Modeling and Assessing the Impact of Future Climate Change on Migratory Bird Habitat Pattern Using AI and Machine Learning Algorithms
authors: Vishal Kumar, Sameer Saran, C Jeganathan
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Migratory birds face immense challenges while migrating long distances across countries in their pathways as well as in their destination site. Due to increasing human population, urbanization, anthropogenic activities and changing climate, the migration route of the birds are affected, thereby influencing the pattern of migraton. India is home to many migratory birds, various birds visit India throughout the year. India particularly has 3 major seasons namely summer, monsoon and winter. Therefore, one migratory bird for each season is considered for better analysis of changing climatic conditions. The birds are Blue-tailed Bee- eater (Merops philippinus – summer migrant), Jacobin cuckoo (Clamator jacobinus – monsoon migrant) and Rosy starling (Pastor roseus – winter migrant). This study projects probable habitat distribution in current and future climatic conditions under four Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs) i.e. SSP 126, 245, 370 and 585. To predict the habitat suitability, different AI/ML algorithm was run and based on the ROC plots and AUC values, random forest (RF) algorithm was selected to perform the further analysis. First the model is run to predict the current suitable habitat areas for all three birds. Then its run for all four future scenarios using ACCESS-ESM1-5 modeled CMIP future data for the years (2041-60, 2061-80, 2081-100). In this study its found that the suitable habitat of Clamator jacobinus seems to shift towards the southern part of India in future climatic conditions, under different SSP’s. Similarly for the winter migrant to India i.e Pastor roseus the suitable habitat area appears to be decreased in future indicating rise in temperature. But negligible change is observed in suitable area for the summer migrant Merops philippinus. By examining the spatial distribution of suitable habitats for key migratory species, the study seeks to provide insights into the potential risks and opportunities for conservation planning in the face of climate change.

title: Chirp Sequence Modulated Microwave Sensor for Precipitation Detection and Classification
authors: Michael Schneider, Merle Badura, Thomas Walter, Hubert Mantz
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In the context of increasingly variable weather conditions, attributable in part to climate change, there is a growing requirement for more accurate, reliable and flexible measurement techniques. This study explores the potential of determining the accumulated amount of precipitation using heuristic feature extraction. For this purpose, an 60 GHz FMCW radar sensor is used, which is orientated in zenith direction. The analysis yields a highly significant correlation of 98% between the acquired data ante those recorded at a reference weather station.

title: Analysis of Tropical Cyclone Tilt from Satellite Imagery Based on Deep Learning
authors: Shanshan Mu, Xiaofeng Li, Haoyu Wang, Chong Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Tropical cyclones (TCs) are natural disasters originating over tropical and subtropical oceans, and TC vertical tilt, defined as the displacement between the sea surface center and cloud top center, significantly influences their structure and intensity. This study determined TC tilt by manually locating the sea surface center from Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data and the cloud top center from infrared (IR) imagery, using 500 image pairs spanning 2016 to 2024 and covering 165 TCs across both hemispheres. A comprehensive analysis was conducted from two perspectives: statistical analysis and AI-based interpretability analysis. The statistical analysis examined the relationship between TC tilt and factors such as intensity, movement speed, and movement direction, while the AI interpretability analysis employed a deep learning model to investigate the influence of environmental variables, including vertical wind shear, provided by ERA5 data. Results demonstrated a strong correlation between TC tilt and intensity, and identified 11 environmental variables with high correlation to TC tilt, offering valuable insights into the mechanisms driving TC tilt and providing theoretical support for advancing meteorological predictions and understanding TC dynamics.

title: Semi-supervised Urban Village Recognition from Remote Sensing Images by Integrating Low- and High-Frequency Signals
authors: Yin Zhou, Hongyu Long, Yi Zhang, Rui Cao
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Urban villages, characterized by dense populations, poor infrastructure, and disorganized management, necessitate efficient and accurate identification to ensure effective resource allocation, urban planning, and policy implementation. In this paper, we propose FNet, a model designed to address the challenge of limited annotated data for semi-supervised urban village recognition. FNet leverages the Fourier transform to extract low- and high-frequency features and constrains the outputs of different features, enabling semi-supervised training, which can greatly reduce the dependence on labeled data. In addition, we established a dataset of urban villages in Guangzhou. Experimental results demonstrate that FNet is highly competitive in recognizing urban villages in both semi-supervised and fully-supervised settings. This study not only advances the efficient identification of urban villages, but also highlights the potential of frequency information in remote sensing image analysis.

title: Comparative Study on Fatigue Lifetime of SiC MOSFETs Under Power Cycling Tests
authors: Debao Jing, Xingyu Ji, Xinglai Ge, Huimin Wang, Dong Xie, Zhiliang Xu
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Fatigue lifetime analysis in power cycling test (PCT) is important to guarantee the reliability of the power device. However, silicon carbide metal-oxide-semiconductor field-effect transistors (SiC MOSFETs) are subject to coupling failure modes in the PCTs due to the instability of the gate structure. This digest focuses on the failure mechanism analysis of SiC MOSFETs with different gate structures in the PCTs: trench gate structure and planar gate structure. Temperature calibration of SiC MOSFETs with different gate structures is performed and the effects of gate structure on the PCTs are quantified. The PCTs are performed on SiC MOSFETs with various gate structures under identical conditions. The results demonstrate that there are notable differences in the lifetime of SiC MOSFETs with varying gate structures.

title: Modeling Battery Cells with Different Chemistries Based on EIS
authors: Zhansheng Ning, Prasanth Venugopal, Thiago Batista Soeiro, Gert Rietveld
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: There are several commonly-used battery chemistries, and a variety of equivalent circuit models (ECMs) have been proposed to describe their internal impedance characteristics. However, research on determining the most suitable ECM for each chemistry has not been extensively explored. In this paper, Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS) is employed to identify suitable ECMs for three different battery chemistries. The performance of these models is compared based on fitting accuracy and fitting time, ultimately allowing the selection of the best ECM for each battery chemistry. The experimental results show that the root mean square percentage error (RMSPE) for the selected ECM is less than 1 % for each battery chemistry across the SOC range from 0 % to 100 %, while the fitting time of the selected ECM is less than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0}$</tex> seconds.

title: Permanent Magnet Synchronous Machine Flux and Inductance Estimation Using Experimental Data and Gaussian Process Regression
authors: Chandula Wanasinghe, Xiaoze Pei, Ali Sinmaz, Emre Kural, Dietmar Peinsipp
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Accurate flux and inductance estimation is crucial for high-fidelity modelling and emulation of interior permanent magnet synchronous machines (IPMSMs). This paper presents a systematic workflow for extracting <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$d$</tex>-and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$q$</tex>-axis flux and inductance look-up tables (LUTs) from full-factorial experimental data using voltage equations derived from the IPMSM equivalent circuit model. The workflow begins with data acquisition from an IPMSM testbed, capturing current, voltage, speed, torque, and temperature across a wide operating range. Using the IPMSM voltage equations, the d- and q-axis flux linkages and inductances are computed while accounting for temperature-dependent resistance variations. Gaussian Process Regression (GPR) is then employed to interpolate and extrapolate flux values over an extended operating range, ensuring accurate LUT generation. The final flux and inductance LUTs are formatted for direct integration into electric machine emulators, enabling real-time validation and optimisation of electric drive control strategies. Experimental validation confirms the accuracy and reliability of the proposed approach, demonstrating its potential for hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) testing, virtual prototyping, and control system development in electrified powertrains.

title: Internet of Things (IoT) Enabled Filtration System for Accelerated Struvite Fertilizer Production
authors: Sarah Nada Jinan, Maya Fitria, Daffa Hirta Adharani, Ilham Maulana, Cut Nurul Faizah, Hendrik Leo, Hisbullah, Teuku Mukhriza, Rahmad Dawood
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: Struvite is an environmentally friendly phosphate fertilizer, but its production is constrained by a time-consuming and inefficient manual filtration process. This study proposes an automated filtration system based on the Internet of Things (IoT) to overcome this limitation. The system was constructed using an ESP32 microcontroller, a load cell sensor, a vacuum pump, and the AWS IoT Core platform to enable real-time monitoring and control. Performance testing showed the system could filter 2,000 grams of solution in 5 minutes, a vast improvement over the $\mathbf{2 4}$-hour manual process (representing a $99.56 \%$ reduction in filtration time). Furthermore, the phosphate content of the automatically filtered product (0.4573 $\mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{L}$) was found to be statistically comparable to the manual result ($0.5982 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{L}$). The proposed IoT-based system offers a significant increase in time efficiency and process monitoring without affecting quality, presenting a viable solution for future industrial-scale applications in smart agriculture.

title: Multimodal Registration via Reusable Encoders for Onboard Change Detection
authors: Monikka Roslianna Busto, Takeharu Eda, Hiroyuki Makino
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Image registration is a critical preprocessing step in multimodal change detection (CD) pipelines, where domain differences introduce significant complexity. Misaligned images further complicate accurate CD, yet much of the existing CD research emphasizes algorithmic development while often overlooking the prerequisite of image registration. This can be a limitation in practical remote sensing applications, where accurate alignment is necessary for downstream tasks. To address this challenge, we focus on onboard computing contexts, where computational and memory resources are constrained. We introduce a registration module that reuses encoder components of a CD model, avoiding the introduction of significant additional parameters. Instead of dense keypoint predictions, which are often computationally expensive, our approach identifies key patches to predict a transformation matrix, leveraging a sparse cross-attention to manage modality differences. We evaluated the trade-offs between performance and efficiency under affine distortions prevalent in remote sensing imagery and provided insights into the limits of registration accuracy and robustness in resource-constrained environments.

title: Wearable Wireless System for Microbubble Cavitation Detection and Localization
authors: Yihan Wang, Rudra Biswas, Sujay Hosur, Mehdi Kiani
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: Microbubble cavitation may contribute to blastinduced traumatic brain injuries. While traditional benchtop systems for detecting and localizing cavitation sources offer high precision, their large size and high cost make them impractical for use in field applications. This paper introduces a wearable system for continuous detection and 3D-localization of cavitation sources by measuring the time difference of arrival (TDOA) of ultrasound signals captured by four transducers. The system consists of four identical analog frontend channels, each with measured tunable gain of up to 39.3 dB within a bandwidth of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 17.9 \text{kHz}$</tex> to 1.1 MHz. It also includes a microcontroller and wireless module that can sample signals at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 8.3$</tex> Mega sample per second (MSps) with 8-bit resolution. The proposed system processes data onboard for realtime detection of cavitation onset and efficiently manages data by storing and selectively transmitting only relevant data through a robust local wireless network to a PC for detailed analysis and accurate identification of cavitation events and their source locations. In measurements, the system achieved a maximum TDOA detection error of 288 ns across four channels using 20 mV (peak-peak), 500 kHz ringing signals as input. Our initial 2D localization experiments using three piezoelectric transducers demonstrated an accuracy of 1.95 ± 0.66 mm for sources located within a 50 mm radius from the transducers' geometric center.

title: Inverse Shooting and Bouncing Rays for the Reconstruction of Perfect Electrical Conductors
authors: Yue Feng Tan, Xudong Chen
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Inverse problems for reconstructing electrically large structures are addressed in this paper by using asymptotic electromagnetic simulation methods. This paper proposes a novel method for performing inverse shooting and bouncing rays (ISBR) by formulating a form of differentiable shooting and bouncing rays (DSBR). The DSBR exploits the concept of scattered and incident fields and applies continuous-variable representations of perfect electrical conductor (PEC) scatterers. The DSBR method will be used to perform ISBR for the purpose of reconstructing canonical PEC shapes using gradient-based optimization methods. A key advantage of the proposed method is that no a priori information on the number of scatterers and their shapes is necessary. It is demonstrated that the reconstructed PEC shapes are in good agreement with the ground-truth PEC shapes.

title: A Stratified Intensity Correction to Alleviate Striping Effect in Multispectral ALS Data
authors: Qi Chen, Tiangang Yin, Wai Yeung Yan
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: LiDAR users often struggle with the heterogeneity in airborne laser scanning (ALS) data, particularly dealing with large-scale scanning that likely exhibits significant intensity inconsistencies due to varying scanning angles and ranges. This study introduces a stratified intensity correction approach to mitigate the overlap striping effect commonly observed in multispectral ALS point clouds. By integrating an octree-based region-growing algorithm with an iterative weighted least squares regression, our approach effectively segments the multispectral ALS point clouds into homogeneous regions, thereby enhancing the consistency of intensity values across overlap scans after applying intensity correction to each identified homogeneous region. We conduct a comparative analysis using a multispectral ALS dataset and evaluate the coefficient of variation (cv) in two distinct areas across three channels. Our method demonstrates a reduction of cv by 1.4–9%, indicating improved stability and reliability. These results suggest that our approach not only visually reduces striping effect but also enhances the data quality of multispectral ALS data for environmental monitoring and resource management.

title: A Comparison of Machine Learning Models Based on Feature Variations for Phishing URL Detection
authors: Seksit Prakongsin, Isoon Kanjanasurat
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 9th International Conference on Intelligent Systems, Metaheuristics & Swarm Intelligence
abstract: Phishing attacks are a growing cybersecurity threat, using deceptive websites to steal sensitive information such as login credentials and financial data. As phishing techniques become more sophisticated, effective detection methods are crucial. This study proposes a machine learning-based approach for phishing URL detection, evaluating four classification models: Logistic Regression, Random Forest, Naïve Bayes, and Support Vector Machines. A phishing URL dataset was utilized, extracting 130 features. Mutual Information was applied to select the 10 most significant features. Experimental results indicate that the Random Forest model achieved the highest accuracy of 95.36% when tested with the selected features.

title: Digital Twin for Managed Transportation — Transforming Logistics with AI-Driven Supply Chain Optimization
authors: Manoj Bhalerao
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society Conference - Global (TEMSCON Global)
abstract: Digital Twin technology transforms managed transportation and supply chain optimization by creating virtual twins of physical assets and processes. This paper examines how Digital Twins supplement fleet management, real-time decision-making, and supply chain visibility by leveraging the best technology available today (Internet of Things, AI, and cloud computing This study presents simulation-based case analyses from both the pharmaceutical industry and logistics systems to conceptually demonstrate the potential benefits of Digital Twins, including cost savings, efficiency, and sustainability. However, there are still challenges and barriers to the wide-scale adoption of Digital Twins, such as issues related to data integration and methods, dangerous cybersecurity risks, and expensive upfront costs. The message from this research is that the market needs to embrace Digital Twins through incremental implementation, building up the data infrastructure, and letting machine learning and AI do the work.
