Future research into AI decision automation, Blockchain integration, and scaled replication is the next stage of research to consider. Overall, organizations must incorporate these recommendations to achieve the full potential of Digital Twins for smarter, more resilient, and sustainable logistics operations.

title: Improvement of Spatial Resolution and Strain Measurement Range Based on Adaptive Matrix Block Weighting Method in Long-Distance OFDR System
authors: Qihao Zhang, Shuai Qu, Xibao Gao, Shuo Bai, Chen Guan, Jiasheng Ni
abstract: In this study, we present and experimentally verify a method based on the adaptive matrix block weighting (AMBW) algorithm to achieve large-strain measurement in long-distance, high-spatial-resolution optical frequency domain reflectometry (OFDR) systems. The system generates two-dimensional (2D) cross-correlation images representing strain information by calculating cross-correlations between the reference signals (RS) and measurement signals (MS) for each segment of the sensing fiber, thereby determining the strain distribution along the fiber. In practical applications, however, strain-induced stretching causes spatial misalignment between the measurement and reference signals. Consequently, the cross-correlation images become contaminated with bad points and outliers, leading to a significant reduction in measurement accuracy. To mitigate the above effects and enhance measurement accuracy, we employ the AMBW method to process the 2D cross-correlation images. Unlike conventional image denoising techniques such as Wiener filtering (WF), Gaussian filtering (GF), and median filtering (MF), the AMBW algorithm leverages both the redundancy and inherent correlation within the 2D cross-correlation data by adaptively adjusting the size of the matrix blocks used in similarity weighting based on the spatial distribution of local outliers. This adaptive capability allows it to effectively eliminate bad points and outlier. Experimental results show that the proposed method accurately measures strain gradients from 500μϵ to 5500μϵ with a spatial resolution of 2 mm, operating at a wavelength scanning rate of 10 nm/s over a 56 m sensing fiber. The proposed approach offers an effective solution for long-distance, high-spatial-resolution, large-strain measurement in OFDR systems, underscoring its strong potential and practical value.

title: MalQwen: Fine Tuned LLM for Static Android Malware Analysis Report
authors: Tegar Ganang Satrio Priambodo, Angela Oryza Prabowo, Annisa Dwi Puspitarini, Raihan Adam Handoyo Winarso, Nur Aisyah, Mohammad Yoga Pratama, Diana Purwitasari, Baskoro Adi Pratomo
abstract: The Android operating system continues to face escalating security challenges, primarily due to its open-source nature and the rapid proliferation of applications from untrusted sources. Traditional static analysis tools lack the flexibility to capture evolving malware behaviors, limiting their interpretability and scalability. Large Language Models (LLMs) are now applied in cybersecurity for malware detection, phishing classification, and cyber threat intelligence. However, their use has not been extended to producing detailed and interpretable Android malware analysis reports. This study integrates LLMs into Android malware analysis by creating a dataset for instruction tuning and fine-tuning the Qwen-7B model using the LoRA method. The model MalQwen is developed by fine-tuning Qwen 2.5-7B with 489 malware samples containing decompiled code and expert-labeled security reports. MalQwen outperforms models like Gemini and LLaMA, achieving a BERTscore of 0.84 for SMS malware and a Perplexity score of 3.30 for Scareware. These findings confirm MalQwen’s superior performance in generating precise malware reports, validating LLMs as a powerful new method for Android malware analysis.

title: Unifying Gradient Leakage Attacks Against Privacy-Protected Federated Learning in IoT Networks
authors: Hui Zhou, Zheng Qin, Peng Sun, Xin Deng, Yipeng Zou, Xiaoshuai Wu
abstract: Federated learning (FL) is a transformative paradigm for the Internet of Things (IoT), enabling decentralized model training across distributed IoT devices while reducing reliance on centralized data collection. Crucially, FL cuts communication overhead, an essential benefit in bandwidth-limited IoT environments. However, repeated gradient exchanges between edge clients (e.g., sensors, mobile devices) and the central server expose vulnerabilities to gradient leakage attacks (GLAs), allowing adversaries to reconstruct private training data from shared gradients. While various gradient protection strategies, such as differential privacy, sparsification, and clipping, have been introduced to mitigate this risk, most existing GLAs are designed for specific protection schemes and fail under heterogeneous deployments. In this work, we propose a unified GLA framework that targets diverse gradient protection techniques in FL systems. Our approach tackles two core challenges: (i) aligning protected gradients with their raw counterparts to enable robust feature extraction, and (ii) identifying critical features for efficient and accurate data reconstruction.We introduce a Taylor-based gradient approximation method for alignment and design a feature reconstructor that enhances both performance and computational efficiency. Extensive experiments across various FL scenarios demonstrate the framework’s superior reconstruction capability under different protection schemes, emphasizing the need for robust privacy-preserving mechanisms in IoT networks.

title: Wireless Sensing System Powered by RF Energy for Temperature Monitoring with 7.9mK Resolution
authors: Zihan Yu, Changrong Liu, Baoqing Nie, Dacheng Xu
abstract: This paper proposes a wireless temperature sensing system powered by RF energy for high accuracy temperature monitoring. To enable wireless temperature sensing, an RF energy harvester and frequency-based temperature sensor have been designed. The temperature sensor generates a signal whose frequency is linearly related to temperature. The RF energy harvester harvests RF energy to power the sensor without a battery. A dual-polarized antenna is designed for simultaneously transferring RF energy and temperature data. It features a bandwidth of 0.665~1.295 GHz and a peak gain of ~7 dBi. Experimental results demonstrate that the system achieves a temperature resolution of ~7.9 mK in the temperature range of -35 to 80 °C, a communication distance of 10 meters, an average power consumption of 1.68 mW at a distance of 2m and 12.4μW at a distance of 10m., and a minimum operating power of -10 dBm. The performance of the proposed system indicates its potential for wireless high-precision temperature sensing applications.

title: Semantic-Interactive Clustering Optimization with SAM for Weakly-Supervised Person Search
authors: Xi Yang, Hexun Zhou, De Cheng, Menghui Tian, Nannan Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Weakly-supervised person search presents significant challenges when relying solely on bounding-box annotations, particularly due to inter-class confusion from clothing similarity and intra-class variations caused by illumination changes, which severely degrade cross-view matching accuracy. Existing clustering-based methods, constrained by their heavy dependence on color features, frequently produce unreliable pseudo-labels that ultimately limit model performance. To overcome these limitations, we present Segment Anything Model-based Semantic-Interactive Clustering Optimization (SAM-SICO), a novel framework that integrates the Segment Anything Model’s semantic segmentation capability with adaptive clustering optimization for weakly-supervised person search. Our framework harnesses the representational power of the Segment Anything Model (SAM) to enable detector-free semantic feature learning while significantly improving clustering precision. The proposed solution makes three key advances: the Semantic Contour Embedding (SCE) module leverages SAM’s zero-shot segmentation capability to produce highly accurate human body masks; the Relation-driven Semantic Feature Interaction (RSFI) mechanism effectively mitigates clothing-color bias through innovative dynamic affinity matrix construction across multiscale semantic masks and visual features; and the Adaptive Clustering Optimization (ACO) algorithm introduces parameter adaptation to optimize intra-class compactness and inter-class separation metrics. Experimental results show that our method outperforms existing state-of-the-art approaches on the PRW and CUHK-SYSU datasets. The source code is available at https://github.com//HawlsonZ/SAM-SICO.

title: Message Passing Neural Network (MPNN) for Large-Scale Healthcare IoT Networks in Smart City
authors: Gilang Raka Rayuda Dewa, Jindae Kim, Illsoo Sohn
abstract: In smart cities, real-time monitoring of patients’ health conditions is crucial for ensuring timely interventions. However, due to the extensive geographical coverage required, manually tracking patients’ conditions poses significant challenges. To address this issue, Healthcare IoT (H-IoT) networks have been developed to facilitate data transmission. However, given the limited availability of base stations and various signal issues, maintaining optimal wireless performance in H-IoT networks remains a significant challenge. To mitigate these challenges, this paper proposes a message-passing neural network algorithm to determine a near-optimal user assignment strategy within the H-IoT network. By leveraging the graphical representation of message passing and the aggregation-update mechanism of graph neural networks (GNNs), the proposed algorithm effectively combines both the network model and historical data to optimize decision-making. Unlike conventional GNN-based methods, which either treat user assignment as a black-box regression problem or require centralized training with complex constraints, the proposed algorithm introduces a hybrid architecture that exchanges small-sized messages iteratively and subsequently optimizes via a graph-based rule. The objective function of the proposed algorithm is clearly defined as a nonlinear problem, which is subsequently derived mathematically via the message-passing rule to find an autonomous decision. The solid mathematical formulation and hybrid algorithm enhance scalability, improve interpretability, and support distributed operations with minimal communication overhead. Consequently, the proposed algorithm achieves near optimal performance while maintaining low computational complexity. Extensive simulation results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm outperforms conventional methods in terms of different user and cell sizes, adaptability to varying base station power transmission, robustness in diverse wireless pathloss environments, and computational complexity.

title: Intelligent Edge Caching Strategies for Optimized Content Delivery
authors: Jiacheng Hou, Mourad Elhadef, Amiya Nayak
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: With the proliferation of mobile users and wireless devices, networks are faced with a significant burden due to the explosion of data traffic. The high volume and short lifetime of data pose unique challenges for efficient data management and delivery. To address these challenges, we introduce a proactive caching placement strategy. Specifically, we propose a “spatial temporal graph attention network-soft actor-critic” (STGAN SAC)-based caching placement algorithm. This algorithm is developed to optimize edge caching efficiency in a decentralized manner and enable caching decisions without the need for prior knowledge of content popularities. In addition, our approach jointly considers content popularity and freshness. Our experimental evaluations consistently demonstrate the superior performance of STGAN-SAC compared to two state-of-the-art caching strategies, DDRQN and DDGARQN. STGAN-SAC consistently achieves cache hit ratios that exceed existing solutions by a noteworthy margin.

title: BDFM: Foundation Model for Segmentation and Classification Tasks of Brain Diseases
authors: Jiatian Zhang, Chunxiao Xu, Han Zhong, Yiheng Cao, Lingxiao Zhao
abstract: Objective: The lack of high-quality annotated images and the limited transferability of task-specific models hamper the practical of AI-assisted diagnosis for brain diseases. Developing self-supervised foundation model is a promising solution to address this problem. Methods: We establish a masked image modeling (MIM)-based foundation model of brain disease (BDFM). We construct a database named BD-15k of more than ten brain diseases for pre-training. To improve the lesion feature extraction ability of BDFM, we propose a spatial-frequency dual-domain decoder, and introduce a spatial mean masking strategy to replace the traditional masking methods. Results: Results indicate that these improvements help BDFM outperform the baseline method in reconstructing lesion details. Extensive qualitative and quantitative experiments on three downstream tasks show that BDFM generalizes well to segmentation and classification tasks based on small annotated datasets. Conclusion: BDFM outperforms taskspecific models trained from scratch while avoiding complex task-specific designs. Significance: This work contributes to the advancement of medical foundation models, paving the way for more effective brain disease analysis. The source code will be made publicly available upon publication in <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/zzzjjj98/BDFM</uri>.

title: 45–100-GHz UWB and W-Band High-Efficiency SiGe Power Amplifiers With 20-/20.1-dBm P sat and 17.3%/22.4% Peak PAE
authors: Zongxiang Wang, Jixin Chen, Peigen Zhou, Rui Zhou, Dawei Tang, Si-Yuan Tang, Zekun Li, Qianqi Meng, Wei Hong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This article presents two stability- and linearity-enhanced power amplifiers (PAs) in a 0.13-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu $</tex-math> </inline-formula>m SiGe BiCMOS technology. The ultrawideband (UWB) PA comprises four differential cascode (CC) stages with a two-way differential power combining architecture at the last stage. The W-band PA originates from the last two stages of UWB PA and aims for higher power-added efficiency (PAE). A metal–oxide–metal (MOM) capacitor-based stability-enhancement technique and an adaptive-bias circuit are proposed to improve the stability and linearity of the two PAs, respectively. A compact power splitter is utilized between the last two stages to reduce the chip area. The UWB PA achieves a measured 3-dB gain bandwidth (BW) from 45 to 100 GHz with a peak gain of 30.6 dB at 94 GHz. The 3-dB saturated output power (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$P_{\mathrm {sat}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>) BW ranges from 62 to 100 GHz with a peak <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$P_{\mathrm {sat}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> of 20 dBm and a peak PAE of 17.3% at 92 GHz. The peak output-referred 1-dB compression point (OP<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${}_{\mathbf {1 dB}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>) is 16.5 dBm at 92 GHz. The W-band PA achieves a measured 3-dB gain BW from 80 to 97 GHz with a peak gain of 21.4 dB at 90 GHz. The 3-dB <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$P_{\mathrm {sat}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> BW is from 76 to 100 GHz with a peak <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$P_{\mathrm {sat}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> of 20.1 dBm and a peak PAE of 22.4% at 94 GHz. The peak OP<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${}_{\mathbf {1 dB}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> is 16.7 dBm at 96 GHz. In addition, modulation measurements show that both the UWB and W-band PAs support 18–Gb/s 64-quadrature-amplitude modulation (QAM) at 94 GHz with error-vector magnitudes (EVMs) of −27.3 and −29.6 dB, respectively.

title: Demystifying Higher-Order Graph Neural Networks
authors: Maciej Besta, Florian Scheidl, Lukas Gianinazzi, Grzegorz Kwasniewski, Shachar Klaiman, Jürgen Müller, Torsten Hoefler
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Higher-order graph neural networks (HOGNNs) and the related architectures from Topological Deep Learning are an important class of GNN models that harness polyadic relations between vertices beyond plain edges. They have been used to eliminate issues such as over-smoothing or over-squashing, to significantly enhance the accuracy of GNN predictions, to improve the expressiveness of GNN architectures, and for numerous other goals. A plethora of HOGNN models have been introduced, and they come with diverse neural architectures, and even with different notions of what the “higher-order” means. This richness makes it very challenging to appropriately analyze and compare HOGNN models, and to decide in what scenario to use specific ones. To alleviate this, we first design an in-depth taxonomy and a blueprint for HOGNNs. This facilitates designing models that maximize performance. Then, we use our taxonomy to analyze and compare the available HOGNN models. The outcomes of our analysis are synthesized in a set of insights that help to select the most beneficial GNN model in a given scenario, and a comprehensive list of challenges and opportunities for further research into more powerful HOGNNs.

title: Learning-Based Methods for Aerial Manipulation: A Focused Review
authors: Chao Zeng, Zhan Li, Yipeng Yang, Cunjia Liu, Chenguang Yang
abstract: Learning techniques are increasingly empowering aerial robots with manipulation capabilities and have, as a result, attracted growing attention over the past decade. This work provides a focused review of recent advancements in learning-based methods for aerial manipulation (AM). Four categories of learning-based methods, i.e., imitation learning, reinforcement learning, deep learning, and learning-based control, are identified and analyzed in detail. The AM tasks enabled by these methods are also summarized and analyzed, resulting in six categories: Grasping, pick-and-place, load transportation, contact-rich operations, contact impact, and human–UAV interaction. In addition, we provide further discussions and perspectives on the current achievements and future directions of learning-based AM.

title: Bridging Data Gaps: Enhancing Wireless Localization with Physics-Informed Data Augmentation
authors: Md Mumtahin Habib Ullah Mazumder, Frost Mitchell, Aditya Bhaskara, Sneha Kumar Kasera, Neal Patwari
publish: Proceedings of the ACM on Networking
abstract: Machine learning (ML) models have emerged as the state-of-the-art approach for wireless applications such as transmitter localization. One of the challenges for ML models, however, is their reliance on the abundance of high quality data. Specifically for localization, a significant challenge is to obtain training data that ''covers'' the entire landscape, in order to ensure a high accuracy for the ML approaches. This issue is compounded when trying to localize multiple transmitters. To address this problem, we introduce a new data augmentation pipeline, termed Physics-informed Augmentation and RF Modeling (PhARMNet), that can combine existing data with a physics-based simulation model, producing a larger dataset with an improved coverage of the landscape of interest. Our results show that PhARMNet offers significant advantages over traditional path loss models. For localization, we demonstrate that augmenting training data with PhARMNet-produced samples improves localization accuracy, particularly in out-of-distribution regions and multi-transmitter settings.

title: A Self-Supervised Framework for Multi-Function Radar Signal Sequence Prediction
authors: Kangan Feng, Yu Huang, Mou Wang, Xianxiang Yu, Wei Yi, Lingjiang Kong
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Predicting multi-function radar (MFR) signal sequences is essential for radar signal analysis. Traditional methods often face challenges due to noise and outliers in intercepted signal sequences. This article proposes a novel two-stage self-supervised framework to predict pulse repetition interval (PRI) sequences of MFR signals, consisting of a preprocessing stage and a prediction stage. The preprocessing stage employs robust enhanced trend filtering (RETF) and interpolation to reconstruct the PRI pattern of the MFR signal sequence. In the prediction stage, the reconstructed PRI sequence is fed into a segment recurrent neural network (SegRNN) model, trained in a self-supervised manner, to generate predictions. Experimental results show that the proposed framework significantly enhances PRI prediction accuracy, outperforming existing algorithms even under non-ideal conditions.

title: A CNFET-Based Full-Swing Reconfigurable Spiking Neuron for Ultra-Efficient Neuromorphic Computing
authors: Prasanna Kawatkar, Kasem Khalil, Magdy Bayoumi
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a carbon nanotube field-effect transistor (CNFET)-based full-swing reconfigurable spiking neuron for ultra-low-power neuromorphic computing. Building on the prior FSR-SN architecture implemented with CMOS, this design leverages the ballistic transport and electrostatic advantages of CNFETs to overcome the energy and scaling limitations of traditional MOSFETs. The proposed neuron implements the Integrate-and-Fire model using only seven transistors, eliminating the need for external capacitors by utilizing intrinsic parasitic capacitance. Designed at the 32 nm node with (17,0) chirality CNFETs, the neuron achieves a spiking frequency of 31.25 GHz and energy consumption of just 12.81 attojoules per spike. Only simulation was performed, with all results validated by transient analysis using the Stanford CNFET model in Cadence Virtuoso. This transition from CMOS to CNFET technology yields a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$38 \times$</tex> improvement in energy efficiency (482 aJ → 12.81 aJ) and over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20 \times$</tex> spiking frequency boost (1.54 GHz → 31.25 GHz). Comparative benchmarks with neurons based on CMOS, Z2FET, SOI, and PD-SOI demonstrate significant improvements in energy efficiency and spike quality. This compact and reconfigurable architecture is well suited for scalable neuromorphic systems in edge AI, biomedical sensing, and robotics.

title: Reconfigurable Operational Amplifiers Utilizing Emerging RFETs
authors: Andreas Kramer, Julian Kulenkampff, Klaus Hofmann
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: The inherent functional behavior of reconfigurable field effect transistors (RFETs) is applied to different topologies of operational amplifiers. This leads to op-amps with unique abilities. By switching the internal bias voltages, the proposed op-amps can still perform even if the supply voltage is inverted. Furthermore, we demonstrate that the tunability of RFETs allows for parameter adjustment at runtime. In that manner, the op-amp can be optimized for specific performance characteristics, such as higher DC-gain or GBW. The developed floating biasing circuit for the differential pair based on RFETs enables utilization of the full reconfigurability that would not be possible with regular CMOS devices.

title: Grid Compliance and Performance Analysis of a Hybrid Load–Generation Site Integrating Wind Farm, Battery Storage, and Hydrogen Generation
authors: Mohamed Abouyehia, Anup Nambiar, Irfan Yousuf, Michael Smailes, Khaled H. Ahmed
publish: 2025 10th IEEE Workshop on the Electronic Grid (eGRID)
abstract: The increasing penetration of hybrid load–generation sites is expected to play a pivotal role in future power grids. This paper investigates the challenges associated with a hybrid load–generation site comprising offshore wind farms (OWFs), battery energy storage systems (BESS), and hydrogen production units, with a focus on its impact on grid compliance. The study begins with a detailed numerical modelling of the entire hybrid site in PSCAD, incorporating real-world technologies such as Siemens-Gamesa wind turbines, ABB eStorage Max-STPP BESS and Siemens Silyzer 300 electrolyser systems to ensure accurate representation of industrially deployed components. The proposed hybrid site includes a 1.2 GW OWF, a 400 MW BESS, and a 400 MW electrolyser plant, all operating behind a single 400 kV grid connection point. Scenario-based simulations reveal several critical challenges associated with the operation of hybrid load–generation sites. These include the slow dynamics of electrolysers, high reactive power requirements from transmission infrastructure, and constraints in fault ride-through performance. To address these issues, potential mitigation solutions are thoroughly analysed and evaluated. The findings, verified through PSCAD simulations, provide a comprehensive understanding of regulatory compliance in large-scale hybrid energy systems and present practical recommendations for the development of future grids.

title: Hybrid Voltage Balancing Method Applied to 6 Series-Connected 1.2 Kv SiC MOSFETs
authors: Antoine Philippe, Nicolas Ginot, Guillaume Piquet Boisson, Anne-Sophie Descamps, Van-Sang Nguyen, Christophe Batard
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: To simplify the design of MV converters by using a two-level topology, this paper proposes the use of a synthetic MV switch of up to 48 series-connected 1.2 kV SiC MOSFETs. As such a high number of series-connected switches suffer from dynamic voltage unbalancing issues, a new voltage balancing method is proposed using a combination of voltage clamping circuits and gate delay control. This paper studies the behaviour of the clamping circuit for 3 MOSFETs in series at 2.1 kV and validates the use of the proposed method for a number of 6 MOSFETs in series, at 4.2 kV. The aim is to integrate this new synthetic switch into a converter and gradually increase the number of transistors to reach a series connection of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 8 ~ S i C}$</tex> MOSFETs that can withstand up to 34 kV.

title: Motion Compensation Method for FAST-SYISR bistatic SAR Moon Imaging Based on Beetle Antennae Search Algorithm
authors: Yan Yin, Hongkun Yu, Lijia Huang, Jitong Duan, Xianghua Niu, Chibiao Ding
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Five-hundred-meter Aperture Spherical radio Telescope (FAST), with its powerful observation capability, is naturally suited for celestial radar observation tasks. Due to FAST’s inability to transmit signals, we utilize Sanya Incoherent Scatter Radar (SYISR) as the transmitting radar to form a bistatic synthetic aperture radar (SAR) system with FAST. However, the non-cooperative relationship between the transmitting and receiving radars introduces complex system errors, such as clock synchronization errors and radar pointing errors. These errors result in significant motion through range cells even after motion compensation based on range curves calculated by ephemeris, leading to severe defocusing. To address this issue, this paper proposes a motion compensation method based on Beetle Antennae Search Algorithm (BAS). The method models the range curve as a 5th-order polynomial and employs image entropy as the objective function. By leveraging BAS’s global optimization capability, it adaptively optimizes range curve parameters, effectively improving compensation accuracy. Experiment results demonstrate that this method can effectively overcome the impact of bistatic SAR system errors and significantly enhance image quality, providing technical support for FAST’s participation in radar celestial exploration missions.

title: Simulation of Passive Millimeter-Wave Monitoring Imaging for Civil Aircraft
authors: Zixiang Xu, Yayun Cheng, Jiayi Chen, Dong Zhu, Jinghui Qiu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Passive millimeter-wave (PMMW) imaging can operate under all-weather low visibility conditions such as fog, haze, clouds, smoke, and sandstorms, and is an important auxiliary method for detecting aircraft in the air. However, the description of the millimeter-wave radiation characteristics of aircraft at different distances and directions in typical aerial scenarios is still insufficient. This paper models and analyzes the detection capability of PMMW imaging for civil aircraft at multiple distances and angles under different flight altitudes and observation angles through computational simulation. The raytracing method is used to simulate PMMW imaging in typical observation scenarios. The simulation results reveal the influence of observation distance and pitch angle on the brightness temperature difference. These findings have important reference value for designing new aerial target detection systems and aircraft detection methods.

title: Inversion of Snow Depth on Multi-Year Sea Ice Based on the SMRT Model
authors: Li Lele, Yang Meng, Chen Haihua, Fan Yanfei
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: L-band microwaves can penetrate snow and ice deeply due to their low frequency. Their propagation in snow is affected by snow's physical properties, which modulate the microwave signal and enable it to carry information about the snow layer. The L-band microwave radiative transfer model is the foundation for the retrieval of snow depth on Arctic multiyear sea ice. In this study, the snow depth on Arctic multiyear ice is retrieved based on Snow Microwave Radiative Transfer model (SMRT). First, the key process of forward simulation is improved to enhance the accuracy. Then the snow depth retrieval algorithm combining L-band model with radar altimeter data is selected, and the feasibility of applying the improved SMRT model to the multi-year ice snow depth retrieval is verified. Finally, the average monthly snow depth from January to March of each year between November 2012 and April 2021 has been analyzed. The comparison between the retrieval results and the snow depth product indicates that the algorithm used in this study is more effective in determining the distribution of snow depth in the Arctic. The verified result using Operation Ice Bridge (OIB) data from 2013 to 2015 shows that the retrieval snow depths are in good agreement with OIB data, with a RMSE of 0.07m. This indicates the validity of the snow depth retrieval algorithm on Arctic multi-year ice based on the SMRT model.

title: CEASeg: Cross-modal Efficient Attention Semantic Segmentation Method for Remote Sensing Images
authors: Huayu Zhang, Yufeng Wang, Zehao Zhang, Dacheng Qi, Wenrui Ding
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Cross-modal semantic segmentation plays a significant role in Remote Sensing due to the complementary and heterogeneous nature of multi-source data. Nevertheless, existing cross-modal segmentation methods tend to extract shared features with complex network structures, which restrict the efficiency of segmentation and lead to considerable computational redundancy. To overcome the limitations, a cross-modal efficient attention segment model (CEASeg) for RS images is designed. CEASeg first extracts multi-level features through a well-designed dual-branch network. Next, we design two efficient blocks for cross-modal fusion. The attention-based cross-modal fusion block (ACMFusion) can learn feature correlations between two modalities and perform weight up-sampling, while the partial cross-attention fusion block (PCAFusion) emphasizes the global interaction information of deep features. The promising experimental results on two datasets show that CEASeg outperforms the state of the art approaches in both accuracy and efficiency.

title: HALOC-AxA: an Area/-Energy-Efficient Approximate Adder for Image Processing Application
authors: Hasnain A. Ziad, Ashiq A. Sakib
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: The design of approximate adders has been widely researched to advance energy-efficient hardware for computation intensive multimedia applications, such as image/audio/video processing. Several static and dynamic approximate adders exist in the literature, each of which endeavors to balance the conflicting demands of high performance, computational accuracy, and energy efficiency. This work introduces a novel approximate adder that is more energy- and area-efficient than existing adders, while achieving improved or comparable accuracy, as demonstrated by simulation results. The proposed adder's ability to digitally reconstruct high-quality images is further demonstrated by the deployment of the design for an image processing task.

title: Collaborative Innovation in Early-stage Startups: Insights from Nova Scotia's Innovation Ecosystem
authors: Uchechukwu Nwogu, Muhammad Faraz Mubarak, Marco Cuvero, Richard Evans
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society Conference - Global (TEMSCON Global)
abstract: Early-stage startups face significant innovation challenges from resource constraints, limited network access, and restricted external knowledge. While critical, how startups integrate external expertise, funding, and technology in product development is largely underexplored in current literature. This study, therefore, aims to investigate collaborative innovation in Nova Scotian early-stage software startups, focusing on design decision factors and product development challenges. Grounded in Dynamic Capability and Absorptive Capacity theories, this study analyzed 26 semi-structured interviews with startup founders and developers. The findings show that iterative feedback, user-centered design, and ecosystem engagement are key to overcoming funding instability, staff turnover, and technical hurdles. Thematic analysis shows that external collaboration improves access to resources, reduces time-tomarket, and improves innovation performance. The study's results extend dynamic capability and absorptive capacity theories to early-stage startups and offer practical guidance to improve innovation performance in dynamic environments.

title: Enhanced Target Detection Method Based on Optical and SAR Image Fusion
authors: Rufeng Guo, Rong Gui, Jun Hu, Pinjun Tang, Lihuan Tan
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Target detection, as a research hotspot in the field of remote sensing image processing, plays a crucial role in applications such as environmental protection and military reconnaissance, in terms of reliability, speed, and accuracy. However, target detection techniques based on a single data source face the issue of a high false detection rate. Multi-source remote sensing image fusion technology is an important means of obtaining high-quality feature observation data. Compared to a single sensor, this technology overcomes limitations in observation content and data acquisition time, enabling more accurate interpretation of the observation scene. It not only improves the quality of the image and the visualization effect, but also enhances the target information, thus improving the accuracy of subsequent target detection. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a target enhancement detection method based on the fusion of optical and SAR images. This method enhances scene detail information using optical images and improves the scattering feature information, such as geometry, material, and spatial distribution characteristics of the target using SAR images. The effectiveness of the fused-image target recognition method is demonstrated through the example of oil tank identification. Experimental results show that the method effectively reduces false detections of oil tank targets and overcomes the limitations of using single optical or SAR images for target detection. In terms of mAP50 metrics, the method shows an improvement of 0.3% and 31.7% compared to models trained with optical and SAR images alone, respectively. Furthermore, this model can be extended and applied to other target recognition studies based on the fusion of multi-source remote sensing images, thereby improving target detection accuracy.

title: Advancing Earth Observation with Trainable Quanvolutional Neural Networks for Classification Tasks
authors: Francesco Mauro, Francesca De Falco, Andrea Ceschini, Gabriele Meoni, Alessandro Sebastianelli, Massimo Panella, Paolo E. Gamba, Silvia L. Ullo
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The growing complexity of Earth observation data demands innovative approaches for efficient processing and analysis. Quantum convolutional neural networks integrate quantum computing principles into classical deep learning architectures, offering enhanced feature extraction capabilities. Building on the Quanv4EO framework, this study introduces a trainable quanvolutional layer within a hybrid neural network, enabling dynamic parameter optimization during training. Experiments using the EuroSAT dataset demonstrate that the trainable quanvolution surpasses both its non-trainable quantum and the classical counterparts, achieving a higher accuracy value with fewer parameters. These findings underscore the potential of trainable quantum models for earth observation applications.

title: FES-UAP: A Feature Enhancement Strategy-Based Adversarial Attack for SAR Target Classification
authors: Yuntian Liu, Weibo Qin, Feng Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) based synthetic aperture radar automatic target recognition (SAR-ATR) systems are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, where carefully crafted perturbations can mislead predictions on clean images. A universal adversarial perturbation (UAP) is a single perturbation that can cause the target model to misclassify most images when applied to images in a dataset. This property makes it highly relevant to real-world application scenarios. However, existing UAP generation methods rarely consider SAR’s unique imaging characteristics, leaving room for improvement. In this paper, a feature enhancement strategy-based universal adversarial perturbation named FES-UAP is proposed, which is designed specially for SAR images. Before the generation of UAP, augmentation of the SAR scattering features is conducted to improve its performance. The enhancement strategy amplifies the weak scattering features of the SAR images while preserving the main scattering features. Moreover, over-fitting can be prevented by the random rotation of the original images. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm can achieve higher transferability without prior knowledge of original data. Furthermore, the introduced method maintains high transferability under limited data conditions.

title: Pharameutical Nonadherence Monitoring in Initial Tuberculosis Treatment: An IoT and Web-Based Integration Approach
authors: Yusrina Latansadina, Achmad Rizal, Ario Harry Prayogo
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: Treatment adherence is critical to the success of tuberculosis (TB) therapy, particularly during the initial intensive phase. However, traditional and digital adherence tools such as SMS reminders, Video-Observed Therapy (VOT), and Medication Event Monitoring Systems (MEMS) face several limitations, including scalability issues, high costs, lack of environmental monitoring, and privacy concerns. This paper proposes a low-cost, IoT-enabled smart drug dispenser that integrates an ESP32 microcontroller, a DHT22 temperature and humidity sensor, and a 28BYJ-48 stepper motor to ensure both environmental compliance and scheduled medication delivery. The system interfaces with a web-based application developed using PHP, MySQL, and XAMPP, allowing healthcare providers to remotely monitor environmental conditions and adherence data. Calibration tests demonstrated that the DHT22 sensor met World Health Organization (WHO) standards after humidity offset correction. Functional testing yielded $100 \%$ dispensing accuracy with a timing deviation of only one second. Designed with affordability (costing under USD ${\$}$100) and energy efficiency (estimated 387-day battery) in mind, the system operates on minimal power, making it suitable for low-and middle-income countries. This integrated platform supports real-time monitoring, improves treatment reliability, and enhances pharmaceutical integrity, offering a scalable solution aligned with WHO’s goals to minimize TB treatment default and reduce the emergence of drug-resistant strains.

title: Hyperspectral Object Tracking Using Spectral Adaptive Imaging Model
authors: Yuning Wang, Mingyang Ma, Zhiyong Wang, Shaohui Mei, Yan Feng
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Hyperspectral video data, with its high spectral resolution and unified imaging and spectroscopy, holds great potential for fine-grained object recognition and tracking. However, traditional hyperspectral imaging sensors are large in size and heavy in weight, hindering the integration on small platforms. Moreover, high spectral similarity exists between adjacent narrow-band video frames, leading to significant information redundancy. Based on a spectral adaptive imaging model, this paper proposes a task-solving framework for typical video object tracking. By establishing an imaging quality index evaluation criterion and time constraints, the proposed method can adaptively select the optimal detection and tracking band from spectral video data. The paper conducted experimental validation and analysis on multiple hyperspectral object tracking videos. Results show the proposed spectral band adaptive video object tracking method can screen out the optimal spectral detection and tracking narrow band. The method proposed in this paper can effectively improve processing and analysis efficiency and reduce data acquisition cost, facilitating the design of a simplified spectral imaging detection system.

title: Spatio-temporal changes in beach width before and after the earthquake of 27 February 2010. Case study: La Pesca and La Trinchera beaches, Maule Region, Chile
authors: Idania Briceño De Urbaneja, Waldo Pérez-Martínez, Isidora Díaz-Quijada, Joaquín Valenzuela-Jara, Carolina Martínez, Catalina Aguirre
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Beach width serves as a crucial indicator of coastal dynamics, reflecting sediment transport and shoreline evolution. This study analyzes two relatively undisturbed coastal areas, characterized by dune fields, mudflats, and beaches, to assess the impacts of wave-induced processes, ENSO, earthquakes, and storm surges on accretion and erosion. Using the CoastSat algorithm, satellite imagery, wave climate data, and in situ measurements, spatiotemporal variations were examined. The results highlight the influence of both seasonal and interannual processes, with the February 27, 2010 earthquake (Mw 8.8) significantly altering shoreline variability. These findings reinforce the need for high-resolution monitoring to improve predictive modeling and support sustainable coastal management in the face of climate change.

title: Dual-Superpixel Graph Convolutional Network for Landslide Susceptibility Mapping
authors: Yuchen Li, Tao Chen, Xin Yu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Landslide, as one of the most numerous and frequent geological disasters, often brings huge loss of life and property to the people, so landslide susceptibility mapping (LSM) is very important. At present, graph convolutional network (GCN) has become an important tool to improve LSM model because of its ability to process graph structure data effectively. However, GCN has the problem of high computation and memory consumption when processing large-scale graph data. To overcome this problem, a dual-superpixel graph convolutional network (DSGCN) based on superpixel segmentation is proposed. The model uses the SLIC algorithm to perform superpixel segmentation on the image, and then performs convolution and feature fusion both within and between the superpixels, thus effectively reducing the computational complexity and making full use of the spatial relations inside the superpixel. The experimental results show that DSGCN model has significant advantages in landslide susceptibility assessment. Compared with traditional convolutional neural networks (CNN) and densely connected networks (DenseNet), DSGCN performs well on several performance indicators, especially on OA, F1 score, Kappa and AUC. DSGCN is 95.09%, 70.23%, 0.6779 and 0.9932 respectively, which shows its superiority in landslide prediction. It also provides accurate and reliable support for landslide prediction in the Three Gorges Reservoir Area.

title: Hybrid Statistical Framework for Bayesian Model Averaging of Evapotranspiration on the Tibetan Plateau
authors: Ziyin Liu, Guiyun Zhou
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Accurate estimation of terrestrial evapotranspiration (ET) on the Tibetan Plateau is essential for understanding its impacts on regional and global climate dynamics. Remote sensing-based ET algorithms have been widely used, yet each algorithm has uncertainties that result in variability among ET estimates. To incorporate different algorithms based on their applicability, we refined the Bayesian model averaging (BMA) framework with flexible hybrid statistical distribution assumptions. By determining the optimal distribution of each model and initializing BMA with prior distribution parameters, we merged four widely used ET products to estimate monthly ET over the Tibetan Plateau at a 0.1° spatial resolution from 2007 to 2021. The proposed method effectively integrates multiple ET estimates assessed by in situ measurements. It improved the average correlation coefficient by 12.25% and reduced the average root mean square error by 4.25 mm/month.

title: Multi-Model Ensemble and Progressive Prediction for Aircraft Detection and Recognition
authors: Tianjun Shi, Xuan Wang, Guangzhen Bao, Pengfei Zhang, Yongqi Mu, Shikai Jiang, Xiyang Zhi, Jinnan Gong, Wei Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Aircraft detection and recognition in satellite imagery can provide crucial technical support for military and civilian applications such as battlefield early warning and air route control. However, existing methods struggle to meet the high accuracy demands due to the interference from complex scenes, as well as the high intra-class variations and low inter-class differences from the aircraft. To address the above challenges, this work fully exploits the potential of existing detectors and proposes a multi-model ensemble prediction framework for aircraft detection and recognition. Specifically, the complementary strengths of Transformer and CNN architectures are leveraged by incorporating multi-scale image inputs and decision-level fusion. The ensemble prediction mitigates the interference from complex scenes and assists the network in making more accurate decisions. On this basis, the oriented progressive prediction is proposed by cascading multiple prediction stages after the region proposal network for each model, which refines the detection and recognition results. Besides, diverse augmentation strategies are employed to generate various training samples, which enhances the model’s generalization capability. Experimental results prove that the proposed method can improve the mean Average Precision (mAP) by over 10% compared to single-model prediction.

title: Exploring Parallelism in FPGA-Based Accelerators for Machine Learning Applications
authors: Sed Centeno, Christopher Sprague, Arnab A Purkayastha, Ray Simar, Neeraj Magotra
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: Speculative backpropagation has emerged as a promising technique to accelerate the training of neural networks by overlapping the forward and backward passes. Leveraging speculative weight updates when error gradients fall within a specific threshold reduces training time without substantially compromising accuracy. In this work, we implement speculative backpropagation on the MNIST dataset using OpenMP as the parallel programming platform. OpenMP's multi-threading capabilities enable simultaneous execution of forward and speculative backpropagation steps, significantly improving training speed. The application is planned for synthesis on a state-of-the-art FPGA to demonstrate its potential for hardware acceleration. Our CPU-based experimental results demonstrate that speculative backpropagation achieves a maximum speedup of 24% in execution time when using a threshold of 0.25, and accuracy remaining within <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3-4 \%$</tex> of the baseline across various epochs. Additionally, when comparing individual step execution time, speculative backpropagation yields a maximum speedup of 35% over the baseline, demonstrating the effectiveness of overlapping forward and backward passes.

title: Lightweight Single-Stage Detector for Small-Object Detection in SAR Images with Hardware-Optimized Implementability
authors: Siyu Zhang, Xinyang Pu, Feng Xu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Efficient small-object detection in Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) images is critical for maritime applications, particularly in resource-constrained environments. Deploying detection models on hardware platforms offers advantages such as low power consumption, real-time processing, and operational stability. However, the increasing complexity of deep learning models poses significant challenges for hardware implementation, while the reduced image resolution needed for rapid detection compromises pixel details, impacting accuracy for small targets. This paper presents a lightweight single-stage detection network, based on the YOLO architecture, optimized for efficient deployment on hardware-limited platforms. The proposed model achieves a 39.2% reduction in parameters, a 33% decrease in GFLOPs, and 34.44% fewer layers, processing images at 3.4ms per frame with only a 3.7% decrease in mAP50. This design ensures compatibility with resource-limited hardware, simplifying the implementation and making it ideal for embedded and edge systems. Balancing speed, accuracy, and efficiency, it excels in real-time ship detection in low-resolution SAR image, making it highly suitable for maritime applications in hardware-constrained environments.

title: Teaching Future Skills Through Interdisciplinary Problem-Based Learning: A Three-Year Capstone Study
authors: Johannes Kern
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society Conference - Global (TEMSCON Global)
abstract: Future-ready engineers must blend business acumen, data literacy, self-direction and teamwork. The author redesigned a two-semester capstone at DHBW Lörrach where Digital Business and Data Science students jointly build data-driven ventures, then tracked three cohorts (2022-2024) with surveys <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(n=48)$</tex> and qualitative feedback. Four interventions -version-controlled “single source of truth,” workload-credit symmetry, graded interim milestones, and just-in-time micro-lectures - increased assessment-clarity agreement from 16% to 30% and doubled perceived course effectiveness, while workload appropriateness rose by a large effect (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{d}=1.06$</tex>). Students reported sharper self-organization and cross-disciplinary communication, though some instructor-alignment issues persist. The study shows that carefully scaffolded, interdisciplinary problem-based learning can measurably accelerate future skills acquisition and offers practical levers for educators to balance authentic ambiguity with structural support.

title: HyFusion: Enhanced Reception Field Transformer for Hyperspectral Image Fusion
authors: Chia-Ming Lee, Yu-Fan Lin, Yu-Hao Ho, Li-Wei Kang, Chih-Chung Hsu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Hyperspectral image (HSI) fusion addresses the challenge of reconstructing High-Resolution HSIs (HR-HSIs) from High-Resolution Multispectral images (HR-MSIs) and Low-Resolution HSIs (LR-HSIs), a critical task given the high costs and hardware limitations associated with acquiring high-quality HSIs. While existing methods leverage spatial and spectral relationships, they often suffer from limited receptive fields and insufficient feature utilization, leading to suboptimal performance. Furthermore, the scarcity of high-quality HSI data highlights the importance of efficient data utilization to maximize reconstruction quality. To address these issues, we propose HyFusion, a novel Dual-Coupled Network (DCN) framework designed to enhance cross-domain feature extraction and enable effective feature map reusing. The framework first processes HR-MSI and LR-HSI inputs through specialized subnetworks that mutually enhance each other during feature extraction, preserving complementary spatial and spectral details. At its core, HyFusion utilizes an Enhanced Reception Field Block (ERFB), which combines shifting-window attention and dense connections to expand the receptive field, effectively capturing long-range dependencies while minimizing information loss. Extensive experiments demonstrate that HyFusion achieves state-of-the-art performance in HR-MSI/LR-HSI fusion, significantly improving reconstruction quality while maintaining a compact model size and computational efficiency. By integrating enhanced receptive fields and feature map reusing into a coupled network architecture, HyFusion provides a practical and effective solution for HSI fusion in resource-constrained scenarios, setting a new benchmark in hyperspectral imaging. Our code will be publicly available.

title: Spatiotemporal Evolution and Coupling Coordination of Ecological Environment and Urbanization in Jiangsu Province from 2002 to 2022
authors: Qingqu Luo, Yuwei Guan, Binbin He
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Achieving harmony between the ecological environment and urbanization is essential for sustainable development. In China, the rapid pace of urbanization and intensified human activities have heightened the conflict between human progress and environmental sustainability. Using MODIS and socioeconomic data, this study analyzed the spatiotemporal evolution and interaction between the Modified Remote Sensing Ecological Index (MRSEI) and Urbanization Level Index (ULI) in Jiangsu Province from 2002 to 2022. The findings are as follows: (1) Northern Jiangsu has experienced consistent improvement in ecological environment, while southern Jiangsu saw significant degradation between 2002 and 2010, followed by recovery and stabilization from 2010 to 2022. (2) Southern Jiangsu maintains a higher urbanization level with rapid growth, whereas urbanization in northern Jiangsu accelerated after 2014 but still lags behind the south. (3) Both the urbanization lag in northern Jiangsu and the ecological environment lag in southern Jiangsu have improved over time, contributing to enhanced coordination between ecological environment and urbanization across the province.

title: Buildings’ BLS And UAV Photogrammetry Point Clouds Rough Registration Method
authors: Hao Tang, Shihua Li, Minfeng Xing, Jiayu Zhu, Ziyi Wang, Chenghao Li, Ruoyi Qiu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: With the increasing demand for urban data visualization, the acquisition and processing of point cloud data has become more and more important. BLS and UAV photogrammetric point cloud can complement each other and provide data basis for further 3D reconstruction after registration. This study proposes a BLS and photogrammetric building point clouds rough registration method. In this method, the DSM imagery of the point cloud is constructed, and the Laplace operator is used to extract the regions with obvious height variations. Then the KAZE feature extraction algorithm is used to calculate the rotation and scaling matrices, and further generate the registration matrix. Finally, the translation is calculated to realize the point cloud rough registration. In this study, two buildings are used for method validation. The average error is about 0.7m and the average processing time is about 200s. The results show that the method can efficiently realize the rough registration of BLS and UAV photogrammetric building point clouds with high accuracy. The results of this study can be further used for 3D reconstruction.

title: Dynamic Deformation Monitoring of Bridge Using Low-cost MIMO-SAR And FMD Analysis: A Case Study of Railway Bridge in Shenzhen, China
authors: Lin He, Bochen Zhang, Songbo Wu, Chuanhua Zhu, Jiasong Zhu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Terrestrial radar interferometry (TRI) is a high-flexible technique for monitoring the dynamic deformation of infrastructures with high temporal and spatial resolution. However, the radar sensors used by TRI often employ large or movable antennas; such sensors are typically expensive and have low flexibility. In recent years, autonomous driving has developed millimeter-wave radar sensors quickly, reducing radar’s hardware cost and size. Multi-input multi-output synthetic aperture radar (MIMO-SAR), a low-cost and high-flexibility millimeter-wave radar system, can acquire measurements under adverse weather conditions. This study focuses on the dynamic deformation monitoring of a railway bridge in Shenzhen, China, by MIMO-SAR. Results show that dynamic loading displacements of different bridge parts were captured during train passing, with a maximum displacement of 0.6 mm. In addition, the vibration frequency of the bridge displacement was analyzed with feature mode decomposition (FMD). Three feature modes were obtained by applying FMD to the deformation time series. The results demonstrated that the low-cost MIMO-SAR system can precisely measure the dynamic deformation caused by the loadings of the passing trains. An innovative and cost-effective approach to structural health monitoring has been presented in this study, which offers a transformative solution for structural safety and sustainable urban development.

title: Hyperspectralization: Hyperspectral Image Reconstruction from a Patch-Sampled Observation
authors: Saori Takeyama, Shunsuke Ono
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This paper proposes a new hyperspectral (HS) image reconstruction framework, named hyperspectralization. This framework assumes a pair of a patch-sampling HS image and a luminance image as observations, where the resolution of the two images is almost the same. The sampling HS observation has limited spatial information but full-band spectral information, so a desirable HS image can be reconstructed by effectively spreading the spectral information. We also propose a reconstruction method for hyperspectralization. The proposed method evaluates the spatial and spectral piecewise smoothness of an HS image using hybrid spatio-spectral total variation and utilizes the patch-preserving hard constraint to keep the spatial and spectral information included in a luminance image and an HS observation, respectively. In the experiment, we confirmed the reconstruction performance of the proposed method to verify the utility of hyperspectralization. As a result, we illustrated that the proposed method can effectively estimate spectral information of no sampled pixels keeping captured spectral information.

title: Analysis and Optimization of the Dual Active Bridge Converter Based on Power Losses and Soft-Switching
authors: Alper Soysal, Deniz Yıldırım
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The increasing demand for sustainable energy solutions has driven the development of efficient energy storage and power management technologies. The Dual Active Bridge (DAB) converter stands out due to its bidirectional power flow, galvanic isolation, and high power density. This paper analyzes the DAB converter with a focus on the Triple Phase Shift (TPS) modulation technique, which improves control flexibility. The study explores optimization strategies to minimize inductor RMS current while considering system losses and soft-switching constraints. The results show that soft-switching can restrict the optimization algorithm and cause inefficient results in some operating points. Nevertheless, switches can throw away the heat and work with minimal efficiency changes without soft-switching.

title: RFI Mitigation on Raw SAR Data Using U-Net for Enhanced Signal Reconstruction
authors: Nermine Hendy, Akram Al-Hourani, Mikolaj Czerkawski, Nicolas Longépé, Thomas Kraus, Maximilian Schandri, Markus Bachmann, Haytham M. Fayek
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) systems are increasingly at risk of Radio Frequency Interference (RFI), driving the need for effective mitigation techniques to maintain data quality in challenging operational settings. This paper introduces a lightweight and effective framework designed to mitigate the impact of RFI directly on raw Radio Frequency (RF) SAR data. Given the scarcity of publicly labeled raw SAR data with interference events, a synthetic RFI dataset is created using a realistic RF-level SAR emulation tailored for spaceborne scenarios. A twin U-Net model is developed to mitigate RFI in affected segments, inferring clean SAR data from contaminated RFI inputs. The model’s mitigation performance is quantitatively validated on unseen synthetic data. This approach has the potential to enhance the quality of SAR imagery impacted by RFI with the advantage of operating directly in the raw signal domain.

title: A visible-near infrared spectral library for critical metals exploration
authors: Carsten Laukamp, Bobby Pejcic, Peter Warren, Nick Owen, Tina Shelton, Tenten Pinchand, Matilda Thomas, Ian C. Lau, Monica LeGras
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Optical remote and proximal sensing instruments, collecting reflectance spectra of rocks and sediments in the visible to near infrared (VNIR) wavelength range (350 to 1200 nm) of the electromagnetic spectrum at high spectral and spatial resolution, provide a unique fingerprint of a wide range of rock forming, alteration and ore minerals. This paper presents a newly compiled VNIR spectral reference library, comprising reflectance spectra of 249 mineral samples over the 350 to 1350 nm wavelength range, which were acquired by the CSIRO from single crystals, crystal aggregates, pulp and rock samples. The collection comprises representatives from the following mineral groups: sulfides, oxides, hydroxides, carbonates, sulfates, phosphates, molybdates/tungstates, nesosilicates, cyclosilicates, inosilicates and phyllosilicates. Many mineral species amongst those mineral groups are host minerals of critical metals, such as Co, Ga, Ge, Sb, Sc, W, and Rare Earth Elements (REE). Importantly, the spectral library also comprises gangue minerals common to the respective commodities, such as iron oxides in regolith-hosted REE-deposits. In addition to the VNIR, the short-wave infrared (SWIR) region, between 1300-2500 nm, was also collected and is only provided here for comparison purposes rather than detailed spectral peak assignment/analysis. The validation of the 249 mineral reference reflectance spectra is an ongoing process. Based on completed X-ray diffractometry, the reflectance spectra currently comprise 98 pure mineral species samples, 117 samples that are impure, but where the target minerals form an assemblage with typically associated minerals. Selected samples may require further validation methods, such as scanning electron microscopy, inductively coupled plasma spectrometry and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy. The reflectance spectra as well as metadata for each sample, such as location and validation, are being made publicly available on https://spectroscopy-dev.csiro.au/reflectance.

title: Multisource Fusion of Remote Sensing and Mobility Data for Traffic Analysis Zone Definition
authors: Martina Pastorino, Marisdea Castiglione, Federico Gallo, Marialisa Nigro, Nicola Sacco, Gabriele Moser
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The spatial discretization into traffic analysis zones (TAZs) is a crucial yet often overlooked step in transport systems analysis in an urban area. Beyond general guidelines and case-specific experience, the formulation of an automatic or semiautomatic approach remains an open challenge. Nevertheless, the joint availability of remote sensing images, whose segmentation allows identifying homogeneous regions and separating built and non-built areas, of databases that collect information on the activities performed therein (shops, workplaces, etc.), and of floating car data (FCD) provided by GPS sensors on mobile phones and cars, exhibits a remarkable potential in this framework. This paper introduces a novel method for the automatic definition of traffic analysis zones in urban areas, based on the multimodal fusion of satellite multispectral imagery and ancillary geospatial data (OpenStreetMap, land cover, and FCD) and aimed at maximizing homogeneity within zones and minimizing the number of trips with origin and destination in the same zone. The proposed approach integrates the above data sources to generate a TAZ configuration that can be directly applied in travel demand forecasting models. The methodology was applied to a case study in a neighborhood of Rome, Italy.

title: A SUMO-Based Digital Twin for Evaluation of Conventional and Electric Vehicle Networks
authors: Haomiaomiao Wang, Conor Fennell, Swati Poojary, Mingming Liu
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Digital twins are increasingly applied in transportation modeling to replicate real-world traffic dynamics and evaluate mobility and energy efficiency. This study presents a SUMO-based digital twin that simulates mixed ICEV-EV traffic on a major motorway segment, leveraging multi-sensor data fusion from inductive loops, cameras, GPS probes, and toll records. The model is validated under both complete and partial information scenarios, achieving 93.1% accuracy in average speed estimation and 97.1% in average trip length estimation. Statistical metrics, including KL Divergence and Wasserstein Distance, demonstrate strong alignment between simulated and observed traffic patterns. Furthermore, CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions were overestimated by only <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 8 - 2. 4 \%}$</tex>, and EV power consumption underestimated by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 0}-\mathbf{5. 4} {\%}$</tex>, highlighting the model's robustness even with incomplete vehicle classification information.

title: Frequency Synchronization Error Analysis And Estimation In Airborne Bistatic Sar
authors: Wenlong Dong, Guangcai Sun, Wenhua Li, Yuqi Wang, Wenkang Liu, Mengdao Xing
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In airborne bistatic synthetic aperture radar (BiSAR), the distributed configuration leads to frequency synchronization errors, degrading image quality. In this paper, we proposed an extended frequency synchronization error estimation method using the direct wave signal. Characteristics of the frequency synchronization error are analyzed, and the frequency error estimation method based on extended interpulse processing is introduced. Moreover, the phase unwrapping and sliding window averaging techniques are used to enhance the accuracy. The proposed method effectively mitigates estimation bias caused by noise and motion error. Simulation results verify the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: An Improved Deep Learning Approach to Spatiotemporal Super-Resolution of Radar Precipitation Echoes
authors: Yonghua Zhang, Jianxing Wu, Ping Zhu, Haonan Chen, Yi Zhang, Ping Shen, Zhecheng Wu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: High spatiotemporal resolution weather radar observations are essential for the monitoring, forecasting, early warning, and in-depth investigation of hazardous weather phenomena and their underlying mechanisms. In the context of limited radar observation equipment, leveraging super-resolution algorithms for weather radar data is an effective approach to obtaining high spatiotemporal resolution observations. To this end, we propose an improved spatiotemporal super-resolution algorithm for radar precipitation echoes, termed RadBDG-INL, which integrates bidirectional deformable convolutional GRU with implicit neural representation learning. Leveraging the high spatiotemporal resolution data from X-band phased-array radar, the algorithm enhances the spatiotemporal resolution of S-band dual-polarization radar observations, doubling the resolution from 6 minutes and 1000 meters to 3 minutes and 500 meters. Compared to the optical flow method followed by bicubic interpolation, the RadBDG-INL approach achieves improvements of 9.4% in PSNR and 2.54% in SSIM. Additionally, subjective evaluations by meteorological experts indicate that RadBDG-INL demonstrates a noticeable advantage. These results underscore the significant potential of RadBDG-INL for advancing spatiotemporal super-resolution in meteorological radar precipitation echo applications.

title: Evaluation of Doppler Weather Radar Derived VVP Wind Profiles
authors: Vaibhav Tyagi, Saurabh Das
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Doppler weather radar (DWR) is a critical tool in meteorology, providing invaluable insights into atmospheric conditions and detecting precipitation, storm intensity, and movement. The present study focuses on utilizing DWR radial velocity observations to retrieve local wind fields, which play a key role in transporting mass, momentum, and energy across the atmosphere and influencing meteorological processes. The study evaluates the quality of velocity volume processing (VVP) wind profiles and validates them against radiosonde observations and other reanalysis data. VVP is a well-known technique for wind field retrieval, however, it has not been rigorously evaluated over the region of interest, i.e., the southern Pensula, India. The study found that the high conditional number poses significant challenges in retrieving wind with desirable accuracy. Statistical analysis of the quality-controlled winds demonstrates a strong correlation of 0.86 for the U component and 0.77 for the V component between DWR-derived and different sources, with RMSE values of 3.16 m/s and 3.10 m/s, respectively. The study evaluates the reliability of DWR-derived wind profiles as a complementary data source for numerical weather prediction (NWP) applications. This research highlights the potential for enhancing weather forecasting accuracy, especially in areas with limited radiosonde coverage, by providing alternative wind profiles.

title: Multi-Level Energy Decomposition For Polsar Radiation Information With 2D-C-VMD
authors: Jun Huang, Jun Ni, Dapeng Tao, Mingke Li, Carlos López-Martínez
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Polarimetric Synthetic Aperture Radar (PolSAR) imagery is widely used in land cover classification and target recognition due to its rich scattering information. However, the nonlinear, non-stationary nature of PolSAR data, along with its complex scattering characteristics, makes feature extraction a challenging task. To address this, we propose a novel feature extraction method for PolSAR data based on 2D Compact Variational Mode Decomposition (2D-C-VMD). This approach decomposes the original features into modes with narrow Fourier bandwidths and enhances feature representation by reconstructing each mode using a binary support function. Specifically, 2D-C-VMD is first applied to decompose the PolSAR data, extracting modal components from different frequency ranges. A binary support function is then used to reconstruct each mode, ensuring that each mode contributes to signal reconstruction only within its support region, thus preventing interference between modes.To validate the effectiveness of this method,classification experiments were conducted on Radarsat-2 Flevoland dataset and UAVSAR Yucatan Lake dataset, and the experimental results show that this method can significantly improve the classification accuracy.

title: Integrating UAV and Spaceborne Datasets for Enhanced Forest Aboveground Biomass Estimation: A Hybrid Approach
authors: Muhammad Nouman Khan, Yumin Tan, Wenquan Dong
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Estimating aboveground biomass (AGB) is significant in sustainably managing the forest. Such forests could then be expected to play an increasing role in carbon storage and emission reduction. The Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) offers a low-cost, high-resolution complement to spaceborne datasets and can provide detailed 3D forest structure data. The current study evaluates plot-level AGB estimation using UAV-LiDAR derived height and crown diameter, calibrated GEDI-L4A AGB and GEDI- L2A rh98 heights, and spectral variables from UAV-multispectral and RGB datasets. Pearson correlation analysis revealed that the 10 most important predictors were used as predictor variables. In this sense, a random forest (RF) regression model was developed using calibrated AGB and height values and spectral variables from UAV data. The results showed that the model, including calibrated AGB, height, and spectral variables from UAV data, performed best, with training evaluation metrics of R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.95, RMSE = 13.66 Mg/ha, MAE = 6.56 Mg/ha). AGB predictions range between 29 Mg/ha to 303 Mg/ha, with standard errors ranging between 0.17 Mg/ha to 11.1 Mg/ha. This hybrid approach substantially enhances the accuracy of AGB prediction and addresses several uncertainties in AGB modelling. These results provide a robust framework that can be used to improve forest carbon stock assessments, advance global AGB monitoring, and support sustainable forest management and ecological research methodologies.

title: Family of AC/AC Retrofitted Hybrid Distribution Transformers for Grid Voltage Swell Compensation
authors: Amirhossein Malekipour, Michael M.C. Merlin, Bortecene Yildirim, Mohamed Dahidah
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: A family of retrofitting converters to hybridise distribution transformer with the purpose of grid-side voltage swell compensation is proposed in this paper. With this new design, the series voltage compensation is realised indirectly using the fully-controlled voltage source inverters connected in a shunt manner to improve the system resilience to over-current events. An interface impedance network with integrated partially-rated power converters is placed between the source and the load, making the overall system a direct single-stage AC/AC converter. Through appropriate design of the impedance network topology and the control system applied to the power converters, it is possible to perform the voltage compensation when the power converters have fractional currents and terminal voltages within acceptable range. A systematic analytical approach for designing the system is adopted and several topologies are introduced. Given each topology, simulation results are provided to verify the analytical findings and finally, a comprehensive comparison is drawn which highlights the advantages and disadvantages of each presented topology.

title: Thermal Stress Balancing Algorithm Using Nearest-Level PWM for Medium Voltage MMCs
authors: Jun-Hyung Jung, Davide D'Amato, Chang-Hwan Park, Marco Liserre
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Modular multilevel converters (MMCs) are considered a promising topology in medium- and high-voltage applications due to their modular structure. With a large number of submodules (SMs) employed in MMCs, maintaining SM capacitor voltage balancing is important for stable operation. In addition, as reliability becomes an increasingly critical design factor in power electronic converters, thermal stress balancing has also emerged as a key design consideration alongside capacitor voltage balancing. This paper proposes an enhanced thermal stress balancing algorithm using dual-SM selection for the nearest-level PWM. By selecting two SMs for PWM operation, the proposed method ensures that the SM with the lowest temperature is always loaded, thereby enhancing overall thermal stress balancing performance. Additionally, distributing switching losses across two SMs effectively reduces temperature peaks. The effectiveness of the proposed method is validated through simulation and experimental results.
