title: Segmentation of Non-Cloud Regions of Tropical Cyclones with Segformer
authors: Joshua May, Mehrtash Harandi, J Scott Tyo, Elizabeth A. Ritchie
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In this study, progress towards an automated system that can perform semantic segmentation on Tropical Cyclone (TC) regions, including regions that do not include clouds, is demonstrated. Through the use of brightness temperature (BT) images from geostationary satellites and wind information from reanalysis data, a SegFormer-based model produces segmentation maps that incorporate TC circulation. These can be used to more accurately calculate physical contributions from TCs such as precipitation or upwelling radiation, compared to previous papers that only detected clouds. The production of an expert-labeled dataset was required and utilized for the first time to train the model.

title: APC2Building: A Novel Method for Building Reconstruction from Airborne Point Clouds
authors: Qifan Yang, Ying Shang, Jiangbo Huang, Tao Shen, Qingwang Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Building reconstruction from airborne LiDAR point clouds is often challenging due to missing structures and sparse point densities. These issues make it difficult to establish accurate relationships between building components, leading to incorrect reconstruction results. To overcome these challenges, we introduce APC2Building, a completion-based generative geometric reconstruction network, that converts airborne point clouds to buildings. APC2Building utilizes a multi-scale cross-attention mechanism to fill in missing building points. This mechanism leverages the geometric features of building structures to generate a dense point cloud. After that, the network applies skip cross-attention combined with mesh convolution to reconstruct the polygonal mesh model from the completed dense point cloud. Experimental results show that APC2Building significantly improves the quality of reconstructed mesh models. It also outperforms existing methods on a real-world airborne LiDAR building point cloud dataset.

title: Global Sea Surface Salinity Retrieval Using Heterogeneous Multimodal Spaceborne BDS-3/Galileo Reflected Signals Data Fusion in Complex Marine Environments
authors: Jinwei Bu, Huan Li, Qiulan Wang, Xinyu Liu, Chaoying Ji, Xiaoqing Zuo
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Sea Surface Salinity (SSS) is crucial for marine ecosystems. Traditional L-band microwave radiometers can achieve SSS retrieval by correcting sea surface brightness temperature (BT). However, the calibration process is influenced by various complex factors and cannot be quantified to date. The Spaceborne Global Navigation Satellite System-Reflectometry (GNSS-R) can directly reflect changes in sea surface roughness, providing a new method for SSS retrieval. The spaceborne GNSS-R observations of the Cyclone Global Navigation Satellite System (CYGNSS) in conjunction with Soil Moisture and Ocean Salinity (SMOS) have successfully retrieved SSS. However, in addition to the proven factors such as wind speed and wave height, there are still many potential influencing factors for SSS. Therefore, in this study, a Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN)-Transformer fusion model based on BDS-3 and Galileo reflection signal data was proposed to incorporate rainfall and sea surface currents under low to medium wind speeds (<20m/s) into the retrieval. The Tianmu-1 data with global coverage was used to invert global SSS accurately. The results showed that the correlation coefficient between SSS and Soil Moisture Active Passive (SMAP) data retrieved using the CNN-Transformer fusion model based on BDS-3 reflected signals was as high as 0.87. Compared with the Artificial Neural Network (ANN) model, the retrieval accuracy of BDS and Galileo signals in the proposed model has been improved by 33.45% and 34.64%, respectively. The Bais of the BDS-3 signal retrieval ranges from -0.122 psu to 0.049 psu. The Bais of Galileo signal retrieval ranges from -0.568 psu to -0.202 psu. This provides a reference for the future application of spaceborne GNSS-R in SSS retrieval, especially in complex sea conditions and processing high spatiotemporal complexity data, which has significant advantages.

title: SAR Image Generation via a Differentiable Framework Leveraging 3D Gaussian Splatting
authors: Zinan Liu, Shengren Niu, Xiaolan Qiu, Lingxiao Peng, Lihua Zhong, Chibiao Ding
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) is extensively employed in Earth remote sensing. With the application of advanced intelligent methods in SAR image interpretation, the cost of image analysis and target recognition has been reduced. However, due to the limitation in the platform incident angle, measured SAR images often suffer from insufficient angular coverage, which reduces the robustness of intelligent methods such as neural networks. To effectively augment SAR samples, this paper proposes a differentiable framework for SAR target image generation from novel views. Specifically, the framework utilizes 3D Gaussian distributions and spherical harmonics to represent the target attributes. By leveraging 3D Gaussian splatting, the differentiable framework reconstructs the target scene representation by training on the samples from existing viewing angles. Finally, SAR imaging space transformation and differentiable accumulation are used to render the SAR images from novel views. Experiments conducted on both simulated datasets and MSTAR measured data, along with method comparations, validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Partial Least Squares Regression Chlorophyll-A Estimation Pipeline for Hypso-1 & -2 Hyperspectral Cube Satellites
authors: Cameron Penne, Perumthuruthil Suseelan Vishnu, Milica Orlandić
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Estimating chlorophyll-a (Chla) concentrations in coastal regions is crucial for monitoring algal blooms using satellite hyperspectral remote sensing which can detect the spectral signatures of Chla present in algae. However, downlinking full hyperspectral images from satellites for analysis is resource intensive, making onboard estimation preferable. In this work, we present a method for Chla estimation adaptable for onboard satellite processing, based on partial least squares regression (PLSR). The PLSR method is trained using multivariate hyperspectral images of the Norwegian coast acquired by HYPSO-1, a hyperspectral imaging CubeSat operated by the Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU) and on Chla concentration estimates from Sentinel-3 OLCI products. The PLSR Chla estimation model is applied to a HYPSO-1 capture of Rørvik to produce a map of Chla estimates.

title: A New High-Resolution Dataset of Multispectral Remote Sensing Images for Aerial Target Detection
authors: Wenyi Zhang, Xiaoyi Yin, Yuxin Hu, Xiangyu Dai, Qingwei Chu, Guangzuo Li
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Aerial target detection has traditionally been relying on various approaches including conventional optical images, infrared images, and radio frequency signals, each with its own limitations. Recently, multispectral remote sensing has emerged as a promising alternative, offering rich spectral information. However, current multispectral detection methods are hindered by low spatial resolution and the scarcity of comprehensive datasets, leading to reduced detection accuracy and limited applicability. To address these gaps, we present PATROL, the first high-resolution multispectral dataset specifically designed for aerial target detection. Derived from two advanced satellite systems - GFDM and CM-01, PATROL comprises 1,301 high-resolution images with 2-meter ground resolution and 512×512 pixel dimensions, featuring diverse scenarios including varying weather conditions and complex backgrounds, with all targets cross-validated using ADS-B data to ensure annotation accuracy. Comprehensive experiments demonstrate that our proposed detection framework achieves significant improvements over existing methods in challenging conditions. Each target is annotated with precise bounding boxes across all available spectral bands. Our baseline experiments demonstrate that the multispectral nature of PATROL enables more robust detection compared to single-band approaches, achieving up to 8.5% improvement in mean average precision (mAP) under challenging conditions such as low visibility and heavy cloud coverage. The dataset and baseline implementations are publicly available to facilitate future research in aerial target detection.<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>

title:
Efficient Vision Transformer Framework: Near-Surface O
                    <sub>3</sub>
                    Prediction with Missing Satellite Data
authors: Prasanjit Dey, Soumyabrata Dev, Bianca Schoen-Phelan
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This paper presents an efficient Vision Transformer (ViT) framework for predicting near-surface Ozone (O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>) concentrations using incomplete satellite data. Industrial activities have significantly increased atmospheric O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>, a pollutant with severe health and environmental impacts. Traditional ground observation techniques lack the geographical coverage provided by satellite data, but these satellite observations often suffer from continuity issues. To address these gaps, we propose a novel framework that integrates satellite and corresponding ground observation grid cells data to improve the accuracy of O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> predictions over large areas. Our primary contributions include: introducing a ViT framework that leverages multi-source data for accurate O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> prediction; using satellite data for training and ground observations for validation to reconstruct missing data and provide continuous O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> predictions. We demonstrate through experimental analysis that our framework achieves Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) values of 16.2 μg/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>, significantly outperforming four state-of-the-art models in prediction accuracy. The code for this research is available here: https://github.com/Prasanjit-Dey/O3_Prediction.

title: Remote Sensing Estimation of Fluorescent Dissolved Organic Matter (fDOM) Concentration in Wuhan Lakes Based on the Basis of Machine Learning
authors: Kai Yu, Yadong Zhou, Qi Feng, Baoyin He, Fan Yang, Xueer Geng, Xiaoqin Yang, Pengcheng Zhao, Zhou Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Fluorescent Dissolved Organic Matter (fDOM) is a pivotal parameter for evaluating the pollution levels in inland lakes and reservoirs. It functions as a reliable indicator of land-based pollution. This study explores the use of machine learning techniques, combined with the Case 2 Regional Coast Colour (C2RCC) algorithm, to estimate fDOM levels. In-situ observations were conducted in Wuhan lakes in July 2018, November 2020, January 2021, May 2022, and October 2024. The models applied in this study include Random Forest (RF), Support Vector Machine (SVM), and Back Propagation (BP) Neural Network. The findings suggest that the BP and RF models, employing remote sensing band ratio inputs, offers the more precise fDOM estimations. fDOM concentrations in Wuhan's lakes exhibit fluctuations between 4.50 and 7.50 RFU from 2019 to 2024 during the autumnal season, demonstrating a substantial decline at the onset of the pandemic and a subsequent gradual rise from 2021 onwards. Significant lakes such as Wu Lake (associated with aquaculture farming), Liangzi Lake (in Ezhou City), and Hou Lake exhibit relatively high fDOM concentrations, which may indicate significant sources of pollution.The proposed machine learning approach, when combined with validation through the C2RCC algorithm, provides a novel perspective for estimating fDOM levels.

title: A Combined Supression Method for Interrupted Sampling Repeater Jamming
authors: Jisheng Tang, Jixiang Fu, Mengdao Xing, Dan Xu, Liang Guo, Yan Lan
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Interrupted sampling repeater jamming (ISRJ) is an effective SAR imaging jamming method which has abundant jamming parameters, and the variation of these jamming parameters makes the existing jamming suppression methods do not often function ideally. Aiming at the problem of insufficient robustness of ISRJ suppression, this thesis provides a method that combines the Jamming Reconstruction method with the Frequency Filtering method. The jamming signal for counteracting is first reconstructed in the time domain to increase the signal-to-jamming ratio (SJR), and then frequency filtering is used to remove the correlation of the residual jamming. The combination provides a large improvement of the jamming suppression ratio compared with the existing methods. The robustness and effectiveness are verified by simulation.

title: Five-Phase Switched Reluctance Motor with Low Torque Ripple for Variable Speed Applications
authors: Hassan Moradi, Moslem Geravandi, Solmaz Kahourzade, Amin Mahmoudi
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: In conventional switched reluctance motors (SRMs), such as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10 / 8$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6 / 4$</tex> configurations, the number of stator poles exceeds that of rotor poles. This paper introduces a novel five-phase switched reluctance motor (SRM) with 10 stator poles and 18 rotor poles for variable-speed applications. The torque ripple of the proposed SRM is minimized based on a rigorous analytical design. The studied SRM design is then compared against that of conventional <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10 / 8$</tex> SRM design. 2D finite element analysis confirms SRM design with higher rotor pole count realizes a significant reduction in torque ripple against the conventional <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10 / 8$</tex> SRM design of similar volume and phase count. The proposed SRM design is prototyped for further performance evaluation.

title: Simulation of Airborne Circular Trace Scanning SAR Imaging Based on Full-Aperture Algorithm
authors: Jianan Yan, Pengbo Wei, Min Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Airborne Circular Trace Scanning Synthetic Aperture Radar (CTS SAR) play a significant role in microwave remote sensing because of its high resolution, all time as well as sufficient polarized information, which had been used in sensing global surface or detecting target as an efficient tool as well as also require the Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) to scan along a circular trajectory, with the radar antenna placed outside the circular scanning trajectory. This paper based on the full-aperture w-k airborne circular scanning SAR imaging algorithm, used the Geometrical Optics-Physical Optics (GO-PO) method to calculate the Radar Cross-Section (RCS) of ships under different heading and incident angle conditions. By simulating airborne circular scanning SAR images of point targets and ship models, a comparative analysis of the image characteristics under different conditions was conducted. The results illuminated that the w-K full aperture algorithm with fine focus operation had better imaging capability than coarse opaeration.

title: Directional Land Surface Emissivity Retrieval from the FY-3D MERSI-II Mid-Infrared Data
authors: Jun-Liang Pan, Geng-Ming Jiang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This paper presents the directional land surface emissivity (LSE) retrieval from the mid-infrared observations acquired by the advanced MEdium Resolution Spectral Imager (MERSI-II) on Fengyun 3D (FY-3D) satellite. First, the radiometric calibration biases in the MERSI-II channels 20 (~3.8 pm) and 21 (~4.05 pm) are corrected against the channels of the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) on Aqua satellite. Then, a method, which combines a cubic split-window method to estimate bi-directional reflectance and the RossThick-LiSparse-R model, is developed to retrieve the directional LSEs from the daytime MERSI-II mid-infrared observations. Next, the directional LSEs in the MERSI-II channels 20 and 21 in July of 2020 over the Eastern Asia (18°N~50°N, 95°E~130°E) are retrieved from the daytime MERSI-II observations. Finally, the results are cross-validated with the MOD11C2 product. The results show that the calibration biases in the MERSI-II channels 20 and 21 are 0.51±0.44 K and -0.33±0.41 K, respectively. The directional LSEs range between 0.75 and 1.0 depending on land cover types. Over the sparsely vegetated and bare areas, where the normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI) is less than or equal to 0.3 (NDVI≤0.3), the LSEs vary from 0.75 to 0.9, and the retrieval errors are about 0.06 against the MOD11C2 product. Over the densely vegetated areas (NDVI>0.3), the LSEs change from 0.9 to 1.0, and the retrieval errors are about 0.004 against the MOD11C2 product.

title: A High Payload Hybrid Audio Watermarking Scheme Using DWT, DST, QR Decomposition, and Spread Spectrum
authors: Muhammad Hilmi Izzulhaq, Gelar Budiman
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: This paper proposes a hybrid audio watermarking scheme with high embedding capacity by integrating Discrete Wavelet Transform (DWT), Discrete Sine Transform (DST), QR decomposition, and Spread Spectrum (SS) techniques to embed a $64 \times 64$ binary watermark image in audio signals. The method attains an embedding rate of 383.45 bits per second (bps), outperforming several existing techniques in terms of capacity. However, the increased capacity introduces compromises, such as elevated Bit Error Rates (BER) under certain signal processing attacks and decreased imperceptibility, as indicated by a Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR) of 21.21 dB. The scheme demonstrates selective robustness, particularly maintaining effectiveness against highrate resampling attacks. This makes it suitable for scenarios where embedding capacity is prioritized over robustness or audio quality. Future enhancements may focus on improving synchronization and perceptual transparency through psychoacoustic modeling or adaptive parameter tuning.

title: Domain Transfering Enhanced Foundation Modal For Landslide Detection From High-Resolution Remote Sensing Images
authors: Kaiyuan Li, Yong Xue, Wenhao Liu, Liying Han, Shuhui Wu, Guochao Hu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Landslide detection has become increasingly important for disaster prevention and mitigation. However, the domain adaptation challenge, particularly the domain shift between different geographical regions and sensor types, significantly hinders the widespread application of deep learning models in this field. This study aims to develop an effective domain adaptation approach for landslide detection using the SAMRS (Segment-Anything Model for Remote Sensing) framework. We propose a three-stage methodology: utilizing SAMRS's pre-trained features as the foundation, leveraging its rich geospatial knowledge; implementing a global histogram matching module that aligns feature distributions across domains by matching cumulative distribution functions of RGB channels; and developing a teacher-student knowledge distillation framework where the adapted SAMRS model guides a lightweight student network's training on the target domain. Experimental results on various geographical regions and sensor types demonstrate that our approach effectively bridges the domain gap while maintaining high detection accuracy, significantly reducing the dependency on labeled data in target domains. This study provides a practical solution for cross-domain landslide detection in real-world applications.

title: Impact Assessment of Cyberattacks in Inverter-Based Microgrids
authors: Kerd Topallaj, Colin McKerrell, Suraj Ramanathan, Ioannis Zografopoulos
publish: 2025 10th IEEE Workshop on the Electronic Grid (eGRID)
abstract: In recent years, the evolution of modern power grids has been driven by the growing integration of remotely controlled grid assets. Although Distributed Energy Resources (DERs) and Inverter-Based Resources (IBR) enhance operational efficiency, they also introduce cybersecurity risks. The remote accessibility of such critical grid components creates entry points for attacks that adversaries could exploit, posing threats to the stability of the system. To evaluate the resilience of energy systems under such threats, this study employs real-time simulation and a modified version of the IEEE 39-bus system that incorporates a Microgrid (MG) with solar-based IBR. The study assesses the impact of remote attacks impacting the MG stability under different levels of IBR penetrations through Hardware-in-the-Loop (HIL) simulations. Namely, we analyze voltage, current, and frequency profiles before, during, and after cyberattack-induced disruptions. The results demonstrate that real-time HIL testing is a practical approach to uncover potential risks and develop robust mitigation strategies for resilient MG operations.

title: Optimized Soil Moisture (OSM) Index for Enhanced Soil Moisture Estimation Using Dual-Pol SAR Data
authors: Sabreen Sadhak, Shoba Periasamy
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) is widely used for soil moisture (SM) retrieval, making it ideal for continuous environmental and agricultural monitoring applications. This study was carried out for Agastheeswaram and Thovalai taluks of Kanniyakumari District, Tamil Nadu (Site 1). In the present study, a novel model, the Optimized Soil Moisture Index (OSMI), was proposed, combining the unique features of the modified Dubois (DB) model and the free water index (FWI) to estimate SM levels across a range from dry to field-capacity conditions. The study employed GRD data from the Sentinel-1 mission. The proposed OSMI has yielded promising accuracy, with performance metrics of R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.85, RMSE = 0.08, and Bias = 0.03 for the entire range of SM levels evaluated. Hence, the OSMI has addressed the varying behavior of VV polarization in representing SM under bound and free water conditions prevailing in the clay soils. The performance of the OSMI was tested for Perambalur District, Tamil Nadu (Site 2), a region dominated by clay soil. The model demonstrated a strong correlation with observed field moisture dynamics, achieving an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.84, RMSE = 0.09, and Bias = 0.06.

title: Detection of Grapevine Viral Symptoms Using UAV-based Point Cloud Data and Vegetation Indices
authors: Fernando Portela, Pedro Marques, Leilson Gomes, Raul Morais, Joaquim J. Sousa, Luís Pádua
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) equipped with RGB sensors offer a cost-effective solution for vineyard mapping. This study presents a methodology that uses colored point cloud data to detect vineyard anomalies, specifically focusing on the identification of viral symptoms in red grapevine varieties. The methodology comprises several steps, including point cloud creation, normalization, ground removal, vegetation index computation, and data filtering. A case study was conducted in an experimental vineyard using UAV-based RGB data to create a photogrammetric point cloud, which was compared against raster-based analyses. The accuracy of the methodologies was evaluated using ground-truth data. Results indicated that the point cloud approach detected 91% grapevine areas with viral symptoms, outperforming the raster-based method, which identified only 48%. This study highlights the potential of point cloud data for improving precision viticulture and optimizing field inspections. Future developments will explore the integration of additional sensors to improve disease detection accuracy and robustness.

title: RS-ScaleGAN: A Hierarchical Multi-Scale GAN Network for Data Augmentation in Remote Sensing
authors: Yan Lu, Jiang Li
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Deep learning has shown strong performance in remote sensing image processing but relies heavily on large labeled datasets, making it prone to overfitting in data-scarce environments. To address this challenge, we propose RS-ScaleGAN, a hierarchical multi-scale generative adversarial network (GAN) designed for data augmentation in remote sensing tasks. RS-ScaleGAN can learn from one single natural image and generate realistic synthetic data samples. We applied the RS-ScaleGAN generated synthetic image samples in refugee tents detection near the Syrian border and compared the results with the traditional data augmentation methods. Our experiment results show that the RS-ScaleGAN model effectively generates diverse, high-quality remote sensing image samples, and significantly improves the classification model performance compared the the traditional methods. Specifically, the area under the ROC curve (AUC) increased by 0.6–3.3%, recall by 1.2–7.2%, and F1-scores by 0.9–3.4%. For semantic segmentation, IoU scores improved by 0.2–1.5%, with the highest IoU of 68.7% achieved with a 32×32 input and with the largest augmented dataset used on the Fully Convolutional Network as the classification model.

title: Effects of Interaction of Climate, Terrain, Soiland Human Factors on Eco-Environmental Quality in Mining Areas of China
authors: Jiao Pan, Tao Chen
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Understanding the interaction of climate, topography, soil and anthropogenic factors on Remote Sensing Ecological Index (RSEI) is helpful to reveal the feedback mechanism of mining disturbance in response to environmental conditions and climate change. Based on Google Earth Engine platform, this paper uses partial least squares model to quantitatively analyze the direct and indirect effects of climate, terrain, soil and human factors on RSEI in Yuzhong mining area of Henan Province. The results showed that the average RSEI value increased from 2000 to 2020, and the degradation rate of ecological environment decreased from 31.5% to 21.7%. Natural factors such as climate, terrain and soil have positive effects on RSEI distribution, while anthropogenic variables have negative effects on RSEI distribution, showing an N-type trend. This study introduces quantitative methods to understand the development of ecological environmental conditions in mining areas, which is essential to effectively manage safety in mine plans and to promote sustainable development on a regional scale.

title: FlexBits-SNN: RISC-V Based SNN Processor with Programmable Temporal Spike Resolution
authors: Yuru Li, Xingbo Wang, Xinyu Kang, Yuxuan Zhang, Terry Tao Ye
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of artificial intelligence, Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) have shown great potential for resource-constrained edge computing systems thanks to SNN's efficient temporal processing and low-power characteristics. However, most existing hardware designs for SNN inference rely on a fixed number of timesteps in spike temporal encoding, limiting SNN's flexibility. In this paper, we present FlexBitsSNN, a RISC-V-based general-purpose processor architecture. It incorporates multiple custom extension instructions along with a variable number of timesteps for spike encoding. FlexBitsSNN accelerates inference in both one-dimensional and twodimensional SNN networks. The custom instructions, invoked via inline assembly in C, provide greater flexibility compared to traditional processors and support complex SNN architectures. The FlexBits-SNN processor executes SNN inference tasks with an arbitrary number of timesteps and achieves over a 90% reduction in inference time as compared to conventional RISCV ISA. Performance evaluation under 55 nm CMOS process demonstrates a peak energy efficiency of 6.42 pJ/SOP (Synaptic Operation), highlighting its suitability for efficient SNN inference.

title: A Novel Approach for SAR Target Detection Based on Unsupervised Complex-Valued Extreme Learning Machine
authors: Qinglong Hua, Zhaoxin Guo, Yong Dai, Shuojia Feng, Haotian Wang, Wanghao Hu, Huilin Mu, Chang Ding, Yun Zhang, Xiaomeng Ma, Weiting Han, Ziting Zhao
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Strong clutter seriously affects target-of-interest detection in synthetic aperture radar (SAR) images. This letter proposes an unsupervised target detection method (U-TDM) based on a complex-valued extreme learning machine (CV-ELM), the essence of which is to transform the target detection problem into a pixel binary classification problem. The SAR image is first divided into several unlabeled patches, and fuzzy c-means (FCM) is used to construct the reference target patch set and the clutter patch set. Based on these two patch sets, CV-ELM is used to classify the neighboring patch of the pixel to be detected. Since the pixel intensity and distribution of target-of-interest and clutter are different, unsupervised pixel classification could be realized without ground-truth through U-TDM. Experimental results on GF-3 data and Sentinel-1 data show the efficiency of the proposed method in target detection with a heterogeneous clutter environment.

title: A 99.3% Efficient Five-Level ANPC Converter for High-Speed Aircraft Cabin Pressurization Systems
authors: Johan Dijkstra, Thiago Batista Soeiro
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Commercial aviation is a major contributor to global <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> emissions, highlighting the need for innovative solutions to reduce the environmental impact of air travel. The More Electric Aircraft (MEA) concept addresses this challenge by replacing conventional hydraulic and pneumatic systems with electrically powered alternatives, thereby improving overall efficiency. This article presents the design and implementation of a five-level interleaved Active Neutral Point Clamped (ANPC) converter as a case study for an aircraft pressurization system. The developed prototype achieves an efficiency of 99.3% at an output power of 20 kW. The results underscore the viability of multilevel converter topologies in MEA applications, supporting the transition toward greener aviation and compliance with future emissions regulations.

title: A Deep Learning Framework for Predicting Ultrasound Array Geometry and Skull Shape in Precision Ultrasound Neuromodulation
authors: Jongchan Pyeon, Rudra Biswas, Mehdi Kiani, Farnaz Tehranchi
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: Transcranial focused ultrasound stimulation (tFUS) is a promising noninvasive neuromodulation technique that enables targeted brain stimulation with higher precision than other noninvasive methods. However, unknown parameters such as the geometry of the ultrasound (US) phased array (i.e., positions of US elements) particularly in flexible US arrays and variations in skull shape complicate accurate focusing and targeting in US beamforming through electronics. This study presents a deep learning framework using simulated backscattered RF signals to estimate the US array geometry and skull shape. Validated on 5,700 RF simulations, the framework achieved 99.55% training accuracy and 96.84% validation accuracy for array geometry estimation, and Dice scores of 93.99% (training) and 91.15% (validation) for skull segmentation. Testing on unseen datasets demonstrated robust spatial precision, with a mean Euclidean distance of 1.85 mm and strong precision, recall, and F1 scores.

title: A Broadband Interference Suppression Method Based on Match Filtering for Lutan-1 Satellite SAR
authors: Xikai Fu, Huiming Chai, Tingting Jin, Xiaolei Lv
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Low-frequency SAR satellites(e.g. Lutan-1) are inevitably interfered by the radio frequency signals of ground equipment in the same frequency band, resulting in image quality degradation and phase accuracy loss, which affects subsequent quantitative applications. In this paper, a linear frequency modulation broadband interference suppression method based on matched filtering is proposed to address the problem of radio frequency interference, especially broadband interference. This method firstly performs time-frequency analysis on the SAR echo signal, uses Lv’s Distribution to detect and estimate the center frequency and modulation rate of the linear frequency modulation broadband interference signal, then performs pulse compression on the echo signal, converts the broadband interference signal into a narrowband impulse response, uses frequency domain notching to remove broadband interference, and finally performs reverse matched filtering on the signal to obtain the interference suppressed signal. Interference suppression experiments were carried out using the data from the Lutan-1 SAR satellite, which can effectively remove the influence of the linear frequency modulation interference signal, proving the effectiveness of this method.

title: A Deep Ensemble Physics-Informed Koopman Operator for Fault-Tolerant Induction Motor Control
authors: Philip Desenfans, Zifeng Gong, Dries Vanoost, Konstantinos Gryllias, Jeroen Boydens, Davy Pissoort
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Data-driven approaches to the identification and control of induction motors offer solutions to longstanding challenges such as parameter estimation and fault modeling. Recent studies have demonstrated that Koopman operator theory enables the construction of machine-learned global linearizations of electrical machines, thereby enhancing the applicability of linear control techniques to inherently nonlinear drive systems. In this work, an ensemble of deep Koopman models is proposed to reinforce the theoretical foundation of Koopman-based control for induction motors powered by voltage source inverters. The methodology is validated through simulation, with a focus on the selection of measurable state variables and the incorporation of stator flux linkage physics. When trained on sequences of three control vectors, the models achieve accurate predictions of stator current and flux linkage for sequences extending up to 40 control vectors, equivalent to 1 ms into the future. Detailed descriptions and evaluations of torque and stator flux linkage control are provided, yielding mean tracking errors of 1.2% for torque and 0.07% for flux linkage relative to nominal values. The simulation results support the potential of Koopman theory as a robust framework for induction motor linearization, combining the predictive accuracy of deep learning with the stability and interpretability of linear control methods. Finally, while the findings are encouraging, they underscore the critical importance of minimizing controller latency.

title: Height-Adaptive Multi-UAV Collaborative 3D Detection: A Novel Approach
authors: Liangjin Zhao, Zhechao Wang, Ziyang Yuan, Yundu Li, Xiaodian Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) as an emerging way of remote sensing, have gained significant popularity in recent years. Collaboration between drones further enhances the robustness of perception systems. However, existing multi-drone datasets assume fixed swarm formations and constant altitudes, limiting the ability to monitor targets at varying distances. To address this, we introduce the Multi-Altitude Collaborative Perception Dataset (MACP), which facilitates research on high-andlow altitude collaboration by incorporating UAVs at different altitudes. The MACP dataset, generated using the CARLA simulator, includes 24,000 images captured by five drones at altitudes of 30m, 50m, and 70m, observing dynamic targets such as vehicles and pedestrians. Along with the dataset, we propose a novel model that incorporates normalized depth estimation to improve depth accuracy across varying altitudes, leveraging ground priors. Additionally, we introduce a Homologous Point Geometric Consistency Loss (HPGCL) to ensure geometric consistency between homologous points across different views, enhancing 3D object detection. Experimental results on the MACP dataset show that our model outperforms state-of-the-art methods such as BEVDet and BEVStereo in terms of mean Average Precision (mAP) and mean Average Translation Error (mATE). Ablation studies demonstrate that the Perspective Transformation Module (PTM) and HPGCL can significantly improve detection accuracy. This work not only advances multi-UAV collaborative perception but also provides a valuable dataset and baseline model for future research in UAV swarm applications, including surveillance, search and rescue, and environmental monitoring.

title: Exemplar-Free Lifelong Hyperspectral Classification with Spectral-Spatial Prototype Alignment
authors: Zhenlin Li, Shaobo Xia, Jun Yue, Leyuan Fang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Deep learning-based hyperspectral image (HSI) classification models often suffer from catastrophic forgetting when sequentially learning new tasks. Existing lifelong learning methods for HSI classification mostly rely on exemplar replay strategies, which are constrained by data storage and privacy concerns. We propose a novel prototype-based, exemplar-free lifelong learning method that incorporates both a prototype distillation learning (PDL) module and a spectral-spatial prototype alignment (SSPA) network. The PDL module integrates training samples from the new task with prototypes from previous tasks to train the classification model, which is then used to learn a prototype for each new class. The SSPA network compensates for prototype drift in the spectral-spatial feature space by mapping the prototypes from the previous tasks to new spectral-spatial feature spaces. Experimental results demonstrate that our method significantly outperforms other compared methods in mitigating catastrophic forgetting while preserving the ability to learn new tasks.

title: Cross-Scale Water Body Extraction from Very-High-Resolution Remote Sensing Images Based on Segment Anything Model 2
authors: Tianyi Zhang, Yi Ren, Weibin Li, Xuan Sun, Xihui Feng, Chenhao Qin, Wenbo Ji
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Deep learning algorithms are becoming increasingly important for water body extraction from very-high-resolution (VHR) remote sensing images. However, existing deep learning models require a large amount of high-quality labeled data. Therefore, how to effectively use existing low-resolution (LR) images and labels to guide water body segmentation in VHR images is a challenge. This study proposes a new method that fine-tunes the Segment Anything Model 2 (SAM2) using positive and negative point prompts for cross-scale water body segmentation. It uses LR images and labels at 10 m resolution to guide segmentation of VHR images at 0.3 m resolution. The proposed method achieves Dice and MIOU values of 0.932 and 0.906 for water body extraction on VHR images, outperforming comparison algorithms with the best performance. This research provides technical support for further cross-scale water extraction studies.

title: Dynamic Model of Series Resonant Converter Feeding Constant Power Loads
authors: Arnab Dey, Utsab Kundu, Vinod John
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The Series Resonant Converter (SRC) is widely used in resonant power conversion applications due to its high efficiency and soft-switching characteristics. In cascaded architectures, downstream converters often act as Constant Power Loads (CPLs), introducing unique challenges that are not adequately captured by traditional dynamic models. While the behavior of SRCs with resistive loads is well understood, modeling SRCs under CPL conditions remains relatively unexplored. This paper presents a unified modeling framework for the SRC-CPL system using the Dynamic Phasor (DP) method. A large-signal model is first developed to capture the system's nonlinear transient and steady-state behavior. Subsequently, small-signal linearization is applied to derive analytical expressions for key transfer functions: control-to-output, audio susceptibility, and output impedance. Conditions for reducing these to canonical forms are provided. The proposed models are validated through circuit simulations and experimental measurements involving a practical, finitebandwidth CPL operating under above-resonance conditions. The results confirm the accuracy of the models and highlight the impact of CPL dynamics on transient performance, offering critical insights for the design and control of resonant converters feeding constant power loads.

title: MSDGNet: A Point-based Weakly Supervised Semantic Segmentation Model
authors: Yuanhao Zhao, Genyun Sun, Aizhu Zhang, Jinchang Ren
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Semantic segmentation of remote sensing images is essential for applications in environmental monitoring, urban planning, and land cover classification. However, creating large-scale pixel-level annotations for these images is both labor-intensive and costly, which posing a significant challenge for developing high-accuracy segmentation models. In this paper, we propose a novel architecture, Multi-Scale Spectral-Detail-Global Network (MSDGNet), which leverages point-level annotations to minimize annotation requirements while preserving segmentation accuracy. MSDGNet comprises three primary modules: the Spectral-Detail-Global (SDG) encoder, the Multi-Scale Attention Feature Fusion (MSAFF) module, and a simple decoder. The SDG encoder captures comprehensive features by focusing on spectral, detail, and global contextual information, enhancing the model’s ability to distinguish complex land cover types and resist noise. The MSAFF module applies a multi-scale attention mechanism to dynamically weight key features across scales, refining the segmentation performance with limited annotation. Experimental results on the ISPRS Vaihingen and Zurich Summer datasets validate the effectiveness of MSDGNet, showing it outperforms other state-of-the-art models in overall accuracy (OA) and mean intersection over union (mIoU). This model offers a practical solution for large-scale remote sensing applications where minimizing annotation costs is essential.

title: Prototype Metric Decision for Few-shot Object Detection in Optical Remote Sensing Imagery
authors: Tong Zhang, Yin Zhuang, Guanqun Wang, Wei Zhang, Ye Zhu, He Chen, Lianlin Li
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Few-shot object detection (FSOD) aims to detect unseen objects only relying on few training samples, but low-resource images are hard to provide robust representation for unknown testing scene. There currently exist some works focusing on applying prototype learning to tackle with this challenging task. Nevertheless, prototype learning was always incorporated in FSOD by simple feature weighting during feature extraction, which hampers to fully leverage the categorical discrimination capability of prototype learning. To address this problem, a prototype-learning-based similarity metric decision is applied for FSOD in a single end-to-end training process, namely, Proto-RCNN. Firstly, these object patches from support images are employed for calculating the class prototypes to avoid the inference of complex background. Secondly, the similarity distances between features of potential proposals and the class prototypes are measured for judging the foreground classes. Without any bells and whistles, it has been proven to be very effective by conducting comparison experiments with advanced FSOD detectors.

title: Frequency Domain Mask Guided Diffusion Model for Hyperspectral Anomaly Detection
authors: Guorong Zhang, Tao Sun, Jie Yin, Shaoquan Zhang, Yuhao Wu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Hyperspectral anomaly detection (HAD) identifies targets with unique spectral characteristics without prior knowledge. In recent years, deep learning-driven HAD methods have pushed the boundaries of innovation, yet these models often falter in accurately modeling the background in complex scenes with noise interference, leading to a challenging conflation of anomalies with the background. Moreover, a significant proportion of deep detection models are finely tuned for specific background contexts, thereby exhibiting a constrained ability to generalize in real-world scenarios. To address these challenges, this study proposes a frequency domain mask-guided diffusion model (FMDiff). By analyzing amplitude spectrum disparities between anomalies and backgrounds, FMDiff constructs a frequency mask that weights background regions (with values close to 1) and suppresses anomalies (with values close to 0). This mask directs a dual-phase diffusion process: in the forward diffusion, it imposes noise selectively on background pixels; in the reverse phase, serving as a condition for the denoising network to effectively estimate and remove background noise. Experimental results illustrate that FMDiff achieves superior performance and is highly competitive with other sophisticated state-of-the-art methods.

title: Tailoring Injection Molding Parameters to Recycling History: A Full-Factorial Analysis of Property Optimization in Recycled Polypropylene
authors: Daniel Stehle, David Exposito Gallardo, Maximilian Kromen, Tobias Renkert
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society Conference - Global (TEMSCON Global)
abstract: This study presents a systematic investigation into the effects of injection molding parameters and multiple recycling cycles on the mechanical performance of polypropylene (PP), with particular relevance to automotive applications. A full-factorial experimental design <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(3 \times 3 \times 4)$</tex> was applied, varying screw temperature <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(220^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, 240^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, 260^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)$</tex>, cooling rate (slow, medium, fast), and recycling state <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(0 \times, 7 \times, 14 \times, 21 \times)$</tex>. Tensile strength, elongation at break, and notched impact strength were evaluated using ISO 527-1 and ISO 179-1 standards. Statistical significance of main and interaction effects was assessed via ANOVA at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\alpha=0.05$</tex>. The results show that mechanical recycling significantly reduces tensile strength and elongation at break. Increasing screw temperature from 220 °C to 260 °C decreased elongation at break by 14% on average and notched impact strength by 15%. Cooling rate had a significant influence on elongation at break, with medium cooling consistently yielding higher values across all recycling states. Three statistically significant two-factor interactions were identified, including a notable screw temperature-recycling interaction on tensile strength, a screw temperature-cooling rate interaction on elongation at break and a screw temperature-recycling cycles interaction on notched impact strength. These findings support process optimization strategies that maintain mechanical integrity in recycled PP while balancing economic and ecological efficiency. These insights enable process engineers and decisionmakers to align manufacturing strategies with sustainability regulations and cost-efficiency targets

title: High Step-Down Series-Capacitor Quadratic-Buck Converter
authors: Guanlin Li, Fangyuan Xiong, Wenkang Huang, Mahshid Amirabadi, Xianmin Mu, Brad Lehman
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper proposes a new high step-down quadratic converter combining a buck stage and a seriescapacitor buck stage. The proposed converter achieves a high step-down conversion ratio with extended duty cycles, reduced sensitivity to small duty-cycle variations, and lower switch voltage stress. The steady-state characteristics, including average inductor currents, normalized voltage stresses, and the effect of the number of the series-capacitor cells are analyzed. Experimental results demonstrate a peak efficiency of 91.9% when converting 48V to 1V, with a full-load efficiency of 86.5% at 100-W output power. The proposed design addresses key limitations of traditional buck converters and traditional quadratic converters in low-output, high-step-down applications.

title: Spatiotemporal Air Quality Mapping in Urban Areas Using Sparse Sensor Data, Satellite Imagery, Meteorological Factors, and Spatial Features
authors: Osama Ahmad, Zubair Khalid, Muhammad Tahir, Momin Uppal
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Monitoring air pollution is crucial for protecting human health from exposure to harmful substances. Traditional methods of air quality monitoring, such as ground-based sensors and satellite-based remote sensing, face limitations due to high deployment costs, sparse sensor coverage, and environmental interferences. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a framework for high-resolution spatiotemporal Air Quality Index (AQI) mapping using sparse sensor data, satellite imagery, and various spatiotemporal factors. By leveraging Graph Neural Networks (GNNs), we estimate AQI values at unmonitored locations based on both spatial and temporal dependencies. The framework incorporates a wide range of environmental features, including meteorological data, road networks, points of interest (PoIs), population density, and urban green spaces, which enhance prediction accuracy. We illustrate the use of our approach through a case study in Lahore, Pakistan, where multi-resolution data is used to generate the air quality index map at a fine spatiotemporal scale.

title: Using Upwelling At-Sensor Irradiance to Account for the Atmospheric Effects on SIF Quantification from High-Resolution Airborne Hyperspectral Imagery
authors: N. Wang, A. Belwalkar, T. Poblete, R. Wang, P.J. Zarco-Tejada
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Sun-induced chlorophyll fluorescence (SIF) is considered a probe of plant photosynthetic activity. Most radiance-based SIF retrieval strategies leverage the oxygen absorption features from different sensor spectral configurations on board various platforms. Atmospheric effects at high altitudes largely influence these oxygen features, necessitating careful atmospheric correction. Existing atmospheric correction methods relying on radiative transfer models (RTM) are mostly applied to upwelling radiance. However, very small pixels/footprints over heterogeneous canopies can violate their assumptions, such as a fully illuminated, homogeneous, and Lambertian surface. Furthermore, upwelling radiance simulation at both canopy and sensor levels is challenging, primarily due to the low reflectance of vegetation in the red spectral region, hindering the accurate retrieval of surface reflectance and SIF. This work proposes using upwelling irradiance at the sensor level to mitigate atmospheric effects in SIF quantification. Upwelling irradiance refers to the downwelling irradiance that reaches a surface with uniform diffuse reflectance and then travels directly upward to the sensor. We hypothesize that upwelling irradiance and radiance (including SIF) experience similar atmospheric influences, enabling effective mitigation of atmospheric effects on SIF retrieval. Upwelling at-sensor irradiance was derived through two methodologies: (1) MODTRAN RTM (E<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sens</inf>) and (2) a ground Lambertian reference target (E<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sens-tar</inf>). E<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sens-tar</inf> was calculated using the upwelling at-sensor radiance over the ground target surface (L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sens-tar</inf>) divided by the target reflectance. E<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sens-tar</inf> was proved to be a specific case of E<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sens</inf>. Our synthetic data results revealed weak correlation between SIF from the top of canopy (TOC) downwelling irradiance (E<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">TOC</inf>) and upwelling at-sensor radiance (L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sens</inf>) at 1000 m and 2000 m and TOC SIF (SIF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">TOC</inf>) from E<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">TOC</inf> and TOC radiance (L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">TOC</inf>), with R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> values of 0.21 and 0.50 and RMSEs of 5.17 and 9.25 mW m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-2</sup>nm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-1</sup>sr<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-1</sup>, respectively. Conversely, SIF extracted from L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sens</inf> using both E<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sens</inf> and E<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sens-tar</inf> showed strong linear correlations with SIF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">TOC</inf>, attaining R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> values of 0.99 for the E<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sens</inf> approach and 1 for the E<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sens</inf> method at both altitudes, accompanied by substantially reduced RMSEs (< 0.30 mWm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>nm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-1</sup>sr<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-1</sup> at 1000m and < 0.65 mWm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-2</sup>nm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-1</sup>sr<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-1</sup> at 2000m). Airborne data further confirmed high agreement in both red and far-red SIF between E<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sens</inf> and E<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sens-tar</inf> approaches. This method illustrates great potential for accurate SIF retrievals from various platforms, including high-altitude tower-based, UAV-based and airborne systems.

title: Efficient Diffusion Model for SAR-Assisted Optical Remote Sensing Image Cloud Removal
authors: Jiangong Xu, Xiaoyu Yu, Jun Pan
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Reconstructing missing information in cloud-contaminated optical satellite images is essential for continuous Earth monitoring. Since synthetic aperture radar (SAR) images are unaffected by severe weather, SAR-optical fusion has become a common approach for cloud removal. However, existing methods often struggle to recover high-frequency information. To address this limitation, we propose a novel framework, SARDiff_CR, which integrates diffusion models into a wavelet-based cross-domain fusion Transformer. By utilizing diffusion models in a compact latent space, SARDiff_CR generates high-frequency prior features that align with the ground truth distribution. Experimental results on the globally and seasonally diverse SEN12MS-CR dataset demonstrate that SARDiff_CR significantly outperforms most existing SAR-assisted cloud removal methods.

title: TERRAQ: Spatiotemporal Question-Answering on Satellite Image Archives
authors: Sergios-Anestis Kefalidis, Konstantinos Plas, Manolis Koubarakis
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: TerraQ is a spatiotemporal question-answering engine for satellite image archives. It is a natural language processing system that is built to process requests for satellite images satisfying certain criteria. The requests can refer to image metadata and entities from a specialized knowledge base (e.g., the Emilia-Romagna region). With it, users can make requests like "Give me a hundred images of rivers near ports in France, with less than 20% snow coverage and more than 10% cloud coverage", thus making Earth Observation data more easily accessible, in-line with the current landscape of digital assistants.

title: Deep Learning-Based Individual Tree Segmentation Based on Airborne Lidar and Very High-Resolution Aerial Images
authors: Yingtan Li, Zhanmang Liao, Jie Wang, Yiru zhang, Jialin Hou, Lei Wu, Rui Chen
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Individual tree segmentation using very high-resolution (VHR) remote sensing images can provide an unprecedentedly fine insight into forest status and changes at a large scale, attracting increasing attention in recent years. Methods such as deep learning and computer vision have been widely adopted to enhance the accuracy and efficiency of individual tree crown detection. However, deep learning algorithms require a large number of samples which are time-consuming to obtain by manual selection. Therefore, we aim to use airborne Lidar-based single-tree segmentation to quickly obtain enough training samples, which will then be used as references for the following Deep learning-based individual tree segmentation from VHR aerial images (National Agricultural Imagery Program, NAIP, data, 0.6 m). Meanwhile, a noise filter process was proposed to improve single tree segmentation from LiDAR cloud point data, and the Deep learning algorithm of YOLOv11 instance segmentation model was adopted. Results show that LiDAR-derived single tree segmentation has a relatively high accuracy (F 0.87) and can quickly generate enough training samples. By visual comparison, the canopy edge of LiDAR-derived single trees well matches with the VHR images, except for some areas with a large visual angle in VHR images. As a result, VHR segmentation results show a high precision, with mAP@50 of 0.836. Besides, we found that the deep-learning method is sensitive to the accuracy of reference samples from LiDAR. In conclusion, the proposed process in this study demonstrated the feasibility of integrating LiDAR and VHR images for a rapid and reliable individual tree segmentation, which is practicable for large-scale applications in the future.

title: Test Methodology for Inverters with Parallel Connected IGBTs in Asymmetrical Configuration
authors: Danielle Jaye S. Agron, Patrick Palmer
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper presents a test methodology for high power inverters with three parallel connected insulated gate bipolar transistors (IGBTs) on each leg. This study emphasizes the inference created during the static on-current due to the imposed current generated by the switching other leg of an inverter. This characteristic is additional crucial consideration in the formation of current imbalance among the parallel connected devices but haven't been characterized in the past. This paper discusses the phenomena of imposed currents with mathematical formulas and validated using simulation. The results are further justified by performing an experiment with 300A IGBT modules connected in parallel with laminar 'style' bus bar at the AC output.

title: Special Session Paper: Simulation Methodologies and Experiments for Reliability Analysis of Devices in Radiation Harsh Environments
authors: Nikoloas Chatzivangelis, Nikoloas Zazatis, Wesley Grignani, Georgios-Ioannis Paliaroutis, Douglas A. Santos, Carolina Imianosky, Maria Kastriotou, Carlo Cazzaniga, Frédéric Wrobel, Alessandro Veronesi, Christos Sotiriou, Marko Andjelkovic, Fabian L. Vargas, Davide Bertozzi, Luigi Dilillo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Defect and Fault Tolerance in VLSI and Nanotechnology Systems (DFT)
abstract: As digital systems become increasingly integrated into radiation-prone environments, such as aerospace, automotive, and edge computing platforms, their ability to operate reliably under radiation-induced faults is essential. These faults, ranging from transient disruptions to permanent errors, can affect various system layers. In this work, we present an investigation into such challenges, combining simulation-based fault analysis with experimental validation. We introduce a novel methodology for modeling Single Event Transients (SETs) in clock distribution networks, enabling precise evaluation of Flip-Flop (FF) sensitivity. Additionally, a cross-layer framework is introduced to analyze how low-level hardware faults affect inference behavior in Dynamic Neural Networks (DyNNs), highlighting the unique reliability challenges posed by adaptive neural architectures. Finally, we present neutron irradiation results from a soft-core fault-tolerant RISC-V SoC implemented on an SRAM-based FPGA, revealing the critical role of architectural mitigation strategies for Single-Event Upsets (SEUs) and preserving system functionality.

title: A Radar Data Based Strategy for the Estimation of the Frequency Sweep Rate of Airborne FMCW SAR Systems
authors: Carmen Esposito, Paolo Berardino, Antonio Natale, Jorge Andrés Rosero Legarda, Stefano Perna
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In this work, we present a new approach for estimating the Frequency Sweep Rate (FSR) value of an airborne Frequency Modulated Continuous Wave (FMCW) Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) system.The proposed method is based on the use of acquired radar data and extends the recently developed the FSR Estimate Through Corner reflectors (FSRETC) algorithm, which requires the availability of one SAR acquisition and at least two Corner Reflectors (CRs) located on the illuminated scene at different range distances from the sensor. The proposed approach instead exploits only one CR and at least two non-coincident parallel SAR acquisitions. It is thus very useful in application scenarios, such as the emergency ones, where the proper deployment of different CRs on the scene to be illuminated, along with the corresponding measurement of their positions, can be difficult. The algorithm is very easy to implement and it has been tested on real airborne SAR dataset acquired at X-Band by the Italian Multiband Interferometric and Polarimetric SAR (MIPS) system. Comparison with the results achievable with the FSRETC algorithm are also provided.

title: Unsupervised Hyperspectral Image Super-resolution via Learning Kernel distributions in Alternating Framework
authors: Lingyu Zheng, Zhixiong Yang, Jingyuan Xia
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Hyperspectral image (HSI) super-resolution (SR) seeks to transcend the constraints of imaging system hardware to improve the spatial resolution of hyperspectral images, thereby procuring more comprehensive and precise information regarding the Earth’s surface. Current deep learning-based super-resolution approaches encounter challenges, including an insufficient number of training samples, limited generalization capabilities, and overly simplistic degradation assumptions. To address these challenges, this paper proposes an unsupervised hyperspectral image super-resolution method, incorporating a blurring kernel estimation based on Gaussian distribution learning. Specifically, An alternating optimization framework for blind HSI SR modeling is proposed, wherein the blurs are approximated using a learning-based approach that leverages randomly generated weighted Gaussian blurs. The HSI images are then estimated using a deep image prior (DIP) network. The proposed method demonstrates a plug-and-play mechanism that addresses HSI SR tasks through the optimization of the DIP network during the process of evaluating solution alternatives, thereby obviating the need for traditional training and reducing data dependency. Extensive simulation results reveal that our proposed method outperforms existing state-of-the-art techniques in HSI SR tasks, demonstrating enhanced results in most datasets and excellent generalization capabilities across diverse degradation scenarios.

title: Flight Verification of the L-Band Scatterometer for the Chinese Ocean Salinity Mission
authors: Zihao Chen, Wenming Lin, Xiaoheng Mou
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The Chinese first Ocean salinity satellite was successfully launched in November 2024 and is undergoing in-orbit testing. Before the launch mission, in order to verify the performance of the payloads and examine the data processing algorithms, various institutions jointly carried out an airborne test. This paper describes the test overview, data preprocessing methodologies and results of the L-band scatterometer with a phased-array push-broom type used in this test. Despite challenges such as low wind speed measurements and aircraft attitude variations, the backscattering coefficients obtained from this test exhibit good consistency with those calculated using the L-band Geophysical Model Function (GMF), which verifies the feasibility of the scatterometer and the effectiveness of the current data preprocessing methods, laying a foundation for the in-orbit testing of the spaceborne equipment.

title: ProMSC-MIS: Prompt-Based Multimodal Semantic Communication for Multi-Spectral Image Segmentation
authors: Haoshuo Zhang, Yufei Bo, Meixia Tao
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: Multimodal semantic communication has great potential to enhance downstream task performance by integrating complementary information across modalities. This paper introduces ProMSC-MIS, a novel Prompt-based Multimodal Semantic Communication framework for Multi-Spectral Image Segmentation. It enables efficient task-oriented transmission of spatially aligned RGB and thermal images over band-limited channels. Our framework has two main design novelties. First, by leveraging prompt learning and contrastive learning, unimodal semantic encoders are pre-trained to learn diverse and complementary semantic representations, where each modality serves as a cross-modal prompt for the other. Second, a semantic fusion module that combines cross-attention mechanism and squeeze-and-excitation (SE) networks is designed to effectively fuse cross-modal features. Experimental results demonstrate that ProMSC-MIS substantially outperforms conventional image transmission combined with state-of-the-art segmentation methods. Notably, it reduces the required communication cost by 50%–70% at the same segmentation performance, while also decreasing the storage overhead and computational complexity by 26% and 37%, respectively. Ablation studies also validate the effectiveness of the proposed pre-training and semantic fusion strategies. Our scheme is highly suitable for applications such as autonomous driving and nighttime surveillance.

title: &#x00B7;Embedding Porous Structure Electrodes into T-Shirt for ECG Monitoring: Combining Low Impedance and High SNR for Optimized Comfortability and Performance_supp1-3634355.pdf
authors: Jun Xu
abstract: This study proposes a customized design T-shirt embedded with a porous structured dry electrode for ECG monitoring. The porous electrodes are based on graphene nanoplatelets (GNP-3A) and polyamide 66 (PA66) materials. First, through electrical performance testing, it is demonstrated that the proposed dry electrode has high conductivity, with a skin contact impedance of 17.6 kΩ at 100Hz, significantly lower than commercial Ag/AgCl wet electrodes. In addition, the electrode can accurately capture ECG signals with a high signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of 34.76 dB, which is an 8% improvement over traditional Ag/AgCl wet electrodes. Additionally, the design optimizes wearability by using soft and highly elastic fabric and integrates electrodes using metal snap buttons to reduce the discomfort typically caused by traditional wet electrodes, thereby enhancing comfort during prolonged use. Subsequently, to evaluate the performance improvements of the smart ECG T-shirt in terms of comfort and signal acquisition, a self-constructed ECG monitoring system was used to record single-lead ECG signals from adult males wearing the smart ECG T-shirt, under different motion states such as resting, walking, and jogging. The P-Q-R-S-T characteristic peaks, motion artifacts, and noise were assessed and compared with commercially available ECG monitoring T-shirts. The comparison results indicate that the integrated design of the electrode and T-shirt effectively balances comfort and performance in practical applications, with no skin irritation or discomfort observed during prolonged use. This work offers an innovative and practical solution for daily, comprehensive, wearable, and scalable ECG monitoring, showing great promise for future applications.

title:
Anchoring MoO
                    <sub>3</sub>
                    on magnetic nickel ferrite: A sustainable green nanocatalyst in conjunction with UV light irradiation toward efficient degradation of Penicillin G in water environments
authors: E. Derakhshani, A. Naghizadeh
abstract: Photocatalytic decomposition has attracted much attention due to its great potential in removing antibiotics from aqueous solutions. The aim of this study is to evaluate photocatalytic degradation for the destruction of the antibiotic penicillin G, which is widely used in human and veterinary medicine, in aqueous solutions. This study utilized a NiFe2O4@MoO3 nanocomposite, synthesized via a green method using Pulicaria Gnaphalodes extract, for the photocatalytic degradation of penicillin G in aqueous solutions. Analysis of XRD, FT-IR, FESEM, VSM, DLS, and EDX-mapping confirmed successful synthesis of the nanocomposite with a size below 100 nm. Various parameters such as pH, catalyst dosage, penicillin G concentration, and contact time were optimized to enhance the efficiency of the NiFe<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>O<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sub>@MoO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub> nanocomposite in removing penicillin G. About 68% of penicillin G was decomposed under optimal conditions (pH = 9, nanocomposite dose: 0.8 g/L and penicillin G concentration: 10 mg/L). The results suggest that the photocatalytic process using the NiFe<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>O<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sub>@MoO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub> nanocomposite is a promising method for the removal of penicillin G antibiotics from water.

title: Terahertz Wireless Data Center: Gaussian Beam or Airy Beam?
authors: Wenqi Zhao, Sergi Abadal, Guochao Song, Jiamo Jiang, Chong Han
abstract: Terahertz (THz) communication is emerging as a pivotal enabler for 6G and beyond wireless systems owing to its multi-GHz bandwidth. One of its novel applications is in wireless data centers, where it enables ultra-high data rates while enhancing network reconfigurability and scalability. However, due to numerous racks, supporting walls, and densely deployed antennas, the line-of-sight (LoS) path in data centers is often instead of fully obstructed, resulting in quasi-LoS propagation and degradation of spectral efficiency. To address this issue, Airy beam-based hybrid beamforming is investigated in this paper as a promising technique to mitigate quasi-LoS propagation and enhance spectral efficiency in THz wireless data centers. Specifically, a cascaded geometrical and wave channel model (CGWCM) is proposed for quasi-LoS scenarios, which accounts for diffraction effects while being more simplified than conventional wave-based model. Then, the characteristics and generation of the Airy beam are analyzed, and beam search methods for quasi-LoS scenarios are proposed, including hierarchical focusing-Airy beam search, and low-complexity beam search. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the CGWCM and demonstrate the superiority of the Airy beam over Gaussian beams in mitigating blockages, verifying its potential for practical THz wireless communication in data centers.

title: Enhanced power allocation strategy of hybrid energy storage system for MEA
authors: Shuhao DENG, Renhao Chang, Ming HUANG, Tao LEI, Weilin LI, Xiaobin ZHANG
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: The aviation hybrid energy storage system (HESS) has emerged as one of the pivotal technologies driving the revolution in green aviation and low-carbon transportation technologies, owing to its superior energy density and rapid power response capability. However, conventional control methods face difficulties in fully optimizing the compensation performance of energy storage systems while ensuring system stability. To address this challenge, this paper proposes an improved adaptive control method. By integrating a voltage outer-loop adaptive algorithm with second-order frequency division technology, the proposed approach effectively suppresses DC bus voltage fluctuations and achieves notable capacity savings in HESS under identical compensation conditions. Bode diagram analysis demonstrates that the improved adaptive algorithm exhibits higher phase margins compared to conventional control methods, thereby significantly enhancing system stability. Furthermore, based on simulation results, this study establishes a control-in-the-loop experimental validation platform. The experimental results confirm that the proposed control method delivers substantial improvements in both HESS capacity configuration and system stability, verifying its effectiveness in practical applications.

title: Post-Quantum Authentication and Communication Security for Drone Networks
authors: Parya Derakhshan Roodsari, Siavash Bayat Sarmadi, Hatame Mosanaei Boorani
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Modern societies increasingly rely on interconnected devices and individuals for information exchange and monitoring. In this manner, drones, as flying smart nodes in the wireless network ecosystem, facilitate diverse applications, such as industrial, civilian, and disaster response operations. However, the widespread adoption of drone networks introduces significant challenges regarding interoperability, privacy, and security. Advances in quantum computing exacerbate these issues by rendering classical cryptographic measures inadequate, necessitating the adoption of quantum-safe approaches. Existing solutions fail to address all potential threats or lack post-quantum security. This work sets out to propose a robust lattice-based authentication and communication protocol for drone networks, addressing these challenges. The protocol integrates dynamic credentials, timestamps, multi-factor authentication, and context information to enhance security. The scheme's security is analyzed using the DY and BPR models and formally verified via the AVISPA tool. Performance evaluations and comparisons with existing solutions demonstrate the protocol's functionality, showcasing a reasonable trade-off between security and performance.
