authors: Jin Xu, Yuanchao Su, Lianru Gao, Xu Sun, Mengying Jiang, Sheng Li
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Hyperspectral image super-resolution (HSI-SR) techniques can improve the spatial resolution of hyperspectral images (HSIs). Some of the existing HSI-SR methods are realized by fusing high-resolution multispectral images (Hr-MSI) with low-resolution hyperspectral images (Lr-HSI). Most of these methods use Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) to extract image features. CNNs have a strong feature acquisition capability, but their receptive field limits their ability to acquire long-range relationships between different pixels. Therefore we propose a graph-based network (GNet) for HSI-SR. This method first acquires the primary features of different images, and then constructs the connections between nodes from the acquired spectral features of Lr-HSI and transfers them to the feature graph of Hr-MSI. We use GNet to obtain long-distance relationships between pixels and to facilitate information flow in multi-stream networks. The performance and competitive advantages of GNet are evaluated by comparing it with several state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods.

title: Unlocking Free-Position Electric Vehicle Charging: A Neural Network-Driven Approach for Optimisation of Multi-coil Wireless Power Transfer Systems
authors: Hannah Merrigan, Yu Hsin Wu, Antoine Lesage-Landry, Koichi Shigematsu, Masayoshi Yamamoto, Jun Imaoka
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Wireless power transfer offers a convenient solution for public electric vehicle charging by eliminating physical connectors, enabling seamless operation. However, traditional single-coil inductive power transfer systems suffer from sensitivity to misalignment, reducing power transfer efficiency (PTE) and limiting real-world viability. This study proposes a multi-coil transmitter design to enable free-position parking, improving adaptability to vehicle misalignment and receiver variations. A blackbox optimisation framework is implemented, leveraging a neural network-based surrogate model trained on simulation data, achieving a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$9000 \times$</tex> speedup while maintaining prediction errors below 2.5 %. A scenario-based stochastic optimisation formulation solved via the meshadaptive direct search algorithm ensures adaptability across real-world receiver conditions. The optimised four-coil design achieves an average PTE of 86.93 % while minimising material costs, balancing efficiency and affordability. These findings confirm the feasibility of a scalable, user-friendly universal wireless charging system for commercial parking environments.

title: YOLO V8-Based Autonomous Surface Vessel for Real-Time Oil Spill and Waste Removal in Waterways
authors: Mario Leo Nardo, Soraya Norma Mustika, Ir.Arya Kusumawardana, Achmad Hamdan, Viola Malta Ramadhani, Wan Jen Huang
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: Handling and detecting oil spills is a crucial issue that requires innovative technological solutions and efficient approaches. This research proposes the utilization of Autonomous Surface Vehicles (ASV) equipped with YOLO (You Only Look Once) algorithms to identify and address oil spills through an integrated vacuum system. The primary objective of this study is to design a detection system that is fast and accurate, allowing for immediate cleanup response once an oil spill is detected. With the implementation of an integrated vacuum system, ASV can sort the oil spills present in the water environment to minimize ecosystem damage. The use of this robot demonstrates the importance of responses from the object detection system that has been implemented

title: Global Attention Fusion Model Based on Dual-Path Diffusion
authors: Hao Cai, Lu Wang, Min Ouyang, Zekun Long, Chunhui Zhao, P. Takis Mathiopoulos
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Heterogeneous image fusion integrates image data captured by different types of sensors, enabling joint processing to achieve richer and more reliable results. However, due to significant differences in imaging mechanisms, geometric properties, and radiometric characteristics, challenges remain in feature alignment and information integration. To address these issues, this paper proposes a dual-path diffusion-based global attention fusion model. The model trains two independent diffusion processes to extract deep features of heterogeneous images during the reverse diffusion stage, effectively preserving the color information of optical images and the stable thermal radiation characteristics of infrared images. To validate the effectiveness of the proposed model, extensive comparative experiments were conducted on the MSRS dataset. The results demonstrate that, compared to existing methods, the proposed model exhibits significant advantages in color fidelity, information retention, and overall performance.

title: One Polarimetric Mechanism-Guide Network for Polsar False Sea Scene Generation
authors: Tianyi Zhang, Jiyuan Liu, Feiming Wei, Jin Ma, Zhen Yang, Tao Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The synthesis of false Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) images, particularly for sea surface mixed scenes, has significant potential in modern military applications. For example, artificially synthesized false scenes can effectively disrupt enemy target recognition and tracking systems. In this paper, we propose a diffusion-based method for generating false PolSAR sea surface mixed scenes, synthesizing fused polarimetric scenes of specified ships and the sea while ensuring authenticity. It focuses solely on synthesizing the boundary region between the ship and the sea while preserving the main bodies of both the ship and the sea. So, the proposed method can effectively integrate the target with the background, resulting in high-fidelity images. Experimental results demonstrate that our method outperforms existing methods in terms of both authenticity and image quality removing clutter around ships. Compared to the baseline method, our method reduces FID by 23.3%, lowers LPIPS by 48.7%, and improves PSNR by 14.8%.

title: A Validation Method for Satellite Optical Imagery Reflectance Using Airborne Hyperspectral Data with BRDF Reconstruction
authors: Wen Jia, Yong Pang, Zengyuan Li
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Accurately validating satellite surface reflectance data in rugged forested areas is of crucial importance for applications such as forest resource assessment, ecological monitoring, and climate change research. However, these areas have inherent complexities, characterized by diverse terrains, solar-viewing geometries, and canopy structures. This introduces significant uncertainties and errors when validating satellite reflectance using ground/airborne-based data. This study focuses on validating optical satellite reflectance data by leveraging airborne hyperspectral reflectance data reconstructed through the Bidirectional Reflectance Distribution Function (BRDF) model. Pu'er City, Yunnan Province, China, was selected as the study area. Instead of directly validating the acquired airborne data against satellite data, the BRDF model was employed to reconstruct airborne reflectance data corresponding to the satellite imaging time. The results show that when validating near-infrared (NIR) reflectance data, direct validation using traditional airborne remote sensing data yielded a coefficient of determination (R) of 0.80, a root-mean-square error (RMSE) of 0.084, and a bias of-0.07. In contrast, the airborne reflectance data reconstructed by the BRDF according to the satellite imaging time improved these metrics. The R value reached 0.81, the RMSE was 0.035, and the bias was 0.0097. These results indicate that the BRDF-based method is more effective in validating satellite reflectance images in complex forest terrains. The findings provide valuable insights into the accuracy and reliability of satellite optical data, enhancing its applicability and understanding in challenging forest environments.

title: Triple Phase Shift Modulation Strategy Optimized Losses of Semiconductor Devices and Transformer for DAB Converters
authors: Kimihisa Furukawa, Yuichi Mabuchi, Takae Shimada, Hiroaki Miyata, Masaya Ichinose, Kazuki Gorai
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper proposes an improved modulation method of the Dual Active Bridge (DAB) DC/DC converter. The method is categorized as an optimized Triple Phase Shift (TPS) modulation. The TPS minimizes overall power loss of the DAB based on basic equations, which are newly derived to express loss of semiconductors and a high-frequency transformer as functions of switching phase angles. The derived equations are characterized by use of a floor function, and transformer currents and input/output direct currents can be represented universally regardless of switching angles conditions. Furthermore, as a result of this optimization, it was found that the DAB can be controlled very efficiently by dividing the operating region of output voltage and current into four modes, including both Zero Voltage Switching (ZVS) and Zero Current Switching (ZCS). The proposed method was applied to a 25 kW DAB converter, and its effectiveness was verified through both analysis and experimentation. The developed approach exhibited high efficiency, maintaining more than 98% across a wide operating range-output voltages from 300 V to 800 V and currents from 30 A to 60 A-and the peak efficiency was industry-leading value of 98.8%.

title: Small-Signal Analysis of Digitally Controlled DAB Converter Under Transient Dc-Bias Current Elimination Strategies
authors: Manex Aizpurua, Erik Garayalde, Giorgio Spiazzi
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: A discrete-time small-signal modelling strategy is developed for the dual active bridge converter operating under modulation strategies for transient dc-bias inductor current suppression. Most of these techniques consist on changing the phase-shift in a two-step manner, which is modelled by expanding the matrices that form the difference equation. The dynamics of two different current offset mitigation strategies are compared with the basic single-step single-side modulation. The obtained control-to- output voltage and input current transfer functions are validated in simulations, which demonstrate the model effectively accounts for the high frequency dynamics of the different modulation strategies. Finally, by integrating an averaging filter of the measured variables into the model, the additional delay caused by the two-step phase-shift transition is observed in the results, which causes a higher phase decay at high frequencies than in the case of the single-step modulation.

title: OptiSarFormer -Change Detection in Multi-Sensor Remote Sensing with Transformer-CNN Fusion
authors: Ankit Khivasara, Biplab Banerjee
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Satellites and aerial imaging technologies are essential for capturing pre-and post-change imagery to monitor urban transformations and natural events like floods. Although optical imagery provides clarity, its reliance on visibility makes it prone to cloud cover issues in post-change scenarios. To address this, we propose OptiSarFormer, a fusion model that combines pre-change optical images with pre-and post-change Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) imagery, which can penetrate clouds. OptiSarFormer integrates diverse modalities using a Siamese network architecture with hierarchical transformer encoders for efficient feature extraction. It features two shared encoder branches for SAR imagery and a third branch for independent optical image processing, aggregating all features, including SAR-based differentials, into a CNN-based decoder to produce a final change map. A simple adaptation to test time further enhances its versatility, and extensive testing of benchmark datasets confirms its effectiveness for complex change detection tasks.

title: Target Discrimination and Strong Clutter Suppression in Airborne Environment Using ST-PSLR Spectrum
authors: Hongyu Chen, Ding Wang, Shunsheng Zhang, Lei Wu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Airborne radar detection faces the challenge of ground clutter. Space-Time adaptive processing (STAP) technology realizes the effective suppression of strong clutter. However, most of the existing researches are based on target discrimination, which is difficult to implement in engineering. To address the issue, a approach of target discrimination and strong clutter suppression is proposed in this paper. This method involves compensating for clutter Doppler, target discrimination and clutter suppression. Firstly, for the non-stationary clutter, the algorithm of derivative based updating (DBU) is adopted to solve the non-stationary problem. Subsequently, a space-time peak to side-lobe ratio (ST-PSLR) spectrum is proposed to discriminate the target from the strong clutter. Finally, the clutter is suppressed through STAP algorithm utilizing the discrimination result of the target. The numerical simulation result verify the effectiveness of this methodology.

title: CoSGMN: Cooperative 3D Object Detection with Spatial Grouping Multiscale Fusion
authors: Jie Guo, Min Ouyang, Tong Wang, Lu Wang, Yajie Sun, Peng Xue
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Vehicle-To-Vehicle (V2V) and Vehicle-To-Everything (V2X) collaborative perception have become key methods to address the limitations of individual vehicle perception. This paper presents a novel multi-scale feature fusion framework for collaborative 3D object detection in connected vehicles. To reduce errors from spatial transformations, we propose a CoSGMN that aligns features across various granularity, enhancing fusion stability. Then, a Global Grouped Coordinate Attention (GGCA) mechanism is proposed to leverage global spatial information from multiple vehicles’ high-dimensional feature maps, improving spatial awareness. Finally, a Global Pooling Module (GPM) combines overlapping features from different vehicles to generate a consistent output map. Experimental results on the OPV2V dataset show that our method significantly outperforms existing collaborative 3D object detection approaches in terms of AP@0.5 and AP@0.7, providing a promising solution for collaborative autonomous driving.

title: A Study of the Effects of Grid Forming Converters on Stability of Wind Power Systems
authors: Lawrence Hiquiana, Jian Sun
publish: 2025 10th IEEE Workshop on the Electronic Grid (eGRID)
abstract: This paper studies the effects of GFM converters on different instability modes in a wind power system. Results show that GFM converters can enhance stability of type-IV turbines in weak grids, with the converters’ placement playing a consistent role in this benefit. On the other hand, the effects on SSR of type-III turbines in grids with series-compensated lines are dependent on electrical proximity to compensation capacitors. When the GFM converter was located at nodes directly connected to the series capacitor the system stability worsened, whereas other locations showed stability improvements. In all cases, the rating of the converter emphasized the converter’s effect.

title: Research on Wide-Range Charging Control Strategy for Bidirectional Charger Based on Dual Active Bridge Converter
authors: Zechun Dou, Liangui Wu, Shuai Zhou, Xiaoyong Zhang, Fengwu Zhou, Chenghong Liu
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The Dual-active-bridge bidirectional battery charger (DAB-BBC) is a critical device for railway trains to achieve emergency traction functionality. This paper initially derives the expression for the root mean square (RMS) value of the ripple current in the output filter capacitor of a DAB-BBC based on Single Phase Shift (SPS) control, theoretically uncovering the fundamental reason for the excessive ripple current in the capacitor when the battery voltage is low. Subsequently, to address the issue of excessive capacitor ripple current under SPS control, a Primary Side Phase Shift (PSPS) control strategy is proposed. The operational modes, power transfer model, and the expression for the RMS value of the capacitor ripple current under PSPS control are analyzed in detail. Then, to solve the problem of the inability to charge under high battery voltage with PSPS control, a wide-range charging control strategy that switches between PSPS and SPS is introduced. Finally, the correctness of the theoretical analysis is verified through simulations and experiments.

title: Preliminary LuTan-1 Time Series Interferometric Performance Evaluation
authors: Changyang Hu, Zhang Yunjun, Bryan Marfito, Yidi Wang, Robert Wang, Sang-Ho Yun, Weizhen Lin, Xiang Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: LuTan-1 is the first Chinese SAR mission dedicated for interferometry. Since the launch of early 2022, it has accumulated more than 3 years of L-band SAR data. In this work, we evaluate LuTan-1’s time series interferometric performance, including the interferometric coherence, and capability for measuring large-scale and transient deformation. We described some technical features required to process LuTan-1 InSAR time series based on the open-source ISCE-2 and MintPy softwares. We analyzed the interferometric coherence characteristics over different land cover types in China, Japan and Turkey and compared them with the L-band ALOS-2 and C-band Sentinel-1 data. We also evaluated LuTan-1’s performance in mapping coseismic deformation and demonstrated its capability for long-track imaging.

title: Individual Tree Detection using YOLOv8 and Transfer Learning via Drone Data
authors: Samet Aksoy, Esra Sengun, Elif Sertel, Basam Dahy, Johan E.S. Fransson
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Effective forest monitoring requires the accurate detection of trees, but traditional methods usually fail due to cost, scale, and precision limitations. This study applies transfer learning using the state-of-the-art YOLOv8 model to improve tree detection from very high-resolution drone imagery. A pre-trained YOLOv8 network was initially trained on the high-resolution VHRTrees satellite imagery dataset and fine-tuned on a smaller very high-resolution drone image dataset. It will resolve issues related to both limited data and domain differences. Experiments explored the impact of spatial resolution at 15 cm and 30 cm, data augmentation, and layer freezing. The results showed that the best accuracy is achieved by fine-tuning using 15 cm resolution while freezing 10 layers; this outperforms models without any transfer learning and those trained from scratch. Data augmentation further reduced false positives, enhancing detection reliability. These findings highlight transfer learning as a cost-effective means to achieve both scalable and precise ecological monitoring-feasible for several applications in forest management and environmental care.

title: Investigation of Si IGBT/SiC MOSFET Based Hybrid Switch with Common Gate Control
authors: Nisith Bhowmick, Andreas Apelsmeier, Chetan Ugare, Vishal Undre, Lathom Louco, Vishal Iyappan
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper investigates the behaviour of hybrid switch which is configured with Silicon Carbide Metal Oxide Semiconductor Field-Effect Transistor and Silicon Insulated Gate Bipolar Transistor in parallel, considering its potential use in high power inverter used in the vehicular technology. This configuration can offer cost effectiveness over Silicon Carbide Metal Oxide Semiconductor Field-Effect Transistor based inverter. On the other hand, it will be more efficient than Silicon Insulated Gate Bipolar Transistor based inverter. To validate this idea, a detailed study has been done on switching loss, conduction loss and the gate control strategies of the hybrid switch configuration.

title: Design of an Asymmetric Double-Sided LCC Compensation Network with High Efficiency and Low Current Stress
authors: Haiyue Jiang, Songyan Li, Mohamad Abou Houran, Hongchang Li
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Wireless Power Transfer (WPT) systems are widely used in electric vehicles, drones, and medical devices for their safety and convenience. Compensation networks, particularly the double-sided LCC topology, are essential for optimizing efficiency and ensuring stable energy transfer under varying loads and distances. However, research on parameter selection and optimization for asymmetric double-sided LCC topology is limited. This paper bridges this gap by emphasizing the need for symmetric T-type compensation networks on both primary and secondary sides to maximize efficiency. It determines self-inductance values for coupling coils, focusing on reducing voltage-current stress while enhancing efficiency, and derives parameters for auxiliary inductors. A comprehensive parameter design method is proposed to optimize the efficiency and reduce component stress. The results are validated by experiments.

title: Study on Monitoring and Mechanism of Induced Subsidence of Groundwater Mining Based on InSAR
authors: Licheng Sun, Wenbo Xu, Pengke Li, Yu Li, Boyang Zhang, Haitao Jia
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In this paper, the North China Plain is used as a groundwater simulation environment. The Sentinel-1 data of C-band satellite-based synthetic aperture radar (SAR) is used to analyze the correlation between the area with large groundwater extraction and the area with serious land subsidence in Cangzhou City. To achieve InSAR monitoring of large-scale land subsidence, this paper utilizes PS-InSAR technology, which involves segmented processing followed by splicing. Based on the hydrogeological parameters and groundwater extraction data of the North China Plain, a numerical simulation model was established in this paper, and combined with the InSAR land subsidence monitoring results, it was verified that groundwater extraction has a profound impact on the development of land subsidence. The main research results are as follows: (1) Using Sentinel-1 image data from January 2018 to June 2019 and time series analysis based on SNAP and StaMPS software, the center rate of land subsidence in Cangzhou City is -125.6mm/y. (2) A quasi-three-dimensional groundwater numerical simulation model for the North China Plain was constructed by using groundwater simulation system software. According to groundwater mining data and the SUB sedimentation module, a ground subsidence model induced by groundwater mining in Cangzhou City was established. The simulation results show that if only the induced factors of groundwater exploitation are considered, the land subsidence center rate in Cangzhou City in 2019 can reach -130mm/y. The two experiments have proved that groundwater exploitation is the dominant factor in the inducement of land subsidence in Cangzhou City.

title: Volcanogenic Massive Sulphide Deposit Related Alteration Zone Mapping with PRISMA Hyperspectral Imagery
authors: Saraah Imran, Ajanta Goswami, Sriram Jallu, Riyaaz Uddien Shaik, Pradeepkumar T
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: PRISMA hyperspectral data is used for mapping the hydrothermal alteration zones associated with Volcanogenic Massive Sulphide (VMS) deposits in the Betul Belt, Madhya Pradesh, India. Based on the absorption features of Al-OH and Mg-OH, absorption depth indices are used to demarcate the Al- and Mg-alteration zones. Laboratory spectroscopic studies of collected samples provide a comprehensive understanding of the variation of absorption features in the Short-Wave Infrared Region (SWIR) with variations in mineralogy. Field validation and SEM-EDS confirm the mineralogy of the alteration zones. The results demonstrate PRISMA's potential for mineral mapping and its integration with spectroscopy techniques for resource exploration. This study involves remote sensing-based alteration zone mapping of the Betul Belt for the first time.

title: Preliminary Results of Seafloor Topography Recovery from Marine Gravity Field Inverted by Swot Altimetry
authors: Xiaoyang Liu, Qiankun Liu, Ke Xu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The accuracy and resolution of gravity data affect the inversion results of seafloor topography. In contrast to the traditional nadir altimetry, wide-swath radar altimetry systems can measure two-dimensional sea surface heights so that vertical deviations in any direction have the same accuracy, thus improving the accuracy of gravity data. The December 2022 launch of The Surface Water and Ocean Topography (SWOT) will bring new advances in gravity field and seafloor topography inversion. The use of neural networks for gravity inversion of seafloor topography instead of traditional methods such as SAS is a current research hot spot. In this study, the FCNN network is used to recover the bathymetry of the western Pacific Ocean north of the equator (147.5°E 155°E, 10°N 20°N), using the V32.1 gravity modeling released by the SIO team, which is based on the 30-year surface height data from the traditional nadir altimetry, and the VSWOT.02 gravity modeling released by the SWOT satellite, which is based on the 1-year surface height data, to compare the effect of the two data in the seafloor topography inversion. The study shows that the VSWOT.02 gravity data have improved the accuracy and resolution of the seafloor topography compared with the traditional gravity data, and the RMSE has been reduced from 205 m to 182 m, and more details of the seafloor can be observed.

title: Grey-Box Reverse Derivation of a Grid-Forming Inverter Based on Output Impedance Spectrum
authors: Zhenshuai Liu, Yitong Li, Cheng Ai, Fengwei Han, Yao Qin, Jinjun Liu
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The grid-forming inverter (GFM) has been attracting increasing interest because of its great potential in applications of renewable energy systems in future power grids. However, the detailed controls of inverters are normally hidden by manufacturers which brings difficulties of analyzing the dynamics of the inverter itself as well as the whole power grids. Therefore, in this paper, a grey-box reverse derivation method is proposed, which enables us to reversely derive the internal control parameters of a grid-forming inverter based on its output impedance spectrum. Frequency-domain Bode diagrams and time-domain simulation waveforms are presented in different situations to verify the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: UAV-based RGB-Infrared Object Detection via Multi-Domain Feature Interaction
authors: Jia Yao, Huayu Zhang, Wanru Mao, Yufeng Wang, Wenrui Ding
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) are playing an increasingly important role in the field of remote sensing due to their flexibility and efficiency. Meanwhile, UAV-based RGB-infrared image pairs possess stronger environmental adaptability and can provide rich object details, making them worthy of research. In this paper, we propose a multi-domain interaction detector (MDID) to detect various objects in extreme environments through the multi-domain effective integration of RGB-infrared images. The main feature interaction blocks consist of the dual wavelet enhancement block (DWEB) and the dual inception fusion block (DIFB). Specifically, DWEB can acquire valuable shared features between RGB-infrared image pairs in the frequency domain to mitigate modality feature conflicts during the feature extraction process. Then, DIFB can represent the object fusion information of varying scales and enhance the channel attention of the fused feature maps, which achieves the fusion of RGB-infrared image pairs in the spatial and channel domains. The experimental results with a challenging dataset confirm that our MDID performs better than the SOTA methods.

title: Improved Densefuse Infrared and Visible Remote Sensing Image Fusion Based on Multiscale Spatial Attention
authors: Puxi Huang, Hao Chen, Ye Zhang, Bin Xiao, Dong Chen
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Remote sensing images play a significant role in diverse fields such as disaster response, agriculture, and forestry management. Single infrared or visible images are subject to limitations due to the impact of complex factors such as the atmosphere and clouds, and image fusion can effectively integrate information. To achieve better fusion of infrared and visible remote sensing images, this paper proposed an improved DenseFuse method. This method incorporates a multiscale spatial attention module and gradient loss, enabling targeted fusion of important regions and preservation of image details and structures. The experimental results indicate that, compared with the DenseFuse method, when tested on the RoadScene dataset, the proposed method demonstrates superior performance.

title: Coregistration of Highly Ambiguous SAR Images for Multi-Baseline Distributed SAR Interferometry
authors: Átila A. A. Diniz, Dimas Irion Alves, Renato Machado
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Using clusters of small satellites instead of traditional large SAR satellites presents significant advantages, including reduced costs, increased system redundancy, and enhanced temporal resolution. However, the smaller antennas inherent to these systems introduce higher phase and range ambiguities, which pose challenges for accurate image coregistration and subsequent interferometric analysis. This study employed synthetically generated SAR images to evaluate the effectiveness of cross-correlation techniques, both incoherent and coherent, in mitigating these ambiguities. The approach was further validated using a real SAR image from the TanDEM-X mission, where controlled ambiguities were artificially introduced to test the robustness of the proposed methodology. The results demonstrate the potential of this technique to enable reliable coregistration in distributed SAR systems, paving the way for broader adoption of small-satellite clusters in advanced remote sensing applications.

title: Investigation of On-Chip Temperature Measurement in Power Cycling Using Fibre Bragg Grating Sensors
authors: Mark Sherriff, Ricardo Correia, Chenyang He, Paul Evans, Ke Li
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Condition monitoring techniques underpin the successful drive towards the net zero economy, providing more accurate predictive maintenance for electrical infrastructure and hence increasing system service life. Fibre Bragg grating (FBG) sensors provide an electrically isolated temperature measurement, which can be utilized for fast and accurate semiconductor junction temperature estimation. Compared with traditional temperature-sensitive electrical parameters, FBG temperature measurement is immune to electromagnetic interference and is not affected by device ageing. In this paper, the procedure of on-chip FBG temperature measurement is presented in the context of power cycling for silicon diode test vehicles. Accuracy of the sensor transient response is discussed, alongside mitigating factors and potential avenues for future improvements.

title: Post-launch vicarious calibration-validation of Pixxel’s technology demonstrator vnir hyperspectral satellite using RadCalNet data
authors: Rahul Raj, Karthik Billa
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Three visible-near-infrared (VNIR) technology demonstrator satellites were successfully launched by the private space company Pixxel between June 2021 and November 2022. Subsequently, commercial-grade constellations of VNIR and SWIR hyperspectral satellites, planned to deliver the highest spatial resolution and a 24 hour revisit rate, are slated to be launched in 2025, of which three VNIR satellites were already launched in February 2025. In this study, the vicarious calibration of the first technology-demonstrator satellite is discussed. The gain and offset values determined during pre-launch calibration may change over time and thus need to be re-calibrated once the satellite is in orbit. RadCalNet sites were scanned and used as vicarious targets by Pixxel's hyperspectral satellite; radiometric gains/offsets and spectral shifts were calibrated and validated. The calibration resulted in an average radiance accuracy of 7 W/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>/um/Sr with 4 W/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>/um/Sr Spectral accuracy, assessed using the atmospheric oxygen absorption notch, was found to have a shift of less than 2.1 nm.

title: DepthLiteNet: A Feature Selective and Lightweight Architecture for Road Extraction from Satellite Imagery
authors: Jayakumar T V, Amrutha Aneesh, Deepak Mishra, Ramiya Anandakumar M, Jai G Singla
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Accurate road extraction from satellite images is critical for applications such as urban planning, navigation systems, and disaster response. Recent advancements in computer vision has paved the way to achieving this task efficiently. However, maintaining both high accuracy and low computational complexity remains a challenge. To address this we propose a feature selective and lightweight UNet architecture (DepthLiteNet). It combines a reduced depth UNet structure with a novel Feature Selection Module (FSM) and aims to improve the precision of a standard UNet model along with reducing its complexity. The number of parameters is 35% less than standard UNet. Three different datasets — the Massachusetts Roads Dataset, the DeepGlobe Road Extraction Dataset, and the CHN6-CUG Roads Dataset — were used to validate DepthLiteNet. When compared to state of the art techniques, our results demonstrates notable and consistent increase in Intersection Over Union (IOU) by values 0.98%, 5.62%, and 2.7% for the Massachusetts Roads Dataset, the DeepGlobe Road Extraction Dataset, and the CHN6-CUG Roads Dataset respectively.

title: Heterogeneous Cloud-Based EV Charging Management System with Rust and Multi-Device Integration
authors: Shah Meeran Zia, Minglei You, Mark Sumner, Christian Klumpner, Mohamed Hajj
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The rapid adoption of electric vehicles (EVs) has created a need for scalable, secure, and efficient charging management systems. Traditional implementations rely on cloud-based architecture using Python or C++, but they often suffer from performance bottlenecks and security vulnerabilities. This paper introduces a novel Rust-powered cloud-native EV charging management system that integrates multiple energy sources, including EV chargers, solar panels, and batteries, into a heterogeneous smart home environment. The system leverages Rust for its high performance and memory safety and is deployed on the AWS cloud for scalability and remote management. The platform enables secure communication, real-time energy monitoring, and AI-driven energy optimization. The initial prototype of the system has been successfully implemented as a Rust-based web application and is currently being migrated to AWS (Amazon web services) for full deployment. However, significant work remains in optimizing energy management algorithms and improving cross-device interoperability.

title: Mapping vegetation-geothermal interactions using VNIR-SWIR, thermal and SAR data
authors: Gabor Kereszturi, Kerry Cawse-Nicholson, Alejandro C. Frery, David R. Thompson, Avik Bhattacharya, Nicholas Parazoo, Cecilia Rodriguez-Gomez, Robert Reeves, Simon Hook
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Monitoring and mapping geothermal activity from airborne and satellite platforms is challenging due to extensive vegetation cover. This study explores the ways to use vegetation and its spectral, thermal, and phenological signatures to track underlying geothermal activity. We explored and developed a series of prediction models for predicting foliar antimony concentration at Waiotapu Geothermal Field in New Zealand using a combination of hyperspectral, thermal, and SAR datasets from high spatial resolution airborne- (e.g., AisaFENIX, thermal, and LiDAR) and coarse resolution satellite platforms (e.g., EMIT, ECOSTRESS and Sentinel-1). Our results indicate that geothermal fields and the extent of the geothermal activity can be successfully mapped using their vegetation cover. This approach can open new uses of Earth observation data to monitor geothermal activity from space.

title: Decomposable Multi-kernel Convolutional Networks for Object Detection in Remote Sensing Images
authors: Ziye Zhang, Chenzi Wang, Mingyang Ma, Yifan Zhang, Shaohui Mei
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Remote sensing object detection (RSOD) algorithms can accurately capture the distribution of objects on the Earth’s surface with powerful spatial resolution. Deep learning-based RSOD algorithms have achieved excellent performance, which is mainly attributed to strong backbone networks with powerful feature extraction abilities. However, existing backbone networks typically use fixed receptive fields to extract image features, neglecting the requirement for varying receptive fields in RSOD. Additionally, the large number of parameters and high computational costs of these models limit their real-time performance. In this paper, a Decomposable Multi-kernel Convolutional Network containing a Multi-kernel Receptive Field Module (MRF) and a Feature Selection Module is proposed for RSOD. Specifically, the MRF module employs sparse convolutional computations to achieve feature extraction across multiple receptive fields, exploring the local spatial features of targets at multiple scales while reducing model complexity. Meanwhile, the FSM module leverages attention modeling in both spatial and channel dimensions for feature selection, enhancing effective object features across different receptive fields. The proposed algorithm is evaluated on the publicly available DIOR and DOTA datasets, and the experimental results show that our method significantly outperforms the other state-of-the-art methods.

title: Vulnerabilities of Multimodal Fusion Models in Remote Sensing: Analyzing the Impact of Adversarial Attacks on Spatial Data Content
authors: Chaman Banolia, Shailesh Deshpande, Biplab Banerjee
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Adversarial attacks pose a significant challenge to the robustness of deep learning models, particularly in multi-modal fusion (MMF) systems used in remote sensing, where diverse data modalities such as hyperspectral imagery (HSI), LiDAR, and SAR are combined to enhance classification and detection accuracy. While MMF has demonstrated improved predictive performance in remote sensing applications, its susceptibility to adversarial attacks remains a critical issue. This study investigates the impact of spatial data content on adversarial attacks in MMF, focusing on how perturbations in remote sensing modalities affect system robustness. Using gradient-based attacks (FGSM, BIM, PGD), we evaluate the vulnerability of MMF models under varying spatial patch sizes. Our findings reveal that MMF models are highly susceptible to adversarial perturbations, even when only a single modality, such as HSI, is targeted. Although fusion improves accuracy on clean samples, it does not inherently enhance robustness against adversarial attacks. Experiments on the Houston13 and MUUFL datasets demonstrate relatively high accuracy on clean samples, while adversarial accuracy remains significantly lower, highlighting a critical trade-off. These results emphasize the need for specialized defense strategies tailored to the unique characteristics of remote sensing data to ensure the security and reliability of MMF models in critical applications such as environmental monitoring and military surveillance.

title: Quickest Attempt Attack (QuAck) Against Randomized KF Innovations-based Detection in AVs with Integrated GPS-IMU
authors: Marim Mahmoud, Wesam Al Amiri, Terry N. Guo, Syed Rafay Hasan
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: Advancements in GPS technology have significantly enhanced navigational accuracy, yet they remain vulnerable to spoofing attacks. This paper presents a spoofing attack capable of manipulating the trajectory of an autonomous vehicle (AV) equipped with a global positioning system and inertial measurement unit system. This is achieved without triggering detection mechanisms that rely on Kalman Filter's innovationsbased detection. In recent literature, randomized normalized innovation squared (NIS) detection alarm has been used to detect GPS spoofing. However, our proposed algorithm, quickest attempt attack (QuAck), identifies that an attacker can bypass randomized NIS in a realistic threat model. This result highlights the need for further investigation to ensure the security of AV's navigational perception system.

title: Few-Shot ISAR Image Segmentation Using 4D Convolutional Transformer
authors: Haoran Sun, Feng Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The segmentation of inverse synthetic aperture radar (ISAR) images is essential for comprehensive analysis and identification of critical components. This step is also essential for the reconstruction of 3D point clouds pertaining to satellite components. However, ISAR primarily observes non-cooperative targets, resulting in a significant limitation in the number of samples. To mitigate this issue, a novel cost aggregation network is proposed, termed cost aggregation with pyramidal transformer (CAPT), which can effectively address the challenges ISAR image segmentation faces. Features are first extracted from the input image, then four-dimensional convolution is adopted to capture spatial relationships in the image for cost aggregation. Finally, the output image corresponding to the predicted projection mask is decoded by the affinity-guided transformer decoder (ATD). Multiple sets of experiments are conducted to demonstrate the performance of CAPT for ISAR few-shot image segmentation.

title: Live Fuel Moisture Content Estimation from Himawari-8 Data and Scope Model Inversion
authors: Jixuan Jiang, Jingyu Zhang, Qinglong Jia, Xingwen Quan
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Under the context of global warming, the increasing frequency of extreme weather events and natural disasters poses significant threats to ecosystems and human societies. Wildfires, as a globally prevalent natural disaster, not only directly endanger lives and property but also have far-reaching impacts on the ecological environment and climate systems. Previous studies predominantly utilized polar-orbiting satellite data such as MODIS, typically achieving retrieval results with a temporal resolution of one scene per day. This study employs geostationary satellite data to retrieve FMC, utilizing the SCOPE model combined with lookup tables (LUT) and numerical optimization methods. Through an appropriate parameterized model and initial value estimation based on a random forest approach, satisfactory retrieval results were achieved for regions in central-western China and Australia. The LUT method demonstrated an accuracy of R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.58, RMSE = 50.25 for grasslands, and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>=0.40, RMSE = 35.52 for forests. The numerical optimization method further improved results, with R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.66, RMSE = 33.3 for grasslands, and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>=0.59, RMSE = 33.97 for forests. Both methods enable FMC retrieval at temporal resolutions of up to 10 minutes. However, given the rapid variation in angular information from geostationary satellites, the numerical optimization approach—being more scalable—is better suited for high-temporal-resolution FMC retrievals.

title: Analysis and Design of Fault-Tolerant Dual Three-Phase Permanent Magnet Synchronous Machines for eVTOL Applications
authors: Yuwen Xu, Shun Cai, Mehdi Baghdadi, Zachary Edwards, Zeliang Zhang, Guangzhao Luo
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The electric aircraft industry has received an increasing impetus over past decades, driven by the growing attention on environmental sustainability. This paper aims to propose a dual 3-phase fault-tolerant interior permanent magnet synchronous machine (FT-IPMSM) for electric vertical takeoff and landing (eVTOL) applications. Firstly, trade studies were performed on four permanent magnet (PM) configurations with considerations of high-torque-density and high reliability. Then, the multi-physics evaluation is undertaken on a 48-slot/8-pole FT-IPMSM with 2-layer V-shaped PM, during which the thermal viability and mechanical challenges are addressed from design aspects. The results demonstrate the mechanical performance of the machine can be improved by carefully optimizing the rotor structure. This paper also attempts to evaluate the fault-tolerance of the prototype with two different dual 3-phase winding configurations. It verifies that the proposed segregated dual 3-phase winding has comparable performance to the conventional design under both healthy and open-circuit (OC) fault, while the segregated winding has superior short-circuit (SC) fault currents and output torque under the SC condition.

title: Flux Distribution of a Triple-Stator Induction Motor Under Series and Parallel Configurations
authors: Abdulrahman Alharbi, Shafiq Odhano, Andrew Smith, Xu Deng, Barrie Mecrow
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Multi-phase induction machines have received growing attention in recent years due to their distinct advantages over conventional three-phase machines. Notably, their capability to continue operating under fault conditions without requiring inverter modifications has made them an attractive option in fault-tolerant applications. However, effective control of these machines requires a comprehensive understanding of their internal behaviour, particularly the distribution of the magnetic flux, with the flux information fundamental to many control strategies such as Field-Oriented Control (FOC) and Direct Torque Control (DTC). In the following work, the flux distribution of a three-phase induction motor which has been reconfigured into a triple-stator induction machine, is investigated under both series and parallel stator configurations. An experimental result based around a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.2 k W$</tex> machine shows that the flux in each stator of the triple-stator configuration is approximately one-third that of the original machine, whilst maintaining the same current amplitude.

title: Enhancing Maize Yield Prediction by Assimilating MODIS LAI with Pre-classification Data into the WOFOST Model
authors: Ran Kang, Hui Ying Yin, Jian Guo, Tian He Xu, Si Qi Yang, Cai Yun Deng
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Accurate yield predictions are crucial for addressing potential food shortages and ensuring global food security. Among the most valuable parameters for yield prediction is the Leaf Area Index (LAI), which correlates with various physiological processes and growth stages. This study proposed a data assimilation algorithm integrated MODIS LAI (500 m) product with pre-classified maize areas derived from Landsat data (15 m) to improve maize yield prediction in the WOFOST model. A classification method was developed to extract maize areas in intercropping scenarios based on phenological stages, achieving an overall R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.92 and an RMSE of 458.47 km<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> from 2017 to 2022, compared with official statistical data. The maize area was classified into four categories based on percentage levels to account for the spatial resolution of the MODIS LAI product. Pixels with more than 60% maize coverage were identified as pure pixels and assimilated with the MODIS LAI data into the WOFOST model. Three methods were employed for comparison: the original WOFOST model, MODIS LAI assimilation, and the proposed maize percentage-based method. While all three methods exhibited similar overall trends, our proposed method yielded the most accurate results (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.64, RMSE = 239.35 kg/ha). These findings demonstrate the potential of the proposed method to reduce the influence of low-resolution datasets and enhance regional maize yield estimation.

title: An Accelerated Ambiguity Resolving Scheme for Dual-Channel Forward-Looking SAR Imaging
authors: Rui Chen, Wenchao Li, Kun Zhang, Bowen Cheng, Jianyu Yang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: With the echo difference between different channels, a linear equation between echo and scattering coefficient can be established according to the time-frequency-space steering matrix, thereby achieving left/right ambiguity suppression and resolution enhancement of forward-looking SAR imaging simultaneously. However, the resolving process of the linear equation involves high-dimensional matrix inversion, resulting in a significant computational burden. In order to address this issue, an accelerated left/right ambiguity resolving scheme for dual-channel forward-looking SAR imaging is proposed in this paper. This method uses the low-rank approximation theory to perform dimension reduction processing firstly, and then uses the low-dimensional echo matrix to efficiently reconstruct the scattering coefficients. At last, the effectiveness of the proposed scheme is verified through simulation results.

title: Nonlinear Blind Hyperspectral Unmixing Via Generalized Mixing Mechanism Fitting and Endmember Constraints
authors: Dong Chen, Xuejian Liang, Linlin Wang, Junping Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Blind hyperspectral unmixing (HU) is designed for decomposing pixels into endmembers with estimating their abundances. Current deep learning-based methods rely on autoencoders under the linear mixing model assumption, where endmembers are represented by decoder parameters. These approaches limit their applicability in nonlinear and complex scenarios, and also make them challenging to impose constraints on endmembers, potentially resulting in poor endmember estimation. In this paper, we propose a novel nonlinear blind HU method called GMMFU through decoder-based generalized mixing mechanism fitting grounded in the initial nonlinear mixing model assumption. GMMFU simultaneously estimates abundances and endmembers while fitting the mixing mechanism, expressed as a generalized form that surpasses current autoencoder-based methods. Additionally, GMMFU separates the endmembers from the decoder and constrains them to the hyperspectral image data distribution using the proposed endmember consistency and discrepancy losses. This improves the accuracy of endmember estimation, which in turn enhances successively the abundance estimation. Experimental results show that GMMFU outperforms other algorithms qualitatively and quantitatively.

title: Method for Sustainable Analysis of a Traction Inverter Assuming Several Use Phases
authors: Daiyi Hu, Yuanzhao Tian, Paula Burfeind, Regine Mallwitz, Christine Minke
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The car electrification is taking place for reasons of responsible resource and energy use. The components of electromobility, including the traction inverter, are enablers but also consume resources and energy themselves. The sustainability of these components is usually assessed with the help of a life cycle analysis (LCA). This paper focuses on the carbon footprint assessment of a 250 kW SiC traction inverter in B6 configuration during both manufacturing and use phases. Because the use of a car varies, different operating scenarios, including fixed hours, mileage-based, and mission profile-based cycles, were evaluated for the use phase. The results show that, in addition to the mission profile, e.g., the switching frequency and the choice of semiconductors, also influence the carbon footprint. A GaN-based ANPC inverter offers improved durability and lower annual emissions. Integrating use phase insights into early design, such as topology and semiconductor selection, enhances the carbon footprint.

title: Impact of Atmospheric Correction for Turbidity Estimation in Coastal Waters with Sentinel-2 Data and AI Techniques
authors: Elisa Liparulo, Pietro Di Stasio, Francesca Razzano, Simona Reale, Gilda Schirinzi, Paolo Gamba, Silvia Liberata Ullo
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In recent years, Artificial Intelligence (AI) has been a key element in addressing complex issues in many fields, thanks to its ability to analyze large amounts of data and provide innovative solutions. This study focuses on the application of AI to estimate turbidity values in the coastal waters of the Veneto region in Italy using Sentinel-2 satellite data. The primary goal is to assess the impact of atmospheric correction on the reliability of derived parameters, an essential factor in monitoring water quality and safeguarding marine ecosystems. The project integrates in situ data provided by ARPAV, the regional Agency of Environment Protection, with satellite imagery accessed through Google Earth Engine (GEE), generating separate datasets based on L1C and L2A images, respectively. These datasets were employed to train and evaluate multiple Machine Learning (ML) models to identify the most effective approach for turbidity estimation and environmental monitoring optimization. The analysis highlighted that the use of atmospherically corrected data is not strictly necessary and underlined the need for strategies to improve model performance, especially in conditions of limited data availability. The results obtained demonstrate the feasibility and effectiveness of using AI algorithms for water quality monitoring, providing a concrete basis for future developments. This approach has the potential to support timely and targeted interventions for the protection of the marine environment and public health.

title: Uncertainty Calculation of Ozonesonde at Gcos Reference Upper Air Network( Gruan) Station in Xilinhot
authors: Chi Wang, Junli Jin, Xuewu An, Fang Liu, Yan Li, RiTu Su
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This study assesses the uncertainty in ozone sounding data obtained from the CYT-1 ozonesonde at the Xilinhot Station of the World Meteorological Organization’s (WMO) Global Climate Observing System’s Reference Upper-Air Network (GRUAN). The primary sources of uncertainty in the ozone sounding data from the Xilinhot GRUAN Station are identified, and a quantitative analysis method is applied to evaluate the contribution of each source to the overall uncertainty. A synthetic uncertainty formula is utilized to develop a model for calculating the uncertainty of the ozone sounding data from this station. The calculated uncertainty results are then analyzed to assess the level of data uncertainty.

title: Practical Study on Remote Sensing Data and Products Calibration and Validation in ISO 19124 Standard Series
authors: Wen Hong, Fangfang Li, Jiankun Guo, Qiang Yin, Yun Lin
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The continuously and rapidly increasing amount of remote sensing data has given rise to the demand for standardization of data and products. Calibration and validation, as indispensable means to enhance and evaluate the quality of remote sensing data and products, are of great significance for their standardization in order to improve the quantitative application ability of data and products. This paper introduces the recent progress of ISO/TC 211 in calibration and validation of data and derived products. Especially for the all day and all weather SAR sensors, the current status of SAR data and products and related efforts in ISO 19124 series of technical specifications are presented.

title: Design of the Robotic Arm Configuration Automatic Monitoring and Control System
authors: Hongguang Li, Jie Li, Wei Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computational Intelligence and Robotics (CIR)
abstract: This paper presents the design of a low-cost, long-distance three-axis Cartesian coordinate robotic arm, featuring a gantry structure compatible with existing crane equipment. It is controlled by a computer and servo motors, supporting manual, teach, and automatic operation modes. The system includes features such as posture simulation, trajectory preview, and anomaly alerts, ensuring precise control through inverse kinematics and traj ectory optimization. The design incorporates photoelectric limit switches and vacuum suction cups for improved safety and efficiency. Experimental results demonstrate the system's flexibility and reliability in real-world applications, and future research will focus on optimization algorithms and adaptive learning to further enhance performance.

title: SAR and Optical Image Registration Based on Style Transfer
authors: Ruijie Shao, Tianming Zhao, Yunxiao Chen, Tian Tian, Ruyi Feng
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Traditional SAR and optical image registration methods often struggle to address the inconsistency of features in multimodal images, while deep learning-based methods typically require large amounts of labeled data, making them unsuitable for practical scenarios. To tackle this issue, this paper proposes a multimodal image registration method based on style transfer. On one hand, an unsupervised style transfer model is introduced to achieve modality fitting, transforming SAR images into optical images and effectively reducing modality differences. On the other hand, to enhance registration performance, we design a phase congruency-based feature matching algorithm. This algorithm offers advantages such as a higher number of features and improved robustness, which significantly enhance registration accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms existing mainstream handcrafted methods, enabling the registration of SAR-optical cross-modal image pairs effectively.

title: Trade Study of DC-DC Converter Topologies for Non-Propulsive Energy Generation from Aircraft Propulsive Electrical Networks
authors: Abdelrahman Elwakeel, Douglas Pedroso, Tania Cuesta Cano, Ignacio Castro, Paul Lefley, Ali Al-Karaghouli, Andrew Benn, Mustansir Kheraluwala, Josh Swenson
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: A focus on power electronics within the aerospace industry is being driven by the increase in the electrification of aircraft systems, particularly towards all-electric aircraft. The HECATE (Hybrid-ElectriC regional Aircraft distribution TEchnologies) program is a key program in enabling future aircraft electric distribution by developing technology demonstrators to TRL5. This article presents a trade analysis of isolated DC-DC converter topologies designed for hybridelectric and all-electric aircraft applications. Where the trade study focused on an 800 V to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$540 \mathrm{V}, 150 \text{kW}$</tex> DC-DC converter specification, engineered to meet aviation standards while maximizing power density and efficiency.

title: A Comparative Study of SGD, Adam, AdamW, and RMSprop Optimizers for VGG19-Based Rupiah Banknote Classification
authors: Huzain Azis, Maharani Safwa Andini, Herman, Lukman Syafie, Abdul Rachman Manga’, Lutfi Budi Ilmawan
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: This study employs a VGG19 convolutional neural network to evaluate and compare four optimization techniques SGD, Adam, AdamW, and RMSprop—for classifying images of Rupiah banknotes. 1,400 photos from seven denominations make up the dataset, which has been preprocessed by shrinking to 224 by 224 pixels and normalizing to [0, 1]. To ensure a fair comparison the models were trained using the same parameters, which included 50 epochs, a batch size of 32, and a learning rate of 0.0001. Accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 score were among the evaluation criteria that were evaluated using macro averaging. According to the results, AdamW outperformed other optimizers in terms of convergence and generalization, achieving the highest validation accuracy ($92.43 \%$) and the lowest loss (0.2877). These results show that AdamW is the best optimizer for creating trustworthy systems for recognizing Rupiah currencies.

title: Towards Deep Line-Based Architectures for Onboard Hyperspectral Image Super-Resolution
authors: Davide Piccinini, Diego Valsesia, Enrico Magli
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Hyperspectral images can provide the fine spectral resolution needed for several tasks involving material identification, but they suffer from limited spatial resolution due to instrument constraints. The emerging paradigm of onboard computing seeks to address several detection problems of interest directly onboard of a satellite, in order to minimize latency due to the downlink and processing chain. In this paper, we design a novel lightweight architecture for onboard spatial super-resolution of hyperspectral images with the goal of improving onboard detection methods that rely on such images. The core of our contribution is a novel neural network architecture that works in a line-by-line fashion thanks to a recurrent-attentive mechanism in the along-track direction. This design greatly limits the memory requirements and computational complexity of the model, making it suitable for onboard usage. We show that this novel architecture is competitive with respect to the state of the art in term of super-resolution quality, while providing significant savings in complexity and memory.

title: Design and Optimization of Efficiency for Solar Power Generation in Battery Energy Storage Through Automatic Control System Based on Microcontroller
authors: Ferry R A Bukit, Naemah Mubarakah, Inggit Onike
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: Solar power generation has great potential as the most widely used renewable energy due to its environmental friendliness and zero emission of greenhouse gases or other pollution. However, the limitations of energy storage from batteries are one of the obstacles in this system. Optimizing the use of solar energy in batteries is expected to reduce household energy costs and reduce dependence on conventional energy sources. This study aims to optimize battery energy storage in solar power systems through the design of a microcontroller-based Autocharger Controller (ACC) Version 1 and the addition of a battery-supercapacitor combination. The research methods include the design of a microcontroller-based ACC version 1 and a battery-supercapacitor, testing the performance of PWM-type SCC and ACC version 1, as well as a cost-benefit analysis. Data collection was conducted using voltage, current, and temperature sensors. Data analysis was performed using efficiency comparisons calculated based on input and output power in solar power systems, state of charge (SoC), and depth of discharge (DoD) in energy storage, as well as feasibility analysis of the ratio-present value (NPV), Payback period, and Benefit-Cost Ratio (BCR). The test results indicate that the ACC can enhance charging efficiency, as demonstrated by the test data collected at noon WIB, which showed a $\mathbf{2 . 1 9 \%}$ increase in efficiency. Based on the SoC level, the ACC has a lower level compared to the SCC; however, the depth of discharge (DoD) of the energy storage is lower for the ACC, at $45.60 \%$, compared to the SCC’s energy storage discharge depth of $\mathbf{5 2 . 4 0 \%}$. The cost-benefit analysis of solar power systems using the ACC is more profitable than those using SCC, with a profit of approximately $\mathbf{4 4 . 9 9 \%}$. Optimizing the energy storage system through a microcontroller-based active power control (ACC) and the addition of a supercapacitor can enhance the solar power system, making it a worthy consideration.

title: Physics-Based Machine Learning Approach for Estimating Tropical Cyclone Intensity in the North Atlantic
authors: Dae-Hui Kim, Elizabeth A. Ritchie, J. Scott Tyo, Mehrtash Harandi
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: A physics-based machine learning (ML) model for estimating tropical cyclone (TC) intensity is developed in the North Atlantic basin by using all TCs from 2017 to 2023 to create training and testing datasets. TC features are explicitly extracted from satellite brightness temperature images and used as inputs to the model, which is comprised of Light Gradient Boosting Machines coupled with Multilayer Perceptrons. Overall, the model achieved a root mean square error of 3.40 kt in 2023. The relative importance of input TC features for estimating intensity depending on the TC intensity and the size of the feature extraction area is analyzed. The results show that, by leveraging domain knowledge such as the deviation angle variance, the performance of a ML model can be improved with less computational costs and more interpretability.

title: AI-Driven Innovation and Digital Twins: Integrating MHE Automation to Enhance Smart Warehousing, Logistics, and FSMA Compliance in the Food Industry
authors: Nirmal Kumar Balaraman, Prabhakaran Rajendran, Sridhar Thirumalai, Devyani Borse
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society Conference - Global (TEMSCON Global)
abstract: The food industry under the Food Safety Modernization Act (FSMA) benefits greatly from the application of Artificial Intelligence (AI), Digital Twins, and automation through Material Handling Equipment (MHE). This research investigates the way AI innovations with Digital Twins improve warehouse efficiency along with supply chain tracking and adherence to FSMA requirements. Real-time data analysis together with predictive maintenance and automated systems through AI and Digital Twins deliver better inventory control and lower operational expenditures and better maintain regulatory compliance. The widespread implementation of the systems encounters various obstacles that stem from the high expense of deployment along with data security risks and issues during system integration with conventional infrastructure. This investigation uses Systematic Literature Review (SLR) methodology to evaluate academic studies about AI and Digital Twin implementations within smart warehousing solutions. Researchers studied the advantages together with implementation obstacles of these systems thus identifying their instrumental role in optimizing food logistics operations and adherence management. The research makes final recommendations about how to overcome obstacles for adoption while establishing AI-driven automation as a sustainable part of Food Supply Chain operations.

title: Loop Closure Detection Based on 3D Panoramic Semantic Topological Map
authors: Shenjie Chen, Yanhui Luo, Congyu Zhang, Wenjie Hong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computational Intelligence and Robotics (CIR)
abstract: Loop Closure Detection, also referred to as visual place recognition, is a critical component of visual SLAM systems. It facilitates the identification and correction of accumulated drift errors, thereby significantly enhancing map accuracy and consistency. Compared to traditional perspective images, panoramic images provide richer environmental information. This effectively mitigates perceptual ambiguities in place recognition and reduces feature mismatches caused by the viewpoint limitations of perspective images. Furthermore, the omnidirectional view provided by panoramic images partially addresses the common reverse loop-closure problem, which refers to place recognition mismatches caused by viewpoint reversal when a robot retraces its original path. We propose a loop closure detection method based on a 3D panoramic semantic topological map, leveraging the advantages of semantic, depth, spatial information, and panoramic images. Benchmark experiments on the Pitts250K-P2E and YQ360 datasets demonstrate the method is efficiency and precision. Furthermore, it has the potential to enhance the PanoVPR model, thereby improving localization accuracy.

title: Decentralized Synchronization and Sensorless Current Balancing in Parallel LLC Converters
authors: Orest Cobani, Benjamin Liang, Luca Bertolini, Olivier Trescases
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The rising demand for high-power battery chargers necessitates modular and scalable power conversion architectures. This paper presents a fully decentralized, sensorless synchronization scheme for multi-phase dc-dc resonant converters operating under charge control. The charge-control strategy is implemented using hysteretic control on the resonant capacitor voltage. The proposed method leverages the intrinsic relationship between switching frequency and the resonant capacitor's dc voltage, enabling each phase to autonomously adjust its hysteretic-control offset voltage and achieve frequency synchronization and output-current balancing without current sensors or centralized control. Experimental results from a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3-\text{kW}$</tex>, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$400{-}$</tex> V three-phase LLC converter prototype show that the proposed scheme maintains nearly identical operating frequencies across all phases and reduces worst-case current deviation by 72%, even with component mismatches over 20%. This demonstrates its suitability for high-power, modular power-conversion systems, such as EV chargers.

title: Study and Analysis of Components Stress Factor in Step-down Fractional Power Converters
authors: Omar Gsous, Ramy Georgious, Jorge García
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: A comparative study of three step-down configurations of Fractional Power Converters (FPC) in Input Series Output Parallel (ISOP) and Input Parallel Output Series (IPOS) formations, based on non-isolated essential buck and boost topologies. Key components' voltages and currents stresses are analytically derived and used to evaluate the Component Stress Factor (CSF). Furthermore, voltage gain and processed power ratio relations versus duty cycle are revised. Calculated CSF at four different duty ratios are compared against simulated values obtained by Piecewise Linear Electrical Circuit Simulation (PLECS). Step down FPC based on boost ISOP found to be an alternative to the full power buck at step-down ratios greater than 50 % in terms of efficiency and components ratings.

title: 4D monitoring of port areas through photogramemtry
authors: Sara Gonizzi Barsanti, Adriana Rossi
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: 3D surveying is crucial for recording, tracking, and examining artifacts, structures, and sites. Combining data from various sources is essential for achieving precise and reliable results. UAVs, due to their agility, are frequently employed for data collection in challenging terrains, and their lower cost compared to airplane surveys enables repeated data acquisition through regular missions, facilitating ongoing monitoring. This study outlines a project focused on monitoring a pier within Naples' port, a structure that has experienced morphological alterations over time due to powerful storm surges. Currently in its initial phase, the project seeks to establish a comprehensive 4D database, enabling intelligent and precise management of the pier and its surrounding area. A well-defined process was employed, involving the comparison of satellite imagery to pinpoint coastline alterations. UAV technology, coupled with close-range photogrammetry, was utilized to generate 3D models of the region, serving as the foundation for a 4D database. A thorough evaluation of the UAV survey results was conducted to determine the most effective workflow. The project's objective is to conduct annual drone flights, approximately at the same time each year, ensuring continuous and current monitoring.

title: Denoising Method for Underwater Point Cloud Data based on Pattern Mining
authors: Yi-Horng Lai, Hangyu Zhang, Kun Su
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Underwater 3D sonar point clouds, based on acoustic principles, are susceptible to noise interference. Compared to terrestrial laser point clouds, underwater point cloud data has disadvantages such as low resolution and high noise intensity. Underwater 3D sonar point cloud denoising technology can reduce the labored manual denoising load. In this study, the denoising method for underwater sonar 3D point cloud based on pattern mining is developed. Two algorithms (SOR and GMM) have cooperated to adaptively mine noise patterns such as underwater ambient noise, biological or suspended object noise, reverberation reflection signals, and self-mechanical noise. Two actual undersea experiments have verified that the proposed method can effectively remove multiple noises from underwater 3D sonar point clouds.

title: Canopy Height Estimation From MODIS Hotspot Direction Observations
authors: Lei Cui, Mei Sun, FangFang Luo, Yeting Lin
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Conventional canopy height mapping single-angle remote sensing approaches often suffer from limited information utilization and saturation effects, making it challenging to accurately capture the complex three-dimensional structure of forests. To address these issues, we propose a hotspot-driven multi-angle index that leverages the near-infrared-to-red band ratio of hotspot reflectances from a surface roughness perspective, thereby enhancing the representation of canopy height variations. Results have revealed the intended correlation between forest canopy height and surface roughness through the hotspot multi-angle index. Furthermore, the hotspot multi-angle index does not exhibit saturation as forest cover increases in real-world applications. There is a logarithmic relationship between this index and forest canopy height (R = 0.71, RMSE = 7.99 m), demonstrating its strong explanatory power and effectiveness in characterizing vertical forest structure. However, its effectiveness in representing canopy height is influenced by factors such as solar zenith angle (SZA) and terrain to some extent. Our results indicate that the explanatory ability of the index declines significantly at large SZA, such as 65° (R = 0.71 vs. 0.51); and large topographic variations can affect the performance of the multi-angle index in predicting forest canopy height, with 15° serving as a typical threshold. Overall, our findings highlight the potential of the hotspot-driven multi-angle index as a promising tool for large-scale forest canopy height mapping using multi-angle remote sensing observations.

title: Lightweight Dual-Encoder UNeXt for Remote Sensing Image Segmentation
authors: Chunxiu He, Yi Tang, Jiasheng Xu, Guoqing Zhou
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: With the continuous growth of remote sensing image data, improving computational efficiency while ensuring segmentation accuracy has become a core challenge in the field of semantic segmentation. To address this, a lightweight remote sensing image segmentation model based on a dual-encoder fusion is proposed in this paper. The model innovatively combines UNeXt with the RWKV-SAM encoder, aiming to achieve an optimized balance between model lightweighting and segmentation performance. By introducing the RWKV-SAM encoder, the global perception ability and computational efficiency of the UNeXt model are enhanced for processing high-resolution remote sensing images. Experimental results on remote sensing image datasets such as Vaihingen and LoveDA demonstrate that the proposed model significantly improves segmentation accuracy without a substantial increase in model parameters or computational complexity, especially excelling in boundary accuracy and detail restoration. Compared with the original UNext baseline, the improved model achieves a 10.35% increase in mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) on the Vaihingen dataset and a 7.26% improvement in Overall Accuracy (OA) on the LoveDA dataset.

title: PSRGS: Progressive Spectral Residual of 3D Gaussian For High-Frequency Recovery
authors: BoCheng Li, WenJuan Zhang, Bing Zhang, YiLing Yao, YaNing Wang
