publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: 3D Gaussian Splatting (3D GS) achieves impressive results in novel view synthesis for small, single-object scenes through Gaussian ellipsoid initialization and adaptive density control. However, when applied to large-scale remote sensing scenes, 3D GS faces challenges: the point clouds generated by Structure-from-Motion (SfM) are often sparse, and the inherent smoothing behavior of 3D GS leads to over-reconstruction in high-frequency regions, where have detailed textures and color variations. This results in the generation of large, opaque Gaussian ellipsoids that cause gradient artifacts. Moreover, the simultaneous optimization of both geometry and texture may lead to densification of Gaussian ellipsoids at incorrect geometric locations, resulting in artifacts in other views. To address these issues, we propose PSRGS, a progressive optimization scheme based on spectral residual maps. Specifically, we create a spectral residual significance map to separate low-frequency and high-frequency regions. In the low-frequency region, we apply depth-aware and depth-smooth losses to initialize the scene geometry with low threshold. For the high-frequency region, we use gradient features with higher threshold to split and clone ellipsoids, refining the scene. The sampling rate is determined by feature responses and gradient loss. Finally, we introduce a pre-trained network that jointly computes perceptual loss from multiple views, ensuring accurate restoration of high-frequency details in both Gaussian ellipsoids geometry and color. We conduct experiments on multiple datasets to assess the effectiveness of our method, which demonstrates competitive rendering quality, especially in recovering texture details in high-frequency regions.

title: A Novel Geometric Method for Reconstruction of NDVI During Cloudy Period Using Sentinel-1 & Sentinel-2
authors: Davoud Ashourloo, Francesca Devoto, Ruizhu Jiang, Yan Zhao, Andries Potgieter
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Cloud-induced gaps in optical satellite imagery hinder the continuous monitoring of vegetation dynamics using indices like NDVI. This study introduces a novel geometric-weighted method to reconstruct NDVI values during cloudy periods by leveraging cloud-free RVI data derived from Sentinel-1 radar imagery. The proposed method employs angular relationships between RVI vectors on neighboring clear-sky dates and the normal vector at the cloudy point to compute weighted contributions for NDVI reconstruction. The approach was applied to wheat fields in Iran (48 sites, 2021) and Australia (32 sites, 2022–2023). The method achieved the highest accuracy (RMSE = 0.020) when using two dates before and after the cloudy date. It performed best during early to mid-growth stages, with minimal error (RMSE = 0.014–0.021) in the first 60 days of the season. The proposed method showed a significant reduction in error (25% to 50%), offering a reliable solution for long-term vegetation monitoring under persistent cloud cover.

title: Power Management IC for Electric Vehicle Charging Stations Using E-Mode p-GaN HEMTs
authors: Andy Silva, Nataly Pozo, Luis-Miguel Prócel, Lionel Trojman
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: This paper presents the design of a compact Power Management Integrated Circuit (PMIC) utilizing 650 V Enhancement-mode (E-mode) p-GaN technology for medium power Electric Vehicles (EV) charging applications. The proposed PMIC achieves Integration Level 3 by incorporating a Pulse Width Modulation (PWM) generator, a two-stage fast gate driver, a high-voltage power switch, and a current-mirror sensor. Post-layout simulations conducted in Cadence Virtuoso assess the circuit's performance under varying temperature conditions. The PMIC operates at 1 MHz, with an output power of 1 kW and 97 % of efficiency. The PWM generator features a wide controllability range from 5 % to 95 % duty cycle, while the gate driver achieves rise and fall times of 9.45 ns and 14.5 ns, respectively. The total active area, including pads, measures <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.94 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex>.

title: Towards Both Robust and Concealed Backdoor Attack with Optimizing Trigger in Federated Learning
authors: Wei-Sheng Kao, Yi-Fan Li, Chih-Hung Wang
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 9th International Conference on Intelligent Systems, Metaheuristics & Swarm Intelligence
abstract: Federated learning (FL) is a decentralized framework for machine learning, and it can effectively protect participants’ data privacy during model training. However, recent studies have revealed that FL is susceptible to backdoor attacks. It is all the more reason that many detection and prevention approaches for the backdoor attacks in FL were proposed, which also causes the attack strategies to continue changing. This paper introduces an optimization-based distributed backdoor attack, which requires only a minimal number of malicious participants’ backdoors to be embedded into the model. The experimental results show that our method outperforms existing methods with respect to attack effectiveness and persistence, and successfully evades two anomaly detection methods specifically designed for discovering backdoor attacks.

title: Exploring PSO, ACO, and a Hybrid PSACO Approach: A Comparative Study for System Parameter Tuning
authors: Serda Hauser, Bogdan Franczyk
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 9th International Conference on Intelligent Systems, Metaheuristics & Swarm Intelligence
abstract: This study evaluates the use of Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), Ant Colony Optimization (ACO), and a hybrid PSACO approach to optimize system requirements in software development. In the face of the increasing complexity of modern software systems and the need for efficient development processes, this work evaluates these algorithms’ effectiveness, flexibility, and combination possibilities. PSO is characterized by rapid convergence and precise optimization of numerical parameters, while ACO is characterized by its ability to solve logical dependencies and discrete decision problems. The PSACO algorithm combines the strengths of both approaches to enable robust and, at the same time, precise solutions for mixed requirements. By applying simulation-based methodologies that use PSO, ACO, and PSACO to fifteen realistic functional system requirements, the study aims to identify optimal solutions.

title: Few for Many: Towards Efficient and Flexible Many-Objective Optimization
authors: Yilu Liu, Xi Lin, Liang Zhao, Qingfu Zhang
abstract: Many-objective optimization (MaO) can be found in many areas. Most current MaO methods aim to approximate the Pareto set or find a single trade-off solution. They could become infeasible when the number of objectives is large. Some recent studies have demonstrated the efficiency of using a few solutions to synergistically optimize many objectives. This paper further refines and extends this idea for MaO. Specifically, we formulate this idea as a conditional set-optimization problem, termed the few-for-many (F4M) problem. Its optimization objective, referred to as the synergistic optimization index (SOI), is compatible with any user-specified scalarization method, enabling this formulation to flexibly model diverse MaO scenarios. Then, we introduce two specific forms of SOI: linear SOI and Tchebycheff SOI, followed by a theoretical analysis of their optimization complexity, monotonicity, and supermodularity. To apply the F4M formulation to MaO, we develop a greedy estimation-of-distribution algorithm (GEDA) and further design a generic multi-objective test suite (GMOTS). Extensive experimental studies illustrate the ability of GEDA in solving both continuous and discrete MaO problems.

title: A Recycling-Driven Dynamic Budget Allocation Strategy for Human–Agent Collaboration
authors: Xinrui Tao, Yuping Tu, Jiadi Liu, Ying Wang, Fan Yang, Quyuan Wang
abstract: In the era of rapid artificial intelligence development, human–agent collaboration holds the potential to significantly enhance work efficiency. While existing studies have explored various collaboration strategies and resource methods, there remains a notable lack of in-depth research on how to economically allocate a limited budget to acquire both human and agent computing capacities. To address this gap, we first construct a developer model based on theories from psychology and economics, providing a quantitative description of human working time and efficiency. Building upon this, we further investigate the impact of dynamic budget allocation strategies on consumer decision-making. Specifically, a novel budget recycling mechanism is introduced to redistribute unused resources, thereby enhancing system responsiveness. Experimental results demonstrate a 56% improvement in resource utilization and a 32% increase in task completion. This confirms the effectiveness of our proposed method in optimizing collaboration and supporting sustainable project execution.

title: Accurate and Efficient Localization with a Uniaxial Rotating Permanent Magnet
authors: Jingyang Yun, Tao Chen, Deqiang Xiao, Hengzhuo Duan, Danni Ai, Jingfan Fan, Tianyu Fu, Yucong Lin, Hong Song, Jian Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Existing magnetic localization methods are often fall short to achieve the high accuracy and robustness. Therefore, we propose an accurate and efficient 6-DoF localization method using a uniaxial rotating permanent magnet. In the proposed method, a stepper motor and a permanent magnet are applied to produce the magnetic field containing the extremely low frequency (ELF) magnetic waves. Subsequently, the magnetic field and the pole orientation of permanent magnet are detected by a magnetic sensor and an encoder to collect the meta data of localization information. After that, the tracking algorithm is proposed to convert the meta data to the 3D position and orientation. The innovations of this method mainly contain three components: First, as the ELF magnetic waves are employed, the generated magnetic field with a wide range is able to be measured by the sensors under simplified hardware settings. Second, we apply the magnetic dipole model, combined with the geometric constraints derived from our uniaxial rotating structure design, to construct the analytic localization module of tracking algorithm to calculate the real-time 6-DoF localization. Third, the cross loss function is introduced into the localization refinement module of tracking algorithm to improve the method’s accuracy and reliability. Extensive experiments have been conducted to evaluate the proposed method. The results demonstrates its high localization accuracy over a large operation range, and robustness to magnetic interferences. Therefore, our approach outperforms the conventional methods and has a good potential for various tracking applications.

title: High-Quality Ultrafast Ultrasound Imaging with FPGA Implementation_supp2-3635821.avi
authors: Jianguo Ma
abstract: Ultrafast ultrasound imaging is essential for blood flow imaging. However, achieving an optimal balance between high frame rates and high image quality remains a challenge. Some advanced beamforming techniques can produce high-quality images, but often at the cost of reduced frame rates. In this work, we propose an FPGA-based beamforming method combining the sign multiplication coherence factor and simplified sign coherence factor (SMCF-sSCF), which achieves both high image quality and high frame rates. Meanwhile, the proposed beamformer is implemented on a 128-channel open ultrasound platform, supporting a maximum sub-aperture size of 64, and achieves dynamic focusing through a weighted vector. Simulation results show that, compared to conventional delay-and-sum (DAS), the SMCF-sSCF beamformer improves the contrast ratio (CR), the contrast-to-noise ratio (CNR), and the generalized contrast-to-noise ratio (gCNR) by 41.95%, 16.93%, and 4.89%, respectively, while reducing the full width at half maximum (FWHM) by 36.03%. In an open ultrasound platform, the SMCF-sSCF beamformer achieves a frame rate of 10,557 frames per second (fps) for 128×2048 images, corresponding to an output rate of 2.7 Gpixels/s. Furthermore, compared to a parallel DAS implementation, the resource consumption of LUTs, FFs, and DSPs increases by only 35.24%, 46.51%, and 33.33%, respectively.

title: High-Sensitivity Graphene-Based Terahertz Biosensor for Cervical Cancer Diagnosis: SVM-Assisted Optimization
authors: Hamza Ben Krid, Hamza Wertani, Aymen Hlali, Hassen Zairi
abstract: This work introduces a high-sensitivity graphene-based terahertz biosensor optimized using a support vector machine (SVM) approach for accurate cervical cancer diagnosis. The proposed structure demonstrates strong reconfigurability, with the resonance frequency shifting from 4.84 THz at <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu _{c} = 0~\text {eV}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> to 5.03 THz at <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu _{c} = 0.5~\text {eV}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>, confirming the efficient tunability enabled by graphene’s chemical potential. Sensitivity analysis reveals distinct responses for representative biomarkers, yielding 57.6, 76.9, 100.3, and 116.9 (GHz/RIU), respectively. To enhance predictive reliability, a SVM regression model was implemented, achieving an excellent coefficient of determination of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$R^{2} =0.978$</tex-math> </inline-formula>. After optimization, the predicted sensitivities improved to 93, 129.2, 171.4, and 231.6 (GHz/RIU), demonstrating the model’s capacity to accurately capture nonlinear dependencies between chemical potential, temperature, and relaxation time. These results confirm that modulation of graphene’s electronic properties plays a decisive role in resonance control and sensitivity enhancement, establishing a compact, label free, and machine-learning-assisted platform for early detection of cervical cancer.

title: Multiobjective Design Methodology of Series–Series Compensated Wireless Power Transfer Systems Considering Compensating Capacitance Tolerance
authors: Yinchao Liu, Wenxing Zhong
abstract: Series–series (SS) wireless power transfer (WPT) is widely adopted. However, the parameters of the resonant tanks have tolerances when facing mass production, which poses challenges for SS WPT systems to achieve rated output power and zero-voltage switching (ZVS) within the possible receiver (RX) position range. In this article, a tolerance-considered design methodology for SS WPT systems is proposed to ensure rated output power and ZVS in the designated RX position range. Detailed design procedures are introduced, and design constraints are provided in analytical form. Based on the proposed methodology, a 3.3 kW prototype system is designed and built, compared with a 3.3 kW reference system designed in the conventional way. The experimental results agree well with the theoretical predictions.

title: Secure and Robust Aggregation for Federated Learning with Dynamic User Update
authors: Hu Xiong, Yaxin Zhao, Hourui Deng, Erqiang Zhou, Chaosheng Feng, Abubaker Wahaballa
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: Existing secure aggregation schemes in federated learning (FL) face challenges related to detecting poisoning attacks and managing dynamic membership updates. To address these limitations, this article proposes a robust and dynamic aggregation framework for FL (RDFL), a robust and dynamic aggregation framework for FL. RDFL integrates a trimmed median algorithm with noninteractive range zero-knowledge proofs, providing a tunable mechanism for detecting abnormal updates. Client behavior is evaluated through a dynamic reputation scoring module, with malicious clients being added to a revocation list. By incorporating revocable attribute-based encryption, RDFL supports dynamic user management, ensuring that only authorized participants can access or update the global model. In addition, RDFL employs Shamir’s secret sharing and a pseudorandom double-masking scheme to maintain aggregation accuracy and protect communication privacy despite client dropouts. Experimental evaluations on the Extended MNIST (EMNIST) and CIFAR-100 datasets demonstrate that RDFL achieves strong security, communication efficiency, and model accuracy, making it suitable for FL involving a large number of clients with dynamic participation.

title: AutoHall: Automated Factuality Hallucination Dataset Generation for Large Language Models
authors: Zouying Cao, Yifei Yang, Xiaojing Li, Hai Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Audio, Speech and Language Processing
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have gained broad applications across various domains but still struggle with hallucinations. Currently, hallucinations occur frequently in the generation of factual content and pose a great challenge to trustworthy LLMs. However, hallucination detection is hindered by the laborious and expensive manual annotation of hallucinatory content. Meanwhile, as different LLMs exhibit distinct types and rates of hallucination, the collection of hallucination datasets is inherently model-specific, which also increases the cost. To address this issue, this paper proposes a method called AutoHall for Automatically constructing model-specific Hallucination datasets based on existing fact-checking datasets. The empirical results reveal variations in hallucination proportions and types among different models. Moreover, we introduce a zero-resource and black-box hallucination detection method based on self-contradiction to recognize the hallucination in our constructed dataset, achieving superior detection performance compared to baselines. Further analysis on our dataset provides insight into factors that may contribute to LLM hallucinations. Our codes and datasets are publicly available at https://github.com/zouyingcao/AutoHall.

title: Vetaverse: Technologies, Applications, and Visions toward the Intersection of Metaverse, AI, Vehicles, and Transportation Systems
authors: Peng Yuan Zhou, Jinjing Zhu, Yiting Wang, Yunfan Lu, Zixiang Wei, Haolin Shi, Yuchen Ding, Yu Gao, Qinglong Huang, Yan Shi, Ahmad Alhilal, Lik-Hang Lee, Tristan Braud, Pan Hui, Lin Wang
abstract: Since 2021, the term “Metaverse” has been the most popular, garnering much interest. Due to its contained environment and built-in computing and networking capabilities, a modern car makes an intriguing location to host its own little metaverse. Also, travelers don’t have much to do to pass the time while traveling, making them ideal customers for immersive services. Metaverseerse is envisioned as a blended immersive realm that scales to cities and countries, as digital twins of the intelligent Transportation Systems, referred to as “TS-Metaverse”, as well as customized XR services inside each Individual Vehicle, referred to as “IV-Metaverse”. The two subcategories serve fundamentally different purposes, namely longterm interconnection, maintenance, monitoring, and management on scale for large transportation systems (TS), and personalized, private, and immersive infotainment services (IV). By outlining the framework of Vetaverse and examining important AI and facilitating technologies, we reveal this impending trend. Lastly, we examine unresolved issues and potential routes for future study while highlighting some intriguing Vetaverse services.

title: A Minimal Subset Approach for Informed Keyframe Sampling in Large-Scale SLAM_supp1-3636035.mp4
authors: Nikolaos Stathoulopoulos
abstract: Typical LiDAR SLAM architectures feature a front-end for odometry estimation and a back-end for refining and optimizing the trajectory and map, commonly through loop closures. However, loop closure detection in large-scale missions presents significant computational challenges due to the need to identify, verify, and process numerous candidate pairs for pose graph optimization. Keyframe sampling bridges the front-end and back-end by selecting frames for storing and processing during global optimization. This article proposes an online keyframe sampling approach that constructs the pose graph using the most impactful keyframes for loop closure. We introduce the Minimal Subset Approach (MSA), which optimizes two key objectives: redundancy minimization and information preservation, implemented within a sliding window framework. By operating in the feature space rather than 3-D space, MSA efficiently reduces redundant keyframes while retaining essential information. Evaluations on diverse public datasets show that the proposed approach outperforms naive methods in reducing false positive rates in place recognition, while delivering superior ATE and RPE in metric localization, without the need for manual parameter tuning. Additionally, MSA demonstrates efficiency and scalability by reducing memory usage and computational overhead during loop closure detection and pose graph optimization.

title: Robust Viral RNA Sensing Using Non-Negative Matrix Factorization of Optical and Electrochemical Signals.
authors: Ranamay Saha, Sagnik Sarma Choudhury, Kapil Manoharan, Ekta Gupta, Shantanu Bhattacharya
abstract: Conventional nucleic acid methods often face challenges in achieving both high sensitivity and specificity for reliable detection of viral RNA. Reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) provides excellent sensitivity but fluorescence readouts often face ambiguity of detection at low template concentrations. Reverse transcription loop mediated isothermal amplification (RT-LAMP) integrated with electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) enables easy, cost effective, label-free detection and supports portable assays, however, non-specific impedance responses often reduce assay specificity. To overcome these limitations, we apply non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) as a post-processing strategy for heterogeneous biosensing signals. NMF decomposes data into physically interpretable latent components by enforcing non-negativity, making it well suited for effective amplification and detection analysis. Two datasets are analyzed: cycle-dependent fluorescence intensity from RT-PCR and frequency-dependent impedance magnitude from RT-LAMP EIS. NMF successfully discriminates amplification-specific contributions from residual noise, improving sensitivity in fluorescence data and specificity in electrochemical measurements. The resulting component scores enable robust classification of positive and negative samples achieving an overall sensitivity and specificity of 100% and 86.7%, outperforming conventional both optical and electrochemical schemes. Using hepatitis C virus RNA as a representative case, we demonstrate that non-negative decomposition framework offers a generalizable strategy for improving the accuracy of molecular diagnostics across diverse biosensing platforms.

title: Dual-Polarized Dielectric-filled Cavity Antenna with Air-Gap-Free Metasurface Loading for LTCC-based 5G-and-Beyond Antenna-in-Package Phased Arrays
authors: Yingqi Zhang, Stanislav Ogurtsov, Vasilii Vasilev, Artem R. Vilenskiy, Ahmed A. Kishk, Marianna V. Ivashina, Diego Caratelli
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This work introduces a dual-polarized (DP) slot-excited dielectric-filled cavity antenna phased array designed for 5G and beyond AiP solutions using low-temperature co-fired ceramic (LTCC) technology. The primary challenge is to maximize a two-dimensional (2-D) beamsteering range with a compact form factor in a DP operation. Most reported LTCC AiP arrays have ≤ 55° beamsteering range at 5G mmWave frequencies and lack experimental validation for DP 2-D beamsteering operation. In contrast, the proposed antenna element in the infinite array enables ±60° 2-D beamsteering in the 5G n261 (27.5-28.35 GHz) band with the form factor as small as 5mm×5mm×1.3mm. This performance is achieved by introducing a wide-angle impedance matching (WAIM) structure directly at the antenna aperture, comprising a dual-layer metasurface formed by periodically arranged electrically small patches in a staggered configuration. The antenna is jointly optimized with a DP feeding network to minimize parasitics in the multilayer LTCC stack and a co-integrated printed circuit board (PCB) carrier to mitigate package-carrier coupling often neglected in previous works. It is fabricated in a single LTCC process without air gaps to ensure precise layer-to-layer alignment and eliminate losses from additional support structures inherent to conventional air-gap WAIM stacks. A custom equivalent-circuit model enables efficient analysis of scan-dependent impedance matching for the optimization. A 128-element AiP prototype employs 4×4 subarrays of four DP elements on the PCB carrier and is packaged with ball grid arrays (BGAs) to facilitate integration. This modular approach allows scaling to large arrays while considering the critical effects of the package stack-up and DP feeding. The simulated active reflection coefficient is < -8.5 dB within ±60° (with a scan loss marginally above 3 dB) at 27.5-29.5 GHz. Measurements confirm simulations for all relevant performance metrics in ±60° 2D-range.

title: Text-Guided Semantic Alignment Network with Spatial-Frequency Interaction for Infrared-Visible Image Fusion under Extreme Illumination
authors: Guanghui Yue, Wentao Li, Cheng Zhao, Zhiliang Wu, Tianwei Zhou, Qiuping Jiang, Runmin Cong
abstract: Although text-guided infrared-visible image fusion helps improve content understanding under extreme illumination, existing methods usually ignore semantic differences between textual and visual features, resulting in limited improvement. To address this challenge, we propose a Text-Guided Semantic Alignment Network, termed TSANet, for extreme-illumination infrared-visible image fusion. The network follows an encoder-decoder structure, with two image encoders, two text encoders, and one decoder. It uses a Semantic Alignment and Fusion (SAF) block to bridge the two image encoders in each layer. Specifically, the SAF block consists of two parallel Semantic Alignment (SA) modules, corresponding to the infrared and visible modalities, respectively, and a Spatial-Frequency Interaction (SFI) module. The SA module aligns the visual feature from the image encoder with its corresponding textual feature from the text encoder, to guide the network focus on key semantic regions of infrared and visible images. The SFI module aggregates the spatial and frequency information extracted from the modality-aligned features of two SA modules for complementary representation learning. The network progressively complements two image modalities by connecting the SAF blocks from top to down, and finally provides a visually pleasing fusion effect by feeding the output of the last block into the decoder. Recognizing that existing datasets lack illumination diversity, we contribute a new dataset specifically designed for extreme-illumination image fusion. Extensive experiments show the effectiveness and superiority of TSANet over seven state-of-the-art methods. The source code and dataset are available at https://github.com/WentaoLi-CV/TSANet.

title: Community Detection-Based Renormalization Method for Power Grids Topology
authors: Dan Chen, Housheng Su, Hua Zhang
abstract: The cross-regional interconnections of the power system complicates the network topology behind it, which undoubtedly brings great computational challenges to the related simulation analysis. To address this issue, this article introduces an innovative framework for power grid topology renormalization based on the Louvain community detection algorithm. This framework aims to coarse-graining the original power grid into a smaller-scale network, thereby significantly simplifying its topology while preserving key properties. To validate the feasibility and effectiveness of this approach, we conducted extensive simulation experiments on a class of synthetic power grids and six real-world power grid datasets. The results demonstrate that the proposed method can nearly perfectly retain the critical structural characteristics and power flow properties of the original power grid during the renormalization process. From a practical application perspective, our findings provide a powerful tool for understanding and predicting the structural evolution and dynamical behavior of large-scale power grids.

title: Adaptive Digital Twin Synchronization: A Mechanism for Where, When, and What to Measure
authors: Zhiheng Yang, Francisco Vogt, Adam Belloum, Christian Rothenberg, Paola Grosso, Chrysa Papagianni
publish: Proceedings of the CoNEXT'25 Student workshop
abstract: Network Digital Twins (NDTs) require timely and cost-effective synchronization with physical networks. Existing telemetry and monitoring tools provide the plumbing to collect rich measurements and show potential for synchronizing the twin with its physical component. However, they lack a principled, fine-grained policy to identify and transmit only the necessary information, in order to save communication costs. In this paper, we present the idea of a Neural Measurement Field (NMF), a learning-based adapter that unifies where the measurements are taken (space/location), when they are updated (time), and what information is synchronized (content) into a single continuous intensity function, trained online to maximize decision utility under the budget.

title: Vivisecting Starlink Throughput: Measurement and Prediction
authors: Zikun Liu, Fan-Xue Gabriella Reidys, Sarah Tanveer, Deepak Vasisht
publish: Proceedings of the ACM on Networking
abstract: Internet connectivity using low earth orbit (LEO) satellites is gaining significant traction, with nearly 3 million users worldwide. While these networks promise to provide universal broadband connectivity, they suffer from large throughput fluctuations over short time scales. We conduct an extensive evaluation of Starlink's throughput across three devices in different countries, with measurement durations ranging from one to six months. We identify various factors that cause throughput variations at varying timescales. Given our analysis, we design StarNet, a new learning-based throughput prediction system. StarNet incorporates satellite network-specific insights and accurately predicts future throughput for end users. We demonstrate that StarNet's accurate predictions can improve the experience of end user applications like video streaming.

title: MorphOS: An Extensible Networked Operating System
authors: Peter Okelmann, Ilya Meignan-Masson, Masanori Misono, Pramod Bhatotia
publish: Proceedings of the ACM on Networking
abstract: This paper introduces MorphOS, a novel, extensible networked operating system that addresses the runtime inflexibility of unikernels for dynamic, stateful network-intensive applications like Virtual Network Functions (VNFs). While unikernels offer superior performance and minimal resource overheads, their traditional update mechanisms require costly rebuilds and restarts, leading to service disruption and state loss. MorphOS addresses this by integrating eBPF to enable dynamic, verified code execution for seamless updates to packet processing logic. It employs an out-of-band verification service to offload computationally intensive verification tasks and utilizes hardware-assisted memory isolation (Memory Protection Keys) for enhanced execution hardening. Our evaluation of MorphOS with four VNF implementations demonstrates significant benefits: MorphOS drastically reduces reconfiguration time, effectively amortizes verification costs, and achieves up to 3× better performance compared to Linux-based VNF deployments, all while preserving the inherent lightweightness of unikernels. MorphOS thus paves the way for adaptable, efficient, and state-preserving networked applications in cloud environments.

title: MIMRS: A Survey on Masked Image Modeling in Remote Sensing
authors: Shabnam Choudhury, Akhil Vasim, Michael Schmitt, Biplab Banerjee
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Masked Image Modeling (MIM) is a self-supervised learning technique that involves masking portions of an image, such as pixels, patches, or latent representations, and training models to predict the missing information using the visible context. This approach has emerged as a cornerstone in self-supervised learning, unlocking new possibilities in visual understanding by leveraging unannotated data for pre-training. In remote sensing, MIM addresses challenges such as incomplete data caused by cloud cover, occlusions, and sensor limitations, enabling applications like cloud removal, multi-modal data fusion, and super-resolution. By synthesizing and critically analyzing recent advancements, this survey (MIMRS) is a pioneering effort to chart the landscape of mask image modeling in remote sensing. We highlight state-of-the-art methodologies, applications, and future research directions, providing a foundational review to guide innovation in this rapidly evolving field.

title: Unveiling Key Drivers of Wheat Yield in Vidisha Region using Remote Sensing and Machine Learning
authors: Priyanka Goyal, Adway Mitra, Manjira Sinha
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Understanding the factors influencing crop yields is crucial for optimizing agricultural practices. Wheat, a cornerstone of global food security, plays a significant role in achieving the United Nations Sustainable Development Goal 2 (Zero Hunger). In India, wheat contributes 33.5% of the country’s total cereal production. Accurate and cost-effective yield predictions are essential for ensuring food security. This study presents a comprehensive framework for identifying the key drivers of wheat yield during the Rabi 2021 season in the Vidisha region using hybrid feature selection techniques. By leveraging data from Google Earth Engine (GEE), including remote sensing indices, soil properties, climatic variables, and productivity indicators, critical drivers such as the 90th percentile of Photosynthetically Active Radiation (PAR), nitrogen content, and 50th percentile of Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) were identified. These findings provide actionable insights for precision agriculture, enabling optimized input management and climate-resilient practices. The proposed framework demonstrates the potential of integrating hybrid feature selection with machine learning models for robust and scalable agricultural planning.

title: Quantifying Cotton Growth Rate from Multispectral UAV Imagery at Plot Scale
authors: Francesca Devoto, Davoud Ashourloo, Yan Zhao, Ruizhu Jiang, Rakesh Awale, Michael Bell, Tim McLaren, Sean Reynolds-Massey-Reed, Loren Otto, Michael Bange, William Woodgate, Scott Chapman, Andries Potgieter
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Cotton (Gossypium spp.) growth and yield are influenced by genetic, environmental, and management (G × E × M) interactions, requiring efficient and scalable monitoring tools to support timely management decisions. This study leverages remote sensing (RS) and structural vegetation indices (VIs) to develop algorithms for monitoring cotton growth dynamics and predicting morphological (i.e. height) and productivity (i.e. biomass and yield) traits. These tools support data-driven management strategies aimed at enhancing productivity and sustainability in cotton farming systems. The experiment was conducted at the University of Queensland’s Gatton campus during the 2023–2024 growing season. Direct observations included the canopy height and the dry matter from the biomass cuts, just prior to crop defoliation, to capture peak biomass conditions. Eight multispectral images from unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) were captured throughout the season. To address temporal gaps between UAV flights, we applied a Savitzky-Golay (SG) filter to fit growth curves for each plot and each VI. Derivative-Based functions were used on the fitted curves to generate the curve-derived metrics (CDMs). CDMs from both single and multiple dates of the OSAVI index were used as predictors into machine learning (ML) models for the final plant height (m), dry matter (Mg/ha), and yield (kg/ha), achieving strong predictive performance (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.85, 0.87, 0.84; RMSE = 0.05 m, 0.73 Mg/ha, and 118 kg/ha, respectively). Together, these results demonstrate that UAV-derived VIs and SG-based CSMs offer a scalable, accurate framework for real-time monitoring and prediction of key cotton traits—laying the groundwork for their integration into precision management and breeding programs.

title: Voltage Profile Based ANN Strategy for Optimal Distributed Generation Placement in Distribution Networks
authors: Manuel Jaramillo, Diego Carrioń, Jorge Munõz, Luis Tipán
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: This paper presents an efficient and scalable methodology for determining the optimal placement of distributed generation (DG) units in radial distribution systems using artificial neural networks (ANN). The proposed strategy aims to enhance voltage profiles and overall system performance while minimizing computational effort. Unlike traditional optimization techniques that require iterative power flow simulations, this approach leverages an ANN trained on voltage profile data from the IEEE 33-bus system to predict optimal DG locations across multiple configurations. After training, the model is validated on a structurally different IEEE 34-bus system to assess generalization capabilities. The ANN achieves $\mathbf{1 0 0 \%}$ classification accuracy in both training and test cases. Additionally, the method successfully identifies configurations that improve voltage stability, with deviations reduced by up to $4.2 \%$ in selected scenarios. The results confirm that the ANN-based method can efficiently classify and prioritize DG placement without exhaustive simulation, offering a promising solution for real-time planning in smart distribution grids.

title: Multi-Agent Geospatial Copilots for Remote Sensing Workflows
authors: Chaehong Lee, Varatheepan Paramanayakam, Andreas Karatzas, Yanan Jian, Michael Fore, Heming Liao, Fuxun Yu, Ruopu Li, Iraklis Anagnostopoulos, Dimitrios Stamoulis
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: We present GeoLLM-Squad, a geospatial Copilot that introduces the novel multi-agent paradigm to remote sensing (RS) workflows. Unlike existing single-agent approaches that rely on monolithic large language models (LLM), GeoLLM-Squad separates agentic orchestration from geospatial task-solving, by delegating RS tasks to specialized sub-agents. Built on the open-source AutoGen and GeoLLM-Engine frameworks, our work enables the modular integration of diverse applications, spanning urban monitoring, forestry protection, climate analysis, and agriculture studies. Our results demonstrate that while single-agent systems struggle to scale with increasing RS task complexity, GeoLLM-Squad maintains robust performance, achieving a 17% improvement in agentic correctness over state-of-the-art baselines. Our findings highlight the potential of multi-agent AI in advancing RS workflows.

title: Forest-Type Change Detection by Synergizing Multi-Source Remote Sensing Data in a Deep Learning Model FCCDNet
authors: Zongqi Yao, Lingting Lei, Guoqi Chai, Langning Huo, Xin Tian, Xiaoli Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This study introduces an end-to-end deep learning model (FCCDNet) for forest-type change detection using bi-temporal Sentinel-1 (S1) or Sentinel-2 (S2) images. FCCDNet consists of a parallel Swim Transformer backbone network, a feature aggregation module, and a multitask learning decoder. The trained model can produce maps highlighting the areas with a change on forest types, using a pre-event and post-event image pair, either S1-S1, S2-S2, S1-S2, or S2-S1. The performance was validated and demonstrated in southern Sweden between 2018 and 2023. FCCDNet achieved land cover classification accuracy of 93.26% and change detection accuracy of 90.56% when using S2-S2 pair, significantly outperforming four other algorithms tested. When using S1-S2, S2-S1, or S1-S1 pairs, changes can also be detected but with lower accuracy (65.94% - 76.68%). The results show that FCCDNet can achieve forest change detection with higher accuracy than commonly used methods, and can tolerate certain levels of replacement from multispectral images to SAR images in cloudy conditions. The FCCDNet model also showed robustness against salt-and-paper effects of mapping and exhibited sensitivity to changes with smaller amplitude. The FCCDNet model and data processing framework could support the dynamic monitoring of forest resources with high automation and fast response.

title: Exploring the Impact of Volcanic Activity on Surface Deformation Using SBAS-InSAR Technology
authors: Yuan Cai, Hongguo Zhang, Binbin He
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Volcanic eruptions are highly destructive natural geological hazards, often accompanied by lava flows and gas emissions, which lead to surface deformation. The Lewotobi volcano erupted again on December 23, 2023. To investigate the impact of volcanic eruptions on surface deformation, this study employs multi-temporal Sentinel-1A data and the Small Baseline Subset Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar (SBAS-InSAR) technique to monitor temporal changes in surface deformation in the Lewotobi volcano region one year before and after its first eruption. The results indicate that continuous volcanic activity leads to surface subsidence or collapse, while large explosive eruptions are associated with widespread surface uplift prior to the event.

title: Integrative Use of C- and L-Band SAR Data over European sites
authors: Francesco Mattia, Anna Balenzano, Giuseppe Satalino, Davide Palmisano, Antonella Belmonte, Carsten Montzka, Mehdi Rahmati, Michele Rinaldi, Sergio Ruggieri, Deodato Tapete, Julia Kubanek
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of C-and L-band Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data in estimating surface soil moisture (SSM). The dataset consists of approximately 650 images obtained from various sources, including the European Radar Observatory (Sentinel-1), the Advanced Land Observing Satellite-2 (ALOS-2), and the Satélite Argentino de Observación COn Microondas (SAOCOM). These images were acquired between 2019 and 2024 at two European locations: the Apulian Tavoliere (AT) in Italy and the Rur catchment in Germany. In situ SSM data, collected from both permanent and temporary ground station networks, are available along with information on crop cover and other auxiliary data. An initial analysis on a subset of 119 images found a root mean square error (RMSE) of 0.06 m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> and a Pearson correlation coefficient (R) of approximately 0.6.

title: SiC MOSFET Condition Monitoring Using Compensated ON-State Resistance for Identifying Package Failures
authors: Bhanu Pratap Singh, Shahriar Sarmast Ghahfarokhi, Enes Ayaz, Hans-Peter Nee, Staffan Norrga
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper presents a condition monitoring approach for SiC MOSFET devices by compensating the ON-state resistance (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R_{\text {dson }}$</tex>) to effectively detect package-related failures. While <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R_{\text{dsON}}$</tex> is a promising health indicator, its strong dependence on junction temperature (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$T_{\mathbf{j}}$</tex>) and threshold voltage (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{\text {th }}$</tex>) can obscure degradation signals. This study proposes compensation techniques to mitigate the influence of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$T_{\mathrm{j}}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{\text {th }}$</tex> drift, enabling reliable monitoring. The methodology is validated using a custom-designed power cycling test bench, in compliance with AQG-324, to stress SiC MOSFETs under controlled thermal conditions. Two <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R_{\text {dson }}$</tex> drift compensation methods are compared to analyze the evolution of compensated <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R_{\text{dSON}}$</tex>: a moving polynomial fit (Method 1) and a derivative-based technique with post-filtering (Method 2). Results show that both methods can differentiate between linear (die-level degradation) and non-linear (package-related failure) regions of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R_{\text {dsON }}$</tex> drift. However, Method 1 provides more stable estimates with lower noise, especially for smaller window sizes. The findings support the use of compensated <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R_{\text{dSON}}$</tex> as a practical and robust condition monitoring parameter for SiC MOSFET reliability assessment.

title: Adversarial Feature Disentanglement for Semi-Supervised Heterogeneous Domain Adaptation
authors: Giuseppe Guarino, Cássio F. Dantas, Dino Ienco, Raffaele Gaetano, Gemine Vivone, Matteo Ciotola, Giuseppe Scarpa
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Semi-supervised domain adaptation methods aim to generalize from a labeled source domain to a scarcely labeled target domain, despite potential distribution shifts. This challenge becomes even more complex when the source and target data differ in modality representation, such as when acquired using sensors with varying characteristics. In remote sensing, for example, data may differ in acquisition modes (e.g., optical vs. radar), spectral properties (e.g., RGB vs. multispectral), or spatial resolution. This scenario, known as Semi-Supervised Heterogeneous Domain Adaptation (SSHDA), introduces additional challenges due to the heightened distribution shift caused by modality heterogeneity. This work builds upon SHeDD (Semi-supervised Heterogeneous Domain Adaptation via Disentanglement), a recently proposed method for SSHDA, adapting it to address a more challenging scenario where the target domain has extremely limited labeled data. By introducing a novel adversarial module to compel the domain-invariance of features and incorporating a mean teacher approach to improve pseudo-labeling, the enhanced framework demonstrates robust and stable performances. Empirical evaluations on a well-known remote sensing benchmark for scene classification involving heterogeneous data (radar-multispectral) show that the proposed method outperforms both its predecessor and state-of-the-art competitors. Our code is publicly available at https://github.com/giu-guarino/A-SHeDD.

title: Structured Data Flow and Multi-Level Access Control for Landfill Smart Weighing System
authors: Siti Sendari, Qurrotul A’ini, Danang Arengga Wibowo, Yuni Rahmawati, Fadila Claudia Pramesti, Bakhrul Mukhid, Mochamad Farhan Ali Irfani, Mukaromah, Aan Anjar Setyowati, Syamsul Bachri, Norrima Mokthar
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: Current digital landfill monitoring systems suffer from unstructured data flow and poor access control, which may weaken data precision, security, and decision-making. A digital weighing system is already used at the Supit Urang Landfill in Malang, Indonesia, to record incoming waste. However, operational inefficiencies persist, especially in how users manage and share information. Therefore, a smart weighing system with structured data flow and secure access control is needed. This study aims to increase the reliability and security of the system by looking at the data flow and the user privilege system. The research process involves identifying the user roles and system requirements through a Use Case Diagram, followed by Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) in order to clearly define access privileges. These data access control rules and roles are then conveyed into specific processes in Data Flow Diagrams, illustrating the flow of data between layers and user activity control. The system was evaluated using access accuracy metrics and simulated misuse scenarios through negative testing. Results show that integrating access control with structured data flow enhances data integrity and user accountability. The system achieved an Access Accuracy Rate (AAR) of 93.3% and an Access Violation Rate (AVR) of 6.3%, indicating robust enforcement of permission boundaries.

title: Area-Time Efficient Hardware Design for Crystals-Dilithium
authors: Hien Nguyen, Tuy Tan Nguyen
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: CRYSTALS-Dilithium (Dilithium), a digital signature scheme based on lattice cryptography, has recently been designated as a standard for post-quantum digital signatures by the National Institute of Standards and Technology. Known for its strong security guarantees and efficient use of polynomial arithmetic, Dilithium offers a promising foundation for futureproof digital signatures. However, implementing such latticebased schemes in hardware introduces significant challenges due to the high computational demands and structural complexity of their core operations. To overcome these issues, this work focuses on optimizing Dilithium for field-programmable gate arrays (FPGAs), which offer substantial potential for performance gains through parallelism and customized architectural design. We introduce a novel hardware design that improves performance and area by employing a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 \times 2$</tex> butterfly number-theoretic transform capable of computing two transform stages per cycle, along with a conflict-free memory subsystem that leverages pipelined coefficient rearrangement and an address resolution mechanism to ensure continuous data access. Evaluation on an Xilinx Versal Premium FPGA shows that our design enhanced resource utilization and performance, reaching 328 MHz and an area-time product of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5. 4}$</tex> KLUTs <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\times \mathbf{m s}$</tex> at security level <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2}$</tex>.

title: Indoor Lidar Relocalization Using Deep Pose Regression and a 3D Model Based on Difference Detection
authors: Hang Zhao, Yang Yi
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: LiDAR relocalization has become a crucial component across multiple disciplines, such as robotics and automation, navigation and localization, and sensor networks, driven by significant advancements in computational capacity and a marked reduction in the costs of LiDAR scanners. In indoor environments, the low availability of global navigation satellite systems (GNSS) poses a challenge for LiDAR relocalization. Current LiDAR relocalization methods rely on a large dataset of real LiDAR scans or synthetic LiDAR scans to train a pose regression network. However, Acquiring a large set of real LiDAR scans with exact ground truth poses is costly. Moreover, synthetic LiDAR scans differ from real LiDAR scans, which introduce large relocalization errors. To address these problems, this paper proposes a novel LiDAR relocalization method implementing a 3D model and deep pose regression networks based on difference detection. The proposed method applies a coarse-to-better strategy. In the coarse relocalization phase, the initial pose of the LiDAR scanner will be estimated using an off-the-shelf pose estimation method. Then, the estimated pose will be used to generate a synthetic LiDAR scan using a low-detail 3D model, which only contains main structural surfaces. A difference detection network will be applied to detect differences between the synthetic LiDAR scan and the real LiDAR scan, and therefore, the pose regression network will mask the points representing differences and only focus on the same parts. Experiential results show that our proposed method outweighs previous pose regression networks trained with original synthetic LiDAR scans.

title: An Elaborate and Fast Large-Scale Phase Unwrapping Method for InSAR
authors: Yang Lan, Wenxin Cui
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: For the demand of solving large-scale phase unwrapping (PU) in synthetic aperture radar interferometry (InSAR) technology, one of the relatively mature methods is to first divide the interferogram into sub-interferograms, and then solve each sub-interferogram separately and splice them together to obtain the PU result. To improve the processing speed, one of the strategies is to generate convex hull regions that can enclose dense residues and then abandon solving these regions to reduce the computational load. However, this method also decreases the utilization of effective information in the discarded regions. In this paper, we propose an elaborate and fast large-scale phase unwrapping method (EFLS). Based on the quality map, EFLS divides the sub-interferograms into high-quality and low-quality regions. By modifying the constraint conditions of the optimization model, it prevents the errors in the low-quality regions from spreading to the high-quality regions, thus solving the problem of solution accuracy in traditional mask-based methods. It masks the low-quality regions and only solves the high-quality regions, improving both the processing efficiency and information utilization while ensuring the solution accuracy.

title: Screening and Artifact Detection of RFI Based on Time-Series SAR Images Using Change Detection Techniques
authors: Zhizheng Zhang, Gaofeng Shu, Ning Li, Dan Huang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: As a wideband radar system, spaceborne synthetic aperture radar (SAR) is susceptible affected by other high-power radiation sources, which can cause radio frequency interference (RFI) artifacts in ground observations. Given that RFI significantly impacts data processing and image interpretation, screening and artifacts detection of RFI have become top priorities for spaceborne SAR systems which generate massive data daily. In this paper, a novel screening and artifacts detection method based on change detection techniques is proposed. Due to the time-varying feature of RFI artifacts in time-series SAR images, local areas affected by RFI can be masked by the change detection operator. The screening step is performed by quantifying the feature differences between RFI artifacts and ground-truth information, and an RFI-free background is constructed based on the results, enabling effective artifacts detection of RFI-containing images. Experimental results of Sentinel-1A products indicates that the method can accurately screen RFI-containing images from massive time-series images and effectively detect the location of RFI artifacts.

title: CIT: A Cross-Modal Interaction Transformer Network Based on Multi-Source Remote Sensing Images
authors: Zhonghuai Zhou, Liansong Zhang, Linxin Wang, Hongtao Shi, Fengkai Lang, Jinqi Zhao
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Semantic segmentation of remote sensing images is crucial for land cover classification. Optical and synthetic aperture radar (SAR) images provide complementary information by reflecting the characteristics of different land cover types from varying perspectives. However, these images belong to different modalities, leading to discrepancies and irrelevancy in representing ground objects, complicating multimodal semantic segmentation. In this paper, we propose a novel cross-modal interaction Transformer (CIT) network that facilitates information exchange and adaptive fusion of optical and SAR images, which addresses the feature alignment discrepancies in different scenes. To validate the effectiveness of our proposed method, we conducted experiments on the publicly available Pohang dataset. Our results demonstrate that the proposed CIT achieves a mean intersection over union (mIoU) of 93.27% and an overall accuracy (OA) of 97.06% on the Pohang dataset.

title: Investigation of Surface Reflectance Reconstruction Considering Topography Over Mountainous Areas
authors: Wentao Yu, Shanxin Guo, Jingwen Wang, Juan Cheng, Jinsong Chen
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Seamless surface reflectance is essential in facilitating time-series analysis and deep learning applications using high-resolution remote sensing data. Despite numerous efforts to develop methods to reconstruct time series surface reflectance, attention is rarely focused on mountainous areas. In this study, we aim to generate seamless surface reflectance in mountainous areas with consideration of topography. An integrated framework with topographic correction and time series modeling based on the harmonized Landsat Sentinel-2 dataset (HLS) has been developed. First, we removed the spatiotemporal varying terrain effects in HLS reflectance using topographic correction methods. Then, we modeled the corrected reflectance time series using harmonic analysis to fill gaps and remove outliers. Finally, we generated seamless reflectance using the constructed time series model. We evaluated the generated seamless reflectance and compared the performance of different TOC methods. The results demonstrated that the proposed framework with the PSC method is superior in the generation of surface reflectance images with better elimination of terrain textures in winter seasons.

title: Grid-Forming Applied to Converter-Dominated Marine Power Systems in Offshore Applications
authors: Antonio Zambrano, Andres Tarraso, Alvaro Luna
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: In recent years, zero-emission boats using shipboard microgrids have become common in shallow-water applications like tugboats and ferries. However, deep-water applications, including cargo ships and offshore vessels, still rely on multifuel combustion engines. As land power grids evolve with more renewable resources by shifting to converter-dominated systems, the same approach has a potential impact on the marine power systems as well, presenting both pros and cons. The paper discusses how converter-dominated power systems can improve marine power systems in offshore operations, which face challenges like large pulsed power loads, limited space, and maritime conditions. Key benefits include seamless blackout recovery, reduced power system stress, and increased operability. Energy storage systems managing peak consumption offer additional space for other loads, highlighting the importance of converter technology in improving the resilience and efficiency of future marine power systems.

title: Cross-City Solar Power Prediction: Feature Reduction and ML Model Comparison
authors: Joanne Gomes, Ekta Desai, Jignesh Patel
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Accurate solar power prediction is crucial for renewable energy management and smart grid optimization. Many studies have used high-dimensional weather data to improve forecast accuracy, however, these approaches often introduce challenges such as increased computational complexity and noise from irrelevant or redundant features. This study explores the enhancement of solar power prediction using a reduced, highly relevant feature set derived from a combination of four feature selection methods and evaluates its effect on cross-city projections through transfer learning. Using various ML algorithms, we then evaluate the prediction performance in both same-city and cross-city scenarios. Our findings reveal that in same-city projections, reducing the feature set to 50% yields minimal loss in accuracy. For cross-city projections, transfer learning enhances model adaptability, achieving an improved performance with the reduced feature set compared the full set. This novel combination of feature reduction and transfer learning not only simplifies computational requirements but also lowers data collection and preprocessing costs, making predictive models more scalable. These findings provide actionable insights, showcasing a new approach to robust and interpretable solar power forecasting that has not been explored in this way before.

title: Multi-angle Radiometer at X- to Ku-bands For Snow Depth Estimation: Synthetic, Ground-based and Airborne Experiments
authors: Jinmei Pan, Lingmei Jiang, Chuan Xiong, Guangjin Liu, Jiancheng Shi, Feng Zhao, Jinbiao Zhu, Zhanxiao Yan, Yanxing Hu, Lifu Wang, Siyuan Du, Jiahao Wang, Shuhao Huang, Gongxue Wang, Jingtian Zhou, Wei Ma, Xiaowen Gao, Xudong Li, Liang Yuan, Wenhui Wang, Jing Wang, Bo Liu, Yucheng Gong, Juha Lemmetyinen
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The advancement of synthetic aperture radiometer technology enables the deployment of multi-angle radiometers at high frequencies for snow depth estimation. In this paper, we analyzed the characteristics and sensitivity of multi-angle brightness temperature to snow depth, and conducted snow depth retrieval experiments utilizing both model-simulated and ground-based radiometer observed datasets. Results showed that, compared to the X-Ka brightness temperature (TBD) at a single angle, the angular difference of the X-Ka TBD at vertical polarization exhibits a stronger correlation with snow depth. Employing the Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) method, we successfully retrieved snow depth and snow grain size simultaneously in both the synthetic and the ground-based experiments. In the end, we briefly introduced the Altay Airborne Snow Experiment 2025, which involves the observation of snow in the Altay foreland plain and mountainous regions through the use of multi-angle radiometers operating at the X, Ku, and Ka bands.

title: Downscaling NPP-VIIRS Nighttime Light Data Based On Generative Adversarial Networks
authors: Weihua Lin, Weixing Xu, Zhaocong Wu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Nighttime light (NTL) data captured from the Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite (VIIRS) aboard the Suomi National Polar-orbiting Partnership (Suomi NPP) satellite have provided invaluable support for Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). However, the NPP-VIIRS NTL data suffer from relatively coarse spatial resolution (15 arcsec), limiting their potential for finer-scale applications. In this study, we constructed a NTL Downscaling Generative Adversarial Network (NTL-DSGAN) model utilizing NPP-VIIRS NTL data and multi-source spatial variables, resulting in the creation of yearly GAN-based 130-meter downscaled NPP-VIIRS (DSGAN-VIIRS) NTL data for Shanghai. When validated against 130-meter Loujia1-01 NTL imagery, our DSGAN-VIIRS NTL imagery effectively mitigates the blooming effect compared to the 500-meter NPP-VIIRS NTL data, demonstrating improved data quality. Furthermore, the DSGAN-VIIRS NTL data show stronger correlation with socioeconomic indicators, yielding higher coefficient of determination (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) values than those of NPP-VIIRS NTL data, which is comparable to or even exceeds the performance of Luojia1-01 NTL data. Therefore, our proposed NTL-DSGAN method advances the spatial resolution of NPP-VIIRS NTL data, potentially facilitating refined applications related to SDGs.

title: SAR-W-MixMAE: SAR Foundation Model Training Using Backscatter Power Weighting
authors: Ali Caglayan, Nevrez Imamoglu, Toru Kouyama
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Foundation model approaches such as masked autoencoders (MAE) or its variations are now being successfully applied to satellite imagery. Most of the ongoing technical validation of foundation models have been applied to optical images like RGB or multi-spectral images. Due to difficulty in semantic labeling to create datasets and higher noise-like content (speckle) with respect to optical images, Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data has not been explored a lot in the field for foundation models. Therefore, in this work as a pre-training approach, we explored masked auto-encoder, specifically MixMAE [1] on Sentinel-1 SAR images and its impact on SAR image classification tasks. Moreover, we proposed to use the physical characteristic of SAR data for applying weighting parameter on the auto-encoder training loss (MSE) to reduce the effect of speckle and very high values on the SAR images. Proposed SAR intensity-based weighting of the reconstruction loss demonstrates promising results both on SAR pre-training and downstream tasks specifically on flood detection compared with the baseline model.

title: Innovative Technologies for Non-Invasive Assessment of Plant Health Condition to Support Precision Farming
authors: Maurizio Migliaccio, Giuseppe Mazzarella, Francesco Prudenzano, Andrea Buono, Alessandro Fanti, Francesco Anelli, Emanuele Setale, Luigi Di Michele, Samiullah Yousaf, Mario Latronico
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In this study, the advancements of the InnoVative tEchnoloGies for non-invasivE assessmenT of plAnt healTh conditIon to support precisiOn farmiNg (VEGETATION) experimental research project, coordinated by the University of Naples Parthenope in collaboration with the University of Cagliari and the Polytechnical University of Bari, are reported. The main objective is to investigate the ability of new electromagnetic solutions to boost localized or ultra-localized millimeter wave and optical measurements in the framework of precision farming to improve the information retrieval about plant health. The electromagnetic solutions consist of exploring the potential of millimeter waves to provide information about the leaf water content and sap flow in individual plants and of mid-infrared waves to get information about the presence of pesticides on the leaves.The above-mentioned theoretical electromagnetic solutions will be implemented and experimentally verified in controlled indoor environments to fairly analyze their strengths and weaknesses and, therefore, to pave the way towards a potential reliable proof-of-concept of a sensing setup on the field, i. e., to be installed, for instance, onboard a tractor bar.

title: Transformer-Based Radar and Infrared Sensor Fusion for Multi-Target Tracking
authors: Linao Zhan, Xiaolong Wan, Sinuo Zheng, Xinwei Wei, Wei Yi
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Deep learning (DL) methods, which bypass the need for explicit models and can capture intricate relationships within data, are attracting growing interest in the model-free multi-target tracking (MTT) domain. However, relatively few studies have applied deep learning methods to MTT based on heterogeneous sensor fusion. This paper introduces a fusion queries generation mechanism for integrating heterogeneous sensor data, enabling an end-to-end multi-target tracking (MTT) method called RIFT (Radar and Infrared sensor Fusion tracking with Transformer). The method leverages continuous multi-frame infrared (IR) measurement sequences to capture detailed target orientation motion characteristics and mitigate the impact of missed angle measurements resulting from mutual occlusion among targets. Specifically, we employed an encoder-decoder architecture to process the radar measurement sequences to generate initial state estimates, which are then combined with IR data in the fusion queries mechanism to update azimuth estimations and produce fusion queries. These queries guide the radar decoder to predict subsequent target states, enabling iterative regression that fully exploits multi-sensor inputs to achieve a high-accuracy, continuous MTT method. Simulation results show that our proposed algorithm outperforms the traditional sequential filtering and existing state-of-the-art Transformer-based MTT methods.

title: Application of Categorical Triple Collocation in Soil Freeze-thaw Product Merging
authors: Xiaoci Wang, Linna Chai, Hongjing Cui, Shaojie Zhao
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Soil freeze/thaw (FT) cycling is highly sensitive to temperature variations, but existing soil FT products often exhibit pronounced temporal and spatial inconsistencies, with considerable accuracy variations among different products, limiting their reliability and stability. These challenges are particularly significant in regions like Northeast China and the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau (QTP), where climatic and geographical complexities further hinder the production of high-accuracy soil FT products. This study applies a categorical triple collocation (CTC)-based merging method to merge multi-source soil FT products (SMAP, ESDR, ERA5) from 2018 to 2020, fully accounting for nonstationary classification errors in original products. Validation using meteorological stations and six dense in-situ observation networks demonstrates that the merged product achieves more stable classification accuracy than the original products, consistently ranking among the top two in performance at most sites. This stability highlights the method's ability to reduce the impact of temporal/spatial heterogeneity in the original products. The proposed approach enhances the reliability of soil FT products and provides a robust framework for merging multi-source soil FT and other categorical variable products in related fields, particularly on a global scale where ground observation data remains sparse.

title: Polarization Orientation Angle Estimation from Vegetated Hilly Areas Based on a Polarimetric Decomposition Technique
authors: Yanpeng Li, Shiyu Luo, Fanghong Xiao, Qi Li, Ling Tong
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Polarization information correction is essential in the pre-processing step in full-polarization synthetic aperture radar (SAR) measurement over mountainous areas. Generally, polarization data correction is achieved based on polarization orientation angle (POA), which is commonly estimated from a polarimetric scattering matrix. However, many studies show that the estimation of POA from vegetated hilly areas is not satisfactory since the de-correlation characteristics of vegetation severely affect polarimetric scattering information. To address this problem, we propose a new POA estimation method for vegetated hilly areas based on the seven-component scattering power decomposition model (7SD). First, the ratio of the oriented dipole scattering power P<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">od</inf> related to uneven terrains derived by the 7SD is estimated over vegetated flat areas, which is then used to calculate the real ratio of P<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">od</inf> over mountainous vegetated areas. Second, a few possible POA values are estimated by the ratio of P<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">od</inf>. Third, the correct POA is selected using a neighborhood comparison algorithm. The experiment on a real full-polarization SAR image acquired from a mountainous area shows the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Linear Structure Recognition Algorithm Based on UAV Color Point Cloud
authors: Chen Jie, Sang Xuejia, Liu Dunlong
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Accurate identification of linear structures is crucial for terrain feature recognition. Traditional identification methods rely on manual observation, which are time-consuming, labor-intensive, and susceptible to subjective bias. Therefore, developing an efficient, accurate, and safe method for linear structure recognition holds significant practical importance and application value. This study proposes a linear structure recognition algorithm based on colored point clouds. The algorithm fully leverages high-quality 3D colored point cloud data acquired by UAVs, integrating geometric features and color information to achieve efficient and precise identification of linear structures. Methodologically, the approach begins with preprocessing of the colored point cloud and applies DBSCAN clustering based on color features to extract potential structural regions. Subsequently, local curvature and normal vector information are used to filter the initially detected structural areas. Finally, a region growing algorithm is employed to optimize the preliminary detection results, further enhancing the accuracy and completeness of the recognition.

title: YMCNet: Enhanced SAR Ship Detection in a Range-Compressed Domain Based on Structured State-Space
authors: Zutong Wen, Ke Ma, Huiyao Wan, Jie Chen, Wei Yang, Jie Chen, Zhixiang Huang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In recent years, convolutional neural network–based ship detection in SAR images has made remarkable strides. However, applying conventional SAR detection methods to extensive ocean regions can lead to excessive storage and computational overhead. Range-compressed domain imaging addresses this issue by offering efficient data compression at the acquisition stage. In this paper, we present YMCNet, a method that leverages multi-domain feature extraction for ship detection in the range-compressed domain. Specifically, we note that ship targets in this domain often have large aspect ratios, meaning conventional CNN receptive fields may fail to capture global information effectively. Therefore, drawing on Mamba, we propose a backbone network that enlarges the pixel receptive area, facilitating better long-distance feature extraction and enhancing target representations. Additionally, we introduce an L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">RC</inf> loss function that combines scattering-intensity-weighted and edge-enhancement loss terms, guiding the network to extract hazy target edges in SAR images. Experimental results on the public RCShip dataset show that YMCNet achieves significant improvements in both accuracy and speed compared with existing deep learning models.

title: Research on Electric Tower Detection Method Based on Improved YOLOv11
authors: Siao Liu, Ye Tian, Jianyu Wang, Lei Chen, Hongwei Li, Yihuan Li
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Aiming at the problems of small scale, vulnerability to complex background interference, and low recognition accuracy of electric towers in high resolution remote sensing satellite images, this paper proposes an improved YOLOv11-based detection method. Building upon the YOLOv11 architecture, a novel C2f_C3 fusion convolutional module is designed to enhance the backbone network's capability for semantic feature extraction and structural stability. Additionally, DCNv4 is optionally integrated into the feature aggregation stage of the fusion module to improve the model’s perception of electric towers under varying scenarios, thereby increasing adaptability and robustness. Considering the unique structural characteristics of electric towers, the multi-scale feature detection layer is reconstructed to better capture semantic and locational features of small targets. The model is trained and evaluated on a custom dataset, and detection experiments are conducted in transmission corridor areas. Experimental results show that the proposed method achieves an average precision of 0.923 in electric tower detection, which is 3.2% higher than the baseline YOLOv11. Furthermore, it outperforms other methods such as Mask R-CNN and YOLOv8, demonstrating superior overall performance. This approach offers effective support for high-precision electric tower detection in remote sensing imagery.

title: Forest Volume Estimation in Southern China Border Areas Using High-Resolution Optical Satellite Imagery and Airborne LiDAR Data
authors: Shili Meng, Yong Pang, Wen Jia, Zhen Li, Chungan Li
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Forests are essential carbon sinks, regulating the Earth's carbon balance, with forest stock volume serving as a key indicator of forest resource quality and quantity. Remote sensing technologies such as optical, SAR and LiDAR technology, are considered effective methods for estimating forest stock volume. However, challenges persist, particularly in regions with limited LiDAR data. This study employs high-resolution optical imagery combined with LiDAR data to estimate forest stock volume along the southern border of China (Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region). By extracting optical features (spectral bands, vegetation indices and texture indices) and integrating them with machine learning models, we estimate forest stock volume across various species and regions.
