Our results demonstrate a strong correlation between optical-based estimates and LiDAR-derived volumes, with texture features proving most influential in improving accuracy. However, high-stock regions (>150 m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>/ha) are prone to underestimation, highlighting the limitations of optical remote sensing in such contexts. This study provides an effective methodology for forest stock volume estimation in border regions where LiDAR data is scarce, offering insights for broader applications in forest resource management and environmental monitoring.

title: Frequency Hopping Interference DOA Estimation Method Based on Difference Frequency
authors: Yongjia Dou, Yuqi Wang, WenHua Li, Wenkang Liu, Guangcai Sun, Mengdao Xing
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Frequency hopping (FH) interference, characterized by its complex modulation and low probability of intercept, presents significant challenges in parameter estimation. This paper proposes a novel method for the direction-of-arrival (DOA) estimation of non-cooperative FH interference based on difference frequency processing (DFP). The method transforms the DOA estimation of FH signals into that of single-frequency signals, significantly reducing computational complexity and laying a foundation for effective interference suppression. The approach begins by classifying FH pulse signals based on their carrier frequencies. Next, the DFP technique is employed to extract the difference-frequency signal, effectively aligning the carrier frequencies of each pulse and eliminating intra-pulse modulation. Coherent accumulation is then performed to enhance signal quality, followed by the application of the MUSIC algorithm for DOA estimation. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

title: Special Session Paper: Application of Functional Verification Techniques in Hardware Trust
authors: Mohammad Reza Heidari Iman, Rolf Drechsler, Chandan Kumar Jha, Ali Azarpeyvand, Tara Ghasempouri, Sharjeel Imtiaz, Jaan Raik, Samuele Germiniani, Daniele Nicoletti, Graziano Pravadelli, Giorgio Di Natale
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Defect and Fault Tolerance in VLSI and Nanotechnology Systems (DFT)
abstract: Functional verification techniques, particularly assertion-based verification, play a critical role in ensuring both correctness and security of modern hardware designs. In this paper, we propose and integrate a spectrum of formal and assertion-driven methods that extend conventional functional verification to address emerging security threats-ranging from stealthy Hardware Trojans (HTs) to adversarial cyber-attacks and cache side-channel exploits. First, we review traditional formal verification approaches such as SAT, BDD, and SCA, and discuss their adaptation to approximate computing and resource-bounded contexts. Next, we present an assertion-driven HT-detection paradigm at RTL, using control-flow graph matching and LTL-based specification mining with a hybrid similarity metric. We then demonstrate three complementary assertion- based methodologies for uncovering hardware secu-rity vulnerabilities: (1) deriving countermeasure assertions from an extracted finite-state machine model of an HT trigger; (2) automatically mining ISA-aware temporal assertions for RISC- V processors to detect embedded Trojans; and (3) mining temporal assertions from vehicle-dynamics traces to detect adversarial cyber attacks in autonomous vehicles. Finally, <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">we</sup> propose a formal assertion-generation framework for securing RTL designs against cache side-channel attacks and HT insertions-generating security assertions for both cache memory and RISC-V processor implementations, and validating their efficacy against known CSCAs and Trojan benchmarks. Through these case studies, we demonstrate that assertion-based verifi-cation not only enhances functional correctness guarantees but also provides a high-fidelity, scalable mechanism for detecting and locallzing a diverse range of hardware security threats.

title: State of the Art Review of Condition Monitoring in Solid Oxide Cell Based Power-to-Hydrogen Application
authors: Hans-Heinrich Früchtnicht, Huai Wang
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper aims to provide a literature review of research aspects of degradation mechanisms and condition monitoring methods in Solid Oxide Cell (SOC) based Power-to-Hydrogen (P2H) systems. Component failure mechanisms and detection of semiconductor modules, capacitors and SOCs are reviewed and compared. Options to utilize the converters sensing and signal injection capabilities for condition monitoring of the SOC are reviewed.

title: A Moving Target Imaging Method Based On KT Transform
authors: Peng Han, Shiyang Tang, Yifan Wang, Zhixin Lian, Linrang Zhang, Zixuan He
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The moving target imaging is difficult due to its noncooperative property, which poses a great challenge to SAR systems. In this paper, a moving target imaging method based on keystone (KT) transform is proposed to realize fast refocusing. Firstly, the consistent compensation processing of the stationary scene and the moving target is completed in the range-frequency domain according to the platform parameters, and the echo information of a single moving target is then extracted from the SAR image, and the range migration processing is completed by using slow time reversal, KT transform and second-order KT (SOKT) transform. Finally, the echo signal falling into the same range unit is extracted for azimuth focusing processing, and a two-dimensional high-resolution moving target image is obtained. The superiority of the proposed method is verified by simulation and real data results.

title: High Throughput Arithmetic Computing Unit for BFV Homomorphic Encryption
authors: Rella Mareta, Ardianto Satriawan, Hanho Lee
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Circuits and Systems
abstract: Homomorphic Encryption (HE) enables secure computations on encrypted data, which is crucial for cloud and edge computing. The BFV scheme, widely used for integer arithmetic, faces performance bottlenecks in polynomial multiplication, especially in tensor operations. The Residue Number System (RNS) helps address this, leading to the BEHZ and HPS BFV variants. The Halevi-Polyakov-Shoup (HPS) variant simplifies implementation but still struggles with the overhead of modular arithmetic. We propose an Arithmetic Computing Unit (ACU) optimized for key BFV operations, including modular addition, multiplication, NTT/INTT, and MAC to improve efficiency. Implemented on a Xilinx Alveo U250 FPGA, our design achieves up to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2.3{\times }$ </tex-math></inline-formula> higher throughput, <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2.2{\times }$ </tex-math></inline-formula> less latency, and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$9.4{\times }$ </tex-math></inline-formula> better BRAM efficiency than existing solutions, demonstrating FPGA acceleration’s for homomorphic encryption.

title: An Intersection Localization Method for RFI in Multi-Channel SAR Based on Motion Characteristics
authors: Yifei Liu, Mingliang Tao, Sijue Li, Yanyang Liu, Junli Chen, Jia Su, Ling Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Radio frequency interference (RFI) poses significant challenges to the earth observation capabilities of synthetic aperture radar (SAR). RFI source localization provides crucial prior information for RFI mitigation and spectrum management. Existing direction of arrival (DOA) estimation algorithms for multi-channel SAR systems face severe ambiguities due to the limitation of the long baseline. To mitigate this issue, this paper proposes an RFI intersection localization method based on phase matching and grid search. It avoids the problem of multiple phase-wrapping and effectively reduces the impact of ambiguity values. The localization accuracy is validated in measured dual-channel SAR data with simulated RFI, which yield only one cluster of points within the valid localization area and achieve high localization accuracy.

title: Stochastic Simulation of Ultra-Low Power Boost Converter for Biomedical Application
authors: Aripriharta, Muhammad Yazid, Nuryani, Muchamad Wahyu Prasetyo, Muhammad Cahyo Bagaskoro, Sasmita Bagus Sang Kesuma, Ika Noer Syamsiana, Pria Eka Reswana, Gwo-Jiun Horng
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: The development of biomedical devices requires reliable and efficient power management, especially under limited energy sources. This study evaluates the performance of an ultra-low power boost converter using stochastic simulations: Gaussian Analysis, Monte Carlo Simulation, and Worst-Case Analysis. The average output voltage was 4.20 V, with variations from 3.10 V to 4.87 V. Gaussian Analysis showed the highest stability, with the smallest standard deviation of 0.1437 V and the narrowest voltage range $(4.80-5.00 \mathrm{~V})$, making it the most suitable for precise voltage regulation in biomedical devices. Monte Carlo Simulation revealed moderate stability with wider fluctuations, while Worst-Case Analysis exposed significant deviations under extreme conditions. These results confirm Gaussian Analysis as the best method for ensuring stable voltage, while the other methods help identify variability and risk. Future work includes physical testing, validation with real biological data, and developing adaptive or AI-based controllers to improve voltage stability.

title: Enhancing Semantic Segmentation of SAR Images Using the Pyramid Attention Network Model
authors: Neeraj Kumar Nadipelli, Hitendra Sarma T, Mrudula K
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Deep learning models are extensively utilized for Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) image segmentation, as they effectively tackle challenges such as speckle noise, varying resolutions, and the need for fine-grained feature extraction. In recent years, numerous models have been developed based on the concept of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and enhanced by integrating attention-based mechanisms for SAR image segmentation. Pyramid Attention Network (PAN) is a recent attention-based model for computer vision tasks. This paper presents a fine-tuned version of the PAN architecture for SAR image segmentation and compares its performance with state-of-the-art deep learning approaches. Sentinel-1 data in combination with CORINE Land Cover (CLC) maps from the BigEarthNet dataset is used for model evaluation. The training data include over 1,500 images representing five land cover classes: Artificial Surfaces, Agricultural Areas, Forest and Seminatural Areas, Wetlands, and Water Bodies. This analysis highlights the strengths of these models in terms of segmentation accuracy and computational efficiency. The experimental results demonstrate that the PAN model outperforms the others, exhibiting superior accuracy and enhanced feature discrimination for classifying land cover types.

title: Multipath Exploitation in TomoSAR Imaging Based on Local Outlier Factor Detection
authors: Yuqing Lin, Xiaolan Qiu, Lingxiao Peng, Hang Li, Zhang Zhe, Chibiao Ding
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Tomographic Synthetic Aperture Radar (TomoSAR) offers a significant advantage over conventional SAR by providing three-dimensional(3D) representations of target. Drone-based TomoSAR systems, owing to their flexibility, have garnered considerable attention. However, urban environments present challenges due to strong reflections from buildings, leading to severe multipath effects. Traditionally, multipath-induced ghost points are treated as noise and discarded, hindering accurate reconstruction. This study aims to transform multipath from a detrimental factor to a valuable asset for improving urban scene analysis. A polar coordinate model for low-altitude scenarios is introduced. Then, by performing Local outlier factor (LOF) detection on each look angle, multipath signals are identified during the 3D imaging process. Finally, the multipath virtual points are relocated to their true positions during the 3D imaging process. Experimental results demonstrate a 0.1 reduction in 3D entropy, validating the efficacy of the proposed method. This research highlights the potential of exploiting multipath phenomena to enhance TomoSAR imaging in complex urban environments.

title: On The NLOS Building Layout Relocation in Array Insar 3D Imaging
authors: Yisen Zhou, Shisheng Guo, Zhihao Zhu, Xujing Zeng, Yupeng Yu, Yubo Wang, Guolong Cui
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: When UAV-borne Tomographic Synthetic Aperture Radar (TomoSAR) operates at a low altitude, the presence of significant non-line-of-sight (NLOS) multipath effects in complex urban environments poses considerable challenges for three-dimensional (3D) imaging using array interferometric synthetic aperture radar (Array InSAR). Although recent studies have begun transitioning from suppressing multipath effects to lever-aging them, there remains limited exploration of the conditions under which multipath effects can be maximally utilized. Furthermore, most existing approaches that exploit multipath effects rely heavily on prior knowledge of building layouts, lacking adaptability to diverse geometric structures. To address these issues, this study first introduces the signal model of Array InSAR and analyzes the relationship between NLOS imaging coverage and the vertical height and horizontal distance of a UAV relative to the target area during low-altitude observations in urban canyon environments. Building on this foundation, we further propose an NLOS building layout relocation method that does not rely on prior layout information. Finally, electromagnetic simulation data are generated to validate the proposed system model and algorithm.

title: Tree Height Extraction from UAV-based Point Cloud Data Using Improved Cuboid Filtering
authors: Zhengying Wei
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Tree height is an important parameter of forest ecosystems, closely related to biomass, carbon storage, and forest health. Traditional ground-based tree height measurement methods are time-consuming and have limited coverage. Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) provide a cost-effective and flexible alternative that is capable of generating high-resolution point cloud data. This study develops a method for extracting tree heights based on drone point cloud data. The method utilizes photogrammetry techniques and the Structure from Motion (SfM) algorithm to generate point cloud data, and employs a cuboid filtering method to separate ground points from tree points. Tree height extraction is conducted by fitting a model to the ground points to predict ground elevation. The method was validated in two representative plots with different tree densities. The results showed that in the sparsely vegetated area after filtering, the R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> reached 0.9873, the Mean Absolute Error (MAE) was 0.3044, and the Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) was 0.379522; in the densely vegetated area after filtering, the R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> reached 0.9587, the MAE was 0.96, and the RMSE was 1.1141. The results indicate that the method can accurately extract tree heights in both sparse and dense tree distributions.

title: Geoenvironmental zoning of the Santa Elena Peninsula-Ecuador for sustainable management
authors: Gricelda Herrera-Franco, Lady Bravo-Montero, FJ Montalván, Maribel Aguilar-Aguilar, Paúl Carrión-Mero
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The Santa Elena Peninsula is one of the main tourist attractions along the Ecuadorian coast. It is constantly developing and requires sustainable management and territorial planning. This study aims to identify areas of tourist, industrial, urban, and rural interest through geospatial tools to formulate adaptive geoenvironmental management strategies and territorial planning for sustainable development. The methodology includes i) data collection and processing, ii) spatial analysis of areas of interest, and iii) sustainable development strategies. The results indicate that 24.8% of the study area has coastal tourism potential that integrates natural, geological, and cultural wealth, with management measures focused mainly on addressing environmental, social, and political needs for stakeholders' future decision-making. This study represents a tool for the sustainable and responsible management of coastal tourism development through geospatial analysis.

title: Development of a digital model for end-to-end simulation of interferometric hyperspectral remote sensing imaging
authors: Juan Cheng, Yihao Wang, Tieqiao Chen, Shuang Wang, Geng Zhang, Bingliang Hu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: A digital model for interferometric hyperspectral sensor end-to-end imaging simulation has been developed in this paper. The model achieves both the forward and backward imaging chain simulation. It can simulate hyperspectral images such as interferometric spectrum, digital number (DN), and top-of-atmosphere (TOA) radiance, as well as the surface reflectance images after preprocessing, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction of the raw images from the interferometric hyperspectral remote sensing satellite sensor. This paper provides a detailed description of the full-chain digital model for the interferometric hyperspectral remote sensing satellite sensor, including the forward simulation mechanisms or backward inversion algorithms for each module (such as the mechanism of the interferometric imaging spectrometers, atmospheric effect mechanisms and atmospheric correction algorithms, ghost mechanisms and correction algorithms, etc.). Several results are presented to demonstrate the reliability of the full-chain imaging digital model. The digital model has supported data processing and quality enhancement algorithm research for operational satellite hyperspectral sensors, such as those carried on HJ-2 A/B and GaoFen-14. It can also be used for developing the next-generation high-resolution, large-swath hyperspectral satellite sensors.

title: Novel Configurable Hysteresis Schmitt Trigger for General Purpose Input Output Applications
authors: Sanmitra Bharat Naik, Nithin Thomas Abraham, Asif Iqbal
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: This work presents a novel configurable hysteresis Schmitt trigger for Automotive Grade-1 General-Purpose InputOutput (GPIO) applications. The proposed circuit is designed using the GF 22FDX™ process technology. The Schmitt trigger thresholds, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{H}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{L}$</tex>, can be configured either through externally applied control voltages or via internally generated ones. The hysteresis range is adjustable from 300 mV up to 1.5 V, with the observed <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{H}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{L}$</tex> values being 1.25-3.1 V and 0.3-1.0 V, respectively. This proposed circuit is compact, with an area measuring <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$29.54 \times 18.925 \mu \mathrm{m}^{2}$</tex>. The dynamic power consumed is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$280 \mu W$</tex>, whereas the leakage power is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.25 n W$</tex>.

title: SoC Integrated Multi-Outputs DC-DC Converter for Microcontroller Supply on 18 nm Node
authors: Mathieu Ginet, Eric Feltrin, Nicolas Jeanniot, Bruno Allard, Xuefang Lin-Shi
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Using a DC-DC converter with multiple voltage outputs within a microcontroller has many advantages. However, the control of this type of converter is more complex to design than that of single-output converters, and the results presented in the literature are difficult to compare due to different contexts (voltages, load currents, size of passive components, etc.). This paper presents a comparative study of control strategies for a Single Input Multiple Output (SIMO) DC-DC converter used in microcontroller power supplies. The power stage of a SIMO converter adaptable to various control topologies is modeled and high-level analog control structures are implemented. By analyzing transient and steady-state performance metrics in a standardized simulation context, the most suitable solutions can be identified. This approach provides a fair evaluation of topologies, establishing a foundation for developing robust, efficient multi-output power converters. Based on this evaluation, a new control topology is proposed and implemented on a transistor-level design.

title: Demographic-Enhanced Collaborative Filtering: Improving Accuracy and Diversity in MovieLens-Based Recommender Systems
authors: Yuri Ariyanto, Triyanna Widiyaningtyas, Ilham Saifudin, Wiwik Suharso, Wahyu Caesarendra, Adinda Salsa Leviona
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: This study presents a demographic-enhanced collaborative filtering approach for improving the accuracy and diversity of movie recommendation systems, evaluated on the MovieLens 100K and MovieLens 1M datasets. The proposed method integrates K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) clustering for user demographic profiling with matrix factorization-based collaborative filtering using Singular Value Decomposition (SVD). The system is evaluated against established baselines (SVD, User-Based CF, Neural CF) across four key performance metrics: precision, recall, F1-score, and diversity. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method consistently outperforms baseline models, with significant improvements in accuracy metrics when scaling from MovieLens 100K to 1M. Precision increased by $3.91 \%$, recall by $20.99 \%$, and F1-score by $15.12 \%$. Notably, the recall improvement indicates an enhanced capability to capture diverse user preferences. However, the diversity score remained constant at 0.6666 across both datasets, suggesting that algorithmic design, rather than data volume, predominantly influences recommendation variety. Comparative analysis reveals that while the proposed method excels in accuracy, it yields slightly lower diversity than User-Based CF, highlighting a potential trade-off. These findings confirm that incorporating demographic data enhances collaborative filtering effectiveness, particularly for addressing cold-start issues and capturing broader user preferences. This research contributes to more accurate and personalized recommendation systems by leveraging demographic insights within a scalable collaborative filtering framework.

title: Multi-Domain Spatio-Temporal Feature Representation with Graph Neural Networks for Radar Target Detection
authors: Junjie Wang, Dongying Li, Wenxian Yu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: To better explore the implicit representational information in radar echo signals, this paper proposes a radar target detection method based on multi-domain spatio-temporal feature representation using graph neural networks. Considering the intrinsic properties of radar signals, an adjacency matrix is constructed based on the temporal and spatial relationships between signals. On the basis of multi-domain features, raw signal information is incorporated to obtain richer and more discriminative de-redundant representations. Experimental results on the publicly available IPIX dataset demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms several classical feature-based detection methods in radar target detection performance.

title: Multi-Label Vegetation Segmentation Dataset for Urban and Forest Regions in South Korea
authors: Changhui Lee, Aisha Javed, Heein Yang, Daehee Kim, Jinmin Lee, Youkyung Han
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Urban vegetation plays a crucial role in urban ecosystems, but existing datasets are often focused on specific regions or large forests, failing to adequately reflect the characteristics and diversity of urban vegetation. In particular, high-resolution satellite imagery-based datasets are essential for vegetation analysis in regions like South Korea, where seasonal variations are pronounced. In this study, a multi-label vegetation segmentation dataset (MultiVeg) was constructed to reflect the geographical characteristics of South Korea, primarily consisting of urban and forest regions. The dataset was created through handcrafted labeling and visual inspection, and oversampling techniques were applied to mitigate class imbalance issues. To validate the quality and utility of the MultiVeg dataset, performance evaluation was conducted using the DeepLabV3+ model. In identifying the target classes of tree and grass, MultiVeg was shown to outperform or exhibit higher reliability compared to benchmark datasets (Wuhan Urban Semantic Understanding (WUSU), Zurich summer). Future research aims to enhance the performance of MultiVeg by collecting additional regional data to increase the diversity of the grass class, which showed relatively lower accuracy compared to the tree class. Furthermore, the multi-temporal data in MultiVeg will be utilized to perform precise geometric corrections and expand the dataset into a time-series vegetation change detection dataset. The dataset constructed in this study can be accessed via the following link: https://github.com/pang914/MultiVeg

title: A Cross-Modal Image Registration Method for Small UAV Targets via Unsupervised Refined Keypoint Matching
authors: Wen Jiang, Keyi Zhang, Yanping Wang, Yang Li, Yun Lin, Wenjie Shen
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: With the rapid development of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and their applications in various fields, accurate image registration, especially for small UAV targets, has become crucial. Existing feature point matching methods face challenges in small UAV target registration due to scarce feature points, small size, and complex backgrounds, leading to unstable outcomes. To overcome this issue, this paper proposes a cross-modal image registration (CMIR) model, which consists of a multi-scale feature point extraction network (MSFEN) and a feature refinement matching module (FRMM). In this method, optical images are first transformed into pseudo-infrared images using a modality transformation network (MTN) to reduce modality disparities. The MSFEN then extracts robust feature points for preliminary matching, while the FRMM refines the matches by analyzing the relative positions and local structures of the points. Experimental results show the method excels in small UAV target image registration, effectively addressing challenges like scarce feature points, small target size, and complex backgrounds.

title: Multiterminal HVDC System with Combined AC and DC Grid-Forming Control of the Modular Multilevel Converter
authors: Werner Fritsche, Tayssir Hassan, Malte Eggers, Peter Teske, Hendrik Just, Sibylle Dieckerhoff
publish: 2025 10th IEEE Workshop on the Electronic Grid (eGRID)
abstract: The transmission of electric energy over long distances, such as from offshore wind parks (OWPs), is typically realized using high-voltage direct current (HVDC) systems. Modular multilevel converters (MMCs) are particularly suitable for this application. System configurations can vary, but coordination and stable control become more complex as the number of MMCs increases. In this work, a multiterminal HVDC (MTDC) system with four MMCs is introduced and investigated, with the system using a combined AC and DC grid-forming control algorithm at each station.

title: Optimal Transmit Parameters Based on TPFI-PSO Algorithm for Deceptive Jamming Suppression
authors: Tiantian Zhong, Haihong Tao, Haiyun Liao, Han Cao
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: To further enhance the performance of mainlobe deception jamming suppression, according to the working mechanism of polarimetric antennas and FDA-MIMO radar, based on Transmitting Polarization and Frequency Increment of Particle Swarm Optimization (TPFI-PSO) algorithm is proposed to optimize the selection of transmit parameters of radar, which can upgrade the estimation accuracy of target and jamming, and achieve precise jamming suppression. Simulation experiments show that the optimization efficiency of transmit parameters of radar is significantly improved and the premature convergence is avoided through the proposed TPFI-PSO algorithm.

title: Leakestimator: a Unified Framework for Pvt Aware Leakage Power Estimation in Digital Circuits
authors: Sarang Kudtarkar, Khanh M Le, Zia Abbas
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: In this paper, we propose an efficient and robust framework for estimating leakage power while considering statistical variations in process parameters, supply voltage, and temperature (PVT) in FinFET-based digital circuits. Extensive testing reports an average error of less than 1 % in the ML models for standard digital cells, with an average MAPE (Mean Absolute Percentage Error) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 7 6 4 \%}, \mathbf{0. 7 7 0 \%}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 8 1 4 \%}$</tex> in the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7 ~\text{nm}, 10 ~\text{nm}$</tex>, and 16 nm FinFET technology nodes, respectively, which ensures a highly accurate leakage estimate for larger circuits. Additionally, we investigated the transistor-level approach, which distinctively estimates subthreshold, gate, and body leakage power using only transistor-level models and stacks, and investigated its trade-offs to gate-level models. Using ML techniques, we achieve a speedup of over 400 times compared to HSPICE for the characterization of digital blocks, using which complex cell designs can be analyzed across various input test combinations, significantly saving the time required for extensive simulations.

title: CLIP-Based Content-Aware Change Detection for Bi-Temporal Remote Sensing Imagery
authors: Jintao Chen, Bo Peng, Nianzheng Yuan, Mingmin Chi, Dejing Dou, Sicong Liu, Jón Atli Benediktsson
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Change detection (CD) is a critical task in remote sensing, enabling the identification of temporal changes in various applications. However, existing methods lack a systematic mechanism to leverage the complementary semantic content and discriminative discrepancy information embedded in vision-language features, limiting their capacity for robust pseudo-change perception. To tackle these challenges, we propose CEDCLIP, an innovative content-enhanced and differential learning framework for remote sensing change detection. CED-CLIP introduces three key modules: a Change Feature Module for flexible extraction of differential features from bitemporal images, a Change Detection Decoder Module that incorporates content information to refine context-aware change representations and a Vision-Language Interaction Module that integrates visual and textual features to enhance semantic understanding. The modular design ensures seamless compatibility with existing algorithms and facilitates efficient adaptation to various scenarios. Experimental results demonstrate that CED-CLIP achieves state-of-the-art performance, paving the way for robust multimodal learning in change detection.

title: Analysis of Local Methane Emissions Using Near-Simultaneous Multi-Satellite Observations: Insights from Landfills and Oil-Gas Facilities
authors: Alvise Ferrari, Giovanni Laneve, Raul Alejandro Carvajal Tellez, Valerio Pampanoni, Simone Saquella, Rocchina Guarini
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Methane (CH<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf>) is a potent greenhouse gas, and its detection and quantification are crucial for mitigating the greenhouse effect. This study presents a comparative analysis of methane emissions observed using near-simultaneous observations from hyperspectral imaging spectrometers hosted aboard different satellite platforms (PRISMA, EnMAP, EMIT and GHGSat). Methane emissions from oil and gas facilities and landfills are analyzed to evaluate the consistency and precision of the sensors and temporal variability of the source. Landfills, characterized by diffuse and stable emissions, and dynamic oil and gas facilities, subject to operational variability, provide contrasting use cases for emission monitoring. Emission rates are quantified using the Integrated Mass Enhancement (IME) model and validated across satellites with overlapping acquisitions. This study highlights the advantages and limitations of each satellite system, emphasizing the critical role of multi-sensor integration in bridging temporal and spatial observation gaps. Insights derived here aim to enhance global methane monitoring frameworks and guide future satellite design for improved emission quantification.

title: Evaluation of Water Surface Elevation Using SWOT Mission in the Indus Basin
authors: Tauqeer Ali, Arjumand Zaidi, Muhammad Kareem, Farkhanda Noor, Jasra Rehman, Stefano Vignudelli
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The surface water ocean topography (SWOT) satellite, equipped with a k-band radar interferometer, measures water elevation levels with high precision. It aims to monitor global hydrological and climatic changes and support sustainable water resource management. The SWOT River Database (SWORD) provides water level data at 200-meter intervals along river reaches. This study focuses on plotting time series dynamics and validating SWORD water levels for Guddu, Sukkur, and Kotri barrages against in-situ and DAHITI products. The statistical analysis between SWOT and in-situ indicates a good agreement for the Sukkur barrage, with an R of 0.98 and a Mean Absolute Error (MSE) of 0.74 meters. For Guddu Barrage, a comparison with in-situ data yielded an R of 0.90 and an MAE of 0.44 meters. Similarly, for Kotri Barrage, the R and MAE were 0.98 and 0.60 meters, respectively. The discrepancies may be due to in-situ data handling or due to SWORD-derived water levels. The water surface elevation (WSE) is averaged between two adjacent nodes. This averaging may not capture abrupt changes in water levels caused by obstructions such as barrages.

title: Monitoring Mangrove Biomass and Carbon Stocks in the Brazilian Amazon: Insights from GEDI and Sentinel-2 for Conservation
authors: Dayla Carolina Rodrigues Santos, Ramadhan, Lucas Lima Raiol, Andrés Velastegui-Montoya, Sanae Nogueira Hayashi, João Santos Nahum
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Mangroves are essential coastal ecosystems due to their rich biodiversity, carbon sequestration capacity, and role as natural barriers against flooding, but they are threatened by human activities. This study analyzes the dynamics of aboveground biomass (AGB) and carbon stocks in the mangroves of the Caeté-Taperaçu Marine Extractive Reserve (RESEX Caeté-Taperaçu), Brazilian Amazon, between 2019 and 2023. Data from NASA’s Ecosystem Dynamics Investigation (GEDI) and Sentinel-2 imagery were integrated into a linear regression model using Random Forest (RF) to estimate biomass, validated by metrics such as RMSE and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. Mangrove areas expanded by 169.1 ha (0.75%) during this period, indicating natural regeneration. Total AGB was 1.6 Tg in 2019, decreasing to 1.4 Tg in 2021 and 2023, a reduction of 0.2 Tg. The results highlight the relevance of geotechnologies in monitoring and adaptive management to conserve and enhance the resilience of these ecosystems in the face of climate change.

title: SOCANet: A Deep Learning Wetland Classification Strategy Based On Improved CNN and Attention Mechanism
authors: Hanwen Xu, Qinxin Wu, Zhe Wang, Chang Liu, Zixuan Wang, Hongtao Shi
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) have demonstrated remarkable performance in extracting local features for complex scene analysis. However, their ability to capture global feature representations is limited, posing challenges for complex land cover classification. To address these limitations, we propose a hybrid network structure named SOCANet, which integrates convolutional operations with linear self-attention mechanisms. In detail, the network is divided into encoder and decoder two parts. In the encoder, a cross-modal feature fusion module and a multi-level feature extraction module are integrated. The multi-level feature extraction module adopts a parallel structure and combines CNN and focused linear attention to improve the feature expression ability. The decoder part consists of two classifiers, which are responsible for different levels of feature classification tasks. Furthermore, the Nanjishan Wetland Nature Reserve region is used to verified the effective of our proposed method. Experimental results indicate that SOCANet achieves a comprehensive classification accuracy (OA) of 97% and a Kappa coefficient of 0.959, significantly outperforming mainstream baseline methods. Notably, the proposed approach excels in distinguishing complex land cover types, such as carex, mudflat, reeds, et al., offering a novel solution for feature learning and fusion in intricate scenarios.

title: Performance of Multiple Circularly Polarized Slotted Waveguide Array Antennas for mmWave Applications
authors: Subuh Pramono, Meiyanto Eko Sulistyo, Muhammad Hamka Ibrahim, Faisal Rahutomo, Sutrisno, Joko Hariyono
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: This research presents the performance of multiple circularly polarized slotted waveguide array antennas (SWA). The proposed antenna is aimed at mmwave covering the upper K and lower Ka spectrum frequencies. We employ two SWAs with two antenna elements for every SWA. The SWA is ideal for millimeter wave because of low-loss transmission, highpower handling, and high gain. Based on simulation results, this antenna has an impedance bandwidth of 6.8 GHz, an axial ratio bandwidth of 6 GHz, a maximum gain of 11.87 dBi, an envelope correlation coefficient (ECC) of around 0.0005, a diversity gain (DG) of more than 9.99, and mutual coupling in the range of 33.2 dB to -68.8 dB. The proposed antenna has good characteristics for millimeter wave applications.

title: Fixed-Time Augmented Resonant Extended State Observer for PMSM Current Disturbance Suppression
authors: Jiaxing Ye, Mingyi Wang, Shun Cai, Yunchong Wang, Sihang Cui, Chengming Zhang, Liyi Li
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Conventional driving methods are often plagued by numerous disturbances and uncertainties within the current loop of permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) systems, which can significantly degrade current control efficacy. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a current control strategy utilizing a fixed-time augmented resonant extended state observer (FARESO) to detect current disturbances and mitigate their effects through redesigned control law. Initially, the proposed method introduces a measured current integral term as the augmented state variable to decouple the interaction between current measurement noise and high observer gain. Additionally, to enhance the observation and suppression for harmonic disturbances, the quasi-generalized integrator term is incorporated in the observer. Furthermore, recognizing the exponentially asymptotic convergence characteristic of the conventional observers, this study proposes an enhanced nonlinear correction term for the observer to ensure fixed-time convergence of the state estimation error. This modification accelerates the observer's convergence rate, thereby improving both observation and control bandwidth. Finally, experimental results obtained from a PMSM test rig validate the effectiveness of the proposed scheme.

title: Multi-Sensor Measurement Data Assignment Using Infrared Frequency Characteristics of Ballistic Target Micromotion
authors: Cheng Cheng, Dehua Mao, Minghui Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This paper studies a multi-sensor measurement assignment approach using infrared frequency characteristics of ballistic target micromotion. The infrared frequency characteristics of ballistic target micromotion are estimated to obtain stable target features, and then assignment cost matrices based on the frequency characteristics associated with target micromotion are developed. The assignment problem is solved using the Lagrangian relaxation algorithm. A simulation study is conducted to compare the proposed method with state-of-the-art approaches for detecting ballistic targets using space-based infrared satellites.

title: Band-Focused Adversarial Attacks on Multispectral Images Exposing Hidden Vulnerabilities in Land Use Land Cover Scenery Classification
authors: Anastasios Temenos, Nikos Temenos, Ioannis Rallis, Nikolaos Bakalos, Anastasios Doulamis, Nikolaos Doulamis
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This work presents band-focused adversarial attacks that expose hidden vulnerabilities in multispectral images used for land use land cover (LULC) classification in remote sensing (RS). By applying Fast Gradient Sign Method (FGSM) adversarial attack with iterative replacement and isolation strategy on each spectral band, the resilience and susceptibility to perturbations of individual bands are highlighted. This approach deviates from existing methods, which focus on induced perturbations on RGB images and considering all bands collectively. Experimental results on the EuroSAT dataset using a convolutional neural network (CNN) with various perturbation levels, demonstrate that overall accuracy, 96.72% in the absence of attacks, can drop by 2.59% up to 16.68% depending on the targeted band. To further emphasize the CNN vulnerability and their implications for different LULC cases, F1-scores using a selected perturbation value for each available class are reported, highlighting high-confident miss-classifications.

title: Wide-Region Search Using TMA in Radar Applications
authors: Fuhao Wang, Huake Wang, Dongchang Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This paper investigates the application of 4-D TMA (Four-Dimensional Time-Modulated Array) in radar systems and proposes an efficient method for wide-region search space coverage based on 4-D TMA. The 4-D TMA extends the conventional three-dimensional degrees of freedom—spatial position, excitation amplitude, and excitation phase of the antenna elements—by incorporating an additional degree of freedom in the time domain. Compared to conventional antenna arrays, the 4-D TMA incorporates high-speed RF switches in its feed network, enabling precise control of the periodic switching on and off of the RF switches to achieve time modulation of the array. Building on the ability of 4-D TMA to achieve low sidelobe suppression and beam pointing control, this paper applies the 4-D TMA to radar systems and realizes multibeam simultaneous transmission over a wide area, meeting the needs of radar wide-region search tasks. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Current Share Rate and Thermal Stress Analysis in Si/SiC Fusion Power Modules During Active DC-Link Capacitor Discharge
authors: Julius Schapdick, Tomas Reiter, Michael Krug, Matthias Weinmann, Michael Niendorf
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of discharging the DC-Link capacitor in automotive traction inverters. Traditionally reliant on discharge resistors, this work explores an alternative using an automotive power module using a “Fusion switch” that integrates Si IGBTs and SiC MOSFETs with a common gate driver, reducing complexity and cost. Two pulsed discharge methods were evaluated through measurements. The study focused on current share rates and peak currents between the IGBT and MOSFET to assess semiconductor stress and impact on device lifetime. The results showed that one method stood out as the most suitable, demonstrating its long-term stability over the entire vehicle lifetime.

title: Microwave Radiometry in the Unprotected S-Band: Development of an Adaptive Radiometer and Digital Twin Integration
authors: Kaies Al Mahmud, Mehmet Kurum, Md Mehedi Farhad, A. M. Alam, Ali C. Gurbuz
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The expansion of next-generation communication and satellite systems into additional frequency bands increases interference risks for passive radiometer sensors used in environmental and atmospheric sensing. To address this challenge and explore the use of frequency bands for microwave radiometry beyond the traditionally protected spectrum, we propose a novel approach to microwave radiometry in the unprotected S-band (3.2-3.6 GHz) by utilizing a spectrum scanning system. This system dynamically scans the spectrum in real-time to identify suitable frequency bands for passive sensing. The software-defined radio (SDR)-based radiometer is capable of adaptively adjusting its center frequency in response to spectrum availability. For this study, we focus on the lower mid-band frequency identified as part of the emerging mid-band radar spectrum study (EMBRSS) in the National Spectrum Strategy published in 2023. We also discuss our plan to use the proposed system to collect real-world data using the AERPAW testbed in the presence of 5G communication signals and the development of a digital twin for simulated coexistence experiments.

title: Robust Integrated Navigation for USVs Using Adaptive Event-Triggered Factor Graph Optimization
authors: Yabei Guo, Huigang Wang, Runhe Yao, Longfei Yang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Inertial/GPS/visual integrated navigation systems provide high-precision positioning in complex environments, making them increasingly popular in applications such as unmanned surface vehicles (USVs). However, environmental disturbances can introduce abnormal sensor data, leading to reduced navigation accuracy or even system divergence. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a novel integrated navigation method based on adaptive event-triggered (AET) factor graph optimization. The method incorporates an adaptive event-triggered mechanism into the traditional factor graph optimization framework to dynamically filter sensor errors caused by environmental changes. Simulation experiments conducted in the Robot Operating System (ROS) validate the proposed algorithm, demonstrating its ability to effectively mitigate the impact of sensor anomalies and improve navigation accuracy.

title: Exploring Multiscale Variations in Greenspace Exposure Drivers: A Perspective on the Modifiable Areal Unit Problem
authors: Yumiao Xiao, Wenbo Lv, Wufan Zhao
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Urban greenspaces are vital for enhancing ecosystem services, improving public health, and promoting sustainable development. Despite the growing interest in greenspace research, gaps remain in understanding how scale and zoning effects influence the drivers of greenspace exposure, posing challenges for equitable and effective planning. This study investigated the spatial patterns and driving factors of greenspace exposure across four administrative levels in China (province, city, county, and town) using buffer radii of 100m, 500m, 1000m, and 1500m. Through multiscale remote sensing observations, local spatial autocorrelation analysis, and geographically optimal zones-based heterogeneity model, we examined the modifiable areal unit problem to evaluate scale and zoning effects on greenspace exposure. Results revealed significant geographical disparities, with higher exposure in southwest China and lower exposure in southeastern coastal and northwestern arid regions. Spatial heterogeneity and dependence intensified at finer administrative levels, with Moran’s I increasing from 0.400 at the provincial scale to 0.764 at the township scale. While natural factors dominated the spatial pattern of greenspace exposure at broader scales, anthropogenic influences prevailed at finer scales, underscoring the critical role of zoning-specific analyses. Overall, this study bridged research gaps by providing a multiscale perspective on greenspace exposure and its drivers, offering practical insights for policymakers and urban planners to design equitable and sustainable green space strategies.

title: Monitoring Logging Impacts in Tropical Forest Using Sentinel-1 SAR: the Jamari Forest
authors: Ana C. Teixeira, Leilson Ferreira, Matus Bakon, Domingos Lopes, Luis Pádua, Joaquim J. Sousa
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Monitoring logging activities in tropical forests is essential for sustainable forest management, yet traditional methods like airborne Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) are often costly and complex. This study presents a cost-effective methodology using Sentinel-1 Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data to quantify canopy changes and assess the impacts of selective logging. Multitemporal SAR imagery was processed to detect structural changes in the forest canopy and compare them with mapped logging infrastructure. The methodology was applied to three study areas in the Jamari National Forest, Brazil: two selectively logged areas and one undisturbed area serving as a control. Results showed significant canopy reductions of 6.90% and 4.11% in the logged areas, compared to 0.16% in the control area. Intersection rates of 60.94% and 51.65% confirmed the spatial alignment between SAR-detected impacted areas and logging infrastructure. These findings demonstrate the potential of SAR data as a scalable and accessible alternative to high-cost technologies for monitoring logging activities. Future work will explore the integration of artificial intelligence for automated logging detection and extend this approach to other tropical regions.

title: Exploring the Stray Interstrand Capacitance of Litz Wire for Wireless Power Transfer in Two-Phase Bipolar Coils
authors: Lindemberg Costa Luna, Montiê Alves Vitorino, Vinicius Freire Bezerra, Jens Friebe
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This work investigates the use of internal distributed capacitance formed by grouped strands of Litz wire in two-phase bipolar coils for Wireless Power Transfer (WPT) systems. Different Litz wire structuring methods were applied to modulate interstrand capacitance and achieve resonance frequencies between 70 kHz and 100 kHz. The optimal configuration was selected through impedance measurements with a impedance analyzer. Experimental validation showed stable resonance without external capacitors on the transmitting coils, with the system delivering up to 1000 W and achieving efficiencies up to 95.2% at 5 cm coil distance. Comparative tests using conventional external capacitors confirmed similar resonant behavior, validating internal capacitance as a cost-effective and integrable alternative for WPT and other resonant power applications.

title: Forest Scan Planning for an Under-Canopy Mobile LiDAR Platform using Airborne Point Cloud
authors: Sangyoon Park, Songlin Fei, Ayman Habib
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Recent advancements in laser scanning technology have significantly improved data acquisition efficiency for documenting the geometry of existing trees. However, scan planning in forest environments still heavily depends on in-field decisions made by experienced surveyors. This study proposes an automated framework to determine the forest scan plan for an under-canopy mobile Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) platform using Airborne Laser Scanning (ALS) point clouds. The proposed framework consists of three main phases: Generation of scan-position candidates; optimal scan positioning; path planning. The experimental results showed that the framework effectively provides an optimal scan plan for a backpack LiDAR platform, achieving the Lack of Completeness (LoC) metric of 13.3%. Additionally, the proposed method significantly reduces scan operation time compared to traditional manual approaches by experienced surveyors while maintaining scan coverage quality. Future work will focus on integrating this framework with the navigation system for the under-canopy mobile LiDAR platform.

title: Flexible Context and Adaptive Attention for Visual Grounding
authors: Yaxiong Chen, Shenya Liu, Yichen Zhao, Shengwu Xiong
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Visual Grounding (VG) seeks to locate visual objects using textual descriptions. Existing methods lack the flexibility to capture referred object contexts. In addition, these VG methods often neglect the critical role of local information, which is essential for capturing key properties of referred objects. To this end, we propose a novel VG framework, termed CAVG. Central to this framework are two key components: a language-guided context encoder and an adaptive cross-modal decoder. The language-guided context encoder enhances the referred object contexts by releasing feature dimensions and aligning multi-modal information. Meanwhile, the adaptive cross-modal decoder plays a vital role in the reasoning process by adaptively selecting the visual attention ranges to query global and local information. It utilizes language information as prior knowledge to accurately localize referred objects. Extensive experiments are conducted on five prevalent datasets to verify the effectiveness of CAVG.

title: Weak Target Detection in Radar Sea Clutter Based on Weighted Convex Hull Tree Algorithm
authors: Zi-Xun Guo, Kang-Hui Wu, Xiao-Hui Bai, Jia Su, Yi-Fei Fan, Peng-Lang Shui
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Detecting small targets on the sea with high-resolution radars is difficult because of weak reflections and complex sea clutter. Using multiple features to distinguish targets from clutter is an effective method. Thus, creating a specialized classifier that can handle unequal training samples, especially ergodic sea clutter versus non-ergodic target returns, is crucial. This paper proposes a weighted convex hull tree structure with three parts: convex hull, weight, and threshold decision. First, features are combined to form multiple three-dimensional convex hulls. Second, different convex hulls are weighted based on their detection capabilities about simulated target samples. Finally, a test statistic is built using weights and sample distances to control false alarms. The algorithm uses measured sea clutter and simulated target data, ensuring robustness. On the open IPIX database and a self-collected UAV dataset, the proposed detector outperforms other feature-based detectors on the performance and computation cost.

title: Cross-View Image Geo-Localization Based on an Improved BEV Transformation Method
authors: Zhutao Lv, Junyan Ye, Jinhua Yu, Weijia Li
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Cross-view geo-localization leverages the matching of street-view images with geo-referenced satellite imagery databases to achieve accurate positioning, particularly in environments where GPS signals are weak or unavailable. However, the significant viewpoint discrepancies between street-view and satellite images present considerable challenges for matching. Some existing methods attempt to reduce the viewpoint discrepancies between cross-view images by applying polar transformations to satellite images or BEV (Bird’s Eye View) transformations to street-view images. These methods mitigate viewpoint discrepancies to some extent, but the transformed images still exhibit issues such as a limited perceptual range, which hinders subsequent matching. To address this challenge, this study proposes a novel cross-view retrieval method that introduces the Curved-BEV transformation, effectively narrowing the domain gap between street-view images and satellite imagery. This transformation adjusts street-view images to a form more consistent with the satellite perspective, thereby reducing the impact of viewpoint differences and improving image matching accuracy. During the training, the method employs the InfoNCE loss function from contrastive learning, which maximizes the mutual information between image pairs. This enhances the distinguishability of positive and negative image pairs, improving the representation of features in both street-view and satellite images and strengthening the discriminative power of the image features. Experimental results demonstrate that our method achieves excellent performance on the benchmark datasets CVACT and CVUSA. Specifically, the Curved-BEV transformation improves R@1 by 2.46% over the existing BEV method and by 1.58% over the commonly used polar transformation, validating the effectiveness of the proposed approach. Our method provides a more accurate localization solution for specific scenarios.

title: Predictive Control Strategies for Direct Matrix Converters: A Performance Comparison
authors: Nicolás González, Marco Rivera, Javier Muñoz, Patrick Wheeler
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Model predictive control has emerged as a suitable alternative for controlling power converters. Today, several predictive control strategies have been proposed to enhance the performance and efficiency of the converter, building upon advances made over its predecessors. This paper presents a comparative study of three predictive control strategies -Model-Based Predictive Control (MBPC), Sequential Model Predictive Control (SMPC), and Indirect Model Predictive Control (IMPC) — applied to input and output current regulation in a Direct Matrix Converter (DMC), assessing the degree of advancement between them. The comparison focuses on defining the system's behaviour in terms of control performance, computational efficiency, and harmonic distortion under realistic operating conditions. The simulation results demonstrate that IMPC offers superior current tracking accuracy, minimal ripple, and the lowest Total Harmonic Distortion (THD) among the three strategies. In contrast, SMPC, while eliminating weighting factors, exhibits the highest THD and reference-tracking errors. Finally, this study highlights IMPC as a practical approach for high-performance control in DMC over the other two strategies.

title: Input Variability Analysis of Aerial Imagery in Rice Semantic Segmentation Using UNet-VGG16
authors: Ida Wahyuni, Chin-Chun Chang, Wei-Jen Wang, Deron Liang
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: Semantic segmentation of rice is a crucial aspect of precision agriculture, aimed at enhancing disease detection, quality assessment, or yield estimation. This study conducts a sensitivity analysis on an aerial image dataset from Taiwan to determine how input variability impacts rice semantic segmentation using a UNet-VGG16 model. We analyze three input factors: rice coverage percentage, cloud presence, and Near-Infrared (NIR) value histograms. The findings reveal that a balanced rice coverage percentage, high-quality dataset with normal NIR values and no cloud cover achieves the best performance, yielding a testing Kappa score of 0.815. In contrast, class imbalance or abnormal data conditions lead to underfitting and significantly reduced model performance. This research provides a practical framework for data preprocessing, demonstrating that optimizing input data is essential for developing robust segmentation models for agricultural applications.

title: Proof of Sustainability of Clothing in the Fashion Industry Using Blockchain
authors: Z. Altawil, S. Alwheibi, W. AlKhader, K. Salah, R. Jayaraman, M. J. Zemerly, Z. Aung, J. Antony
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society Conference - Global (TEMSCON Global)
abstract: The fashion supply chain faces significant challenges in achieving transparency, traceability, and more importantly, verification of sustainability claims and practices. This paper shows how blockchain, as an enabling technology, can facilitate and provide a proof of sustainability of clothing items by enabling end-to-end traceability and visibility in the key stages of clothing production, distribution, and sales. Our solution employs a smart contract that automates the management and recording of the sustainability certification process and securely records all key actions on an immutable ledger, ensuring trusted traceability and transparency. The paper outlines the system architecture and implementation of the smart contract, including its underlying algorithms, and validates its functionality through rigorous testing. Security and cost analyses demonstrate that the approach is robust and economically viable. A comparative analysis with existing blockchain-based solutions highlights the unique contributions of our framework. This work demonstrates the potential of blockchain to transform and automate sustainable practices management, mitigate greenwashing, and enhance accountability and transparency in fashion supply chains.

title: Transforming Synthetic Aperture Radar Satellite Images to Optical Images Using Generative Adversarial Networks
authors: Kavita Bathe, Dev Mewada, Sumit Chavda, Vimal Mehta, Aditya Mehta
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Synthetic aperture radar (SAR) and optical remote sensing data, due to their unique strengths, are widely used in remote sensing applications. However, both modalities have limitations in terms of interpretability and data availability. This study proposes conversion of SAR to optical image by leveraging the potential of deep learning. A novel architecture LumiPix is introduced for this task. This proposed method addresses key challenges such as geometrical distortions and loss of fine details. This method utilizes a U-Net generator and PatchGAN discriminator, fine-tuned with LAB color space preprocessing, combining luminance and chrominance to differentiate real and fake images. A different preprocessing pipeline guarantees the model will handle the variations in datasets through "Lab" normalization of color spaces and paired images preparation. Moreover, balancing adversarial and L1 losses, LumiPix achieves high-quality translations with enhanced perceptual fidelity and pixel-level accuracy, thus providing a reliable solution for applications in environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster response.

title: SAR Image Generation Algorithm Based on Azimuth Partition Directed Generative Adversarial Network
authors: Ming Liu, Yuqi Yi, Shichao Chen, Hongchen Wang, Guangcai Sun, Mingliang Tao
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Due to the insufficient of SAR images, the accuracy of automatic target recognition (ATR) often fails to meet the requirements of practical applications. In this paper, we propose an azimuth partition directed generative adversarial network (APDGAN) to generate SAR images. The proposed algorithm divides the azimuths into several partitions, and constructs an integrated condition that combines the category and azimuth partition information as the input of the network. The proposed algorithm realizes joint control of the category and azimuth to generate SAR images. We evaluate the generated images on the moving and stationary target acquisition and recognition (MSTAR) dataset. The effectiveness of the proposed algorithm is verified through recognition accuracy and Fréchet inception distance (FID) values.

title: Vehicle-Mounted Multi-Sensor Fusion Slam System for Autonomous Navigation
authors: Chenlei Hao, Haitao Ja, Daoqiang Zhou, Yihan Sun
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The vehicle-mounted multi-sensor fusion simultaneous localization and mapping system (SLAM), aims to solve the problem of accurate positioning and map building for self-driving vehicles in complex environments. The system adopts an end-to-end visual odometry design based on the LoFTR matching algorithm, which can provide robust feature extraction and matching performance in dynamic and complex environments. Meanwhile, the system unifies and converts the information from camera, LIDAR, IMU and loop closure detection to the shared space through the bird's eye view fusion method, which combines the advantages of multiple sensors to realize high-precision position estimation and map construction. The experimental results show that the system can accurately match feature points in the circular corridor scene, optimize the feature point layout of the map, and construct a coherent and complete map.

title: A Compact 28-GHz Power Amplifier Design with a High Turn-Ratio Transformer for Enhanced $P_{{sat}}$ Without Power Combining in 22nm FDSOI CMOS
authors: Khan Md. Zobayer Hassan, Hossein Miri Lavasani
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a highly compact 28 GHz power amplifier (PA) designed in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$22-\text{nm}$</tex> fully-depleted silicon-on-insulator (FDSOI) for mm-Wave 5G wireless application. The proposed PA utilizes an innovative and efficient transformer-based output matching network (OMN) with a high transformation ratio to boost the saturated output power <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\boldsymbol{P}_{\text{sat }})$</tex> without using bulky power combining network, for compactness and efficiency. Detailed electromagnetic (EM) simulation was performed to create a low-loss <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1-2$</tex> transformer with a high coupling (k) <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 0.8$</tex> at 28 GHz and self-resonance frequency (SRF) <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>50 \text{GHz}$</tex>, with primary and secondary inductances of 175 pH and 857 pH, and quality factor of 14.5 and 10, respectively. Biased in Class-AB, the proposed PA achieves a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$P_{\text{sat }}$</tex> of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 24.2 \text{dBm}$</tex>, a power gain of 21 dB and a peak power-added-efficiency (PAE) of 36.5% with a core area of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.106 \text{mm}^{2}$</tex>, occupying significantly smaller area than the state of the art mm-Wave PAs using power combiner to achieve similar <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$P_{\text{sat }}$</tex>.

title: Exploring Complex Compact Polarimetric Coherence for Crop Growth Monitoring
authors: Jiayin Luo, Juan M. Lopez-Sanchez, Irena Hajnsek, Nisha Bao
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In this study, we explored the complex coherence between two polarisation channels in compact-pol data as a tool for monitoring crop growth. The analysis was conducted using compact-pol data synthesized from quad-pol time-series SAR images at L, C, and X band, acquired with an airborne platform. Results from corn and barley indicate that the scattering components derived from the compact-pol coherence exhibit consistent response patterns sensitive to crop growth at different frequency bands and show correlation with ground measurements.

title: tiny Machine Learning on Android Devices: Continuous Health Monitoring with Wearables
authors: Colin Dupuis, Abu K. M. Masum, M. Hassan Najafi, Ulkuhan Guler, Sercan Aygun
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: The growing use of wearable technology for health and activity tracking requires efficient machine learning (ML) models that can handle real-time data on low-power devices. This paper investigates the potential efficiency improvements that Hyperdimensional Computing (HDC) offers compared to more established, conventional ML models. These conventional models include SVM, MLP, and Random Forest models, all of which we implement within an Android WearOS application for comparison. In such resource and power-constrained environments, even modest improvements in power efficiency can significantly impact the feasibility of real-time model deployment, particularly for applications such as activity trackers or health monitors, where fast execution is critical. Accordingly, this study evaluates key metrics including model accuracy, CPU usage, memory usage, and especially power and battery usage. The findings of this study indicate that HDC not only achieves competitive accuracy but also offers substantially higher computational efficiency compared to traditional models.

title: Enhancing Solder Joint Fatigue Life in a Radar Transmit/Receive Module via Vibration Reduction using a Particle Damper in the PCB Enclosure
authors: Sunil Kumar, Anil Kumar
publish: IEEE Transactions on Components, Packaging and Manufacturing Technology
abstract: Transmit/receive (TR) modules in active electronically scanned array radar systems face critical vibration-induced fatigue issues, which are further aggravated by elevated operational temperatures that accelerate solder joint degradation. To address these interconnected thermomechanical failure mechanisms, particle dampers emerge as a promising vibration mitigation strategy in TR modules, owing to their ability to dissipate energy through both impact and friction mechanisms, exhibit temperature insensitivity, and provide effective broadband vibration attenuation. This study investigates the effectiveness of integrating particle dampers within the PCB enclosure of TR modules in increasing the fatigue life of SAC305 solder interconnects subjected to combined thermal and vibrational loads. A comprehensive methodology integrates experimental modal analysis, finite element (FE) modeling, and frequency domain fatigue life prediction. The particle damper parameters are optimized via artificial neural networks trained on experimental vibration test data, followed by FE model validation and calibration against experimental test data (with/without damper). Stress tensors from Abaqus frequency-domain steady-state dynamic analyses are exported to FE-SAFE, enabling solder fatigue life estimation. The results show that the integration of particle damper within the PCB enclosure of the TR module reduces the von Mises stresses in the most critical solder joint by 20–25% and increases the fatigue life upto 187% under severe thermal vibrational load. These findings underscore the important role of particle dampers in extending the operational reliability of high-power electronics in aerospace and defense applications.

title: MOA: Efficient Scene-aware Multi-object Arrangement in VR_supp2-3636062.pdf
authors: Jian Wu
abstract: 3D multi-object arrangement is a fundamental task in VR that relies on accurate and natural initial selection alongside rapid and convenient subsequent manipulation to ensure high efficiency. However, existing methods fail to support efficient multi-object arrangement in highly occluded scenes with densely packed candidate objects through controller-free natural interactions. In this paper, we propose an efficient, scene-aware multi object arrangement method (MOA) designed for fast, precise, and convenient object arrangement. First, MOA introduces an importance-driven multi-object initial selection algorithm that assigns higher spatiotemporally correlated object importance (IMP) to target objects, establishing a natural multi-object initial selection mode that enables quick and accurate selection of high IMP objects. Subsequently, it presents an auxiliary-structure guided multi-object manipulation algorithm that constructs an auxiliary manipulation structure to assist subsequent multi-object manipulation, alongside a multi-modal interaction mode that facilitates swift and natural manipulation. Compared to state of-the-art controller-free and controller-based methods, MOA significantly improves task performance, reduces task load, and enhances convenience in complex multi-object arrangement scenes involving hundreds of highly occluded objects need to be arranged.

title: A Neural Field-Based Approach for View Computation & Data Exploration in 3D Urban Environments_supp1-3635528.mp4
authors: Stefan Cobeli
abstract: Despite the growing availability of 3D urban datasets, extracting insights remains challenging due to computational bottlenecks and the complexity of interacting with data. In fact, the intricate geometry of 3D urban environments results in high degrees of occlusion and requires extensive manual viewpoint adjustments that make large-scale exploration inefficient. To address this, we propose a view-based approach for 3D data exploration, where a vector field encodes views from the environment. To support this approach, we introduce a neural field-based method that constructs an efficient implicit representation of 3D environments. This representation enables both faster direct queries, which consists in the computation of view assessment indices, and inverse queries, which help avoid occlusion and facilitate the search for views that match desired data patterns. Our approach supports key urban analysis tasks such as visibility assessments, solar exposure evaluation, and assessing the visual impact of new developments. We validate our method through quantitative experiments, case studies informed by real-world urban challenges, and feedback from domain experts. Results show its effectiveness in finding desirable viewpoints, analyzing building facade visibility, and evaluating views from outdoor spaces. Code and data are publicly available at urbantk.org/neural-3d.

title: Edge-Guided Refinement Network with Similarity Perception for Salient Object Detection in Optical Remote Sensing Images
authors: Xin Wang, Xian Fang, Mingfeng Jiang, Jinchao Zhu, Zhigao Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Salient object detection in optical remote sensing images (ORSI-SOD) aims to segment salient regions from high-resolution remote sensing images. However, most existing ORSI-SOD methods primarily rely on feature learning of regions to address the issue of blurred edges, while neglecting the potential advantages of similarity calculation in inferring edge clues. To overcome this issue, we propose a novel network with similarity perception termed edge-guided refinement network (ERNet), which distinguishes the edge region of salient objects from coarse to fine through two-stage similarity calculation. Firstly, we introduce the adaptive uncertainty calibration module (AUCM), which utilizes the proposed similarity-based edge perception mechanism (SEPM) to adaptively calibrate edge uncertain information. Secondly, to effectively capture global semantic information, we propose the hierarchical semantic reconstruction module (HSRM), which comprehensively correlates different levels of semantic clues from both internal and external perspectives. Finally, to supplement the local detail of salient objects, we design the dynamic detail interaction module (DDIM), which dynamically extracts detail information of objects at different scales. Extensive experiments on three challenging benchmark datasets have demonstrated the remarkable superiority of our ERNet compared to 30 state-of-the-art models. The source codes will be publicly available at https://github.com/xinwang11/ERNet.

title: A 64-Mpixel 13-bit 610-frames/s CMOS Image Sensor With 11-fJ/Step TDC Assisted Pipelined Column-Parallel ADC
authors: Ruiming Xu, Zhongjie Guo, Suiyang Liu, Ningmei Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: This paper addresses the speed bottleneck issue of traditional column-parallel analog-to-digital conversion circuits during the readout process of ultra-large array CMOS image sensors. A high-speed and low-power ADC based on a pipelined/time-to-digital converter hybrid architecture is proposed.
