This method is based on TDC technology to reduce the parasitic capacitance at the output of the MDAC circuit without compromising the conversion rate of the pipelined architecture, thus achieving a significant reduction in system power consumption. Additionally, the circuit multiplexing technology further enhances the power efficiency of the system. The proposed ADC method has been implemented and verified in a CMOS image sensor chip with an array size of 8192(H)<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\times 8192$</tex-math> </inline-formula>(V), manufactured with the 55 nm 1P4M CMOS process. Operating at the conditions of a clock frequency of 10 MHz and an input signal range of 1.6 V, the 13-bit ADC achieves a conversion rate of 5 MSPS, an SNDR of 73.82 dB, and an ENOB of 11.97 bits with a power consumption of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$214.9~\mu $</tex-math> </inline-formula>W. Compared with advanced ADCs, the proposed ADC achieves an optimal FOM<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sub> value of 0.011 pJ/step, effectively addressing the design contradiction between power consumption and conversion rate in traditional architectures. This chip achieves a row time of 200 ns and a frame rate of 610 fps with 5.23 W of power consumption.

authors: N/A
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computational Intelligence and Robotics (CIR)
abstract: The 2025 International Conference on Computational Intelligence and Robotics (CIR 2025) concluded successfully in Guangzhou, China, from September 12 to 14, 2025. Sponsored by South China University of Technology and supported by Guangdong University of Education, the conference was organized by the latter's School of Physics and Information Engineering and School of Computer Science. It aimed to provide a pragmatic platform for global scholars, researchers, and engineers. It facilitated exchanges on frontier progress, discussions on technical bottlenecks, and exploration of collaborative opportunities in computational intelligence and robotics, with the modest goal of bridging theoretical innovation and industrial application in related fields.

title: Compact Single-Sideband Modulator with High Side-Mode Rejection Ratio and Low Power Consumption
authors: Xiongping Bao, Xiao Chen, Runwei Zhou, Yuheng Wu, Wenjun Li, Wenbing Jiang, Libing Zhou
abstract: In this article, we demonstrate a silicon-based carrier-injection optical single-sideband (OSSB) modulator featuring a double-parallel Mach-Zehnder interferometer architecture. This design simultaneously achieves ultra-low driving voltage and high sideband suppression ratio (SSR). By optimizing the p- and n-doping profiles, the device achieves a V<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">π</sub>·L of approximately 0.0375 V·cm. In OSSB operation, the unwanted sideband is suppressed by around 33 dB, highlighting the modulator’s exceptional sideband suppression. These characteristics—low driving voltage, low loss, and high suppression—make the device highly suitable for homodyne phase-locking, on-chip sensing, and other integrated photonic applications.

title: High-Axis-Symmetrical Eight-Mass MEMS Gyro With Linear Drive and LQR-Based Quadrature Suppression Control
authors: Bo Jiang, Meng Liu, Lemin Zhang, Yixuan Li, Shenhu Huang, Fumin Liu, Yan Su
abstract: The gyroscope with high axial symmetry and dual differential configuration effectively suppresses common-mode disturbances, such as environmental vibrations, serving as a critical strategy for developing high-precision micro-electromechanical systems (MEMS) gyroscopes. This article proposes a highly symmetric eight-mass structure with linear actuation. The structure exhibits a resonance mode similar to the 2<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\theta $</tex-math> </inline-formula> vibrational mode of a disk structure but with a larger proof mass. By incorporating a decoupling frame and a linear capacitive design, the system enables large-amplitude displacement actuation and detection, thereby reducing mechanical thermal noise. In order to overcome the problem of optimizing the order of multiple interference modes caused by multiple masses, this study uses the Lagrangian multibody dynamics method to establish an eight-degree-of-freedom dynamic model of the eight-mass structure and calculates the modal order of the resonator. The theoretical resonance frequencies, calculated based on structural parameters, show a deviation of only 3.95% compared with finite element simulations. Using this approach, the frequency difference between the operational mode and parasitic modes reaches 3.45 kHz, effectively preventing interference from parasitic modes. To address quadrature errors caused by stiffness coupling, this article proposes a linear quadratic regulator (LQR) closed-loop quadrature suppression scheme incorporating electrostatic stiffness. The LQR-based feedback mechanism enables high-precision adjustment of electrostatic stiffness while ensuring system stability. Furthermore, an MEMS gyroscope control circuit designed for modal matching and force balancing was developed. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed eight-mass MEMS gyroscope achieves a scale factor of 147.4 LSB/°/s, a scale factor nonlinearity of 268 ppm, a bias instability of 0.681°/h, and an angle random walk of 0.0623°/<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\surd $</tex-math> </inline-formula>h.

title: Blockchain-Based Lightweight Key Management Scheme for Secure UAV Swarm Task Allocation
authors: Yaqing Zhu, Liquan Chen, Suhui Liu, Bo Yang, Shang Gao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) swarms are a cornerstone technology in the rapidly growing low-altitude economy, with significant applications in logistics, smart cities, and emergency response. However, their deployment is constrained by challenges in secure communication, dynamic group coordination, and resource constraints. Although there are various cryptographic techniques, efficient and scalable group key management plays a critical role in secure task allocation in UAV swarms. Existing group key agreement schemes, both symmetric and asymmetric, often fail to adequately address these challenges due to their reliance on centralized control, high computational overhead, sender restrictions, and insufficient protection against physical attacks. To address these issues, we propose PCDCB (Pairing-free Certificateless Dynamic Contributory Broadcast encryption), a blockchain-assisted lightweight key management scheme designed for UAV swarm task allocation. PCDCB is particularly suitable for swarm operations as it supports efficient one-to-many broadcast of task commands, enables dynamic node join/leave, and eliminates key escrow by combining certificateless cryptography with Physical Unclonable Functions (PUFs) for hardware-bound key regeneration. Blockchain is used to maintain tamper-resistant update tables and ensure auditability, while a privacy-preserving mechanism with pseudonyms and a round mapping table provides task anonymity and unlinkability. Comprehensive security analysis confirms that PCDCB is secure and resistant to multiple attacks. Performance evaluation shows that, in large-scale swarm scenarios (n = 100), PCDCB reduces the cost of group key computation by 54.4% (up to 96.9%) and reduces the time to generate the decryption keys by at least 29.7%. In addition, PCDCB achieves the lowest communication cost among all compared schemes and demonstrates strong scalability with increasing group size.

title: Multidimensional Constellation Design Based on Geometric Shaping for MISO VLC With Per-LED Optical Power Constraints
authors: Bo Gao, Jia-Ning Guo, Jian Zhang, Yan-Yu Zhang, Dun Li
abstract: Visible light communication (VLC) integrates illumination and communication, offering significant potential for 6 G mobile communications. In 6 G communications, reliability and low latency are critical. To meet these demands, finite blocklength codewords are employed for data transmission. For indoor VLC scenarios, multiple light-emitting diodes (LEDs) serve as transmitters, with each transmitter operating under distinct optical power constraints tailored to user requirements. In this paper, a multidimensional constellation design based on geometric shaping is proposed for multi-input single-output (MISO) VLC with per-LED optical power constraints. This design employs truncated cubic shaping to design the equivalent transmitted signal and decomposes it into transmitted signals using a partition-based greedy decomposition. The proposed scheme designs signals in the finite blocklength regime while adhering to per-LED optical power constraints. Simulation results for indoor MISO VLC systems demonstrate the advantages of the proposed scheme over benchmark schemes and quantify the performance gains as well as the gap to the Shannon limit.

title: Robot-Mediated Physical Human–Human Interaction in Rehabilitation: A Position Paper
authors: Lorenzo Vianello, Matthew Short, Julia Manczurowsky, Emek Barş Küçüktabak, Francesco Di Tommaso, Alessia Noccaro, Laura Bandini, Shoshana Clark, Alaina Fiorenza, Francesca Lunardini, Alberto Canton, Marta Gandolla, Alessandra L. G. Pedrocchi, Emilia Ambrosini, Manuel Murie-Fernández, Carmen B. Román, Jesus Tornero, Natacha Leon, Andrew Sawers, Jim Patton, Domenico Formica, Nevio Luigi Tagliamonte, Georg Rauter, Kilian Baur, Fabian Just, Christopher J. Hasson, Vesna D. Novak, Jose L. Pons
abstract: Neurorehabilitation conventionally relies on the interaction between a patient and a physical therapist. Robotic systems can improve and enrich the physical feedback provided to patients after neurological injury, but they under-utilize the adaptability and clinical expertise of trained therapists. In this position paper, we advocate for a novel approach that integrates the therapist’s clinical expertise and nuanced decision-making with the strength, accuracy, and repeatability of robotics: Robot-mediated physical Human–Human Interaction. This framework, which enables two individuals to physically interact through robotic devices, has been studied across diverse research groups and has recently emerged as a promising link between conventional manual therapy and rehabilitation robotics, harmonizing the strengths of both approaches. Although current findings are largely based on pilot studies and conceptual frameworks, integrating therapists’ expertise with the functionalities offered by robotic systems represents a promising direction for improving rehabilitation outcomes. This paper presents the rationale of a multidisciplinary team—including engineers, doctors, and physical therapists—for conducting research that utilizes: a unified taxonomy to describe robot-mediated rehabilitation, a framework of interaction based on social psychology, and a technological approach that makes robotic systems seamless facilitators of natural human-human interaction.

title: BlockNetSys'25: 1st Workshop on Blockchain-Network Synergy: Addressing Network-Centric Challenges in Decentralized Systems
authors: Huawei Huang, Dusit Niyato, Yi Sun, Hironori Washizaki
publish: Proceedings of the 21st International Conference on emerging Networking EXperiments and Technologies
abstract: BlockNetSys promotes a network-aware co-design of consensus, dissemination, and verifiable networking. With 22 submissions, 10 were accepted (~45.5%), spanning multicast propagation, eBPF/SGX- and SDN-based auditing, Bayesian/game-theoretic DoS defense, and ledger-driven decisions for edge/vehicular and extreme IoT. Results indicate that topology-aware propagation shortens confirmation tails and reduces traffic, tiered evidence (rich off-chain telemetry with on-chain commitments) enables line-rate, compliance-ready accountability, security posture must be tuned against liveness/finality, and edge learning gains from blockchain-backed provenance and incentives. We group contributions into four areas: Network-aware Consensus and Dissemination; On-/Off-chain Auditing and SDN Accountability; Security Modeling and DoS Defense; and Ledger-driven Edge/IoT Offloading and Coordination.

title: INet4AI '25: 1st Workshop on Inter-networking challenges for AI
authors: Dirk Kutscher, Antoine Fressancourt
publish: Proceedings of the 21st International Conference on emerging Networking EXperiments and Technologies
abstract: The CoNEXT 2025 INet4AI workshop explores the networking challenges of large-scale distributed AI workloads in environments characterized by node and network heterogeneity, as well as dynamically changing resource availability and utilization. In this inaugural edition, researchers from both academia and industry present promising approaches for adapting collective communication mechanisms to the unique constraints of Internet-scale distributed AI systems.

title: Hyperspectral Image Classification Based on Class Incremental Learning with Selective State Space Models
authors: Hong Zhou, Dunbin Shen, Zhenrong Du, Jie Wang, Hongyu Wang, Xiaorui Ma
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Deep neural networks have shown significant potential in advancing hyperspectral image classification. However, to enable the adaptive recognition of new land cover categories, class-incremental learning (CIL) plays a crucial role in hyperspectral image classification. Despite its potential, CIL faces limitations such as the memory constraints and data privacy concerns. Furthermore, existing CIL methods often rely on static adaptation, employing a predetermined parameter framework to process sequentially incoming data, which increases the risk of overfitting to the current session. To address these challenges, we first propose a pseudo-sample generation network to prevent the knowledge forgetting of previous classes and enhance the diversity of new classes. Then we employ an adaptive selective state space models (SSMs) projector that adjusts its projection parameters based on intermediate features to enable dynamic adaptation. This SSMs projector design allows the model to preserve essential characteristics of base classes, while dynamically adapting to the feature shifts of new classes. Extensive experimentals and analysis on representative dataset validated the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Pasteables: A Secure On-Body Health Monitoring Platform
authors: Peyman Dehghanzadeh, Reiner N. Dizon-Paradis, Rohan Reddy Kalavakonda, Aritra Dasgupta, Baibhab Chatterjee, Swarup Bhunia
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: In this paper, we present Pasteables, a flexible platform for secure health monitoring through a network of onbody, stick-and-peel, intelligent sensing devices. These devices are equipped with appropriate sensors and integrate compute, storage, and communication capabilities, along with embedded intelligence to extract meaningful insights into health conditions. Despite their advantages, these devices, similar to wearables and implants, are susceptible to a range of confidentiality and integrity threats. We identify the key security and privacy challenges associated with these systems and propose low-cost, effective countermeasures. Additionally, we outline future research directions in the security of such devices.

title: Generalized Fast Back-Projection Algorithm within the ECEF Coordinate System for Geo-Leo Bi-Static TMSAR
authors: Tao He, Weijie Wang, Pengbo Wang, Lei Yu, Tian Qiu, Jie Chen
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In order to improve the imaging efficiency and accuracy for geosynchronous-low-orbit (GEO-LEO) bi-static terrain matching synthetic aperture radar (TMSAR), a generalized fast back-projection algorithm (GFBPA) is proposed in this paper. The imaging grid is creatively composed of fan-shaped cells along the orientation of terrain matching scene, and meshed as a curved surface, instead of a plane, within the Earth-centered Earth-fixed (ECEF) coordinate system. In this configuration, the coarse-resolution grid used for TMSAR sub-apertures back projection can be obtained by down-sampling the full-resolution grid directly along its vertical direction, and the mismatches in the back-projection operation caused by ground curvature and terrain relief can be alleviated significantly. During the GFBPA processing, the two-step spectrum compression filters in three-dimension (3-D) space are re-derived to avoid sub-aperture image spectrum aliasing under Cartesian coordinates effectively, and the multi-stage image fusion is adopted to maximize the acceleration of the entire operation. An experiment is conducted in the end of this paper, which demonstrates the validation of the proposed algorithm.

title: Submodule Output Voltage Compensation with Phase Shifted Carrier Modulation in Modular Multilevel Converters
authors: Constantinos Liagas, Xianwu Zeng, Han Wang
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The control of circulating currents in Modular Multilevel Converters (MMC) is desired for its benefits to stability of the system as well as reducing peak arm currents. In this paper, a simplified method for the control of circulating currents is implemented that is based on a simple scaling of the Sub module (SM) duty cycle reference, itself also based on the ratio of desired vs. actual capacitor voltage. This approach maintains transparency for a conventional 3-phase reference input, in terms of the required adjustments to maintain the MMC balanced and Circulating Currents under control, when using Phase Shifted Carrier Modulation (PS-PWM) as this scheme allows for direct manipulation of individual SM duty cycle values. The use of filtered samples of the voltages of the SM capacitors is shown to offer a strong simplification of the control of circulating currents when using PS-PWM.

title: Multi-Domain Precipitation Retrievals using Machine Learning and Satellite Observations from the GOES-R Series
authors: Yifan Yang, Mahmood R. Azimi-Sadjadi, Haonan Chen
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This paper proposes a deep learning (DL)-based precipitation estimation approach applicable across various domains using the observations from the Advanced Baseline Imager (ABI), and Geostationary Lightning Mapper (GLM) on the GOES-R series. The cloud-top brightness temperature from ABI and lightning flash rate from GLM are used as inputs, and rainfall estimates from the ground-based Multi-Radar/Multi-Sensor (MRMS) system are used as the target labels. The multi-domain scheme allows the trained machine learning model to effectively adapt to data from different application domains. The experimental results show that the adjusted DL model using the proposed multi-domain scheme can offer more accurate precipitation estimates than the results without domain adaptation over the new domains.

title: Least Squares Approximation Overmodulation Based on the Law of Conservation of Energy
authors: Zhekai Liu, Yuan Zhu, Ling Meng
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The classical overmodulation methods exhibit limited fidelity in approximating the output voltage waveform to the ideal sinusoidal waveform, resulting in high total harmonic distortion and suboptimal transition performance at high modulation indices. To address these issues, this paper proposes an approximation function to ensure that the actual output voltage closely approximates the reference voltage. The approximation function is derived based on the law of conservation of energy: by deriving the area equivalence rules for the voltage vector trajectory, comparing the output voltage vector with the sinusoidal reference voltage vector, the problem is reformulated as a least squares function approximation. Specifically, the voltage projection onto real-axis is modeled as the least squares approximation function with respect to the angle and amplitude. The sine wave is to be approximated and the least squares approximation error is applied to optimize angle and amplitude. Finally, simulation analysis and bench experiment results validate the effectiveness of the proposed methods.

title: A Stratified Individual Tree Segmentation Method Using Backpack LiDAR Point Cloud
authors: Linzhi Jiang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Backpack Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) can quickly acquire point cloud data and record the structural parameters of each tree, becoming an important means for estimating individual tree structural parameters. Individual tree segmentation is a key prerequisite for estimating individual tree structural parameters using backpack LiDAR. However, most of the current individual tree segmentation methods are based on airborne or terrestrial LiDAR, and these methods cannot be directly applied to individual tree segmentation from backpack LiDAR point clouds. Therefore, this study proposes a method for individual tree segmentation from backpack LiDAR point clouds. The basic idea of this method is to first detect the under-branch trunk, then separate the under-branch trunk from the canopy, over-segment the canopy, use the information of under-branch trunk to correct the over-segmentation results of the canopy, and finally combine the under-branch trunk with the canopy to form an individual tree. Experiments show that the F1 score of the segmentation results in three areas with different levels of tree density are all above 0.95, indicating that this method has practical application capabilities in the field of individual tree segmentation.

title: Classification of Ergonomic Sitting Positions Behind a Desk using MobileNetV2
authors: Theresia Amelia Pawitra, Anindita Septiarini, Jorghi Inzaghi Tanson, Farida Djumiati Sitania, Aji Ery Burhandenny, Hamdani Hamdani
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: Nonergonomic sitting position is one of the factors that cause workers to experience health problems when working behind a desk. Deviations from ergonomic sitting positions include a bowed head, elbows positioned away from the sides of the body, and sitting without back support. As a result, workers can experience injuries, such as lower back pain and musculoskeletal system disorders. The application of ergonomic sitting positions enables the muscles to adapt and receive the necessary oxygenated blood flow, allowing the body to become more relaxed while working and increasing worker productivity. This research utilizes computer vision and machine learning approaches as a solution to the problem. This research aims to implement the Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) method, utilizing the MobileNetV2 pre-training architecture, to classify ergonomic and nonergonomic sitting positions. The total images used was 1620, with each class totaling 810 images. The images are divided into three types of data with a ratio of 80:10:10. Two CNN models with custom classifier heads were trained using hyperparameters such as the RMSProp optimizer, a learning rate of 0.001, a batch size of 32, and 100 epochs. Model 1 was selected as the best model, achieving a training accuracy of 96%, a training loss of 9%, a validation accuracy of $95 \%$, and a validation loss of $13 \%$. The model was tested using a confusion matrix with test data, yielding the following test results: an accuracy of 95%, a precision of 95%, a recall of 95%, and an F1-score of 95%.

title: Haishao-1: The First VLEO Multi-Polarization Micro-SAR Mission
authors: Jili Sun, Shuohan Cheng, Hongliang Lu, Wen Sun, Yuanchang Li, Xiping Yue, Pengfei Sun, Xingbo Han, Xingqiang Lu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The HaiShao-1 (HS-1) is China’s first very low earth orbit (VLEO) multi-polarization micro synthetic aperture radar (SAR) satellite. Its SAR payload supports multiple imaging modes, achieving a highest resolution of 0.5 meters and a maximum swath width of 160 kilometers. It encompasses various polarization modes, including single, dual, quad, and compact polarizations. Notably, it is the first in the world to achieve 1-meter high-resolution stripmap imaging over a 10-kilometer swath. Additionally, the HS-1 SAR payload features high-performance intelligent computing and on-orbit software reconfiguration capabilities. Despite its compact size, light weight, and low cost, it delivers excellent ground imaging performance. This paper introduces the design of the HS-1’s SAR payload, including its antenna and electronic equipment, and verifies the payload’s imaging performance through on-orbit measured data results.

title: Projected And Past Land Use And Land Cover Change In The Chure Region Of Nepal 1988-2027
authors: Maria Solis-Aulestia, Rohan Sadler, Thayse Nery, Maksym Polyakov, Ram Pandit
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: A fragile geology, a high reliability on forestry and unsustainable agricultural practices within the Chure region of Nepal have accelerated changes in the landscape. Land use and land cover changes (LULC) were analyzed using Landsat imageries from 1988, 2001 and 2014. Also, a simulation for 2027 was performed combining Markov transition probabilities, a multilayer perceptron neural network, and cellular automata. Slope and population density were incorporated as potential explanatory variables. The results show that forests decrease from 1988 to 2001 from 13,500 km<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> to 12,492 km<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, increasing by 2014 to 12,590 km<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. Agriculture increased from 3,804 km<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> to 4,959 km<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> from 1988 to 2001, and decreased to 4,743 km<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> by 2014. Bare areas in 1988 and 2001 represented 1,095 km<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and 925 km<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, increasing by 2014 to 1,026 km<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. By 2027, forest reached 13,386 km<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> while agriculture and bare areas decreased to 4,257 km<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and 781 km<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> respectively. These figures could be attributable to the implementation of Community Forestry and/or adoption of agroforestry.

title: A Novel Ship Recognition Method Based on Multi-Source Image Fusion
authors: Xueying Yang, Gaopeng Li, Yun Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In recent years, the recognition technology for ship targets has become a research hotspot. Ship targets have a variety of detection forms, where optical imaging and radar imaging are two important means. However, the quality of acquired multi-source images can be easily affected by external conditions and their own sensor limitations in practice. It is worth considering how to simultaneously and fully utilize the characteristics of optical and radar images to improve the recognition rate of ships. To solve these problems, this paper proposes a new radar-to-optical image conversion and fusion algorithm for ships based on U-GAT-IT by utilizing the strong correlation between ISAR images and optical images. The proposed algorithm obtains a higher-quality target-generated image, which effectively improves the ship recognition rate. Experimental results verify the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

title: Feasibility Study of Resonant Circuits for Ferrite-Less High Frequency Step-Up DC-DC Converter
authors: Oleksandr Matiushkin, Oleksandr Husev, Mykola Lukianov, Enrique Romero-Cadaval, Carlos Roncero-Clemente
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The integration of new semiconductor materials into power electronic products is becoming increasingly popular to enhance performance and reduce converter costs. This paper presents a comparison of resonant circuits for ferrite-less, Gallium Nitride (GaN)-based step-up DC-DC converters. The converter is designed as a microconverter operating at a high switching frequency (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{MHz}^{+}$</tex>) for photovoltaic applications. A key criterion for high-frequency operation is zero-voltage switching, the conditions for which are analyzed in this study. An experimental prototype is developed, and the corresponding experimental results, including an efficiency estimation, are presented.

title: An Improved Snow Depth Estimation Using ICESat-2 ATL03 Product at 1-Km Scale in Mountainous Regions
authors: Tongrui Chen, Lingmei Jiang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The ICESat-2 onboard LiDAR has achieved snow depth estimation in mountainous areas with high spatial heterogeneity, but the accuracy at scales of 1 km and below still needs improvement. Combining a 3-m ASO DTM and ICESat-2 ATL03 data, we present an enhanced snow depth aggregation method featuring photon coverage filtering and empirical track-to-grid upscaling. Two filtering strategies are applied: (1) elevated photon coverage thresholds for all slopes, and (2) spatial aggregation and upscaling restricted to sparse-photon measurements from slopes <10°. The validation in the Tuolumne River Basin, USA, demonstrated MAEs of 0.28 m and 0.17 m at the 1 km scale, respectively. This study has provided more reliable snow depth estimates for mountainous regions with scarce observational data.

title: Impact of Engine Efficiency Map Deviation on Optimal Energy Management of Hybrid Powertrains
authors: Guikun Tan, Yanfei Li, Shijin Shuai
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Plug-in hybrid vehicles (PHEVs) are a feasible and practical solution to realize the electrification of passenger cars and thus reduce fuel consumption. The optimal fuel economy of PHEVs relies on energy management strategies (EMSs), which coordinate the power of the engine and the motor based on the engine efficiency map. This paper proposes a pattern regarding the impact of engine efficiency map deviation on the optimal control of EMS based on an analysis based on Pontryagin's minimum principle. The pattern is that when the engine efficiency is improved in the region above the maximum efficiency torque, for an EMS optimal control with a state of charge (SOC) that first decreases and then increases, the deviated optimal control will result in a lower SOC trajectory. Then the pattern was applied to improve the equivalent consumption minimization strategy. An engine dedicated to PHEV was tested on a bench to obtain engine efficiency maps with different fuels and a series/parallel PHEV was modeled for the simulation of EMS. The results demonstrated that the modified strategy reduced the equivalent fuel consumption by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.02 \mathrm{L} / 100 \text{km}(0.5 \%)-0.05 \mathrm{L} / 100 \text{km}(1.4 \%)$</tex>.

title: Temporal Differencing Strategies for Optimal Band Selection in Sentinel-2 MSI for Algal Bloom Studies
authors: Vikash K Mishra, Upendra Pratap Singh, Fred Nicolls, Amit Kumar Mishra, Himanshu Maurya
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Multi-spectral images (MSIs) efficiently delineate the feature of interest if the appropriate band imageries are in hand. Due to the several spectral ranges of MSI, the different terrestrial features respond differently in the other spectral range. The spectral response of algae is entirely different from the water in the marine ecosystem. In this study, we propose to use principal component analysis-based features with time differencing operations to determine the most useful bands in the multispectral image (MSI) data for the study of algal bloom. The useful bands obtained from the proposed strategy show significant overlap (of up to 0.429) with the time differencing-based strategies mentioned in the literature in terms of Jaccard, Resemblance, Overlap, and Sorensen-Dice scores, suggesting that the proposed approach correctly and efficiently (as PCA-features are used instead of original features) finds these useful bands with the most recent scheme. From the experiments, we determine that B8, B8a, B6, B7, and B5 are the most useful bands in the Sentinel-2 MSI data. We propose using these bands to train different change detection classifiers to detect and monitor algae growth in the oceans.

title: Patch-Based Tiny Object Classification for High Resolution Aerial Images
authors: Mohammad Iqbal Nouyed, Gianfranco Doretto, Donald A. Adjeroh
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The multiclass classification of tiny objects of images taken from unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) is a challenging task within the field of computer vision research. In order to address this challenge, we propose an efficient patch-based tiny object classification framework. To improve the classification performance and optimize the model efficiency, we present the one-vs-all binary classification-based problem decomposition approach, a z-score-based cluster sampling for selecting the discriminative patches to train the binary classifiers, integration of the decisions from different classifiers at patch level, and finally application of a neighborhood-based image-level decision-fusion to get the image-level label. Using a high-resolution aerial image database, we demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach.

title: Practical Implementation of Distributed Node Selection in Cooperative ARQ-Based Energy Harvesting Wireless Networks
authors: Cooper J. Koch, Alexander H. Burkholder, Ahmed Ammar
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: Wireless networks utilize Cooperative Automatic Repeat Request (C-ARQ) protocols to enhance reliability. A key element of these protocols is selecting the appropriate node for retransmission to optimize performance. While various node selection criteria have been proposed, limited attention has been given to implementing distributed criteria. Therefore, this paper proposes a practical method for implementing distributed node selection criteria in a network of multiple energy-harvesting nodes and a base station. While we apply this method to a criterion that focuses solely on the current energy levels of the nodes, given our emphasis on energy harvesting wireless networks, the method can be easily adapted to other criteria, such as those that also consider channel conditions. The results show that the proposed method performs as expected. However, the method cannot prevent duplicate transmissions caused by nodes having the same or relatively close energy battery levels.

title: Interactive Learning Of Indonesia Wayang Kulit With Slam-Based Markerless Augmented Reality
authors: Andy Pramono, Mitra Istiar Wardhana, Betty Dewi Puspasari, Nuril Kusuma Wardani, Nik Zulkarnaen Khidzir
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: Wayang kulit is a cultural heritage full of life values, both from the characters performed and the storyline of the wayang performance itself. Wayang Kulit has existed and developed rapidly since the 10th century. Wayang Kulit, one of Indonesia cultural treasures recognized by UNESCO as a Cultural Heritage, is currently facing a tough challenge. The decreasing number of wayang kulit performances has resulted in a decrease in the number of spectators. This also causes a lack of public knowledge, especially among the younger generation, regarding wayang kulit. Related to the decreasing socialization and implementation of digital technology related to the Indonesian wayang kulit. To address this, we developed WayangEDU, a mobile application that employs markerless Augmented Reality (AR) based on the SLAM approach. WayangEDU serves as an interactive educational medium to teach users about Wayang Kulit characters and stage props, providing a novel learning experience. We conducted both AR Performance and User Satisfaction tests. The AR performance results demonstrate that WayangEDU runs smoothly on all tested Android devices, particularly mid-range and higher-end models. User Satisfaction tests showed significant improvements in application consistency, error handling, and search functionality. These findings indicate that the AR-based WayangEDU application effectively bridges the gap between traditional culture and modern technology, supporting the preservation of Indonesian Wayang Kulit heritage.

title: Mitigating Frequency Instability in Microgrids Using Virtual Inertia and Fopid Control
authors: Sulaiman Z. Almutairi
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The increasing reliance on renewable energy sources (RES) has resulted in a reduced contribution from conventional generation units in the electrical grid, leading to a gradual decline in microgrid inertia. This reduction poses significant challenges to frequency stability within microgrid power systems. To address this issue, this paper introduces a virtual inertia rotor technique designed to effectively compensate for the loss of system inertia. The proposed method utilizes a Tilt-Integral-Derivative (TID) controller and a Fractional-Order Proportional-Integral-Derivative (FOPID) controller for load frequency control. However, due to the high penetration of RESs or sudden load fluctuations, the microgrid system frequency may experience unexpected deviations. To mitigate these risks, the proposed technique is integrated with a frequency protection relay scheme, ensuring the dynamic security of the microgrid, particularly under critical conditions. The effectiveness of this coordination is validated using MATLAB simulations under various load and generation imbalance scenarios.

title: Comparison of Different min-max based Offset Voltage Injections for Cascaded H-bridge Converters
authors: Mohammad Umar Khan, Obrad Dordevic, Martin Jones
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The equivalence between the space-vector pulse width modulation (PWM) and the carrier-based PWM can be realised through appropriate offset voltage injection to sinusoidal phase reference waveforms. Carrier-based modulation is generally favoured in multilevel converters as the complexity and resource utilization of the space vector PWM is high in comparison. For two-level inverters, min-max offset injection is known to reduce current THD whereas for multilevel converters, like the cascaded H-bridge converter (CHB), the same result is generally achieved through the double min-max offset injection. However, this result is not always true for all regions of the modulation index range when the total harmonic distortion (THD) of the load phase current is evaluated. This paper validates a previously proposed second min-max offset injection as optimal in conjunction with the level-shifted in-phase disposition PWM strategy. It is shown to achieve the lowest THD of the phase current waveforms for a three-phase CHB converter operating in the linear modulation index range below unity. However, in the overmodulation region, the double min-max injection is still preferred. The results have been confirmed experimentally using a three-phase nine-level CHB converter with an RL load.

title: Characteristics of Potential Sources and Transport Paths of Precipitation Surge in Beijing During the Rainy Season
authors: Luping Gong, Yazhen Jiang, Menglin Si, Dandan Duan, Xinyu Lan, Chuan Zhan
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Survey data indicate substantial variations in precipitation in Beijing in recent years; however, a comprehensive investigation into the underlying causes remains lacking. Therefore, this study utilizes the Lagrangian water vapor tracking model to analyze the transport pathways of water vapor during the rainy season from 2020 to 2024. By quantifying the intensity of water vapor transport (QVT) and employing concentration-weighted trajectory (WCWT) analysis, the study further identifies potential source regions of water vapor. The results reveal that: (1) the water vapor responsible for July precipitation in Beijing primarily originates from Eurasian continental and oceanic pathways, including the Pacific Ocean and the South China Sea; (2) the westerly wind belt plays a dominant role in water vapor transport, while the southeast monsoon significantly enhances the contribution of oceanic water vapor; (3) reduced precipitation in low-value years (2020 and 2022) is linked to weakened water vapor transport from the ocean, attributed to a weakened southeast monsoon. This analysis confirms that the water vapor transport mechanism during the July rainy season is shaped by a combination of westerly transport and the monsoon system, with oceanic water vapor making a notably significant contribution to precipitation.

title: Exploring the Potential of Polarimetric and Interferometric SAR Variables for Deforestation Mapping
authors: Anam Sabir, Chumbitha Leena, Unmesh Khati
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) serves as an important data source for continuous monitoring, especially across the tropics. The structural and dielectric properties of targets can be studied with the help of the wide range of SAR derivatives. This study aims at testing and understanding the potential of polarimetric and interferometric SAR variables for deforestation mapping across tropical and sub-tropical areas. Statistical change detection method Cumulative Sums of Change is used in this study for understanding the potential of backscatter and coherence derived from C-band Sentinel-1 SAR data for deforestation monitoring in Haldwani Forest Range in India. A rule-based decision making approach is applied on the change map generated with backscatter using the coherence to reduce the number of false positives due to shorter wavelength. With backscatter-only approach, overall accuracy 0.58 and kappa coefficient of 0.23 were obtained with VH polarization. However, with coherence-based compensation approach an improvement of 39.6% (A<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">O</inf>=0.81) and 120.8% (κ=0.53) was observed in the overall accuracy and kappa coefficient.

title: “Spot the Glacial Lake” with the magic of SAR and Deep Learning
authors: Subhranil Mustafi, Rajkumar Maity, Sarbani Palit, Rajat Kumar Pal
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Glacial lakes serve as a key indicator for analyzing the risks associated with ice-mass loss, glacier retreat, and the potential for glacier lake outburst floods (GLOFs). Existing glacial lake mapping techniques in mountainous regions primarily rely on manual or semi-automated threshold-based methods or the use of highly expensive satellite imagery, which are limited in scalability, efficiency, and financial reach for common researchers. At the heart of the proposed approach is the ‘GLDeepNet’, a fully automated deep convolutional neural network (DCNN) specially designed for glacial lake mapping using publicly, readily available satellite data, including multispectral, thermal, microwave, and digital elevation models (DEM). Its architecture comprises of 2D convolutional layers with carefully selected hyperparameters. An important contribution is the pre-processing step, which includes an optimal choice of the spectral bands and adequate processing of the SAR data to generate the input to ‘GLDeepNet’. An equally noteworthy contribution is the application of morphological operations as a part of the post-processing step. 1050 images have been trained in the eastern Himalayan range, with testing done on 750 images across an entirely different region—the north-central Himalayas, which has significantly greater vulnerability to glacial lakes than other trans-Himalayan ranges. The model produces an accuracy (0.98), precision (0.9) recall (0.94) and a strong correlation (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.91) between predicted and reference lake boundaries. Hence the proposed approach offers a scalable, automated solution for glacial lake mapping across large regions, which is rightfully a feather in its cap, making it stand well apart from other such approaches for glacial lake detection.

title: A Neural Network Algorithm with Three Hidden Layers for Subpixel Target Detection
authors: Edisanter Lo, Emmett J. Ientilucci
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Subpixel target detection in hyperspectral imaging is a binary classification with an abundance of pixels for training the background class but only one pixel for training the target class. The imbalance in sample sizes of training pixels for the two classes is a problem in artificial neural networks. The objective of this paper is to mathematically develop a new algorithm for subpixel target detection of rare targets in hyperspectral imaging and assess its performance. The algorithm is derived from a deep neural network with three hidden layers. The objective function in conventional neural networks is typically solved numerically using a gradient descent method with a fixed step size. The iteration using a fixed step size may lead to divergence in subpixel target detection. The unconstrained minimization problem of the objective function is solved numerically using a gradient descent method with a new variable step size. Additional subpixel target pixels for training the target class are generated from the single full target pixel using synthetic signature modeling. The decision boundary for the deep neural network is nonlinear for the transformed pixels at the input layer. Experimental results from a hyperspectral image are presented to assess the performance of the proposed algorithm. The results show that the algorithm can perform better than conventional algorithms, which are based on generalized likelihood ratio test. Lastly, we note our new variable step size improves convergence.

title: Combining Superpixel Segmentation and Random Forest for Lithological Classification using Advanced Hyperspectral Imager (AHSI) Imagery Onboard Gaofen-5B (GF-5B) Satellite
authors: Jia Weijie, Feng Siwei, Yang Jinzhong, Xu Huize, Chen Ling, Bian Yu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Lithological classification and identification is a significant research focus in the field of remote sensing geology. However, there are still many challenges due to the complexity of lithological compositions, the similar image characteristics of different lithology, and surface conditions, such as weathering and vegetation cover, which complicate the lithological classification process. Hyperspectral remote sensing, with its advantages of high spectral dimensional data, greatly enhances the capability for fine identification and discrimination of terrestrial features. Gaofen-5B satellite launched at Sept. 2021, carried the Advanced Hyperspectral Imager (AHSI) offers broad coverage and extremely high hyperspectral resolution, which promote the needs for large scale lithological mapping and mineral identification. We propose a method which combined superpixel segmentation with random forest (SLIC-RF) for lithological classification. Cluster pixels with similar features into a super-pixel region, then create a training sample set for random forest classification. Traditional and machine learning methods are used as competing methods, trained on GF-5B principal component analysis (PCA) results, and evaluated results according to training sets, overall accuracy, Kappa coefficient. The results indicate that the proposed method exhibits a significant effectiveness in the lithological classification of bedrock exposure areas. Compared with traditional methods, the proposed method based on superpixel segmentation and random forests demonstrates higher accuracy and robustness, enabling better discrimination of lithology with similar features and providing clearer lithological boundaries.

title: Effect of Spatial Resolution on the Remote Detection of Siam Weed
authors: Deepak Gautam, Panagiota Arvanitis
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Chromolaena odorata (Siam weed) is an invasive species posing threats to biodiversity, agriculture, and ecosystems. Effective management relies on scalable monitoring solutions, whereby traditional field surveys are labour-intensive and costly. Drone-based remote detection offers a promising alternative; however, detection performance is influenced by spatial resolution. Finer resolutions provide greater detail at the expense of scalability, while coarser resolutions risk a loss of accuracy. This study investigates the impact of spatial resolution on Siam weed detection using drone-captured RGB imagery processed with the YOLOv5s deep learning model. Detection performance was evaluated at four spatial resolutions (2 cm, 4 cm, 8 cm, and 12 cm), and the assessment utilised precision, recall, and F1-Score metrics. Results demonstrate that while finer resolutions (2 cm, 4 cm) enhance detail, they are prone to higher false-positive rates, whereas coarser resolutions (12 cm) struggle to detect smaller or sparsely distributed occurrences effectively. The 8 cm resolution achieved the best balance, with an F1-Score of 0.92, optimising accuracy, scalability, and computational efficiency. These findings provide practical guidance for refining drone-based monitoring workflows and advancing invasive species management strategies.

title: RC-YOLO: A Modified YOLO Network for Small Oriented Target Detection in RS Images
authors: Haozhe Zhou, Wanying Yang, Xiaoliang Yang, Jinsheng Ren
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Small oriented target detection in remote sensing (RS) images is a challenging task due to inadequate feature representation and background interference. To alleviate these challenges, we propose a modified YOLOv11 model named RC-YOLO. This model incorporates enhancements to the C3k2 module. It uses receptive-field attention convolution and an efficient multi-scale attention module. These changes improve feature extraction adaptability and reduce the overall parameter count. Furthermore, we integrate the content-aware reassembly of features(CARAFE) module in the neck to optimize the upsampling process and enhance feature representation. Two public datasets (DIOR-R and DOTA) for oriented object detection are used to validate the effectiveness of RC-YOLO.

title: Environment-Adaptive Representation Interaction for Privacy-Perturbed Graphs Against Deceptive OOD Attacks
authors: Ju Jia, Renjie Li, Cong Wu, Yebo Feng, Siqi Ma, Lina Wang, Robert H. Deng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have gained increasing popularity in understanding graph-structured data due to their ability to derive meaningful representations by aggregating complicated topological information. However, privacy operations such as differential privacy mechanisms that inject noise into node features or graph structures to protect sensitive information, and distribution shifts in graph data pose tremendous security risks for the wide application of GNN models. Current researches mainly focus on defending the out-of-distribution (OOD) attacks through robust adversarial training and graph structure purification. Nonetheless, privacy perturbations of graph structures may render OOD attacks more deceptive by obfuscating the distinctiveness of nodes, leading to the failure of existing defense methods. To address these shortcomings, we propose an environment-adaptive representation interaction (EARI) scheme that strengthens the privacy perception of GNNs. Specifically, our scheme leverages the interaction between non-private and private data to enable targeted embedding propagation by the guidance of confidence score feedback. Subsequently, the representation-enriched topological aggregation is implemented to capture more discriminative features by exploiting multi-hop neighborhoods rather than stacked multilayers. Finally, the generalization-enhanced cluster-wise adaptation learning is leveraged to highlight the invariant correlations from nodes across different environments. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that our scheme can enhance the capability of learning representations from privacy-protected graph data, enabling GNNs to effectively defend against deceptive OOD attacks on various graph-structured datasets. Moreover, we reveal that the utilization of interactive topological aggregation can extremely enrich the diversity and guarantee the effectiveness for graph representations.

title: Multi-temporal Optical and Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) Satellite Imagery for Estimating Canola Harvest Dates Using Machine Learning
authors: Hansanee Fernando, Kwabena Nketia, Thuan Ha, Sarah van Steenbergen, Steve Shirtliffe
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Canola, a cornerstone of Canadian agriculture, contributes over $43 billion annually to the national economy and occupies approximately 20 million acres. Traditional monitoring methods, such as crop reporter surveys, are often limited by spatial coverage and consistency. This study explores the integration of multi-temporal Sentinel-1 (SAR) and Sentinel-2 (optical) satellite imagery with deep learning to predict canola harvest dates across Saskatchewan, Canada, over five growing seasons (2020–2024). Twenty-two vegetation and radar-based indices were computed within the Google Earth Engine environment, capturing dynamic canopy, moisture, and phenological changes. Gradient time series (first derivatives) of these indices were used to train univariate Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) models, with Mc, RBNI, and NGWI achieving the highest predictive performance (RMSE ≈ 10.2 days). Three indices were then combined in a multivariate LSTM model, which significantly improved prediction accuracy, achieving an RMSE of 8.18 days and demonstrating robust alignment with observed harvest dates. The findings underscore the value of combining SAR and optical data for modeling complex phenological events and highlight the potential of scalable deep learning frameworks in advancing precision agriculture. Future work will expand this methodology across Western Canada and incorporate real-time weather and soil data to further enhance prediction generalizability.

title: Potential Strategies to Promote Residential Distributed Photovoltaic Generation through Grid Parity Analysis: An Ecuadorian Study Case
authors: Jorge Muñoz, Juan Ramírez, Manuel Jaramillo, Luis Tipán
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: In recent years, climate change, natural disasters, and poor management of electrical systems in Latin America have caused an energy crisis. Ecuador currently faces an electricity deficit of 1,000 MW, which could be reduced by installing residential photovoltaic (PV) systems ranging from 1 kWp to 4 kWp. However, limited government incentives mean that homeowners show little interest in PV systems, delaying their future deployment. This work comprehensively analyzes the residential PV deployments according to grid parity and payback periods. To this end, we analyze the case study of Ecuador, evaluating the profitability of distributed PV systems according to user consumption and the electric tariff. Several PV system simulations were performed using empirical data collected in Quito, Ecuador. In addition, we propose a financial model based on Levelized Cost of Energy (LCOE). Scenario analysis indicates that grid parity is achievable when incentives are offered or discount rates are increased, making distributed residential PV more attractive. Empirical results show that the most favorable scenario reduces the time to achieve network parity by up to nine years.

title: Accelerating Diffusion Models with Progressive Distillation for Remote Sensing Semantic Segmentation
authors: Ruben Pascual, Christian Ayala, Ruben Sesma, Aranzazu Jurio, Daniel Paternain, Mikel Galar
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models (DDPMs) have shown significant potential in a variety of generative modeling applications. While they hold promise for semantic segmentation, their use in remote sensing remains limited due to the computational intensity of the inference process. Early attempts using DDPMs in remote sensing have achieved results comparable to state-of-the-art models, but their reliance on a multi-step generation process creates a notable performance bottleneck. To address this issue, this paper explores the application of Progressive Distillation, an acceleration method tailored for DDPMs. This approach is evaluated on a well-known remote sensing dataset focused on building segmentation. The optimized diffusion-based model is compared to state-of-the-art convolutional models in terms of accuracy and inference speed, showing a shrinking performance gap and highlighting the growing practicality of diffusion-based methods for real-world segmentation tasks.

title: Quantum-Inspired Virtual Prism for Multispectral Unmixing
authors: Chia-Hsiang Lin, Si-Sheng Young
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In remote sensing areas, multispectral unmixing (MU) becomes critical as typical multispectral images (MSIs) inevitably suffer from the mixed pixel phenomenon due to the limited spatial resolution. However, MU mathematically corresponds to a challenging underdetermined problem (i.e., less spectral bands than sources), hampering the researchers from tackling it. Current MU methodologies often overlook the underdetermined problem and are simply extended from the hyperspectral unmixing (HU) without theoretical breakthroughs. In this study, we propose a deep light-splitting system (DLS) to address the underdetermined nature of MU wherein the network within the DLS incorporates a specific advanced quantum deep network (QUEEN) serving as the quantum prism. Remarkably, the proposed DLS is virtual, which means the obtained hyperspectral images (HSIs) hold fundamental properties (e.g., non-negativity and geometry structure) but do not need to correspond to any physical sensor, allowing us to easily determine the spectral response as a deterministic matrix. In light of these, we can effectively unmix the spectra through the convex geometry, followed by downsampling the hyperspectral sources back to the multispectral ones. The proposed quantum prism-inspired MU (Q-MU) algorithm successfully recovers 6 spectra sources from 4-band MSIs.

title: Swot Reveals Internal Solitary Wave Modulated Sea Surface Height: Product Comparison and Processing
authors: Hao Zhang, Junmin Meng, Lina Sun
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Internal solitary waves (ISWs), as typical sub-mesoscale processes, have not been extensively investigated in terms of their impact on the sea surface height. The Surface Water and Ocean Topography (SWOT) provided valuable data for examining the ISWs-modulated sea surface height features. SWOT provides a range of height product variants at different levels. This study compares their suitability for ISWs research and proposes a product processing algorithm. Based on the corrected data, statistical results from multiple oceanic regions are presented. Furthermore, compared to Sentinel-3, SWOT demonstrates superior detection performance, effectively identifying ISWs with a 15 km wavelength.

title: Assessing the Potential of Lutan-1 Observation on Forest Height Estimation
authors: Yujie Chen, Zhanmang Liao, Xiqing Deng, Yiru Zhang, Rui Chen
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Forest height is one of the most important forest parameters for quantifying forest carbon stocks. Spaceborne synthetic aperture radar (SAR) has the characteristics of strong penetration and wide coverage, and has great potential in estimating forest height. Recently, China launched a new L-band differential interferometric SAR mission, named Lutan-1. To evaluate the potential of Lutan-1 on estimating forest height, we selected two commonly used SAR information, i.e. backscatter coefficient and interferometric coherence, from Lutan-1 for analysis, and compared it with other satellites. We found that the R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> between the backscatter coefficient in HH polarization of Lutan-1 and forest height reached 0.44, which is better than the performance of Sentinel-1 (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>=0.43 for VH) and ALOS-2 PALSAR-2 (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>=0.18 for HH). The R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> between the interferometric coherence magnitude and forest height can reach 0.47 under a suitable spatial baseline for Lutan-1, while the R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> only reaches 0.38 for Sentinel-1 coherence. In addition, when the temporal baseline is fixed, coherence from interference pairs with a larger spatial baseline has a stronger correlation with forest height.

title: Detection of Clouds, Water, and Shadows in PRISMA Images
authors: Salvatore Maresca, Stefania Matteoli
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This work presents a unified approach to detect cloud, water and shadows in PRISMA hyperspectral images featuring a non-parametric and fully automated methodology. Experimental evidence is provided as regards the capability of the proposed approach to enhance available PRISMA hyper-spectral products in a variety of scenarios. The presented work contributes to increase PRISMA data exploitation possibilities and outlines future outlooks for further product enhancement.

title: Dynamically Adjusting DC-Link Voltage of a Back-to-Back Converter in a Hybrid Transformer
authors: Bortecene Yildirim, Mohamed Dahidah, Amirhossein Malekipour, Michael M.C. Merlin
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: In hybrid distribution transformer (HDT), the series power electronic module (PEM) compensates voltage disturbances to protect sensitive loads connected to the distribution grid. The magnitude of the injected voltage depends on the severity of the voltage disturbance in the grid. The DC-link voltage is set based on the maximum voltage injection scenario and is kept constant across all voltage disturbance conditions. Since the switching losses of a PEM are directly dependent on the DC-link voltage, it can therefore be reduced by maintaining DC-link voltage at lower levels during instances of low voltage disturbance. Therefore, by dynamically adjusting the DC-link voltage based on the required injected voltage magnitude, switching losses can be minimized and overall conversion efficiency can be improved. This paper proposes a variable DC-link voltage control strategy for a back-to-back (B2B) PEM in HDT to enhance conversion efficiency. The proposed control method is verified using MATLAB/Simulink on an 11/0.4 kV distribution network with a 5% voltage sag. The efficiency of a two-level voltage source inverter (VSI) is assessed as an example, and results demonstrate that a lower DC-link voltage yields higher efficiency across the full load range.

title: Optimized ConvLSTM for Spatiotemporal Analysis of Event-Based Data in Space Surveillance Systems
authors: Sara Salim, Ismail M. Ali, Bassel Al Homssi, Melrose Brown
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Event-based sensors represent a novel paradigm for capturing asynchronous and high-temporal-resolution data, addressing the growing demand for efficient and precise monitoring in dynamic and resource-constrained domains. In space surveillance, where rapid object detection, accurate trajectory prediction, and real-time decision-making are paramount, these sensors provide an unparalleled advantage. In this paper, we propose an optimized ConvLSTM architecture, a novel integration of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks, tailored specifically to analyze the sparse and asynchronous nature of event-based data streams. By combining the spatial feature extraction capabilities of CNNs with the temporal sequence modeling strengths of LSTMs, our model captures the spatiotemporal dependencies essential for high-performance space surveillance. The architecture is meticulously fine-tuned with innovations such as dynamic pooling, an optimized learning rate schedule, and a robust event-based data preprocessing pipeline, ensuring robust performance across critical tasks. Experimental evaluations highlight the model’s exceptional performance, achieving a classification accuracy of 99.7%, along with Mean Squared Error (MSE) values of 0.0034 for velocity estimation and 0.0027 for trajectory prediction, surpassing traditional methods. These results underscore the potential of ConvLSTM in advancing space surveillance systems, offering robust capabilities for dynamic space environments.

title: Confirming Coordinates of Archival Radar Data of The Greenland Ice Sheet
authors: Reese Dobson, Dustin Schroeder, Nanna B. Karlsson, Brian Amaro
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Understanding subsurface ice-sheet processes is important for models of glacial melt and projections of sea-level. The Technical University of Denmark (DTU) and Stanford University recently released an archival dataset of radargrams that make observations of englacial and subglacial features from within the Greenland Ice Sheet during the 1970s possible. This dataset has the potential to extend our understanding of the subsurface evolution of that ice sheet by nearly two decades compared to the next oldest radargram data. However, large uncertainties remain in the location of these data ranging between 5.5 to 7 kilometers. In this work, we aim to reduce this uncertainty by comparing the original coordinates and bed-depth estimates from the data acquisitions with the bed rock topography from BedMachineV5.

title: Extraction of Earthquake-induced Landslides From Post-event Optical Satellite Images
authors: Wen Liu, Kyoya Hara, Fumio Yamazaki, Yoshihisa Maruyama
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Landslide detection is a critical task in natural disaster management. The application of deep learning methods for landslide extractions based on remote sensing images demonstrates high accuracy while significantly reducing the need for manual labor. This study conducted comparative experiments using a mask R-CNN model to extract landslides induced by the 2018 Hokkaido-Eastern-Iburi earthquake in Japan. Among different band combinations of a post-event SPOT-7 satellite image and a digital elevation model, the model utilizing the Red, Green, Blue, and Near-Infrared (RGB+NIR) bands achieved the highest accuracy, with an F1-score of 78.2% for segmentation-based evaluation and 81.8% for bounding box-based evaluation.

title: Airborne Multi-Band PolSAR Data Registration Based on RHE-DCT and Edge Enhancement of Polarimetric Features of Agricultural Areas
authors: Wenyu Yu, Hong Yang, Wen Jiang, Qiang Yin
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Polarimetric Synthetic Aperture Radar (PolSAR) can obtain abundant information about ground objects due to its preservation of scattering mechanism. Furthermore, multi-band PolSAR data with its distinct penetrability is widely used in the field of agricultural monitoring. Among them, compared with spaceborne PolSAR, airborne PolSAR can obtain more timely ground information by virtue of its mobility. However, how to perform airborne multi-band PolSAR registration quickly and efficiently has been a difficult problem not yet resolved, due to the differences in resolution and scattering centers, especially in the coherent/covariance matrix level. The paper proposes a polarimetric SAR feature registration method based on Regularized Histogram Equalization–Discrete Cosine Transform (RHE-DCT) and edge enhancement, building upon the SAR-SIFT approach. The experiments employ airborne PolSAR data obtained by Aerial Remote Sensing System Shuangyashan in Heilongjiang Province and Wanning in Hainan Province. Compared with the traditional SAR-SIFT method, the proposed approach significantly reduces registration time in both standard registration scenarios and distorted image registration, while also achieving notable performance improvements.

title: Harmonization of Soil Spectra Across Field and Laboratory Setups: The Application of Internal Soil Standards for Cross-Device Calibration in the Frame of IEEE-SA P4005
authors: Konstantinos Karyotis, Sabine Chabrillat, Thomas Schmid, Maria Dolores Raya-Sereno, János Mészáros, Stefano Pignatti, Marcos Jimenez, Robert Milewski, Maria Pilar Martín, Paul Karlshöfer, Adrian Moncholi-Estornell, Nicolas Venjean, Siri Jodha Khalsa, Simone Pascucci, Rachel Walker, Daniel Kopkane, Juan Jose Peon, Monika Zovko, Kevin Küehl, Eyal Ben-Dor
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Soil spectroscopy has emerged as a transformative tool for rapid and non-destructive assessment of soil properties, by measuring reflectance across the VIS-NIR-SWIR spectrum (0.35-2.5 μm). Despite its potential, harmonizing soil spectral data remains a critical challenge due to inconsistencies arising from diverse instrumentation, protocols, and environmental conditions. To address this, the IEEE SA P4005 "Standards and Protocols for Soil Spectroscopy" initiative developed standardized protocols for laboratory and field soil spectral measurements, aimed at ensuring data reliability, reproducibility, and interoperability. This work presents a validation exercise of the P4005 protocol; measurements were performed using six spectrometers operated by independent groups on diverse targets, including soil, sand, stone, fabric, and wood. The exercise evaluated the harmonization efficacy of Internal Soil Standards with each spectrometer’s Contact Probe setups, and the SoilPro® apparatus for field conditions. Results demonstrated significant reductions in measurement variability through ISS corrections, with the CP setup achieving up to 49% improvement in standard deviation for soil reflectance, underscoring the potential of P4005 protocols and ISS-based harmonization to unify soil spectral datasets provided by different laboratories or user groups, and to reduce measurement uncertainty.

title: Enhancing Pulse Oximetry Accuracy with Personal Parameter Integration in Wearable Devices
authors: Arda Karli, Musa Guler, Hakan Burak Karli, Bige Deniz Unluturk
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: Pulse oximetry is a standard method for noninvasive clinical monitoring of peripheral oxygen saturation (SpO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>), a key vital sign, yet studies highlight its reduced accuracy in individuals with darker skin pigmentation, often resulting in occult hypoxemia. This discrepancy arises from calibration biases and the optical effects of elevated melanin levels, which interfere with light transmission and absorption. To address this disparity, we propose a lightweight, machine learning-based correction model that estimates arterial oxygen saturation from SpO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> readings by incorporating demographic and skin pigmentation metrics. Leveraging the OpenOximetry dataset and deploying compact neural networks, we trained and optimized a model suitable for real-time operation on resource-constrained edge hardware. The model was quantized using TensorFlow Lite to minimize memory and computation requirements. Deployment and testing on a Raspberry Pi 5 confirmed feasibility, with the quantized model achieving an RMSE of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2. 1 0 3 \%}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 9 4 7}$</tex> while requiring 43.5 KB of RAM and 122 ms inference time. Our approach demonstrates a viable path to bias-aware, accurate oxygen monitoring by enabling demographically informed SpO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> correction on edge devices.

title: Leveraging 3D Printing Technology for Advancing Circular Economy to Promote Sustainable Practices
authors: Thamaga Lucas Mohube Makua, Getnet Fanta, Leon Pretorius
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society Conference - Global (TEMSCON Global)
abstract: As linear production results in significant waste generation, adopting a circular economy (CE) approach helps reduce resource inputs, energy consumption, emissions, and material leakage by slowing, closing, and minimising material and energy loops. Additive manufacturing (AM), commonly called 3D printing, is one of the digital technologies capable of advancing a sustainable CE. This research explores the potential of 3D printing to advance CE practices, focusing on its benefits across CE activities and stages and identifying industries that can leverage this technology. A systematic literature review was conducted by searching the titles, abstracts, and author keywords in the Web of Science database and Scopus databases using search terms “3D printing”, “circular economy”, and “sustainability”. The review highlights that raw material input and recycling are critical CE activities where 3D printing has a considerable impact. Among the various CE stages, “reduce” and “recycle” experience the most significant benefits from adopting 3D printing. Additionally, the research identifies the polymer industry as a key sector that can benefit from this technology. These findings enhance the understanding of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 D$</tex> printing's role in supporting CE principles and provide valuable insights for industries aiming to adopt sustainable manufacturing practices.

title: Effect of SAR Resolution on Man-made Target Detection Performance
authors: Zihan Zhou, Huaping Xu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This paper proposes an analysis method for the effect of SAR resolution on target detection performance for artificial targets. After constructing the SAR image distinguished model containing uniform background and target with scattering centers, the relationship between detection performance and resolution is deduced based on sparse detection and hypothesis testing. Simulation results show that the optimal resolution for an artificial target is related to its scattering characteristics and SNR.

title: Design of a Self-Quadruplexing Substrate Integrated Waveguide Antenna for IoT Applications
authors: Haiyue Jiang, Filember Alemu Eshetu, Hongchang Li, Mohamad Abou Houran
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The expansion of IoT applications in smart grids, precision agriculture, intelligent homes, and transportation systems continues to fuel demand for wireless infrastructure. However, their implementation demands tailored solutions to address evolving user needs, component miniaturization, and system complexity. To address these challenges, this study proposes a four-port self-quadruplexing substrate integrated waveguide (SQ-SIW) antenna. The design was rigorously analyzed through comprehensive simulations and experimental validation, achieving reflection coefficients of −10.13 dB (Port 1), −12.1 dB (Port 2), −10.2 dB (Port 3), and −19.86 dB (Port 4). Notably, the orthogonal port configuration enables simultaneous resonance, enhancing both reconfigurability and operational flexibility. This work establishes a new paradigm for multifunctional IoT antennas, offering scalable solutions for spectrum-constrained wireless systems through its unique combination of spatial diversity and frequency-selective characteristics.

title: Digital Twin-Enabled Deep Learning for Carbon-Optimized Scheduling in Integrated Energy Systems
authors: Yinuo Yang, Minglei You, Marco Rivera, Yupeng Wu, Mark Sumner
