publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper proposes a Digital Twin (DT)-enabled Deep Neural Network (DNN) framework for low-carbon scheduling in Integrated Energy Systems (IES). Device-level constraints are embedded directly into the DNN for both memory-based and non-memory-based components. A data augmentation strategy using historical forecast errors improves robustness under uncertainty. Case studies with UK data show the method significantly reduces emissions compared to forecast-driven baselines, approaching the theoretical minimum under varying system conditions.

title: Voltage Space of Five-Phase Voltage-Source Inverters
authors: Jan Laksar, Tomáš Komrska
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Multiphase systems offer several advantages over their three-phase counterparts, such as torque enhancement, fault-tolerant operation, etc. In five-phase systems, the inverter output voltage can be increased using the third harmonic, which produces the voltage vector in the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$x-y$</tex> plane with additional torque and the zero-sequence, torque-non-producing component. The maximum voltage is obtained with a non-circular trajectory of the voltage vector in the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$x-y$</tex> plane, while the machine's optimal operation requires its circular trajectory. The paper focuses on analyzing the space for the voltage increase with respect to the constraints given by the dc-link voltage on the one hand and by the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$x-y$</tex> and non-zero voltage component on the other. Theoretical conclusions are verified by simulations and experimental measurements.

title: Dual Cross-Attention Network for Few-Shot SAR Jamming Recognition
authors: Endong Hui, Jinbiao Du, Weiwei Fan, Feng Zhou, Mingyi You
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The presence of environmental noise substantially restricts the performance of current few-shot Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) jamming recognition techniques. To address this issue, in this manuscript, we introduce a dual cross-attention network (DCN) with two-stage training. At the beginning, in the pre-training stage, we generate base prototypes, offering a distinct path for the ensuing optimization processes. Subsequently, in the meta-learning stage, we create a dual cross-attention module (DCM) to calculate dual cross-attention scores, so as to increase the model's ability to predict new categories under low jamming-to-noise ratio (JNR) conditions. Ultimately, we execute comprehensive experiments on a jamming dataset and make comparisons against existing methods. The experimental results demonstrate the superiority of the proposed method.

title: Spatio-Spectral Regularization Aided by Graph Modelings for Hyperspectral Image Denoising
authors: Shingo Takemoto, Shunsuke Ono
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: We propose a novel regularization function, Graph-Aided Spatio-Spectral Total Variation (GASSTV), for hyperspectral (HS) image denoising. Spatio-Spectral Total Variation (SSTV), defined using second-order spatio-spectral differences, is a widely used regularization approach that effectively captures the spatio-spectral piecewise smoothness specific to HS images, enabling robust noise removal. However, SSTV uniformly computes adjacent differences in spatial and spectral dimensions, leading to the corruption of complex spatial structures and abrupt spectral variations in HS images. To address these limitations, we incorporate spatial and spectral graphs that explicitly reflect the spatial and spectral structures into the regularization model. Furthermore, we design a framework to construct these graphs from the noisy HS image. In addition, we formulate the mixed noise removal problem as a convex optimization problem involving GASSTV and develop an efficient algorithm based on the preconditioned primal-dual splitting method to solve it. Experimental results on mixed noise removal demonstrate the superior performance of GASSTV compared with existing HS image regularization models.

title: SAR Inter-Pulse Chaotic Coding with Dechirp for Jamming Suppression
authors: Jianyuan Li, Pengbo Wang, Pei Wang, Tao He, Zhirong Men
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR), known for its high-resolution imaging, faces challenges in confronting electromagnetic jamming, notably deception jamming. This jamming negatively impacts the SAR system by generating false echoes, which distort target shapes, create false targets, and lead to misidentification and positioning errors. In this study, we propose a scheme for suppressing deceptive jamming signals, referred to as an interpulse chaotic frequency agility scheme based on dechirp imaging processing with LFM (ICFAD-LFM). A series of simulation experiments and data analyses further substantiate this claim. The results demonstrate that our scheme effectively defocuses deceptive jamming signals, instead of using complex orthogonal signals, which make the system more efficient and functional.

title: Investigating the Link between Forest Structural Metrics and Vegetation Optical Depth (VOD) Using GNSS-T Simulations on LiDAR-derived Forests
authors: M. Ehsanul Hoque, Mehmet Kurum, Abesh Ghosh, Dylan R. Boyd, Ines Fenni
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This study investigates the relationship between forest structural metrics and Vegetation Optical Depth (VOD) through a novel simulation framework. This framework, which serves as a digital twin of forests, integrates LiDAR-derived tree structures into a first-order scattering model, enabling the simulation of GNSS-T scenarios with variable forest characteristics. Geophysical metrics, such as woody volume, aboveground biomass (AGB), and diameter at breast height (DBH), are calculated from cylinder-based tree reconstructions generated from LiDAR point clouds. The results interpret the correlation of forest metrics with VOD, advancing our understanding of the impact of forest structure in transmissivity calculations. By bridging the gap between scattering simulations and in-situ measurements, this framework provides a controlled environment to analyze GNSS-T observables and their connection to forest properties, enhancing the accuracy and applicability of remote sensing methodologies.

title: Temporal Dynamics of Landcover Classification Over the Indian Sundarbans Using Sentinel-1
authors: Sukanya Mukherjee, Vaishnavi Joshi, Dileep Singh, Subhadip Dey
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Analysing land use and cover changes is crucial to comprehending how humans and the environment interact. The rapid changes at the regional level around a wetland significantly impact habitats and the overall ecosystem. Hence, in this study, we have employed the well-known Kennaugh matrix elements derived from the dual polarimetric Sentinel-1 data to classify the land cover across the Indian Sundarbans Region. However, a significant concern regarding the classification of these landcover classes is the dynamics of the classification output over a long temporal window. Hence, we analyse the spatio-temporal variations of the classification from 2018 to 2023 for pre-monsoon (April) and post-monsoon (October) months over 13 land cover classes. The classification outcomes were supported using the precision, recall, overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient. Seasonal and annual variations of landcover classes are prominent in the overall time series data. Significant changes were noted in the Agricultural Land, Fallow Land, and Aquaculture classes.

title: A Weighted Ratio-based ROEWA Operator for Optical and SAR Image Registration
authors: Zhixin Lian, Shiyang Tang, Jiahao Han, Zixuan He, Linrang Zhang, Qingyuan Yu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The exponentially weighted averages (ROEWA) operator can resist the multiplicative speckle noise interference, which is widely used in optical and synthetic aperture radar (SAR) image registration to obtain consistent gradients. However, abrupt dark patches in the SAR image cause the horizontal and vertical gradients obtained based on the ROEWA operator to increase dramatically. Thus, the gradient magnitudes at the edges of the dark patches are significantly different from those of the other pixel points. The degree of consistency between the gradients of these two types of images is reduced by this phenomenon, which ultimately affects the accuracy of image registration. Therefore, a ROEWA operator based on weighted ratios (WR-ROEWA) is proposed in this paper. The magnitude extremes are avoided in localized areas by limiting the range of gradient values in the horizontal and vertical directions. The effectiveness of the proposed algorithm for improving gradient consistency is verified by image registration experiments based on real data.

title: Design and Optimization Analysis of Oil-Gas Heat-Exchange Cooling System for Aero-Electric Propulsion Axial Flux PM Motor
authors: Lijiang Zhou, Hao Chen, Yunshuo Gu, Chaohui Tang, Yu Wang, Weiwei Geng
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The flat structural design of axial flux PM motors (AFPMM) allows for higher torque densities, which are gradually paid attention in aerospace applications. Most aeroelectric propulsion motors take advantage of the working environment to adopt forced air-cooled heat dissipation. The air-cooled heat dissipation efficiency of AFPMM with double rotor-single stator structure is low due to the small heat dissipation contact surface between the stator and the housing. Direct liquid cooling systems are more efficient at dissipating heat, but they require the introduction of a liquid circulation system, which occupies and consumes additional space and energy. Based on this, this paper designs a heat sink that can be integrated into the end of the motor, the aim is to simplify the liquid circulation system of the motor while retaining its liquid cooling efficiency. This radiator uses external wind energy to cool hot liquids, saving space and improving energy efficiency. In the article, the influence of different factors on the heat dissipation efficiency of the heat sink is investigated through theoretical analysis, and a three-dimensional CFD (Computational Fluid Dynamics) fluid-solid coupling model is constructed for multi-physics field simulation verification. The results show that the radiator system can simultaneously meet the requirements of heat dissipation and light weight.

title: Simple Decentralized Control Architecture for Modular Converter Applications
authors: Ahmed Topkil, Mohamed Taha, Alan Walker, Abdul Haleem Malik, Jose Ortiz Gonzalez
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper presents a fully decentralized control architecture for cascaded H-bridge (CHB) converters, improving modularity, scalability, and fault tolerance while reducing communication complexity. Unlike centralized approaches, the proposed method assigns independent local controllers (LC) to each sub-module (SM), enabling localized decision-making and minimizing reliance on a central controller (CC). The system is implemented on a scaled-down prototype using STM32 microcontrollers, with UART and SPI communication ensuring accurate synchronization. Experimental validation demonstrates stable operation, precise PWM synchronization, and effective fault handling. The results confirm that a fully decentralized control strategy enhances fault tolerance and efficiency, making it a promising solution for applications such as electric vehicle (EV) fast charging and renewable energy integration.

title: A Fast Algorithm for F-SCAN SAR Data Generation
authors: Wenxin Ou, Bo Li, Yalun Shu, Xiang Xu, Pingping Lu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Frequency scanning (F-SCAN) synthetic aperture radar (SAR) is an advanced imaging mode that offers enhanced system performance. However, the conventional fast algorithm for generating SAR data is no longer applicable for F-SCAN SAR, as the center frequency of the F-SCAN SAR signal varies with the range time. To tackle this problem, we proposed a dedicated fast algorithm for generating F-SCAN SAR data, where a detailed derivation and the method of computational complexity are given. Furthermore, we conduct simulation experiments to verify the algorithm performance in terms of accuracy and efficiency. The results indicate that the proposed algorithm significantly reduces computational costs while maintaining data accuracy.

title: The Impact of Data Augmentations on Coastal Image Segmentation Models
authors: Conor O’Sullivan, Soumyabrata Dev
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Coastal segmentation models often require extensive annotated datasets. Many researchers have turned to data augmentations to reduce their data requirements. However, they apply a collection of augmentation operations, and it is not clear which have contributed the most to model performance. To mitigate this, we systematically evaluate geometric, noise, and brightness/contrast operations using a multispectral coastal segmentation dataset. Through statistical tests, we identify geometric augmentations as the most effective. They produced a model that surpasses the baseline trained on 30,000 rough annotations using only 100 manually labelled examples. Furthermore, we found fine-tuning the baseline with augmentations significantly enhances its performance. These results show that we can limit the number of augmentation operations, improving model efficiency and interpretability, without sacrificing performance.

title: Geometric-Harmonic Mean Based Late Fusion Ensemble For Improved Weather Image Classification
authors: Abhiroop Chatterjee, Dibyendu Chattoraj, Susmita Ghosh, Ashish Ghosh
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The present article introduces the Geometric Harmonic Ensemble (GHE) strategy for weather image classification. For varying perspective feature extraction, properties of transfer learned VGG16, Inception V3, and ResNet50 models have been exploited. GHE combines the geometric and harmonic means to balance the models’ consensus and divergence and is seen to achieve a superior classification accuracy of 92.82%, outperforming baseline ensembles on WEAPD dataset. Statistical analysis reveals significant differences favoring GHE across Precision, Recall, F1-Score, and Accuracy, with t-tests confirming the findings at a 0.05 significance level. GHE is also able to consistently outperform other competing methods, including state-of-the-art techniques.

title: NLOS Tracking with Distributed Radar Using Multipath-Assisted JPDA
authors: Xu Hao, Shisheng Guo, Yu Yao, Peilun Wu, Yufei Wei, Zihan Xu, Guolong Cui
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This paper presents a novel non-line-of-sight (NLOS) target tracking algorithm using distributed multiple input multiple output (MIMO) radar systems. The proposed algorithm leverages back-projection (BP) imaging to process radar echoes, integrating amplitude discrimination from multipath signals within the joint probabilistic data association (JPDA) framework to track targets within the image domain. Key to this algorithm is the filtering and identification of first and second-order reflection paths through trajectory similarity analysis and the use of distance metrics. The true target trajectory is then accurately determined through symmetric transformation and fusion of these tracks. Simulations in an L-shaped scenario demonstrate the enhanced ability of the algorithm to differentiate and accurately track targets, indicating superior robustness and reliability.

title: Comprehensive Derivation of Small-Signal Model for Virtual-Admittance Based Grid-Forming Modular Multilevel Converters
authors: Kavian Kamalinejad, Sohrab Mohtat, Amir Reza Zamani
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper aims to develop an accurate small-signal model of a Grid-Forming Modular Multilevel Converter (GFM-MMC) using a virtual-admittance-based control strategy to establish a general foundation for stability analysis and control design. Yet, the presence of fundamental and second-order harmonics, along with the DC component in the GFM-MMC, complicates the small-signal model derivation. This paper presents a comprehensive framework for modeling and deriving the small-signal model of a GFM-MMC, incorporating fundamental, secondorder, and DC components. To achieve this, a time-invariant representation of the converter dynamics is developed using dqframes synchronized with both the fundamental and second-order harmonic components. The analytically derived input admittance model is then validated through simulation results.

title: Optimization of Distance and Overcurrent Relays Based on Genetic Algorithm on 150kV SUTT
authors: Sujito, Bayu Prihambodo, Langlang Gumilar, Aripriharta, Abdullah Iskandar Syah, Aya Shofia Mufti
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: Relay coordination is the proper sequence of operation of all relays in the event of a fault. The coordination time between the primary relay and the backup relay is referred to as the time coordination interval (CTI). CTI can be interpreted as the difference in operating time of the primary and secondary relays. Genetic Algorithm (GA) is a heuristic method developed based on the principles of genetics and the natural selection process of Darwin’s Theory of Evolution. This algorithm is used to obtain the optimal coordination time value. Relay coordination is carried out based on the limitations derived from the CTI and CTI’ values for critical fault locations. Based on the explanation above, a study was conducted to determine the performance of distance relay coordination and overcurrent relay (OCR) in the Sekarputih Substance to the Mojoagung Substance. This study presents a combination of distance relay coordination with OCR to have the shortest possible fault isolation time. Furthermore, the analysis is based on the IEEE C37.113-2015 standard, IEEE Guide for Protective Relay Applications on Transmission Lines, and the characteristics of the OCR relay are Normally Inverse (NI). Genetic algorithms are used to obtain the optimal values of the multiplier time setting (TMS), plug setting (PS), and second zone operating time (TZ2). The use of MATLAB software is intended to run genetic algorithms and for disturbance simulation and protection coordination using ETAP 19.0.1 software.

title: Generalized Framework For Chlorophyll-A Estimation In Complex Waters Using Simulated Prisma Hyperspectral Data
authors: Raúl Alejandro Carvajal Téllez, Ashish Kallikkattil Kuruvila, Giovanni Laneve, Alvise Ferrari, Simone Saquella, Emilio D’ugo, Fabio Magurano, Alessandro Ursi, Deodato Tapete, Patrizia Sacco
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In recent years, the number of publications related to monitoring and developing algorithms for studying water quality has significantly increased. Missions such as Sentinel-2, Landsat, MERIS, and MODIS have established methodological foundations for estimating chlorophyll-a (Chl-a) using multispectral sensors. However, multispectral sensors are designed to capture generalized spectral information across a limited number of broad wavelength bands, which can be insufficient for distinguishing the subtle and complex spectral variations found in waters with diverse optical properties, commonly known as complex waters. The ability to characterize these subtle spectral variations is crucial to addressing one of the greatest challenges in this field: developing models capable of generalizing predictions in complex waters, such as type I and type II. This study presents a methodological framework for calibrating models capable of addressing such complexity. The methodology uses hyperspectral data obtained via spectroradiometers, which are simulated to replicate the spectral response of the PRISMA sensor. Subsequently, the optical water types (OWTs) are classified, and through spectral sensitivity analysis, specific indices are identified for Chl-a prediction. These indices are used to calibrate regression models based on machine learning. Among the evaluated models, Random Forest showed the best performance, with an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.69, followed by XGBoost (0.62) and Support Vector Machine (0.53). Although RMSE values were close to 30 mg/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>, the need to improve the model is recognized by regrouping OWTs and incorporating new indices.

title: Community-Led Real-Time Snowfall, SWE & Streamflow Monitoring in Climate Impacted Kabul River Basin
authors: Zahoor Ahmad, Abubakr Muhammad
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Snow melt from glacier-rich mountain ranges in the Upper Indus River Basin is the largest contributor to freshwater supplies for Pakistan’s growing and agriculture-dependent population. However, the changing climate has severely affected both glacier stability and seasonal snowfall patterns, leading to flash floods and uncertain water supplies for irrigation and domestic use. This paper reports a community-led indigenous development, deployment, and maintenance of an Internet-of-Things (IoT) enabled hydrometeorological monitoring network spanning seven snowfall seasons (2018-2025) in a small catchment located in the Kabul River sub-basin of the Indus. Validated by companion studies using InDSAR interferometry, the snow level measurements provide insights into the extent, timing, and melt rates of seasonal snowfall patterns. The data from remote and inaccessible areas can be used by the agricultural department to forecast water availability in the summer and issue advisories to farmers for crop selection. Yearly variations, such as early or late winter snowfall, are clearly evident from the sensor data collected, and they can impact flash floods and agricultural water availability in the summer. Stream flow measurements at the drainage point of the catchment provide a glimpse into the contributions of the Kabul River to the Indus and also capture rainfall events outside the winter season with great importance to the community’s flood awareness during the annual Monsoons. Finally, we capture the logistical challenges in maintaining the network, the opportunities in scaling up this network to other catchments of the region and the most recent efforts to incorporate direct measurements of Snow Water Equivalent (SWE) using indigenously designed snow pillows.

title: SAR Vehicle Recognition Based on Wavelet-Kolmogorov-Arnold-Convolution
authors: Yiyang Huang, Di Wang, Daoxiang An
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: SAR can acquire high-resolution microwave images all-weather and all-day, and SAR Automatic Target Recognition (SAR ATR) is one of its key foundational tasks. This paper introduces a new neural network architecture, Kolmogorov-Arnold Network (KAN), for SAR target recognition tasks, whose activation function has learnable weights and can approximate any function. The Wavelet-Kolmogorov-Arnold-Convolution (WKAC) layer extends KAN to a two-dimensional convolutional form, using the Derivative of Gaussian (DoG) wavelets as the basis for the activation function, enhancing the model’s feature extraction capabilities. The model combines the training efficiency of convolutional neural networks with the fine representation ability of KAN and has been tested on the MSTAR dataset under small sample conditions, demonstrating good recognition accuracy and generalization.

title: GDNET: A Graph Convolution And Hybrid Dilated Convolution Network For Road Extraction From High-Resolution Satellite Images
authors: Xiangan Zheng, Mengxiong Tang, Jia Chen, Zhaozhao Zeng, Jun Li
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Road extraction from high-resolution remote sensing images has become a critical task in various applications. Accurate road extraction is essential for generating up-to-date maps,supporting autonomous vehicles, and enabling efficient disaster response. However, challenges such as road occlusions, shadows, and surface similarities make precise extraction of road segments a difficult task. These issues are particularly pronounced in urban areas with dense infrastructure or in rural regions with sparse road networks. To address these challenges,this paper proposes a method called GDNet, which integrates graph convolution network(GCN) and hybrid dilated convolution(HDC). The HDC module enhances the receptive field, improving the completeness of road predictions. This allows the model to capture both large-scale road structures and smaller, intricate details critical for accurate extraction. The GCN module establishes long-range dependencies, enhancing the connectivity of road predictions in complex environments. By modeling pixel relationships as a graph,GCN connects fragmented road segments, improving overall prediction accuracy. Additionally,the dual attention mechanism(DAM) module is applied at the skip connections to strengthen the linear features of the predicted roads.Experimental results demonstrate that GDNet outperforms existing methods, particularly in predicting roads obscured by occlusions or shadows. Moreover, GDNet’s robustness is evident in its ability to handle a wide range of environmental conditions, making it effective across diverse real-world scenarios.

title: Efficient Teacher Behavior Analysis via Adaptive Frame Sampling
authors: Peiyuan Zeng, Yuhuang Zheng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computational Intelligence and Robotics (CIR)
abstract: Analyzing teacher behavior from lengthy classroom recordings presents significant computational challenges. Traditional video analysis methods often rely on fixed-rate frame sampling, such as processing every k-th frame. This approach can lead to redundant processing during periods of low activity, like lectures, and may result in the loss of crucial information during periods of rapid behavioral changes, such as transitions between teaching modalities. This inefficiency hinders the practical application of automated behavior analysis systems in educational settings. This paper introduces an Adaptive Frame Sampling (AFS) technique specifically designed for efficient and accurate teacher behavior analysis. Our approach dynamically adjusts the video frame sampling rate based on scene complexity and the rate of behavioral change. Key innovations include: (1) Dynamic Sampling Rate Control, which intelligently increases sampling intervals during stable behavior periods and decreases them during transitions or complex interactions, significantly reducing computational load. (2) Behavior Boundary Precision Enhancement, employing change trend detection and targeted backtrack sampling to accurately pinpoint the timing of behavioral shifts. (3) Resource Efficiency Optimization, demonstrably reducing processing time by 40-60% compared to fixed-rate sampling while maintaining or even improving the accuracy of behavior detection and boundary localization. We implement and evaluate this technique using a configurable analysis pipeline, orchestrated by scripts like 'run_adaptive.sh’, allowing flexible parameter tuning (e.g., initial, minimum, maximum skip rates). Experiments on relevant educational video datasets show substantial improvements in processing efficiency and the ability to capture fine-grained behavioral dynamics, making large-scale automated analysis of teaching practices more feasible.

title: Sea Clutter Suppression in GEO SAR Imaging of Maneuvering Ships based on L-statistics
authors: Jindong Yu, Ze Yu, Mugen Peng
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The integration time of geosynchronous synthetic aperture radar (GEO SAR) is much longer than that of low Earth orbit SAR (LEO SAR), and the non-cooperative motion of ships leads to imaging defocusing. Sea clutter not only affects the estimation of motion parameters, but also reduces the signal-to-clutter ratio (SCR) of the image, which seriously affects the image quality. In this paper, a sea clutter suppression method based on L-statistics method is proposed. Utilizing the sparse characteristics of ship signals in time-frequency domain, the sea clutter is suppressed nonparametric by retaining a certain proportion of time blocks in each frequency unit in time-frequency domain. Simulation and measured data verify the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Modeling Hierarchical Semantic among Object Queries in DETR-based Detectors for Remote Sensing Images
authors: Dexin Chen, Jingzhou Chen, Fengchao Xiong, Liang Xiao
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Many researchers have investigated DETR-based detectors for remote sensing images due to their promising performance. However, most of these studies focus solely on fine-grained categories, although existing remote sensing datasets typically organize these categories into a hierarchical label structure by adding ancestors to them at coarser-grained levels. Therefore, each object is equipped with hierarchical labels from the root node to the leaf node. In this paper, we propose a novel method to improve DETR-based detectors by modeling the semantic relationships among hierarchical labels into the learning of object queries and hierarchical classification. Specifically, since the object queries in DETR-based detectors represent candidate proposals in the image, hierarchical contrastive learning is introduced to perform clustering on them at each hierarchical level during training, based on the hierarchical labels assigned to them after the bipartite matching. Moreover, in contrast to fine-grained classification in conventional detectors, we encode hierarchical labels into the classification outputs to indicate multi-granularity category assignments to each object. Experiments are conducted on a hierarchically structured dataset, ShipRSImageNet, and our proposed method surpasses the state-of-the-art methods by 1.13 mAP, which demonstrates the effectiveness of our work.

title: Towards Storage-Aware Onboard Change Detection
authors: Gabriele Inzerillo, Diego Valsesia, Enrico Magli, Aniello Fiengo
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Change Detection is typically performed at the ground segment of satellite systems, where images can be carefully post-processed and registered, and complexity is not an issue. We investigate a framework entirely based on neural networks to perform change detection directly onboard of satellites in order to minimize the latency of the detection pipeline. The proposed framework accounts for image compression, registration and detection of change in order to manage the limited storage of the satellite and the lack of image alignment between revisits, while minimizing the computational complexity of the design. Preliminary results on a lightweight design show good change detection performance as a function of compression rate, while managing geometric misalignment.

title: Prior-Based Three-Stage Unsupervised Invertible Neural Network for Hyperspectral and Multispectral Image Fusion
authors: Mengnan Jin, Wenjuan Zhang, Yongchuan Cui, Jie Pan, Dailiang Peng, Zhen Li
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Hyperspectral images (HSI) inherently face a trade-off between spatial resolution and spectral resolution due to the limitations of imaging principles. To rapidly obtain remote sensing images with both high spatial and high spectral resolution, unsupervised deep learning methods for fusing HSI and multispectral images (MSI) have achieved remarkable progress in recent years. However, existing studies often overlook the issue of high-frequency information loss in the fused images. To address this limitation, we propose a Prior-based three-stage unsupervised Invertible neural Fuse Network (PIFNet). Specifically, the framework consists of three key modules: prior information extraction, spectral channel mapping, and detail feature fuse. In particular, the detail feature fuse module leverages an invertible neural network to prevent information loss through mutual generation of input and output features. Experimental results on simulated datasets demonstrate that the PIFNet outperforms existing unsupervised deep learning methods, highlighting its potential and effectiveness in HSI-MSI fusion tasks.

title: An Interpretable Machine Learning Model for Snowstorm Risk Identification and Assessment
authors: Zhenyu Yang, Hideomi Gokon
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Understanding the factors driving snowstorm risks and their nonlinear effects is crucial for improving disaster resilience and mitigation strategies. Despite its importance, few studies have integrated multi-source remote sensing data to explore snowstorm mechanisms. This study investigates the 2018 Fukui snowstorm in Japan using an interpretable machine learning model to identify high-risk areas and analyze key nonlinear relationships and threshold effects. The model integrates GPS data, Digital Elevation Model (DEM), nighttime light (DBN), NDVI (Normalized Difference Vegetation Index), road network and urban classification. Key findings include: (1) Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) outperforms Decision Tree, Random Forest, Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM), Support Vector Machine (SVM), and Artificial Neural Network (ANN) models, achieving an accuracy of 0.8833; (2) elevation, slope, nighttime light intensity, road density, and road width exhibit significant nonlinear and threshold effects; (3) flat terrains and higher rural road density are less affected by snowstorms; and (4) integrating GPS and nighttime light monitoring with optimized road network design can enhance resilience and mitigate traffic congestion during extreme weather.

title: A Multilevel DC/DC Converter for Battery Traction Applications
authors: Denis Kukushkin, Roberto Aceiton, Christian Weiner
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The demand for battery-driven railway vehicles is growing steadily, as they enable green transportation on non-electrified tracks. Railway operators are increasingly focused on achieving high autonomy and minimizing charging times, emphasizing the need for highly efficient battery traction systems. In addition, the overall mass and volume of these systems is also critical, specially as battery traction systems are often retrofitted into older vehicles. This paper introduces a three-level DC/DC converter designed for battery traction applications in railway vehicles. The proposed topology aims to enhance the efficiency, mass, and volume of the overall system, making the adoption of energy-efficient solutions in modern railway vehicles even more attractive. The paper's main focus lies on the practical implementation and commutation-loop inductance characterization of a small laboratory prototype. Further research is needed to explore and validate a control scheme with the battery emulator.

title: Comparison of Tesseract OCR, Easy OCR, and Transformer OCR on Handwritten Image
authors: Kartika Candra Kirana, Ira Kumalasari, Gulpi Qorik Oktagalu, Afwatul Maqbullah, Agung Faradiz Shobari, Bagus Hidayat
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: This study compares the performance of Tesseract, Easy-OCR, and Transformer OCR in recognizing crossed-out text in the Indonesian and English languages. The focus on crossed-out text aims to assess the ability of OCR methods to face the challenges of recognizing text with non-standard formats. This preliminary study provides an important finding for optimizing the OCR technology in crossed-out multilingual handwriting. Testing was conducted on the modified IAM Handwriting dataset and the UM-PTI-Handwriting dataset using the processing time, Character Error Rate (CER), and Word Error Rate (WER) metrics to compare Transformer (Tr-OCR, Donut), Tesseract, and Easy OCR. According to the WER and CER metrics, Transformerbased OCR (Tr-OCR) achieves the lowest error rate, achieving 0,63 WER and 0.63 CER on the modified IAM Handwriting dataset, while 1,92 WER and 3,05 CER on the UM-PTI-Handwriting dataset. In terms of the processing time, Tesseract OCR is the fastest, while Transformer-based OCR (Donut) is the slowest. It concluded that the Transformer OCR (Tr-OCR) excels in recognizing English handwritten. However, all compared OCRs have lower accuracy in Indonesian handwritten text compared to English handwritten text.

title: Automatic Data Redundancy in Safety-Critical Applications Using Trait-Based Code Transformation
authors: Mohammadreza Amel Solouki, Corrado De Sio, Maurizio Rebaudengo, Jacopo Sini
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Defect and Fault Tolerance in VLSI and Nanotechnology Systems (DFT)
abstract: The paper describes a systematic approach for the automatic introduction of data redundancy in a safety-critical application. The transformations aim to make the program capable of detecting potential soft errors caused by transient faults that may alter the program's data. The approach is based on an automated system that leverages the polymorphism features offered by the Rust programming language. Rust is focused on speed, safety, and concurrency, and it also provides powerful high-level abstractions at zero cost. The paper proposes a technique for hardening source code by creating redundant code through an automatic data redundancy system, achieved by defining a trait that enables data duplication and the detection of potential errors. The use of a trait allows the compiler to generate optimized code, without introducing abstraction-related overhead and with minimal programmer effort for boilerplate code generation. Preliminary experimental results are presented, showing the fault coverage achieved by the method, as well as some data related to the performance overhead and the increase in code size.

title: TDOA Positioning System Based on Station Layout Optimization and Gradient Search Algorithm
authors: Yaqin Zhao, Ruchen Lv, Longwen Wu, Zhenyuan Zhang, Kunyu Han, Zhilu Wu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In recent years, the issue of illegal unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) positioning has attracted widespread attention. This paper focuses on the positioning system based on the time difference of arrival (TDOA) in critical areas. In light of the potential positioning blind spots that may arise from regular station deployment strategies, the secretary bird optimization algorithm (SBOA) is introduced to optimize the station layout in key areas. The average value of the root mean square error (RMSE) of positioning is reduced by an order of magnitude compared to regular deployments. On this basis, this paper also studies the high-precision solution method for the TDOA positioning problem. By integrating the fast optimization speed of the gradient descent (GD) with the global-searching characteristic of the search method, a gradient-based search (GBS) method is proposed for optimizing the target position. Experimental results demonstrate that GBS achieves 255 m lower RMSE than GD under 99 ns TDOA errors, and the convergence speed is faster.

title: Spatio-Temporal Transformers For Long Term NDVI Prediction
authors: Ido Faran, Nathan S. Netanyahu, Elena Roitberg, Maxim Shoshany, Fadi Kizel
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Satellite Image Time Series (SITS) analysis is essential for understanding environmental dynamics and forecasting future trends. This study introduces a novel spatio-temporal transformer-based model for long-term Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) prediction, leveraging Landsat data to address the challenges of modeling complex spatial and temporal dependencies in remote sensing. The proposed framework integrates spatial, temporal, and location-specific embeddings with a transformer architecture, enabling accurate predictions across diverse temporal horizons and spatial scales. By combining a scalable embedding framework with self-supervised learning using both spatial and temporal masking, the model effectively learns robust representations without the need for extensive labeled datasets. A comprehensive evaluation on Mediterranean landscapes demonstrates the model’s ability to capture intricate spatio-temporal dependencies and predict NDVI trends effectively. This work bridges a critical gap in remote sensing by offering a unified approach for capturing intricate spatio-temporal and long-term dependencies, providing valuable insights into environmental change, and improving the analysis of dynamic ecosystems.

title: RD Domain Parameter Estimation Algorithm for ISAC System Based on ANM-ADMM
authors: Dan Zhang, Yun Zhang, Hao Wan, Yusi Yang, Zihao Song, Yixuan Lu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Integrated sensing and communications (ISAC) technology is an important research direction of the 6th generation (6G). Aiming at the problem that the accuracy of parameter estimation of multiple dynamic targets by existing subspace algorithms is limited by low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and few snapshots in the ISAC scenario, this paper proposes a gridless compressed sensing algorithm to estimate the range-doppler (RD) domain parameters of the targets. Different from traditional methods, this algorithm can solve both on-grid and off-grid problems while realizing high precision parameter estimation. In order to reduce the computational complexity of the algorithm, a fast algorithm of the atomic norm minimization-alternating direction method of multipliers (ANM-ADMM) is proposed. Finally, the excellent performance of the proposed algorithm in RD domain parameter estimation is fully verified by a large number of simulation experiments.

title: An Adaptive Sparse Transformer with Convolution Mixer for Hyperspectral Image Classification
authors: Zihan Chen, Miaomiao Liang, Weiwei Wu, Siyu Yang, Zhe Meng, Lingjuan Yu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Hyperspectral images (HSI) exhibit complex contextual relationships and spectral variations, which pose significant challenges in capturing local high-frequency and global low-frequency information during feature learning. Integrating the strengths of convolution to balance high and low frequencies with Vision Transformers (ViT) yields impressive results. However, an excessive focus on irrelevant key-value tokens in queries can lead to inaccurate global contextual perception. Thus, we propose an Adaptive Sparse Transformer with Convolution mixer (ASpaCT) for HSI classification. It incorporates Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence into the query-key attention map, guiding the query to concentrate on only a few key tokens. Additionally, we introduce the neighbor-hood information entropy for contextual sparsity estimation, which adaptively determines the sparsity hyperparameter in the KL regularizer. In homogeneous areas, a low-sparsity constraint promotes the query’s connection to more contextual key tokens, whereas in non-homogeneous regions, the contrary holds. Our experiments demonstrate that ASpaCT significantly enhances HSI classification, outperforming both benchmark models and several state-of-the-art approaches.

title: Autofocus Back Projection Method Based on Time-Frequency Information of a Single Point for Airborne SAR with Nonlinear Trajectory
authors: Ruijuan Deng, Ze Yu, Jindong Yu, Kongwen Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Due to the limited accuracy of the navigation system, the deviation between measured trajectory and real trajectory of the radar platform deteriorates the focusing quality of the synthetic aperture radar (SAR) image. Therefore, a time domain autofocus algorithm that can effectively integrate with precise motion trajectory becomes the key to compensate for motion error.In this paper, an autofocus back projection (BP) algorithm based on time-frequency information of a single point is proposed to compensate for motion error. Considering the different influences of each dimension on slant range, this approach simplifies the three-dimensional (3D) motion trajectory errors of SAR into one dimension. By approximating the trajectory in this manner, the method integrated with the BP algorithm improves the quality of image focusing. Simulation and experimental results verify the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Adaptive Observing Synthetic Aperture Radar
authors: Fairouz Stambouli, Marwan Younis, Tobias Rommel, Markus Limbach
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Our world is facing critical challenges in monitoring vast and remote areas, where natural disasters, illegal activities, and environmental hazards are becoming more frequent and severe. Earth Observation using Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) provides consistent high-resolution imaging. However, current sensors face challenges in monitoring extensive regions in real time. This paper introduces a novel concept called ADaptive OBserving SAR (ADOB-SAR), which integrates intelligence on the sensor itself to perform selective data acquisition. It utilizes concurrent and reconfigurable imaging modes to adapt the acquisition to the scene properties and application requirements on the fly. The idea is that the sensor analyzes the scene ahead, extracting coarse information sufficient to identify key areas or objects of interest. Then, it autonomously generates the parameters of new acquisitions adapted to the extracted scene properties and optimized to maximize the acquired information while managing resources. The system performance, such as spatial resolution and energy, is controlled based on a dynamic optimization model that changes with the scenario. This concept significantly reduces stored and transferred data volume, as only the relevant information is kept.

title: In-Land Water Bodies Observation Through Airborne L-band Quad-Polarimetric SAR Imaging
authors: Andrea Buono, Paolo Berardino, Carmen Esposito, Giovanna Inserra, Riccardo Lanari, Maurizio Migliaccio, Antonio Natale, Stefano Perna
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The understanding of the spatial-temporal distribution of small in-land water bodies is a key point when dealing with the management of potable and irrigation water resources, the preservation of local ecosystems and biodiversity as well as to develop effective strategies in respond to flooding event. In this context, airborne and satellite remote sensing tools represent a valuable source for in-land water body mapping at different spatio-temporal scales.In this study, we investigate the potential of full-polarimetric synthetic aperture radar measurements collected at L-band by a very high resolution airborne imaging system to address the waterline extraction task over a small in-land water body. A state-of-the-art coastline extraction algorithm is adopoted and specified with respect to the specific morphological features and scattering behavior of a small basin. The performance of different metrics, including single-polarization backscattering intesities, and some child parameters derived from the complete coherency matrix, are analyzed in terms of waterline extraction accuracy.

title: Power Optimization of Triboelectric Energy Harvesters Based on Rectifier Turn-on Time
authors: Maryam Hosseini, Milutin Stanaćević, Shahrzad Towfighian, Ryan Willing, Emre Salman
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: This paper describes a method for maximizing the power delivered to the rectifier in energy harvesters. It is demonstrated that there is an optimal turn-on time for rectifiers to maximize power transfer from the harvester. Next, a maximum power point tracking methodology based on rectifier turn-on time (RTOT-MPPT) is developed for triboelectric energy harvesters. The primary advantage of the proposed approach is the relative independence of the optimal turn-on time on the frequency and peak voltage of the harvester output. Thus, the proposed RTOT-MPPT method reduces the complexity of power tracking and can be efficient for a wider range of harvesters. The method is implemented for a triboelectric harvester and simulated in a 180 n m industrial HV-CMOS process, demonstrating that 34% higher power is delivered to the rectifier in each cycle.

title: Always-on Hyperdimensional Heartbeats
authors: Tanner Mergist, Sercan Aygun
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: This study presents a novel approach to phonocardiogram (PCG) signal classification using hyperdimensional computing (HDC) with hybrid feature extraction and Sobol-based hypervector encoding. Our method transforms heart sound signals into high-dimensional hypervectors by extracting key audio features, such as Mel-frequency cepstral coefficients (MFCCs), zero-crossing rate (ZCR), spectral contrast, and chroma features, followed by quantization and encoding into highdimensional space. The resulting hypervectors are then classified using multi-centroid class representations, generated via k-means clustering, and evaluated through cosine similarity. Our approach achieves rapid inference, robust noise tolerance, and lower computational complexity compared to traditional machine learning methods. The hybrid feature encoding technique effectively captures both spectral and temporal characteristics of PCG signals, enhancing classification accuracy and consistency. We evaluate our model's performance using confusion matrices, inference time analysis, and energy efficiency estimation on a 3W TinyML embedded device. Our refined classifier demonstrates an overall accuracy of 83%, with an average inference time of 1.15 ms per sample, and energy consumption as low as 0.0035 Joules per classification. These results emphasize the potential of our HDC-based approach for reliable, real-time, and low-power diagnostic applications in embedded and wearable biomedical devices.

title: Discriminative Prototype-Guided Feature Matching Network For Remote Sensing Few-Shot Semantic Segmentation
authors: Xinghai Hou, Zhenhao Yang, Linjie Liu, Fukun Bi
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Few-shot segmentation (FSS) aims to identify regions of interest in a query image using only a limited number of labeled support samples. Most existing FSS methods primarily rely on the similarity between support-query pixel pairs to establish pixel-level semantic correlations. However, in remote sensing scenarios characterized by significant intra-class variation and complex backgrounds, pixel-level correlations can introduce substantial matching biases, leading to semantic ambiguity between foreground (FG) and background (BG) pixels in the query image. To address this challenge, we propose a discriminative prototype-guided feature matching network, consisting of a prototype correction module and a cross-matching module. The network is designed to extract the most discriminative pseudo-prototypes of query foregrounds, with the aim of optimizing pixel-level matching between the query and support features. Experimental results on the iSAID-5i dataset demonstrate that the proposed feature matching network achieves superior performance compared to other state-of-the-art methods.

title: Cross-Domain PolSAR Image Classification Based on Multimodal Domain Generalization Network
authors: Wenxin Yao, Yice Cao, Zhenhua Wu, Jie Chen, Chenchen Liu, Liu Xiong, Zhixiang Huang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Cross-domain models have been successfully applied to polarimetric synthetic aperture radar (PolSAR) image classification tasks to address the issue of scarce labeled samples. However, due to the complexity of polarized data and severe cross-domain shifts, these models face challenges in extracting robust domain-invariant features. Additionally, because target domain data are involved in the training of cross-domain models, it makes these models difficult to adapt to real-world application scenarios. Therefore, this paper proposes a target decomposition feature-guided multimodal domain generalization network (TDDGN) for unsupervised cross-domain PolSAR image classification. Firstly, an image feature extraction module is constructed to extract the modal features of depth images. At the same time, considering that the representative target decomposition features of the same class in the same frequency band have cross-domain consistency, the six-component scattering power decomposition (6SD) method and the kuhn-munkres (KM) algorithm are used to obtain the domain common target decomposition features, and the text encoder transforms them into text modal features. Then, the two modal features are embedded into the unified feature space, but due to the large semantic distribution difference of the multimodal features, a shared knowledge transfer module based on pattern memory is designed, and the multi-modal alignment is achieved in the local in-class and global feature space by combining contrast learning and adversarial learning, so as to guide the image modal feature optimization through the text modes with domain consistency. Therefore, clear class distribution and cross-domain invariant image modal characteristics are obtained for target domain classification. The classification results prove the superiority of text feature-guided image feature strategy in unsupervised PolSAR image classification.

title: Active EMI Filter Solution to Enable a New Electric Aircraft Paradigm
authors: Tania Cuesta Cano, Georgios Erotas, Douglas Pedroso, Ignacio Castro
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Achieving a light electrical power system is crucial for future aircraft electrification. Specific power is identified as one of the main enablers to prompt the new aviation paradigm. As a generic rule, EMI filters are expected to contribute to 20%-40% of the power converter total weight. Consequently, this is a main target on the weight optimization strategies. Active filter solutions are presented as a way of minimizing the EMI filter weight. This paper discusses on the main Active EMI filter (AEF) topologies and proposed a novel solution to be implemented following a Hybrid EMI Filter (HEF) approach. A study case, in which the shunt capacitance of a common-mode filter is actively amplified nearly 10 times has been successfully validated.

title: A Review on Flux Estimation Methods for Variable Flux Machine Applications
authors: Sophia Beck, Julius Kesten, Martin Doppelbauer
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Permanent magnet variable flux machines offer an additional degree of freedom with adjustable rotor flux. To utilise this additional parameter for efficient control a detailed description of the flux condition in the machine is required. A basis for this is the estimation of magnetic field strength, which is the objective of this work. For the analyses, a simulation was set up to model the machine with variable magnetic flux. The simulation model was used to implement and analyze methods for determining permanent magnet flux. Some methods revealed a strong interdependence between inductances and magnetic strength, making them inapplicable. The methods that proved effective in this work are an extended Kalman filter and the use of information from an additional torque measurement.

title: A High Linearity 64-GBaud PAM-4/NRZ Driver With Bandwidth Improvement Technique
authors: Omar Z. Alngar, Kun Zhang, Wenkang Luo, Fuzhan Chen, Quan Pan
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: This letter presents a 64-GBaud 4-level pulse amplitude modulation (PAM-4)/non-return to zero (NRZ) driver with a proposed intermediate transmission line and cross-coupled (ITL-CC) technique, used for bandwidth (BW) extension and group-delay (GD) enhancement. Additionally, a cold-FET analog predistorter (C-AP) is introduced to perform two functions. The first is to improve linearity using its amplitude-dependent term, and the second is to reduce overshooting by incorporating this term with its series capacitance component. It achieves reduced jitter, lower total harmonic distortions, and better eye openings over the required BW, essential for maintaining signal integrity at higher data rates. Fabricated in 130-nm SiGe BiCMOS, the driver achieves a measured −3 dB BW of 53 GHz. It demonstrates eye openings of 0.5 UI/960 mV and 0.17 UI/120 mV for 64-Gb/s NRZ and 128-Gb/s PAM-4 upon the activation of the introduced C-AP, respectively. Furthermore, the driver delivers an energy bit efficiency of 4.8 pJ/b at 128 Gb/s, ranking among the best reported performance within the same technology node.

title: Maximizing the Energy Efficiency of Open Radio Access Networks via Optimizing the Operational Parameters
authors: Wisam Hasan Ali, Mohd Nazri Mahmud, Raad S. Alhumaima
abstract: Open radio access networks (ORANs), characterized by their emphasis on the disaggregation of hardware and software components of radio access networks (RANs) and the utilization of open standards, present fertile ground for flexibility and innovations. However, they also introduce complexities in managing bandwidth, user equipment (UE) power allocations, power consumption (PC), and virtualization. To maximize energy efficiency (EE), PC must be effectively managed, and transmitted power and bandwidth to UEs must be optimized. The task in ORANs is more complex due to new components, designs, and protocols. This paper is concerned with maximizing EE in the context of ORANs. The primary focus lies in the realm of virtual machines (VMs) allocation within a multi-tiered cloud infrastructure. To achieve such optimization, a thorough PC model is developed, incorporating various network parameters, including the number of resource blocks (RBs), the number of connected UEs of each VM, the total number of UEs, the initial and maximum power of the server, the number of VMs, the transmitted power, signal-to-interference-noise ratio (SINR), and bandwidth. This work also optimizes the EE through resource allocation models, focusing on open interfaces such as enhanced common public radio interface (eCPRI) and 7.2x fronthaul. It also explores virtualization and network protocols’ role in managing channel capacity and latency, highlighting the trade-off between throughput and protocol overhead. A complex optimization methodology, namely the Lagrange multiplier has been used along with three numerical algorithms: sequential quadratic programming (SQP), active set, and interior point to solve the objective of maximizing EE. The outcomes of this research show the influence of network parameters on PC and EE under some constraints, including the number of UEs, the number of VMs, the number of RBs, and channel capacity. The problem has been recognized as a non-linear problem characterized by inequality restrictions with mixed convexity and concavity behavior. However, different convergence criteria can impact the EE, as more stringent convergence criteria may result in less accurate solutions, and vice versa. For the three algorithms, the interior point and SQP algorithms outperform the active set in most of the cases. Under optimized configurations, SQP enhanced EE by approximately 15% compared to traditional architecture. In addition, 50% increment in the number of UEs, concurrent with 50% less VMs’ allocation when using SQP were achieved compared with interior point. Finally, 15% decrease in latency was accomplished when using interior point compared to SQP.

title: Aging and Performance Analysis of 18650 Lithium-Ion Cell Capacity Degradation: Data-Driven Insights and Modeling
authors: Victor Olivero-Ortiz, Ingrid Oliveros, Carlos Robles-Algarin
abstract: This work analyzes and models degradation in 18650 lithium-ion cells using segmented experimental charge–discharge data (99 cycles under two cycling profiles, 3C/1C and 2C/2C). Beyond raw electrical and thermal measurements (voltage, current, and temperature), we derive operational indicators—mainly cycle time (charge/discharge duration) and internal impedance—to capture nonlinear relationships with capacity. Gaussian Process Regression (GPR) with multiple kernels (RBF, Rational Quadratic, Matérn, plus white noise) is used to predict capacity from these features. Quantitative results indicate that cycle-time features are the most predictive variables. During charging, the top configurations achieve RMSE values of 2.217–4.606 mAh and MAE values of 1.411–3.290 mAh across two cells. During discharge, the best models reach RMSE values of 3.166–3.518 mAh and MAE of 2.186–2.192 mAh. In contrast, impedance-only settings produce significantly higher errors — RMSE approximately 138–182 mAh during charging and roughly 11.281–11.683 mAh during discharging (MAE approximately 9.159–9.416 mAh) — demonstrating their limited usefulness when used alone under the studied regimes. These results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed GPR plus operational features methodology and show that feature selection has a greater impact on accuracy than kernel choice. The approach delivers low absolute error, stable predictive distributions, and consistent phase performance, supporting SOH/RUL estimation and second-life cell screening. The cycle segmentation based on fragmentation further improves interpretability and model design, offering a practical route toward reliable battery management and sustainable second-life applications.

title: Emotion Recognition in Virtual Reality: EEG and EDA-Based Analysis of Stress in High-Risk Scenarios
authors: Martina Zabcikova, Milan Adamek, Jiri Sevcik, Vaclav Mach, Martin Fajkus, Rui Silva
abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) is a powerful tool for analyzing human emotions in simulated crisis scenarios. This study integrates electroencephalography (EEG) and electrodermal activity (EDA) in VR environments to improve emotion recognition in dynamic, high-stress situations that are difficult to replicate in real-world settings. The experiment involved a simulated elevator sabotage scenario, during which participants’ neurophysiological and physiological responses were recorded as the elevator descended. The collected data were compared with self-reported assessments. The primary objective was to evaluate whether combining VR and biosignal-based measurements enables objective analysis of emotional experiences. A hybrid emotion recognition system combining EEG and EDA was developed to quantify stress levels in dynamic crisis scenarios. Statistical analyses and SVM classification confirmed significant phase differences, with 91.67% accuracy and higher reliability of the combined EEG-EDA approach compared to standalone methods. The results indicate that this approach enhances the understanding of psychophysiological stress responses and provides a reliable tool for identifying emotional states during simulated security incidents. This system has potential applications in emotion research, security training, crisis simulations, and environmental psychology. These findings highlight the potential of VR and biosignal analysis for realistic crisis simulations, offering valuable insights for investigative methodologies and security personnel training.

title: Meta-SimGNN: Adaptive and Robust WiFi Localization Across Dynamic Configurations and Diverse Scenarios
authors: Qiqi Xiao, Ziqi Ye, Yinghui He, Jianwei Liu, Guanding Yu
abstract: To promote the practicality of deep learning-based localization, existing studies aim to address the issue of scenario dependence through meta-learning. However, these studies primarily focus on variations in environmental layouts while overlooking the impact of changes in device configurations, such as bandwidth, the number of access points (APs), and the number of antennas used. Unlike environmental changes, variations in device configurations affect the dimensionality of channel state information (CSI), thereby compromising neural network usability. To address this issue, we propose Meta-SimGNN, a novelWiFi localization system that integrates graph neural networks with meta-learning to improve localization generalization and robustness. First, we introduce a fine-grained CSI graph construction scheme, where each AP is treated as a graph node, allowing for adaptability to changes in the number of APs. To structure the features of each node, we propose an amplitude-phase fusion method and a feature extraction method. The former utilizes both amplitude and phase to construct CSI images, enhancing data reliability, while the latter extracts dimension-consistent features to address variations in bandwidth and the number of antennas. Second, a similarity-guided meta-learning strategy is developed to enhance adaptability in diverse scenarios. The initial model parameters for the fine-tuning stage are determined by comparing the similarity between the new scenario and historical scenarios, facilitating rapid adaptation of the model to the new localization scenario. Extensive experimental results over commodity WiFi devices in different scenarios show that Meta-SimGNN outperforms the baseline methods in terms of localization generalization and accuracy.

title: Two-Timescales Optimization of Content Placement and Delivery in Satellite-Terrestrial Edge Computing Networks
authors: Renchao Xie, Yuhao Zheng, Qinqin Tang, Zeru Fang, Tao Huang, Zehui Xiong
abstract: In this paper, we establish a two-timescale framework for the joint optimization for the content placement and content delivery problem in satellite-terrestrial edge computing networks (STECN). Our goal is to optimize content placement to improve network performance while ensuring diverse quality of service (QoS) for content delivery. We decouple the problem into two timescales to balance real-time responsiveness and long-term efficiency. Specifically, considering frequent content placement incurs huge traffic cost, we optimize the content placement in order to reduce resource expenses in large timescales. The optimization problem is formulated as an integer linear programming (ILP) problem to improve both traffic efficiency and cache resource utilization. We leverage a heuristic atom search optimization (ASO) approach to address the problem, which yields an optimal strategy with low computational complexity. In small timescales, we model content delivery as a Markov decision process (MDP) to minimize content delivery delays at small timescales while maintaining smooth network traffic. A deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework is used for policy learning to dynamically adapt to varying network conditions. By considering the correlation between the small and large timescale optimization, we propose a hierarchical solution to jointly address both issues. Finally, extensive simulations confirm the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed scheme.
