title: iDEAS: Intelligent DVFS for Energy-Efficient Task Scheduling in Mobile Devices with big.LITTLE Computing Architecture
authors: Nima Samadi, Farbod Yadollahi, Hamed Shah-Mansouri
abstract: Heterogeneous multicore computing architectures have fundamentally transformed the computational potential of modern mobile devices by enabling parallel and energy-aware task execution. Dynamic voltage and frequency scaling (DVFS) techniques further allow mobile devices to adjust their operating frequency based on their workload demands to save energy. Additionally, edge computing offers the potential to offload intensive tasks, further enhancing energy efficiency. However, the highly dynamic and unpredictable conditions of mobile environments complicate the effective use of these advancements. To address this challenge and alleviate the burden of short battery life, we focus on enhancing energy efficiency in mobile devices. In this paper, we propose an intelligent DVFS-based algorithm that distinguishes itself from existing literature by jointly optimizing task scheduling, frequency scaling, offloading, and power allocation through learned policies. To do so, we first formulate an optimization problem that aims to minimize the energy while meeting task deadlines. This problem is a highly complex combinatorial optimization, and we prove its NP-hardness. Moreover, the highly dynamic nature of mobile environments further complicates achieving an optimal solution. To address these challenges and adapt to unpredictable changes, we then develop a deep reinforcement learning (DRL)-based algorithm, called iDEAS, which gradually learns the best policy of decision making. We introduce a cost function for different action choices, using which we derive a reward function for the DRL agent. We further evaluate the performance of iDEAS on two distinct task sets and compare it with two state-of-the-art existing works, one prioritizing energy efficiency and the other compromising energy consumption for fewer task drops. The results show that iDEAS reduces energy consumption by 69% and 75% for less computationally intensive tasks, and by 54% and 72% for more demanding tasks, compared to these methods. Notably, iDEAS achieves these energy savings while reducing task drops by 18% for intensive workloads and almost eliminating task drops for lighter workloads.

title: Joint Radiation Power, Antenna Position, and Beamforming Optimization for Pinching-Antenna Systems with Motion Power Consumption
authors: Yiming Xu, Dongfang Xu, Xianghao Yu, Shenghui Song, Zhiguo Ding, Robert Schober
abstract: Pinching-antenna systems (PASS) have been recently proposed to improve the performance of wireless networks by reconfiguring both the large-scale and small-scale channel conditions. However, existing studies ignore the physical constraints of antenna placement and assume fixed antenna radiation power. To overcome this limitation, this paper investigates the design of PASS, taking into account the motion power consumption of pinching antennas (PAs) and the impact of adjustable antenna radiation power. To that end, we minimize the average power consumption for a given quality-of-service (QoS) requirement by jointly optimizing the antenna positions, antenna radiation power ratios, and transmit beamforming. To the best of the authors’ knowledge, this is the first work to consider radiation power optimization in PASS, which provides an additional degree of freedom (DoF) for system design. The cases with both continuous and discrete antenna placement are considered, where the main challenge lies in the fact that the antenna positions affect both the magnitude and phase of the channel coefficients of PASS, making system optimization very challenging. To tackle the resulting unique obstacles, an alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM)-based framework is proposed to solve the problem for continuous antenna movement, while its discrete counterpart is formulated as a mixed integer nonlinear programming (MINLP) problem and solved by the block coordinate descent (BCD) method. Simulation results validate the performance enhancement achieved by incorporating PA movement power consumption and adjustable radiation power into the PASS design, while also demonstrating the efficiency of the proposed optimization framework. The benefits of PASS over conventional multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) systems in mitigating the large-scale path loss and inter-user interference are also revealed.

title: A Lightweight PUF-based Secure Group Communication Scheme for Low Altitude Network With Dynamic Group Membership
authors: Yue Zheng, Harishma Boyapally, Wenye Liu, Yongkui Yang, Chip-Hong Chang
abstract: Low Altitude Network (LAN) has emerged as a critical infrastructure for applications such as surveillance and emergency response. Group communication for LAN offers enhanced energy efficiency and reduced network overhead. However, existing group communication protocols encounter difficulties in managing the rekeying process efficiently for a dynamic group or require computationally expensive public key primitives for shared secret handshaking to overcome this challenge. Moreover, the security of most of the existing protocols relies primarily on the safekeeping of some secrets on the group members' devices. To overcome these limitations, we propose a novel physical unclonable function (PUF)-based lightweight secure group communication protocol. The proposed protocol utilizes a combination of the device's PUF and the one-time pad (OTP) to eliminate secure key storage at both group verifier and prover nodes, and achieves perfect forward secrecy (PFS) by eliminating dependence on static long-term secrets. The proposed protocol also supports efficient group key renewal by using a full binary tree as a secret vault for sharing and updating distributed secrets with the Chinese Remainder Theorem (CRT). Meantime, this data structure also reduces the computation and communication complexity for key renewal to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$O(\log _{2}N)$</tex-math></inline-formula> at the cluster head and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$O(1)$</tex-math></inline-formula> at the sensor nodes. A comparative analysis shows that the proposed protocol surpasses related protocols in terms of security features and overheads in computation, communication, as well as secret storage requirements. The proposed protocol was also validated by formal security analyses and a physical LAN implementation using Ultra96-V2 boards as cluster nodes.

title: Research on Optical Fiber Integrated Sensor System for Bogie Condition Monitoring of High-speed Trains
authors: Hao Wu, Ziyu Yao, Chen Li, Jie Li, Qijing Lin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The bogie of a high-speed train is a key component connecting the car body and the track, operating under complex high-stress mechanical conditions. Traditional methods for bogie condition monitoring rely on independent units such as eddy current sensors and resistance strain gauges. While these methods have been widely used in early-stage monitoring, they gradually reveal issues such as complex wiring, susceptibility to electromagnetic interference, and poor environmental adaptability under the complex working conditions of high-speed trains. This paper proposes a new type of sensor using a Fiber Bragg Grating (FBG) series configuration, which boasts advantages including miniaturization, electromagnetic interference resistance, excellent electrical insulation, operational safety, high sensitivity, light weight, stable chemical properties, and low cost, enabling simultaneous measurement of vibration, temperature, and strain. The working principle and structure of the integrated sensor were systematically studied. Sensitivity characteristics and natural frequency parameters were theoretically analyzed and experimentally verified through a dedicated test scheme. A separate calibration procedure was implemented for each measurement parameter to ensure measurement fidelity. A comprehensive multi-parameter sensing system integrating vibration-temperature-strain monitoring functions was established for performance evaluation. Field validation experiments conducted on a high-speed train bogie test platform showed that, when benchmarked against traditional reference sensors, the proposed FBG integrated sensor achieved a 62% enhancement in Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR) through amplitude domain analysis. The developed sensing system exhibits effective diagnostic capability for faults in key components of high-speed train bogies, thus providing a robust solution for Structural Health Monitoring (SHM) of railway transportation infrastructure.

title: A Design Space for Multiscale Visualization_supp1-3634790.xlsx
authors: Mara Solen
abstract: Designing multiscale visualizations, particularly when the ratio between the largest scale and the smallest item is large, can be challenging, and designers have developed many approaches to overcome this challenge. We present a design space for visualization with multiple scales. The design space includes three dimensions, with eight total subdimensions. We demonstrate its descriptive power by using it to code approaches from a corpus we compiled of 52 examples, created by a mix of academics and practitioners. We demonstrate descriptive power by analyzing and partitioning these examples into four high-level strategies for designing multiscale visualizations, which are shared approaches with respect to design space dimension choices. We demonstrate generative power by analyzing missed opportunities within the corpus of examples, identified through analysis of the design space, where we note how certain examples could have benefited from different choices. We discuss patterns in the use of different dimension and strategy choices in the different visualization contexts of analysis and presentation.

title: Envisage: Towards Expressive Visual Graph Querying
authors: Xiaolin Wen, Qishuang Fu, Shuangyue Han, Yichen Guo, Joseph K. Liu, Yong Wan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Graph querying is the process of retrieving information from graph data using specialized languages (e.g., Cypher), often requiring programming expertise. Visual Graph Querying (VGQ) streamlines this process by enabling users to construct and execute queries via an interactive interface without resorting to complex coding. However, current VGQ tools only allow users to construct simple and specifc query graphs, limiting users' ability to interactively express their query intent, especially for underspecifed query intent. To address these limitations, we propose Envisage, an interactive visual graph querying system to enhance the expressiveness of VGQ in complex query scenarios by supporting intuitive graph structure construction and fexible parameterized rule specifcation. Specifcally, Envisage comprises four stages: Query Expression allows users to interactively construct graph queries through intuitive operations; Query Verifcation enables the validation of constructed queries via rule verifcation and query instantiation; Progressive Query Execution can progressively execute queries to ensure meaningful querying results; and Result Analysis facilitates result exploration and interpretation. To evaluate Envisage, we conducted two case studies and in-depth user interviews with 14 graph analysts. The results demonstrate its effectiveness and usability in constructing, verifying, and executing complex graph queries.

title: Guest Editorial Special Issue on the 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
authors: Antonio Liscidini
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs

title: Intermittent Pursuit of Noncooperative Space Targets under Discontinuous Observations via Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Zhaoyang Liu, Sihan Xu, Liran Zhao, Zhaohui Dang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: This paper proposes a Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL)-based framework to develop optimal intermittent pursuit strategies against stochastic, noncooperative space targets under discontinuous observation conditions. Traditional pursuit-evasion models, such as those grounded in differential games, typically rely on continuous observation and control—assumptions that are often invalid in practical space missions due to limited visibility windows and intermittent tracking. These limitations reduce the applicability of classical approaches in real-world scenarios. To address these challenges, we formulate a pursuit-evasion model that explicitly incorporates both discontinuous observations and intermittent control across four representative scenarios. Building on the Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (DDPG) algorithm, we propose an enhanced method—Intermittent Observation and Control DDPG (IOC-DDPG)—designed to learn robust pursuit policies under realistic constraints. We validate the proposed approach in a noncooperative spacecraft rendezvous case study involving stochastic target maneuvers. Simulation results show that IOC-DDPG consistently achieves a success rate exceeding 70%, outperforming traditional methods across diverse and challenging mission conditions. These results highlight the practical potential of deep reinforcement learning in addressing real-world space mission constraints, and pave the way for future extensions to multi-agent pursuit-evasion scenarios and partially observable environments.

title: An Array Decomposition Method for Finite Arrays with Electrically Connected Elements for fast Toeplitz Solvers
authors: Lucas Åkerstedt, Harald Hultin, B. L. G. Jonsson
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: A large part of the geometry of array antennas is often partially defined by finite translational symmetries. Applying the method of moments (MoM) with the Rao-Wilton-Glisson (RWG)-like element on an appropriately structured mesh to these arrays results in an impedance matrix where the main part exhibits a multilevel block Toeplitz structure. This article introduces a memory-efficient construction method that effectively represents and reuses impedance calculations. The proposed method, applicable to electrically connected elements, also accounts for all non-symmetric parts of the array. The core idea involves nine distinct electrically connectable components from which the array can be assembled. The derived multilevel block Toeplitz matrix is further utilized by an in-house inverse solver to achieve faster and more memory-efficient MoM current vector calculations. We demonstrate the method by computing the far-field of a 32x32 array and the scattering parameters of two tightly coupled 9x9 arrays. This approach reduces the memory allocation from O(Nx2Ny2) to O(NxNy), for an Nx×Ny array.

title: Knee-Inspired Hinge Absorbs Longitudinal Impacts to Enhance Robot-Environment Interaction Safety
authors: Lianxin Yang, Xinyan Li, Tianyu Zhao, Zhihua Zhao
abstract: As robots integrate into human society, ensuring safe robot-environment interaction, particularly in the event of collisions, has emerged as a growing design priority. A promising solution is introducing proper compliance into existing rigid robots, akin to musculoskeletal systems, to absorb impacts in various directions. However, mimicking longitudinal compliance seen in biological joints to absorb compressive impacts along limbs, such as the role of cartilages like menisci, remains a challenge shadowed by the complexity of joint architecture. Here, exploring and adapting the elastic longitudinal movement structure of knee, we incorporated traditional mechanical hinges with a compact buffer structure to enable both simple rotational motion and effective longitudinal impact absorption. Under longitudinal loading, the buffer structure functions as a mechanism transmitting the limited compression to amplified deformations of elastic elements, thus producing resistance against load. The resistive load-displacement relationship is tailorable by tuning diverse elastic components, allowing for a high-static-low-dynamic stiffness to improve energy absorption efficiency. Drop tests and walking robot demonstrations confirm that the proposed knee-inspired hinge not only mitigates acceleration transmitted to the robot's main body but also reduces ground reaction forces, thereby improving robot-environment interaction safety. This work highlights the design paradigm of adapting natural solutions to mechanical systems, and holds potential for direct integration into diverse robots, exoskeletons, and prostheses.

title: Poster—Reconnaissance via Certificate Transparency Logs: Exposing Self-Hosted Web Applications
authors: Damiano Ravalico, Martino Trevisan, Idilio Drago
publish: Proceedings of the 21st International Conference on emerging Networking EXperiments and Technologies
abstract: None

title: An Efficient Multi-Direction State Space Model for Hyperspectral Reconstruction
authors: Chengle Zhou, Zhi He, Li Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The state space model (SSM) has received extensive attention in the field of hyperspectral image (HSI) processing due to its advantages in capturing long-range dependencies and linear complexity. However, SSM, which originates from natural language processing, has one-way modeling limitations and cannot effectively represent the multi-directional information flow of images in HSI reconstruction task. To overcome this issue, this paper proposes a lightweight multi-directional SSM for HSI reconstruction, which aims to recover the corresponding HSI from a given RGB image. Specifically, the proposed method adopts a selective scan mechanism in four spatial directions to effectively model the image information flow, overcoming the limitation of unidirectional modeling of the SSM. Experiments on UAV remote sensing dataset demonstrate that the proposed method can outperform classical and advanced hyperspectral reconstruction methods while using less computational resources and parameters.

title: Time-Discrete Propagation of Uncertainty in Voltage and Current Measurements to Active Power and Efficiency of Converter-Fed Drives
authors: Alexander Stock
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This document presents a method for propagating the measurement uncertainty (MU) of voltages and currents to calculated parameters such as active power and efficiency. Since these parameters are usually calculated by modern power analyzers based on discrete-time samples of the measured voltages and currents, the underlying discrete-time calculation algorithms are taken into account. Compared to other established approaches, this methodology is also suitable for the MU propagation of nonsinusoidal voltages and currents and is therefore particularly suitable for measuring inverter-fed drives.

title: Estimation of Nitrogen Content in Canola and Wheat Using Hyperspectral Drone Imaging
authors: Amir M. Chegoonian, Keshav D. Singh, Charles M. Geddes, Christian Hansen, Hongquan Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Accurately estimating nitrogen (N) content in crops is essential for assessing nitrogen use efficiency (NUE), a critical parameter for optimizing fertilizer management and improving crop productivity. Traditional methods for N estimation are often destructive, time-consuming, and labor-intensive, making them impractical for large-scale applications. This study presents a non-invasive approach using unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV)-based hyperspectral imaging to estimate N content in canola and wheat at different growth stages. Hyperspectral images were collected at three growth stages during an experimental field trial conducted in Lethbridge, Alberta, Canada. Concurrently, leaf tissue samples were gathered from seven nitrogen treatment levels, each replicated four times, to serve as ground truth data. Several machine learning (ML) models were developed and evaluated to predict plant N-uptake. The results demonstrated that hyperspectral imaging could estimate N content with high accuracy. For canola, the root mean square error (RMSE) ranged from 0.51 to 0.65, with R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> values between 0.73 and 0.84. For wheat, the RMSE ranged from 0.28 to 0.49, with R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> values between 0.75 and 0.92. These findings highlight the potential of UAV-based hyperspectral imaging, combined with ML models, as a powerful and efficient tool for estimating N-uptake. This approach offers significant benefits for precision agriculture, enabling sustainable nitrogen management and improving crop productivity.

title: Deep Learning-Based SHARAD Surface Echo Extraction and Permittivity Inversion
authors: Dongfang Fan, Siting Xiong, Bochen Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Mars is a terrestrial planet in the habitable zone of the solar system, and liquid water is considered the foundation for the existence of life. Therefore, the search for various forms of water has become an important scientific objective of Mars exploration missions. This paper proposes a deep learning-based method for SHARAD surface echo extraction and permittivity inversion, providing new insights into the study of Martian surface soil properties. By using SHARAD images and clutter information, two training datasets—full waveform and non-full waveform—are constructed. The surface echo signals are predicted and compared using deep learning models U-Net, AttUNet, GAU_UNet, and HRNet. Echo peaks are extracted from the prediction results. Based on the assumption that the terrain exhibits self-affine fractal characteristics, the permittivity of two regions in eastern Koprates and Caprichas of Valles Marineris, Mars, were estimated using signal values corresponding to peaks, digital terrain models (DTM), and radar detection data.

title: Investigation of the Effect of Magnetic Coupling on the Capacitor Current of Dual Three-Phase Permanent Magnet Synchronous Machine Drives
authors: Bernhard Hopfensperger, Marcel Vanselow, Andrew Hopkins, Ingo Hahn
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The drive towards electrification of vehicles and transport systems has led to research into multiphase drive topologies beyond the conventional three. Dual three-phase machine drives are attractive due to reduced torque and DC-link harmonic content in addition to fault tolerance. Further DC-link rms-current reductions can be realised by applying appropriate modulation schemes and shifting/interleaving PWM patterns. However, the magnetic cross coupling between the two three-phase systems impacts the output current harmonics and subsequently the torque ripple which is further exacerbated by interleaving of their respective carriers. The impact of magnetic coupling on the DC-link and output current ripples is investigated.

title: Down-Sized Prototype of Axial-Flux Type Electromagnetic Stirrer for Electromagnetic Stirring of Liquid Metals
authors: Masahiro Aoyama, Moka Ishikiriyama
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: This paper proposes an electromagnetic stirrer with an axial-flux structure, with the aim of shortening the head length required to realize a fully electrified casting system. The prototype was produced using a 12 -slot pressed soft magnetic composites (SMC) core that allows the number of poles to be switched between 4, 8 and 10. Elemental experiments were conducted using the prototype to rotate a low-melting-point liquid metal (gallium) by Lorenz force when the number of poles, excitation frequency and magnetomotive force (MMF) were changed. As a result, the flow velocity distribution due to electromagnetic stirring was successfully visualized, and the relationship between the pole numbers, the excitation conditions and the flow velocity of liquid metal were clarified.

title: An IoT-Based Industrial Monitoring System for Multi-Vendor PLC Integration Using Node-RED
authors: Murie Dwiyaniti, Hatib Setiana, Respati Prajna Vashti, Adam Risky Muharam, Rizqi Elok Fatihah Lutfi, Nanda Afrian Nurzeha, Nuha Nadhiroh, Danang Widjajanto
publish: 2025 9th International Conference On Electrical, Electronics And Information Engineering (ICEEIE)
abstract: The advancement of Industry 4.0 technology demands intelligent and highly integrated industrial automation systems. However, integrating systems that utilize PLCs from different vendors, such as Siemens and Schneider Electric, continues to face interoperability challenges due to differences in communication protocols and data structures. This study aims to design and implement an IoT-based monitoring system using Node-RED capable of integrating two PLCs from different vendors-Siemens S7-1200 and Schneider Modicon TM221. The research employs an experimental prototyping method involving two industrial plants: a water tank filling system controlled by a Schneider PLC and an automated sorting system simulated using Factory I/O and controlled by a Siemens PLC. Both systems are interconnected via a Modbus TCP/IP network and monitored in real time through a web-based Node-RED dashboard. The test results indicate that the system is capable of transmitting data in real time with minimal delay, ranging from 10 to 20 milliseconds, in compliance with ISA-95 standards for industrial vertical communication. Moreover, connection stability tests reveal that Node-RED can automatically reconnect during network disruptions, with recovery times ranging from 3 to 20 seconds depending on the type of disturbance. This study demonstrates that a Node-RED-based cross-vendor PLC integration can serve as an efficient and adaptive solution for industrial monitoring systems in the digitalization era.

title: Warehouse Network Optimization: Hybrid Approach Using Spatial Demand Analytics and ML Based Optimization
authors: Bhubalan Mani, Yashodhan Shirolkar
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society Conference - Global (TEMSCON Global)
abstract: With growing complexity and competition to gain more market share in the markets served, companies should optimize the supply chain network to improve customer service levels and reduce the overall cost incurred. Optimizing operations footprint is a key factor in improving supply chain efficiency. With digitization and technological advancement valuable tools are available at the disposable to gain competitive advantage. This paper provides information about a methodology which uses Hot-spot analysis and optimization techniques together to locate warehouses optimally to prioritize the high value customer demand. The Hot-Spot analysis provides the capability of effective segmentation and visualization whereas the optimization techniques build mathematical models for solving business scenario. The methodology uses different optimization techniques and compares the outcome. The paper then provides information on the possible future research and its applications from Supply Chain Planning perspective.

title: EKF-Based SOC Estimation with Analytical Noise Covariance for Sodium-Ion Batteries in EVs
authors: Elisa Irujo, Alberto Berrueta, Pablo Sanchis, Alfredo Ursúa
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The growing demand for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) in electric vehicles and renewable energy integration, along with lithium scarcity, underscores the need for alternative battery technologies, with sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) as a promising candidate. Significant effort is being directed towards developing sodium-ion technology to meet future energy storage needs. A key challenge for its practical integration is the battery management system (BMS), where accurate state of charge (SOC) estimation is crucial for efficiency performance and longevity. However, research on SOC estimation for sodiumion batteries remains limited. This paper proposes using the Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) for SOC estimation for sodiumion batteries in urban electric vehicles (EVs). The experimental EKF parameter tuning methodology is detailed, filling a gap in existing research. The algorithm performance is evaluated across the full SOC range, under typical disturbances, showing that EKF outperforms the Coulomb counting (CC) method for more accurate SOC estimation in sodium-ion batteries. Validation using a standardized urban driving cycle demonstrates the suitability of the proposed algorithm for small electric vehicles.

title: A Low-Complexity Algorithm for Fast One-Bit SAR Imaging
authors: Luwei Zhang, Tian Zeng, Hongcheng Zeng, Xinwei An, Yamin Wang, Wei Yang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Imaging based on direct matched filtering of one-bit quantized echo signals results in significant degradation of imaging quality, deterioration of the Signal-To-Noise Ratio (SNR), and the generation of false targets. One-Bit compressed sensing technology enables the recovery of one-bit quantized signals, and under the prior assumption of sparsity in the scene, the one-bit compressed sensing recovery algorithm can reconstruct the scattering characteristics of the scene while effectively suppressing the generation of false targets. However, existing Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) imaging algorithms based on one-bit compressed sensing typically employ vector observation models, which leads to high-dimensional matrices and limit their applicability to large-scale sparse imaging scenarios. In this paper, we propose a low-complexity fast one-bit SAR imaging algorithm, which uses a matrix observation model to decompose the vector observation model in two dimensions. Finally, simulation validation was carried out and the experimental results based on point and surface targets verified the effectiveness of the algorithm.

title: First Results of the 3D Ground Displacements Retrieval through Capella Space Mid-Inclination Orbit DInSAR Measurements: the Campi Flegrei Caldera Case Study
authors: F. Cotugno, P. Berardino, M. Bonano, F. Casu, V. Cazcarra-Bes, G. Farquharson, M. Manunta, A. Renga, C. Stringham, N. Yague-Martinez, R. Lanari
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In this work we present the first results achieved by processing three interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) datasets acquired between late June and August 2024 by the Capella Space satellite Capella-14, with a repeat cycle of approximately 3 days and operating at a 45° mid-inclination orbit (MIO). An MIO Differential SAR Interferometry (DInSAR) configuration can measure displacements also along the North-South direction, offering complementary insights to those provided by sun-synchronous satellites. For this reason, this study focuses on the Campi Flegrei caldera (Italy), an area characterized by significant ground deformation due to the bradyseism phenomenon, which has been in an uplift phase since 2005. The SAR data are processed using the Parallel Small BAseline Subset (P-SBAS) technique, and the first results detailing Line of Sight (LOS) displacements are presented. This work highlights the potential of upcoming SAR missions optimized for MIO configurations, such as the NIMBUS SAR sub-constellation within the forthcoming Italian IRIDE constellation.

title: A Review of Challenges and Applications in Remote Sensing Foundation Models
authors: Peijin Wang, Ziqi Zhang, Yingchao Feng, Wenxin Yin, Wenhui Diao, Xian Sun
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Intelligent interpretation of remote sensing (RS) data is crucial for applications such as environmental protection and economic analysis. While foundation models have demonstrated remarkable success in the field of computer vision, directly applying them to RS remains a significant challenge due to the unique characteristics and complexity of RS data. In recent years, researchers have increasingly recognized the potential of foundation models tailored for RS. Key areas of focus include large-scale pre-training, multimodal RS data integration, and RS-specific feature embedding. However, with the growing volume of related publications, it has become challenging for researchers to systematically grasp the progress and trends in this field. Although a few review papers on foundation models in RS exist, this paper stands out by addressing the topic from the perspective of the unique challenges encountered, encompassing aspects of data, methodologies, and applications. Notably, this is the first review to comprehensively explore the applications of foundation models, offering researchers deeper insights into the intelligent interpretation of RS data.

title: Not Every Tree is A Forest: Benchmarking Forest Types from Satellite Remote Sensing
authors: Yuchang Jiang, Maxim Neumann
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Developing accurate and reliable models for forest types mapping is critical to support efforts for halting deforestation and for biodiversity conservation (such as European Union Deforestation Regulation (EUDR)). This work introduces ForTy, a benchmark for global-scale FORest TYpes mapping using multi-temporal satellite data<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>. The benchmark comprises 200,000 time series of image patches, each consisting of Sentinel-2, Sentinel-1, climate, and elevation data. Each time series captures variations at monthly or seasonal cadence. Per-pixel annotations, including forest types and other land use classes, support image segmentation tasks. Unlike most existing land use products that often categorize all forest areas into a single class, our benchmark differentiates between three forest types classes: natural forest, planted forest, and tree crops. By leveraging multiple public data sources, we achieve global coverage with this benchmark. We evaluate the forest types dataset using several baseline models, including convolution neural networks and transformer-based models. Additionally, we propose a novel transformer-based model specifically designed to handle multi-modal, multi-temporal satellite data for forest types mapping. Our experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model surpasses the baseline models in performance.

title: Dynamic Programming Resolution of Memristive Synapse
authors: Graham Buchanan, Sree Nirmillo Biswash Tushar, Hritom Das, Garrett S. Rose
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: Metal-oxide memristors, including <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{H f O}_{\text{2}}$</tex>, provide programmable memory based upon the actuation of a NFET gate in a 1T1R configuration. For computation, a digital-to-analog converter (DAC) modulates this gate with a fixed resolution. In this paper, a dynamic R-2R based DAC provides varying resolutions when setting the weights of the 1T1R synapse. This particular design allows the implementation of four binary resolutions with which to program the memristor, which can be independently set for each cell of the DPE. By setting the load of a current source, the device can achieve normal operation across multiple binary ranges simultaneously. Our proposed design shows a dynamic bit-resolution adaptation for a memristive architecture in a 65 nm process.

title: A Synergistic Thermal Image Sharpening Approach to Analyse The Cooling Effects of Urban Biodiversity Parks in Delhi India
authors: Dyvavani Krishna Kapuganti, Kailash C Tiwari, Gopala Areendran
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Green Spaces (UGS) play a crucial role as nature-based solution for fostering climate resilience in urban centres. This study investigates the cooling efficiency of two prominent biodiversity parks in Delhi, India, using a synergistic thermal sharpening approach. The DisTrad algorithm was applied to enhance the spatial resolution of 70 m ECOSTRESS data to 10 m, utilizing spectral indices derived from Sentinel-2A data for the summer and winter seasons of 2024. Five indicators of cooling effect were assessed using buffer analysis based on the sharpened Land Surface Temperature (LST) data. The average park cooling intensity and park cooling area were 1.47 °C and 28.45 ha in summer, respectively, and 1.14 °C and 27.56 ha in winter, respectively. The findings highlight the significance of wetlands and natural vegetation communities of the biodiversity parks in mitigating urban heat.

title: Three-Dimensional SAR Imaging Based on Composite Prior With Multitasking Framework
authors: Yangyang Wang, Xu Zhan, Xingcheng Han, Jing Gao, Yuxuan Liu, Zhiliang Yang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Three-dimensional (3-D) synthetic aperture radar (SAR) imaging can achieve 3-D spatial information of targets. The L1 penalty function, as a sparse representation of the target, is widely used in 3-D SAR imaging. However, as a convex relaxation strategy, the L1 frequently causes bias of the amplitude in SAR imaging and only enhances the sparse features of the target, resulting in the loss of non-sparse structural information. To address above problem, a novel 3-D SAR imaging method with composite sparse and low-rank prior is developed. Firstly, we construct an imaging optimization model integrating the non-convex penalty function and the nuclear norm. Next, we present a multitasking framework that integrates variable splitting and alternating minimization (VSAM) to solve the optimization problem of composite prior, which effectively reduces computational complexity and is applied to high-dimensional imaging scenarios. A series of simulations and real experiments validate the proposed method achieve superior 3-D imaging.

title: Discriminating Vachellia karroo from cohabiting vegetation through seasonal differences using in-situ hyperspectral data and simulated Sentinel-2 bands
authors: Siphokazi Ruth Gcayi, Samuel A. Adelabu, Mcebisi Qabaqaba, George J. Chirima
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Encroaching woody plants like Vachellia karroo (V. karroo) cause significant ecological changes to grasslands and savanna biomes and have environmental and socio-economic impacts that negatively affect the livelihoods of farmers and rural communities. Thus, effective control methods are required to manage and monitor V. karroo. Effective management and monitoring of encroaching woody plants require mapping their spatial distribution. The challenge associated with effectively managing V. karroo is that it regenerates quickly and causes vegetation heterogeneity making it difficult to distinguish from other vegetation through low resolution data. This study aimed to discriminate V. karroo from cohabiting vegetation types using in-situ hyperspectral data and simulated Sentinel-2 bands across spring and summer seasons, while also identifying important variables in discriminating V. karroo. Spectral reflectance of the V. karroo and cohabiting vegetation (aloe, mixed bush, grass, and forbs) were collected in October (spring) and December of 2022 (summer). The random forest classifier was used to discriminate V. karroo from cohabiting vegetation types. The study compared the performance of all hyperspectral bands; top 10 important bands selected from hyperspectral data and simulated Sentinel-2 bands in discriminating V. karroo. The results of this study showed that V. karroo can be discriminated using all hyperspectral bands, and simulated Sentinel-2 bands. This is evident from the high classification accuracy, with overall accuracies of between 99% and 100% and Kappa values between 0.995 and 1.00, when discriminating V. karroo using all hyperspectral bands, the top 10 selected hyperspectral bands, and simulated Sentinel-2 bands. The results also showed that the summer season was the best season to discriminate V. karroo from cohabiting vegetation. The high classification accuracy (between 98.4% and 100%) obtained from simulated Sentinel-2 bands shows the robustness of the random forest classifier and indicates the potential of using Sentinel-2 data to discriminate V. karroo.

title: Landslide Monitoring from the Perspective of Surveillance Cameras with Change Detection Technology
authors: Jun Yin, Fei Wu, Jisheng Huang, Yupeng Ren, Qiankun Li, Heng Jin, Hongbin Zhou
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Landslide is one of the most dangerous natural disasters, which cause significant economic and even human life loss every year. To reduce the loss caused by landslide, it is important to monitor the occurrence of landslide and give an alarm in time. At present, there are two mainstream technical routes for landslide monitoring, namely with IoT sensors and with satellite imagery. However, IoT sensors cannot monitor large area of land, while satellite image cannot alarm in time. In this paper, we present monitoring landslide with surveillance cameras, which are able to cover large area of land, and to send alarm promptly. To detect landslide on surveillance camera image, we use deep learning based change detection technology, which can tell newly occurred landslide from historical landslide scar. Furthermore, AIGC technology is used to build up a dataset to train the landslide change detection model.

title: Non-Linear Modeling and Analysis of Amplifier-Less Potentiostat Architectures
authors: Andrea Sannino, David-Peter Wiens, Maurits Ortmanns, José I. Artigas, Aránzazu Otín
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: In this article, a previously published amplifier-less potentiostat architecture is further examined. Starting with a linearized model, the impact of the most important parameters is studied taking in account the electrodes-solution electrochemical interface. A detailed model is obtained and thoroughly verified, and recommended operating conditions are given for certain limit load conditions. Then, a more complete non-linear model is developed to take in account the measurement uncertainty introduced by the circuit non-linear components. This non-linear model is compared to a time domain description of the circuit and it is verified that it can predict the non-linear behavior with a precision better than 20%. This result enables the circuit designers to compensate for these effects and ultimately reduce the overall measurement uncertainty.

title: Satellite Remote Sensing And Groundwater Records Reveal Land Subsidence In Diamond Valley, Nevada
authors: Sayantan Majumdar, Justin L. Huntington, Ryan G. Smith, Peter ReVelle, Thomas J. Ott, Sean A. McKenna, Vicken Etyemezian, Steven N. Bacon
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Diamond Valley (DV) is a key agricultural basin in Central Nevada that fully relies on groundwater for irrigation, with alfalfa and grass hay being the dominant crops. Due to excessive groundwater pumping, particularly in southern DV, groundwater levels have declined by almost 25 m (80 ft) over the past fifty years. As a result of groundwater overdrafts, the Nevada State Engineer’s office designated DV as a "Critical Management Area" in 2015. Despite the formulation and implementation of the DV groundwater management plan, to date, there have been no research that investigated groundwater pumping-induced land subsidence in this region. Here, we conducted the first short baseline subset (SBAS) interferometric synthetic aperture radar (InSAR) time series analysis using Sentinel-1 data and compared the estimated subsidence with in-situ groundwater level records and OpenET-based groundwater pumping estimates. Our results indicate that, between 2014 and 2024, central DV experienced land subsidence (more than 600 mm, or 2 ft), which can be attributed to the presence of unconsolidated clays in the basin fill deposits across the valley floors, increased groundwater pumping for irrigation, and the resulting decline in groundwater levels. Moreover, some of these high-subsidence areas have existing infrastructure like houses and roads, potentially leading to future risks. While further research is needed to comprehensively validate these findings, this study represents the first use of SBAS InSAR to investigate groundwater pumping-driven land subsidence in Nevada, establishing a framework for monitoring land deformation (subsidence and uplift) throughout the state and evaluating the associated infrastructure risks.

title: Realistic GPS Spoofing via Customized CARLA GPS Navigation and Controller Systems
authors: Thomas D. Robertson, Wesam Al Amiri, Abhijeet Solanki, Syed Rafay Hasan, Terry N. Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: The vulnerability of autonomous vehicle (AV) systems to Global Positioning System (GPS)-based attacks presents a significant challenge in ensuring reliable navigation and sensor integrity. This work addresses the lack of modifiable GPS data output in CARLA which limits the evaluation of sensor vulnerabilities under different attack scenarios. To overcome this limitation, we introduce a novel unbounded GPS navigation framework within the CARLA simulator. A Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) controller is integrated with the GPS approximation method to improve navigation performance under adversarial conditions. The framework has been tested under two GPS attack models, demonstrating its ability to handle small deviations while revealing limitations in correcting larger biases. Experimental results demonstrate successful navigation in both straight-line and waypoint-based scenarios, establishing a foundation for future work focused on mitigating sensor manipulation through reverseengineering techniques and improved GPS tracking systems.

title: A Single-Phase Common Ground Rectifier with Power Decoupling Ability
authors: Xu Yang, Weimin Wu, Houqing Wang, Mingsan Ouyang, Frede Blaabjerg, Liang Yuan
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: In this paper, a common ground three-terminal rectifier with active power decoupling ability is proposed. The proposed topology establishes a direct connection between the AC and DC ground, thereby suppressing common mode leakage currents and eliminating the demand for an isolation transformer. Additionally, the active power decoupling function enables the double line frequency ripple power to be absorbed by the decoupling circuit, significantly reducing the DC-link capacitance, which in turn enhances the power density and operational lifespan of the converter. Moreover, compared to existing decoupling topologies, the proposed design imposes lower voltage stress on the decoupling components, reducing the performance requirements for these devices. Finally, the feasibility of the proposed <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{AC} / \text{DC}$</tex> converter is validated through simulation studies.

title: Research on Hypersonic Vehicle-Borne SAR with Spiral Trajectory Based on Two-Dimensional Chirp-Z Transform
authors: Zixuan He, Shiyang Tang, Yifan Wang, Jiahao Han, Zhixin Lian, Feng Luo, Chenghao Jiang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Hypersonic vehicles usually employ a spiral trajectory during glide flight to achieve high maneuverability. The complex motion characteristics of the spiral trajectory poses significant problems for hypersonic vehicle-borne (HSV) synthetic aperture radar (SAR). To address these problems, a geometric model based on the motion characteristics of HSV with spiral trajectory is established. Then, the echo characteristics are analyzed. The imaging slant range is reconstructed through vector calculation and high-order fitting. A new azimuth and range frequency Chirp-Z Transform (CZT) based method is proposed to eliminate the spatial variation and cross-coupling. The method demonstrates higher focusing accuracy and more effective for HSV SAR with spiral trajectory. Finally, the effectiveness of the method is validated through simulation data and semi-real data experiments.

title: A 25 Kw 4-Port High-Power Density Multiple Active Bridge as an Efficient Means to Incorporate Hydrogen Into Buildings and Small Industries
authors: Alejandro Llop, Kepa Mendibil, Salvador Ceballos, David Garrido Diez, Igor Baraia-Etxaburu
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: In this paper, the investigation, design and implementation of a 25 kW power converter for the integration of Hydrogen Technologies (namely electrolysers and fuel cells) with other renewable energy sources is presented, including PV cells and the grid. Working at high switching frequencies, thanks to the use of wide bandgap devices, it is able to achieve very high efficiency and power density; besides, due to the topology selected, the Quadruple Active Bridge (QAB), the component list is drastically reduced and any of the four ports can function as a source or load, choosing the requested power as desired. Before its implementation, several simulations have been conducted for which the electrical model of an electrolyser has been previously obtained. As regards the modulation and control, single phase shift (SPS) modulation with a novel control strategy has been devised. Furthermore, employing Processor-in-the-loop and Model Based Design for the control part, the design has been validated and, eventually, tested experimentally.

title: Comparison of ML and DL Based Methods for Forest Height Estimation Through Multi-Channel SAR Data
authors: Francesca Razzano, Wenyu Yang, Sergio Vitale, Giampaolo Ferraioli, Vito Pascazio, Silvia Liberata Ullo, Gilda Schirinzi
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Forest measurement plays a vital role in monitoring climate change and quantifying the global carbon cycle. Synthetic Aperture Radar Tomography (TomoSAR) has long been an effective technique for reconstructing three-dimensional (3D) forest structures. With recent advancements in Artificial Intelligence (AI), methods based on Machine Learning (ML) and Deep Learning (DL) have been proposed for estimating parameters in forested areas. Both approaches address the height retrieval problem as a classification task. In this paper, two methodologies—ML-based CatBoost and DL-based TomoSAR Neural Network (TSNN)—are introduced and compared in terms of accuracy and computational load, demonstrating that they can effectively replace traditional model-based TomoSAR methods.

title: An Ultra-Low-Power 4-Channel Neural Recording IC with Clock Recovery for Scalable Wireless Implants
authors: Heng Wang, Hamed Rahmani
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a miniaturized, energy-efficient <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 \times 2$</tex>-channel neural recording front-end IC for high-density neural signal acquisition. Each channel features a bandwidth- and gain-tunable Analog Front-End (AFE) and a 10-bit Successive-Approximation Register (SAR) ADC. The AFE employs a capacitive feedback network with voltage-controlled pseudoresistors and digitally controlled capacitors, enabling tunable bandwidth (0.1-5 kHz) and gain (40-50 dB). The SAR ADC utilizes a bootstrapped switch and monotonic switching scheme, reducing switching energy by 81% while achieving an SNDR of 57.8 dB and an ENOB of 9.3 bits. The IC integrates a clock recovery unit that extracts a 1.1 MHz square wave with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \mu \mathrm{W}$</tex> of power consumption, eliminating the need for an on-chip oscillator. The entire design is based on TSMC 180 nm CMOS technology, occupying a total area of 2.2 × 2.3 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>.

title:
SAR Image Classification using Neural Networks and G
                    <sup>I</sup>
                    <sub>0</sub>
                    Data
authors: Andrea Rey, Juliana Gambini, Emiliano Churruca, Alejandro C. Frery, Juan Santos
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) image classification is a challenge because this type of images are contaminated with speckle noise, an interference phenomenon which is non additive and non Gaussian. Then, statistical modeling of SAR data is essential. The ${\mathcal{G}}_I^0$ distribution is a good selection because it can describe a wide variety of targets, and for this expressiveness, it is often referred to as the “Universal Model.” It is governed by three parameters: the number of looks L, the roughness α, and the scale γ. By estimating the parameter values from SAR data samples, it is possible to obtain relevant information about an image area, hence the importance of developing an accurate estimation method. Unfortunately, classical methods of estimating statistical parameters fail when applied to the ${\mathcal{G}}_I^0$ distribution. The goal of this work is parameter estimation of the ${\mathcal{G}}_I^0$ distribution by using a low-cost neural network. We apply these estimates to classify synthetic SAR images with promising results.

title: Parallel Connection of 3.3 kV SiC Power Modules – Influence of Device Parameters
authors: Junya Sakai, Yu Ando, Ryo Tsuda, Nils Soltau, Eugen Wiesner
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Since SiC power modules are being used more often in various applications, the parallel connection of such modules becomes more popular as well. This paper investigates the influence of power module parameters, such as on-state voltage and gate threshold voltage, on parallel connection. Particularly, current sharing and differences in switching losses are analyzed. Two different generations of 3.3 kV SiC power modules are measured and compared. Moreover, parallel connection of SiC power modules is compared with previous results from 3.3 kV Si power modules. The fact that SiC power modules are in general more challenging to parallel connect, has been addressed for the Unifull <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{\text{TM}}$</tex> SiC MOSFET. It independently adjusts its transfer characteristics, achieving parallel-operation performance comparable to Si-based devices.

title: Adopting Beidou Navigation Satellites to Estimate Vegetation Effects on Deformation Measurements Through GNSS-Based InBSAR
authors: Xiyue Zeng, Zhanze Wang, Feifeng Liu, Jinyi Dong, Fukun Bi
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: To comprehend the impact of vegetation coverage on the efficiency of deformation measurement via Global Navigation Satellite System-Based bistatic Interferometric synthetic aperture radar (GNSS-based InBSAR), a comprehensive analysis was conducted based on raw data collected from the Beidou Navigation Satellite (BDS) spanning from November 13, 2023, to March 20, 2024. A coherence coefficient-based evaluation method is introduced. Meanwhile, the deformation measurement results are presented, validating the applicability of GNSS-based InBSAR observations in monitoring vegetated landsides in Chongqing. Regional analysis facilitated by subarea partitioning was employed to elucidate the effect of vegetation cover types on GNSS-based InBSAR performance. The results indicates that the coherence in areas covered by arboreal vegetation is inferior to that of areas with shrubbery coverage, proving the potential of GNSS-based InBSAR in estimating vegetation effects.

title: A Novel Additive Manufactured Polymer-Based Liquid Cooling System (AMPoLiCoolS) for Double-Sided Cooled Power Modules
authors: Emmanuel Arriola, Jose Emmanuel Ignacio, Ren Andrew Untalan, Abrey Angelo Arroyo, Rigoberto Advincula, Guo-Quan Lu, Toni Beth Lopez
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: To meet the increasing thermal demands of double-sided cooled power modules in high-power electronics, this study presents the design and evaluation of AMPoLiCoolS, a polymer-based, additively manufactured liquid cooling manifold optimized for enhanced heat dissipation. Leveraging design-for-additive-manufacturing strategies, the manifold was iteratively developed from a baseline flow path to advanced impingement-based structures with integrated relief features. CFD simulations was conducted across varying flow rates to assess thermal and hydraulic performance. The optimized design achieved a 23% increase in heat transfer coefficient and approximately 20% reduction in peak power module temperature compared to traditional aluminum-based heat sinks, with only a moderate increase in pressure drop. These results emphasize the potential of polymer additive manufacturing to deliver lightweight, customizable, and highperformance thermal solutions for compact and energy-efficient power module applications.

title: Sequencing on Silicon: AI SoC Design for Mobile Genomics at the Edge
authors: Sebastian Magierowski, Zhongpan Wu, Abel Beyene, Karim Hammad
publish: 2025 IEEE 68th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS)
abstract: Miniature DNA sequencing hardware has begun to succeed in mobile contexts, driving demand for efficient machine learning at the edge. This domain leverages deep learning techniques familiar from speech and time-series analysis for both low-level signal processing and high-level genomic interpretation. Unlike audio, however, nanopore sequencing presents raw data rates over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100 \times$</tex> higher, requiring more aggressive compute and memory handling. In this paper, we present a CMOS system-on-chip (SoC) designed for mobile genetic analysis. Our approach combines a multi-core RISC-V processor with tightly coupled accelerators for deep learning and bioinformatics. A hardware/software co-design strategy enables energy-efficient operation across a heterogeneous compute fabric, targeting realtime, on-device genome analysis. This work exemplifies the integration of deep learning, edge computing, and domain-specific hardware to advance next-generation mobile genomics.

title: Boosting Change Captioning in Remote Sensing based on Data Augmentation and Diffusion Models
authors: Xiaofei Yu, Jie Ma, Hanlin Wu, Liqiang Qiao
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Remote Sensing Image Change Captioning (RSICC) has emerged as a significant research focus. This task aims to describe the changes between bi-temporal remote sensing image pairs using natural language. It provides valuable insights into geospatial understanding and land planning. However, the ability to detect changes and generate accurate descriptions is strongly constrained by the generative capacity of models and the quality of datasets. To address this, we propose a diffusion-based framework for RSICC, leveraging the generative power of diffusion models (DMs). Furthermore, in RSICC tasks, the most commonly used dataset LEVIR-CC has significant issues related to sample imbalance. Therefore, we devise a novel data augmentation strategy to supplement the LEVIR-CC dataset by swapping the temporal order of change image pairs. And we utilize a large language model (GPT-4) to generate antonymous captions for the new image pairs. On the augmented LEVIR-CC dataset, our diffusion-based framework demonstrates superior performance across various metrics, outperforming existing methods and showcasing the robustness of our approach. Dataset and relevant materials are available at https://github.com/Fay-Y/The-augmented-LEVIR-CC.

title: ESAD-GPT: Earth’s Surface Anomaly Detection Using Large Vision-language Models
authors: Xing-Ao Wang, Zhi Gao, Zhaohong Liao, Shuying Xia, Min Cao, Qiao Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Earth’s surface anomaly detection (ESAD) plays a pivotal role in disaster monitoring, emergency response, and rescue operations. Existing ESAD methods are typically trained on datasets containing specific types of anomalies, achieving satisfactory performance on these known categories but exhibiting limitations when addressing unknown or unexpected anomaly types. We propose ESAD-GPT, a novel vision-language model (VLM) tailored for ESAD task, exploring the utilization of VLM to tackle these challenges. Specifically, we introduce an automated pipeline for generating image caption by utilizing the Google’s Gemini model with tailored prompts designed for various image types, ultimately creating a comprehensive multi-modal ESAD (MM-ESAD) dataset. Subsequently, we fine-tune the model using the LoRA technique, integrating carefully crafted user instructions to prompt the model towards learning generalized anomaly concepts rather than specific category information. This approach improves the model’s generalization capabilities and its adaptability to novel anomaly categories. Experimental results on the MM-ESAD dataset demonstrate that our ESAD-GPT improves accuracy by 5.33% compared to existing SOTA models, exhibiting superior zero-shot performance, and highlighting its potential for broader applications.

title: Using Social Media During an Earthquake: The Case of Ahbap
authors: Deniz Tuncalp, Dilek Cetindamar Kozanoglu
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society Conference - Global (TEMSCON Global)
abstract: The study explores how humanitarian organizations use social media in disaster response. Drawing on a case study approach, this work analyzes 1577 X messages (formerly Twitter) of Ahbap, a prominent grassroots organization in Türkiye, during and after the Türkiye earthquake on February 6, 2023. The thematic analysis contributes to disaster management literature by documenting how social media shaped a humanitarian organization's communication activities around disaster recovery. Results indicate that X messages fall into one of the nine distinct categories: Coordination and Updates, Gratitude and Recognition, Problem-Solving and Initiatives, Calls to Action, Emotional Appeals, Transparency and Accountability, Community Engagement and Support, International Collaboration, and Future Plans and Ongoing Projects. The findings further offer actionable insights for managers of humanitarian organizations regarding using social media in disaster response.

title: Integrated Approach for Scalable Cross-Pollination Risk Assessment in Hybrid Rice Seed Plots Using Satellite and Weather Data
authors: Jayantrao Mohite, Sagar Tarsariya, Suryakant Sawant, Ankur Pandit, Srinivasu Pappula
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This study presents a remote sensing-based approach to assess cross-pollination risk in hybrid rice seed plots using Sentinel-1 and Sentinel-2 satellite data combined with meteorological data. Rice area mapping was done through k-means clustering of Vertical Horizontal (VH) backscatter and Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) data. The method was validated using 109 known rice plots, achieving an accuracy of 85.08% across the study area. Transplanting dates were estimated based on minimum VH backscatter values, with an average estimation error of 4.39 days and a median error of 4 days. The phenological stages derived from this analysis were critical for assessing temporal isolation. An integrated cross-pollination risk assessment was conducted by incorporating spatial buffers, temporal isolation checks, and wind speed adjustments. The results showed that 71% of plots were classified as low risk, 19% as medium risk, and 10% as high risk. The proposed approach effectively combines spatial, temporal, and environmental factors to evaluate cross-pollination risks. It provides an efficient and scalable tool for initial cross-pollination risk assessment. This approach leverages freely available satellite data, making it a cost-effective and practical solution for hybrid seed producers seeking to optimize genetic purity and production efficiency.

title: A Study of the Relationship Between Severe Convective Clouds and Severe Convective Weather Using Himwarik8/9 Geostationary Satellite
authors: Yi Xu, Kaimin Sun, Fangyi Lv, Shunxia Miao
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This paper investigates the relationship between severe convective clouds and severe convective weather. Using geostationary satellite imagery combined with an adaptive threshold algorithm, we extracted severe convective clouds, and leveraged GPM precipitation data and ERA5-Land reanalysis data to obtain severe convective weather information. The spatial relationship between convective points and clouds was then examined using buffer and overlay analysis, and the internal convective weather regions within clouds were segmented using the Deeplab V3 model. Results show that: (1) identified cloud regions are consistent with high reflectivity areas in radar images; (2) 90% of severe convective weather events occur within the cloud interior or within a 40km buffer from the cloud boundary; (3) the Deeplab V3 model achieved a segmentation mIoU(mean Intersection over Union) of 78% and an accuracy of 85% for severe convection within the clouds. This paper combines statistical, spatial analysis, and deep learning to reveal the close spatial correlation between severe convective weather and severe convective clouds, confirming that severe convection weather is prevalent within cloud interiors and at their boundaries. This study holds significant implications for understanding the mechanisms of severe convective weather and improving forecasting accuracy.

title: Novel Approach for Asymmetrical Operation of Transmission Lines Using Enhanced Line Model
authors: Ansar Berdygozhin, Dauren Akhmetbayev, Gulbakyt Ansabekova, David Campos-Gaona
publish: 2025 10th IEEE Workshop on the Electronic Grid (eGRID)
abstract: This paper presents the development of a complete solution to enable transmission lines to operate asymmetrically (i.e. operation with disconnected phase) with and without pre-fault power restoration. First, a power line model for the analysis and control of current flow during asymmetric operation of transmission lines is developed. This model includes ground wires, which are used to facilitate zero-sequence current flow. For high fidelity modelling, each span of the transmission line is represented. A 200km, 500kV line is used as case study. Second, a phase-to-ground fault is then introduced at the midpoint of the line, after which the faulted phase is disconnected, and asymmetric operation is achieved using E-STATCOMs (located at the line extremities) equipped with advanced control methodologies that compensate the circulation of negative and zero sequence currents. The proposed solution is validated through simulation.

title: Estimating CO2 Emissions from Wildfire-Induced Biomass Loss using Satellite Remote Sensing
authors: Elizabeth Menezes, Hong Xu, Shengan Zhan
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The data fusion of multiple satellite remote sensing imagery has revolutionized the mapping of land cover and forest locations. We describe a comprehensive analysis of the aboveground biomass lost due to the devastating wildfire that occurred on July 10, 2023, in Quebec to estimate CO2 emissions. By leveraging a diverse array of remote sensing datasets from multiple satellite sensors, our study illustrates the power of collaborative data integration in environmental monitoring. Our methodology employs machine learning tools within ArcGIS Pro, through integrating LiDAR point data from the NASA GEDI mission, surface reflectance bands from the USGS Landsat Collection 2 archive, backscatter polarization bands from the ESA Sentinel-1 Level-1 products, and a 30-meter Copernicus DEM. The assessment of lost biomass not only highlights the immediate impacts of the wildfire but also facilitates the estimation of over 715,000 tonnes of CO2 emissions released from this natural disaster.

title: Amplitude-Varying High-Frequency Voltage Injection Method for Reducing the Number of Submodules in DR-MMC-Based Hybrid Converters in Offshore Wind Farms
authors: Haiyu Chen, Jinjun Liu, Sixing Du
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: The hybrid topology with a modular multilevel converter-based (MMC-based) auxiliary converter and diode rectifiers connected in paralleled (DR-MMC) has emerged as a promising solution for offshore wind power transmission. To reduce the submodule (SM) number of this hybrid topology, an amplitude-varying high-frequency voltage injection method is proposed in this paper. The amplitude of the injected highfrequency voltage is changing with the instantaneous value of the fundamental output voltage. Thus, the high-frequency voltage can be injected without increasing the SM number of arms. By replacing the MMC with a three-phase seriesconnected MMC (SC-MMC), the AC side voltage is unaffected by injection. Meanwhile, the amplitude fluctuations of injected high-frequency voltage can be canceled out on the DC side. As a result, the high-frequency voltage with constant amplitude can be injected in the DC side of SC-MMC without increasing the SM number. Therefore, the SM number of the converter can be further reduced. The equation of injected high-frequency voltage is derived, and the SM number of the proposed and existing methods are compared. The feasibility of the proposed method is verified via 800-kV 110-MW/330-Mvar simulation.

title: Special Session: Effective Design, Modeling and Testing Techniques for Digital Computing-in Memories with MAC Function
authors: Jin-Fu Li, Chun-Lung Hsu, Yu-Guang Chen, Ting-Yi Wu, Wei-Hung Lin, Shih-Hsu Huang, Yung-Chi Chia, Yu-Chieh Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Defect and Fault Tolerance in VLSI and Nanotechnology Systems (DFT)
abstract: Digital computing-in-memory (DCIM) with multiply and accumulate (MAC) function has been considered as an acceleration engine of deep neural networks (DNNs). A basic DCIM unit with MAC function consists of a bit-multiplication memory (BMM) and an adder tree. A DCIM typically consists of a huge amount of DCIM units for massive parallel computing. Effective modeling and design techniques are needed for designing energy-efficient DCIMs. Also, effective testing techniques are very important for ensuring the quality of DCIM chips. In this paper, design, modeling, and testing techniques for DCIMs with MAC function will be introduced. Firstly, a precision-aware tolerance technique for adder tree circuits is presented, aiming to reduce dynamic power consumption in DCIMs across various DNN applications. Secondly, a scalable and accurate delay modeling framework that accelerates architecture-level optimization for systems integrating DCIM circuits is introduced. Thirdly, a DCIM-FaultSim, the first efficient fault simulator specifically designed for DCIMs is introduced. The DCIM-FaultSim supports a wide range of fault models, covering both conventional memory faults and compute-related faults induced by in-memory bit-level operations. Finally, a novel transparent test scheme for DCIMs is introduced.

title: Modeling Vegetation Scattering Over Topographical Surfaces for GNSS-R DDMS
authors: Amer Melebari, Mahta Moghaddam
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Modeling the effect of vegetation attenuation and volume scattering for global navigation satellite system (GNSS)-reflectometry (GNSS-R) delay-Doppler maps (DDMs) aids in understanding the effects of vegetation on DDMs and, consequently, their impact on the estimation of various geophysical parameters from DDMs, such as soil moisture. This work focuses on extending the improved geometric optics with topography (IGOT) GNSS-R DDM model to account for the vegetation attenuation effect in the scattered signal from the ground surface and the vegetation direct scattering. The IGOT model estimates DDMs over topographical surfaces and has been validated against Cyclone GNSS (CYGNSS) mission observations. The developed vegetation scattering model is based on the distorted Born approximation (DBA) and represents tree components as finite canonical shapes. The normalized bistatic radar cross section (BRCS) (NBRCS) values of vegetation scattering for various forest types are presented. Additionally, using parameters from CYGNSS, simulated DDMs are studied. The results showed that the vegetation volume scattering contribution is negligible compared to surface scattering. Additionally, the vegetation has an attenuation effect on the surface scattering component.

title: Ageing Determination of SiC Power Modules by Piezoelectric Effect and Acoustic Emissions
authors: Philipp Bickel, Marco Jung, Albrecht Donat, Kai Kriegel, Gerhard Mitic, Sherif Madkour, Christian Walbrecker-Baar
publish: 2025 Energy Conversion Congress &amp; Expo Europe (ECCE Europe)
abstract: Ageing in power modules, often due to chip solder degradation, limits system reliability and lifespan. Traditional assessments use power and temperature cycling with statistical models, while this work introduces a novel method leveraging the inverse piezoelectric effect in wide bandgap semiconductors. Under voltage, materials like SiC generate small mechanical oscillations, allowing real-time monitoring of the chip's eigenfrequency as a natural indicator of solder health. Shifts in eigenfrequency can reveal solder degradation early, supporting predictive maintenance. This method, compared with conventional techniques, aims to extend condition monitoring and system durability in power electronics applications.

title: Satellite Sensing Into Agricultural Practices: Cal/Val Campaign of Satellite, Airborne and Ground GNSS-Reflectometry of Soil Moisture
authors: Matthew Wilson, Shin-Chan Han, Mehdi Khaki, In-Young Yeo, George Townsend, Fang Yuan, Martin Nguyen, Xaiodong Cai, Clevon Ash, Delwyn Moller
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Irrigation exploits most of agricultural use of water, consuming more than half of the total water in Australia and New Zealand. Given the size of water use in irrigation, using more efficient water management will lead to a great impact on freshwater resources. Soil moisture probes are widely used in irrigation, but sampling is only available "point-wise", not necessarily representing the overall water need over fields. To measure soil moisture comprehensively, our joint research exploits the L-band microwaves reflected off land surface and ubiquitously available from the GNSS constellation. The GNSS signal’s reflectance changes with soil moisture content and is sensitive to wider areas in contrast to point-wise ground probes. Here, we present early results from cross-validation of three GNSS remote sensing systems from satellite (CYGNSS), airborne (Rongowai), and ground-borne sensors, which work in the identical principle but at different resolutions and coverages. In this research, we are conducting field campaigns of co-located experiments and extensive calibration and validation of three different types of GNSS-based soil moisture data. Ultimately, we will develop a soil moisture data assimilation system to put all together with land surface models for practical applications in agricultural and farming practice.
